Description: International students must be in Australia and able to attend campus to commence this program. Griffith's Bachelor of Acting is a highly practical and skill intensive program that will prepare you to forge a life-long career across stage and screen. The program focuses on developing both the individual and the actor through ensemble building, collaborative laboratories, industry-led workshops and public performances. This boutique program is offered to a small number of high quality performers and is designed around four key pillars: core craft; context; repertoire; and industry engagement. Under the direction of renowned teachers and performers, you will undertake intensive training in acting, voice and speech, singing, movement and dance. The Bachelor of Acting will unlock your imagination, encourage curiosity and build resilience.
Career_Outcomes: It is expected that this program will interface with Griffith Film School, Queensland Theatre Company, Brisbane Powerhouse and other local and national performing arts companies. Discussions are also underway with interstate and overseas academies and international providers. As such, many opportunities will be presented to graduates from the Bachelor of Acting. You will emerge skilled in highly skilled in acting and performance and ready for a career on stage or on screen, including (but not limited to) theatre, television and film.
Subject_Description_1: This course continues the work begun in Acting I, II, III and IV. The acquisition and development of Acting, Voice and Speech, Movement and Dance techniques. Students are introduced to the audition platform. This course connects with Performance Project IV. This course continues the development of the student's potential as a performer as fully as possible, through class tuition in Acting, Voice and Speech, Movement and Dance and through master classes, workshops, seminars and public performances. PRE-REQUISITE: 2072QCM Acting IV
Subject_Description_2: The program culminates in a public/industry showcase of works where students use the skills and knowledge they have accumulated through and across the program's courses. PRE-REQUISITE: 3073QCM Performance and Engagement 1
Subject_Description_3: This course continues the work begun in Acting I, II, III, IV and V. The acquisition and development of Acting, Voice and Speech, Movement and Dance. Students will deepen and broaden their audition practice and portfolio. This course continues the development of the student's potential as a performer as fully as possible, through class tuition in Acting, Voice and Speech, Movement and Dance through master classes, workshops, seminars and public performances. PRE-REQUISITE: 3071QCM Acting V
Subject_Description_4: This course continues to build and develop students' performance capacity through ensemble-focussed workshops. Through the study of a published Shakespeare text, students rehearse towards performance. PRE-REQUISITE: 1074QCM Performance Project II
Subject_Description_5: This course continues to build and develop students' performance capacity through ensemble-focussed workshops. Drawing on a published Chekhov text, students will rehearse towards performance. PRE-REQUISITE: 1073QCM Performance Project I
Subject_Description_6: This course is designed to provide an overview of musical theatre styles and practices from the early 20th century to the present day. The course discusses compositional features, structures and dramatic conventions to allow students to identify and evaluate functions of musical theatre. There are no pre-requisites for this course. Students from backgrounds other than music are welcome to undertake the course.
Subject_Description_7: This course continues the work begun in Acting I and II. The acquisition and development of Acting, Voice and Speech, Singing, Movement and Dance techniques are interdependent elements in a process that connects with Performance Project III. This course continues the development of the student's potential as a performer as fully as possible, through class tuition in Acting, Voice and Speech, Singing, Movement and Dance and through master classes, workshops, seminars and public performances. PRE-REQUISITE: 1072QCM Acting II
Subject_Description_8: The history of theatre is primarily concerned with its origins, influences and subsequent development as dramatic stories, theatricality and performance reflecting the broader culture in a society.
Subject_Description_9: Most actors begin their careers focusing their attention intensely on the development of their core craft capabilities. While this is necessary and encouraged, it is not the sole contributing success factor of developing your life as a performer. There are other aptitudes and capabilities required for any performer to confidently achieve their ambitions: whether you define success as the ability to sustain your passion for acting, to be financially remunerated for your artistic efforts and/or make a difference in the world with your performance. Overall, this can be summarised as the ability to create an independent sustainable artistic enterprise from your acting skill within the competitive industry environment.
Subject_Description_10: Through the study of a published modern text, students rehearse towards performance. PRE-REQUISITE: 2073QCM Performance Project III
Subject_Description_11: This course is designed to cover historical, analytical and contextual aspects of musical theatre and film. There are no prerequisites, co-requisite and prior-assumed courses. By investigating the music used in musicals and in film, students should be able to identify and evaluate the functions of a musical score in depicting the time and place of a setting, conveying character or ideas, highlighting mood or atmosphere, or communicating the thoughts and emotions of characters.
Subject_Description_12: The acquisition and development of Acting, Voice and Speech, Singing, Movement and Dance techniques are interdependent elements in a process that connects with Performance Project I, a learning opportunity consisting of short performance works presented simply, to an audience. This course aims to develop the student's potential as a performer as fully as possible, through group tuition in Acting, Voice and Speech, Singing, Movement and Dance. Master classes, workshops, seminars and public performances are also utilised from time to time.
Subject_Description_13: This course continues the work begun in Acting I, II and III. The acquisition and development of Acting, Voice and Speech, Singing, Movement and Dance techniques are interdependent elements in a process that connects with Performance Project IV, and performing to an audience. This course continues the development of the student's potential as a performer as fully as possible, through class tuition in Acting, Voice and Speech, Singing, Movement and Dance and through master classes, workshops, seminars and public performances. PRE-REQUISITE: 2071QCM Acting III
Subject_Description_14: This course is designed to provoke interest in, and understanding of Australian Theatre. Students will explore three key Australian plays written between 1950 and the present day. They will develop knowledge about the plays selected for study as well as the necessary skills to interpret and present excerpts of script in ensemble performance.
Subject_Description_15: This course continues the work begun in Acting I. The acquisition and development of Acting, Voice and Speech, Singing, Movement and Dance techniques are interdependent elements in a process that connects with Performance Project II. This course continues the development of the student's potential as a performer as fully as possible, through class tuition in Acting, Voice and Speech, Singing, Movement and Dance and through master classes, workshops, seminars and public performances. PRE-REQUISITE: 1071QCM Acting I
Subject_Description_16: This course introduces students to the foundations of drama through practical exploration of a genre. Students engage in ensemble-focussed workshops. Through the study of a published modern Australian text, students rehearse towards performance.
Subject_Description_17: This course continues the work begun in Performance Project 1, 2, 3 and 4 and the Acting courses. The acquisition and development of Acting, Voice and Speech, Singing, Movement and Dance techniques are interdependent elements in a process that culminates in a Performance Project, a learning opportunity consisting of a series of fully produced existing works presented to an audience of tutors, fellow-students and paying public or on screen. This course develops the student's potential as performer as fully as possible, through rehearsal, research and public performances. There is potential for a student to take up a professional work integrated learning internship in place of one of the performance projects. PRE-REQUISITE: 2074QCM Performance Project IV

Description:
This degree program will be offered from 2021. The  Bachelor of Advanced Business (Honours) is designed to deliver a thorough  understanding of the complex concepts facing organisations today whilst  allowing customisation toward the business skill of your choice. This new degree takes you  through a unique skill set that will give you a competitive edge in the  employment market. You'll be equipped with the skills necessary to plan and  conduct research in business and government, and will be well-placed for  positions in the private, not-for-profit, and public sectors.  Delivered using the latest innovations in  learning, your courses/subjects will be integrated with first-hand work  experiences and organisational simulations, so you’ll apply the latest academic  learning in workplace environments. This  degree is designed to allow students from all business disciplines to commence  in the same foundation year and then specialise in the business application of  your choice. So, whether you want to be an accountant, an advertising  executive, an international business consultant or an entrepreneur; all you  need to do is enrol and customise as you go.   In your third and fourth year, you will choose  a thesis which will further develop and demonstrate your proficiency and  application in your chosen area. You can also apply to take an internship or  study overseas as part of your thesis, helping you graduate with  advanced skills that will ensure you stand out in the employment market. Offered  through the Griffith Business School which is ranked in the top 200 worldwide  by the prestigious Academic Rankings of World Universities, this degree can  also provide a pathway to a Higher Degree Research (for example, PhD) and a  career in academia. Discover your passion
  You’ll  complete six discovery courses/subjects that are based in the core skills critical to  successful business operations (including analysis, accounting, economics,  management, organisational psychology, marketing, international business) and  apply them across a range of interdisciplinary and authentic activities. The  discovery year is designed to simulate practical environments across a variety  of commercial applications so that you learn to apply theory in practice to the  trends and challenges of today’s environment. They will help you discover your  strengths, choose your majors and hone your skills in your discipline of  choice. More importantly, you will start to investigate the purpose that drives  you and brings meaning and motivation to drive your career. Plus, when you  graduate, you’ll stand out in the job market because you’ll be able to apply  the skills gained in your major across a wide range of business simulations.  You’ll also add two courses/subjects from  another area of study like science or the arts. This is your opportunity to  embrace your passion or discover a new one. You’ll graduate with extra skills  which set you apart in the work place; and a thorough understanding of the  links that business draws between all industries. Customisation and professional outcomes
  In your  second year, you can choose from 20 Business majors, and from 4 Language  majors. After you have completed your first year, you can move seamlessly into  and between majors and languages. Alternatively, you can choose not to major and  select from an extensive list of business and interdisciplinary electives. You  don’t need to select your major until your second year of study. Transformational international  opportunities, with hands-on learning
  You  will have the opportunity to choose local or overseas study, competitions and  internships as part of your degree. You can apply with one of our partners or  receive support to find your own. Griffith Business School supports all  students with the opportunity for experiences that transform the way you think and help uncover the passion which drives your work. You can apply for both  academic credit toward your degree and for financial assistance with academic  support just a call or email away. This  degree culminates in an integrative learning experience where you will use the  knowledge accumulated through your studies to address an authentic business  problem. Explore all majors here. Flexible, fast-track or online degree
  At  Griffith, you can build your business studies around the lifestyle that suits  you. Choose to study part-time or full-time, on campus or online, and take  advantage of our advanced online learning system providing you with the  flexibility and support to study anytime, anywhere. Fast-track degree
  You  can fast-track your business degree and be ready for the job market sooner. You  can complete this degree in two years studying on a three-trimester per year  basis (four courses/subjects per trimester).   Business majors that are available in fast-track mode include Innovation  and Entrepreneurship, Human Resource Management, Management and Marketing. Online degree
  This  degree can be completed online. Not all  majors are available if you wish to study wholly online. Please refer to the  list of majors above to identify which majors are available online. You can  also mix your studies by selecting to study some trimesters online with others  on campus. Graduate with a head start in the job market
When  you study Business at Griffith you get more than just a high-quality degree.  BusinessPLUS is a program designed to give Griffith Business School students  the skills and networks you need for a headstart in the workplace. You’ll  participate in skills-based, career management training with opportunities for  internships, our mentoring program and industry engagement projects that  introduce you to the business networks of your chosen profession. The program  can be personalised for beginners as well as those who have more advanced  skills.
Career_Outcomes:
As an Honours graduate, you will be able to plan and conduct research in business and commerce and will be well-placed for positions in the private, not-for-profit and public sectors. You'll graduate with strong business networks and the authentic business knowledge to apply problem solving skills to a broad range of business environments from planning and strategy to management and specific skills like advertising, economics and accounting, depending on your customised degree. No major option
  A business degree gives you the foundation to take your career just about  anywhere. You will be prepared to use your extensive business skills in a range  of increasingly diverse settings including not-for-profit, government and  corporate organisations. Accounting
  You will be equipped for a career in a range of private, public sector or  not-for-profit organisations where you could work in areas such as accounting,  administration, auditing, business management, commercial and taxation law,  managerial accounting, and taxation. Opportunities exist for exciting and  challenging careers locally, nationally and internationally, and aren't limited  to accounting firms. Asian Business
  You will find career opportunities in government, businesses with overseas  profiles, international aid and other non-governmental organisations, news and  media organisations, and the education industry in Asia. Asian Studies
  You  will be prepared for work in government, business, travel and tourism,  education, international agencies, training, and export consultancy, in  Australia and overseas. You will find opportunities in foreign affairs, foreign  trade, business consultancy, defence, security agencies, and media. Behavioural Science
  You will find career opportunities in government, private enterprise and  not-for-profit organisations across various disciplines including marking and  advertising, human services, healthcare, economics, policy development,  research and evaluation of programs and services. Economics
  You will be prepared for work in the banking and finance industry as an analyst  or advisor, in property development or real estate; in government policy in  fields such as the environment, health, education and transport; or in large  mining companies analysing markets and investment opportunities. You may also  find career opportunities in major international organisations such as the  World Bank, the United Nations, the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and  Development (OECD) and the Asian Development Bank. Employment Relations
  You will be able to work as an employment relations manager or consultant, or  in roles dealing with workplace planning and policy, managerial strategy,  industrial advocacy, occupational health and safety, and workplace negotiation. Event Management
  You will be well prepared for an exciting career working for event and  conference organisers in the sport, tourism, marketing, media and cultural  sectors as well as coordinating and managing government event portfolios. Finance 
  You will be prepared for work as a financial advisor or controller, financial  planner, or stockbroker. You may also find opportunities in insurance and  superannuation, futures, options and foreign exchange trading. Financial Planning
  You will be equipped for a career as a financial planner, financial advisor or  controller, or stockbroker. You will also find opportunities in insurance and  superannuation, futures, options and foreign exchange trading. Government and International Relations
  You  will find opportunities providing advice to government and business leaders,  developing policy and managing programs with domestic and international  organisations in areas such as economic, environmental and social policy,  diplomacy, and trade relations. Human Resource Management
  You will graduate with a degree recognised by the Australian Human Resources  Institute and be ready for a career as a human resource manager or consultant.  Human resource professionals work in many sectors including business  management, counselling, workforce planning and policy, and recruiting and  training staff for the public and private sectors and non-government  organisations. Innovation and Entrepreneurship  
  As a graduate of the  Innovation and Entrepreneurship major, our courses highlight the ways you can  create and develop innovative ideas that enable scale and societal impact.  You will have an understanding of the entrepreneurial mindset, ways  to identify or create opportunities and the strategic and operational issues in firm creation. Create your own career by starting your own  lifestyle or high-potential startup, be entrepreneurial while working in a  family business or being an intrapreneur within someone’s business. International Business
  You will be prepared to work with international trade and investment  organisations or in the public and private sectors in management, strategic  planning, research, corporate government relations, global operations and  public relations. Logistics and Supply Chain Management
  You will be able to work as a logistics and supply chain manager, purchasing  manager, business or strategy manager, or export and import operations manager.  Career opportunities exist in the public, private and not-for-profit sectors. Management
  Good managers are needed across all sectors and in businesses of all sizes.  With this qualification, you can apply your business management knowledge to an  area of personal interest and find work in roles as a business manager in human  resources, strategy, planning and policy, and training and development. Marketing
  You will be able to work in any industry or organisation that needs to promote  its products or services, including entertainment and fashion, tourism,  advertising, public relations, and business consulting. You might work as a  brand manager, marketing manager, advertising account manager, market research  analyst, public relations manager, or sales manager. Real Estate and Property Development
  The property sector is expanding in Australia and around the world, creating a  wide range of employment opportunities in the commercial, residential and  tourism sectors of the real estate and property management industries. You will  be prepared for a career in property finance, development and investment, real  estate agency management, project management, and marketing and promoting real  estate. Sport Management
  Sport is big business. You will find opportunities in government departments,  local, national and international sporting clubs and event management  organisations. There are also positions in sport tourism, marketing, media and  athlete representation. Sustainable Business
  Increasingly,  public and private sector organisations are hiring sustainability and corporate  social responsibility specialists. The growing trend in consumers demanding  sustainable, ethical products and services has seen businesses place  sustainability and social benefits within their core values. These new business  models means that leaders and managers need to know how the financial bottom  line relates to other important elements of business; and how to transform  traditional models to capitalise in the current environment. As this field  continues to grow, you will find more and more career opportunities in a wide  variety of organisations in the public and private sectors and with  non-government organisations. Tourism Management
  With this qualification, you could travel the world. Tourism managers are  employed by destination marketing organisations and all levels of government  throughout Australia and internationally. You will be able to work on major  tourism infrastructure and planning projects, shaping the visitor experience in  tourism destinations.

Description:
This degree will prepare you for a career in the animation and visual effects
industries. The theoretical and practical skills that are essential to these
career paths are comprehensively covered through majors in Character
Animating, Art Direction and Technical Direction. Using top of the line
hardware and premium, industry-recognised software, you will produce
original animated films from script to screen. In doing so, you will learn skills
in concept development, storyboarding, 2D and 3D character animation,
editing, sound recording, visual effects and post-production. You will also develop the ability to work out the most appropriate animation
format for specific projects - traditional drawn animation, 2D, 3D and
motion-captured digital animation, 3D puppet or clay animation and other
experimental media. Your academic studies will be extended by studio
courses and engagement with industry production, which will enable you
to gain first-hand experience. You will work alongside film and screen media production and games design
students to complete community projects and have opportunities to
collaborate with students from the Queensland Conservatorium.
Career_Outcomes:
You will be able to work in 2D and 3D character animation and visual effects
for film, television, computer games and interactive media companies. You will be prepared for a career that includes many exciting and
creative pathways, such as designing characters and environments
for 2D and CGI/3D-animated projects, scriptwriting, storyboarding
and previsualisation, animation in 2D and 3D, illustration, graphic art,
compositing, matte painting, and visual effects.
Subject_Description_1: In tandem with the capstone 3126GFS Animation Portfolio, this course prepares students for entry into the professional arena of their chosen career paths. Preparation is via the development of career plans, of website folios and reels, and of professional skills such as resumes, personal presentation and grant writing. Representatives from local studios guest lecture into the course, providing insight into career options and studio roles and procedures. Pre-Req: 3101GFS Intro to Professional Practice AND all 1st & 2nd year core courses.
Subject_Description_2: An introductory course where students will develop an understanding of the concepts of movement and timing whilst learning fundamentals of character animation within a digital context.
Subject_Description_3: This subject provides a collaborative space where students from animation, games and film work together to devise, plan and create documentation to EPOC (electronic proof of concept) stage for an interactive project. The subject focuses on the idea of interactivity in either the physical or digital realm, or a combination of the two. The creation of cogent storyworlds and engaging interactivity will be the hallmarks of successful assessment items in this course.
Subject_Description_4: The tools and techniques required to animate a character in a 3D animation software program are presented in this course. It includes a strong focus on demonstrating strategies for the application of traditional animation skills in the 3D environment.
Subject_Description_5: Advancing the concepts developed during the first semester's Drawing for Moving Image, Digital Storytelling and Principles of Animation courses, students will investigate time based mechanics and motion using 2D based software whilst researching and developing an understanding of character animation principles. Pre-Req: 1108GFS Principles of Animation.
Subject_Description_6: This course introduces students to the fundamental elements and techniques of narrative scriptwriting for short film in both theoretical and practical terms. Applying a sound understanding of narrative form, structure,scriptwriting techniques and strategies. Students will be required to produce a screen play in professional format of an appropriate length depending on the actual medium.
Subject_Description_7: Through screenings, lectures, analytical discussion and critical exercises, students will develop their appreciative systems for evaluating all aspects of animation genres, forms and histories. They will develop recognition for movements and theories and begin to structure their knowledge of relevant animated precedents.
Subject_Description_8: This course develops students' critical faculty to analyse and deconstruct an external 'client' brief and think critically about feasibility, 'produceability', functionality and usability. Students are introduced to workflows, project management and professional protocols across freelance and studio animation practice.
Subject_Description_9: This course encourages students to express their own identity and history in space and time, with a focus on tools that allow multi layered and composited work and the creation of three dimensional objects. It explores electronic forms of both still and moving imagery and audio within networked on-line environments and provides practical competencies in these media areas. NB: The 'Off Campus' offering is ONLY available to Sheldon College students for enrolment.
Subject_Description_10: Foundation principles of observation and synthesis for drawing techniques and processes used in screen media productions, using a variety of analogue and digital tools. Particular emphasis is placed on life drawing, perspective, and structures as preparation for subsequent study in moving image related fields.
Subject_Description_11: This course is an introduction to reading the moving image and academic research more generally. It includes an introduction to semiotics, scene composition, narrative structure, sound/image relations, colour theory and viewer psychology. Examples and teachings are drawn from animation and games, as well as cinema and television, so that it becomes apparent how forms and terms developed for one screen medium might apply to another. Screenings as well as readings are integral to the study undertaken. This course provides a grounding in media analysis skills and their practical application to conceptual productions in this course and for students to build on over the course of their degree.
Subject_Description_12: This course introduces students to the fundamentals of character development, location, set and layout design, colour theory, screen composition and screen production planning for screen media, animation and games environments. Pre-Req: 1104GFS Drawing for Moving Image.

Description: The Bachelor of Animation (Honours) provides a fourth year of study for students who have completed a Bachelor of Animation or an equivalent program. It is a full-time or part-time program that comprises a significant independent studio research project to be completed under formal supervision. This project is driven by methodological and theoretical inquiry and complemented with an appropriate elective course to be chosen with the supervisor's approval. As well as the opportunity for career and skill advancement, this Honours program creates a pathway for Animation students to move into research and higher degree studies - Master of Visual Arts (5052), Doctor of Visual Arts (6009) or Doctor of Philosophy (6001).

International students must be in Australia and able to attend campus to commence this program. Architecture at Griffith has been ranked in the world's Top 100 in the prestigious QS World University Rankings. We are ranked in the top four architecture programs in Australia for teaching quality. As a Griffith student, you will have access to our wide research portfolio in environmental planning, arts and design, engineering, climate adaptation and science. This will give you the opportunity to expand your knowledge and skills. Our program provides graduates with knowledge and skills for the real world; practice ready, focusing on digital and green technologies, and engaged with the Asia-Pacific region. Bachelor of Architectural Design will set you on the path to a career as an architect, as it provides a stepping stone to Griffiths Master of Architecture degree. Our architecture degrees are distinctive in their emphasis on environmental sustainability and urban design. You will combine classroom studies, studio work, fieldwork and practical experience to learn about urban systems, public places, designing buildings and all aspects of the built environment. You will develop your design and creative problem-solving skills, and learn how to develop designs that meet aesthetic, functional and user needs now and in the future. In your third year, you will get hands-on experience when you complete a supervised industry-based design project. Griffith University's International students receive dedicated support from their arrival in Australia through to their departure after graduation. You will be introduced to Griffith through an orientation program, and receive ongoing social, personal and academic support throughout your degree.
Career_Outcomes: Griffith's Bachelor of Architectural Design will set you on the path to a career as an architect. Graduates will be eligible to apply for admission to the Master of Architecture, which provides the academic qualifications needed for accreditation as an architect. As a graduate, you will be in high demand in Australia and overseas. With your design, technical knowledge and creative visual thinking skills, you will be qualified to assist architects and other built environment professionals in the design, documentation and procurement of buildings. You will find employment in a broad spectrum of creative roles in government agencies, statutory bodies, design practices and studios (urban design, architecture, interior design, virtual environments, graphic design and the film and games industries), commercial development companies, building product manufacturing and distribution companies and research organisations.
Subject_Description_1: Sixth of six courses in the design stream, this studio-based course will build on the studio practices, knowledge and activities introduced in previous Architecture Studio courses. The course is employability and practice focused and develops a single significant capstone project. Prerequisite for this course is 3901ENV. You must be enrolled in program 1492 to enrol in this course.
Subject_Description_2: This course introduces students to the concept of environmental sustainability and its uses in solving real world problems. It explores the relationships between the natural, rural, industrial and urban environments and includes the study of the impact humans have upon nature. The course also considers the way environmental sustainability can be used to address environmental, economic and social issues in an integrated way. Assessment includes on-line tests, a written assignment, workshop exercises and an end of trimester examination. Incompatible: 1301ENV The Global Environment, 1181ENV Sustainable Development, 1161ENV Environmental Economics and Policy.
Subject_Description_3: This course is a Computer Aided Drafting Course, using Autodesk Revit software. Students will be taught fundamental industrial computer generated drawing skills, techniques in conceptualising, 3D modelling, appropriate terminology, construction methods, and presentation layout skills. The Outcomes of this course require students to have a thorough critical understanding of the environmental impact of structural design. Critical analysis will be developed through evaluation of the relationship between architect and designer There will be five in class, assessment exercises and one major assignment that is divided into two parts.
Subject_Description_4: Fifth of six courses in the design stream, this studio-based design-integration course will build on the studio practices, knowledge and activities introduced in previous Architecture courses. The course will be project focused, developing the design process. It will focus on theories and ideas to generate meaningful architecture. The studio courses will integrate knowledge from all other Architecture courses. You must be enrolled in program 1492 to enrol in this course. Prerequisite for this course is 2902ENV.
Subject_Description_5: First of three courses in the history theory stream, this lecture-based course provides a global overview of the history of architecture and landscape architecture from antiquity to the present. Lectures will survey key historical developments in architecture and landscape architecture and the role of architects and patrons therein. Students will learn how to understand and interpret buildings, monuments, urban zones and landscapes. The course will consider architecture and landscape architecture's relationships with culture, society, institutions, economy, knowledge, science and technology, art, design, cities and the environment.
Subject_Description_6: This lecture-based course develops building construction, materials and practices introduced in 2914ENV">2914ENV Construction Materials and Practice, and aspects of sustainable architecture introduced in 2904ENV Principles of Sustainable Design. Lectures will address methods of achieving building environmental conditions and the services systems required. Medium-scale building construction will also be addressed. Knowledge from this course will be integrated into studio course 3902ENV. This course is only open to students enrolled in 1492 and 1598. Prerequisite for this course is 2914ENV">2914ENV.
Subject_Description_7: This course provides an introduction to the fundamental elements and principles of all Art and Design Practices, and cements a platform of visual literacy encompassing perceptual, analytical and expressive skills. The focus of the course is using the two dimensional image as a primary instrument of creative expression, problem solving and communication. This course is a component of the foundation program for the Bachelor of Design and the Bachelor of Architectural Design, and has been designed as a core study to complement activities in both disciplines. This course is incompatible with 1603QCA.
Subject_Description_8: This course gives students a practical and historical understanding of the development, processes and outcomes of innovations in design and in architecture. Students will be exposed to current industry innovations and technology.
Subject_Description_9: Second of six courses in the design stream, this studio-based course will build on the studio practices, knowledge and activities introduced in the first trimester course 1911ENV">1911ENV Introduction to Architecture and Landscape Design. The course will be project focused, allowing students to further develop an understanding of design concepts and processes. Within 1912ENV, students will be encouraged to respond to a range of existing conditions relevant to architectural design, including site, landscape and the urban environment, as well as social and cultural contexts and architectural references. This course is only open to students enrolled in the Bachelor of Architectural Design (Program Code 1492). Prerequisite for this course is 1911ENV">1911ENV Introduction to Architecture and Landscape Design.
Subject_or_Unit_10: URBAN DESIGN HISTORY, THEORY AND METHODS
Subject_Description_10: Second of three courses in the history theory stream, this lecture-based course provides an introduction to the history and theory of urban design and introduces concepts, tools and practices for the analysis, design and implementation of interventions to the built environments of towns and cities. Knowledge from this course will be integrated into the studio course 2901ENV Architecture Studio 2.
Subject_Description_11: Third of three courses in the history theory stream, this lecture and seminar course provides a historical survey of architectural practice in Australia. Lectures will survey key historical developments in Indigenous and colonial architecture and position these within broader geographical, professional and intellectual settings. Students will engage with relevant literature and conduct research on source material in local libraries and archives. Prerequisite: For 1492 B Architectural Design students, 1903ENV">1903ENV Architecture and Landscape Architecture History 1 and 2903ENV Urban Design History, Theory and Methods. For students of other degrees, at least 80CP plus 1903ENV">1903ENV Architectural History 1 or an approved alternate substitute.
Subject_Description_12: The course introduces structural concepts to architect students. The behaviour of structures will be covered to give the future architect an overall understanding of structural engineering. Fundamental structural mechanics concepts and structural design principles will be covered in some detail. Topics taught include equilibrium, internal forces, stress, structural elements and systems, design loads, load transfer, buildings... The course is taught as a series of weekly lectures and tutorials, supported by laboratory experiments.
Subject_Description_13: Fourth of six courses in the design stream, this studio-based course builds on the practices, knowledge and activities which were introduced in the previous architecture courses. This project focused course will creatively explore architectural design methods, to resolve the functional, spatial and construction requirements of a medium-scale building. The studio courses will integrate knowledge from all other Architecture courses. The course is only open to students enrolled in 1492. Prerequisite for this course is 2901ENV.
Subject_Description_14: This lecture-based course provides an overview of the principles relating to sustainable architectural design. Lectures will address material choice, indoor environment quality, passive design strategies, energy and water efficiency, and the relationship between design, people and the environment. Knowledge from this course will be integrated into the studio course 2902ENV Architecture Studio 3.
Subject_Description_15: The course is an introduction to construction materials and techniques and contemporary issues in construction design and detailing. The main aim is to help students understand the importance and fundamentals of key construction materials, their basic properties, characteristics and performance, and how they are combined to create simple buildings
Subject_or_Unit_16: INTRODUCTION TO ARCHITECTURE AND LANDSCAPE DESIGN
Subject_Description_16: First of six courses in the design stream, this studio-based communication and design course introduces students to the Griffith Architecture program, fundamental design concepts and the nature of the profession. It will introduce modes of observation, experimentation and representation as they relate to the architectural design process. The course encourages students to build skills across a range of manual and digital media in order to document observed conditions and design small-scale architectural proposals. The studio courses will integrate knowledge from all other Architecture courses. This course is only available to students enrolled in the Bachelor of Architectural Design (Program Code 1492).
Subject_Description_17: Understanding Australian Cities is an introductory overview of the origin, patterning and functioning of the urban system. The course specifically examines the dynamics of population, infrastructure, governance and culture in Australian cities. These understandings frame examination of the possibilities of planning intervention. This introductory course will allow students to better appreciate the range of planning challenges and the opportunities for further study. This course is delivered via weekly lectures and tutorials and is supplemented with web materials and readings.
Subject_Description_18: Third of six courses in the design stream, this problem based course will build on the studio practices, knowledge and activities embedded in first year courses. The course will be project focussed, developing the design process. The projects will develop the theme of a strong urban and environmental design emphasis, and national and international perspectives. This course is only open to students enrolled in 1492. Prerequisite for this course is 1912ENV.

Description: The Bachelor of Arts (via Open Universities Australia) broadens access to the University and encourages students to undertake study towards a Griffith degree by maximising the advantages of alternative forms of program delivery. The degree produces graduates with a broad background in general studies. The tertiary, higher education and business sectors increasingly need graduates trained in a range of humanities, social sciences and professional courses. The degree addresses this need by providing a structured degree that requires students to undertake a program of study across a broad range of offerings. This degree offers you  the opportunity to specialise in: For further information, please contact either of the following areas: Further information is available by contacting either of the following areas:
Career_Outcomes: This program develops student skills as they progress through each level of the degree. Students will build advanced skills in reading, analysis, interpretation and debate. These skills are essential for careers in the media, education, public administration and business.

Description: This program will be available to commencing students at the Gold Coast and Nathan from 2021. The Bachelor of Arts degree gives you the freedom to choose majors and minors according to your passions and interests. By doing so, you will develop a unique set of interdisciplinary skills that will set you up for a highly adaptable future across a range of industries. You'll become a creative thinker and clear communicator with a high level of cultural awareness, capable of guiding businesses and organisations through the complexities of modern life. Work-integrated learning is hard-wired into this degree and you are encouraged to take advantage of extensive industry-relevant experiences such as internships, study tours and other work-integrated learning opportunities. You'll be prepared for a career across a diverse range of industries, equipped with skills in research, analysis, communication, leadership and critical thinking. You will be a mobile, informed and engaged global citizen, ready to make a difference within any field that you choose. With its emphasis on critical thinking and information literacy, this degree also lays the groundwork for further study in research. *All majors and minors are taught at the Gold Coast and Nathan campuses except where indicated. Majors can be also taken as minors. Take control of your time  - This degree has intakes in Trimester 1, 2 and 3. So, whenever you're ready to study, we're ready to get you started. Depending on your major, you may be able to take up overseas learning opportunities through culturally focused courses such as 3610LHS Muslim World Study Tour.
Career_Outcomes: Graduates of the Bachelor of Arts have flexible and adaptable skills that are valued in the workplace. Your highly developed skills in critical thinking, leadership, problem-solving and information analysis will be well-suited to a range of workplaces. Your choice of major will influence the direction of your career. There are a diverse range of job opportunities across an array for sectors for Bachelor of Arts graduates. *Source: Australian Government Job Outlook.

Description: This program will be available to commencing students at the Gold Coast and Nathan from 2021. Bachelor of Arts graduates can undertake an additional year of study in the Honours program, which gives you the opportunity to build on the skills and knowledge gained in the foundation degree. The Honours degree allows you to put to practical use the knowledge you've gained in the first three years of your degree, and it prepares you for postgraduate study and professional opportunities. An Honours qualification may also help to set you apart from your peers, signalling to employers that you possess the abilities and knowledge they value, including critical thinking, time management and interpersonal engagement. The Bachelor of Arts (Honours) is an excellent entry path towards a PhD, and also signals to employers that you're capable of managing a large independent program under supervision. Internships may be available to students within the Honours program. In this year-long professional and educational experience, you'll do original research, use analytical skills,and work as part of a team environment to take your learning to the next level. As a graduate, you will be ready for highly skilled professional work or may choose to continue your education with a higher degree by research. There are no declared majors in the Honours program. Students will work under an academic supervisor in their chosen discipline or disciplines. Tailor your timetable - Even if you study full-time on-campus, you may still be able to customise your degree to suit your needs. From a range of tutorial times to online access to lectures and other course material, we're here to help you fit study in with your work and life commitments. Students in this degree may be able to participate in an overseas program specifically designed to fit the degree's teaching objectives. Learn more about going global at Griffith.
Career_Outcomes: Honours graduates will be ready for highly skilled professional work or may choose to continue their education with a higher degree by research. *Source: Australian Government Job Outlook.

Description: The Bachelor of Aviation (Standard) program is only available for International students who are in Australia and able to attend campus to commence this program. Griffith University has one of Australia's largest and most highly recognised aviation teaching programs. Over the past 25 years teaching in this field, we have built an international reputation for graduates who are industry ready. Our aviation staff have strong industry ties and some are world leaders in aviation research. The Bachelor of Aviation is a two-year, accelerated degree allowing students to progress more quickly into a flying career. You will be introduced to the sciences underpinning the theory and practice of aviation. You will also study courses in areas such as navigation, safety management systems and the human factors in aviation. Through the Bachelor of Aviation, you will develop the skills needed for lifelong learning in the evolving aviation environment. The Bachelor of Aviation together with self-funded flight training will allow graduates to be ready to work in the aviation industry as a commercial pilot. The Trimester 2 intake is only available to students completing a Professional Entry pathway.
Career_Outcomes: The Bachelor of Aviation will prepare you for employment in the aviation industry and, together with the Graduate Diploma of Flight Management, for work as a commercial pilot. Our graduates have been successful in gaining a range of flying and management positions with organisations such as Cathay Pacific, Emirates, Etihad, Jetstar, Qantas, Regional Express, and Virgin Australia, as well as Airservices Australia and the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA). On completion of both programs (B Aviation and GDip Flight Management), you will also be able to apply the skills acquired in your degree to many areas of the aviation industry such as management, research and human resources. You will find employment opportunities in charter work, regional airlines, flight instruction (theory and practical), aerial services (agricultural spraying, aerial surveying and photography), airline and airport management, research, human resources and in government organisations such as CASA.
Subject_Description_1: Towards the higher speed ranges, the forces acting on the aircraft, its controllability and performance changes significantly. In this course, students study the principles underlying high speed design and corresponding flight characteristics. Prerequisite: 2521NSC Aerodynamics Part I or 2505NSC Aerodynamics.
Subject_Description_2: The Flight Procedures I course introduces students to the basic principles associated with each of the different phases of ab initio flying exercises. The course covers the aerodynamic principles, technical and procedural aspects, and regulatory framework of each aspect delivered in lecture format. The aspect is then practised and fully examined in the flight procedures laboratory utilising flight simulation software at workstations fitted with flight controls.
Subject_Description_3: This is an introductory course to law with respect to the aviation industry in Australia. The course will cover two primary topics: (i) Basic principles of law in relation to the aviation industry. - Contract law - Tort law (Negligence, Trespass and Nuisance) - Administrative law (relating to the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA), and - International law (ii) Introduction to Aviation Regulation, designed to guide students through the extensive regulatory system governing aviation. Incompatible: 2509NSC Aviation Legal Studies; 2509BPS Aviation Legal Studies.
Subject_Description_4: This course builds on the underpinning knowledge of atmospheric Science and applies this knowledge to a practical aviation environment in accordance with the CASA CPL Meteorology syllabus. Prerequisite: 1304NSC/1304BPS/1502BPS/2002AVN Atmospheric Science Incompatible with: 2507BPS/2507NSC All Weather Operations
Subject_Description_5: Aviation Science is an introduction to scientific themes as applied in the world of aviation. The syllabus covers selected concepts from algebra, geometry and calculus, and from physics, with emphasis on forces and movement of bodies. The study is essential to understanding of aerodynamics and a variety of aviation-specific studies at a later stage
Subject_Description_6: The course introduces students to aerodynamics associated with small fixed-wing aircraft in sufficient depth to enable students to demonstrate their knowledge in subsonic aerodynamics. Note: Incompatible with 2505BPS/2505NSC Aerodynamics
Subject_Description_7: It has been identified that exposure to practical aspects of the aviation industry are an essential part of undergraduate courses. Though many students strive for final employment within the airline industry, it is the general aviation industry that will see most students beginning their aviation careers. Research with current/past students, staff and industry identified important skills that in some cases lack with new pilots within the general aviation industry. This course goes part of the way in assisting to develop some of these skills. Incompatible with: 1106AVN Introductory Aviation Studies 1501BPS Introductory Aviation Studies
Subject_Description_8: This course is designed for the purpose of educating first year students in basic meteorology in the Australian region, informing them, as well as providing a sound knowledge base of weather systems, which not only impact on flight planning, but could compromise aviation safety. The online offering of this course is only available to 'professional entry' students. Those students should email the Program Officer, Aviation, at aviation@griffith.edu.au for permission to enrol. Incompatible with 1502BPS Atmospheric Science; 2002AVN Atmospheric Science; 1102AVN Atmospheric Science. There are no prerequisites for this course.
Subject_Description_9: This course introduces students to a variety of Light Aircraft Systems, and builds on their aircraft general knowledge. This course will also assist in the practical aviation environment, by having a thorough and broad knowledge of different Light Aircraft Systems in accordance with the CASA CPL Aeronautical knowledge syllabus. Note: Incompatible with 2503BPS/2503NSC Light Aircraft Systems
Subject_Description_10: In Flight Procedures III students are introduced to the added systems complexity of a multi engine aircraft as well as the fundamental performance aspects relating to normal two engine and abnormal one engine in-operative operations. The twin engine platform is also used to extend their exposure to glass panel technology by introducing the full range of departure, arrival and approach procedures available under the Instrument Flight Rules [IFR]. Prerequisites: 1505NSC Flight Procedures I and 2533NSC Flight Procedures II OR 2531NSC Flight Procedures I/II
Subject_Description_11: This course covers the theory of Navigation under the Visual Flight Rules (VFR) in accordance with the CASA CPL Navigation syllabus. Note: Incompatible with 2508BPS/2508NCS Navigation
Subject_Description_12: This course will introduce students to the history of international aviation, and investigate the formation, structure and roles of the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO), one of the specialised agencies of the United Nations, and its interactions with other international organisations that affect international civil aviation operations. The online offering of this course is only available to 'professional entry' students. Those students should email the Program Officer, Aviation, at aviation@griffith.edu.au for permission to enrol. There are no prerequisites for this course. Incompatible with: 1506BPS International aviation; AVN2004 International Aviation Organisation; AVN7010 and 7010AVN International Aviation; 7506BPS and 7506NSC International Aviation.
Subject_or_Unit_13: AIRCRAFT OPERATIONS, PERFORMANCE AND PLANNING PART II
Subject_Description_13: This course is the second part of 2520NSC (Light Aircraft Operations, Performance and Planning Part I) in accordance with the CASA CPL Operations, Performance and Planning syllabus.
Subject_Description_14: 2515NSC focuses on the human factors issues faced by pilots. It considers the human factors relevant to single-pilot and multi-crew operations. This course examines human performance and limitations, from both a theoretical and practical perspective; with the aim of improving flight safety
Subject_Description_15: This course aims to equip students with a working knowledge of both global and domestic air traffic management environments, as the transition to the new Communications, Navigation and Surveillance/Air Traffic Management systems described in ICAO's Global Air Navigation Plan for CNS/ATM Systems is implemented. The online offering of this course is only available to 'professional entry' students. Those students should email the Program Officer, Aviation, at aviation@griffith.edu.au for permission to enrol. Incompatible with course AVN3004 Airways Operation and Design.
Subject_Description_16: The importance of managing for safety has been re-emphasised in recent years by the ICAO recommendation for aviation operators to implement a Safety Management System (SMS) based on the published ICAO SMS framework. This course will examine the key elements of a safety management system and the associated systems, processes and procedures used in achieving high safety standards in aviation organisations. There will be a strong emphasis on the importance of leadership and sound management principles and their important contribution to achieving high safety standards. Prior Assumed: Nil Incompatible: AVN3005 Flight Safety, 3005AVN Safety Management, 2511BPS Safety Management
Subject_Description_17: This course educates students in modern onboard navigation systems and associated ground based technology. In addition, the course consolidates prior knowledge gained in the fields of Meteorology, Flight Planning and Performance, Basic Navigation and Aviation Regulation.
Subject_Description_18: This course introduces students to aspects of aviation biology and medicine essential for safe and effective pilot performance and for preservation of wellbeing while in overseas locations. Theoretical knowledge is integrated with some practical exercises designed to enhance student learning. The online offering of this course is only available to 'professional entry' students. Those students should email the Program Officer, Aviation, at aviation@griffith.edu.au for permission to enrol. Incompatible: Course AVN2001 Aviation Biology and Medicine
Subject_or_Unit_19: AIRCRAFT OPERATIONS, PERFORMANCE AND PLANNING PART I
Subject_Description_19: The course content covers the key areas of; aerodromes and aeroplane landing areas, take off, climb, en route, descent and landing performance; pre-flight and in-flight operational considerations; aeroplane loading; airworthiness and equipment requirements; flight rules and procedures. The course is covered in sufficient depth to enable students with limited flying experience or aviation industry exposure to grasp the fundamentals of aeroplane operation, performance and planning in accordance with the CASA CPL Operations, Performance and Planning syllabus. Incompatible with: 2510BPS/2510NSC Light Aircraft Operations, Performance and Planning
Subject_Description_20: 3524NSC focuses on the human factors issues faced by pilots. It considers the human factors relevant to various flying operations in the aviation industry. This course examines human performance and limitations, from both a theoretical and practical perspective; with the aim of improving flight safety.
Subject_Description_21: Language and Communication for Sciences is offered to students from a non-English speaking background (NESB). Students whose first language is English are NOT PERMITTED to undertake this course. The aim of this course is to introduce students to the language, knowledge and communication skills required for study and practice in their discipline. A further aim is to develop and practice English language skills relevant to the academic culture of Australian universities. It therefore involves intensive English language practice and language immersion activities, with elements applied to contextualised, discipline-specific settings. This course constitutes part of the overall English Language Enhancement Strategy at Griffith University. Prerequisites: NIL; Incompatible: 5901LHS/5901LAL, 5902LHS/5902LAL, 5904LHS/5904LAL and 5903LAL.
Subject_Description_22: "Flight Procedures" is a workshop style course series, where students implement aviation theory and regulatory rules in a simulation laboratory environment. Flight Procedures II uses the Cessna 182RG software to introduce the constant speed propeller, retractable landing gear and glass cockpit design features initially, before exploring Instrument Flight Rules and procedures based on the Private Instrument Rating - all without any weather issues. We cover Instrument Flight Rules and associated Standard Operating Procedures ending with 2D non-precision approaches. Prerequisite: 1505NSC Flight Procedures I

Description: This degree will help you advance your career in aviation management and thrive in the constantly changing aviation environment. You will study courses that directly relate to job functions in the aviation industry. In your final year, you will have the opportunity to undertake a short research project, which allows you to make a valuable contribution to an area in the aviation industry that interests you and can be sponsored by an organisation or individual within the aviation industry. Griffith University has Australia's most highly recognised aviation teaching program. Our aviation staff have strong industry ties and are world leaders in air travel safety research and focus on the human elements in flight operations to help improve safety. Over the past 20 years teaching in this field, we have built an international reputation for graduates who are industry ready.
Career_Outcomes: As a graduate, you will be prepared for employment in aviation management. You will also be able to apply your management skills to many areas of the aviation industry including: airlines, air traffic service providers, maintenance and repair organisations, and government organisations, such as the Australian Defence Force and the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA). Our graduates have been successful in gaining a range of flying and management positions with organisations such as Cathay Pacific, Emirates, Etihad, Jetstar, Qantas and Regional Express as well as Airservices Australia and CASA.
Subject_Description_1: This course explores the highly specific economics associated with the aviation industry. It will introduce students to basic economic theories and concepts and applies these concepts to the aviation industry.
Subject_Description_2: The project will allow the student to combine all of the knowledge and practical skills which have been developed during the degree. Students will be required to conduct a research project. Although not essential, students may be sponsored by an organisation or individual within the aviation industry. The research project will address an issue of relevance to the industry.
Subject_Description_3: The aviation industry today is fiercely competitive, operating in a highly dynamic and global environment. Aviation businesses require aviation professionals with the knowledge, understanding and skills to be able to deliver sustainable and competitive products and services in this challenging climate. This course builds on principles of the air transport industry, infrastructure considerations, management functions specific to the airline environment and general management functions in aviation business. While concentrating on the contemporary issues affecting the aviation industry, the course emphasizes practical managerial applications within aviation organizations. Prior Assumed: Nil Incompatible: AVN3008 Aviation Management for Pilots, AVN7001 Airline Management and 7001AVN Airline Management.
Subject_Description_4: This course aims to provide students with a sound understanding of research methods applicable to the aviation industry. The course provides an introduction to the variety of approaches to designing good research. With a focus on research in the aviation industry, the course covers both quantitative and qualitative designs, from experiments to case studies, and map their fit to theory and research question, as well as their advantages and disadvantages. The course aims to provide students with the research skills necessary to tackle 3502NSC, or 3504NSC.
Subject_Description_5: Language and Communication for Sciences is offered to students from a non-English speaking background (NESB). Students whose first language is English are NOT PERMITTED to undertake this course. The aim of this course is to introduce students to the language, knowledge and communication skills required for study and practice in their discipline. A further aim is to develop and practice English language skills relevant to the academic culture of Australian universities. It therefore involves intensive English language practice and language immersion activities, with elements applied to contextualised, discipline-specific settings. This course constitutes part of the overall English Language Enhancement Strategy at Griffith University. Prerequisites: NIL; Incompatible: 5901LHS/5901LAL, 5902LHS/5902LAL, 5904LHS/5904LAL and 5903LAL.
Subject_Description_6: The course intends to offer students a deeper perspective of project management within the aviation industry. The course includes discussion of key elements of project management in aviation. This includes consideration of planning, controlling, time management, managing conflicts, controlling costs, executive involvement, performance, review, communication and decision-making. A number of industry specific cases are discussed to illustrate the application of project management theory. Incompatible with: 3512BPS/3512NSC Managing Projects in Aviation.
Subject_Description_7: The project will allow the student to combine all of the knowledge and practical skills which have been developed during the degree. Students will be required to conduct a short research project. Although not essential, students may be sponsored by an organisation or individual within the aviation industry. The research project will address an issue of relevance to the industry.
Subject_Description_8: This capstone course directs student teams towards tackling a complex issue that a BSI client is facing. Each phase of the course builds-up to provide our clients with a report that proposes possible solution(s) to problem. The aim of the capstone is to offer confidential managerial assistance to firms in a variety of industries (manufacturing, tourism, general services, etc.) across a variety of contexts (e.g. SMEs, community groups, NGOs, overseas clients, potential exporters). This course offers a student team that provides consultancy services to each BSI client to identify and solve a business problem. Examples of outputs include: Feasibility studies, strategic plans, market research reports, product reviews and customer satisfaction reports.
Subject_Description_9: Quality Management has emerged as one of the main management philosophies in the developed world and forms the basis of Business Excellence Models World-wide. This approach to management has been engaged in both the public and private sector. This course is aimed at providing an introduction to the concepts and practice of Quality Management, and an integration of the ideas of Quality Management within broader management concerns. This course directly addresses the major philosophies behind the design and development of a Quality Improvement Program. It guides the student through the concept of quality, and the establishment of quality improvement mechanisms. In addition, various analytical tools used by Quality Improvement professionals for the collection and analysis of data are taught. These approaches are addressed within a team context which is pivotal to many quality programs. This provides the student with the analytical skills to design, evaluate and implement a Quality Improvement Program. Prerequisites: 1101IBA/1181IBA OR 1001MGT/1081MGT Management Concepts OR 2005IBA Comparative Management Corequisites: Nil Incompatible: 3044MGT Quality Management
Subject_Description_10: Note: This course is not offered from 2021. Check program requirements for details of alternative courses. This course is designed as a first formal course in basic statistical methods. It aims to provide recognition of situations where statistical analysis may be of benefit and the range of methods that may apply to a given situation. In this course, students will learn to use statistical methods to extract useful information from a set of data, and to utilize the information gathered appropriately in the business decision making process. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: 1304AFE Business Statistics, 1003PSY Research Methods and Statistics in Psychology
Subject_Description_11: This is a capstone course for the Management major, where students draw on theories from previously studied courses and bring them together to solve challenging problems in a simulated management environment. In order to be adequately prepared, Bachelor of Business students must have completed 160 Credit Points. Students from other degrees or majors must be in their 3rd year to have a comparable foundation to undertake the experiential exercises. It is assumed that ALL students will be in the FINAL year of their program, otherwise they will have difficulties to complete this course successfully. The course has a multi-disciplinary focus, drawing on previous learning from a variety of courses. It gives students an opportunity to view problems through different lenses and encourages them to take initiative and approach problems in a reflective and creative manner. Prerequisites: Nil Corequisites: Nil Incompatible: Nil
Subject_Description_12: It has been identified that exposure to practical aspects of the aviation industry are an essential part of undergraduate courses. Though many students strive for final employment within the airline industry, it is the general aviation industry that will see most students beginning their aviation careers. Research with current/past students, staff and industry identified important skills that in some cases lack with new pilots within the general aviation industry. This course goes part of the way in assisting to develop some of these skills. Incompatible with: 1106AVN Introductory Aviation Studies 1501BPS Introductory Aviation Studies
Subject_Description_13: This course provides students with a sound understanding of the principles and practices relating to airport planning, operation and management. The course introduces students to the airport sector of the aviation industry, how airports are planned and developed, current and contemporary strategies for obtaining revenue and identifying and controlling costs
Subject_or_Unit_14: INTRODUCTION TO HUMAN FACTORS FOR AVIATION MANAGERS
Subject_Description_14: 1510NSC introduces students to various human factors principles and practices. It encourages proactive implementation of human factors in the aviation industry. This course examines human performance and limitations, from both a theoretical and practical perspective; with the aim of improving flight safety.
Subject_Description_15: The course serves as an introductory platform to business processes. It offers both conceptual and practical guidance for achieving competitive advantage by managing business processes. Business process management involves the deliberate and collaborative design, management and goal definition of end-to-end sets of activities that create value for customers. Extensive use of supplementary material from Management, Marketing, Logistics and Human Resources literature is made. Key aspects of business processes at the management, operational and support level are investigated and supporting theories explored looking at the work of Taylor, Harmon, Davenport, Hammer and Porter to name some. By taking a holistic view of the organization, that transcends vertical, horizontal, external and geographical boundaries, this course provides a road map for guiding organisations to analyse, re-design and improve business processes. Finally, the effects of the application of Information Systems on business processes are investigated in terms of how the processes themselves are captured and become an integral part of the technology. Prerequisites: Nil Corequisites: Nil Incompatible: 2188IBA OR 2028MGT Business Processes/Operations Management/Production and Management Systems
Subject_Description_16: The project will allow the student to combine all of the knowledge and practical skills which have been developed during the degree. Students will be required to conduct a research project. Although not essential, students may be sponsored by an organisation or individual within the aviation industry. The research project will address an issue of relevance to the industry.
Subject_Description_17: This course introduces students to a perspective of the purpose of business that embeds values such as responsible leadership, integrity and ethical behaviour, respect for others, trust, and sustainable enterprise. The relevance of these values and their impact on behaviour and outcomes in a business context is demonstrated to students through case studies, real world examples, and testimonials from industry partners. Following from the discussion of values, the course then looks at how businesses develop solutions to respond to increasing demand for sustainability, transparency and good governance. The framework of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) is introduced and used to examine the alignment between business practices and sustainable solutions to real life problems faced by a business. The course also considers the role and responsibility (including legal) of professionals and professional standards in today's society.
Subject_Description_18: Aviation security affects all areas of operation and is of great concern for everyone in the industry. This course provides students with a sound understanding of security measures and regulations in the aviation industry, including principles and practices of risk management in addressing aviation security.
Subject_Description_19: The aim of the course is to explain the way people behave and make decisions in a business environment and the role that information has in the context of decision-making. The course will introduce some elements of behavioural sciences and game theory applied to business problems. It will also tackle some of the critical questions around the use of information for business decision making: how to assess the validity/reliability and relevance of the information we receive? how to use it effectively? how to simplify information, make it relevant, and present it to different audiences? The course combines different aspects. First, it encourages students to account for the psychological, cognitive, emotional, cultural, and social factors that affects decisions made by individuals and organisations (e.g. private corporates, government, civil society, etc). Second it provides simple analytical tools to contextualise strategic decision-making in real world situations through lenses such as that of the consumer and the future role of social marketing. Third, it introduces students to the idea that business decision making requires reliable, timely information. The course takes a positive (as opposed to normative) approach to the analysis of interactive strategic decisions and behaviours. Through case studies, the course provides a description of what happens in a variety of business situations, with a focus on understanding the elements/dynamics that leads to a certain outcome of decision. In so doing, the course helps students identify the role of information (qualitative or quantitative), how it is sourced and assessed in terms of its validity/quality, and how it can be used to deal with uncertainty in decision-making. Basic approaches to the analysis, interpretation and presentation of various types of information are also discussed, including the foundations of big data analytics and qualitative data analysis.
Subject_Description_20: The course aims to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of leadership: theory, application and skill development in the context of the aviation industry and competitive environment. The course will cover leadership theory and concepts whilst improving students ability to apply the theory through critical thinking, and to develop leadership skills.
Subject_Description_21: The importance of managing for safety has been re-emphasised in recent years by the ICAO recommendation for aviation operators to implement a Safety Management System (SMS) based on the published ICAO SMS framework. This course will examine the key elements of a safety management system and the associated systems, processes and procedures used in achieving high safety standards in aviation organisations. There will be a strong emphasis on the importance of leadership and sound management principles and their important contribution to achieving high safety standards. Prior Assumed: Nil Incompatible: AVN3005 Flight Safety, 3005AVN Safety Management, 2511BPS Safety Management
Subject_Description_22: This course provides students with a general introduction to organisations and the functions of management. Topic areas will address issues related to organisations, management, and society. The course will cover the core management functions of leading, planning, controlling and organising. Prerequisites: Nil. Co-requisites: Nil. Incompatible: 1181IBA Management Concepts/ 1201HSL Management Concepts/ 1106HSL Leisure Management/ 2031HSV Working in Organisations.
Subject_Description_23: The course explores the impact that government and business have on one another in a national and international context. It asks what consequences these relationships have for both government and business, particularly in the context of the aftermath of the global financial crisis. It offers insights into how government policies and practices affect business and how business influences and relates to government. At the heart of this course lies the issue of government intervention in business in Australia and elsewhere around the world. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatibles: 1004GIR Government-Business Relations, 1004PPP/1184PPP Government-Business Relations, 2004PPP Government-Business Relations.
