Subject_Description_18: This course examines the two most common methods of inquiry in research - qualitative and quantitative. Topics include theoretical paradigms (emic and etic), research questions, literature reviews, research design, sampling, data collection and analysis, reliability and validity, and ethics in research. It will be comprised of 90 min lectures (viewed online before the tutorial) and 90 minute tutorials (usually on campus). Students can also attend additional PASS sessions for further assistance. At the completion of this course, students will be able to understand the research process, critically analyse the methodology of published research, and design their own research proposal with a methodology that is appropriate for their hypothesis/research question. Assessment will include a mid trimester online test, the design of a research proposal (for either a qualitative or quantitative study), and an end of trimester exam. Incompatible: 1017HSV">1017HSV Human Services Research; 1017HSV">1017HSV Research Methods. Restriction: The online offering is restricted to students enrolled in HSV External programs ONLY. Students outside HSV will not be permitted to complete the online option of this course.
Subject_Description_19: A sound understanding of the institutions of public policy is essential for effective practice in a range of human service professions. With this knowledge practitioners can influence, advocate, improve social policy and legislation and contribute toward social change. This course is intended to give students a solid grounding in the Australian system of Government and the Australian legal system. It is also intended to provide students with an understanding of how policies are developed, and therefore how they can participate in and influence the policy making process. The course is broken into two parts. The first half of the trimester examines the Australian system of Government, and aspects of the Australian legal system that impact on both practitioners and their future clients. The second half of the course examines the policy making process, with a particular focus on influencing change from outside the policy making system. The latter half is intended to equip new front line human service workers with the knowledge and skills needed to be effective advocates for social change.
Subject_Description_20: This course sets out the foundations for human services processes and practices, establishing students as 'emerging practitioners' and providing the knowledge, skills and values framework for development of professional identity. In particular, it tracks the identification of need, service delivery models and systems, and the organisational context in which assessment and intervention processes take place across the domains of practice. The course also explores the influences of knowledge and theory, and uses case analysis to identify the perspectives of service users, as well as the challenges for practice. Restriction: The online offering of this course is available for HSV students only. Students outside HSV will not be permitted to complete the online offering. Psychology students can choose this course as a free-choice elective in their program however they can only choose the on-campus offering and not the online offering of this course. NOTE: ONLINE OFFERING: Please be aware that online learning is different to learning on campus. Depending on the structure of the course, you may have access to the same content and resources as on campus students. You will not have separate tutorials or lecture slides as this content is already represented on your Learning@Griffith course site. Online learning requires that you self pace through the content, under weekly direction from your teaching staff, which means that you need to take responsibility for your learning in a different way.
Subject_Description_21: This course presents knowledge and skills for working with family members who have lived, or are living in abusive relationships. The course covers child maltreatment, sexually abusive and other problem behaviours in children and young people, elder abuse, and family/domestic/intimate partner violence. Discussion of prevention and intervention strategies encourages students to critically reflect on social and personal values. Please Note : (1) This is a restricted course - This course is open to student who have this course listed in their program and they must have completed 160CP of Human Services Courses (or equivalent) to be eligible to enrol in 3023HSV Working with Family Violence. (2) The workload for this course continues after the end of the intensive. NOTE: ONLINE OFFERING: Please be aware that online learning is different to learning on campus. Depending on the structure of the course, you may have access to the same content and resources as on campus students. You will not have separate tutorials or lecture slides as this content is already represented on your Learning@Griffith course site. Online learning requires that you self pace through the content, under weekly direction from your teaching staff, which means that you need to take responsibility for your learning in a different way.
Subject_Description_22: Working in Organisations focuses on developing the skills and knowledge of students to work in human service organisations. Students will acquire an understanding of the organisational structures, accountability requirements, management responsibilities and industrial issues which influence the nature of the work and work relations specifically in human service organisations. Restriction: The online offering is restricted to students enrolled in HSV External programs ONLY. Students outside HSV will not be permitted to complete the online option of this course. Psychology students who do not have this course listed in their program can choose the on-campus offering only as a free-choice elective. Students outside Psych and HSV must have this course approved as an elective option in their course to complete it. NOTE ONLINE OFFERING: Please be aware that online learning is different to learning on campus. Depending on the structure of the course, you may have access to the same content and resources as on campus students. You will not have separate tutorials or lecture slides as this content is already represented on your Learning@Griffith course site. Online learning requires that you self pace through the content, under weekly direction from your teaching staff, which means that you need to take responsibility for your learning in a different way.

Description: International students must be in Australia and able to attend campus to commence this program. This degree includes advanced coursework in the exercise sciences, combined with a minimum of 500 hours of professional practice. You'll be prepared for work in a range of professional areas as a dual-accredited Exercise Scientist and Exercise Physiologist. Your deeper knowledge of the human body and how exercise affects it will enable you to assess, design and deliver exercise-based programs that improve health and performance, prevent chronic conditions, and treat or manage a range of health conditions.
Career_Outcomes: Students who graduate from this program will be prepared to work in the fields of Exercise Science and Exercise Physiology. Exercise Scientists can gain employment in the fields of: community recreation, fitness or sports; clinical measurements in the field of cardiac; respiratory and sleep medicine; rehabilitation, sports or recreation management; strength and conditioning; or occupational health and safety. Accredited Exercise Physiologists are allied health professionals equipped with the knowledge, skills and competencies to design, deliver and evaluate safe and effective exercise interventions for people with acute, sub-acute or chronic medical conditions, injuries or disabilities. Pathology domains covered by the services of Accredited Exercise Physiologists include cardiovascular, metabolic, neurological, musculoskeletal, cancers, kidney, respiratory/pulmonary and mental health, and any other conditions for which there is evidence that exercise can improve the client's clinical status.
Subject_Description_1: Introductory Biomechanics is an introductory biomechanics course designed for exercise science and physiotherapy students. Prerequitise 1001AHS Foundations of Exercise and Sports Science
Subject_Description_2: Musculoskeletal Biomechanics is the science that examines the internal and external forces acting on a body and the effects produced by these forces. This course builds upon knowledge and skills gained in Introductory Biomechanics. Topics covered include gait analysis, tissue mechanics, musculoskeletal biomechanics, with application to sport, work and the clinical and rehabilitation settings.
Subject_or_Unit_3: FOUNDATIONS OF EXERCISE AND SPORTS SCIENCE
Subject_Description_3: Exercise and Sports Science is a multidisciplinary field encompassing physiology, biomechanics, nutrition and the psychosocial aspects of human movement. This course provides foundational knowledge that is key to developing a sound base for understanding the health and wellness continuum between performance athletes and chronic disease patients. Theoretical and practical learning in the biophysical knowledge domains (cell & tissue physiology as well as biophysics) will be combined with professional awareness and career pathways in the exercise and sports science industry. Note. Only available to students enrolled in AHS Programs.
Subject_or_Unit_4: PROFESSIONAL PRACTICE IN EXERCISE PHYSIOLOGY III
Subject_Description_4: This course will support students to develop a range of clinical skills essential in the practice of exercise physiology. Through a range of simulation and inter-professional learning environments students will advance their 'soft' clinical skills in areas including client engagement, motivational interviewing and inter-professional collaboration. Learnings acquired in this course will compliment those developed through clinical practicum. Prerequisites: 4601AHS Exercise for Clinical Populations I, 4602AHS Exercise for Clinical Populations II, 4603AHS Professional Practice in Exercise Physiology I, 4604AHS Professional Practice in Exercise Physiology II Co-requisites: 4606AHS Exercise Physiology Practicum
Subject_Description_5: This course introduces organic and biological chemistry, which underpins all biochemical processes and the molecular basis of life. Pre-Requisite: 1001MSC Chemistry of Biological Systems I or 1023SCG Chemistry 1 Assumed Knowledge: Maths B and One of Biology, Chemistry or Physics (4SA).
Subject_Description_6: This course will focus on the pathophysiological basis, and clinical assessment, of a range of acute and chronic musculoskeletal and neurological conditions that are relevant to Exercise Physiology practice.
Subject_or_Unit_7: PROFESSIONAL PRACTICE IN EXERCISE PHYSIOLOGY I
Subject_Description_7: This course aims to introduce students to aspects of professional practice as they relate to an Accredited Exercise Physiologist. Students will gain an understanding of professional, legal and ethical issues in practice, and learn to navigate the public and private health systems. Students will be taught report writing skills and formulating referrals. Additionally, this course will also highlight some of the current/emerging roles of an Exercise Physiologist; for example, in occupational health assessment, workplace injury management and return to work strategies, that are specific to the Australian setting and within the scope of practice of an ESSA-accredited Exercise Physiologist. Prerequisites: Satisfactory completion of year 1, 2 and 3 of the Bachelor of Clinical Exercise Physiology Co-requisites: 4601AHS Exercise for Clinical Populations I, 4602AHS Exercise for Clinical Populations II, 4604AHS Professional Practice in Exercise Physiology II
Subject_Description_8: This course introduces the basic chemical principles that underlie biological systems. The foundation provided in this course will allow students to be able to further develop their chemistry knowledge and skills relevant to health and medical sciences in later years. Assumed Knowledge: Maths B and One of Biology, Chemistry or Physics. Incompatible with 1023SCG Chemistry I
Subject_Description_9: This course introduces students to the fundamental design, organisation and workings of the human nervous system.
Subject_Description_10: This course provides a sound theoretical and practical background in clinical exercise testing including specificity, sensitivity, reliability, and validity of selected tests and procedures. Particular attention is given to the interpretation of test results from patients with cardiovascular or lung disease as well as highly trained athletes, and aged persons. Case studies will be widely used. The laboratory sessions are designed to help students develop technical skills needed to conduct a graded exercise test as well as understand the theoretical principles associated with exercise testing.
Subject_Description_11: This course introduces students to key motor learning and control concepts relating to exercise and sport contexts. Upon completion of the course students will have developed the ability to interpret, contrast, and evaluate a range of motor learning and control approaches, theories and models. Students will also develop a practical appreciation of key concepts in terms of designing effective skill acquisition and performance environments for exercise and sport settings.
Subject_Description_12: This course focuses on changes in body systems and function that occur throughout the lifespan, and how exercise may be used to improve function. The effects of sedentary behaviour and common lifestyle-related diseases on function and the benefits of physical activity are explored. Pre-requisites: 1001AHS Foundations of Exercise and Sports Science, 1016MSC Anatomy and Physiology Systems I and 1017MSC Anatomy and Physiology Systems II.
Subject_Description_13: This course covers the anatomy and physiology of the cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, digestive and immune systems. Both the study of the anatomy and the physiology of these systems draws on the experience gained in the lectures, laboratories and practicums. Prerequisites for Gold Coast students: 1016MSC">1016MSC Anatomy and Physiology Systems I, and 1014MSC Cells, Tissues and Regulation OR 1001AHS Foundations of Exercise and Sport Science. Prerequisites for Nathan students: 1016MSC">1016MSC Anatomy and Physiology Systems I and 1001NSC Human Biology.
Subject_Description_14: This course aims to integrate knowledge acquired in previous courses of the program. 3005AHS Exercise Programming & Prescription I is focused strongly on the theoretical basis underpinning exercise prescription. The principles are revised and then further developed with the extension of evidence based prescription Theoretical knowledge will be complemented by strong practical skills and sound reasoning skills, integrated to enable safe and effective measurement and prescription skills.
Subject_Description_15: Clinical practicum forms a key component of work-integrated learning activities that integrates theoretical learning with its application in the workplace. Exercise Physiology Practicum will require students to undertake a minimum of 360 hours of clinical practicum across a diverse range of relevant practice domains. This course will provide students with opportunities to practice and further develop their vocational skills in professional practice settings. Prerequisites: 4601AHS Exercise for Clinical Populations I, 4602AHS Exercise for Clinical Populations II, 4603AHS Professional Practice in Exercise Physiology I, 4604AHS Professional Practice in Exercise Physiology II Co-requisites: 4605AHS Professional Practice in Exercise Physiology III
Subject_Description_16: This course is designed to provide students with advanced theoretical knowledge and practical skills for the prescription of resistance, endurance, and speed exercise programming. The information presented in 3013AHS will be applicable for those wanting to improve health and fitness, sports performance and rehabilitating and preventing common musculoskeletal injuries. Effective exercise prescription requires identifying individuals' goals, competency in determining specific demands of different sports, understanding exercise responses and adaptations and the ability to design and individualised and evidence based training program. Finally, the course will also further develop a student's appreciation on how evidence-based research supports exercise prescription.
Subject_Description_17: This Foundation Year course takes a multi-disciplinary and integrated approach to examine population health in the 21st century. Using a socio-ecological perspective, the course will take a systems approach (i.e. from prevention through to treatment) to introduce students to the environmental, social and behavioural determinants of health and disease. The course will link these determinants with global and national priority health challenges of the 21st century together with the implications for effective health care practice.
Subject_Description_18: Exercise Science Practicum is a mandatory course in the Bachelor of Exercise Science program. The rationale for including this course is to make students aware of the requirements of the industry they wish to enter and the working environment of various organisations in which they may seek employment. The course is designed to link and complement the student's program of study by introducing them to the work environment. The main purposes of this course are: a) to provide students with work experience within the industry they may seek to be employed; (b) to introduce students to various topics concerning the work environment and field of exercise science; and (c) to outline career planning procedures. Students need to have successfully completed the first two years of the Bachelor of Exercise Science program.
Subject_or_Unit_19: PROFESSIONAL PRACTICE IN EXERCISE PHYSIOLOGY II
Subject_Description_19: This course aims to build on the student's knowledge of psychology in exercise, sport and rehabilitation by introducing them to the psychological aspect of managing rehabilitation and chronic disease as they relate to a practicing health professional. Additionally the student will learn how to effectively identify and address psychological factors within their professional scope of practice and how to treat a patient/client as part of a multidisciplinary team. Prerequisites: Satisfactory completion of year 1, 2 and 3 of the Bachelor of Clinical Exercise Physiology Co-requisites: 4601AHS Exercise for Clinical Populations I, 4602AHS Exercise for Clinical Populations II, 4603AHS Professional Practice in Exercise Physiology I
Subject_Description_20: The course will provide the basis for an understanding of the principles that underpin rehabilitation (including prevention and management) of selected clinical conditions and how a detailed understanding of those principles and mechanisms may improve clinical outcomes. Clinical conditions examined in this course will include cardiovascular, respiratory, and metabolic diseases. Prerequisites: Satisfactory completion of year 1, 2 and 3 of the Bachelor of Clinical Exercise Physiology Co-requisites: 4602AHS Exercise for Clinical Populations II, 4603AHS Professional Practice in Exercise Physiology I, 4604AHS Professional Practice in Exercise Physiology II
Subject_Description_21: Musculoskeletal Anatomy course has been designed to consolidate knowledge of structure and function of the musculoskeletal system. A thorough understanding of musculoskeletal anatomy is imperative to the practice of physiotherapists, exercise physiologists and other health professionals. Students will build on theoretical knowledge and practical skills obtained in prerequisite courses through a series of online lectures, specialised laboratory sessions and a weekly online tutorial. Prerequisite: 1016MSC Anatomy & Physiology Systems I or other approved anatomy course
Subject_Description_22: The course will provide the basis for an understanding of the principles that underpin rehabilitation (including prevention and management) of selected clinical conditions and how a detailed understanding of those principles and mechanisms may improve clinical outcomes. Clinical conditions examined in this course will include musculoskeletal and neurological conditions. Prerequisites: Satisfactory completion of year 1, 2 and 3 of the Bachelor of Clinical Exercise Physiology Co-requisites: 4601AHS Exercise for Clinical Populations I, 4603AHS Professional Practice in Exercise Physiology I, 4604AHS Professional Practice in Exercise Physiology II
Subject_Description_23: The course introduces students to the fundamental principles of psychology as applied to the areas of exercise, sport and rehabilitation. Issues relevant to participants (across the lifespan and functional capacity), patients, coaches, practitioners, and promoters involved in the optimization of individual and group performance are considered. Prerequisite: 1001PSY - Introduction to Psychology 1 OR 1002PSY - Introduction to Psychology 2 OR equivalent
Subject_Description_24: This course will provide foundational knowledge of medicines and pharmacology for allied health professions. The course will cover principles such as pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, pharmacogenomics; drug interactions and side effects; and orientation to the use of medicines for common disorders of the musculoskeletal, neurological, cardiovascular, respiratory, endocrine, and gastrointestinal, and immune systems. It is expected that students wishing to study 2011PHM will have completed tertiary level courses in anatomy and physiology.
Subject_Description_25: Five body systems: Skeletal, Muscle, Nervous, Endocrine and Reproductive Systems are studied in this course, which integrates anatomy with physiology. The theory presented in this course is supported by practical laboratory experiences, which include the study of human cadaveric material.
Subject_Description_26: This course, Research Methods and Statistics provides students with the mathematical skills used in measurement, processing and analysing of data typical of those obtained in Exercise Science. The course also provides an introduction to experimental design and statistical analyses appropriate to investigations in Exercise Science. No Prererquisites.
Subject_Description_27: This course builds on content from previous trimesters, and provides students with an in-depth understanding of the physiological responses that occur during exercise. Particular attention will be given to the responses of the cardiovascular, respiratory, endocrine and metabolic systems during exercise, their integration and regulation. The adaptations to acute and chronic exercise will be examined in healthy and diseased populations. Prerequisites: 2012AHS Integrated Systems Physiology or 2004AHS Exercise, Health and Disease
Subject_Description_28: Language and Communication for Health is offered to students from a non-English speaking background (NESB). Students whose first language is English are NOT PERMITTED to undertake this course. The aim of this course is to introduce students to the language, knowledge and communication skills required for study and practice in their discipline. A further aim is to develop and practice English language skills relevant to the academic culture of Australian universities. It therefore involves intensive English language practice and language immersion activities, with elements applied to contextualised, discipline-specific settings. This course constitutes part of the overall English Language Enhancement Strategy at Griffith University. Prerequisites: NIL; Incompatible: 5901LHS/5901LAL, 5903LHS/5903LAL, 5904LHS/5904LAL and 5902LAL.
Subject_Description_29: This course provides students with an understanding of the relationship between nutrition, health and exercise performance. Students will develop an understanding of nutrient metabolism during exercise and the role of food, fluid and nutrition supplements in enhancing exercise performance, training and recovery. Current nutrition recommendations for overall health and well-being will also be covered along with nutrition and physical activity guidelines for modifying body composition and preventing and managing chronic disease.
Subject_Description_30: This course provides a foundation for understanding the cognitive and biological bases of human behaviour, including the role of the brain and neural processes in behaviour, perception (how the senses allow you to see, hear, taste, touch and smell the world around you), conditioning and learning (how humans and other animals learn about their environment), cognition and memory (how people think, solve problems and remember). Drawing on various research traditions in experimental psychology, this course demonstrates how cognitive and biological psychology contributes to our knowledge of human well-being and performance. Students apply this knowledge through a series of practical in-class exercises. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: 1004HLS_Y2

Description: The Bachelor of Communication is offered through Open Universities Australia (OUA). Students will qualify for this degree after the completion of at least eight Griffith units along with two majors of six units each, chosen from either Business Communication, Creative Writing, Journalism, Public Relations or Screen Studies, plus the core units, associated prerequisites, and the required number of free-choice electives. All students are recommended to select their electives from the  OUA list, and should contact Griffith for approval of alternative elective units. For further information, please contact either of the following areas:
Career_Outcomes: Graduates of this program may find employment and receive enhanced professional recognition in areas such as:

Description: Developed in close consultation with industry, the Bachelor of Communication and Journalism will produce communication specialists who understand the diversity and complexity of the contemporary communication and media landscape and are able to thrive within it. Specifically designed to respond to the demand for graduates who are ready for the challenges and opportunities of next generation media and associated industries, this degree will equip students with a comprehensive set of advanced writing skills, multimedia production abilities, and the capacity to think both laterally and creatively. You will work alongside and learn from some of the best journalists, editors, producers, content makers and communication professionals in the country. Our top industry placements open doors to a diverse media career. Our graduates will be professional storytellers, journalists and communicators who are set to lead innovation and change in the 21st century communication and media industry. Graduates will be well equipped to work within journalism, freelance writing, strategic or public relations, corporate promotions, commercial communication, creative industries, public relations and communications firms, government and non-government organisations, not-for-profit and aid organisations, media and the film industry, entrepreneurial and start-up organisations.
Career_Outcomes: Occupations include: social media coordinator, community and stakeholder engagement officer, digital marketing specialist, communications officer, events manager, social media manager, public relations consultant, public relations professional, strategic communications specialist, media liaison officer, campaign manager, media analyst, promotions officer, copywriter, journalist, reporter, producer, researcher, editor freelance writer, corporate promotions and communications.
Subject_Description_1: This course builds a foundation for a successful career in journalism, strategic communication and public relations. Critical reflection will allow students to examine their roles as ethical and socially responsible professionals in a dynamic and changing communication landscape.
Subject_or_Unit_2: RESEARCH SKILLS AND WRITING FOR COMMUNICATION AND JOURNALISM
Subject_Description_2: Students learn the essential research and writing skills required for their dynamic roles as media and communication professionals. These include information selection and management, data analytics, fact verification, critical appraisal, source selection, and various genres of communication writing.
Subject_Description_3: This course is designed to help students develop a practical and critical understanding of the communications process. The course introduces students to foundational communication techniques necessary to developing a broadcast voice, non-verbal communication and public 'performance' skills. The course explores the essential physical and vocal processes necessary in a range of journalism and strategic communication settings. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: NIL
Subject_Description_4: This course canvasses the key thinkers and ideas that have established the disciplinary field of Communication, Media and Journalism Studies. This course will position students to both understand and enhance their practice via reflection on the scholarly insights of their chosen discipline. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: NIL
Subject_Description_6: This course is designed to enable an intensive application of research, writing, and production skills associated with producing journalism for radio. Prerequisites: 2511HUM News Writing and Ethics and 2513HUM Media Law. Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: 2523LHS / 2523HUM Radio Journalism
Subject_Description_7: This course will equip students with essential, practical skills for communicating information about health and science issues to a wide range of audiences. Students will learn to critically evaluate and interpret health and science information and adapt it for news stories, as well as health promotion and education campaigns. They will also learn to develop and produce a health podcast that forms part of a major group assessment. This course will provide you with skills to help you become an effective communicator across health and medicine, journalism, and public relations.
Subject_Description_8: This course introduces students to an essential toolkit of multi-media technologies. Students participating in this course are engaged in constructing their online professional identity and taking the first steps in developing their professional portfolio. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: NIL
Subject_Description_9: This course facilitates student involvement in a structured Work Integrated Learning (WIL) placement in journalism or a related communications industry under the guidance of an academic supervisor. Students will couple the practical experience gained while on internship with critical reflection on industry practice and standards as part of their assessment. PREREQUISITE: Students must have completed at least 160 credit points of their degree and successfully completed 2513LHS Media Law and/or 2515LHS Media Relations, PLUS one of the following Ethics courses: 2505LHS Ethical Communications; 2501LHS Public Relations Theory, Ethics and Professional Practice; or 2511LHS News Writing and Ethics. Co-requisites: NIL. INCOMPATIBLE: 3532HUM / 3532ART">3532ART Public Relations Internship 2; 3532ART">3532ART Communication Project 2.
Subject_Description_10: This course is designed to equip students with knowledges of ways in which journalism is theorised and applied across different media cultures in the Asia-Pacific region. The course looks more broadly at the different roles of journalism as a cultural resource. The course will focus on case studies drawn from Australia, the Pacific, and Canada, along with others selected by students, according to their needs. INCOMPATIBLE: 3025HUM / 3025AMC Journalism Cultures. INCOMPATIBLE: OUA Course Code: CJR300
Subject_Description_11: This course explores the ever increasing importance of data - big and small - in the work of communication professionals. It gives students skills in sourcing, analysing, interpreting and presenting data across multiple media platforms to tell rich and relevant stories to a range of audiences.
Subject_Description_12: This course introduces students to the critical role of communication in the public understanding of contemporary environmental issues and climate change. The course will examine successful environmental and climate change journalism and communication strategies, and furnish students with an opportunity to develop their own.
Subject_or_Unit_13: SOCIAL MEDIA FOR JOURNALISM AND PUBLIC RELATIONS
Subject_Description_13: Social media literacy has become essential to the work of professional communicators, particularly those working in journalism and public relations. This course covers the theory and practice of social media usage in the news and public relations contexts. It positions social media as a communication platform before considering the uses of social media in reporting, source identification, verification, attribution, issues management, audience building and public relations campaigning. Students learn the practices of ethical social media use and, via a series of case studies, learn the potential legal and ethical hazards in the misuse of social media. Students learn to distinguish between personal and professional social media use and to work within their organisations' social media policies when engaging in social media. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: NIL
Subject_Description_14: This course enables students to develop a critical understanding of ethics and professional practice in the contexts of journalism and strategic communication. It offers a highly practical, 'hands on' focus on ethical decision-making, law, and social considerations in the workplace. Prerequisites: NIL; Incompatible: 2511LHS News Writing and Ethics; 2501LHS Public Relations Theory, Ethics and Professional Practice.
Subject_Description_15: This course facilitates student involvement in a structured Work Integrated Learning (WIL) placement in journalism or a related communications industry under the guidance of an academic supervisor. Students will couple the practical experience gained while on internship with critical reflection on industry practice and standards as part of their assessment. PREREQUISITE: Students must have completed at least 160 credit points of their degree and successfully completed 2513LHS Media Law and/or 2515LHS Media Relations, PLUS one of the following Ethics courses: 2505LHS Ethical Communications; 2501LHS Public Relations Theory, Ethics and Professional Practice; or 2511LHS News Writing and Ethics. Co-requisites: NIL. INCOMPATIBLE: 3531HUM/3531ART Public Relations Internship 1.
Subject_Description_16: This course examines how political decisions and policy outcomes are influenced by public opinion and the news media. A key purpose of this course is to equip communications graduates with the knowledge and skills necessary to identify Australia's levers of powers and to systematically advocate for policy change on behalf of clients. In so doing, this course examines the Australian people through six sociological cleavages, and evaluates theories around power, communication and rhetoric. The course also identifies the levers of power residing in our political institutions, including prime ministers, cabinet, parliament, political parties, pressure groups and electoral systems. Students will also develop other knowledge and skills transferable to other fields of communication. Prerequisites: NIL; Co-requisites: NIL; Incompatible: NIL.
Subject_Description_17: This course meets the challenges of the changing media landscape where innovation and entrepreneurship are becoming crucial to the way in which careers are built. Students become professionals engaging in forms of mobile journalism and communication, who are able to work effectively within established newsrooms, communication agencies and pop-up communication spaces.
Subject_Description_18: Public Writing and Professional Practice aims to help students become competent and ethical strategic communicators. Immersing students in the craft of persuasive writing within contemporary communications industries, the course introduces relevant conceptual and ethical issues that are typically encountered in a professional communications environment. Designed to help students develop and refine their writing skills, Public Writing is highly relevant to anyone considering a career in professional communications or public relations. Students will be able to use their coursework to develop their e-Portfolios. INCOMPATIBLE: CMM251 Public Writing (Equivalent OUA Course).
Subject_Description_19: This course considers the role of risk and crisis communication within a business and public relations context. The course explores international case studies, theory and practice. It aims to equip the students with the skills necessary to identify and manage issues facing an organisation, build a crisis response plan and team, and effectively manage communication during a crisis event. Effective risk and crisis communication skills are an important element of public relations, business management and corporate governance. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: 3517LHS Risk and Crisis Communication.
Subject_or_Unit_20: COMMUNICATION FOR SOCIAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGE PROJECT
Subject_Description_20: This course provides an opportunity for students to make a final addition to their professional portfolio using the core critical thinking and practical skills developed throughout their degree. Project ideas will be refined in consultation with academic staff and will showcase the contribution of professional communicators and journalists to social and environmental change.
Subject_Description_21: This course introduces students to the techniques of researching and writing in a variety of longform journalism genres such as documentaries and features. Students are encouraged to critically analyse the work of a variety of longform practitioners while developing their own ideas about news values, styles and contents in multiplatform storytelling. Prerequisites: NIL; Co-requisites: NIL; Incompatible: NIL
Subject_Description_22: This course introduces beginning students to the pillars of Australian society, politics and power. It is designed especially, but not exclusively, for communications (PR) and journalism students who will regularly engage professionally with government, business and other powerful groups and figures throughout their careers. Where other introductory communications and journalism courses explore what questions to ask, this course identifies exactly to whom, and why, those questions should be put. Incompatible: 1509LHS Storytellers Toolkit; Prerequisites: NIL.
Subject_or_Unit_23: LANGUAGE AND COMMUNICATION FOR ARTS AND SOCIAL SCIENCES
Subject_Description_23: Language and Communication for Arts and Social Sciences is offered to students from a non-English speaking background (NESB). Students whose first language is English are NOT PERMITTED to undertake this course. The aim of this course is to introduce students to the language, knowledge and communication skills required for study and practice in their discipline. A further aim is to develop and practice English language skills relevant to the academic culture of Australian universities. It therefore involves intensive English language practice and language immersion activities, with elements applied to contextualised, discipline-specific settings. This course constitutes part of the overall English Language Enhancement Strategy at Griffith University. Prerequisites: NIL; Incompatible: 5901LHS/5901LAL, 5902LHS/5902LAL, 5903LHS/5903LAL, 5904LAL and 1019LHS.
Subject_Description_24: This course is designed to enable an intensive application of research, writing and production skills associated with creating content for audio visual media. Students in this course will take a hands-on approach to developing essential skills around producing online visual media, news documentary, news packages, and broadcast program development. Prerequisite: 2523LHS Digital Audio Media Production. Co-requisites: NIL. Incompatible: NIL.
Subject_Description_25: This course considers the role of media relations in the overall picture of public relations theory and practice. It aims to equip the student with the skills necessary to function in this role. It further aims to develop an understanding of the critical relationship between the public relations practitioner and the media, while providing insights into the different needs and expectations of the various media. INCOMPATIBLE: CMM220 Media Relations (OUA Course Equivalent).
Subject_Description_26: This course explores how journalism, media and communication is understood and practiced across different cultures and contexts. This course considers case studies drawn from around the world to prepare students for cross cultural communication as foreign correspondents and global content producers.
Subject_Description_27: This course brings public relations and media campaign strategies to life through students' role play of a mock state election campaign where theory, learned in the classroom, is applied by students to their real-time election campaigns. Given this is an advanced public relations course, students are expected to possess the knowledge and skills necessary to write and circulate media releases / media alerts, and know the basics of crisis management communication. As such, most of this course's assessment is drawn from students' practical application, in teams, of acquired knowledge and skills that are then applied to a mock election campaign for an imaginary forthcoming election. The course emphasises - and the assessment rewards - teamwork, independence and innovative thinking of the type relevant in real-world situations. While desirable, a knowledge of Queensland and / or Australian political institutions is not mandatory. PREREQUISITES: 2515LHS Media Relations. RECOMMENDED: 2509LHS Media, Politics & Public Opinion.
Subject_Description_28: This course exposes students to the real-world challenges and constraints of journalistic research. It confronts them with the difficult and complex decisions required in the professional environment. It also gives them the opportunity to work through practical problems. This course allows students to develop a systematic approach to information gathering that reflects their own style and interests. They must meet tight deadlines, confront ethical uncertainties and work across a range of fields. At the same time they must reflect on the role of their profession within a wider society. Prerequisites: 2505LHS Ethical Communication; or 2511LHS / 2511HUM News Writing & Ethics; or 2501LHS / 2501HUM Public Relations Theory, Ethics and Professional Practice; or CJR220 News and Information Gathering (OUA). Co-requisites: NIL. Incompatible: NIL.
Subject_Description_29: This course provides an overview of legal constraints on public communication, along with an outline of law as it impacts on the Australian media and social media environment. Topics include free expression, open justice, defamation, contempt of court, publication restrictions, privacy, confidentiality, defamation, hate speech, national security laws and copyright within the context of an information society. It also addresses some key communication business laws affecting freelancers, public relations practitioners and new media entrepreneurs. INCOMPATIBLE: 2513HUM / 2513ART / 2012AMC Media Law; 4080LAW Media Law and Regulation; CMM26 Media Law (OUA Course Equivalent).

Description: The Bachelor of Communications (Honours) program is designed as an 'end-on' fourth year from corresponding undergraduate degrees in Communications. This Honours program qualifies students to apply skills and knowledge in their discipline and prepare them to undertake highly skilled professional work and/or advanced study. The degree will require students to plan and execute a research dissertation or a creative/professional product with minor dissertation/exegesis under the supervision of an appropriate academic supervisor as a pathway for further learning. The Bachelor of Communication (Honours) degree will  consist of 80 credit points of assessed student work. This will include 40 credit points of coursework and 40 credit points of supervised research leading to the completion of a written dissertation, or to the completion of a creative or professional product with minor dissertation/exegesis. Students will be instructed in key research  principles and methodologies in Communications.

Computer Science is a dynamic and developing field that is increasingly pervading every aspect of society. In this program you will learn the fundamental principles underpinning computer science and learn practical software technology development skills for many different platforms and applications. You will have the choice of studying topics such as Programming Languages, Distributed Computing, Computer Architectures, Algorithms and Operating Systems, Machine Learning, Intelligent Systems, Robotics, Programming for Web, Mobile and Embedded Applications, Scientific Computing, Visualisation and Big Data Mining, and Analytics. You can choose between one of two majors and also select from a range of elective courses. In the last year of your studies, you will complete a practical project for industry or research placement providing first-hand experience of the knowledge, skills and attributes required to succeed in full-time employment.
Career_Outcomes: This program prepares students for careers as a software developer, computer programmer, web and mobile applications developer, data scientist, systems analyst, computer games programmer, software systems architect and computer scientist.
Subject_Description_1: The course revises and extends basic integral and differential calculus of one variable and introduces differential equations. It provides a foundation in the mathematical sciences needed for later studies both in an engineering and science context. This course is for Engineering or ICT students ONLY. Incompatible: 1202SCG Calculus I
Subject_Description_2: This course introduces students to a number of key elements in software development processes including scripting languages, software project management and the design processes for data schemas and user interfaces. These processes are presented in the context of the relevant background theories of each area, and applied by students to a range of relevant tasks. Software project management processes provide systematic approaches to measuring and managing software development tasks. Similarly User interface design processes ensure effective, and usable interfaces. Likewise entity relationship modelling permits efficient and data storage that is accessible and manageable. The concepts taught will be practiced through the creation of databases and user interfaces along with the use of scripting languages, DBMSs and SQL. Pre-requisite: 1806ICT Programming Fundamentals. For students in the Bachelor of Engineering (Honours)/Bachelor of Computer Science: 1305ENG Engineering Programming is the listed pre-requisite. Incompatible: 1810ICT Software Development Processes, 2810ICT Software Technologies
Subject_Description_3: The course introduces basic vector algebra in two and three dimensions, matrices, complex numbers, probability and revises basic functions. It provides a foundation in the mathematical sciences for later studies in science and engineering. Prior Assumed Knowledge: It will be assumed that students have the knowledge equivalent to a grade of SA over 4 semesters in Mathematics B (Qld high school subject), or equivalent study over 4 semesters of a high school subject that includes the study of differential and integral calculus or 1017SCG">1017SCG Foundation Mathematics (grade of 4 or higher). For students who do not have this level of mathematics background, it is strongly suggested that they first complete 1017SCG">1017SCG Foundation Mathematics. Incompatible: 1201SCG Linear Algebra, 1011SCG Mathematics 1A, 1201BPS Mathematics 1A, 1666NSC Mathematics 1A for Engineers.
Subject_Description_4: Discrete structures are foundational in that many areas of computer science require the ability to work with concepts from discrete structures and it is pervasive in the areas of data structures and algorithms. Discrete structures includes important material from such areas as set theory, relations, functions, logic, proof techniques, basic counting graph theory, automata and discrete probability theory. Incompatible: 2804ICT: Discrete Structures
Subject_Description_5: Foundation Mathematics aims to provide a solid basis from which to build a wider set of mathematical skills across a broad range of disciplines. You may be looking to further studies in Education, IT, Business, Engineering, or any of the Physical or Social Sciences; all of which require a solid grounding in mathematics. The course has been constructed to cater for those who either did not study and pass Mathematical Methods (or Qld Maths B) in Year 11/12, OR have been away from study for some years and wish to refresh the mathematical skills required for further study. Successfully completing this course will satisfy all courses that have Mathematical Methods (or Qld Maths B) as a prerequisite, such as Linear Algebra and Calculus I. Foundation Mathematics covers the following topics. Working with Numbers, Algebraic methods, Solving equations, Understanding Functions, and both Differential and Integral Calculus. Mathematical thinking, as well as problem solving and reasoning, are developed throughout the course. Assumed Background: Basic mathematical skills to Year 10 level. Any Senior School Mathematics course would be an advantage but not necessary. Note that Foundation Mathematics is not permitted for students who have HA or VHA in Year 12 Mathematics B (Qld high school subject), or SA or higher in Year 12 Mathematics C (Qld High school subject), or the equivalent.
Subject_Description_6: This is a foundational course that covers all the fundamental programming concepts of data structures, algorithmic processes and IO. Also developed are the skills, independent of the underlying paradigms which are essential to becoming a proficient programmer. A widely deployed programming language is used. A Co-requisite of 1010ENG Engineering Mathematics or 1017SCG Foundation Mathematics applies to students that have not obtained a grade of SA over 4 semesters in Mathematics B (Qld high school subject) in place of the first year listed elective.
Subject_Description_7: This course provides an introduction to the basic concepts and practices of data analysis and inferential statistics. It will provide and understanding of several techniques including testing one or more means from sampled populations (t-Tests and ANOVAs), relationships between scale variables (correlations and regressions), and contingency table analysis (Chi-square tests). The course places emphasis on understanding the use of appropriate data for these tests, the use of exploratory data analysis and the underlying distributions and assumptions associated with these tests. Students will learn how to carry out these tests by hand, via the use of statistical software (SAS or SPSS), check assumptions, interpret results and report findings in plain English. Assumed prior knowledge: Grade 12 Maths A or B or equivalent. Incompatible: 1003ENV Statistics, 2012MSC Biostatistics, 2012HSC, Intro to Biomedical Data Analysis, Bioinformatics, 1003PSY Research Methods and Statistics in Psychology, 1002MSC Introduction to Biomedical Data Analysis
Subject_Description_8: The real-world performance of any software system depends on the algorithms used and the efficiency of their implementation. The ability to select algorithms appropriate to solving particular problems, based on understanding the range of algorithms that address well-defined problems, analyzing their complexity and performance, and their suitability in particular contexts and implementing them is critical for building effective software. A number of general algorithmic strategies are presented including brute force, heuristics, greedy, recursive backtracking and divide and conquer. Common algorithms pertaining to searching, sorting, binary trees, graphs, and string / expression parsing are also discussed. Also both in-memory and file data structures and their interrelationship with specific algorithms are reviewed. Pre-requisites: 1801ICT">1801ICT Object-Oriented Programming (this course was previously named 1801ICT">1801ICT Programming Languages) and 1020ENG Engineering Mathematics 2.
Subject_Description_9: The theory of computation is the core area of computer science that attempts to achieve deep understanding of computational processes by means of mathematical models, tools, and techniques. It is important for algorithm, compiler and VLSI design, the creation of intelligent systems, and cognitive psychology. This course aims to provide generic skills and concept tools that practitioners use in computer engineering. For instance, grammars studied in this course are useful in dealing with strong searching and pattern matching. Studying this course significantly helps in training generic abilities to think and to solve computational problems. The course will cover a selection of the following topics: 1. Finitestate machines, regular languages 2. Turing machines and computational complexity 3. Recursive functions and Lambda calculus 4. Cellular automata 5. Quantum computation and its applications 5. Context free languages 6. Number theory 7. Information and coding theory 8. Cryptographic algorithms Pre-requisite: 1808ICT Discrete Structures Incompatible: N/A
Subject_Description_10: Programming is a foundational skill for all computing disciplines. This course develops skills and concepts that are essential to good programming practice and problem solving. It covers fundamental programming concepts, event-driven programming, object-oriented programming, basic data structures, and algorithmic processes. Incompatible: 2807ICT Programming Principles
Subject_Description_11: Software engineering applies to small, medium, and large-scale systems. It encompasses all phases of the life cycle of a software system including requirements analysis and specification, design, construction, testing, deployment, and operation, software project management and maintenance. This course aims to provide students with a solid software engineering foundation to support their further study. It focuses on providing introductory material to modelling, requirements engineering, testing and validation as well as formal methods. The course is incompatible with 1809ICT">1809ICT since 1809ICT">1809ICT has overlapping learning outcomes. Prerequisites: 1811ICT or 1806ICT or 1305ICT
Subject_Description_12: This course explores the major ethical, professional, social and legal issues arising from the widespread use of IT, highlighting dilemmas that may be faced by IT practitioners. The subject examines the key debates and controversies pertinent to IT and their social consequences through the use of key case studies. *This course replaces 2003ICT Professional Issues in IT. Prerequisite: Successful completion of 120CP of first or second year Information Technology /Multimedia courses
Subject_Description_13: This course introduces the underlying architecture and principles of modern computer hardware, software and networks that is the foundation of modern Computer Science. The course provides students with the basic knowledge of how the components that define a computer work together and by extension an appreciation of the capabilities and limitations of computer systems. This knowledge assists students in the application of computing technologies to solve real world problems and builds a foundation for further study in the field of computer science. Incompatible: 1007ICT Computer Systems and Networks.
Subject_Description_14: This course is conducted with students participating in a Project-based engagement with industry. Projects are sourced from a range of industry and university partners that require significant analysis, design, development, communication and documentation effort. The problem is addressed by a number of students working in a team within the Agile lifecycle. Significant importance is placed on effective project management and excellent communication strategies between team members, the project manager, and with the industry client. Students work in close liaison with their external client and academic supervisor throughout the project and are expected to demonstrate a good understanding of their project. Prerequisites: 160CP of coursework, with a minimum of 60CP from second or third year courses. 3820ICT">3820ICT_P2 is a continuation of 3820ICT">3820ICT_P1
Subject_Description_15: This course is conducted with students participating in a Project-based engagement with industry. Projects are sourced from a range of industry and university partners that require significant analysis, design, development, communication and documentation effort. The problem is addressed by a number of students working in a team within the Agile lifecycle. Significant importance is placed on effective project management and excellent communication strategies between team members, the project manager, and with the industry client. Students work in close liaison with their external client and academic supervisor throughout the project and are expected to demonstrate a good understanding of their project. Prerequisites: 160CP of coursework, with a minimum of 60CP from second or third year courses.
Subject_Description_16: This course is conducted with students participating in a project-based engagement with industry: projects are sought from a range of industry and university partners (project sponsors) that require significant development, communication and documentation effort. The problem is addressed by a number of students working in a group to form a student project team. Significant importance is placed on effective project management and excellent communication strategies between team members, the project manager, and with the industry client. Within this strand, students may undertake different "tracks" depending on the development lifecycle model appropriate to the project. Students work in close liaison with their external client and academic supervisor throughout the project and are expected to demonstrate a good understanding of their project. Students should be in the final year of study, having completed of 80CP of first year level subjects and 80CP of second year level subjects which define the program. Pre-requisite: Must have completed 160CP
Subject_Description_17: In this course, students conduct an industry-based placement within a commercial or industrial environment under professional supervision while managing their learning and course assessment. The placement provides students with the opportunity to undertake a substantial body of work that has an industry application. This body of work will be focused on the student's academic degree and major, and may be project based working on a single implementation, or task based supporting the industry partner. Students work in close liaison with their industry supervisor and academic supervisor throughout the placement and are expected to demonstrate a good understanding of their work. To be eligible for placement, students must have completed the online registration form in the trimester prior to enrolment: https://bblearn.griffith.edu.au/webapps/blackboard/content/listContent.jsp?course_id=_66918_1&content_id=_4338944_1. Students must complete all requirements of the Griffith Sciences WIL office in preparation for placement, including confirmed allocation to an industry placement. Prerequisites: Students should be in the final year of study, having completed 80CP of first year level subjects and 80CP of second year level subjects which define the program and have a cumulative GPA of 5.0.

Description: The program aims to bring students to a level of maturity in their understanding and practice of scholarly work within the Computer Science discipline as well as providing training in the techniques, skills and theoretical background necessary for subsequent postgraduate research.
Career_Outcomes: This program prepares students for careers as a software developer, computer programmer, web and mobile applications developer, data scientist, systems analyst, computer games programmer, software systems architect and computer scientist.

Description: In this degree, you will learn about construction and building practices, developing a rigorous understanding of construction law and ethics, business management, construction economics, and property development in a global context. On commencing your degree, you will be introduced to the principles of built environment, learning the fundamentals of construction sustainability, project development, construction materials and site operations. From your third year, you will undertake in-depth study of core construction business areas including estimating, tendering, planning and procurement, with a strong focus on ICT applications in the built environment. In your final year, you will grow your professional skills through an industry placement.
Career_Outcomes: As a graduate, you will be prepared for a rewarding career as a construction professional. Your industry knowledge combined with strong skills in problem-solving, decision-making, communication and technology will prepare you for leadership roles across the full spectrum of construction projects. Career opportunities for construction managers are expected to grow over the next few years. You will find employment opportunities in roles such as:
Subject_Description_1: The course provides opportunities to develop technical, professional, legal and managerial competencies to survey property, diagnose defects, design and alter premises, manage contracts and provide professional advice to clients. Particular emphasis will be placed on compliance with the regulatory requirements of refurbishment and new build projects.
Subject_Description_2: This lecture-based course develops building construction, materials and practices introduced in 2914ENV">2914ENV Construction Materials and Practice, and aspects of sustainable architecture introduced in 2904ENV Principles of Sustainable Design. Lectures will address methods of achieving building environmental conditions and the services systems required. Medium-scale building construction will also be addressed. Knowledge from this course will be integrated into studio course 3902ENV. This course is only open to students enrolled in 1492 and 1598. Prerequisite for this course is 2914ENV">2914ENV.
Subject_Description_3: This course introduces and applies Information Communication Technologies (ICT) and Building Information Modelling (BIM) in the construction management discipline. The course offers knowledge and skills essential for successful adoption of ICT and BIM in construction planning, construction cost management, design coordination and modelling. ICT and BIM competencies are becoming core requirements for design and construction professionals; this course covers the challenges and case studies of the adoption of ICT and BIM in the construction industry.
Subject_Description_4: As an engineer you will be faced with problems that require you to devise innovative and practical solutions. Some problems may be simple and you will solve them drawing on knowledge you acquired through your course of study or using your accumulated experiences. On the other hand, there will be cases where your experience and academic training are not sufficient. In these cases, you will need to engage in research. Being able to source valid and credible information and analyse information statistically in order to formulate viable solutions is an important skill that all engineers need and which Engineers Australia expects you to have. The research and statistics skills you learn in this course will also help you throughout your studies at Griffith University. Research is a key component in Undergraduate degrees at Griffith University. Moreover, the skills learnt in this course are of vital importance to students who intend to pursue higher degree research studies. Therefore, this course aims to equip you with the skills needed to conduct valid research and statistical analysis be it in academic or industrial practice context.
Subject_Description_5: All construction projects have the common feature of utilising engineering principles, people, machines and materials as well as requiring organisation and planning. This course covers the range of construction equipment and techniques in common use and the planning and direction of construction works. Attention is also given to rock and bulk excavations, health and safety at work sites, preliminary works, formwork design and an introduction to engineering economics. Assessment is by assignments and examinations. Incompatible: 2104ENG Construction Engineering
Subject_Description_6: The course introduces students to the principles of law, contract administration and dispute resolution in the construction industry. The course content comprises a range of issues and claims arising in construction process. In particular, the students will develop an understanding of certain general conditions of contract; the relevance of legal concepts including unjust enrichment, frustration, waiver, estoppel, and specific performance; gain knowledge of alternative dispute resolution methods; and become familiar with the Building and Construction Industry Security of Payment Act.
Subject_Description_7: This course provides construction business management skills which help produce a generation of business leaders in construction. The perspective of all parties, including national and international construction companies, major contractors, house builders, construction clients and government agencies, manufacturers, consultants and others, is considered. Topics include fundamentals of construction industry operations, leadership, persons in organizations, financial analysis and control systems, and innovation in construction. Prerequisite for this course is 1606ENG Construction Economics
Subject_Description_8: This course covers the principles and rules of building measurement using the Australian Standard Method of Measurement of Building Works, and applies them to the measurement of detailed construction works examples. Alternative approaches to measurement for detailed builder's quantities and estimates are demonstrated.
Subject_Description_9: This course is a Computer Aided Drafting Course, using Autodesk Revit software. Students will be taught fundamental industrial computer generated drawing skills, techniques in conceptualising, 3D modelling, appropriate terminology, construction methods, and presentation layout skills. The Outcomes of this course require students to have a thorough critical understanding of the environmental impact of structural design. Critical analysis will be developed through evaluation of the relationship between architect and designer There will be five in class, assessment exercises and one major assignment that is divided into two parts.
Subject_or_Unit_10: REAL ESTATE AND PROPERTY DEVELOPMENT PRINCIPLES
Subject_Description_10: As the largest industry in Australia, generating more economic activity than any other sector, and creating approximately 25% of all employment the property industry creates prosperity, jobs and strong communities. This course presents property principles for students entering the real estate and property development sectors. This course is offered: Gold Coast: Trimester 1 Day Nathan: Trimester 1 Day Incompatible: 1208HSL Intro to Real Estate & Property Development, AND 2009HSL Real Estate and Property Development Principles.
Subject_Description_11: This course is designed to teach and familiarise students with construction contracts and construction law; liabilities and responsibilities of all parties to a Contract, compiling and submitting proper extras and claims, and ways and means for construction managers to avoid conflict with contracts, owners, trades, and labour.
Subject_Description_12: This course will introduce students to the processes and procedures of cost planning as a cost control tool in the pre-construction process. They will examine the impact of design on the capital and life cycle cost of buildings, and develop their understanding of concepts such as value engineering and management. This course will foster their appreciation of bidding strategies and build their understanding of the relationship and differences between the cost planning and tendering processes.
Subject_Description_13: The course develops students' knowledge, skills and application for buildings classification under the building code of Australia (BCA). The course provides students with an overview of regulations and construction techniques on the low-rise residential buildings in Australia. The course covers construction processes including building regulations; environmental issue, footing systems, flooring and timber, wall framing and roof designing systems, waterproofing and first fix and fit-out. Students will be taught how to read plans and build a house by studying construction theory and legislation, visiting building sites and sketching construction details.
Subject_Description_14: This course is designed to equip you with project management skills and particularly emphasised on construction site management and the management of design and development of infrastructure/building projects. Management aspects on project planning, risk and environmental impact assessment, cost and cash flow management, and progress progress management throughout the life cycle of projects, from project development state through delivery, commissioning and operation, are taught in this course. Attention is also given to modern management topics such as benchmarking, life-cycle costing, value analysis and concurrent engineering. Your ability and proficiency will be assessed through assignments and written examinations.
Subject_Description_15: The course introduces structural concepts to architect students. The behaviour of structures will be covered to give the future architect an overall understanding of structural engineering. Fundamental structural mechanics concepts and structural design principles will be covered in some detail. Topics taught include equilibrium, internal forces, stress, structural elements and systems, design loads, load transfer, buildings... The course is taught as a series of weekly lectures and tutorials, supported by laboratory experiments.
Subject_Description_16: This course introduces students to the concept of environmental sustainability and its uses in solving real world problems. It explores the relationships between the natural, rural, industrial and urban environments and includes the study of the impact humans have upon nature. The course also considers the way environmental sustainability can be used to address environmental, economic and social issues in an integrated way. Assessment includes on-line tests, a written assignment, workshop exercises and an end of trimester examination. Incompatible: 1301ENV The Global Environment, 1181ENV Sustainable Development, 1161ENV Environmental Economics and Policy.
Subject_Description_17: In this course students will learn about new technologies to improve building performance, about building and site services, facilities management, and green retrofits. The subject covers building pathology from defect recognition and diagnosis to remedial works. The focus is on the project and building scale. The latest innovations and emerging technologies are also highlighted.
Subject_Description_18: This course is to equip students with the skills and knowledge to procure, establish and manage all resources and services required for efficiently and safely operating a construction site. The students will gain a practical understanding of the site establishment and organise personnel, site accommodation and amenities, material coordination and managing plant and equipment. The course content ensures students learning capacity to evaluate work health and safety principles, procedures and legislative and regulatory requirements applicable to construction sites. Prerequisite for this course is 1604ENG Construction Communication. Note: 1492 Bachelor of Architectural Design students are exempt from this prerequisite.
Subject_Description_19: This course aims to offer students the opportunity to develop an understanding of the fundamentals of construction cost estimating. Students will engage with pre-tender and tender estimating practices, the use of estimating software, and tender pricing and strategies in the construction industry.
Subject_Description_20: This course provides engineering and architecture students with an overview of the principles, skills and techniques required for the evaluation, planning, and management of projects from inception through to completion.
Subject_Description_21: The course introduces students to procurement methods and the practice of construction contract management. Students will learn about: (a) different options for project delivery and the options for contract price; (b) the common matters covered in the general conditions of a major construction contract, including (but not limited to) practical completion, extension of time, liquidated damages, latent conditions, delay costs, bonus and variation clauses; (c) the relevance of legal concepts, including unjust enrichment, frustration, waiver, estoppel, and specific performance to contract administration; (d) alternative dispute resolution methods; and (e) the purpose and application of security of payment legislation for the construction industry.
Subject_Description_22: Understanding Australian Cities is an introductory overview of the origin, patterning and functioning of the urban system. The course specifically examines the dynamics of population, infrastructure, governance and culture in Australian cities. These understandings frame examination of the possibilities of planning intervention. This introductory course will allow students to better appreciate the range of planning challenges and the opportunities for further study. This course is delivered via weekly lectures and tutorials and is supplemented with web materials and readings.
Subject_Description_23: The course introduces students to written and geometric communications used in building design and construction. It includes: Introduction to personal, project and practice communication. Detailing domestic building elements and components including foundations, footings, floors, walls, roofs and finishing trades. Preparation and use of the lifetime specification. Using engineering and surveying documentation.
Subject_Description_24: This course prepares the students for a professional life in which they will inevitably discuss issues relating to the economics of built facilities. The course discusses three key aspects: the economics of building designs, project feasibility appraisals, and the economics of the construction and property industry. The skills and expertise acquired in this course are vitally important for working in the construction and property industry.
Subject_Description_25: The capstone engineering project is undertaken in the final year of the program. Students are required to plan, execute and report on a research project with some independence while working with an academic supervisor who maintains regular contact and provides support and direction in the design and execution of the research. Projects based on industry requirements will be encouraged.
Subject_Description_26: This course provides students with critical knowledge in 'Digital Earth', and experiences in applying core digital and spatial knowledge and skills from design through to project management. Students will use a range of industry-relevant software to conceptualise, design and visualise linear and vertical asset solutions such as rail, roads and buildings. Students will also gain an appreciation of the importance of geospatial technology and geo-tagged data to assist in problem-solving, particularly in the context of reducing the consumption of natural resources and associated greenhouse gas emissions. This course is run in collaboration with Bentley as the software provider, and Chubu University (Japan) as a member of the International Society of Digital Earth.
Subject_Description_27: The course is an introduction to construction materials and techniques and contemporary issues in construction design and detailing. The main aim is to help students understand the importance and fundamentals of key construction materials, their basic properties, characteristics and performance, and how they are combined to create simple buildings

Description: Graduates will gain skills in providing professional counselling to assist others in resolving personal or professional problems. Working in the counselling profession involves guiding and empowering people to develop self-understanding and to make changes in their lives in order to accomplish mental health, wellness, education, and career goals. They assist people by offering them a structured and focused way of addressing their problems, and work with clients on developing strategies to overcome obstacles and personal challenges that they are facing.
Career_Outcomes: Graduates will be skilled in a range of counselling approaches with their clients and can develop careers in specific areas, including family and relationship counselling, career counselling, and telephone/internet counselling, correctional counselling, addiction counselling, domestic violence counselling, and student advising.
Subject_Description_1: This course prepares graduates across health professions to provide culturally safe health services to Australia's First Peoples. Through the enhancement of the previously introduced capabilities of respect, communication, safety and quality, critical reflection, and advocacy students will be supported to apply these capabilities in First Peoples' health contexts to engender the development of cultural capabilities that reflect a lifelong journey and are tested in every interaction. The course takes a holistic perspective to engage students in exploring the historical, socio-cultural, political and dominant cultural paradigms that influence First Peoples' health today.
