Pre-requisite: Students must have successfully completed 3035DOH">3035DOH_Y1 in the current year to progress to 3035DOH">3035DOH_Y2.
Subject_Description_14: Advanced Dental Hygiene Practice provides opportunity for students to work in collaboration in periodontology, dental implants and orthodontics. Students will participate in oral health promotion activities in the community. Pre-requisite: All year 2 courses must have been successfully completed prior to proceeding to year 3 courses.
Subject_Description_15: Health Care Systems is designed to give the student a deeper understanding of key concepts in how health systems are funded, operated and evaluated. The course will introduce the student to concepts such as social determinants of health; how health care decisions are evaluated; health reform; disadvantaged groups and health; and assessing quality of health services. The course will explore the Australian health care system in detail and compare it to other health care systems in developed and developing countries.
Subject_Description_16: This is an introductory pharmacology course on the basic principles influencing drug action in the human body. The content delivered in this course has specific relevance to drugs associated with dental care. Students are only permitted to enrol in this course in the specified year of their program structure.

Description: International students must be in Australia and able to attend campus to commence this program. This GRADUATE ENTRY program will be offered from 2021. This degree is designed for someone who has a  recognised Dental Technology Bachelor degree who is ready to upgrade their  qualification.to work directly with patients. It will suit someone  interested in working as an independent clinician to diagnose, design,  manufacture and fit removable dentures. Graduates from the Bachelor of  Oral Health in Dental Technology/Bachelor of Dental Technology at Griffith  University should apply for this degree to gain a Dental Prosthetist  qualification and will receive advanced standing towards the program. Through coursework and supervised clinical  practice, Dental Prosthetists are educated in all facets of removable dental  prosthetics in an inter-professional setting, learning and working alongside other dental and health care professionals. This degree is not suited to applicants pursuing a  Dentistry qualification and is not open to applicants holding a dentistry qualification. A number of key benefits set Griffith's Dental  Prosthetist education apart from other teaching institutions. Students develop  advanced critical analytical skills to solve difficult technical and clinical  situations. They learn in an inter-professional environment from experienced dental  prosthetists and specialists in their field such as: Dental Prosthetic students practice alongside  Dentistry students to develop communication and collaboration skills in  individual cases. Whether this is inserting and monitoring immediate dentures  or witnessing a variety of complex dental procedures. This process is managed  through the Team Based Treatment Planning Process which develops patient  referral skills.
Career_Outcomes:
With this qualification, graduates will find employment  opportunities in the public and private health sectors through government  health department clinics and private practice as a Dental Prosthetist or  Clinical Dental Technician. Prosthodontic Technician and Clinician  (Removable Prosthodontics)
  Dental Prosthetists work directly with patients to provide removable partial  dentures and the prosthodontic technician designs and fabricates the full and  partial dentures in plastic or alloy. Graduates will be well equipped for  the variety of procedures and techniques to replace missing teeth and will work  alongside Dentists and Prosthodontists. Self-employment
  Graduates will gain an understanding of the operational issues involved in  establishing a new business. Graduates may own and operate a dental laboratory  or clinic. Graduates can progress onto employment in management roles such as  senior or chief technician or prosthetists positions; quality control  technicians/prosthetist; teaching or dental sales. Research opportunities
  Graduates can apply to progress their research skills through an Honours,  Masters or PhD qualification which may lead to various roles in academia,  large-scale organisations (corporations/companies, government departments,  non-profit/charity organisation). International opportunities
  Graduates will be equipped to apply for dental technician registration in other  countries. They will have gained the necessary knowledge and skills to adapt to  the examination process required for registration.

Description: International students must be in Australia and able to attend campus to commence this program. This degree is ideal for students who like to work behind the scenes  creating and manufacturing dentures, crowns, bridges and orthodontic appliances  but not fitting the final denture or appliance to the patient.  It suits students who like working with their  hands, can pay attention to detail and prefer not to work directly with the  patient. Dental Technologists  (or Dental Technicians as they are often referred to) are highly skilled  members of the dental team. They combine art and science skills to construct  custom-made dental devices to replace, restore and correct defects that may  affect our facial appearance and the ability to use our teeth properly. As an undergraduate  student, you will learn and work alongside Dentistry students in our state of  the art dental clinics and laboratories located in the same building. Our  students enjoy working with industry-standard equipment including CAD-CAM (Computer Aided Design/Manufacturing) facilities. You will also expand  your hands-on experience working with registered and experienced Dental Technicians  in our commercial laboratory and through professional practice placements. Honours is available through an additional year of study.
Career_Outcomes:
As a Dental Technologist  (or Dental Technician as they are often referred to) you  will find employment with Dental Technicians, Dentists, Dental Prosthetists,  Prosthodontists, Orthodontists, Periodontists, and Oral Surgeons in the public or  private health sectors. Working to referring dental practitioners and  specialists prescriptions. You will be able to  design and construct appliances according to international standards that meet  individual patients needs. You will work  with a wide range of materials and techniques such as:  gold, porcelain, plastic and lost wax technique and CAD-CAM (Computer Aided  Design/Manufacturing). You may see patients to record the colour, shape and  characteristics of existing teeth. With this qualification,  you can apply your scientific knowledge, artistic skills and  compassionate nature across three distinct specialist areas - Prosthodontic,  Conservative and Orthodontic - or you may eventually choose self-employment. Graduates will be well  equipped to sit for a 'skills exam' requested by employers. Prosthodontic Technician  (Removable Prosthodontics)
Prosthodontic  technicians design and make full and partial dentures in plastics or alloy.  Graduates will be well equipped for the variety of procedures and techniques to  replace missing teeth and will work  alongside  dentists, dental prosthetists and prosthodontists. Self-Employment 
  Graduates will gain an  understanding of the operational issues involved in establishing a new  business. Graduates may own and operate a dental laboratory. Graduates can progress onto  employment in management roles such as senior or chief technician positions;  quality control technicians; teaching or dental sales. Research  opportunities
  Graduates can apply to  progress their research skills through an Honours, Masters or PhD qualification  which may lead to various roles in academia, large-scale organisations  (Corporations/Companies, Government Departments, Non-Profit/Charity  Organisation). International  opportunities 
  Graduates will be  equipped to apply for dental technicians registration in other countries. They  will have gained the necessary knowledge and skills to adapt to the examination  process required for registration.
Subject_Description_1: This course introduces the student to the practical applications of orthodontic and orthopaedic appliances. It also introduces students to the fundamentals of removable partial acrylic dentures. Students will extend on the foundation skills and knowledge gained in the Laboratory Practicum 1 and Laboratory Materials. This course gives students ample time and opportunity to develop and craft their skills in the manufacture/construction of thermoformed materials, acrylics and the application of metal componentry. Giving the student an opportunity to further develop their level of accuracy and speed using the skills gained in the Laboratory Practicum courses as well as apply knowledge gained in the Prosthetic Technology courses. Students will have an opportunity to begin work integrated learning activities within a commercial laboratory setting at the Griffith University Dental Clinic. Pre-requisite: All year 1 courses must have been successfully completed prior to proceeding to year 2 courses. Co-requisite: 2202DOH and 2204DOH must be studied simultaneously.
Subject_Description_2: This course focuses on fixed prosthodontics and continues the development of the student's practical skills. Previous skills and knowledge gained will be applied in this course. Students will develop the practical skills and competence required to analyse, evaluate and construct fixed prostheses required to restore and or improve the aesthetics, function and phonetics of full and partially dentate patients. Students have the opportunity to further develop their level of accuracy and speed using the skills gained in previous courses, as they will be involved in work integrated learning, providing a wider range of services than previous laboratory practicums, for the Griffith University Dental Clinic. Students will have the opportunity to learn in the team environment. Pre-requisite: All year 2 courses must have been successfully completed prior to proceeding to year 3 courses. Co-requisite: 3031DOH and 3032DOH must be studied simultaneously.
Subject_Description_3: This course introduces the concepts of entrepreneurship and the development of small health business practices. A summary of the essentials for small business success is presented with the necessary activities involved in getting a new business started as a series of stages. The basics of planning and managing the four key resources and areas of activity found in all small enterprises - marketing and sales, finance, operations and human resources - are presented. Finally, management of small business growth and change is explained. Course Restricted: Not available to first year students.
Subject_Description_4: Integration of human body structure (Anatomy) and maintenance of healthy function (Physiology) is fundamental biological knowledge, relevant and applied by many health and allied health professions. This comprehensive introductory course facilitates student exploration of each body system through lectures, laboratory classes and on-line resources. Incompatible: 1016MSC Anatomy and Physiology Systems 1; 1017MSC Anatomy and Physiology Systems 2; 1001NSC Human Pre-requisites: None
Subject_Description_5: This course introduces the practical application of dental technology and its relationship to dentistry and oral health. This course allows students time to develop and craft their skills in the precise technical application of design and construction of removable oral prostheses and appliances. It provides students with the opportunity to develop dexterity, hand-eye coordination and pay attention to details using the skills gained in the Laboratory Materials courses. Students will also have the opportunity to improve their skills within a commercial laboratory setting at the Griffith University Dental Clinic and on work placement. All year 1 courses must be successfully completed prior to proceeding to year 2 courses.
Subject_Description_6: This course provides dental hygiene, technology and prosthetic students with knowledge of anatomy, histology and embryology of the mouth, head and neck region. It covers the macroscopic and microscopic anatomy of the dentition, jaws, oral cavity, salivary glands, tongue and temporomandibular joint. Pre-requisites: 1018DOH Oral Biology 1, 1006MSC Fundamentals of Anatomy and Physiology. All year 1 courses must be successfully completed prior to proceeding to year 2 courses.
Subject_Description_7: This course introduces students to the theories surrounding malocclusions, orthodontics and thermoformed appliances. This course is integral to the function of a dental technologist as the physics of design and function introduced in this course will provide the foundation for Professional Practice course in final year. The design principles learnt in this course will be applied in Laboratory Practicum 2; providing a solid grounding for future commercial practice. Pre-requisite: All year 1 courses must have been successfully completed prior to proceeding to year 2 courses. Co-requisite: 2202DOH and 2204DOH must be studied simultaneously.
Subject_Description_8: Research is fundamental in guiding decisions in professional practice. This course develops students' ability to prepare, conduct and evaluate research related to their practice. The student has the opportunity to pursue a detailed study in a chosen field to enhance the skills and knowledge previously gained throughout the program. Pre-requisite: All year 2 courses must have been successfully completed prior to proceeding to year 3 courses.
Subject_Description_9: Prosthetic Technology 3 further develops students' knowledge in removable prosthodontics. This course is integral to the design, biomechanics and functions of removable partial dentures. The principles of design learned in this course will be applied in Laboratory Practicum 3. Pre-requisite: All year 1 courses must have been successfully completed prior to proceeding to year 2 courses. Co-requisite: 2203DOH and 2205DOH must be studied simultaneously.
Subject_Description_10: This course prepares graduates across health professions to provide culturally safe health services to Australia's First Peoples. Through the enhancement of the previously introduced capabilities of respect, communication, safety and quality, critical reflection, and advocacy students will be supported to apply these capabilities in First Peoples' health contexts to engender the development of cultural capabilities that reflect a lifelong journey and are tested in every interaction. The course takes a holistic perspective to engage students in exploring the historical, socio-cultural, political and dominant cultural paradigms that influence First Peoples' health today. The First Peoples' Health and Practice course supports students to meet the Griffith University Graduate Attribute E.1 Awareness of and respect for the values and knowledge of Australian Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander First Peoples and to meet the requirements of the relevant professional body's competency standards and codes of professional conduct to provide culturally safe care. Pre-requisite: Students must have successfully completed at least 80CP of undergraduate study. This requirement will be strictly enforced.
Subject_Description_11: This course is the practical component of removable partial prosthodontics in which students put into practice knowledge gained in prosthetic technology 3 during the construction of removable partial dentures. This course also gives students an opportunity to improve on the practical skills gained in previous courses. The work integrated learning aspect of the course enables students to develop and utilise skills acquired in a commercial laboratory setting. Pre-requisite: All year 1 courses must have been successfully completed prior to proceeding to year 2 courses. Co-requisite: 2203DOH and 2205DOH must be studied simultaneously.
Subject_Description_12: This course provides students with foundational skills and knowledge of communications theory and practice, including a range of interpersonal, group and mass communication theories as well as a range of written, oral and non-verbal communication skills.
Subject_Description_13: The course aims to provide basic knowledge of tooth structures, characteristic features and anatomical landmarks of both deciduous and permanent dentitions. It also helps them be familiar with nomenclature and structure of tissues they will be operating on later in their academic and professional careers. This course also helps early development of tactile and visual-motor skills. Incompatible: 1007DOH Oral Biology 1 All year 1 courses must be successfully completed prior to proceeding to year 2 courses.
Subject_Description_14: This course focuses on fixed prosthodontics and continues the development of the student's theoretical knowledge from Prosthetic Technology 1, 2 and 3. It develops students' theoretical knowledge they require to construct fixed prostheses required to restore and/or improve the aesthetics and functions of the oral cavity. Pre-requisite: All year 2 courses must have been successfully completed prior to proceeding to year 3 courses. Co-requisite: 3031DOH and 3032DOH must be studied simultaneously.
Subject_Description_15: Language and Communication for Health is offered to students from a non-English speaking background (NESB). Students whose first language is English are NOT PERMITTED to undertake this course. The aim of this course is to introduce students to the language, knowledge and communication skills required for study and practice in their discipline. A further aim is to develop and practice English language skills relevant to the academic culture of Australian universities. It therefore involves intensive English language practice and language immersion activities, with elements applied to contextualised, discipline-specific settings. This course constitutes part of the overall English Language Enhancement Strategy at Griffith University. Prerequisites: NIL; Incompatible: 5901LHS/5901LAL, 5903LHS/5903LAL, 5904LHS/5904LAL and 5902LAL.
Subject_Description_16: This course introduces students to the professional practice of dental technology. Students will study the clinical and technical principles behind the design and fabrication of removable prosthodontics and associated components. It will include theory on occlusion, workplace health and safety, ethics, infection control, care of equipment and efficient use of materials will be included as underlying principles of laboratory practice. All year 1 courses must be successfully completed prior to proceeding to year 2 courses.
Subject_Description_17: Professional Practice provides the students with the opportunity to experience the use of materials and further develop skills required to conduct dental technical procedures. The course is intended to develop an awareness or appreciation of the range of treatment regimes and recognise and, apply design solutions to regain form and function of the oral cavity. Through the development of: knowledge and skills, evaluation of work practices and a critical eye for detail this course provides students with a framework that underpins quality work practices for the graduate Dental Technologist. The course aims to relate to the 'real-life' environment of a dental laboratory. Providing an 'in context' atmosphere requires professional behaviour, critical evaluation of work practices, communication with health professionals and the application of teamwork. Practical artistic skills are developed, improved and built on throughout this course. The course allows students to develop their time management and technical skills, while communicating with clinicians at the same time understanding the financial and operational nature of a dental laboratory. Real life real time learning maximises the learning opportunity to prepare the student beyond graduation. Students will have the opportunity to learn in the team environment. Pre-requisites: All year 2 courses must have been successfully completed prior to proceeding to year 3 courses AND students must have successfully completed all trimester 1 courses prior to enrolling in this course.
Subject_Description_18: This course provides an introduction to dental technology / dental prosthetic students on their chosen profession. An introduction to materials and construction of a variety of stages of dental prosthesis and appliances will be achieved. Students will also be introduced to basic concepts in chemistry to aid their understanding in dental materials. A hands-on approach will be taken with laboratory sessions as well as lectures to provide an understanding and evaluation of how different materials are used. This course provides the basic content of material science principles to the Bachelor of Dental Technology / Bachelor of Dental Prosthetics. The course also provides the foundation and framework to critically analyse materials and make informed choices when designing and constructing dental prostheses and appliances at University and in practice. All year 1 courses must be successfully completed prior to proceeding to year 2 courses.

Description: This program is designed to provide students with an opportunity to undertake advanced study and supervised research work in the specialisation defined by their undergraduate degree program within the context of a multidisciplinary cohort. The research skills developed within this program will provide an attractive credential for students seeking employment in the public or private sectors. The program will also provide the necessary preparation for entry into a higher degree research program. The multidisciplinary context of the program, involving team-teaching of students and the sharing of coursework and seminar experiences across disciplines will be invaluable to students given the importance of a multidisciplinary approach to researchers and practitioners seeking to understand complex problems in health.
Career_Outcomes: Graduates of the program will be able to plan and conduct research in dental technology and related health disciplines and therefore will be well-placed for positions in the private, not for profit and public sectors. In addition, graduates will be eligible to apply for admission to higher degree research programs, thereby preparing them for high level research careers.

Description: This program will not be offered in Trimester 3, 2020. The next intake for commencing students will be Trimester 1, 2021. This program prepares graduates for diverse professional practice as designers through practical and theoretical learning. First year focuses on the development of manual and technological skills, design thinking, problem-defining and solving. Students will gain an understanding of the changing role of design and how they can become leaders in the industry. In the following years students work on industry-related and research projects and specialise in selected studio areas.
Career_Outcomes: You will be prepared for work in Graphic design, Interior design, Product design, Digital web design, Design management, Design education, Film and Television, Theatre, Furniture design, and Digital media.
Subject_Description_1: This course emphasises integrating creative and imaginative applications of the design and communication processes to contemporary interior environment design problems. Wherever possible, industry-based projects are undertaken and students are expected to apply a professional code of ethics to all activities. They are expected to solve complex and demanding problems within fixed deadlines and present work in a professional manner. Assessment is studio-project based. Wherever possible, assessable items are required to comply with the Design Futuring principles and students are encouraged to see design as a profession through broader social, cultural, political, and economic contextualisation.
Subject_Description_2: This course emphasises integrating creative and imaginative applications of design and communication processes to contemporary graphic design problems. Wherever possible, industry-based projects are undertaken and students are expected to apply a professional code of ethics to all activities, to solve complex and demanding problems within fixed deadlines, and present work in a professional manner. Assessment is studio-project based. This course reconceptualises design as a profession through broader social, cultural, political, and economic contextualisation. What is design practice and what kind of practices exist? Students explore the friction between different commercial and social visual communication practice-based cultures with the aim of reforming design practice.
Subject_Description_3: This course concentrates on the graphic aspects of visual communication design to provide an expansive and critical understanding of this discipline and its social context. It includes a number of approaches to visual problem solving that provide both logical as well as intuitive ways of arriving at solutions to design problems. The ability to select appropriate strategies is as important as the ability to apply those strategies. The course continues to embrace sustainable design practice but now begins to go beyond them. Students will further analyse design problems and develop and apply sustainability principles and solutions to communication design projects.
Subject_Description_4: This course expands on the student's understanding of design processes and further explores how people inhabit, interact with and transform interior environments. Systematic approaches to interior design are investigated and applied to a range of design problems requiring interior solutions
Subject_Description_5: Design Lab Practice is a core capstone interdisciplinary course for Bachelor of Design and Bachelor of Interactive Media students. Students undertake design research and practice in a team based interdisciplinary environment and within a critical context of socially engaged and sustainable futures. Through strategic and relational thinking, reflection, creation and writing, students practice proficiency in multiple design processes towards a formal grant style submission of their design ideas. In this, students build graduate work-readiness through learning real-world project operational systems.
Subject_Description_6: The purpose of this course is to prepare students for employment by introducing them to the role of effective interpersonal communication, business communication, management, business principles, ethics, and professional association within contemporary contexts. This course explores the major professional issues arising from the widespread use of digital media and highlights dilemmas that may be faced by creative media practitioners. By providing the fundamentals of professionalism, this course aims to make students 'job ready'.
Subject_Description_7: Digital Designer Maker: Designing for local studio batch production using digital fabrication to increase design opportunities and efficiencies allows designers to explore creating objects that have valued connections to people, communities and place. This timber-based unit considers the environmental and social impact of technology in design, both positive and negative, in the local context. Connection to community, changing production patterns, re-localisation of production, distributed manufacturing, embodied energy, renewable materials, and value-adding processes are fundamental to the course. Local studio designer makers are involved in the course and students are expected to have practical invested design outcomes, such as digitally fabricated furniture.
Subject_Description_8: Theory, research methods and design practice will integrate together as solution focused 'praxis' in this capstone course. Students will combine their discipline specific technical and procedural skills with a range of design research methods and procedures, to ideate, plan design, project manage and produce a creative, human focused solution to a specified problem. Students can choose to work independently or in a team. However, each student will be assessed individually. It is expected that the design outcomes will represent each student's potential as an emerging design professional. Pre requisites: Must have completed all 1st year and 2nd year courses.
Subject_Description_9: This course extends on industry standard design and parametric solid modelling techniques with a focus on ergonomics and user centred design outcomes. Students develop competencies in complex part, assembly and drawing development including physical dynamics, surfacing, performance enhanced component assembly, applied problem solving with geometric & mathematical dimension relationships, detailed drawing and file management to prepare you for an international working environment. Pre-requisite: 2639QCA - Digital Modelling for Design
Subject_Description_10: Through the exploration of space, and its design and impact on human interaction, human response and reaction to space, students will apply the principles of design for interior and environmental spaces and develop design communication techniques such as rapid visualisation, drafting, presentation skills and model making. Students will explore the field through theories of interaction which inform practice, studio practice and workshops modelling working in multi-disciplinary companies in fields such as design and construction, retail, games and virtual environments, stage, theatre and exhibitions.
Subject_Description_11: This course will explore some of the methods, principles, processes and theories that makes design a special form of human inquiry. From analysis to synthesis, students will apply their understanding of 2 and 3 dimensional space through a series of linked, practical exercises, active visual experimentation and resolved production. Through 'praxis', i.e. the convergence of theory and practice, students will apply their understanding of design to real outcomes.
Subject_Description_12: This course introduces fundamental precepts of communicating ideas and information around the delivery of products and services (branding) and investigate how visual communication and brand identity can be used as a form of social critique. Systematic approaches are investigated and applied to a range of design problems and students are encouraged to work towards developing their own ethical framework within a global brand design context. The course will introduce students to the concept of developing their own brand strategy and a solution-driven procedure is adopted in which problem-solving is a means by which learning takes place and design processes are developed.
Subject_Description_13: This course explores the power of motion, in the form of animation in three-dimensional spatial environments, as a tool in presenting both information and narrative for human viewers. The principals of the human sensory system are covered to gain an understanding of how movement, and animation, can be used to enhance the ability to convey knowledge, immersion and understanding to the viewer. Students will gain both a theoretical understanding of the history, principals, mechanics and human interpretation of motion & animation, and will also gain practical skills in the production and presentation of 3D animated content.
Subject_Description_14: This course introduces fundamental precepts of communicating ideas and information, such as grid systems, semiotic analysis and visual hierarchy, as well as typographic knowledge and skills within wider social and cultural contexts. Students are expected to respond through research-based creative studio activity in a timely and professional way and at a level which shows a sophistication of type handling. The course will develop a social and historical framework of typography through Roman lettering, the introduction of moveable type, and the subsequent history of printing.
Subject_Description_15: This first-year course critically examines design history and theory. Design history, in its traditional form, focuses on design movements, designers and the materiality of the design object and the ways in which it connects to production and consumption, integrated into circulated systems of meaning. The course distinguishes between the concepts and historical figures of the past to frame and inform the key themes influencing art and design theory, practice and culture today and in the future. The relation between design and its place in history, why the designer needs such knowledge and how they need to employ it in future practice will be examined.
Subject_Description_16: This course addresses the diverse and rapidly evolving nature of lens-based digital imagery as a discipline. As an introduction to these processes, both existing and emerging, the course is designed to develop, support and enhance creative practice. Conceptual sophistication and technical aptitude in this area are highly valuable qualities in terms of the potential that they afford us in the creation, documentation and dissemination of visual ideas.
Subject_Description_17: This course concentrates on communication design issues relating to interior environments to provide an expansive and critical understanding. This includes a number of approaches to space problem-solving that provide both logical as well as intuitive ways of arriving at solutions to design problems. The ability to select appropriate strategies is as important as the ability to apply those strategies. An essential and deeper knowledge of techniques and process associated with the production of space is taught. The course continues to embrace sustainable design practices but also goes beyond them. Students will further analyse design problems and develop and apply sustainability principles and solutions to interior environment design projects.
Subject_Description_18: This course introduces designing for 3D printing. This practical course introduces students to key stages of the design development process and human centred design strategies, identifying user behaviours and needs in the development of niche products. Fundamental skills are developed in the design and preparation of digital files, to create resolved 3D printed prototypes.
Subject_Description_19: This course critiques current construction methods, processes, and material use in commercial and residential construction through the design and construction. You will critically analyse and compare cases and redesign to meet green-star rated sustainable practices. Industry professionals will introduce building/interior construction methods and technical criteria for selection and specification of fixtures and finishes.
Subject_Description_20: Visual communication is a powerful force to drive new ideas, and obtaining access to the tools that 'make media' is an integral part of a perpetually changing world. It has the power to influence society (think: body image, sexualised imagery, consumerism) and environment (think: greenwashing, property development, transport industries) and culture (think: political campaigns, volunteerism, social media).
Subject_Description_21: Whilst 3D designers are focused on object outcomes, good design is situational. This course introduces the student to more complex problems, such as design meets disability, or large scale projects where outcomes may require design research, design process and practice with a transdisciplinary approach.
Subject_Description_22: This is an intermediate course that gives students a firm basis for refining their typographic knowledge and skills. This course develops a critical awareness to provide effective expression of meaning through the visible word, which in turn demands an understanding of content and constant attention to detail. The aim is to produce outcomes of a high technical and aesthetic standard through concentrating on the thoughtful combination of word and image. The primary objective of this course is to further prepare students with the technical and cognitive competencies that enable them to deal effectively and professionally with visual communication design problems and prepare sophisticated type outcomes for print.
Subject_Description_23: This course introduces designing for 3D printing. This practical course introduces students to key stages of the design development process and human centred design strategies, identifying user behaviours and needs in the development of niche products. Fundamental skills are developed in the design and preparation of digital files, to create resolved 3D printed prototypes.
Subject_Description_24: This course provides students with an introduction to leading concepts of sustainability (ecological worldview, circular design, bio-inspired design, biophilia) and their application to Interior/Spatial Design. Students will be trained to become ecological design thinkers who can integrate sustainability into their conceptual and practical processes.
Subject_Description_25: This course provides students with an understanding of the theories, principals and concepts of virtual three dimensional space, and the use of human and digital tools to imagine, design and construct effective 3D forms in virtual environments. Students will gain knowledge of the history of 3D systems, from creative sculpture to scientific scanning/information capture, as well as the potential influence these forms have on human experience. Students will develop an understanding of differing approaches to the design of 3D form such as, polygonal, solid & organic modelling). The application of digital modelling, and links to a number of other fields, including design for applied uses in architecture, health, entertainment are explored during the course.
Subject_Description_26: During this course students will explore the technical, social and ethical dimensions of producing and curating content online. Specific attention will be paid to understanding varying modalities of communication (production, dissemination, consumption) and related impacts for creative arts and design disciplines.
Subject_Description_27: In this course, students experience designing propositions that address issues and opportunities afforded by an existing transformative large-scale design project. Students become familiar with socially responsible design in an interdisciplinary design lab studio environment. Students will practise experimenting, fabricating, iterating, proposing and implementing concepts that have potential to transform organisations, businesses, institutions, systems, politics and cultures at local, regional and global level.
Subject_Description_28: This course covers the application of motion graphics and visual effects, as a tool in enhancing the visual experience and presenting more powerful forms of visual information and narrative experience. The principals of human computer interaction, and their link to motion based presentation is covered with students gaining knowledge in the design and implementation of motion based visual effects to improve the human visual experience of motion based imagery. Students will gain both a theoretical understanding of visual effects and will also gain practical skills in the production and presentation of motion based visual effects outcomes.
Subject_Description_29: How does research feed into design practice? This first-year course investigates how creative research methodologies are used to support and inform the design process. Design research explores issues in a focused and systematic way to arrive at new insights in an ever-changing world.
Subject_Description_30: This course introduces students to leading edge and experimental design practices, particularly looking at procedural and generative design systems. Students will gain knowledge of node based or visual programming systems within three-dimensional virtual environments using parametric workflows, standard and bespoke modifiers. They will also be introduced to the principals of fractal complexity and how the generation of procedural form can apply to human experience. During this process they will develop knowledge and practical skills in the methodologies used in experimental design practice and the application of experimental systems. Students in this course will become emerging professionals at the leading edge of generative design practice.
Subject_Description_31: This course covers the field of immersive environments as applied for use in visualization (architectural, 3D, health), reconstruction (archaeology, criminology) and learning (gameplay, education). The application of computer game systems, to create immersive experiences is explored with students gaining knowledge in the theory of immersive design, its history, human physiology and the science behind the technologies that make immersive systems work. Students will develop both skills and a deeper understanding, in the creative design and practical development of strong immersive experiences with digital visualization tools (eg. game engines, VR and AR).
Subject_Description_32: This third year course builds on previous courses to develop an advanced level of theoretical knowledge and practical understanding of typographic design. Curriculum departs from the traditional typographic discourse of form and function and encourages students to consider their work through the lens of form and content. Engaging with experimental and rhetorical approaches to typography, students explore their own position and practice in relation to the overall context of intended (and unintended) audiences, subject matters, social environments, and available media. PREREQUISITES: 2681QCA Typography and Print and 2682QCA Typography and Expression or equivalents.
Subject_Description_33: This course provides an introduction to the fundamental elements and principles of all Art and Design Practices, and cements a platform of visual literacy encompassing perceptual, analytical and expressive skills. The focus of the course is using the two dimensional image as a primary instrument of creative expression, problem solving and communication. This course is a component of the foundation program for the Bachelor of Design and the Bachelor of Architectural Design, and has been designed as a core study to complement activities in both disciplines. This course is incompatible with 1603QCA.
Subject_Description_34: This course introduces students to the fundamental precepts of product design. Building on the introduction to design process in the first year, students have the opportunity to develop their approach to design, their particular interests and focus and the skills to support the resolution of a design idea. The creation of object outcomes using advanced technologies is supported in this course, and the contrast between conventional technology and advanced technology, and designing and specifying for both are explored.
Subject_Description_35: This course enables students to explore the boundaries between reality and virtual space through an understanding of spatial and photorealistic visualization. The course expands upon prior skills in computer aided design in reference to design approaches and principals for objects, structures, interior spaces, and products, inclusive of detailed components. Students will develop methods of design for 3D visualized forms from architectural and scientific reference plans and engineered processes. Visualization is explored through students gaining a deep knowledge of light and material and the correspondence of the real world to virtual environments. A strong knowledge of the science and technology behind rendering systems is developed, particularly how to apply materials and lighting for the purpose of rendering to photo-realistic quality for presentation.

Description: This Honours program has been designed to enable students who have demonstrated substantial ability at an undergraduate level to develop advanced levels of studio practice, supporting theory and an advanced level of research understanding. The program will allow students the flexibility to undertake Honours that best fits their area of study.
Career_Outcomes: You will be able to work in corporate and brand design for print, web, publishing, advertising and digital media. You will have the skills needed to work in design for social change, culture and education.
Subject_Description_1: Honours Research Project constitutes a 40CP honours research commitment within the (Bachelor of Fine Art (Honours) and Bachelor of Photography (Honours). Each of the four components of the course combine to introduce students to the rigors of research and engage them in an advanced level of study within visual practice. The expectation is that the research project undertaken will be based within the visual and incorporates high levels of visual literacy. Assessment of the four courses will culminate in one assessment item. Honours Research Project includes the practical component and the exegesis for assessment in a professional context at the completion of all four courses Co-requisite/Pre-requisite: 6303QCA">6303QCA Visual Arts Research Methods.Co-requisite/Pre-requisite: 6303QCA">6303QCA Visual Arts Research Methods.
Subject_Description_2: This course will enable you to advance your academic writing and to understand impactful techniques for critically documenting, evaluating and reflecting upon the research process. You will learn how to generate effective and engaging content for communicating research across physical, social and online platforms, and to disseminate your research to professional, peer and academic audiences.
Subject_Description_3: Excellence in practice is predicated on a reflective and rigorous approach to design practice as a method of inquiry and comment. This course introduces students to a number of exemplarily research practices through which they may contextualise their work. It looks at different modes of inquiry and encourages students to develop research practices that are appropriate to their particular area of study. This course provides an opportunity for students to explore the basic principles of research methods and consider how these may be applied to their research project. Students will identify their topic/research question and appropriate methods of inquiry through peer review, students will present their research topic, investigations and work-in-progress for scholarly interrogation.
Subject_Description_4: Honours Research Project constitutes a 40CP honours research commitment within the (Bachelor of Fine Art (Honours) and Bachelor of Photography (Honours). Each of the four components of the course combine to introduce students to the rigors of research and engage them in an advanced level of study within visual practice. The expectation is that the research project undertaken will be based within the visual and incorporates high levels of visual literacy. Assessment of the four courses will culminate in one assessment item. Honours Research Project is presented with the Exegesis (completed in 6012QCA) for assessment in a professional context at the completion of all four courses. Co-requisite/Pre-requisite: 6303QCA Visual Arts Research Methods.
Subject_Description_5: Honours Research Project constitutes a 40CP honours research commitment within the (Bachelor of Fine Art (Honours) and Bachelor of Photography (Honours). Each of the four components of the course combine to introduce students to the rigors of research and engage them in an advanced level of study within visual practice. The expectation is that the research project undertaken will be based within the visual and incorporates high levels of visual literacy. Assessment of the four courses will culminate in one assessment item. Honours Research Project is presented with the Exegesis (completed in 6012QCA) for assessment in a professional context at the completion of all four courses. Co-requisite/Pre-requisite: 6303QCA Visual Arts Research Methods.
Subject_Description_6: Honours Research Project constitutes a 40CP honours research commitment within the (Bachelor of Fine Art (Honours) and Bachelor of Photography (Honours). Each of the four components of the course combine to introduce students to the rigors of research and engage them in an advanced level of study within visual practice. The expectation is that the research project undertaken will be based within the visual and incorporates high levels of visual literacy. Assessment of the four courses will culminate in one assessment item. Honours Research Project is presented with the Exegesis (completed in 6012QCA) for assessment in a professional context at the completion of all four courses. Co-requisite/Pre-requisite: 6303QCA Visual Arts Research Methods.

Description: International students must be in Australia and able to attend campus to commence this program. This program prepares students to teach in primary or secondary settings. Students undertake a foundation first year and then undertake studies in either primary or secondary education from Year 1/Trimester 3. Students undertake professional practice which includes observation and participation in schools, practice teaching and community field studies. Foundation (First) Year: All courses in the foundation year of the Bachelor of Education are offered across all three campuses (Gold Coast, Logan, Mt Gravatt). Trimester 3 offerings of 1199EDN, 1399EDN, 1499EDN and 1599EDN for students who commence in Trimester 2 will be offered on the Gold Coast and Mt Gravatt campuses only. Primary Education (Gold Coast, Logan, Mt Gravatt): Curriculum areas include history and geography, the way language develops and works, mathematics, science and technology, health and physical education, and the  arts. Students studying Primary Education may also take a major in either Health and Physical Education or Special Needs Education or Early Childhood Education or select one of the available minors. Core courses in the Primary Education Major are offered across all three campuses (Gold Coast, Logan, Mt Gravatt). Students may need to travel to another campus to undertake courses specific to a particular second Major or Minor that are not offered on their home campus. Primary Majors Primary Minors Secondary Education (Gold Coast, Mt Gravatt): Students undertake studies in two teaching areas or one teaching area and one major (conditions apply to some teaching area combinations). Core courses in the Secondary Education Major are offered on the Gold Coast and Mt Gravatt  campuses. Students may need to travel to another campus to undertake courses specific to a Secondary Teaching Area that are not offered on their home campus. Secondary Majors Secondary Teaching Areas Students  undertaking two Teaching Areas will select one area from the Teaching Area  Content 1 list and one area from the Teaching Area Content 2 list. Students undertaking the Learning Support major will select one area  from the Teaching Area Content 2 list. Teaching Area Content 1 Teaching Area Content 2 Note: Mt Gravatt students may be required to undertake their Content Teaching Areas at Nathan or South Bank.
Career_Outcomes: As a graduate, you will be eligible to apply for registration with the Queensland College of Teachers. The Early Childhood Major is recognised by the Australian Children's Education and Care Quality Authority. You will be prepared for a career as a teacher in the public or private sector which can lead to senior positions such as a head of department or principal. An education qualification is also a good general qualification for many areas of  work. Rather than teaching in schools, you could choose to follow a different  pathway, and you may find work in: training settings in industry and  government, outdoor education, adult literacy, libraries, educational research, education policy, or consultancy. Griffith University has the highest education graduate success rates in Australia. Our graduates are in demand and find employment in the independent, Catholic and state education systems in Queensland as well as overseas. Students wishing to seek teacher registration in another state should seek advice from that state's appropriate professional body.

Description: This is your chance to have an impact on the way the world works. You could have the opportunity to make your mark on major global systems and infrastructure or be at the forefront of localised urban projects. When you choose this degree, you'll be engineering from day one. In your first year, you'll develop a strong foundation in basic science and engineering principles. You'll study a range of engineering areas, letting you decide which area interests you the most. We're strong believers in `learning by doing', so this degree has a strong practical focus. You'll learn from teachers who are passionate about engineering and the difference it makes in the world, so you'll get to experience their energy in your studies. In your second year you'll choose your preferred major so you can focus on the area you feel passionate about. Learning from industry kicks into another gear, and you'll participate in genuine engineering projects. You'll also hear from the very best, with guest lecturers explaining their vision and the results of significant projects. You'll have direct access to them for questions and advice as part of our smaller more personalised experience. Entering your final year, you'll take your skills and work with one of our industry partners here or overseas, undertaking a trimester-long project through our capstone Industry Affiliates Program. As a graduate you'll have the hands-on skills that employers tell us they're after. Plus, because this is an accredited degree, you will have met Engineers Australia stage one competencies. This degree is also internationally recognised, which means you can put your skills into practice right around the world.  Fast-track your finish line - With intensive study options (and/or) year-round classes available, this degree can be finished in less time than a standard full-time study load, getting you into the workforce faster. Students may be eligible to do an international field trip, organised by the academic staff. This may count towards a component of the degree, depending on the structure.
Career_Outcomes: *Source: Australian Government Job Outlook Your future career will be guided by your choice of major. Here¿s an overview of where your choice could take you: Civil engineers support the design and development of essential services and manage and improve the built environment. By studying civil engineering, you'll develop your knowledge in the planning, design and construction of buildings and infrastructure. Demand for civil engineering professionals has grown and is expected to continue be an area of high demand. You could find employment in jobs such as chief civil engineer, construction engineer, municipal engineer, structural engineer, transport engineer, water supply distribution engineer, project manager and consulting engineer. If you want a career creating tomorrow's cities, then this major is for you. In our modern world, we¿re surrounded by technologically advanced electronic devices. The phone in your pocket, your computer, or the jet airliner flying overhead only exist because of advanced electronic circuits developed by electronic engineers. In this major, you¿ll focus on the development, construction and design of electronic parts and systems, ranging from everyday items to applications for large corporations and industries. You could find employment in areas such as energy production, transport control systems development, and communications, including satellite navigation, broadband services and telecommunications. The energy sector is a fast-advancing engineering discipline, with huge investments expected in the coming decades. You will be prepared for a career in areas such as electronics design and fabrication, power transmission, renewable power generation, solar energy systems, wind energy systems, electric vehicles, efficient lighting and energy research. As Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) are rapidly finding application in many areas, the need for both certified pilots and for engineers to design and maintain these vehicles is on the rise. The Electronic and UAV Engineering major offers UAV flight training and professional pilot licence theory. Graduates will be employable as UAV pilots, UAV designers, engineers in the aviation and general electronics industries. This degree is also a pathway for students wishing to be a Pilot Engineer but with a private rather than commercial licence. Electrical and electronic engineers work with senior administrators, civil and mechanical engineers, computer scientists and various workers in the business, building and construction industries. The essential nature of an electrical engineer's role places them in the position to influence the development and application of new and emerging technologies. This includes the fast-growing energy industry. You could work to incorporate locally generated renewable energy resources into our more conventional supply systems, helping to reduce costs, save energy and cut greenhouse gas emissions. Environmental professionals with strong ecological social science backgrounds are in demand both in Australia and internationally. You'll find opportunities in government departments such as Transport and Main Roads, Natural Resources and Mines, Department of Science, IT and the Arts (DSITIA) along with Environment and Resource Management. You'll also enjoy opportunities with consulting firms in the construction, mining, oil, smelting and manufacturing industries. Mechanical engineering is the most diverse of all the engineering disciplines. As a graduate, you'll be qualified for a career in medical, automotive, aerospace, renewable energy, marine and sports-related sectors. With specialised skills across both electronic and mechanical engineering, as a graduate you'll be prepared for work in the design, development and production of smart engineering systems and products. You'll find career opportunities across many industries including manufacturing, mining, transport and defence and emerging fields such as medical and assistive technology smart cities, precision agriculture and robotics. Software engineers design and implement the software systems our society depends on, from biotechnology to sports to submarines. As a graduate, you'll be prepared for a career in software development and be equipped to meet the demands of the evolving software industry. You could find employment as a software architect, software developer, software engineer, software tester, IT project manager, systems analyst, security specialist, computational scientist, programmer, networking and communications specialist.
Subject_Description_1: This course provides some of the essential mathematical techniques to mathematicians and physical scientists, and applies them to scientific problems. The course covers basic material on multiple integrals of scalar functions as well as line and surface integrals of vector fields, the theorems of Gauss, Green and Stokes, Fourier series and integrals. It also introduces some of the common partial differential equations of applied mathematics and methods of solution mostly based on separation of variables. It also covers some topics on ordinary differential equations. Incompatible: 2001ENG Advanced ENG Mathematics, 2203NSC Mathematics 2A. Prerequisites: 1201SCG">1201SCG Linear Algebra and 1202SCG Calculus I. (Please note: for students enrolled in Program 1567 1201SCG">1201SCG Linear Algebra is a co-requisite). Students must pass both courses to enrol in 2205NSC.
Subject_Description_2: This course introduces the basic semiconductor concepts, the principles of diode and transistor operation, and the fundamental transistor circuits (common amplifier topologies, op-amp building blocks, and low-frequency amplifiers). Circuit simulation (SPICE) with appropriately set device parameters and simplified equivalent circuits are used for circuit analysis. Circuit design is based on circuit analysis and is facilitated by an understanding of semiconductor properties and device operation. Laboratory exercises will complement the teaching approach for this course. Incompatible: 2030MEE Microelectronic Circuits Prerequisites: 1301ENG Electric Circuits and 1302ENG Introduction to Electronics
Subject_Description_3: This course will explore in detail the modern implementations of electronics in the control of aircraft. Sensors, navigational instruments, control systems, collision avoidance systems and glass cockpit integration will all be studied. Students will gain practical experience in the implementation of these systems by working with real aircraft instrumentation and aircraft. An exposure to maintenance of aircraft is also included and students successfully completing the course will be awarded a Certificate II in Aeroskills. The course is restricted to students enrolled in 1542 BEng(Electronic and UAV major) and 1584 BEng/BAvn
Subject_Description_4: This course introduces students to the basic concepts and principles of thermodynamics, and its selected engineering applications. Topics include the first law of thermodynamics, volumetric properties of pure substances, heat effects, the second law of thermodynamics, thermodynamic properties of fluids, and thermodynamic analysis of processes.
Subject_Description_5: This course provides the fundamental knowledge of fluid mechanics and hydraulics including fluid properties, fluid statics, conservation of mass, energy equation, flow in conduits, pumps and turbines, flow around objects, open channel flow and compressible flow.
Subject_Description_6: This course introduces the fundamental concepts of electronics from the systems and signals perspective. Hardware implementations, such as A/D and D/A converters, rectifiers, wave-shaping circuits, and amplifiers are developed by making use of operational amplifiers, diodes, resistors, and capacitors to emphasise the system-building concepts (feedback, frequency response, transfer characteristics, impedance matching, and analysis by equivalent circuits). Circuit simulation (using SPICE) is used concurrently with real circuits and measurements to establish links between theory and practice. Incompatibles: 1005MEE Electronic Devices, Circuits and Systems AND 1031MEE Introduction to Electronics. Advised Prerequisites: 1301ENG Electric Circuits
Subject_Description_7: The course will initially explore topics in relation to generic data communications, including: OSI model; PSTN modem technology ; Error correction ; Data compression ; Physical layer standards; Line codes ; Signals in noise ; Idle RQ and continuous RQ ; Link utilisation ; Link layer protocols ; Data over terrestrial and satellite radio. The second half of the course will look specifically at topics related to the application to computer networks, including: Network topologies; Network bearers and physical attachment ; LANs and WANs; CSMA and token protocols ; Networking protocol performance ; Bridges and routing ; Encryption and compression; Internet protocols ; SSL. A series of laboratories will cover relevant topics, in particular related to signals and performance of data systems. Please check the "assumed knowledge" for this course under the course profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment.
Subject_Description_8: Organisations typically use many disparate technologies to achieve their business objectives. This course first gives an overview of low-level technologies such as programming with a focus on code reuse, scripting techniques and software configuration tools. This is followed by a practical presentation of software packages commonly used for handling data and producing reports and presentations. Pre-Requisite: 2807ICT Programming Principles for BIT students OR 2701ICT Interactive Application Development OR 2702ICT Intelligent Media Systems for BCIM students
Subject_Description_9: This course explores the common modulation techniques including amplitude and angle modulation for both analogue and digital information signals. Applications examined include radio, television and telecommunications. The course looks at both system level and circuit level. Many examples are examined for circuits for mixers, modulators, demodulators, oscillators, frequency synthesisers, RF amplifiers and radio and television receivers and transmitters. Design of amplification stages utilising classes A, B, C and D are examined. Methods and importance of shielding at high frequencies is also covered. A series of laboratories explore construction and measurement of communication circuits. Incompatible: 2304ENG Communication Systems and Circuits AND 3007MEE Communication Systems and Circuits
Subject_Description_10: This course covers the principles of electric motors and generators. Both DC and AC motors and generators are explored along with the application of single and multi-phase machines. State of the art drive, control and protection circuitry will also be considered along with solid state methods of providing AC supply. Practical work will enhance the understanding of these topics. Please check the "assumed knowledge" for this course under the course profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. This course will be offered from 2018 at the Gold Coast campus, in trimester 2, and replaces 6509ENG.
Subject_Description_11: This course provides engineering and architecture students with an overview of the principles, skills and techniques required for the evaluation, planning, and management of projects from inception through to completion.
Subject_Description_12: This course has a major design project which further develops the practical engineering design skills students have already gained through the Environmental Engineering Design 1 and 2 courses. Students are required to design the basic infrastructure for a proposed site development with significant environmental issues to be addressed. The development of a cost effective and appropriate design solution and development of design and documentation skills are emphasised. The design project is carried out in teams, giving students the opportunity to experience the issues involved in working in teams towards a realistic project outcome. Advised Prerequisite: 4045 EVE - Environmental Engineering Design Project OR 3213ENG Environmental Engineering Design Project
Subject_Description_13: This course introduces students to engineering design practice utilising real world design exercises. The course gives students a solid grounding in current engineering practice and emphasises the importance of incorporating sustainable approaches and sound practices to their designs. This course may involve individual or team approaches, depending on the nature of the design task. Incompatible: 2106ENG Design for Civil Engineers
Subject_Description_14: The course introduces students to the concepts of Information Systems Architecture (ISA) and demonstrates how Information Systems, Engineering and Management views can be unified by an enterprise architecture approach. The course covers relevant international standards (ISO15704, ISO42010) and discusses frequently used industry frameworks (TOGAF, DoDAF, etc). Pre-Requisite: 2511ICT Business Analysis or 3812ICT Agile Business Analysis
Subject_Description_15: Stress analysis (also known as solid mechanics) provides techniques by which engineers can predict stress and strain distributions resulting from known loading conditions, so that the stability and strength of structural members and machine components under load can be assessed. Stress analysis is an essential tool in the analysis and design of structures and machines under load.
Subject_Description_16: This course mainly covers the analysis and design of reinforced and prestressed concrete structural elements. Both strength and serviceability design requirements are covered. Problem solving exercises based on actual design situations are utilised extensively in this course. After completing this course students will be able to analyse and design structural concrete elements and structures. Assessment is by, tutorial and design assignments, and examinations.
Subject_Description_17: This course deals with continuous-time signals and systems and is designed to build on the basic circuit analysis concepts covered in the course Electric Circuits. It provides a detailed study of continuous-time signals and systems in time domain as well as in transformed domain. Signal transforms (Fourier series, Fourier transform and Laplace transforms) are covered in detail. Further concepts such as signal sampling and aliasing are introduced. The theory is exemplified with processing of signals in MATLAB. Incompatible: 2006MEE Signals and Systems AND 2075ENG Signals and Systems
Subject_Description_18: As an engineer you will be faced with problems that require you to devise innovative and practical solutions. Some problems may be simple and you will solve them drawing on knowledge you acquired through your course of study or using your accumulated experiences. On the other hand, there will be cases where your experience and academic training are not sufficient. In these cases, you will need to engage in research. Being able to source valid and credible information and analyse information statistically in order to formulate viable solutions is an important skill that all engineers need and which Engineers Australia expects you to have. The research and statistics skills you learn in this course will also help you throughout your studies at Griffith University. Research is a key component in Undergraduate degrees at Griffith University. Moreover, the skills learnt in this course are of vital importance to students who intend to pursue higher degree research studies. Therefore, this course aims to equip you with the skills needed to conduct valid research and statistical analysis be it in academic or industrial practice context.
Subject_Description_19: This course explores the major ethical, professional, social and legal issues arising from the widespread use of IT, highlighting dilemmas that may be faced by IT practitioners. The subject examines the key debates and controversies pertinent to IT and their social consequences through the use of key case studies. *This course replaces 2003ICT Professional Issues in IT. Prerequisite: Successful completion of 120CP of first or second year Information Technology /Multimedia courses
Subject_Description_20: This course covers some aspects of a computer system architecture and organisation. It will introduce the students to the basic components of a computer system showing how the system components interact with the processor such as the operating system, the memory controller, and the I/O subsystem. The course also contains an in depth look at many mainstream bus architectures used in industry. It not only focuses on the hardware components of computer based systems, the students are also taught the importance of the components that make an operating system. Students are encouraged to learn about operating systems through the development of a Real-time operating system for a mainstream micro-controller. Throughout the course, the assignments and laboratories will be used to further develop the practical skills of the students. Incompatible: 3021MEE Computer Systems
Subject_Description_21: Engineering mechanics is both a foundation and a framework for most engineering disciplines. This course provides a basic knowledge of Newtonian mechanics, rigid-body mechanics, elasticity and structural analysis. In particular, the principles of statics and their applications in engineering, the methods of static analysis, and techniques of engineering computation are expounded. Students are expected not only to acquire a good grasp of the principles but also to develop the computational and analytical skills which are vital in obtaining correct engineering solutions. In practice, a wrong solution can lead to an engineering disaster. This course is designed to enable students to acquire fundamental knowledge in engineering. It forms an integral part of the analysis and design training provided in the Engineering programs. This course is offered in trimester 2 and 3 at both the Gold Coast and Nathan campuses.
Subject_Description_22: Mechanics of Materials 2 provides techniques by which engineers can determine stress and strain distributions resulting from known loading conditions, so that the stability and strength of structural members under load can be examined. The learners will acquire the knowledge in the analysis and design of structures and machines under load.
Subject_Description_23: This course covers fundamental electromagnetic theory including Electrostatics, Magnetostatics, Electromagnetic Induction, Electromagnetic Radiation, Properties of Matter and finally finishing with Maxwell's equations. This basic theory is then used to explore the principles of propagation on guided media such as cables and waveguides. Basic principles such as the Telegraph equations lead to characteristic impedance, reflection and transmission coefficient, standing and travelling waves. Simple modes in rectangular and circular waveguides are examined and fundamental dispersion issues are addressed. Smith charts are used as a calculation tool for transmission problems and numerous matching and coupling problems are attempted. A series of laboratories explore measurements of signals and fields on simple systems.
Subject_Description_24: The Course introduces students to advanced materials and their applications with the aim to deepen their understanding about i) how materials properties guide materials selection at the product design stage, ii) how core materials properties (either surface- or bulk properties) are changed, adapted or mended to specific user environment and/or an application field through a variety of manufacturing methods, and iii) how commercial material objects (or products) are manufactured in a factory setting. The Course will endue students with relevant knowledge on current materials surface technology, material treatment processes and manufacturing and production system processes, process technology and manufacturing systems design. Additive and rapid prototyping technology and lean engineering/lean production will be also be discussed in this Course. The Course is designed for 3rd year engineering students that already possess university-level fundamental knowledge on properties of common engineering materials such as metals, polymers, ceramics and attained theoretical and practical knowledge on fabrication and processing methods for these materials. The Course is developed to provide a practical, project-based immersion into materials selection process (with real, commercial products used as study samples) where students will learn how initial material selection process effects the geometry, structure, performance and cost of a final product. Assessment is by group assignment, oral presentation and individual examination. Please check the "Assumed Knowledge" for this course under the Course Profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. Incompatible: 2506ENG Materials and Manufacturing
Subject_Description_25: The main aim of this course is to provide sound knowledge of the principles and practices of digital systems, both at the device and circuit level. The course covers topics in digital electronics including: Number Theory, Boolean Algebra, Logic Circuits, Logic Minimisation Techniques, Multiplexers, Adders, Flip-Flops, Counters, Registers, State Machines, Memory Circuits, Digital / Analog Conversion, Programable Logic Circuits and Microcomputer Bus Architecture. Incompatible: 1004MEE Digital Networks and Systems AND 2072ENG Digital Systems AND 1303ENG Digital Systems
Subject_Description_26: The course introduces students to the theory and practice of control systems. It discusses the basic (introductory) methods of control systems analysis and design, with emphasis on the principle of negative feedback which is the essence of operation of control systems. Engineering examples are used to introduce and illustrate the usefulness of the control systems theory and to make the students aware of this important engineering area. Assessment is by lab preliminaries, reports on laboratory experiments, and a final examination.
Subject_Description_27: This experiential learning based course introduces the natural and physical sciences that underpin the practice of engineering. Through projects students will apply science fundamentals to the systematic investigation, interpretation, and analysis of some engineering problems. Topics covered include Newtonian mechanics and electrical principles. Incompatible: 1031SCG (Physics IA).
Subject_Description_28: This course introduces the fundamental concepts and methods of general chemistry. Basic skills of laboratory chemical analysis are developed. Lecture content includes three modules: Introduction and basic concepts; molecular structure and bonding; and energy and physical processes. Incompatible: 1001SCE Chemistry 1A, 1009ENV General Chemistry, 1001ENV Chemistry 1, 1023SCG Chemistry 1
Subject_Description_29: Mechanical engineers need to possess sound understanding of the physics of the design and use of machine elements such as gears, cams, springs, pulleys, joints etc., that are used in engineered components. This design process is deeply enshrined in established design standards/codes that all engineers should be knowledgeable of. 3511ENG Design of Machine Elements is aimed at integrating and applying prior knowledge in fundamental design, materials sciences, statics and dynamics coupled with design strategies and knowledge of machine elements to design various machines. These skills and knowledge help engineers to design, analyse, synthesize and deliver robust engineering solutions. The main learning outcome of this unit is the students' acquisition of strong analytical knowledge of machine elements, their design and load carriage/power transmission mechanics. This course will be delivered through a combination of specially developed lectures, design problem solving methods, case studies and hands-on design assignments' all rolled together into workshops. Please check the "assumed knowledge" for this course under the course profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. This course is planned to be offered for the first time in 2019, trimester 2 and replaces 2505ENG">2505ENG. Incompatible: 2505ENG">2505ENG Design of Machine Elements
Subject_Description_30: Mechanical Engineering Design is the creative development of mechanical products or systems. This course focuses on mechanical design through a project based learning approach. Students will work on a design and analyse (and/or build) project, developing a solution to a real-world engineering design problem.
