Assessment is by a written design report, oral presentation/s and peer group assessment when relevant.
Subject_Description_31: The capstone engineering project is undertaken in the final year of the program. Students are required to plan, execute and report on a research project with some independence while working with an academic supervisor who maintains regular contact and provides support and direction in the design and execution of the research. Projects based on industry requirements will be encouraged.
Subject_Description_32: Kinematics & Dynamics equips graduates with a solid understanding of the key concepts of mechanics required for design and analysis of mechanisms and mechanical devices. Topics covered include kinematics and dynamics of mechanical components modelled as particles and plane rigid bodies, interconnected objects, rotational dynamics, work and energy methods, translating and rotating coordinate systems, vector methods, three-dimensional dynamics of rigid bodies and an introduction to vibration Please check the "assumed knowledge" for this course under the course profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. This course is planned to be offered for the first time in 2018, trimester 1 and replaces 3317ENG.
Subject_Description_33: This course introduces students to the programming and interfacing of a modern microprocessor. The course outlines the theory behind microprocessors, with a focus on architecture, memory structures, and peripheral interfacing. The course also involves an insight into programming methodologies in assembler and illustrates ways of successfully debugging embedded systems. The course will give the student the background knowledge to successfully develop an embedded system using any microprocessor. The course is highly practical in approach and covers such areas as data acquisition, sensor interfacing, electronic control, and microprocessor communication protocols. Incompatible: 2303ENG Microprocessor Techniques AND 2010MEE Microprocessor Techniques AND 1073ENG Microprocessors
Subject_Description_34: Hydrology is concerned with the distribution and dynamics of water and water quality on or near the surface of earth. As fundamental engineering sciences, hydrology plays an important role in developing technical skills in water engineering and in understanding many of the contemporary water management issues. The course covers fundamental hydrologic processes such as rainfall, evaporation, infiltration, surface and ground water, and hydrologic extremes ie floods and droughts. In addition, the course develops technical skills to apply some basic techniques for hydrologic analysis and design with particular emphasis on flood estimation, flood frequency analysis, and flood routing. Learning activities include lectures and workshops.
Subject_Description_35: This course provides a practical and theoretical introduction to manufacturing technology with a primary focus on metal processing technologies and their applications in modern manufacturing industry. The course is designed for the 2nd year engineering students that already possess university-level fundamental knowledge about the properties of common engineering materials, the application of forces in engineering systems and have a basic understanding about the tools, machines and processes employed in fabrication of engineered products.
Subject_Description_36: The course revises and extends basic integral and differential calculus of one variable and introduces differential equations. It provides a foundation in the mathematical sciences needed for later studies both in an engineering and science context. This course is for Engineering or ICT students ONLY. Incompatible: 1202SCG Calculus I
Subject_Description_37: This course covers the theory required to undertake the CASA BAK examination. It will also provide ab initio UAV flight training to students.
Subject_Description_38: This course develops an integrated approach to understanding and analysis of natural catchments. Principles and methods in hydrology and hydraulics will be used to analyse the dynamics of water and water-borne substances. We will address their sources, transport, mixing and dispersion in the environment as well as the implications to catchment management. Computer modelling software popular in the water engineering industry will be extensively used in this course.
Subject_Description_39: Engineering solutions are developed from an in depth understanding of the subject knowledge combined with a creative approach to problem solving that takes a step back from details to consider the challenge as a whole. Complex problem solving involves an understanding of individuals and systems, interconnections and innovation. Furthermore these solutions must also be considered in terms of sustainable development. This course introduces the student to engineering design through a project-based approach to the development of a product or piece of infrastructure as part of small design team.
Subject_Description_40: This course begins with Maxwell's equations and uses these to let the student explore propagating fields as applied to communication systems and energy applications. Propagation and reflection of EM fields through media and examination of more advanced applications, such as waveguide structures and antennas are covered. More specifically the curricula covers: Maxwell's equations; boundary conditions; plane EM waves; polarisation; plane waves in lossy media; low-loss dielectrics; good conductors; boundary reflections; waveguides, antennas, radar and satellite communications. Laboratories provide for practical verification of a number of these topics. Incompatible: 3307ENG Linear Electromagnetics or 7512ENG Linear Electromagnetics

Students may be eligible to do an international field trip, organised by the academic staff. This may count towards a component of the degree, depending on the structure.

You could find employment as a software architect, software developer, software engineer, software tester, IT project manager, systems analyst, security specialist, computational scientist, programmer, networking and communications specialist.
Subject_Description_1: The course introduces basic vector algebra in two and three dimensions, matrices, complex numbers, probability and revises basic functions. It provides a foundation in the mathematical sciences for later studies in science and engineering. Prior Assumed Knowledge: It will be assumed that students have the knowledge equivalent to a grade of SA over 4 semesters in Mathematics B (Qld high school subject), or equivalent study over 4 semesters of a high school subject that includes the study of differential and integral calculus or 1017SCG">1017SCG Foundation Mathematics (grade of 4 or higher). For students who do not have this level of mathematics background, it is strongly suggested that they first complete 1017SCG">1017SCG Foundation Mathematics. Incompatible: 1201SCG Linear Algebra, 1011SCG Mathematics 1A, 1201BPS Mathematics 1A, 1666NSC Mathematics 1A for Engineers.
Subject_Description_2: As an engineer you will be faced with problems that require you to devise innovative and practical solutions. Some problems may be simple and you will solve them drawing on knowledge you acquired through your course of study or using your accumulated experiences. On the other hand, there will be cases where your experience and academic training are not sufficient. In these cases, you will need to engage in research. Being able to source valid and credible information and analyse information statistically in order to formulate viable solutions is an important skill that all engineers need and which Engineers Australia expects you to have. The research and statistics skills you learn in this course will also help you throughout your studies at Griffith University. Research is a key component in Undergraduate degrees at Griffith University. Moreover, the skills learnt in this course are of vital importance to students who intend to pursue higher degree research studies. Therefore, this course aims to equip you with the skills needed to conduct valid research and statistical analysis be it in academic or industrial practice context.
Subject_Description_3: The capstone engineering project is undertaken in the final year of the program. Students are required to plan, execute and report on a research project with some independence while working with an academic supervisor who maintains regular contact and provides support and direction in the design and execution of the research. Projects based on industry requirements will be encouraged.
Subject_Description_4: This course covers fundamental and advanced topics in communications systems which are essential for Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Mechatronic Engineers, and Electronic and Biomedical Engineering. Knowledge on signals and systems, and Fourier transform is prerequisite for this course. Topics to be covered: (i) modulation AM, FM, (ii) digital modulation, digital transmission, (iii) introduction to mobile communications system and smart antennas, (iv) Wireless LANs, MIMO-OFDM for wireless, (v) Cellular Radio Communications, (vi) Microwave Engineering and communications, and (vii) introduction to Satellite Communications..
Subject_Description_5: Hydrology is concerned with the distribution and dynamics of water and water quality on or near the surface of earth. As fundamental engineering sciences, hydrology plays an important role in developing technical skills in water engineering and in understanding many of the contemporary water management issues. The course covers fundamental hydrologic processes such as rainfall, evaporation, infiltration, surface and ground water, and hydrologic extremes ie floods and droughts. In addition, the course develops technical skills to apply some basic techniques for hydrologic analysis and design with particular emphasis on flood estimation, flood frequency analysis, and flood routing. Learning activities include lectures and workshops.
Subject_Description_6: This course introduces students to the programming and interfacing of a modern microprocessor. The course outlines the theory behind microprocessors, with a focus on architecture, memory structures, and peripheral interfacing. The course also involves an insight into programming methodologies in assembler and illustrates ways of successfully debugging embedded systems. The course will give the student the background knowledge to successfully develop an embedded system using any microprocessor. The course is highly practical in approach and covers such areas as data acquisition, sensor interfacing, electronic control, and microprocessor communication protocols. Incompatible: 2010MEE Microprocessor Techniques AND 1073ENG Microprocessors AND 3323ENG MicroController Techniques
Subject_Description_7: This course provides an in-depth knowledge of physical, data link and network layer technologies of modern wireless communications. The emphasis is on principles and protocols concerning the lower layers of the OSI model. Prerequisite: 7611ICT Computer Systems and Networks
Subject_Description_8: Engineering solutions are developed from an in depth understanding of the subject knowledge combined with a creative approach to problem solving that takes a step back from details to consider the challenge as a whole. Complex problem solving involves an understanding of individuals and systems, interconnections and innovation. Furthermore these solutions must also be considered in terms of sustainable development. This course introduces the student to engineering design through a project-based approach to the development of a product or piece of infrastructure as part of small design team.
Subject_Description_9: Stress analysis (also known as solid mechanics) provides techniques by which engineers can predict stress and strain distributions resulting from known loading conditions, so that the stability and strength of structural members and machine components under load can be assessed. Stress analysis is an essential tool in the analysis and design of structures and machines under load.
Subject_Description_10: Soil Mechanics is an important part of geotechnical engineering that deals with the engineering properties of various soils. This course provides students with valuable opportunities to develop their understanding of the fundamentals of soil behavior, and skills that will allow them to apply their knowledge to solve real-life problems. Students will also have the opportunity to become familiar with various testing procedures and learn how to perform laboratory tests to determine the geotechnical properties of soil such as grain-size distribution, plasticity, compaction characteristics, and permeability. After completing this course, students will acquire sufficient knowledge and develop critical skills that will enable them to solve practical problems related to soil mechanics
Subject_Description_11: All electrical signals produce electromagnetic fields be they communication signals or high current power transmissions. It is therefore vital to understand about the generation and manipulation of these fields. This course covers classical electrostatics in terms of charge and charge density in volumes, force due to charge, electric field intensity, electric potential and electric flux density. It also explores magnetostatics in terms of magnetic field intensity and flux density, magnetic forces, magnetic potential and inductance. Finally time varying fields are covered including moving conductors, transformers, displacement current and generation and motion. The outcome should be a complete understanding of Maxwell's equations applied to engineering problems.
Subject_Description_12: Mechanical Engineering Design is the creative development of mechanical products or systems. This course focuses on mechanical design through a project based learning approach. Students will work on a design and analyse (and/or build) project, developing a solution to a real-world engineering design problem. Assessment is by a written design report, oral presentation/s and peer group assessment when relevant.
Subject_Description_13: This course covers the theory and algorithms of statistical digital signal processing, estimation and modelling together with their applications in the electrical and electronic engineering disciplines. The first half of the course covers the mathematical preliminaries in deterministic digital signal processing, such as the z-transform, discrete-time Fourier transform, FIR and IIR filter design. The second half covers the core of the course, which examines the modelling and estimation of random signals and processes using spectral estimation, optimal filtering, linear MMSE estimation (Wiener and Kalman filtering), and adaptive filters. Emphasis is placed on electrical and electronic engineering applications, such as signal enhancement, signal detection in noise, adaptive noise cancellation, time-series prediction and machine learning. Students will also learn how to implement signal processing algorithms in software (using the Python language) and embedded DSP hardware. Incompatible: 3303ENG Digital Signal Processing
Subject_Description_14: Mechanics of Materials 2 provides techniques by which engineers can determine stress and strain distributions resulting from known loading conditions, so that the stability and strength of structural members under load can be examined. The learners will acquire the knowledge in the analysis and design of structures and machines under load.
Subject_Description_15: The course will initially explore topics in relation to generic data communications, including: OSI model; PSTN modem technology ; Error correction ; Data compression ; Physical layer standards; Line codes ; Signals in noise ; Idle RQ and continuous RQ ; Link utilisation ; Link layer protocols ; Data over terrestrial and satellite radio. The second half of the course will look specifically at topics related to the application to computer networks, including: Network topologies; Network bearers and physical attachment ; LANs and WANs; CSMA and token protocols ; Networking protocol performance ; Bridges and routing ; Encryption and compression; Internet protocols ; SSL. A series of laboratories will cover relevant topics, in particular related to signals and performance of data systems. Please check the "assumed knowledge" for this course under the course profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment.
Subject_Description_16: This course provides engineering and architecture students with an overview of the principles, skills and techniques required for the evaluation, planning, and management of projects from inception through to completion.
Subject_Description_17: A key component to the discipline of Information Technology is the understanding and the advocacy of the user in the development of IT applications and systems. IT graduates must develop a mind-set that recognizes the importance of users and organisational contexts and employ user-centred methodologies in the development, evaluation, and deployment of IT applications and systems. This requires graduates to develop knowledge of HCI, including user and task analysis, human factors, ergonomics, application domains, user interface development tools and GUI frameworks, accessibility standards, and cognitive psychology.
Subject_Description_18: Structural design forms a major part of the work of a professional civil engineer. This course is designed to enable students to do the prerequisite analysis prior to design. It also forms an integral part of the structural analysis and design training provided in the four-year Bachelor of Engineering program in Civil Engineering. This course provides a thorough coverage of the theoretical basis for linear analysis of various types of skeletal (planar) structures encountered in Civil Engineering design work. The main purpose of this course is to develop the ability of the students to analyse planar structures using manual and computer-based methods.
Subject_Description_19: Mechanical engineers need to possess sound understanding of the physics of the design and use of machine elements such as gears, cams, springs, pulleys, joints etc., that are used in engineered components. This design process is deeply enshrined in established design standards/codes that all engineers should be knowledgeable of. 3511ENG Design of Machine Elements is aimed at integrating and applying prior knowledge in fundamental design, materials sciences, statics and dynamics coupled with design strategies and knowledge of machine elements to design various machines. These skills and knowledge help engineers to design, analyse, synthesize and deliver robust engineering solutions. The main learning outcome of this unit is the students' acquisition of strong analytical knowledge of machine elements, their design and load carriage/power transmission mechanics. This course will be delivered through a combination of specially developed lectures, design problem solving methods, case studies and hands-on design assignments' all rolled together into workshops. Please check the "assumed knowledge" for this course under the course profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. This course is planned to be offered for the first time in 2019, trimester 2 and replaces 2505ENG">2505ENG. Incompatible: 2505ENG">2505ENG Design of Machine Elements
Subject_Description_20: This course covers the concepts and components of electrical circuits and develops the fundamental circuit analysis and fault finding skills necessary to understand all electrical circuits. Circuit components such as resistors, capacitors and inductors and non-linear components such as diodes are studied progressing onto rectifiers, comparators and A/D and D/A converters. Analysis techniques include Kirchoff's laws, Thevenin/Norton equivalent circuits, time response of energy storage elements, sinusoidal steady state and frequency-domain analysis.
Subject_Description_21: This course provides some of the essential mathematical techniques to mathematicians and physical scientists, and applies them to scientific problems. The course covers basic material on multiple integrals of scalar functions as well as line and surface integrals of vector fields, the theorems of Gauss, Green and Stokes, Fourier series and integrals. It also introduces some of the common partial differential equations of applied mathematics and methods of solution mostly based on separation of variables. It also covers some topics on ordinary differential equations. Incompatible: 2001ENG Advanced ENG Mathematics, 2203NSC Mathematics 2A. Prerequisites: 1201SCG">1201SCG Linear Algebra and 1202SCG Calculus I. (Please note: for students enrolled in Program 1567 1201SCG">1201SCG Linear Algebra is a co-requisite). Students must pass both courses to enrol in 2205NSC.
Subject_Description_22: Heat and Mass Transfer gives the engineer a firm grounding in the fundamental processes of conduction, convection and radiation heat transfer. Topics covered include transient conduction, forced convection in internal and external flow, free convection, lumped heat capacity analysis, two and three-dimensional heat transfer, radiation exchange between surfaces, diffusion mass transfer, boiling, evaporation and condensation, and heat exchanger design & optimisation. Assessment is by assignments consisting of engineering problems in heat and mass transfer and a final examination. Incompatible: 3505ENG Heat and Mass Transfer
Subject_Description_23: The course introduces students to the concepts of Information Systems Architecture (ISA) and demonstrates how Information Systems, Engineering and Management views can be unified by an enterprise architecture approach. The course covers relevant international standards (ISO15704, ISO42010) and discusses frequently used industry frameworks (TOGAF, DoDAF, etc). Pre-Requisite: 2511ICT Business Analysis or 3812ICT Agile Business Analysis
Subject_Description_24: Modern software frameworks reduce development time and provide a solid foundation for building high quality software applications. This course covers full-stack development of real-world software applications using the selected frameworks. Prerequisite: 2807ICT Programming Principles. Incompatible: 2811ICT Web Programming.
Subject_Description_25: Traditional IT project management approaches work well under stable conditions, when intended project outcomes are well understood. Yet, under conditions of delivering value to clients early, in innovation projects, or new product development, traditional methods of software development are often too restrictive and inflexible. This course offers an alternative approach to software development that values flexibility, time-to-market and self-organisation over rigorous planning and processes. This course is based on the IIBA's Agile Extension to the BABOK. Pre-requisites: 140CP and 1802ICT Foundations of Systems Development
Subject_Description_26: This course introduces students to the process of structural design including: dealing with a client and defining a design brief, load estimation, elementary structural analysis and the design of timber and steel members and connections using the relevant Australian Standard design codes.
Subject_Description_27: Organisations typically use many disparate technologies to achieve their business objectives. This course first gives an overview of low-level technologies such as programming with a focus on code reuse, scripting techniques and software configuration tools. This is followed by a practical presentation of software packages commonly used for handling data and producing reports and presentations. Pre-Requisite: 2807ICT Programming Principles for BIT students OR 2701ICT Interactive Application Development OR 2702ICT Intelligent Media Systems for BCIM students
Subject_Description_28: These concepts introduce students to the fundamental issues in modern data communications and computer networks. Students learn about the layered networking model and are introduced to networking devices and protocols. They learn how these are used in computer networks and in net-based application programs. The primary focus of this subject is Local Area Networks (LAN). Student practical work includes designing and building simple peer-to-peer networks and LANs that are connected to the Internet. The core set of protocols employed on the global Internet, TCP/IP, is studied. Pre-Requisite: 1007ICT Computer Systems and Networks OR 80CP of completed courses.
Subject_Description_29: Web applications interact with users, connecting to back-end databases and dynamically generating results to the browser through a web server. This course presents a systematic introduction to the development of dynamic, community-based, Web applications through the integration of HTML/CSS, with server-side scripting languages, database systems, modern web frameworks and other related technologies. Prerequisite: 2807ICT Programming Principles or 2701ICT Interactive App Development Incompatible: 2503ICT Web Programming
Subject_Description_30: This course deals with continuous-time signals and systems and is designed to build on the basic circuit analysis concepts covered in the course Electric Circuits. It provides a detailed study of continuous-time signals and systems in time domain as well as in transformed domain. Signal transforms (Fourier series, Fourier transform and Laplace transforms) are covered in detail. Further concepts such as signal sampling and aliasing are introduced. The theory is exemplified with processing of signals in MATLAB. Incompatible: 2006MEE Signals and Systems AND 2075ENG Signals and Systems
Subject_Description_31: This course provides a practical and theoretical introduction to manufacturing technology with a primary focus on metal processing technologies and their applications in modern manufacturing industry. The course is designed for the 2nd year engineering students that already possess university-level fundamental knowledge about the properties of common engineering materials, the application of forces in engineering systems and have a basic understanding about the tools, machines and processes employed in fabrication of engineered products.
Subject_Description_32: The course introduces students to the theory and practice of control systems. It discusses the basic (introductory) methods of control systems analysis and design, with emphasis on the principle of negative feedback which is the essence of operation of control systems. Engineering examples are used to introduce and illustrate the usefulness of the control systems theory and to make the students aware of this important engineering area. Assessment is by lab preliminaries, reports on laboratory experiments, and a final examination.
Subject_Description_33: This course covers the principles of electric motors and generators. Both DC and AC motors and generators are explored along with the application of single and multi-phase machines. State of the art drive, control and protection circuitry will also be considered along with solid state methods of providing AC supply. Practical work will enhance the understanding of these topics. Please check the "assumed knowledge" for this course under the course profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. This course will be offered from 2018 at the Gold Coast campus, in trimester 2, and replaces 6509ENG.
Subject_Description_34: This course introduces students to the basic concepts and principles of thermodynamics, and its selected engineering applications. Topics include the first law of thermodynamics, volumetric properties of pure substances, heat effects, the second law of thermodynamics, thermodynamic properties of fluids, and thermodynamic analysis of processes.
Subject_Description_35: This course provides the fundamental knowledge of fluid mechanics and hydraulics including fluid properties, fluid statics, conservation of mass, energy equation, flow in conduits, pumps and turbines, flow around objects, open channel flow and compressible flow.
Subject_Description_36: Electrical Design Project is a practical project based course in which students are challenged to apply fundamental knowledge of analogue and digital components, circuitry and systems to design, implement and demonstrate a functional electronic device meeting prescribed system requirements. Students are guided through a systematic design process involving analysis of requirements, circuit design and simulation, component selection, prototype construction, testing, evaluation and revision. An integral part of the process is the production and maintenance of engineering documentation in the form of technical specifications, schematic diagrams, list of components, test procedures and performance results. Incompatible: 3312ENG Practical Electronics I
Subject_Description_37: This course introduces students to engineering design practice utilising real world design exercises. The course gives students a solid grounding in current engineering practice and emphasises the importance of incorporating sustainable approaches and sound practices to their designs. This course may involve individual or team approaches, depending on the nature of the design task. Incompatible: 2106ENG Design for Civil Engineers
Subject_Description_38: This course will combine an extension of the study of geomechanics to pavement engineering techniques with the principles of traffic flow theory and pavement engineering techniques so that students can apply them to practice. The course covers traffic flow models, headway models, traffic fundamental diagrams, intersection design and assessment, pavement engineering and design, pavement condition survey and pavement management. This course will be assessed by individual based assignment, mid trimester exam, and final exam.
Subject_Description_39: Heat and Mass Transfer Engineering aims to equip future engineers with fundamental knowledge together with practical design and implementation skills for applications involving mass and energy balances, mass transfer, psychrometry, convection, heat conduction, and radiation heat transfer. Students will engage in engineering design project(s) involving selection, sizing and/or design of devices such as heat exchangers, fans, pumps, ducting, condensers, distillation columns and air conditioners. Students will be required to propose fit-for-purpose solutions that meet the competing demands of their profession including sustainability, legal issues and commercial aspects. Engineering responsibility and skills in leadership, project control, whole systems design, whole systems thinking, risk management and effective human relations will be refined through this course.
Subject_Description_40: This course provides a broad coverage and detailed discussion of principles and practices of technology and standards, and security protocols for computer networks. It covers topics related to the fundamental concepts needed to understand security in modern networking applications, including cryptography, digital signatures, authentication, access control, trust and privacy. An introduction to a selection of technologies and application areas is given. Current challenges that confront security designers and security administrators, identifying threats, evaluating risks, developing countermeasures are discussed. Security related to wireless networks and cloud, security models and vulnerabilities are also covered. Prerequisite: 1007ICT Computer Systems and Networks OR 1807ICT Computer and Network Architecture.

Description: This program will be available to commencing students at the Gold Coast and Nathan from 2021. You will gain knowledge and skills from across the broad environmental science spectrum, exploring environmental issues from social, physical and biological perspectives. On completion of core science courses in your first year of study, you will choose a major that suits your interests and career plans. The final year includes a "capstone" experience where you have the option to undertake a research project or participate in industry internships to gain employment-relevant experience. Combining a discipline specific major with a major in Environmental Management will equip you with the broad set of knowledge and skills needed to be an environmental science professional.
Career_Outcomes: Graduates may find employment in the following areas:
Subject_Description_1: This course introduces the fundamental concepts and methods of general chemistry. Basic skills of laboratory chemical analysis are developed. Lecture content includes three modules: Introduction and basic concepts; molecular structure and bonding; and energy and physical processes. Incompatible: 1001SCE Chemistry 1A, 1009ENV General Chemistry, 1001ENV Chemistry 1, 1023SCG Chemistry 1
Subject_Description_2: Understanding Australian Cities is an introductory overview of the origin, patterning and functioning of the urban system. The course specifically examines the dynamics of population, infrastructure, governance and culture in Australian cities. These understandings frame examination of the possibilities of planning intervention. This introductory course will allow students to better appreciate the range of planning challenges and the opportunities for further study. This course is delivered via weekly lectures and tutorials and is supplemented with web materials and readings.
Subject_Description_3: Mathematics underpins and informs all scientific fields and is the language of science. Quantitative Reasoning is a mathematics course with a difference. Students will learn how to translate scientific problems into mathematical form, and how to understand and interpret mathematical and numerical results. With modern software, they will use case studies to learn how to apply mathematical concepts, from basics up to simple calculus, to real-world scientific problems. Incompatible: 1013SCG
Subject_Description_4: Human Biology provides the foundation knowledge for human anatomy, physiology and cell biology inherent in the biological and biomedical sciences. The course examines the major body systems along with the integration and regulation of these physiological systems to maintain homeostasis.
Subject_Description_5: This course provides students with content related to organisations, people and employability and offers practical skills focusing on the development of employable skills whilst providing foundation knowledge of Employment Relations for their transition to and participation in the world of work. The course covers contemporary workplace issues from the employers and the employees perspective. Topics include, the changing nature of work and the contemporary workplace; managing people in organisations; developing employability skills, including professional values and social networking; workplace planning, recruitment and selection; training and talent development; performance in organisations; rewards and motivation; negotiation and communication and ethics in the workplace, in addition to the development of professional skills and awareness, industry knowledge and workplace readiness. Industry engagement will be a core strategy with video vignettes, guest speakers and case studies. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: 1001EHR Employment Relations/ 1081EHR Employment Relations/ EHR101 Employment Relations
Subject_Description_6: This course explores the future of work in a rapidly globalizing, knowledge and service-intensive economy. Advances in IT and associated technologies are enabling firms to automate and/or outsource routine work, displacing the jobs of low-skilled workers, while enhancing the power of knowledge workers. In parallel, new industries and forms of collaborative and distance-based work are emerging, offering new challenges and opportunities. This course investigates the causes of technological, industrial and organisational change and their potential impacts of work arrangements and stakeholder relationships. Strategies and policies for managing change and coping with the new world of work outlined, drawing on latest research from Australia and other countries. Students would investigate how the future of work affects the business landscape of both large companies and smaller firms. It would cover sources of value creation and the benefits and challenges of the new technologies. There will be an overview of IoT and futurist thinking and of selected technologies to examine how such digital innovations are being developed and used by leading organisations. Content will address the implications for managers of social media, big data, artificial intelligence and newer technological innovations.
Subject_Description_7: This course examines several major environmental challenges to society where natural systems have been severely affected as a result of the pressures of population growth, technology change, and economic growth based on increasing production and consumption. These issues will be considered from an interdisciplinary natural and social science perspective with a special secondary focus on the traditional knowledge of, and impacts to, First Nations' Peoples. Assessment for this course will emphasise development of diverse communication skills relevant for environmental analysis and effective problem-solving for achieving sustainability.
Subject_Description_8: This course introduces the main environmental spheres and important natural processes of the Earth, considered as a series of systems interacting at various scales. Features of the lithosphere, atmosphere, hydrosphere and biosphere are explained, with emphasis given to the interrelationships between these spheres. In doing so, basic concepts of the more specialized fields of meteorology, climatology, hydrology, oceanography, soil science, geology, geomorphology and biogeochemistry will be studied. Incompatible: 1303ENV Earth Sciences, 1051AES Earth Sciences, 1302EAS Earth Sciences, 1004EAS Earth Sciences and GIS, 1004ENV Earth Science and GIS.
Subject_Description_9: The aim of the course is to explain the way people behave and make decisions in a business environment and the role that information has in the context of decision-making. The course will introduce some elements of behavioural sciences and game theory applied to business problems. It will also tackle some of the critical questions around the use of information for business decision making: how to assess the validity/reliability and relevance of the information we receive? how to use it effectively? how to simplify information, make it relevant, and present it to different audiences? The course combines different aspects. First, it encourages students to account for the psychological, cognitive, emotional, cultural, and social factors that affects decisions made by individuals and organisations (e.g. private corporates, government, civil society, etc). Second it provides simple analytical tools to contextualise strategic decision-making in real world situations through lenses such as that of the consumer and the future role of social marketing. Third, it introduces students to the idea that business decision making requires reliable, timely information. The course takes a positive (as opposed to normative) approach to the analysis of interactive strategic decisions and behaviours. Through case studies, the course provides a description of what happens in a variety of business situations, with a focus on understanding the elements/dynamics that leads to a certain outcome of decision. In so doing, the course helps students identify the role of information (qualitative or quantitative), how it is sourced and assessed in terms of its validity/quality, and how it can be used to deal with uncertainty in decision-making. Basic approaches to the analysis, interpretation and presentation of various types of information are also discussed, including the foundations of big data analytics and qualitative data analysis.
Subject_Description_10: This course introduces students to the concept of environmental sustainability and its uses in solving real world problems. It explores the relationships between the natural, rural, industrial and urban environments and includes the study of the impact humans have upon nature. The course also considers the way environmental sustainability can be used to address environmental, economic and social issues in an integrated way. Assessment includes on-line tests, a written assignment, workshop exercises and an end of trimester examination. Incompatible: 1301ENV The Global Environment, 1181ENV Sustainable Development, 1161ENV Environmental Economics and Policy.
Subject_Description_11: This course covers core chemistry concepts in a biological and physical context in the areas of organic chemistry, inorganic chemistry and the energetics of matter and living systems. Incompatible courses: 1102SCE Chemistry 1B, 1104SCE Foundations of Biological and Medicinal Chemistry, 1106SCE Chemistry B, 1111AES Introduction to Environmental Chemistry, 1502ENV Chemistry II, 1502SCE Introduction to Nanoscience,
Subject_Description_12: Genetics and Evolutionary Biology is an introductory course that will provide foundational concepts in molecular genetics and evolutionary biology. Students will gain an understanding of the process of inheritance and mutation, population genetics, and evolutionary theory at the molecular, organismal and population level. Students will also learn commonly used genetic analysis methods and techniques employed by scientists. Course content will be delivered through a combination of lectures, workshops, and online material.
Subject_Description_13: The course revises and extends basic integral and differential calculus of one variable and introduces differential equations, in applied scientific contexts. It provides a foundation in the mathematical sciences needed for later studies. Prerequisite: A grade of SA over 4 semesters in Mathematics B (Qld high school subject), or equivalent study over 4 semesters of a high school subject that includes the study of differential and integral calculus or 1011SCG Mathematics 1A (grade equivalent to 4 or higher) .
Subject_Description_14: The course introduces basic vector algebra in two and three dimensions, matrices, complex numbers, probability and revises basic functions. It provides a foundation in the mathematical sciences for later studies in science and engineering. Prior Assumed Knowledge: It will be assumed that students have the knowledge equivalent to a grade of SA over 4 semesters in Mathematics B (Qld high school subject), or equivalent study over 4 semesters of a high school subject that includes the study of differential and integral calculus or 1017SCG">1017SCG Foundation Mathematics (grade of 4 or higher). For students who do not have this level of mathematics background, it is strongly suggested that they first complete 1017SCG">1017SCG Foundation Mathematics. Incompatible: 1010ENG Engineering Mathematics 1, 1011SCG Mathematics 1A, 1201BPS Mathematics 1A.
Subject_Description_15: This course provides knowledge and practice in the analytical, creative and strategic functions of marketing. The course presents a set of approaches and frameworks centred upon the "4Ps" (Product, Price, Place, and Promotion), to develop your competence to create a marketing plan, one of the major tools of business. Marketing starts with understanding consumer's preferences for products and services and attempts to satisfy their different wants and needs in a profitable manner. Prerequisites:NIL Co- requisites : NIL Incompatible: 1083MKT Introduction to Marketing, 1007IBA International Marketing
Subject_Description_16: Biological Systems is an introductory course that provides an appreciation of the main concepts of modern biology. Students will gain an understanding of the origin, function and structure of living organisms by examining life at increasing levels of biological complexity, from the molecular and cellular level to whole organisms and ecosystems. Course content will be delivered through a combination of lectures, workshops, laboratory sessions and online material. Incompatible: 1601ENV Biological Systems; 1
Subject_Description_17: Foundation Mathematics aims to provide a solid basis from which to build a wider set of mathematical skills across a broad range of disciplines. You may be looking to further studies in Education, IT, Business, Engineering, or any of the Physical or Social Sciences; all of which require a solid grounding in mathematics. The course has been constructed to cater for those who either did not study and pass Mathematical Methods (or Qld Maths B) in Year 11/12, OR have been away from study for some years and wish to refresh the mathematical skills required for further study. Successfully completing this course will satisfy all courses that have Mathematical Methods (or Qld Maths B) as a prerequisite, such as Linear Algebra and Calculus I. Foundation Mathematics covers the following topics. Working with Numbers, Algebraic methods, Solving equations, Understanding Functions, and both Differential and Integral Calculus. Mathematical thinking, as well as problem solving and reasoning, are developed throughout the course. Assumed Background: Basic mathematical skills to Year 10 level. Any Senior School Mathematics course would be an advantage but not necessary. Note that Foundation Mathematics is not permitted for students who have HA or VHA in Year 12 Mathematics B (Qld high school subject), or SA or higher in Year 12 Mathematics C (Qld High school subject), or the equivalent.
Subject_Description_18: This course considers the molecular organisation of cells and the biochemical properties of the major classes of biological compounds which exist in, and contribute to, the cellular environment eg amino acids, carbohydrates and lipids. It covers the properties of water, pH and buffers, the structure and function of proteins, including an introduction to enzymes, the cell membrane and membrane transport.
Subject_Description_19: This course provides an introduction to the basic concepts and practices of data analysis and inferential statistics. It will provide and understanding of several techniques including testing one or more means from sampled populations (t-Tests and ANOVAs), relationships between scale variables (correlations and regressions), and contingency table analysis (Chi-square tests). The course places emphasis on understanding the use of appropriate data for these tests, the use of exploratory data analysis and the underlying distributions and assumptions associated with these tests. Students will learn how to carry out these tests by hand, via the use of statistical software (SAS or SPSS), check assumptions, interpret results and report findings in plain English. Assumed prior knowledge: Grade 12 Maths A or B or equivalent. Incompatible: 1003ENV Statistics, 2012MSC Biostatistics, 2012HSC, Intro to Biomedical Data Analysis, Bioinformatics, 1003PSY Research Methods and Statistics in Psychology, 1002MSC Introduction to Biomedical Data Analysis

Description: International students must be in Australia and able to attend campus to commence this program. You will gain the skills and  knowledge in the physical, biomedical and psychological sciences that you will  need to become an exercise specialist. You will learn the role of exercise in  health maintenance and rehabilitation. Students undertaking the professional  practice placement course will have an opportunity to put their knowledge and skills into practice. Honours is available through an additional year of study.
Career_Outcomes: You will be prepared for work as an exercise specialist for community or sports organisations as a clinical scientist specialising in cardiac; respiratory and sleep medicine; as a rehabilitation, sports or recreation manager; a strength and conditioning coach; or as an occupational health and safety officer.
Subject_Description_1: Exercise Science Practicum is a mandatory course in the Bachelor of Exercise Science program. The rationale for including this course is to make students aware of the requirements of the industry they wish to enter and the working environment of various organisations in which they may seek employment. The course is designed to link and complement the student's program of study by introducing them to the work environment. The main purposes of this course are: a) to provide students with work experience within the industry they may seek to be employed; (b) to introduce students to various topics concerning the work environment and field of exercise science; and (c) to outline career planning procedures. Students need to have successfully completed the first two years of the Bachelor of Exercise Science program.
Subject_Description_2: This course, Research Methods and Statistics provides students with the mathematical skills used in measurement, processing and analysing of data typical of those obtained in Exercise Science. The course also provides an introduction to experimental design and statistical analyses appropriate to investigations in Exercise Science. No Prererquisites.
Subject_or_Unit_3: FOUNDATIONS OF EXERCISE AND SPORTS SCIENCE
Subject_Description_3: Exercise and Sports Science is a multidisciplinary field encompassing physiology, biomechanics, nutrition and the psychosocial aspects of human movement. This course provides foundational knowledge that is key to developing a sound base for understanding the health and wellness continuum between performance athletes and chronic disease patients. Theoretical and practical learning in the biophysical knowledge domains (cell & tissue physiology as well as biophysics) will be combined with professional awareness and career pathways in the exercise and sports science industry. Note. Only available to students enrolled in AHS Programs.
Subject_Description_4: This course introduces organic and biological chemistry, which underpins all biochemical processes and the molecular basis of life. Pre-Requisite: 1001MSC Chemistry of Biological Systems I or 1023SCG Chemistry 1 Assumed Knowledge: Maths B and One of Biology, Chemistry or Physics (4SA).
Subject_Description_5: This course focuses on changes in body systems and function that occur throughout the lifespan, and how exercise may be used to improve function. The effects of sedentary behaviour and common lifestyle-related diseases on function and the benefits of physical activity are explored. Pre-requisites: 1001AHS Foundations of Exercise and Sports Science, 1016MSC Anatomy and Physiology Systems I and 1017MSC Anatomy and Physiology Systems II.
Subject_Description_6: This course introduces students to key motor learning and control concepts relating to exercise and sport contexts. Upon completion of the course students will have developed the ability to interpret, contrast, and evaluate a range of motor learning and control approaches, theories and models. Students will also develop a practical appreciation of key concepts in terms of designing effective skill acquisition and performance environments for exercise and sport settings.
Subject_Description_7: This course introduces the basic chemical principles that underlie biological systems. The foundation provided in this course will allow students to be able to further develop their chemistry knowledge and skills relevant to health and medical sciences in later years. Assumed Knowledge: Maths B and One of Biology, Chemistry or Physics. Incompatible with 1023SCG Chemistry I
Subject_Description_8: This Foundation Year course takes a multi-disciplinary and integrated approach to examine population health in the 21st century. Using a socio-ecological perspective, the course will take a systems approach (i.e. from prevention through to treatment) to introduce students to the environmental, social and behavioural determinants of health and disease. The course will link these determinants with global and national priority health challenges of the 21st century together with the implications for effective health care practice.
Subject_Description_9: Introductory Biomechanics is an introductory biomechanics course designed for exercise science and physiotherapy students. Prerequitise 1001AHS Foundations of Exercise and Sports Science
Subject_Description_10: This course introduces students to the fundamental design, organisation and workings of the human nervous system.
Subject_Description_11: The course introduces students to the fundamental principles of psychology as applied to the areas of exercise, sport and rehabilitation. Issues relevant to participants (across the lifespan and functional capacity), patients, coaches, practitioners, and promoters involved in the optimization of individual and group performance are considered. Prerequisite: 1001PSY - Introduction to Psychology 1 OR 1002PSY - Introduction to Psychology 2 OR equivalent
Subject_Description_12: This course provides students with an understanding of the relationship between nutrition, health and exercise performance. Students will develop an understanding of nutrient metabolism during exercise and the role of food, fluid and nutrition supplements in enhancing exercise performance, training and recovery. Current nutrition recommendations for overall health and well-being will also be covered along with nutrition and physical activity guidelines for modifying body composition and preventing and managing chronic disease.
Subject_Description_13: This course aims to integrate knowledge acquired in previous courses of the program. 3005AHS Exercise Programming & Prescription I is focused strongly on the theoretical basis underpinning exercise prescription. The principles are revised and then further developed with the extension of evidence based prescription Theoretical knowledge will be complemented by strong practical skills and sound reasoning skills, integrated to enable safe and effective measurement and prescription skills.
Subject_Description_14: This course builds on content from previous trimesters, and provides students with an in-depth understanding of the physiological responses that occur during exercise. Particular attention will be given to the responses of the cardiovascular, respiratory, endocrine and metabolic systems during exercise, their integration and regulation. The adaptations to acute and chronic exercise will be examined in healthy and diseased populations. Prerequisites: 2012AHS Integrated Systems Physiology or 2004AHS Exercise, Health and Disease
Subject_Description_15: Musculoskeletal Biomechanics is the science that examines the internal and external forces acting on a body and the effects produced by these forces. This course builds upon knowledge and skills gained in Introductory Biomechanics. Topics covered include gait analysis, tissue mechanics, musculoskeletal biomechanics, with application to sport, work and the clinical and rehabilitation settings.
Subject_Description_16: Five body systems: Skeletal, Muscle, Nervous, Endocrine and Reproductive Systems are studied in this course, which integrates anatomy with physiology. The theory presented in this course is supported by practical laboratory experiences, which include the study of human cadaveric material.
Subject_Description_17: This course provides a foundation for understanding the cognitive and biological bases of human behaviour, including the role of the brain and neural processes in behaviour, perception (how the senses allow you to see, hear, taste, touch and smell the world around you), conditioning and learning (how humans and other animals learn about their environment), cognition and memory (how people think, solve problems and remember). Drawing on various research traditions in experimental psychology, this course demonstrates how cognitive and biological psychology contributes to our knowledge of human well-being and performance. Students apply this knowledge through a series of practical in-class exercises. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: 1004HLS_Y2
Subject_Description_18: Language and Communication for Health is offered to students from a non-English speaking background (NESB). Students whose first language is English are NOT PERMITTED to undertake this course. The aim of this course is to introduce students to the language, knowledge and communication skills required for study and practice in their discipline. A further aim is to develop and practice English language skills relevant to the academic culture of Australian universities. It therefore involves intensive English language practice and language immersion activities, with elements applied to contextualised, discipline-specific settings. This course constitutes part of the overall English Language Enhancement Strategy at Griffith University. Prerequisites: NIL; Incompatible: 5901LHS/5901LAL, 5903LHS/5903LAL, 5904LHS/5904LAL and 5902LAL.
Subject_Description_19: This course covers the anatomy and physiology of the cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, digestive and immune systems. Both the study of the anatomy and the physiology of these systems draws on the experience gained in the lectures, laboratories and practicums. Prerequisites for Gold Coast students: 1016MSC">1016MSC Anatomy and Physiology Systems I, and 1014MSC Cells, Tissues and Regulation OR 1001AHS Foundations of Exercise and Sport Science. Prerequisites for Nathan students: 1016MSC">1016MSC Anatomy and Physiology Systems I and 1001NSC Human Biology.
Subject_Description_20: This course is designed to provide students with advanced theoretical knowledge and practical skills for the prescription of resistance, endurance, and speed exercise programming. The information presented in 3013AHS will be applicable for those wanting to improve health and fitness, sports performance and rehabilitating and preventing common musculoskeletal injuries. Effective exercise prescription requires identifying individuals' goals, competency in determining specific demands of different sports, understanding exercise responses and adaptations and the ability to design and individualised and evidence based training program. Finally, the course will also further develop a student's appreciation on how evidence-based research supports exercise prescription.
Subject_Description_21: This course provides a sound theoretical and practical background in clinical exercise testing including specificity, sensitivity, reliability, and validity of selected tests and procedures. Particular attention is given to the interpretation of test results from patients with cardiovascular or lung disease as well as highly trained athletes, and aged persons. Case studies will be widely used. The laboratory sessions are designed to help students develop technical skills needed to conduct a graded exercise test as well as understand the theoretical principles associated with exercise testing.
Subject_Description_22: Musculoskeletal Anatomy course has been designed to consolidate knowledge of structure and function of the musculoskeletal system. A thorough understanding of musculoskeletal anatomy is imperative to the practice of physiotherapists, exercise physiologists and other health professionals. Students will build on theoretical knowledge and practical skills obtained in prerequisite courses through a series of online lectures, specialised laboratory sessions and a weekly online tutorial. Prerequisite: 1016MSC Anatomy & Physiology Systems I or other approved anatomy course

Description: This program is designed to provide students with an opportunity to undertake advanced study and supervised research work in the specialisation defined by their undergraduate degree program within the context of a multidisciplinary cohort. The research skills developed within this program will provide an attractive credential for students seeking employment in the public or private sectors. The program will also provide the necessary preparation for entry into a higher degree research program. The multidisciplinary context of the program, involving team-teaching of students and the sharing of coursework and seminar experiences across disciplines will be invaluable to students given the importance of a multidisciplinary approach to researchers and practitioners seeking to understand complex problems in health.
Career_Outcomes: Graduates of the program will be able to plan and conduct research in exercise science and related health disciplines, and therefore will be well-placed for positions in the private, not for profit, and public sectors. In addition, graduates will be eligible to apply for admission to higher degree research programs, thereby preparing them for high level research careers.

Course: Bachelor of Film and Screen Media Production
Description:
You will receive a hands-on education across various formats, including high
definition video, and will have access to a state of the art cinema. You will learn
how to work in a team to bring visions to life on the screen, as well as gain a
thorough grounding in the history, practice and critical analysis of film. You will have the choice of electives in editing, producing, cinematography, directing and production design, among many
others. You will also take courses in screen production and screen distribution,
which will help you learn about finding support and audiences for your
screen production work. Your academic studies will be enhanced by regular exposure to national
and international artists-in-residence working in different areas of film
and screen media production, as well as a supervised work placement.
Career_Outcomes:
Depending on your areas of specialisation and choice of electives, your
career options could include roles in the mainstream film and television
industries, commercials, music videos, corporate videos, streamed online
content, film festivals and awards and video/digital art practice.
Subject_Description_1: This 20CP signature course is the first half of the major production project for year three and involves industry sized crews working together to produce short form projects across various storytelling formats including drama, documentary, television and interactive. Scripts and projects are competitively pitched at the start of the course, with a select number of projects forming the production slate.
Subject_Description_2: Asia Pacific film (Eastern, South-eastern, and South) as well as emerging Middle East explorations. Themes included a culture's accepted cinematic structures and expectations as well as issues of globalisation and cultural and political modernity in film. Topics include the concept of national cinemas and their distinct approaches, traditions, and genres as well the relationship between "First" and "Third" cinemas, issues of traditional and modernization, and melodrama as a transnational cinematic mode. Included will be Chinese (Hong Kong, Mainland, Taiwan), Southeast (Malaysia, Philippines, Thailand, Indonesia), Japan, India, Western Asia (Turkey, Iran, Israel, Lebanon) and Australia. The course will include film clips and interviews with filmmakers along with key weekly screenings. Assessment will include participation, a journal, and a curatorial essay. This is an online course.
Subject_Description_3: This course explores entrepreneurial career-building options in the local and global screen industries by allowing students to work on their own business idea, which they could with them after graduation.
Subject_Description_4: Where do our stories come from? This course introduces students to basic principles of ideation, narrative and storytelling. Through personal storytelling, students will explore film theory and narrative as a means of communicating and understanding the world around them.
Subject_or_Unit_5: REAL PEOPLE, TRUE STORIES: DOCUMENTARY AND CLIENT-BASED CONTENT
Subject_Description_5: Building on skills and knowledge acquired in Year 1, this course expands students knowledge of and ability in making non-fiction, single camera screen projects.
Subject_Description_6: In this course students will expand the skills and knowledge they have explored in Television Studio Production [1719GFS] in the development and 'as live' recording of a 12-minute magazine show.
Subject_Description_7: This course introduces students to the fundamental elements and techniques of narrative writing for screen-based projects, and how a consideration for audiences influences the process. Applying a sound understanding of narrative form, structure, scriptwriting techniques and strategies, students will work towards producing a screenplay in professional format.
Subject_Description_8: Through the application of the skills and knowledge learned thus far, students will create screen-based short stories.
Subject_Description_9: This course exposes students to the final stage of the storytelling process: post-production - including technical, creative and editorial concepts and skills. Collaboration, feedback and reflection are critical components of this course.
Subject_Description_10: This course expands students knowledge and ability in narrative storytelling by focusing on narrative in an episodic form. A specific focus of this course will be on the collaborative nature of working in episodic filmmaking.
Subject_Description_11: This subject provides a collaborative space where students from animation, games and film work together to devise, plan and create documentation to EPOC (electronic proof of concept) stage for an interactive project. The subject focuses on the idea of interactivity in either the physical or digital realm, or a combination of the two. The creation of cogent storyworlds and engaging interactivity will be the hallmarks of successful assessment items in this course.
Subject_Description_12: This introductory course develops television market awareness, idea pitching and a knowledge of visual effects history, workflow and basic compositing skills.
Subject_Description_13: This 10CP signature course is the second half of the major production project for year three and involves industry sized crews working together to produce short form projects across various storytelling formats including drama, documentary, television and interactive.
Subject_Description_14: This introductory course develops a critical awareness of the history, impact and future of studio television and provides hands-on training in the technologies, production procedures and creative opportunities of live, or 'as live', multi-camera production.
Subject_Description_15: In this course, students explore the expression of a story through mise-en-scene, cinematography and sound.

Course: Bachelor of Film and Screen Media Production (Honours)
Description: This Honours program will provide a fourth year of study for students who have completed the Bachelor of Film and Screen Media Production (1284), or an equivalent undergraduate program. It is a full-time or part-time program that comprises a significant independent film or screen media project to be completed under formal supervision. This project is complemented by associated methodological and theoretical courses and an appropriate elective course to be chosen with the supervisor's approval. As well as the opportunity for career and skill advancement, this Honours program creates a pathway for Film students to move into research and higher degree studies - Master of Visual Arts (5052), Doctor of Visual Arts (6009) or Doctor of Philosophy (6001).
Career_Outcomes: Graduates from the Bachelor of Film and Screen Media Production (Honours) program will be able to find high-level employment within the film and television and/or digital media professions or continue to research in the area by undertaking a research higher degree.

Description:
You will have the opportunity to gain experience in contemporary approaches to visual arts. You will develop studio skills and research methods and focus on both theory and practice. You will develop an appreciation of the artist's role in contemporary society and become equipped for a career in a particular visual arts field. In your first year, you will gain a grounding in the fundamental aspects of visual art practice and theory and develop your individual skills, abilities and
interests. In your second and third years, you will focus your studies towards your major studio area, while developing a wide range of skills, concepts
and experience in other studio areas. Quotas apply to studio majors.
Career_Outcomes: You will be qualified for a career in your specialised study area, or in combination with other areas, be eligible to apply for entry to a graduate entry teacher preparation degree. You will be prepared for work in areas such as in the arts, education and administration.
Subject_Description_1: In this action research course students will consolidate reflexive, arts-based research processes and informing theoretical discourses established in 3365QCA">3365QCA_P1 towards a major body of work suitable for professional presentation. Students will be able to critically articulate and disseminate their work in professional and higher learning contexts. This course replaces the original 3365QCA">3365QCA (20CP).
Subject_Description_2: Foundation Studies in Art Theory is made up of two first year courses. The first of these is 1216QCA Introduction to Western Art. The second is this course, 1217QCA Modern Art and its Legacies. This course introduces students to the concepts of Modernity, Modernism and Postmodernism and considers their legacy for contemporary creative practices. The course combines a chronological survey of European and American avant-garde art movements with themes and theories relevant to contemporary practice. The course focuses on art and photography as located within a broader field of creative practice including dance, design, film, literature and theatre.
Subject_Description_3: Conducted through seminars and lectures, this course considers contemporary visual arts in the context of a global cultural landscape. The course is designed to engage students directly with the histories, tensions and circumstances of global visual arts practice. An investigation of the nuances, sensitivities, protocols and complexities of specific practitioners, movements and events will enable the student to apply a sophisticated and critical knowledge to global contexts with an understanding of a diversity of perspectives. Students will also develop communication skills that reflect contextual awareness and responsiveness to rich and complex intercultural dynamics. This is a third year course. Students must have completed all second year art theory and second year visual arts major courses prior to enrolment.
Subject_Description_4: This course provides an introduction to practices from the Ancient Greeks up until the early 20th century. Students will gain an understanding of key art historical concepts as well as the social, cultural, political and religious contexts for art.
Subject_Description_5: The course complements Studio Foundations 1 to provide an intensive introduction to the materials, methods, concepts and concerns of contemporary visual arts practice. Lecture and studio delivery continues the development of agile and lateral thinking through visual methods rooted in disciplinary and interdisciplinary knowledge frameworks. Studio investigations are grounded in an interdisciplinary framework of sculpture, jewellery/small objects, painting, photography and print media.
Subject_Description_6: This course provides an intensive introduction to the materials, methods, concepts and concerns of contemporary visual arts practice in a multi-disciplinary matrix. Lecture content and studio exercises engage with visual thinking, concept development, material investigation and a diversity of practice as foundational catalysts for lifelong learning. The course initiates responsive approaches to arts practice and reflective learning in a rich, complex and diverse cultural environment. This course complements Studio Foundations 2.
Subject_Description_7: This action research course initiates discourse on ways in which contextual theory informs and shapes the planning stages of arts-based research. Students will establish foundational knowledge of research approaches and methodological innovation towards a preliminary practice-led research project.
Subject_Description_8: Globalisation has had a profound impact on our world, this course examines how these changes have impacted upon the production, exhibition, and consumption of contemporary art. The first part of the course examines the chief theorists of contemporary art (Terry Smith, Hans Belting and Peter Osborne). The second part examines key themes and concepts that have been used to understand the kinds of contemporary art made now. We will consider key theories, such as postcolonialism, and key contemporary themes and issues, such as forced migration, injustice, centre/periphery dynamics, and the fate of the local and the regional in an interconnected world. Pre-requisite: 1209QCA (Mapping the Postmodern) or equivalent.
Subject_or_Unit_9: PROFESSIONAL PRACTICES IN THE VISUAL ARTS
Subject_Description_9: This course prepares students for life and work beyond graduation. Students will explore creative arts industries and design strategies for enhancing their professional practice. Specific skills including CV building, writing artist statements, grant writing, networking and proposal development. In conjunction with seminars led by professional practitioners, students will also investigate arts law, finance, business models, entrepreneurship, copyright law, professional protocols and the attitudes and dispositions of professional visual arts practitioners.
Subject_Description_10: This course builds on ways in which theory and studio practice may extend and inform each other via an arts-based research project. This course works to consolidate studio processes towards a major body of work suitable for professional presentation and prepares students to critically articulate and disseminate their work in professional and higher learning contexts.

Description: The Bachelor of Fine Art (Honours) is a full-time or part-time program that has been designed to enable students (who have demonstrated substantial ability at an undergraduate level) to develop their practical expertise and theoretical understanding to a more advanced level.
Subject_Description_1: Honours Research Project constitutes a 40CP honours research commitment within the (Bachelor of Fine Art (Honours) and Bachelor of Photography (Honours). Each of the four components of the course combine to introduce students to the rigors of research and engage them in an advanced level of study within visual practice. The expectation is that the research project undertaken will be based within the visual and incorporates high levels of visual literacy. Assessment of the four courses will culminate in one assessment item. Honours Research Project is presented with the Exegesis (completed in 6012QCA) for assessment in a professional context at the completion of all four courses. Co-requisite/Pre-requisite: 6303QCA Visual Arts Research Methods.
Subject_Description_2: Excellence in practice is predicated on a reflective and rigorous approach to creative practice as a method of inquiry and comment. This course introduces students to a number of exemplarily research practices through which they may contextualise their work. It looks at different modes of inquiry and encourages students to develop research practices that are appropriate to their particular area of study. This course provides an opportunity for students to explore the basic principles of research methods and consider how these may be applied to their research project. Students will identify their topic/research question and appropriate methods of inquiry through peer review, students will present their research topic, investigations and work-in-progress for scholarly interrogation.
Subject_Description_3: Honours Research Project constitutes a 40CP honours research commitment within the (Bachelor of Fine Art (Honours) and Bachelor of Photography (Honours). Each of the four components of the course combine to introduce students to the rigors of research and engage them in an advanced level of study within visual practice. The expectation is that the research project undertaken will be based within the visual and incorporates high levels of visual literacy. Assessment of the four courses will culminate in one assessment item. Honours Research Project includes the practical component and the exegesis for assessment in a professional context at the completion of all four courses Co-requisite/Pre-requisite: 6303QCA">6303QCA Visual Arts Research Methods.Co-requisite/Pre-requisite: 6303QCA">6303QCA Visual Arts Research Methods.
Subject_Description_4: Honours Research Project constitutes a 40CP honours research commitment within the (Bachelor of Fine Art (Honours) and Bachelor of Photography (Honours). Each of the four components of the course combine to introduce students to the rigors of research and engage them in an advanced level of study within visual practice. The expectation is that the research project undertaken will be based within the visual and incorporates high levels of visual literacy. Assessment of the four courses will culminate in one assessment item. Honours Research Project is presented with the Exegesis (completed in 6012QCA) for assessment in a professional context at the completion of all four courses. Co-requisite/Pre-requisite: 6303QCA Visual Arts Research Methods.
Subject_Description_5: Honours Research Project constitutes a 40CP honours research commitment within the (Bachelor of Fine Art (Honours) and Bachelor of Photography (Honours). Each of the four components of the course combine to introduce students to the rigors of research and engage them in an advanced level of study within visual practice. The expectation is that the research project undertaken will be based within the visual and incorporates high levels of visual literacy. Assessment of the four courses will culminate in one assessment item. Honours Research Project is presented with the Exegesis (completed in 6012QCA) for assessment in a professional context at the completion of all four courses. Co-requisite/Pre-requisite: 6303QCA Visual Arts Research Methods.
Subject_or_Unit_6: COMMUNICATING RESEARCH IN THE VISUAL ARTS
Subject_Description_6: This course will assist you in resolving the two major outputs of practice-led research in the visual arts: an exegesis and exhibition of creative practice. Seminars are geared towards both academic writing and practice development, with a view to equipping you with the tools required for documenting, critically evaluating and communicating your research. Topics include the writing and refinement of core exegesis writing components as well as appropriate methodologies for creative outcomes. The subject facilitates the communication and management of self- directed research projects with written and creative outputs.

Description:
