Students develop competencies in complex part, assembly and drawing development including physical dynamics, surfacing, performance enhanced component assembly, applied problem solving with geometric & mathematical dimension relationships, detailed drawing and file management to prepare you for an international working environment. Pre-requisite: 2639QCA - Digital Modelling for Design
Subject_Description_2: This course provides an introduction to designing for students working in 3D across related disciplines, such as product and interiors, art and engineering, jewellery and graphic objects. Students develop a design process during the course that they can build on in future courses, with the creativity, research skills and understanding to frame design problems, create design intent, develop their designs fed by active research, and present concepts that respond to those problems. It also involves practical activities to develop drawing for design skills, studio modelling skills (e.g. cardboard and foam) and creative communication skills.
Subject_Description_3: Designers are increasingly working in the digital realm, with advances in electronics opening up new possibilities and challenging preconceptions about the design of interactive products and electrical devices. This course provides designers with an introduction to how electronics are supporting design innovation, and practical studio experience of the fundamentals of how electrical devices operate and how to build electronic circuits.
Subject_Description_4: Engineering solutions are developed from an in depth understanding of the subject knowledge combined with a creative approach to problem solving that takes a step back from details to consider the challenge as a whole. Complex problem solving involves an understanding of individuals and systems, interconnections and innovation. Furthermore these solutions must also be considered in terms of sustainable development. This course introduces the student to engineering design through a project-based approach to the development of a product or piece of infrastructure as part of small design team.
Subject_Description_5: This course introduces students to the fundamental precepts of product design. Building on the introduction to design process in the first year, students have the opportunity to develop their approach to design, their particular interests and focus and the skills to support the resolution of a design idea. The creation of object outcomes using advanced technologies is supported in this course, and the contrast between conventional technology and advanced technology, and designing and specifying for both are explored.
Subject_Description_6: This course focuses on the design and manufacture of fibre reinforced composites. The emphasis is on a practical exploration. The course covers the basic make up of composites (fibres and matrices), mould construction, and the design and fabrication of composite parts and structures. Composite manufacturing processes, including basic wet layup and advanced methods such as vacuum bagging and prepreg moulding are addressed in detail. Skills are taught, practiced and assessed in an experiential learning mode.
Subject_Description_7: Visual communication is a powerful force to drive new ideas, and obtaining access to the tools that 'make media' is an integral part of a perpetually changing world. It has the power to influence society (think: body image, sexualised imagery, consumerism) and environment (think: greenwashing, property development, transport industries) and culture (think: political campaigns, volunteerism, social media).
Subject_Description_8: Globalisation, Industrial revolution 2.0 and Web 2.0 are changing the way that industrial designers operate. It is now much easier for graduates to work overseas, to work in Australia but with global partners, or to create and market their own products. Innovation in design through a response to changing practice, the changing relationship of designers and consumers, of designers and off shore production, of designers to making through innovations in digital fabrication mean that students need to be introduced to new ways of working and thinking about work. This course supports the development of an internationalized cohort of graduate entrepreneurs and innovators who can take advantage of the emerging opportunities in industrial design practice in response to improved global communication, global networks and advanced technologies.
Subject_Description_9: Mechanical Engineering Design is the creative development of mechanical products or systems. This course focuses on mechanical design through a project based learning approach. Students will work on a design and analyse (and/or build) project, developing a solution to a real-world engineering design problem. Assessment is by a written design report, oral presentation/s and peer group assessment when relevant.
Subject_Description_10: Design history in its traditional form focuses on design movements, designers and the materiality of the design object and the ways it is connected to production and consumption, integrated in circulated systems of meaning. This course will investigate the social dimension of design in and beyond Western culture and will pose a series of critical questions that will reveal design's wider historical impact, consequences and relation transformations of human understanding in and of the organic and artificial material world.
Subject_Description_11: This experiential learning course introduces students to the engineering design process and professional aspects of being an Engineer or Industrial Designer. The course takes into consideration the increasingly complex interactions between engineering systems, project stakeholders and the environment, including the positive role of engineering in sustainable development as well as the potentially adverse impacts of engineering activities. Exposure to engineers and designers who are in the workforce will be a feature of this course.
Subject_Description_12: This course introduces designing for 3D printing. This practical course introduces students to key stages of the design development process and human centred design strategies, identifying user behaviours and needs in the development of niche products. Fundamental skills are developed in the design and preparation of digital files, to create resolved 3D printed prototypes.
Subject_Description_13: The course considers the fundamental properties of metals and non-metallic materials. Students are introduced to the atomic and microstructure of materials and their relationship to mechanical and electrical properties. The course explores the mechanical concepts of stress, strain, elongation and material failure (including testing) and the phenomenon of electrical conduction. This course will be offered from 2017 in trimester 1 and 3, and replaces 1502ENG.
Subject_Description_14: This course introduces designing for 3D printing. This practical course introduces students to key stages of the design development process and human centred design strategies, identifying user behaviours and needs in the development of niche products. Fundamental skills are developed in the design and preparation of digital files, to create resolved 3D printed prototypes.
Subject_Description_15: Whilst 3D designers are focused on object outcomes, good design is situational. This course introduces the student to more complex problems, such as design meets disability, or large scale projects where outcomes may require design research, design process and practice with a transdisciplinary approach.
Subject_Description_16: This is the capstone course for all third year students. The course allows students to critically examine their place within their chosen discipline and to respond by producing a major studio outcome. Students are encouraged to scope and develop their own project. The course emphasises the integration of creative and innovative applications of the design and visual communication processes to project outcomes. Wherever possible, folio-based projects are undertaken.
Subject_Description_17: This course is a foundation for mechanical engineering design. It introduces students to the basic concepts of heat, thermodynamics and fluid flow. The necessary mathematical concepts will be introduced as required.
Subject_Description_18: The course introduces structural concepts to architect students. The behaviour of structures will be covered to give the future architect an overall understanding of structural engineering. Fundamental structural mechanics concepts and structural design principles will be covered in some detail. Topics taught include equilibrium, internal forces, stress, structural elements and systems, design loads, load transfer, buildings... The course is taught as a series of weekly lectures and tutorials, supported by laboratory experiments.
Subject_Description_19: Mechanics (or engineering mechanics) is both a foundation and a framework for the Industrial Design program, as well as most engineering disciplines. This course provides a basic knowledge of introductory statics, with the elements of elasticity and dynamics, and their principles and applications in design. The necessary mathematical and physical concepts will be introduced as required.
Subject_Description_20: For product solutions (commercial, industrial, medical etc) to work effectively, the industrial designer needs to design for the ergonomics relating to the human machine interface and the psychology that drives the emotional and action responses of the user to the product. In this course students study and evaluate current human machine interfaces, redesign and test examples of current products and, through project based learning, design for innovative interface interaction. The project outcomes are achieved through the application of research, design thinking, electronics and programming.

Description:
This program will be available to commencing students at the Gold Coast and Nathan from 2021. Be at the forefront of a constantly developing industry, ready to help shape the future.
With this degree, you'll achieve a high level of core IT technical knowledge and a major specialisation, ensuring you're prepared for a career across a vast number of roles and industries. You'll learn in purpose-built, industry-leading facilities crafted to reflect genuine workplaces. From our Big Data Visualisation Lab to our virtual reality, augmented reality, gamification and robotics labs, you will have ample opportunity to enhance your learning through cutting-edge technology. Throughout this degree, you'll be learning from world-class researchers and lecturers who have sent robots into space and predicted the outcome of federal elections using big data. What makes our IT degree stand out is the opportunity to put what you learn in the classroom into practice through work-integrated learning. From working in start-ups to large corporations, these opportunities are often a stepping-stone into future employment. Our Apps Factory is another opportunity for you to put what you learn into practice. We also have a wide range of industry contacts and partnerships that help you build your  professional network. Our Industry Advisory Board, which includes members such as IBM and Suncorp, ensures that our degree is focused on what employers are looking for and provides our students opportunities to meet and learn from industry-leading professionals. Depending on your major, you may find a job as a systems analyst, business analyst, software developer, database administrator, systems administrator, network and security administrator, network architect, technical writer, web developer, app developer, game developer, computer engineer, educator or researcher.  You'll be prepared for a career in commerce, industry, corporate IT, government or private consulting. Take control of your time  - This degree has intakes in Trimester 1, 2 and 3. So, whenever you're ready to study, we're ready to get you started. An array of inspiring overseas study opportunities, ranging from a few weeks to a year, are available for students in this degree. Find out more about going global at Griffith.
Career_Outcomes: *Source: Australian Government Job Outlook
Subject_Description_1: Coding is an important part of today's world. In this course you will learn how to code in a creative context, utilising a practical and hands-on approach, producing generative art, data visualisations, and interactive interfaces.
Subject_Description_2: Information derived from data is important to the management, productivity and competitive advantage of an organisation. Data must be efficiently collected, organized, retrieved and managed to make it meaningful to the organisation. It is the role of the IT professional to develop, deploy, manage and integrate data and information systems to support the organisation. This course includes the organisation, modeling, transformation and presentation of data. Incompatible with 1804ICT.
Subject_Description_3: In this course, students conduct an industry-based placement within a commercial or industrial environment under professional supervision while managing their learning and course assessment. The placement provides students with the opportunity to undertake a substantial body of work that has an industry application. This body of work will be focused on the student's academic degree and major, and may be project based working on a single implementation, or task based supporting the industry partner. Students work in close liaison with their industry supervisor and academic supervisor throughout the placement and are expected to demonstrate a good understanding of their work. To be eligible for placement, students must have completed the online registration form in the trimester prior to enrolment: https://bblearn.griffith.edu.au/webapps/blackboard/content/listContent.jsp?course_id=_66918_1&content_id=_4338944_1. Students must complete all requirements of the Griffith Sciences WIL office in preparation for placement, including confirmed allocation to an industry placement. Prerequisites: Students should be in the final year of study, having completed 80CP of first year level subjects and 80CP of second year level subjects which define the program and have a cumulative GPA of 5.0.
Subject_Description_4: This course is conducted with students participating in a Project-based engagement with industry. Projects are sourced from a range of industry and university partners that require significant analysis, design, development, communication and documentation effort. The problem is addressed by a number of students working in a team within the Agile lifecycle. Significant importance is placed on effective project management and excellent communication strategies between team members, the project manager, and with the industry client. Students work in close liaison with their external client and academic supervisor throughout the project and are expected to demonstrate a good understanding of their project. Prerequisites: 160CP of coursework, with a minimum of 60CP from second or third year courses.
Subject_Description_5: This course provides a foundational understanding of computing systems, taking into account the historical, social and technological context within which such systems have developed and are now deployed. The topics covered include the history of computing, the theoretical foundations of computing, the practical foundations of computer hardware and architecture, and an investigation into the theoretical and historical foundations of information technology and the social consequences of the deployment of this technology. This course was previously named Information Technology Fundamentals
Subject_Description_6: This course introduces students to the concepts, tools and skills required to participate in the ubiquitous World Wide Web. The course adopts a particular emphasis on the design and implementation of web pages using up to date technologies (html5, css3, javascript).
Subject_Description_7: This course introduces aspiring IT professionals to two topic areas that are critical to your working life. First, we will help you to unravel the ways in which information underpins business and organisational activity. Second, you will explore ways in which information systems are now critically important for managing activities and relationships with customers and suppliers. Incompatible: 1410ICT Introduction to Information Systems.
Subject_Description_8: One of the roles of the IT professional is to design and build software systems and integrate them into an organisation. This course develops the skills to gather requirements, then develop/source, evaluate and integrate components into a single system, and finally validate the system. It also covers the fundamentals of software lifecycles, quality, software development processes, project management and the interplay between IT applications and organisational processes and relevant standards and tools.
Subject_Description_9: Programming is a foundational skill for all computing disciplines. This course develops skills and concepts that are essential to good programming practice and problem solving. It covers fundamental programming concepts, event-driven programming, object-oriented programming, basic data structures, and algorithmic processes.
Subject_Description_10: This course is conducted with students participating in a Project-based engagement with industry. Projects are sourced from a range of industry and university partners that require significant analysis, design, development, communication and documentation effort. The problem is addressed by a number of students working in a team within the Agile lifecycle. Significant importance is placed on effective project management and excellent communication strategies between team members, the project manager, and with the industry client. Students work in close liaison with their external client and academic supervisor throughout the project and are expected to demonstrate a good understanding of their project. Prerequisites: 160CP of coursework, with a minimum of 60CP from second or third year courses. 3820ICT">3820ICT_P2 is a continuation of 3820ICT">3820ICT_P1
Subject_Description_11: Language and Communication for Sciences is offered to students from a non-English speaking background (NESB). Students whose first language is English are NOT PERMITTED to undertake this course. The aim of this course is to introduce students to the language, knowledge and communication skills required for study and practice in their discipline. A further aim is to develop and practice English language skills relevant to the academic culture of Australian universities. It therefore involves intensive English language practice and language immersion activities, with elements applied to contextualised, discipline-specific settings. This course constitutes part of the overall English Language Enhancement Strategy at Griffith University. Prerequisites: NIL; Incompatible: 5901LHS/5901LAL, 5902LHS/5902LAL, 5904LHS/5904LAL and 5903LAL.
Subject_Description_12: This course introduces the underlying structures and mechanisms of modern computer systems and networks. All students enrolled in an ICT degree need to have an understanding of the basic architecture and operation of computer systems. This course provides an overview of the hardware, software and network technologies that define modern computer systems. The course aims to provide students with the basic knowledge of how the components that define a computer work together and by extension an appreciation of the capabilities and limitations of computer systems. This knowledge assists students in the application of computing technologies to solve real world problems. This course material builds a foundation for further study in the field of information technology, and is a suitable prerequisite for many ICT courses. Incompatible: 1807ICT: Computer and Network Architectures.
Subject_Description_13: A key component to the discipline of Information Technology is the understanding and the advocacy of the user in the development of IT applications and systems. IT graduates must develop a mind-set that recognizes the importance of users and organisational contexts and employ user-centred methodologies in the development, evaluation, and deployment of IT applications and systems. This requires graduates to develop knowledge of HCI, including user and task analysis, human factors, ergonomics, application domains, user interface development tools and GUI frameworks, accessibility standards, and cognitive psychology.
Subject_Description_14: This course explores the major ethical, professional, social and legal issues arising from the widespread use of IT, highlighting dilemmas that may be faced by IT practitioners. The subject examines the key debates and controversies pertinent to IT and their social consequences through the use of key case studies. *This course replaces 2003ICT Professional Issues in IT. Prerequisite: Successful completion of 120CP of first or second year Information Technology /Multimedia courses
Subject_Description_15: Organisations typically use many disparate technologies to achieve their business objectives. This course first gives an overview of low-level technologies such as programming with a focus on code reuse, scripting techniques and software configuration tools. This is followed by a practical presentation of software packages commonly used for handling data and producing reports and presentations. Pre-Requisite: 2807ICT Programming Principles for BIT students OR 2701ICT Interactive Application Development OR 2702ICT Intelligent Media Systems for BCIM students
Subject_Description_16: This course is conducted with students participating in a project-based engagement with industry: projects are sought from a range of industry and university partners (project sponsors) that require significant development, communication and documentation effort. The problem is addressed by a number of students working in a group to form a student project team. Significant importance is placed on effective project management and excellent communication strategies between team members, the project manager, and with the industry client. Within this strand, students may undertake different "tracks" depending on the development lifecycle model appropriate to the project. Students work in close liaison with their external client and academic supervisor throughout the project and are expected to demonstrate a good understanding of their project. Students should be in the final year of study, having completed of 80CP of first year level subjects and 80CP of second year level subjects which define the program. Pre-requisite: Must have completed 160CP

Description: This program will be available to commencing students at Gold Coast and Nathan from 2021. The program aims to bring students to a level of maturity in their understanding and practice of scholarly work within the Computing and Information Technology area, as well as providing training in the techniques, skills and theoretical background necessary for subsequent postgraduate research.

This new degree brings together technical and practical skills in the fields of intelligent digital technologies. You will learn the fundamentals of ICT problem solving and high level programming skills, for application in cutting edge fields such as the Internet of Things (IoTs), robotics, app and web development, big data analysis, and virtual reality (VR) and augmented reality (AR) applications. In your first year you will learn about trends in emerging technologies, coding and human computer interaction. Choose between two majors, IoTs and Robotics or Programming for Visualisation and Entertainment, or undertake both majors. If you choose a single major you will have the flexibility to undertake electives of your choice. 
In your final year of studies, you will bring together your skills and knowledge to form Intelligent Digital Technologies for industry through a work integrated learning course.
Career_Outcomes: The Bachelor of Intelligent Digital Technologies program prepares students for careers as designers and developers for various cutting-edge technologies including Virtual Reality (VR) and Augmented Reality (AR), 3D visualisation, Internet of Things (IoTs), Robotics,  UAVs, Artificial Intelligence and Big Data.
Subject_Description_1: This course utilises advanced techniques and frameworks to teach Virtual Reality (VR) and Augmented Reality (AR) for immersive digital environments that can replicate lifelike physical environments or portray a fictional artificial world, and makes the user feel they are immersed in that environment in real-life.
Subject_Description_2: Engineering solutions are developed from an in depth understanding of the subject knowledge combined with a creative approach to problem solving that takes a step back from details to consider the challenge as a whole. Complex problem solving involves an understanding of individuals and systems, interconnections and innovation. Furthermore these solutions must also be considered in terms of sustainable development. This course introduces the student to engineering design through a project-based approach to the development of a product or piece of infrastructure as part of small design team.
Subject_Description_3: This course is conducted with students participating in a project-based engagement with industry: projects are sought from a range of industry and university partners (project sponsors) that require significant development, communication and documentation effort. The problem is addressed by a number of students working in a group to form a student project team. Significant importance is placed on effective project management and excellent communication strategies between team members, the project manager, and with the industry client. Within this strand, students may undertake different "tracks" depending on the development lifecycle model appropriate to the project. Students work in close liaison with their external client and academic supervisor throughout the project and are expected to demonstrate a good understanding of their project. Students should be in the final year of study, having completed of 80CP of first year level subjects and 80CP of second year level subjects which define the program. Pre-requisite: Must have completed 160CP
Subject_Description_4: Information derived from data is important to the management, productivity and competitive advantage of an organisation. Data must be efficiently collected, organized, retrieved and managed to make it meaningful to the organisation. It is the role of the IT professional to develop, deploy, manage and integrate data and information systems to support the organisation. This course includes the organisation, modeling, transformation and presentation of data. Incompatible with 1804ICT.
Subject_Description_5: This course explores the major ethical, professional, social and legal issues arising from the widespread use of IT, highlighting dilemmas that may be faced by IT practitioners. The subject examines the key debates and controversies pertinent to IT and their social consequences through the use of key case studies. *This course replaces 2003ICT Professional Issues in IT. Prerequisite: Successful completion of 120CP of first or second year Information Technology /Multimedia courses
Subject_Description_6: In this course, students conduct an industry-based placement within a commercial or industrial environment under professional supervision while managing their learning and course assessment. The placement provides students with the opportunity to undertake a substantial body of work that has an industry application. This body of work will be focused on the student's academic degree and major, and may be project based working on a single implementation, or task based supporting the industry partner. Students work in close liaison with their industry supervisor and academic supervisor throughout the placement and are expected to demonstrate a good understanding of their work. To be eligible for placement, students must have completed the online registration form in the trimester prior to enrolment: https://bblearn.griffith.edu.au/webapps/blackboard/content/listContent.jsp?course_id=_66918_1&content_id=_4338944_1. Students must complete all requirements of the Griffith Sciences WIL office in preparation for placement, including confirmed allocation to an industry placement. Prerequisites: Students should be in the final year of study, having completed 80CP of first year level subjects and 80CP of second year level subjects which define the program and have a cumulative GPA of 5.0.
Subject_Description_7: A key component to the discipline of Information Technology is the understanding and the advocacy of the user in the development of IT applications and systems. IT graduates must develop a mind-set that recognizes the importance of users and organisational contexts and employ user-centred methodologies in the development, evaluation, and deployment of IT applications and systems. This requires graduates to develop knowledge of HCI, including user and task analysis, human factors, ergonomics, application domains, user interface development tools and GUI frameworks, accessibility standards, and cognitive psychology.
Subject_Description_8: This course is conducted with students participating in a Project-based engagement with industry. Projects are sourced from a range of industry and university partners that require significant analysis, design, development, communication and documentation effort. The problem is addressed by a number of students working in a team within the Agile lifecycle. Significant importance is placed on effective project management and excellent communication strategies between team members, the project manager, and with the industry client. Students work in close liaison with their external client and academic supervisor throughout the project and are expected to demonstrate a good understanding of their project. Prerequisites: 160CP of coursework, with a minimum of 60CP from second or third year courses.
Subject_Description_9: This course introduces the underlying architecture and principles of modern robotic hardware, software, and communication that is the foundation of modern Intelligent Systems. The course provides students with the basic knowledge of how the components that define a system work together and by extension an appreciation of the capabilities and limitations of computer and robotic systems. This knowledge assists students in the application of technologies to solve problems and builds a foundation for further study in the field of robotics.
Subject_Description_10: User interactivity is at core of digital technology experiences. This course focuses on the implementation of highly interactive application development. The course introduces essential concepts, techniques, software tools and modern frameworks required for designing, creating and testing of interactive web and mobile applications.
Subject_Description_11: This course is conducted with students participating in a Project-based engagement with industry. Projects are sourced from a range of industry and university partners that require significant analysis, design, development, communication and documentation effort. The problem is addressed by a number of students working in a team within the Agile lifecycle. Significant importance is placed on effective project management and excellent communication strategies between team members, the project manager, and with the industry client. Students work in close liaison with their external client and academic supervisor throughout the project and are expected to demonstrate a good understanding of their project. Prerequisites: 160CP of coursework, with a minimum of 60CP from second or third year courses. 3820ICT">3820ICT_P2 is a continuation of 3820ICT">3820ICT_P1
Subject_Description_12: The 'Emerging Technologies' course provides students with a detailed level of knowledge and skills related to planning, designing, and integrating products and systems to meet the demands of the emerging technologies field. Emerging technologies are generally defined as a radically novel and relatively fast growing technology applications, such as smartphones, eLearning, eHealth, eCommerce, 3D printing, robotics, autonomous vehicles, Artificial Intelligence (AI), Internet of Things (IoTs), etc. This course will introduce various cutting-edge technologies and explore the interactions between the technologies and the users.
Subject_Description_13: One of the roles of the IT professional is to design and build software systems and integrate them into an organisation. This course develops the skills to gather requirements, then develop/source, evaluate and integrate components into a single system, and finally validate the system. It also covers the fundamentals of software lifecycles, quality, software development processes, project management and the interplay between IT applications and organisational processes and relevant standards and tools.
Subject_Description_14: This course provides you with an in-depth understanding of how to develop viable novel business ideas through empathetic design and customer discovery and validation. This course focuses on creativity, problem solving and critical thinking tools to create these novel solutions. Prerequisites: Nil. Co-requisites: Nil. Incompatible: 2043MKT Entrepreneurship and New Business Ventures/ 3041MKT Entrepreneurship and New Business Ventures/ 4313AHS Contributing to the Community
Subject_Description_15: The course introduces the foundations of Big Data in a manner that covers the key concepts and characteristics of big data analytics and its real-world application. Students will learn about the practical applications needed to perform analytical tasks with the primary focus being on the visualisation and representation of that data. THIS COURSE WILL BE OFFERED IN SEMI-INTENSIVE MODE (WEEK 1 TO 6) IN TRIMESTER 2, 2020.
Subject_Description_16: This course provides you with an in-depth understanding of the entrepreneurial process. It includes how to recognise new business opportunities, screen these for commercial and/or social viability, unlock market potential, and assess the potential customer demand in the context of competitive environments and financial constraints. This course requires you to identify a market opportunity and to develop ideas using a variety of tools including the Business Model Canvas to assess the viability of new business ideas. Incompatible: 3041MKT Entrepreneurship and New Business Ventures OR 4313AHS Contributing to the Community
Subject_Description_17: Coding is an important part of today's world. In this course you will learn how to code in a creative context, utilising a practical and hands-on approach, producing generative art, data visualisations, and interactive interfaces.
Subject_Description_18: Language and Communication for Sciences is offered to students from a non-English speaking background (NESB). Students whose first language is English are NOT PERMITTED to undertake this course. The aim of this course is to introduce students to the language, knowledge and communication skills required for study and practice in their discipline. A further aim is to develop and practice English language skills relevant to the academic culture of Australian universities. It therefore involves intensive English language practice and language immersion activities, with elements applied to contextualised, discipline-specific settings. This course constitutes part of the overall English Language Enhancement Strategy at Griffith University. Prerequisites: NIL; Incompatible: 5901LHS/5901LAL, 5902LHS/5902LAL, 5904LHS/5904LAL and 5903LAL.

Course: Bachelor of International Tourism and Hotel Management
Description: This degree program will also be available at Nathan from 2021. In this degree, you will gain an in-depth understanding of the tourism sector, underscored by sustainability principles. You will develop core business skills in areas such as financial management, leadership, management, marketing and strategic management, and enhance these with an understanding of how to manage employment relations in a culturally diverse context. Thanks to Griffith's close working relationship with the major hotel chains in South East Queensland and tourism operators, you will have the chance to gain knowledge from guest speakers and experience via a wide range of innovative work-integrated learning activities. You will learn industry-standard systems and graduate with the skills and knowledge employers want, and be fully aware of the culture, service and competitive aspects of international tourism and hotel corporations. You can complement your studies with a second major in:
Career_Outcomes: You will be prepared for work in a range of international tourism and hotel management roles, including in hotel and resort groups and the accommodation sector. You will also find opportunities in independent restaurants and internationally recognised chains, with entertainment and leisure providers, such as theme parks, with suppliers of goods and services to the hospitality industry, in airlines, and with local, state and federal tourism and regional planning authorities.
Subject_Description_1: Patterns of growth and development in the tourism and hospitality industry have long been influenced by innovation in technology - from modes of transport that facilitate travel, to the bespoke global distribution systems that connect the different segments of the travel, tourism and hospitality sectors. In this course, you will trace significant technological developments that have disrupted existing tourism & hospitality business models over time, and consider how technology influences the effectiveness of the overall tourism system. This course will also provide you with insights into leveraging technology to improve the economic, social and environmental sustainability of tourism and hospitality operations.
Subject_or_Unit_2: LANGUAGE AND COMMUNICATION FOR BUSINESS AND COMMERCE
Subject_Description_2: Language and Communication for Business and Commerce is offered to students from a non-English speaking background. Students whose first language is English are NOT PERMITTED to undertake this course. The aim of this course is to introduce you to the language, knowledge and communication skills required for study and practice in your discipline. A further aim is to develop and practice English language skills relevant to the academic culture of Australian universities. This course therefore involves intensive English language practice and language immersion activities, in the context of your own discipline. This course is part of the overall English Language Enhancement Strategy which Griffith University has implemented to enable students from non-English speaking backgrounds to develop academic English skills in their discipline. Prerequisites: NIL; Incompatible: 5902LHS/5902LAL, 5903LHS/5903LAL, 5904LHS/5904LAL and 5901LAL.
Subject_Description_3: In an increasingly complex financial system, and with an aging and longer living population, financial independence and effective financial decision making are seen as important life attributes and skills. The reality however is that many make poor financial decisions, fail to plan for their financial future, adequately protect themselves, their family and their assets, are easily influenced into poor/inappropriate financial products, and fall foul of schemes and scams. In other words there is low levels of financial literacy in the community, including in higher education graduates. A study of money and life will cover a range of content areas including planning and goal setting, behaviour and decision making, financial markets, services and products, rights and obligations under contracts, financial systems and household finances. This could also introduce fintech (including Bloomberg and the SSMIF). The course would provide a range of personal and professional development outcomes for students as well as improve their overall understanding of business. The course will be designed to be relevant for all students of the university and also has potential for development into a standalone credential/MOOC.
Subject_Description_4: The global tourism & hospitality industries are large, multi-faceted and complex, and represented by an array of stakeholders with both complementary and competing interests. The 'systems' perspective in this course has a threefold purpose: (1) you will learn the key sectors and stakeholders in the tourism and hospitality industries, and evaluate the interactions between them; (2) you will understand tourism as a socio-economic activity within the context of socio-cultural, political and operational systems (3) you will apply a systems thinking perspective that will highlight the complexity of tourism and hospitality systems and allow you to identify options for improving the sustainability of the global industry.
Subject_or_Unit_5: MANAGING RISK IN TOURISM, EVENTS AND HOSPITALITY
Subject_Description_5: This course examines risk management concepts and strategies, and disaster management frameworks within the context of the event and tourism industries. It firstly establishes a theoretical foundation which focuses on organisational and operational safeguards followed by consideration of a variety of risk management issues such as natural disasters, terrorism, public health, crowd control and pyrotechnics. This course is offered Gold Coast Trimester 2 DAY Nathan Trimester 2, Trimester 3 DAY Incompatible: 3201HSL Risk, Crisis and Disaster Management
Subject_Description_6: This course introduces students to a perspective of the purpose of business that embeds values such as responsible leadership, integrity and ethical behaviour, respect for others, trust, and sustainable enterprise. The relevance of these values and their impact on behaviour and outcomes in a business context is demonstrated to students through case studies, real world examples, and testimonials from industry partners. Following from the discussion of values, the course then looks at how businesses develop solutions to respond to increasing demand for sustainability, transparency and good governance. The framework of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) is introduced and used to examine the alignment between business practices and sustainable solutions to real life problems faced by a business. The course also considers the role and responsibility (including legal) of professionals and professional standards in today's society.
Subject_Description_7: Career Development: is designed to promote and support students' professional and career development within International Tourism and Hotel Management. This course will contribute to students' professional development through self-awareness exercises focusing on key management decision-making skills. In particular students will cover topics such as career planning, job searching and interviewing. Furthermore, through an exposure to real case studies, students will be given an opportunity to advance their competencies in identifying and applying appropriate theories to resolve business issues arising in today's dynamic hotel and tourism workplaces. Hence, assisting graduates to effectively transition into the work environment and be future leaders. Incompatible: 3400HSL Career Development This course is offered: Gold Coast: Trimester 1 and 2 Nathan: Trimester 1 and 2 Note: This course has a prerequiste Prerequisite: Must have successfully completed 160 Credit Points before enrolling in this course.
Subject_Description_8: The aim of the course is to explain the way people behave and make decisions in a business environment and the role that information has in the context of decision-making. The course will introduce some elements of behavioural sciences and game theory applied to business problems. It will also tackle some of the critical questions around the use of information for business decision making: how to assess the validity/reliability and relevance of the information we receive? how to use it effectively? how to simplify information, make it relevant, and present it to different audiences? The course combines different aspects. First, it encourages students to account for the psychological, cognitive, emotional, cultural, and social factors that affects decisions made by individuals and organisations (e.g. private corporates, government, civil society, etc). Second it provides simple analytical tools to contextualise strategic decision-making in real world situations through lenses such as that of the consumer and the future role of social marketing. Third, it introduces students to the idea that business decision making requires reliable, timely information. The course takes a positive (as opposed to normative) approach to the analysis of interactive strategic decisions and behaviours. Through case studies, the course provides a description of what happens in a variety of business situations, with a focus on understanding the elements/dynamics that leads to a certain outcome of decision. In so doing, the course helps students identify the role of information (qualitative or quantitative), how it is sourced and assessed in terms of its validity/quality, and how it can be used to deal with uncertainty in decision-making. Basic approaches to the analysis, interpretation and presentation of various types of information are also discussed, including the foundations of big data analytics and qualitative data analysis.
Subject_or_Unit_9: FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT FOR TOURISM AND HOTELS
Subject_Description_9: Managers in the hospitality and tourism industries must use timely and customised financial information in order to make effective decisions for business sustainability. In this course you will learn the fundamentals of financial and management accounting, particularly as applied to the management of hospitality and tourism businesses. This course will prepare you to interpret profit & loss and other important financial statements, analyse the financial performance of hospitality and tourism operations, and develop operating budgets.
Subject_Description_10: Successful tourism and hospitality managers require a good understanding of their operating environment, in particular the economy which impacts demand for tourism and hospitality services and costs of doing business. This course takes a very applied approach to demonstrate the importance of understanding both the micro and macro influences on consumer behavior, specifically within the economic operating environment of tourism and hospitality businesses in the global marketplace. This course is offered: Gold Coast: Trimester 1 Day Nathan: Trimester 1 Day Incompatible: 3203HSL">3203HSL Economic Perspectives in Tourism and Hospitality & 3203HSL">3203HSL Tourism and Hotel Economic Analysis & 2305HSL Economic Perspectives in Tourism and Hospitality
Subject_Description_11: This course introduces students to methods for collecting and interpreting information that is relevant to the hotel and tourism industry. Students will be exposed to practical ways of developing analytical skills that will be invaluable to future employment. The course will address industry issues and problems, and students will develop skills that will enable them to make evidence based decisions to improve practice. To achieve this, students will learn important research skills such as how to collect relevant information and, how to analyse, interpret and report information. Incompatible: 2230HSL Interpreting Tourism Management Information; 1002HSL Introduction to Research; 2002HSL Introduction to Research. This course is offered: Gold Coast: Trimester 1 Trimester 2 Day Nathan: Trimester 1 Trimester 2 Day
Subject_Description_12: Australia is geographically situated in the Asia Pacific region, but retains strong cultural links to the Western world. Asia is a community of diverse nations and cultures formed over the millennia. In times of boom and gloom Asian nations and their peoples have exemplified resilience and leadership. This course is designed to engage students in the diverse world of Asian history, culture, business, politics, religion, art and beliefs to develop an appreciation of our near neighbours. It examines the influences of the past and current relationships before delving into the future of the Fourth Industrial Revolution and the potential consequences for the region. The course also looks at how Asia is likely to change over the next 10 to 20 years (e.g. growth of India, evolving role of China, the role of Europe and North America). The Asia region is also a likely constant in all students' future careers and many employers desire a level of Asian literacy in their elite workforce. This course is designed to satisfy that requirement and assist students with employability strategies.

Description: The Bachelor of Journalism (Honours) program is designed as an 'end-on' fourth year from corresponding undergraduate degrees in Journalism. This Honours program qualifies students to apply skills and knowledge in their discipline and prepare them to undertake highly skilled professional work and/or advanced  study. The degree will require students to plan and execute a research dissertation or a creative/professional product with minor dissertation/exegesis under the supervision of an appropriate academic supervisor as a pathway for further learning. The Bachelor of Journalism (Honours) degree will consist of 80 credit points of assessed student work. This will include 40 credit points of coursework and 40 credit points of supervised research leading to the completion of a written dissertation, or to the completion of a creative or professional product with minor dissertation/exegesis. Students will be instructed in key research principles and methodologies in Journalism.

This program will be available to commencing students at the Gold Coast and Nathan from 2021. The ability to communicate in other languages and cultures will help you in almost any career you choose. When you study a language at Griffith, you will not just learn to speak and write the words, you will also study linguistics - the science, nature and function of language and how it is used in society. Understanding how languages are developed and used will help you gain a solid understanding of your chosen language. You will apply your knowledge of linguistics and your chosen language in real world challenges including second language learning and teaching, intercultural communication, and effective use of digital technologies. You will learn in small classes, where you will receive individual attention. Whether you are a total beginner or quite fluent, you will find courses to suit you. You will also be exposed to the cultural context of your chosen language with options to pursue study overseas through exchanges and study abroad programs. You will complete a Linguistics major and a major in one of the following languages: * offered via cross-institutional study at University of Queensland.
** offered online, via cross-institutional study at  Flinders University.
Career_Outcomes: You will find employment opportunities throughout the world in education and teaching, translation and interpreting, tourism and hospitality, publishing and journalism, sales and marketing, advertising and public relations, international business, law, commerce, and the arts. Students considering undertaking an initial teacher preparation program after completion of the  Bachelor of Languages and Linguistics must contact the School of Education and Professional Studies to obtain a listing of courses approved for content teaching areas.
Subject_or_Unit_1: LINGUISTICS 1B - INTRODUCTION TO THE STUDY OF LANGUAGE II
Subject_Description_1: This course teaches foundational concepts and skills for understanding speech sounds and sound systems, both in English and other languages of the world. It also covers how languages relate to society and culture, and about different scripts and writing systems. [1002LHS is a prerequisite for most other linguistics courses.] Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIl Incompatible: NIL
Subject_Description_2: The term 'communication' covers a vast array of human (and non-human) activities, which can be usefully explored from a variety of perspectives. 1003LHS introduces students to communication through the lens of linguistics, in a very broad sense. Topics include animal communication; how culture, gender and technology impact human communication; whether the language we speak influences our thinking, and non-verbal communication, all with an emphasis on real-life applications.
Subject_Description_3: 'What's the best way to learn a language?', 'How can I remember all the new words and grammar rules?', 'Will I be able to sound like a native speaker by the time I graduate?', 'How many hours a week do I need to study?' 'How can I lower anxiety and increase motivation?', 'Can I do well with languages even though I never studied one before?' These are some of the questions that worry many students starting out on their language learning journey. 1012LHS will answer these questions and give you the skills and strategies to learn more effectively in the years ahead.
Subject_or_Unit_4: LINGUISTICS 1A - INTRODUCTION TO THE STUDY OF LANGUAGE I
Subject_Description_4: Language plays a part in just about everything we humans do, think and say. This course provides a first introduction to linguistics: the systematic study of human languages. The course teaches foundational concepts and skills for understanding words and grammar, both in English and other languages of the world. [1001LHS is a prerequisite for most other linguistics courses.]
Subject_or_Unit_5: LANGUAGE AND COMMUNICATION FOR ARTS AND SOCIAL SCIENCES
Subject_Description_5: Language and Communication for Arts and Social Sciences is offered to students from a non-English speaking background (NESB). Students whose first language is English are NOT PERMITTED to undertake this course. The aim of this course is to introduce students to the language, knowledge and communication skills required for study and practice in their discipline. A further aim is to develop and practice English language skills relevant to the academic culture of Australian universities. It therefore involves intensive English language practice and language immersion activities, with elements applied to contextualised, discipline-specific settings. This course constitutes part of the overall English Language Enhancement Strategy at Griffith University. Prerequisites: NIL; Incompatible: 5901LHS/5901LAL, 5902LHS/5902LAL, 5903LHS/5903LAL, 5904LAL and 1019LHS.

Description: The Bachelor of Languages and Linguistics (Honours) is a one year full-time or two year part-time program of 80 credit points. Graduates of this program will have:

When you study law at Griffith, you'll join a law school who are to dedicated to social justice and learn from award-winning teachers and researchers who are challenging the status quo and creating new legal knowledge, models and processes. Griffith is also proud to be the highest ranked Australian University for law in the 2019 Academic Ranking of World Universities. You'll learn through hands-on experiences from year one. You'll make connections between law and ethics, legal theory, Indigenous issues, and internationalisation. You'll also develop understandings of law and legal work through courses that cover areas such as crime, contracts, property and corporate law, torts and law theories. You'll have the opportunity to choose electives based on your interests, plus you may undertake clinical courses that emphasise practical legal skills, insights and experience. These range in subjects from social justice and refugee law to community lawyering and advanced family law. If you want to become a registered solicitor or barrister, the Bachelor of Laws (Honours) will set you on the right path. Your degree could also pave the way for work as a lawyer in a law firm, a policymaker or law reformer working in the government or community sector, or even as a human rights defender. You'll open up a world of non-legal careers too, including careers in journalism, politics or management. Griffith law graduates are highly sought after in the industry and broader workforce. For a law degree that prepares you for a varied and challenging career, choose our Bachelor of Laws (Honours). Tailor your timetable - Even if you study full-time on-campus, you may still be able to customise your degree to suit your needs. From a range of tutorial times to online access to lectures and other course material, we're here to help you fit study in with your work and life commitments.
Career_Outcomes: *Source: Australian Government Job Outlook.
Subject_Description_1: Foundations of Law introduces key legal concepts and ways of understanding the law that are fundamental to the entire law program. Throughout the trimester, you will develop your awareness of the key principles and institutions that underpin the operation of Australia's legal systems, including the separation of powers (incorporating the differing roles of Parliament, the Executive and the Judiciary); and the rule of law. We introduce legal ethics and examine the roles played by lawyers in Australian society. We provide you with frameworks for effectively accessing state and national laws and conducting other forms of legal research. Building on that knowledge, we develop and apply key legal skills, including reading, analysing and summarising the essential features of cases and legislation, and interpreting statutes, collectively helping you to respond effectively to legal problems. Incompatible: 1011LAW Law and the Modern State. THIS COURSE IS ONLY OPEN TO LAW STUDENTS. Prerequisite: Students must be enrolled in a Bachelor of Laws program
Subject_Description_2: This course introduces students to the law of civil wrongs. This is the body of principles aimed at compensating, rather than punishing, the victims of conduct causing harm, distress, or interference with property or reputation. Prerequisite Bachelor of Laws (Honours) students: 1031LAW">1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW">1011LAW Law and the Modern State. Co-requisite Bachelor of Laws (Honours) graduate entry students: 1031LAW">1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW">1011LAW Law and the Modern State. Incompatible: 2013LAW Introduction to Torts.
Subject_Description_3: This course examines the processes involved in the resolution of civil disputes in the context of our court systems. Following a consideration of the differences between, and the interrelationship of, substantive and procedural law and the theoretical foundations of our procedural system, students will closely examine the various steps involved in a civil matter. The emphasis of the course will be on the operation of the Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 1999 (Qld). Consideration will also be given to Federal procedure. Prerequisites: 1029LAW Contracts 1 OR 1014LAW Contracts and Civil Obligations 1; 1030LAW Contracts 2 OR 1015LAW Contracts and Civil Obligations 2; 2021LAW Torts 1 OR 2013LAW Introduction to Torts; 2022LAW Torts 2 OR 3003LAW Negligence and Accident Compensation. Incompatible: 4021LAW Civil Procedure.
Subject_Description_4: Property 2 complements the content of Property 1, and continues to explore the concepts introduced there through a detailed consideration of key land law doctrines. The Course focuses on land law and features the regulation of land through the introduction and operation of the Torrens System, and covers doctrinal areas including boundaries to land, co-ownership, covenants, easements, equitable interests, mortgages and general law leasing. Students in Property 2 will develop and refine their skills in hypothetical problem-solving in the context of property disputes involving land. Prerequisite: 3014LAW Property 1 OR 3011LAW Property Law 1; Students must be enrolled in a Law program. Incompatible: 3012LAW Property Law 2.
Subject_Description_5: In this course, students will engage in a comprehensive examination of the substantive law, rules, and policies governing criminal justice in Queensland. The course covers a series of related criminal procedural issues and the sentencing process in the context of criminal investigations, trials, and appeals. Each week, legal, ethical, and policy issues relevant to substantive and procedural matters will be studied, discussed, and critically reflected upon. You will be encouraged to consider the effectiveness and fairness of Australia's adversarial criminal justice system. You will learn to interpret and apply the general principles and statutory laws governing criminal procedure. Prerequisites: 1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW Law and the Modern State; 2019LAW Crime 1 OR 4032LAW The Principles of Criminal Law; Students must be enrolled in a Law program. Incompatible: 4031LAW Criminal Procedure and Sentencing.
Subject_Description_6: This course introduces students to the law of associations and partnerships, before turning to focus on the nature and legal structure of the corporation in Australia. The doctrinal areas of corporate law covered include: pre-incorporation issues, incorporation, authority and agency, directors' duties, members rights, corporate finance and external administration. Students are encouraged to examine these through theoretical frameworks. Prerequisites: 1030LAW Contracts 2 OR 1015LAW Contracts and Civil Obligations 2; 4024LAW Equity and Trusts OR 2010LAW Equity AND 2011LAW Trusts; Students must be enrolled in a Law program. Incompatible: 3002LAW Corporate Governance and Regulation AND 3005LAW Law of Associations.
Subject_Description_7: Global Law introduces students to the legal systems, traditions and procedures that have importance to Australia but which exist and operates beyond our national jurisdiction and boundaries. In this course you will learn about the basic features of the civil law system and tradition, which in different forms operate in countries like Germany, Brazil, France and Japan. Of particular relevance to Australia's foreign relations is the Chinese legal system and tradition, which has developed out of the Socialist and Confucianist cultural tradition. Knowing some basic things about these other markedly different legal systems will support your learning throughout the law degree and will enable you to become more innovative and entrepreneurial as global lawyers. This will also help you to understand the origins and modes of practice of both private and public international law, which are legal systems that aim to support how people, private entities and States cooperate at the international level. This course will also introduce you to private international law and the way in which people and corporations rely on it to communicate, trade and generally engage with each other globally while ensuring that their transactions are legally secure. Most importantly, this course will introduce you to the basic features of public international law, which is the legal system for ensuring that states like Australia can continue to cooperate and co-exist peacefully with other countries in the world. This course is designed to give you an introductory experience of the range of legal systems and traditions that as global lawyers you need to be aware of and be able to draw on and use as legal advisers or consultants. It also aims to enrich your engagement with other courses in the law degree, so that you can broaden your understanding of the legal and intellectual influences that bear upon Australia's legal system and the people as globally engaged lawyers. Co-requisite: 1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW Law and the Modern State. Incompatible: 1012LAW Introduction to Legal Theory.
Subject_Description_8: This course explores the history and nature of Equity and its relationship to the common law, and covers equitable rights and assignments, estoppel, fiduciary duties and unconscionability. It also describes the law relating to trusts including informal trusts, family settlements, superannuation and managed investment funds. Prerequisite: 1030LAW Contracts 2 OR 1015LAW Contracts and Civil Obligations 2. Incompatible: 2010LAW Equity AND 2011LAW Trusts.
Subject_Description_9: This course provides a broad introduction to the law of contracts. We will examine which promises are legally binding and how contracts are formed. We will also be examining the different categorisations of contracts and the contents and effects of contracts. This course provides students with an understanding of contractual principles which will be built upon in 1030LAW Contracts 2. Co-requisite: 1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW Law and the Modern State. Incompatible: 1014LAW Contracts and Civil Obligations 1. THIS COURSE IS ONLY OPEN TO LAW STUDENTS.
Subject_Description_10: Crime 1 will examine the criminal law of Queensland, though reference may also be made to the criminal law of the Commonwealth and to that of the other Code and 'common law' states. Emphasis will be placed on the more significant indictable offences. The range of excuses, defences and justifications that apply to criminal offences will be canvassed, as will the important central concept of criminal responsibility. Prerequisite Bachelor of Laws (Honours) students: 1031LAW">1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW">1011LAW Law and the Modern State. Co-requisite Bachelor of Laws (Honours) graduate entry students: 1031LAW">1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW">1011LAW Law and the Modern State. Incompatible: 4032LAW The Principles of Criminal Law.
Subject_Description_11: This course introduces students to fundamental elements of the law of property providing the basis for further study in the core course 3015LAW Property 2. This course critically assesses the justifications for property and considers the delineation of property using a variety of examples such as land, chattels and intangibles (intellectual property), illustrating how property is defined and limited through the legal concepts of "ownership", "title" and "possession". A significant focus of this course is a critical assessment of the legal justifications for property and the manner in which particular groups have used conceptual tools to secure their property rights. Prerequisite: 1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW Law and the Modern State. Incompatible: 3011LAW Property Law 1.
Subject_or_Unit_12: ETHICS AND PROFESSIONAL RESPONSIBILITY IN PRACTICE
Subject_Description_12: Ethics and Professional Responsibility in Practice is a 10 credit point compulsory capstone course intended for students in their final year of study. It describes and evaluates key aspects of ethical lawyering and lawyers' professional responsibility including professional rules and their application, lawyers' duties, regulation and discipline of lawyers and aspects of trust accounting required for the purposes of admission to the profession. The course also investigates concepts relevant to legal practice and contemporary issues such as the changing nature of the profession and access to justice. Prerequisites Bachelor of Laws (Honours) students: 2020LAW Crime 2; 2022LAW Torts 2; Students must be in their final year of study. Prerequisites Juris Doctor students: 7720LAW Crime 2; 7722LAW Torts 2.
Subject_Description_13: In the context of an introduction to civil obligations, this course provides a broad introduction to legal processes, the legal system and legal theory. The emphasis in this course is on contract law, but it also introduces related areas of civil obligations, particularly negligence and restitution. Prerequisites: 1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW Law and the Modern State; 1029LAW Contracts 1 OR 1014LAW Contracts and Civil Obligations 1; Students must be enrolled in a Law program. Incompatible: 1015LAW Contracts and Civil Obligations 2.
Subject_Description_14: This course covers the laws that govern the creation and operation of government institutions within their political, social and economic contexts, especially the powers and limits on powers of parliaments to make laws under Australia's federal Constitution. Prerequisite: 1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW Law and the Modern State. Incompatible: 2002LAW Constitutional Law AND 2018LAW Introduction to Public Law.
Subject_Description_15: Administrative Law is the body of common law, statute law and procedural rules through which government institutions and bureaucratic actions are supervised and regulated. This course examines the major principles of administrative law and the various institutions through which the law is developed and applied in practice. Prerequisite:1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW Law and the Modern State; Students must be enrolled in a Law program. Incompatible: 5003LAW Administrative Law.
Subject_Description_16: This course considers core aspects of the private law governing compensation for injuries and economic loss. The course focuses on common law remedies arising out of the law of negligence and non-intentional tort, as affected and modified by recent statutory tort reforms. Students are also introduced to other sources of injury compensation. These include the related torts of Breach of Statutory Duty, and statutory schemes such as Products Liability and Workers' Compensation. The course is taught and assessed in a critical vein, with students asked to consider the goals and efficacy of the common law and statutory compensation schemes, and the central role of policy in shaping legal responses to social problems. Co-requisite: 1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW Law and the Modern State. Incompatible: 3003LAW Negligence and Accident Compensation.
Subject_Description_17: Evidence Law aims to introduce students to the law governing proof in civil and criminal litigation. The subject matter of the course includes study of doctrinal rules in relation to the differentiated roles of judge and jury, evidential and persuasive burdens of proof, the standards of proof, admissibility of evidence, testimony, privilege and judicial warnings. There will also be consideration of the principles underlying particular doctrinal rules. Emphasis will be on the rules of evidence pursuant to provisions of the Evidence Act 1977 (Qld) and common law. Materials from other jurisdictions may be considered to elucidate principles relevant to practice in Queensland and elsewhere. Prerequisites: 1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW Law and the Modern State; 2019LAW Crime 1 OR 4032LAW The Principles of Criminal Law. Incompatible: 4022LAW Evidence.
Subject_Description_18: This capstone course recalls and extends main traditions and themes in Western jurisprudence and the philosophy of law, and integrates signature themes and methods from our law degree. It engages students in critical reflection and analysis of the purpose of law and lawyers, and of the exercise of law-making, law-application, and legal interpretation. Essentially, it investigates, via applied studies and targeted readings in context, the relevance of select theoretical issues to contemporary law. This course must be completed in students' final year of study. LLB(Hons) prerequisites: 1031LAW Foundations of Law; 1028LAW Global Law; 4024LAW Equity and Trusts. Co-requisite: 4025LAW Corporations and Associations. JD Prerequisites: 7731LAW Foundations of Law; 7728LAW Global Law; 7724LAW Equity and Trusts. Co-requisite: 7725LAW Corporations and Associations.

Description: This is a GRADUATE ENTRY degree. It offers graduates, who have previously completed a non-law degree or higher providing it is equivalent to a minimum of 1.5 years fulltime study and achieved a GPA of 4.0 or higher, direct entry into law at Griffith University. You'll join a law school dedicated to social justice and learn from award-winning teachers and researchers who are challenging the status quo and creating new legal knowledge, models and processes. Griffith is also proud to be the highest ranked Australian University for law in the 2019 Academic Ranking of World Universities. From a range of tutorial times to online access to lectures and other course material, we're here to help you fit study in with your work and life commitments.

Subject_Description_22: This course covers the laws that govern the creation and operation of Canadian government institutions within their political, social and economic contexts, especially the distribution of legislative powers between the federal parliament and the provincial legislatures and the impact of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms.
Subject_Description_23: This course introduces students to the Canadian legal system, the role of law in Canadian society, the main institutions of law and government in Canada, the sources of Canadian law, and to fundamental concepts in law such as the differences between common and civil law, and between public and private law. It also introduces students to case analysis in the common law tradition, as well as statutory interpretation. Students will also develop the fundamental skills needed to research legal issues using a range of legal sources, and will be introduced to a range of academic writing skills relevant to research essays and answering hypothetical legal problems. Students will be introduced to the basic tenets of advocacy, negotiating and client interviewing skills, and the role of lawyers to use these skills as stakeholders in civil society. The course will also look at the relationship of Aboriginal Peoples to the Canadian state.

Description: As a student you will address and manage complex issues to ensure that marine industries prosper sustainably in healthy marine ecosystems. As a graduate, you will be equipped to tackle problems that affect our oceans, tourism, fisheries and food production, climate change, maritime pollution and waste management. With cutting-edge teaching and research strengths, Griffith University is an ideal location to study marine science. Located within easy access to a variety of extensive natural and artificial waterways, iconic surf beaches and the diverse wetlands and coastal biodiversity of Moreton Bay, the Gold Coast is the perfect natural laboratory. You will be offered a marine industry placement, through the Industry Affiliates Program and/or a capstone experience that will expose you to professional activities in fisheries, aquaculture, marine conservation, coastal management and/or coastal engineering. In your first year, you will take core courses that provide the necessary foundations in the basic sciences. In second and third years, you focus on your chosen area of specialisation.
Career_Outcomes: You will find opportunities in coastal resource management, fisheries laboratories, conservation and pollution control management, coastal physical science (modelling or meteorology), marine science institutes, medium and large consultancy companies, marine parks, education research and specialist marine-focused organisations such as Coastalwatch.
Subject_Description_1: The course introduces students to the broad field of oceanography with an emphasis on the physical, biological and chemical processes in the ocean. The content begins with descriptive physical oceanography, and then develops the interconnection between the physical, chemical environments and life in the ocean. Frequent reference to the impacts of global warming on ocean processes is made. Students will access a variety of oceanic data sources, and solve quantitative problems using the MATLAB programming environment. Assessment includes weekly assessable workshops, a group literature review plus a final exam. Non-marine science students who wish to enrol in this course must seek approval from the course convenor or the Academic Support Officer.
Subject_Description_2: The course revises and extends basic integral and differential calculus of one variable and introduces differential equations, in applied scientific contexts. It provides a foundation in the mathematical sciences needed for later studies. Prerequisite: A grade of SA over 4 semesters in Mathematics B (Qld high school subject), or equivalent study over 4 semesters of a high school subject that includes the study of differential and integral calculus or 1011SCG Mathematics 1A (grade equivalent to 4 or higher) .
Subject_Description_3: This course introduces the main environmental spheres and important natural processes of the Earth, considered as a series of systems interacting at various scales. Features of the lithosphere, atmosphere, hydrosphere and biosphere are explained, with emphasis given to the interrelationships between these spheres. In doing so, basic concepts of the more specialized fields of meteorology, climatology, hydrology, oceanography, soil science, geology, geomorphology and biogeochemistry will be studied. Incompatible: 1303ENV Earth Sciences, 1051AES Earth Sciences, 1302EAS Earth Sciences, 1004EAS Earth Sciences and GIS, 1004ENV Earth Science and GIS.
Subject_Description_4: The course consists of a coordinated set of lectures, tutorials and laboratory studies designed to give an overview of the most important aspects of environmental microbiology. The course provides a brief overview of the principals which form the basis of bacterial taxonomy and the enormous metabolic diversity of bacteria. The roles of bacteria in the major biogeochemical cycles of nutrients and minerals and differences in biogeochemical cycling in marine, freshwater and soil habitats will be investigated in depth. The final part of the course will focus on some applied aspects of microbiology such as wastewater treatment and the bioremediation of polluted soils. Pre-requisites: 1041SCG Biological Systems or 1601ENV Biological Systems or 1005MSC Cell Biology Incompatible: 2300ENV Microbial Ecology and Biogeochemistry and 3701EAS Microbial Ecology
Subject_Description_5: Students are introduced to Geographic Information Systems that enable the capture, storage, manipulation and analysis of different types of spatial or geographical data. These systems are important tools for environmental scientists in managing environmental systems. Incompatible: 2205ENV Geographic Information Systems, 3047ENV Geographic Information Systems
Subject_Description_6: Mathematics underpins and informs all scientific fields and is the language of science. Quantitative Reasoning is a mathematics course with a difference. Students will learn how to translate scientific problems into mathematical form, and how to understand and interpret mathematical and numerical results. With modern software, they will use case studies to learn how to apply mathematical concepts, from basics up to simple calculus, to real-world scientific problems. Incompatible: 1013SCG
Subject_Description_7: This course serves as a general introduction to the field of Marine Science, and the scope of materials to be covered by the Bachelor of Marine Science degree and the Marine Biology major of the BSc.
