Elements of biological, physical and chemical oceanography and their applications to coastal management will be discussed, with the help of local as well as global examples.
Subject_Description_8: This course provides an introduction to the basic concepts and practices of data analysis and inferential statistics. It will provide and understanding of several techniques including testing one or more means from sampled populations (t-Tests and ANOVAs), relationships between scale variables (correlations and regressions), and contingency table analysis (Chi-square tests). The course places emphasis on understanding the use of appropriate data for these tests, the use of exploratory data analysis and the underlying distributions and assumptions associated with these tests. Students will learn how to carry out these tests by hand, via the use of statistical software (SAS or SPSS), check assumptions, interpret results and report findings in plain English. Assumed prior knowledge: Grade 12 Maths A or B or equivalent. Incompatible: 1003ENV Statistics, 2012MSC Biostatistics, 2012HSC, Intro to Biomedical Data Analysis, Bioinformatics, 1003PSY Research Methods and Statistics in Psychology, 1002MSC Introduction to Biomedical Data Analysis
Subject_Description_9: The course provides an introduction to classical physics, based on mechanics, waves, electricity and magnetism. It will be assumed that students have the knowledge equivalent to a grade of SA over 4 semesters in Mathematics B (Qld high school subject), or equivalent study, or 1017SCG Foundation Mathematics (grade of 4 or higher). Incompatible: 1018ENG Engineering Science
Subject_Description_10: Biological Systems is an introductory course that provides an appreciation of the main concepts of modern biology. Students will gain an understanding of the origin, function and structure of living organisms by examining life at increasing levels of biological complexity, from the molecular and cellular level to whole organisms and ecosystems. Course content will be delivered through a combination of lectures, workshops, laboratory sessions and online material. Incompatible: 1601ENV Biological Systems; 1
Subject_Description_11: The course will discuss chemical properties and the mechanisms of chemical change, with everyday examples from environmental science and medicine. The principles of chemical thermodynamics, organic chemistry, biological chemistry and chemical reactions and properties in solution will be reinforced by a laboratory program. Tutorial assignments will be used to develop problem solving skills. Assessment is by laboratory reports, mid-trimester examination and end of trimester examination. Assumed prior knowledge: 1023SCG Chemistry I OR 1001ENV Chemistry I OR 1001EAS Chemistry 1 OR Year 12 Chemistry AND Year 12 Mathematics B OR 1503ENG Physics and Chemistry. Incompatible: 1502ENV Chemistry II, 1502EAS Chemistry 2.
Subject_Description_12: Environmental research typically involves the collection of data and subsequent statistical analysis. Good research which enables valid conclusions, requires consideration of experimental design and appropriate statistical analysis. This course presents the basic principles of experimental design together with a range of commonly used statistical methods. Through the completion of a project, students experience all aspects of the quantitative process from question definition and initial exploratory data analysis, through formal statistical inference, its interpretation in terms of an original research question, and the implications of underlying assumptions and resulting limitations. The use of commercial statistical software enables real experiences of data management and analysis. Advised Prerequisite: 1003ENV/1014SCG Statistics. Incompatible: 2291ENV Experimental Design and Statistics, 2204ENV Applied Statistics,
Subject_Description_13: The course will introduce the student to the fundamental theoretical and practical principles of the Chemical sciences. Students will be encouraged to develop problem solving skills and apply these to the solution of real chemical problems. Assessment is by laboratory reports, quizzes and a final examination. Incompatible: 1001ENV, 1001MSC
Subject_Description_14: This course provides an introduction to the major chemical and physical processes of natural environments (water, atmosphere and soils/sediments). The sources, effects and chemistry of every major class of pollutants are described. The steps required to design, undertake and report on a comprehensive monitoring program are described and applied through a case study and a major assessment activity. Field trips and laboratory activities will provide practical experience in monitoring techniques and interpretation of natural processes relating to the lecture content. Prerequisite: Completion of a first year chemistry course AND at least 40 credit points. Incompatible: 2503ENV Environmental Monitoring Techniques.
Subject_or_Unit_15: MARINE MEGAFAUNA: SENTINELS OF THE SEA
Subject_Description_15: This course is restricted to students in one of the following degrees: Bachelor of Marine Science (1328), Bachelor of Science (1018, 1210, 1330) with major in Marine Biology, Bachelor of Science in Ecology and Conservation Biology (1315, 1007) with a minor in Marine Biology. Please note there are limited places, being admitted to one of these degrees does not guarantee a place in the course. Marine Megafauna: Sentinels of the Sea, spans a spectrum from fundamental vertebrate biology and ecology, to scientific communication for conservation and management. Students will gain insight into how a species' unique biology/ecology may place it at elevated risk from human impacts, and how this sensitivity can be leveraged for effective ecosystem biomonitoring. Students will gain field experience associated with long-term monitoring of humpback whales, and species surveys of other marine megafauna. On the basis of their course experience, students will be challenged to develop conservation communication and action strategies. Assumed knowledge: a background understanding of vertebrate biology, trophic interactions and anthropogenic pressures on the marine environment.
Subject_Description_16: This course gives students a thorough grounding in the physical and biological processes occurring on the coastline and in near shore marine habitats, especially sandy beaches and rocky headlands, the habitats that dominate the south-eastern Australian coastline. Anthropogenic threats to these habitats will also be discussed. Assessment involves a literature review, laboratory written reports, short presentation, and an end-of-semester written examination. The course is aimed primarily at Bachelor of Marine Science and Bachelor of Science (Marine Biology major) students, but is also suitable for students from other biological or environmental science disciplines." Assumed background: 1041SCG, 1007ENV or equivalent
Subject_Description_17: This course provides some of the essential mathematical techniques to mathematicians and physical scientists, and applies them to scientific problems. The course covers basic material on multiple integrals of scalar functions as well as line and surface integrals of vector fields, the theorems of Gauss, Green and Stokes, Fourier series and integrals. It also introduces some of the common partial differential equations of applied mathematics and methods of solution mostly based on separation of variables. It also covers some topics on ordinary differential equations. Incompatible: 2001ENG Advanced ENG Mathematics, 2203NSC Mathematics 2A. Prerequisites: 1201SCG">1201SCG Linear Algebra and 1202SCG Calculus I. (Please note: for students enrolled in Program 1567 1201SCG">1201SCG Linear Algebra is a co-requisite). Students must pass both courses to enrol in 2205NSC.
Subject_Description_18: This course introduces students to the concept of environmental sustainability and its uses in solving real world problems. It explores the relationships between the natural, rural, industrial and urban environments and includes the study of the impact humans have upon nature. The course also considers the way environmental sustainability can be used to address environmental, economic and social issues in an integrated way. Assessment includes on-line tests, a written assignment, workshop exercises and an end of trimester examination. Incompatible: 1301ENV The Global Environment, 1181ENV Sustainable Development, 1161ENV Environmental Economics and Policy.
Subject_Description_19: The course introduces basic vector algebra in two and three dimensions, matrices, complex numbers, probability and revises basic functions. It provides a foundation in the mathematical sciences for later studies in science and engineering. Prior Assumed Knowledge: It will be assumed that students have the knowledge equivalent to a grade of SA over 4 semesters in Mathematics B (Qld high school subject), or equivalent study over 4 semesters of a high school subject that includes the study of differential and integral calculus or 1017SCG">1017SCG Foundation Mathematics (grade of 4 or higher). For students who do not have this level of mathematics background, it is strongly suggested that they first complete 1017SCG">1017SCG Foundation Mathematics. Incompatible: 1010ENG Engineering Mathematics 1, 1011SCG Mathematics 1A, 1201BPS Mathematics 1A.

Description: For International students commencing study from outside Australia in Trimester 1-2021 due to travel restrictions, Griffith University can offer the first year of study for this program online. This may require a variation to the courses undertaken in the first year and students will be required to liaise with the Program Director to confirm the program structure for online study in the first year. For students commencing study from outside Australia, online delivery is an interim arrangement. Once travel restrictions are lifted, students will be expected to travel to Australia as soon as they are able, to continue their study on campus, and they will require a student visa for this. Students will need to be in Australia at the commencement of second year; if travel restrictions prevent this, students will need to apply for a Leave of Absence. Medical scientists perform diagnostic tests of blood, tissues and other bodily fluids to help doctors diagnose diseases such as glandular fever, diabetes, swine flu and even cancer. Medical scientists can also recommend treatment options and help manage clinical trials. In this degree, you will develop the knowledge and skills to work as a medical scientist. In your first year, you will take courses in chemistry, cell biology, anatomy and physiology. You will learn about the body's structure, how it functions under normal circumstances and general health challenges. From your second year, you will start to focus on specialist courses in medical laboratory science and learn how the body functions under diseased conditions. In your fourth year, you will gain more in-depth knowledge of medical laboratory science and undertake full-time clinical placements in each of the areas of medical science. Honours is available through an additional year of study.
Career_Outcomes: You will be able to work in hospital laboratories, private pathology laboratories, state health laboratories, universities, veterinary sciences, forensic laboratories, food and cosmetic industry with specialisation in haematology, transfusion science, histopathology, clinical microbiology, clinical biochemistry and molecular diagnostics.
Subject_Description_1: This course covers the structure and function of three major classes of biological macromolecules (carbohydrates, fats and proteins) and the metabolic pathways used for the biosynthesis and degradation of these macromolecules, including the mechanisms used for integration and regulation of these pathways. Enzymes are also covered. Incompatible: 2011MSC Metabolism and 2008MSC Structural Biochemistry Prerequisite: 1015MSC Chemistry of Biological Systems II
Subject_Description_2: This Foundation Year course takes a multi-disciplinary and integrated approach to examine population health in the 21st century. Using a socio-ecological perspective, the course will take a systems approach (i.e. from prevention through to treatment) to introduce students to the environmental, social and behavioural determinants of health and disease. The course will link these determinants with global and national priority health challenges of the 21st century together with the implications for effective health care practice.
Subject_Description_3: This course introduces students to the role of Clinical Laboratory and Medical Scientist in the field of diagnostic pathology. The course provides students with the foundational skills and introductory knowledge required for the successful completion of the Medical Laboratory Science Program.
Subject_Description_4: This course will prepare students to work in hospital blood banks and transfusion services by providing them with the knowledge and practical skills to safely perform phenotyping, compatibility testing, investigation of transfusion reactions and problem solve antibody investigations for conditions such as AIHA and HDNB. Prerequisite: 2009MSC Haematology I & 3004MSC Immunology
Subject_Description_5: This course examines the molecular and cellular basis of the immune system which protects animals and humans from infection by pathogens such as viruses, other microbes and parasites. The importance of the immune system in health and disease is emphasised and topics covered include vaccination, auto-immune diseases and cancer immunology. Prerequisite: 1005MSC Genes and Disease AND 2007MSC Microbiology (or MHD Stream of 2003MSC Fundamentals of Microbiology)
Subject_Description_7: The course examines the molecular bases for pathogenesis of major diseases, focusing on cell signalling pathways and their modulation. The major idea is that understanding these pathways makes it possible to design efficient treatment for prevention or suppression of a particular pathology. Prerequisites: 3014MSC Molecular Biology OR 3016MSC Macromolecular & Cellular Biochemistry OR 3009MSC Haematology II
Subject_Description_8: This 20-credit point course includes research projects in two major disciplines of Laboratory Medicine. Students will undertake one self-directed independent research project. Second project will be experimental producing and analysing the data, orally present interpretation and write scientific reports.  Prerequisite: All courses from 1st to 3rd year
Subject_Description_9: Five body systems: Skeletal, Muscle, Nervous, Endocrine and Reproductive Systems are studied in this course, which integrates anatomy with physiology. The theory presented in this course is supported by practical laboratory experiences, which include the study of human cadaveric material.
Subject_Description_10: The course consists of 10-12 weeks of laboratory placement. The schedule of activities to be undertaken by the student will be determined by the placement laboratory and designed to allow achievement each of the learning outcomes and competencies. The evidence of this attainment will be found in the student's weekly journal of activities and in the training records or training booklet of the laboratory.
Subject_Description_11: This course covers the anatomy and physiology of the cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, digestive and immune systems. Both the study of the anatomy and the physiology of these systems draws on the experience gained in the lectures, laboratories and practicums. Prerequisites for Gold Coast students: 1016MSC">1016MSC Anatomy and Physiology Systems I, and 1014MSC Cells, Tissues and Regulation OR 1001AHS Foundations of Exercise and Sport Science. Prerequisites for Nathan students: 1016MSC">1016MSC Anatomy and Physiology Systems I and 1001NSC Human Biology.
Subject_Description_12: This course will extend upon second year physiology by exploring the aetiology of disease and the effects of chronic homeostasis disruption in organ systems. This course will describe the fundamental causes of disease (general pathology) and apply that knowledge to understanding common diseases affecting body systems (systemic pathology) including cancers, cardiovascular, skin and gastrointestinal/hepatic disorders. Prerequisite: 2012AHS Integrated Systems Physiology
Subject_Description_13: This course introduces organic and biological chemistry, which underpins all biochemical processes and the molecular basis of life. Pre-Requisite: 1001MSC Chemistry of Biological Systems I or 1023SCG Chemistry 1 Assumed Knowledge: Maths B and One of Biology, Chemistry or Physics (4SA).
Subject_Description_14: Cells, Tissues and Regulation examines how a single cell exists, and how when they come together in their trillions, we end up with human beings who can adapt to changing environments. Fundamental knowledge for any future health professionals. Assumed Knowledge: Maths B and One of Biology, Chemistry or Physics (4SA)
Subject_Description_15: This course focuses on the application of biochemistry to medicine. We will examine existing and newly developed diagnostic tests that are being used to diagnose human diseases. Student completing this course are equipped to understand the central role of the clinical biochemistry laboratory in medicine. Pre-Requisite: 2005MSC Biochemistry
Subject_Description_16: The course consists of 10-12 weeks of laboratory placement. The schedule of activities to be undertaken by the student will be determined by the placement laboratory and designed to allow achievement each of the learning outcomes and competencies. The evidence of this attainment will be found in the student's weekly journal of activities and in the training records or training booklet of the laboratory.
Subject_Description_17: This course will provide students with theoretical and practical knowledge of the role of haematology in the patient care by investigation and diagnosis of blood disorders and transfusion.  Students will develop skills in research, scientific writing and reporting. Prerequisite: 1003MSC Introduction to Clinical Pathology
Subject_Description_18: This course introduces the basic chemical principles that underlie biological systems. The foundation provided in this course will allow students to be able to further develop their chemistry knowledge and skills relevant to health and medical sciences in later years. Assumed Knowledge: Maths B and One of Biology, Chemistry or Physics. Incompatible with 1023SCG Chemistry I
Subject_Description_19: This course equips students to tackle problems of information transfer by genetic systems. The nature of genes, their organisation in living cells, their expression and methods of manipulation are covered as well as basic Mendelian and human clinical genetics. The course will also focus on the tools and methods of genetic engineering and analysis and the ethical issues involved. Prerequisite: 1005MSC Genes and Disease OR 1042SCG Genetics and Evolutionary Biology
Subject_Description_20: In this course students will explore the biological processes on which the continuity of life is based including cell reproduction, basic genetics and evolution. Case studies and laboratory activities will provide a challenging opportunity to develop the practical and intellectual skills of a scientist or health care worker. Prerequisite: 1014MSC Cells, Tissues and Regulation Assumed Knowledge: Maths B and One of Biology, Chemistry or Physics (4SA)
Subject_Description_21: This course will equip graduates with the knowledge and skills to competently undertake haematological investigations by problem solving exercises examining the clinical presentation and laboratory investigation of a range of blood cell disorders and acquired or inherited disorders of haemostasis. Prerequisite:  2009MSC Haematology I
Subject_Description_22: This course describes the general principles of pharmacology from a contemporary viewpoint. Topics include receptor theory, mechanisms of drug action, absorption and distribution, metabolism and excretion of drugs, pharmokinetics, drug delivery systems, toxicology and clinical testing for drugs. Drug classes are illustrated using prototypical drugs. Prerequisite: 2012AHS Integrated Systems Physiology AND either 2008MSC Structural Biochemistry OR 2002AHS Biochemistry of Exercise OR 2005MSC Biochemistry Incompatible: with 2018PHM Pharmacology
Subject_Description_23: This course examines basic principles of human genetic disease processes from molecular  and diagnostic perspectives. The course is strongly orientated toward developing and learning useful laboratory skills for diagnosis of genetic disease including DNA analysis, clinical genetics, cytogenetics and forensics. Pre-requisite:  1005MSC Genes and Disease,  2000MSC Molecular Genetics AND either 2008MSC Structural Biochemistry  AND 2011MSC Metabolism OR 2005MSC Biochemistry
Subject_Description_24: Microbiology focuses on theoretical and applied knowledge of HEALTH and MEDICAL MICROBIOLOGY including types of microorganisms, growth and culture, control of microbial growth and antibiotics, microbial taxonomy, microorganisms involved in disease, aspects of clinical microbiology and techniques for isolating and identifying microorganisms. Pre-requisite: 1014MSC Tissues, Cells and Regulation or 1601ENV Biological Systems or 1041SCG, Biological Systems or equivalent. Incompatible with: 2003MSC Fundamentals of Microbiology.
Subject_Description_25: This course advances the physiology taught in first year with particular emphasis on the cardiovascular, respiratory, metabolic and renal body systems. The course focuses on the integrated functions of these systems from a clinical perspective. It forms the foundation of applied physiology courses that follow and will consist of on-line lectures, workshops, laboratory sessions and case study analysis. Prerequisite: 1017MSC Anatomy & Physiology Systems II.
Subject_Description_26: This course will enable acquisition and development of knowledge and practical skills to process clinical specimens, assess pathological states, understand aetiology of infections and subsequently identify, diagnose and report infectious diseases caused by bacteria, fungi, viruses and parasites. Prerequisites: 2007MSC Microbiology or 2003MSC Fundamentals of Microbiology MHD Stream Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: NIL
Subject_Description_27: Language and Communication for Health is offered to students from a non-English speaking background (NESB). Students whose first language is English are NOT PERMITTED to undertake this course. The aim of this course is to introduce students to the language, knowledge and communication skills required for study and practice in their discipline. A further aim is to develop and practice English language skills relevant to the academic culture of Australian universities. It therefore involves intensive English language practice and language immersion activities, with elements applied to contextualised, discipline-specific settings. This course constitutes part of the overall English Language Enhancement Strategy at Griffith University. Prerequisites: NIL; Incompatible: 5901LHS/5901LAL, 5903LHS/5903LAL, 5904LHS/5904LAL and 5902LAL.
Subject_Description_28: This course will introduce students to the Fundamental Biology of Microbes, including Bacteria, Viruses and Eukaryotes. The course will cover how Microbes survive in niche environments, Microbes as Pathogens, and will include focus areas of Medical Microbiology, Industrial and Applied, and Environmental Microbiology. Prerequisite: 1010NSC_Y1 Cell biology OR 1014MSC Cells Tissues and Regulation or equivalent. Incompatible with 2007MSC Microbiology
Subject_Description_29: Histopathology is the study of cellular abnormalities and disease processes in human tissues through the application of various histopathological techniques. 3008MSC Histopathology course will introduce application of special staining procedures, cryotomy, immunohistochemistry, and gross anatomical pathology specimen handling. Prerequisite: 3007MSC Histology Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: NIL
Subject_Description_30: This course provides students with fundamental statistical skills required in many health study areas and in careers as health professionals. Students will explore foundational statistical principles and practice the art of statistical data analysis and reporting of results. Assumed Knowledge: Maths B (or equivalent). Incompatible with 1014SCG.

Description: This program is designed to provide students with an opportunity to undertake advanced study and supervised research work in the specialisation defined by their undergraduate degree program within the context of a multidisciplinary cohort. The research skills developed within this program will provide an attractive credential for students seeking employment in the public or private sectors. The program will also provide the necessary preparation for entry into a higher degree research program. The multidisciplinary context of the program, involving team-teaching of students and the sharing of coursework and seminar experiences across disciplines will be invaluable to students given the importance of a multidisciplinary approach to researchers and practitioners seeking to understand complex problems in health.
Career_Outcomes: Graduates of the program will be able to plan and conduct research in medical science laboratories and related disciplines, and therefore will be well-placed for positions in the private, not for profit, and public sectors. In addition, graduates will be eligible to apply for admission to higher degree research programs, thereby preparing them for high level research careers.

Description: In 2021, Griffith University can offer the Bachelor of Medical Science online for commencing students as long as travel restrictions remain in place. For students commencing study from outside Australia, online delivery is an interim arrangement. Once travel restrictions are lifted, students will be expected to travel to Australia as soon as they are able, to continue their study on campus, and they will require a student visa for this. Students will need to be in Australia for the commencement of the Doctor of Medicine; if travel restrictions prevent this, students will need to apply for a Leave of Absence. This degree, designed for high-achieving secondary school leavers, provides the opportunity for you to progress directly into our Doctor of Medicine (5099)*. In your first year, you will be introduced to the basic sciences underpinning biomedical science - anatomy, chemistry, biochemistry, health, genes and disease, law and ethics, microbiology, physiology, molecular genetics and psychology. In second year, you will study these areas in greater depth and take medically focused courses in immunology, infectious disease, pharmacology, metabolism, biochemistry, and epidemiology. Honours is available for this degree (through an additional year of study). * The Doctor of Medicine is an extended Masters program (AQF Level 9).
Career_Outcomes: If you progress to the Doctor of Medicine, you will be preparing for a career in specialist clinical practice, primary care medicine, biomedical research and healthcare services.
Subject_Description_1: In this course students will study basic physio-pathological aspects of the interaction between humans and their most common pathogens. It considers basic aspects of the immune defense against pathogens as well as infectious diseases caused by bacteria, viruses and parasites. The course covers general principles and paradigms of human-pathogen interaction and an overview of knowledge in various disciplines including epidemics, public health, and infectious disease control. The course also covers key aspects of therapeutic approaches against infectious agents. Prior Assumed: 2008NSC General Microbiology and 3007NSC Immunology.
Subject_Description_2: This course aims to deliver a broad range of core practical skills with applications in the biomolecular and biomedical sciences. Students will complete a variety of practical exercises in biochemistry and molecular biology offered in intensive mode over a period of 2 weeks commencing immediately after the end of the Trimester 2 exam period. Students will be expected to do a minimum of 4 hours per day and their progress through the course will be competency based. This course provides the opportunity to work autonomously and to develop and apply time management skills. This course is restricted to students enrolled in the Bachelor of Medical Science - Nathan 1306 and Gold Coast 1280 Prior assumed: 1041SCG Biological Systems or 1005MSC Cell Biology. Incompatible: 2013NSC_Y1 and Y2
Subject_Description_3: This course is only offered to Biomedical Science students. This course describes the general principles of pharmacology from a contemporary viewpoint. Topics include receptor theory, mechanisms of drug action, absorption and distribution, metabolism and excretion of drugs, pharmacokinetics, drug delivery systems, toxicology and clinical testing for drugs. Incompatible: 3014BBS Introductory Pharmacology, 3019BBS Pharmacology Advised Prerequisite: 2002NSC - Human Physiology
Subject_Description_4: This course provides an introduction to human anatomical nomenclature, the relationship between body systems and the clinical significance of internal and external anatomy. Understanding anatomy is central to understanding the function of body systems. Physiological mechanisms can be explained only in terms of anatomical structure. This course allows the student to become familiar with the nomenclature of major anatomical landmarks, directional references, and anatomical/medical terminology. The anatomy of several core body systems will be covered in detail. Prerequisite: 1001NSC Human Biology
Subject_Description_5: This course considers the molecular organisation of cells and the biochemical properties of the major classes of biological compounds which exist in, and contribute to, the cellular environment eg amino acids, carbohydrates and lipids. It covers the properties of water, pH and buffers, the structure and function of proteins, including an introduction to enzymes, the cell membrane and membrane transport.
Subject_Description_6: This course examines the molecular and cellular basis of the immune system which protects animals and humans from infection by pathogens such as viruses, other microbes and parasites. The importance of the immune system in health and disease is emphasised and topics covered include vaccination, auto-immune diseases and cancer immunology. Advised Prerequisites: 1042SCG Genetics and Evolutionary Biology; 1041SCG Biological Systems, 1014NSC Fundamentals of Biochemistry, 2012NSC Molecular Biology
Subject_Description_7: Genetics and Evolutionary Biology is an introductory course that will provide foundational concepts in molecular genetics and evolutionary biology. Students will gain an understanding of the process of inheritance and mutation, population genetics, and evolutionary theory at the molecular, organismal and population level. Students will also learn commonly used genetic analysis methods and techniques employed by scientists. Course content will be delivered through a combination of lectures, workshops, and online material.
Subject_Description_8: This course covers carbohydrate metabolism; oxidation and synthesis of fatty acids, acylglycerides and phospholipids, nucleic acid and amino acid metabolism; and regulation and the influence of hormones on metabolism. Prerequisite: 1041SCG Biological Systems 1014NSC Fundamentals of Biochemistry.
Subject_or_Unit_9: LEGAL AND ETHICAL PRINCIPLES IN HEALTHCARE
Subject_Description_9: Health care practitioners are regularly confronted by legally complex and ethically challenging clinical situations. To ensure that they practice according to current legal and professional standards, a sound understanding of legal and ethical principles that underpin safe and competent practice is required. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: NIL
Subject_Description_10: Human Biology provides the foundation knowledge for human anatomy, physiology and cell biology inherent in the biological and biomedical sciences. The course examines the major body systems along with the integration and regulation of these physiological systems to maintain homeostasis.
Subject_Description_11: This course will address relevant aspects of the spread of disease within health care settings and the community. The online modules are designed to enhance your understanding of medically important microbes and their transmission, infection control measures, effective work practice and procedures and management of infectious diseases. Prerequisites: 1005MSC Genes and Disease or 1042SCG Genetics and Evolutionary Biology| 1812MED Expanding Paramedic Practice 2 Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: NIL
Subject_Description_12: This course introduces the fundamental concepts and methods of general chemistry. Basic skills of laboratory chemical analysis are developed. Lecture content includes three modules: Introduction and basic concepts; molecular structure and bonding; and energy and physical processes. Incompatible: 1001SCE Chemistry 1A, 1009ENV General Chemistry, 1001ENV Chemistry 1, 1023SCG Chemistry 1
Subject_Description_13: This course covers core chemistry concepts in a biological and physical context in the areas of organic chemistry, inorganic chemistry and the energetics of matter and living systems. Incompatible courses: 1102SCE Chemistry 1B, 1104SCE Foundations of Biological and Medicinal Chemistry, 1106SCE Chemistry B, 1111AES Introduction to Environmental Chemistry, 1502ENV Chemistry II, 1502SCE Introduction to Nanoscience,
Subject_Description_14: This course covers all aspects of the functioning of the brain. Topics include neuronal biophysics, sensory physiology, movement, developmental neurobiology, homoestasis and arousal, cognition and emotion, learning and memory, and neuropathology. Prerequisites: 1014NSC Fundamentals of Biochemistry.
Subject_Description_15: This course provides an advanced coverage of the physiology of the major body systems. This includes in depth coverage of the cardiac, vascular and respiratory systems. Prerequisite: 2002BPS/2002NSC Human Physiology or 2002BBS Human Physiology and Anatomy. Incompatible: 3005BBS Cardiovascular Physiology, 3037BBS Advanced Physiology.
Subject_Description_16: This course covers the anatomical structure, physiological function and control of a wide range of human physiological systems. Advised Corequisite: 1014NSC Fundamentals of Biochemistry (formerly 1002BPS Structural Biochemistry). Prerequisites: 1001BPS Human Biology or 1001NSC Human Biology; and 1005BPS Cell Biology and Biological Systems or 1041SCG Biological Systems. Incompatible: 2002BBS Human Physiology or 2002BPS Human Physiology.
Subject_Description_17: The IPS course is designed to facilitate, guide and stimulate your interest and commitment to an increased understanding of what constitutes effective communication and also to develop the ability to communicate effectively. To assist with your skills acquisition, this course has been designed using an active learning approach. Learning actively will provide you with the opportunity to develop both a theoretical understanding and a practical ability to communicate and interact interpersonally. In preparation for your role as professionals in the field, you will be encouraged in this course to think of yourselves as practitioners-in-training. One of the implications of this, is that we expect you to be self managing in terms of your own learning and the learning of your colleagues. The Mixed Mode offering of this course is restricted for students enrolled in an External HSV Program only. Incompatible: 1801NRS Effective Communication; 1008PSY Interpersonal Skills; 2008EHR Business Communication.
Subject_Description_18: Utilizing case-based learning, this program capstone will provide opportunities for integrating and applying knowledge acquired through courses already studied in the Bachelor of Medical Science program; to understand the concepts of foundational sciences that underpin disease, and develop skills of problem-solving and clinical reasoning.
Subject_Description_19: Epidemiology is the study of the distribution and determinants of health-related states or events in specified populations. The application of this study involves studies that elicit information pertaining to prevention, planning, control of population health problems." This course introduces the fundamental principles and practices of epidemiology in public health. Students will examine basic epidemiological concepts and methods, explore their application, perform elementary epidemiological reviews and critiques, and reflect in the role of epidemiology in public health.
Subject_Description_20: This Capstone course brings together the learning across your degree, and covers the principles of pathology, the molecular basis of disease, and modern molecular approaches to the diagnosis and treatment of disease. The course will also provide students with a case-oriented problem-based learning approach to biomedical science. Prerequisites: 2002NSC Human Physiology and 2003NSC Metabolism.
Subject_Description_21: This course covers the basic concepts, principles and techniques of microbiology. It looks at the domains of Archaea, Bacteria and Eukarya, viruses, microbial diseases, and environmental and applied microbiology including areas such as microbial ecology and microbial biotechnology. Incompatible with: 2007MSC Microbiology. Prerequisite: 1014NSC Fundamentals of Biochemistry.
Subject_Description_22: Biological Systems is an introductory course that provides an appreciation of the main concepts of modern biology. Students will gain an understanding of the origin, function and structure of living organisms by examining life at increasing levels of biological complexity, from the molecular and cellular level to whole organisms and ecosystems. Course content will be delivered through a combination of lectures, workshops, laboratory sessions and online material. Incompatible: 1601ENV Biological Systems; 1

Description: In 2021, Griffith University can offer the Bachelor of Medical Science online for commencing students as long as travel restrictions remain in place. For students commencing study from outside Australia, online delivery is an interim arrangement. Once travel restrictions are lifted, students will be expected to travel to Australia as soon as they are able, to continue their study on campus, and they will require a student visa for this. Students will need to be in Australia for the commencement of the Doctor of Medicine; if travel restrictions prevent this, students will need to apply for a Leave of Absence. This degree, designed for high-achieving secondary school leavers, provides the opportunity for you to progress directly into our Doctor of Medicine (5099)*. In your first year, you will be introduced to the basic sciences underpinning medical science - anatomy, chemistry, biochemistry, genes and disease, law and ethics, microbiology, physiology, and epidemiology. You will also undertake a course in "interpersonal skills" which provides you with knowledge and skills in communication and interaction with patients. In second year, you will study these areas in greater depth and take medically focused courses in immunology, infectious disease, pharmacology, metabolism, structural biochemistry, and molecular genetics, as well as undertaking a capstone course (Integrated Medical Sciences) which integrates and applies the knowledge of basic sciences learned in your first and second years. Honours is available through an additional year of study. * The Doctor of Medicine is an extended Masters program (AQF Level 9).
Career_Outcomes: If you progress to the Doctor of Medicine, you will be preparing for a career in specialist clinical practice, primary care medicine, biomedical research and healthcare services.
Subject_Description_1: This course introduces the basic chemical principles that underlie biological systems. The foundation provided in this course will allow students to be able to further develop their chemistry knowledge and skills relevant to health and medical sciences in later years. Assumed Knowledge: Maths B and One of Biology, Chemistry or Physics. Incompatible with 1023SCG Chemistry I
Subject_Description_2: This course advances the physiology taught in first year with particular emphasis on the cardiovascular, respiratory, metabolic and renal body systems. The course focuses on the integrated functions of these systems from a clinical perspective. It forms the foundation of applied physiology courses that follow and will consist of on-line lectures, workshops, laboratory sessions and case study analysis. Prerequisite: 1017MSC Anatomy & Physiology Systems II.
Subject_Description_3: Utilizing case-based learning, this program capstone will provide opportunities for integrating and applying knowledge acquired through courses already studied in the Bachelor of Medical Science program; to understand the concepts of foundational sciences that underpin disease, and develop skills of problem-solving and clinical reasoning.
Subject_Description_4: This course will address relevant aspects of the spread of disease within health care settings and the community. The online modules are designed to enhance your understanding of medically important microbes and their transmission, infection control measures, effective work practice and procedures and management of infectious diseases. Prerequisites: 1005MSC Genes and Disease or 1042SCG Genetics and Evolutionary Biology| 1812MED Expanding Paramedic Practice 2 Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: NIL
Subject_Description_5: This course provides students with fundamental statistical skills required in many health study areas and in careers as health professionals. Students will explore foundational statistical principles and practice the art of statistical data analysis and reporting of results. Assumed Knowledge: Maths B (or equivalent). Incompatible with 1014SCG.
Subject_Description_6: Five body systems: Skeletal, Muscle, Nervous, Endocrine and Reproductive Systems are studied in this course, which integrates anatomy with physiology. The theory presented in this course is supported by practical laboratory experiences, which include the study of human cadaveric material.
Subject_Description_7: You will consider infectious diseases caused by examples of bacteria, viruses, parasites, understanding how common themes aid understanding of complex host-microbe interactions, and prevention and treatment strategies. Topics covered provide a national and international perspective on infectious disease. Prerequisites: 2007MSC Microbiology or 2003MSC Fundamentals of Microbiology Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: NIL
Subject_Description_8: This course describes the general principles of pharmacology from a contemporary viewpoint. Topics include receptor theory, mechanisms of drug action, absorption and distribution, metabolism and excretion of drugs, pharmokinetics, drug delivery systems, toxicology and clinical testing for drugs. Drug classes are illustrated using prototypical drugs. Prerequisite: 2012AHS Integrated Systems Physiology AND either 2008MSC Structural Biochemistry OR 2002AHS Biochemistry of Exercise OR 2005MSC Biochemistry Incompatible: with 2018PHM Pharmacology
Subject_Description_9: In this course students will explore the biological processes on which the continuity of life is based including cell reproduction, basic genetics and evolution. Case studies and laboratory activities will provide a challenging opportunity to develop the practical and intellectual skills of a scientist or health care worker. Prerequisite: 1014MSC Cells, Tissues and Regulation Assumed Knowledge: Maths B and One of Biology, Chemistry or Physics (4SA)
Subject_Description_10: The IPS course is designed to facilitate, guide and stimulate your interest and commitment to an increased understanding of what constitutes effective communication and also to develop the ability to communicate effectively. To assist with your skills acquisition, this course has been designed using an active learning approach. Learning actively will provide you with the opportunity to develop both a theoretical understanding and a practical ability to communicate and interact interpersonally. In preparation for your role as professionals in the field, you will be encouraged in this course to think of yourselves as practitioners-in-training. One of the implications of this, is that we expect you to be self managing in terms of your own learning and the learning of your colleagues. The Mixed Mode offering of this course is restricted for students enrolled in an External HSV Program only. Incompatible: 1801NRS Effective Communication; 1008PSY Interpersonal Skills; 2008EHR Business Communication.
Subject_or_Unit_11: LEGAL AND ETHICAL PRINCIPLES IN HEALTHCARE
Subject_Description_11: Health care practitioners are regularly confronted by legally complex and ethically challenging clinical situations. To ensure that they practice according to current legal and professional standards, a sound understanding of legal and ethical principles that underpin safe and competent practice is required. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: NIL
Subject_Description_12: This course equips students to tackle problems of information transfer by genetic systems. The nature of genes, their organisation in living cells, their expression and methods of manipulation are covered as well as basic Mendelian and human clinical genetics. The course will also focus on the tools and methods of genetic engineering and analysis and the ethical issues involved. Prerequisite: 1005MSC Genes and Disease OR 1042SCG Genetics and Evolutionary Biology
Subject_Description_13: This course covers the anatomy and physiology of the cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, digestive and immune systems. Both the study of the anatomy and the physiology of these systems draws on the experience gained in the lectures, laboratories and practicums. Prerequisites for Gold Coast students: 1016MSC">1016MSC Anatomy and Physiology Systems I, and 1014MSC Cells, Tissues and Regulation OR 1001AHS Foundations of Exercise and Sport Science. Prerequisites for Nathan students: 1016MSC">1016MSC Anatomy and Physiology Systems I and 1001NSC Human Biology.
Subject_Description_14: This course examines the molecular and cellular basis of the immune system which protects animals and humans from infection by pathogens such as viruses, other microbes and parasites. The importance of the immune system in health and disease is emphasised and topics covered include vaccination, auto-immune diseases and cancer immunology. Prerequisite: 1005MSC Genes and Disease AND 2007MSC Microbiology (or MHD Stream of 2003MSC Fundamentals of Microbiology)
Subject_Description_15: This Foundation Year course takes a multi-disciplinary and integrated approach to examine population health in the 21st century. Using a socio-ecological perspective, the course will take a systems approach (i.e. from prevention through to treatment) to introduce students to the environmental, social and behavioural determinants of health and disease. The course will link these determinants with global and national priority health challenges of the 21st century together with the implications for effective health care practice.
Subject_Description_16: This course introduces organic and biological chemistry, which underpins all biochemical processes and the molecular basis of life. Pre-Requisite: 1001MSC Chemistry of Biological Systems I or 1023SCG Chemistry 1 Assumed Knowledge: Maths B and One of Biology, Chemistry or Physics (4SA).
Subject_Description_17: Each project has identifiable problem-solving aspects and is performed under supervision arrangements approved by the Faculty. This course provides opportunities for students to pursue detailed study in a chosen field and to apply the skills and knowledge previously gained. COURSE CANNOT BE UNDERTAKEN WITHOUT THE AGREEMENT OF A NOMINATED SUPERVISOR. Prerequisites: Must be in Final Year of Program. NOTE: In Trimester 3 the course is restricted to students enrolled in the Bachelor of Medical Science and Bachelor of Biomedical Science with Honours programs; and, unless the convenor approves an experimental project, it is restricted to literature or systematic reviews.
Subject_Description_18: This course considers the molecular organisation of cells and the biochemical properties of the major classes of biological compounds which exist in and contribute to the cellular environment. Biochemistry laboratory studies are included. Prerequisite: 1005MSC Genes and Disease AND 1015MSC Chemistry in Biological Systems OR 1042SCG Genetics and Evolutionary Biology AND 1024SCG Chemistry II. Incompatible with: 2005MSC Biochemistry
Subject_Description_19: This course covers carbohydrate metabolism; oxidation and synthesis of fatty acids, acylglycerides and phospholipids, nucleic acid and amino acid metabolism; and regulation and the influence of hormones on metabolism. Prerequisite: 2008MSC Structural Biochemistry Incompatible: 2005MSC Biochemistry.
Subject_Description_20: Cells, Tissues and Regulation examines how a single cell exists, and how when they come together in their trillions, we end up with human beings who can adapt to changing environments. Fundamental knowledge for any future health professionals. Assumed Knowledge: Maths B and One of Biology, Chemistry or Physics (4SA)
Subject_Description_21: Epidemiology is the study of the distribution and determinants of health-related states or events in specified populations. The application of this study involves studies that elicit information pertaining to prevention, planning, control of population health problems." This course introduces the fundamental principles and practices of epidemiology in public health. Students will examine basic epidemiological concepts and methods, explore their application, perform elementary epidemiological reviews and critiques, and reflect in the role of epidemiology in public health.
Subject_Description_22: This course will introduce students to the Fundamental Biology of Microbes, including Bacteria, Viruses and Eukaryotes. The course will cover how Microbes survive in niche environments, Microbes as Pathogens, and will include focus areas of Medical Microbiology, Industrial and Applied, and Environmental Microbiology. Prerequisite: 1010NSC_Y1 Cell biology OR 1014MSC Cells Tissues and Regulation or equivalent. Incompatible with 2007MSC Microbiology

Description: This program is designed to provide students with an opportunity to undertake advanced study and supervised research work in the specialisation defined by their undergraduate degree program within the context of a multidisciplinary cohort. The research skills developed within this program will provide an attractive credential for students seeking employment in the public or private sectors. The program will also provide the necessary preparation for entry into a higher degree research program. The multidisciplinary context of the program, involving team-teaching of students and the sharing of coursework and seminar experiences across disciplines will be invaluable to students given the importance of a multidisciplinary approach to researchers and practitioners seeking to understand complex problems in health.
Career_Outcomes: Graduates of the program will be able to plan and conduct research in medical science  and related disciplines, and therefore will be well-placed for positions in the private, not for profit, and public sectors. In addition, graduates will be eligible to apply for admission to higher degree research programs, thereby preparing them for high level research careers.

Description: This program is designed to provide students with an opportunity to undertake advanced study and supervised research work in the specialisation defined by their undergraduate degree program within the context of a multidisciplinary cohort. The research skills developed within this program will provide an attractive credential for students seeking employment in the public or private sectors. The program will also provide the necessary preparation for entry into a higher degree research program. The multidisciplinary context of the program, involving team-teaching of students and the sharing of coursework and seminar experiences across disciplines will be invaluable to students given the importance of a multidisciplinary approach to researchers and practitioners seeking to understand complex problems in health.
Career_Outcomes: Graduates of the program will be able to plan and conduct research in midwifery and related health disciplines, and therefore will be well-placed for positions in the private, not for profit, and public sectors. In addition, graduates will be eligible to apply for admission to higher degree research programs, thereby preparing them for high level research careers.

Description: International students must be in Australia and able to attend campus to commence this program. Composition major: In 2021, Griffith University can offer the first year (80 credit points) of this program online for International students outside Australia due to travel restrictions and who are studying the Composition major. For students commencing study from outside Australia, online delivery is an interim arrangement. Once travel restrictions are lifted, students will be expected to travel to Australia as soon as they are able to continue their study on campus, and they will require a student visa for this study. Students will need to be in Australia at the commencement of second year. If travel restrictions prevent this, students will need to apply for a Leave of Absence. As a Bachelor of Music graduate, you will be highly  skilled, musically adaptable and equipped to enter professional life as a  creative and flexible twenty-first century musician. Your educational experience will  include exposure to diverse musical styles and idioms including classical,  contemporary, jazz, popular, electronic, experimental and world music. You will  also learn the broadly accepted musical skills of aural awareness training,  music theory, critical listening, contemporary music-making practices, music  literature and collaborative work appropriate to your field of study. You will be admitted into a major which may include  study in an instrument, music composition, recording studio and music  production, electronic and experimental music, voice or composition, in either  classical, popular, jazz or creative music technology strands. The Bachelor of Music now includes majors in popular music and creative music technology. You may audition for more than one major or more than one instrument. However, if successful, your offer will be for only  one of your auditioned areas. There may be an  option after first year to divide your major  between two areas through an innovative cross-study major subject to special  criteria. If you wish to study music education you will enter  a teaching preparation strand in your second year. After successfully  completing your undergraduate studies, you will graduate with a Bachelor of  Music and be eligible to apply for a graduate entry teacher preparation program. Should  you wish to study creative music technology, you will develop a thorough understanding of the role  technology plays in performing, producing, recording, and creating music and  sound. You will be working to develop your artistic abilities and to apply new  knowledge professionally in diverse contexts. As an aspiring composer,  performer, sound designer or audio producer, you will have the opportunity to  work with other Griffith Arts departments on diverse projects such as concerts,  albums, documentaries, art music videos and feature films. You will study music  technology applications in commercial and studio music production and  recording, performance, computing, sound editing, multimedia, film, games,  installation and sound composition contexts. You will have opportunities to gain credit for  project studies and music industry internships enabling you to gain invaluable  experience and preparing you for a smooth transition into professional life. Elective courses are available to deepen and  broaden your musical experience. Elective study areas include: Composition; Conducting; Popular Music; Keyboard Accompaniment; Music Industry Studies;  Music Literature; Creative Music Technology; Music Theory and Aural Studies; Opera and Music Theatre Studies; Pedagogy. Students enrolled in the Bachelor of Music who decide to undertake the Bachelor of Music in Performance or Bachelor of Music in Composition should apply for a transfer into the program once they complete the Bachelor of Music requirements.
Career_Outcomes: Your career opportunities will vary depending on your chosen areas of specialisation. As a graduate of the Bachelor of Music, you will be prepared for a career as an instrumentalist or vocalist, or in many other areas. Through self-directed project work, you will transition from student to professional life while still in the supportive Conservatorium environment. You will have opportunities to refine your skills, focus and target your professional options and gain first-hand professional experience in your chosen area. You will have a clear understanding of what's required by instrumental and vocal ensembles and companies, orchestras, theatre, media, the entertainment industry and community arts. As a jazz musician, you will be equipped to work at a high professional level in jazz, musical theatre, media and entertainment. If you have trained as a composer, you may seek to establish an independent career writing or arranging for film, plays, television, concert performance or musical theatre. As a popular musician, you  will graduate with a high level of instrumental and musicianship skills and an  extensive knowledge of the popular music industry, preparing you for a career  as a soloist or band member. As a Creative Music Technologist, you will be able  to work creatively in producing, performing and recording music and applying  emerging technologies to your work and that of other musical professionals. You  may find career opportunities in music production, performance, multimedia,  recording studios, education, music business, musical composition, sound  design, theatres and performance venues, and in the games, media, publishing,  performance and film industries. Increasingly, the contemporary composer works in a multimedia environment and, appropriately skilled, has opportunities in a range of creative fields in the burgeoning new technology area. If you have included pedagogy electives in your studies, you may be equipped to undertake instrumental or vocal teaching. If you complete a graduate entry teacher preparation Masters program following completion of the Bachelor of Music, you will be eligible to apply for registration as a teacher in Queensland.

Description: International students must be in Australia and able to attend campus to commence this program. As a Bachelor of Musical Theatre graduate, you will have gone through many facets of training to become highly skilled, musically adaptable and equipped to enter professional life as creative and flexible 21st century musical theatre performer. As a student, you will be exposed to diverse musical theatre styles and to the broadly accepted musical skills of aural awareness training, music theory and ensemble work appropriate to this genre. Studying musical theatre at the Queensland Conservatorium will provide you with intensive practical training in acting and improvisation, speech, voice, singing, dance and movement, focused on producing the 'triple threat' performer - one who is proficient in singing, acting and movement. The productions included in the degree emulate professional productions, thereby providing students with authentic professional experiences.
Career_Outcomes: There is an identified shortage of professionally trained musical theatre performers throughout Australia. At the same time, there is an increasing number of musical theatre productions being toured throughout Australia and an increasing demand for musical theatre product. As a graduate, you will be skilled in singing, acting and dancing and be equipped to perform in cabaret, theatre, television, film and musical theatre, as well as more diverse entertainment mediums such as festival, theme parks and cruises. There is endless variety in this broad area of entertainment. It is expected that graduates will write and produce their own work for public performance.
Subject_Description_1: This course continues the work begun in Musical Theatre 1, 2 and 3. The acquisition and development of Acting, Speech, Singing and Dance techniques are interdependent elements in a process that culminates in a Performance Project, a learning opportunity consisting of a short 'Modern Book Musical' performance presented simply, to an audience of tutors and fellow students. This course continues the development of the student's potential as a musical theatre performer as fully as possible, through individual tuition in singing and class tuition in acting, dance, voice and speech and through master classes, workshops, seminars and public performances. Pre-requisite: 2211QCM Restriction: Students must be enrolled in the following program: 1404 Bachelor of Musical Theatre.
Subject_Description_2: The history of theatre is primarily concerned with its origins, influences and subsequent development as dramatic stories, theatricality and performance reflecting the broader culture in a society.
Subject_Description_3: The acquisition and development of Acting, Speech, Singing and Dance techniques are interdependent elements in a process that culminates in a Performance Project, a learning opportunity consisting of a short 'song & dance' performance presented simply, to an audience of tutors, fellow-students and members of the public. This course aims to develop the student's potential as a musical theatre performer as fully as possible, through individual and group tuition in singing and class tuition in acting, dance, voice and speech. Master classes, workshops, seminars and public performances are also utilised from time to time. It is the principal study for students enrolled in the Bachelor of Music in Musical Theatre program.
Subject_Description_4: This course is designed to provide an overview of musical theatre styles and practices from the early 20th century to the present day. The course discusses compositional features, structures and dramatic conventions to allow students to identify and evaluate functions of musical theatre. There are no pre-requisites for this course. Students from backgrounds other than music are welcome to undertake the course.
Subject_Description_5: This course provides comprehensive training in music theory, aural studies and keyboard musicianship assisting music theatre students to develop accurate listening and inner hearing skills within a practical setting. Lectures explore repertoire from music theatre and the basic principles of pitch organisation, rhythmic structure and musical form with the aim of improving the student's comprehension of melodic and harmonic structure in music through the study of pitch relationships. The course also provides the opportunity to develop appropriate aural and keyboard musicianship skills through engaging in activities such as sight-singing, rhythm performance, and aural analysis of melody, rhythm, harmony and form. This course sequence is exclusively for students enrolled in the Music Theatre program. Incompatible: 1511QCM, 1512QCM
Subject_Description_6: This course is designed to cover historical, analytical and contextual aspects of musical theatre and film. There are no prerequisites, co-requisite and prior-assumed courses. By investigating the music used in musicals and in film, students should be able to identify and evaluate the functions of a musical score in depicting the time and place of a setting, conveying character or ideas, highlighting mood or atmosphere, or communicating the thoughts and emotions of characters.
Subject_Description_7: This course continues the work begun in Musical Theatre 1. The acquisition and development of Acting, Speech, Singing and Dance techniques are interdependent elements in a process that culminates in a Performance Project, a learning opportunity consisting of a short '20th Century Drama' performance presented simply, to an audience of tutors and fellow students. This course continues the development of the student's potential as a musical theatre performer as fully as possible, through individual tuition in singing and class tuition in acting, dance, voice and speech and through master classes, workshops, seminars and public performances. PRE-REQUISITE: 1211QCM Musical Theatre 1 Restriction: Students must be enrolled in the following program: 1404 Bachelor of Musical Theatre.
Subject_Description_8: This course continues the work begun in Musical Theatre 1 and 2. The acquisition and development of Acting, Speech, Singing and Dance techniques are interdependent elements in a process that culminates in a Performance Project, a learning opportunity consisting of a short 'Classical Book Musical' performance presented simply, to an audience of tutors and fellow students. This course continues the development of the student's potential as a musical theatre performer as fully as possible, through individual tuition in singing and class tuition in acting, dance, voice and speech and through master classes, workshops, seminars and public performances. PRE-REQUISITE: 1212QCM
Subject_Description_9: This course continues comprehensive training in music theory, aural studies and keyboard musicianship for music theatre students. This course sequence is exclusively for students enrolled in the Music Theatre program. PREREQUISITE: 1524QCM Materials of Music for Music Theatre 2
Subject_Description_10: This course continues comprehensive training in music theory, aural studies and keyboard musicianship for music theatre students. This course sequence is exclusively for students enrolled in the Music Theatre program. Pre-requisite: 1514QCM Materials of Music (Music Theatre) 1
Subject_Description_11: This course continues comprehensive training in music theory, aural studies and keyboard musicianship for music theatre students. This course sequence is exclusively for students enrolled in the Music Theatre program. Pre-requisite: 2514QCM Materials of Music for Music Theatre 3
Subject_Description_12: This course is designed to provoke interest in, and understanding of Australian Theatre. Students will explore three key Australian plays written between 1950 and the present day. They will develop knowledge about the plays selected for study as well as the necessary skills to interpret and present excerpts of script in ensemble performance.
Subject_Description_13: This course continues the work begun in Musical Theatre 1, 2, 3 and 4. The acquisition and development of Acting, Speech, Singing and Dance techniques are interdependent elements in a process that culminates in a Performance Project, a learning opportunity consisting of a fully produced Musical presented to an audience of tutors, fellow-students and paying public. This course continues the development of the student's potential as a musical theatre performer as fully as possible, through individual tuition in singing and class tuition in acting, dance, voice and speech and through master classes, workshops, seminars and public performances. PRE-REQUISITE: 2212QCM. Restriction: Students must be enrolled in the following program and strand: 1268 Bachelor of Music - Musical Theatre or 1404 Bachelor of Musical Theatre.
Subject_Description_14: This course continues the work begun in Musical Theatre 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5. The acquisition and development of Acting, Speech, Singing and Dance techniques are interdependent elements in a process that culminates in a Performance Project, a learning opportunity consisting of a fully produced Musical presented to an audience of tutors, fellow-students and paying public. This course continues the development of the student's potential as a musical theatre performer as fully as possible, through individual tuition in singing and class tuition in acting, dance, voice and speech and through master classes, workshops, seminars and public performances. PRE-REQUISITE: 3211QCM Restriction: Students must be enrolled in the following program and strand: 1268 Bachelor of Music - Musical Theatre or 1404 Bachelor of Musical Theatre.

Description: International students must be in Australia and able to attend campus to commence this program. The Bachelor of Music (Honours) is a one-year Bachelor Honours degree available to students  after graduating with the three-year  Bachelor of Music. The Bachelor of Music (Honours) degree aims to produce  graduates who are highly skilled, musically adaptable and equipped to enter further Higher Degree by Research (HDR) study and/or professional life as creative and flexible 21st century musical performers and researchers This  program will provide the opportunity for students to develop their specialist  interests through a program of research and practice-based work.
Career_Outcomes: Graduates will be realistic and self-motivated, with a clear sense of direction and a repertoire of relevant professional skills acquired through practical experience and workplace training. This academic program is designed for the musician and para-musical professional of the 21st century. It provides the highest level of training in performance, composition and research, and aims to produce professionals who will be leaders in their field and who demonstrate adaptability, self-motivation, technological literacy and breadth of vision.

Description: The Bachelor of Music in Composition builds on the knowledge and skills you gain in the Bachelor of Music. You will develop advanced skills in  composition and learn through exposure to a range of musical styles, theory and literature. With project studies and work integrated learning courses, you will gain invaluable industry and professional experience. Students who graduate with a Bachelor of Music will not be eligible for admission to the Bachelor of Music in Composition.  Students wishing to undertake the Bachelor of Music in Composition should apply to transfer into the program once they complete the Bachelor of Music requirements.
Career_Outcomes: As a graduate composer, your career options include writing or arranging for film, plays, television, concert performance, musical theatre or in new technology multimedia.
Subject_Description_1: This course offers an integrated and analytical approach to the conceptual world of music through cognitive and creative involvement. The course focuses on examining theory and compositional technique, primarily drawing on repertoire from the Common Practice and Romantic periods. Modulation, chromaticism and other harmonic devices are explored in the context of instrumental and vocal repertoire. This course is a continuation of Music Theory 1. PRE-REQUISITE: 1511QCM; CO-REQUISITE: 1612QCM.
Subject_Description_2: This course is designed for musicians and composers who wish to explore aspects of technology in relation to musical performance. Lectures include basic acoustic theory, listening and analysis of seminal works and practical demonstrations in utilising the latest interactive performance technology. INCOMPATIBLE: 1722QCM Performance and Technology
Subject_Description_3: This course offers an integrated approach to the conceptual world of music through cognitive and creative involvement. Although the course focus is on music of the Common Practice period, comparative topics on other music traditions are included as well. This course is a continuation of Music Theory 2, and it reaches to topics related to more recent developments in the musical language. The specific contents include, non-exclusively, Explorations on Meter and Beat, Advanced Chromatic Harmony, Tone Poem, Music in Film, Music Analysis practices PRE-REQUISITE: 1512QCM CO-REQUISITE: 2611QCM
Subject_Description_4: An exploration of basic conducting techniques including correct patterns, cues, score reading, rehearsal skills and stylistic solutions.
Subject_Description_5: Musicians begin their careers focusing their attention intensely on the development of their musical capabilities inspired by their dreams and ambitions. While this is necessary and certainly encouraged, many professional musicians will suggest it is not the sole contributing success factor of developing your life as a musician. They will agree there are other aptitudes and capabilities required for any musician to confidently achieve their aspirations: whether you define success as the ability to sustain your passion for music in the long-term, to be financially remunerated for your artistic efforts and/or make a difference in the world with your music. Overall, this can be summarised as the ability to create an independent sustainable artistic enterprise from your musical skill within the competitive industry environment. My Life as a Musician 1 (MLaaM 1)is the first of three courses, unique to the Queensland Conservatorium Griffith University, in which you will progressively develop your knowledge, understanding and skills in, of and about the music profession that you are already a part of. This will be a personalised experience, so that you may become increasingly informed about yourself as a musician, and your career possibilities far beyond being a person who simply possesses technical musical capability. MLaaM 1, and its subsequent courses, is an essential foundation towards your perceived success as a musician and the identity development necessary to realise your journey.
Subject_Description_6: This foundation-year course will examine a broad and diverse range of music from different styles, periods and cultures (including Western, non-Western and jazz idioms) to explore various ways of studying and understanding issues relating to music.
Subject_Description_7: This course continues from Aural Studies 2 and, through cognitive and creative involvement, further develops aural perception and coordination though listening, performance, memorisation, improvisation, arranging, and aural analysis. It explores diatonic and chromatic melodic and harmonic elements, and more complex rhythmic and formal structures. PRE-REQUISITE: 1612QCM CO-REQUISITES: 2511QCM
Subject_Description_8: This course aims to develop the student's potential as a composer in a principal study as fully as possible, through individual tuition in composition and through masterclasses, workshops and seminars. PRE-REQUISITE: 1390QCM_P1
Subject_Description_9: This course offers an integrated approach to the conceptual world of music through cognitive and creative involvement. Although the course focus is on music of the common practice period, comparative topics on other music traditions are included as well. The topics covered at this stage in the music theory curriculum typically and non-exclusively include Pulse, Meter, Rhythmic Deviations, Scales, Modes, Melodic Structures, Simple Forms, Triads, Tonic and Dominant, the Musical Instruments, and study of textures.
Subject_Description_10: This course aims to develop the student's potential as a composer in a principal study as fully as possible, through individual tuition in composition and through masterclasses, workshops and seminars. PRE-REQUISITE: 1390QCM_Y2 INCOMPATIBLE: 2391QCM
Subject_Description_11: My Life as a Musician 2 is the second of three courses, unique to the Queensland Conservatorium. This course aligns with your current and future ambitions to succeed within and beyond the music career domains of performance, composition, teaching and production. It addresses the results from several Australian-based studies that, amongst many skills, the majority of musicians require knowledge of available artistic support in addition to strategies that nurture and strengthen the employability networks that sustain and further contribute to musicians' lives, whether it be for full/part-time or freelance activity. As the list of capabilities required to enact these activities is vast, two core assessment pieces have been chosen to develop your self-promotional, self-funding, career planning and project management skills. This practical-based and inherently applicable approach includes a reflective component to document your developing career confidence and professional awareness. PRE-REQUISITE: 1020QCM and Performance Study Second Year (2360QCM_Y2)/Composition Study Second Year (2390QCM_Y2).
Subject_Description_12: This course aims to develop the student's potential as a composer in a principal study as fully as possible, through individual tuition in composition and through masterclasses, workshops and seminars. PRE-REQUISITE: a minimum grade of 5 in 2390QCM_Y2 and completion of at least 120 credit points of first and second year courses including required first year theory, aural and literature courses. INCOMPATIBLE: 3391QCM
Subject_or_Unit_13: LANGUAGE AND COMMUNICATION FOR ARTS AND SOCIAL SCIENCES
Subject_Description_13: Language and Communication for Arts and Social Sciences is offered to students from a non-English speaking background (NESB). Students whose first language is English are NOT PERMITTED to undertake this course. The aim of this course is to introduce students to the language, knowledge and communication skills required for study and practice in their discipline. A further aim is to develop and practice English language skills relevant to the academic culture of Australian universities. It therefore involves intensive English language practice and language immersion activities, with elements applied to contextualised, discipline-specific settings. This course constitutes part of the overall English Language Enhancement Strategy at Griffith University. Prerequisites: NIL; Incompatible: 5901LHS/5901LAL, 5902LHS/5902LAL, 5903LHS/5903LAL, 5904LAL and 1019LHS.
Subject_Description_14: This course aims to deve lop the student's potential as a composer in a principal study as fully as possible, through individual tuition in composition and through masterclasses, workshops and seminars. PRE-REQUISITE: 3390QCM_Y1 INCOMPATIBLE: 3392QCM
Subject_Description_15: This course is designed to provide students with the technical and aesthetic mechanisms necessary for the recording, reproduction, and description of music performances. Students will acquire the necessary knowledge and experience to plan, setup and produce recordings using mobile recording systems. INCOMPATIBLE: 2755QCM, 2713QCM
Subject_Description_16: This course aims to develop the student's potential as a composer in a principal study as fully as possible, through individual tuition in composition and through masterclasses, workshops and seminars. PRE-REQUISITE: 2390QCM_P1
