Subject_Description_17: This course aims to develop the student's potential as a composer in a principal study as fully as possible, through individual tuition in composition and through masterclasses, workshops and seminars. PRE-REQUISITE: 3390QCM_Y2 I
Subject_Description_18: This course develops your internal sense of pitch, rhythm, beat and dynamics through crucial musicianship skills of dictation (sound to symbol translation) and singing, and skills required for aural analysis and the recognition of melodic, rhythmic and harmonic structures. Musicians must hear the music in an 'inner' ear - as loud and as real to you as if you were actually hearing someone performing it. Musical memory (long-term and short-term) and creativity are acquired through ear-oriented and improvisatory activities in various settings.
Subject_Description_19: This course aims to develop the student's potential as a composer in a principal study as fully as possible, through individual tuition in composition and through masterclasses, workshops and seminars.
Subject_Description_20: This course aims to develop the student's potential as a composer in a principal study as fully as possible, through individual tuition in composition and through masterclasses, workshops and seminars. PRE-REQUISITE: 4390QCM_Y1
Subject_Description_21: My Life as a Musician 3 has been further scaffolded on the foundations of learning you have received from My Life as a Musician 1 and 2 - where you have been introduced to the careers of musicians, considered your own possible futures, and gained skills such as: opportunity recognition, industry awareness and network development, plus the practical business and fundraising skills required to support your current and future interests. If we look to the lives of the majority of musicians, we find that education is a strong component of their day-to-day activity. Not only is teaching part of their career portfolio but an increasing trend is to further absorb the role as educator within ones performance profile. Where the past courses have been designed with problem-based learning (PBL) outcomes to create career confidence, My Life as a Musician 3 is based on project-based learning i.e. problem-based learning with a project outcome. The project enables all enrolled musicians and composers to consider themselves as a "Performance Educator" and develop their skills required for this role. Performance educators are an increasing "breed" of musicians driven by the desire to connect with their community, educate the value of their craft, and further educate their audiences about real-world concepts via their music. Changing Australian arts policy is further emphasising this approach to create sustainability of all artforms and cultural value. Performance education skill is an additional requirement of those entering medium-to-large music institutions (e.g. orchestral, opera, defence force bands, chamber music) and is a necessity for those wishing to follow a freelance/independent music career that is artistically and financially sustainable.
Subject_Description_22: This course is designed to develop keyboard skills at an appropriate level for the non-keyboard major who has limited skills at the keyboard. Emphasis is on developing keyboard orientation and functional skills such as sight-reading, harmonisation and improvisation.
Subject_Description_23: This course continues from Aural Studies 1 and further develops your audiation skills through a balance of dictation, singing, coordination and analysis. Students are exposed to melodic, rhythmic, and harmonic structures in both traditional and creative settings and skill acquisition is promoted through a range of practical and written activities requiring short-term and long-term musical memory skills. PRE-REQUISITE: 1611QCM; CO-REQUISITE:1512QCM.
Subject_Description_24: This course orients students to the diverse and important roles music and music-making can play in our contemporary world. Across a range of local and global contexts, students will investigate how music intersects with today's most pressing social, cultural, political, and environmental concerns. Students will have opportunity to explore issues of particular interest or concern to them. INCOMPATIBLE: 1102QCM Music in Contemporary Contexts PRE-REQUISITE: 1101QCM
Subject_Description_25: This course introduces the four instrumental families (string, woodwind, brass and percussion) and covers tunings, ranges, harmonics, playing techniques and notation for each family. Basic arranging techniques for various chamber combinations through to small orchestra are explored. PRE-REQUISITE: 1512QCM

Description: The Bachelor of Music in Performance builds on the skills and knowledge you gain in the Bachelor of Music. You will develop advanced skills in classical or contemporary performance. As a graduate, you will be equipped to perform in solo, chamber music, orchestras, ensembles as well as more diverse entertainment mediums. Students who graduate with a Bachelor of Music will not be eligible for admission to the Bachelor of Music in Performance. Students wishing to undertake the Bachelor of Music in Performance should apply to transfer into the program once they complete the Bachelor of Music requirements.
Career_Outcomes: You will graduate with the ability to work at a high level in performance companies, orchestras, theatre, the entertainment industry and community arts.

Description: For Trimester 1-2021, while travel restrictions continue to prevent travel to Australia, students who are currently offshore can complete no more than one full-time trimester (40 credit points) of the Bachelor of Nursing program via online delivery. This can only comprise theoretical components of the program and three of the four courses normally undertaken in the first trimester of the program at Griffith meet this requirement. These restrictions are based on advice from the Australian Nursing and Midwifery Accreditation Council. For students commencing study from outside Australia, online delivery is an interim arrangement. Once travel restrictions are lifted, students will be expected to travel to Australia as soon as they are able, to continue their study on campus, and they will require a student visa for this study. Students will need to be in Australia at the commencement of their second trimester of study. If travel restrictions prevent this, students will need to apply for a Leave of Absence. This program will be available to commencing students at the Gold Coast, Nathan and Logan from 2021. The published Bachelor of Nursing program of study is subject to re-accreditation by the Australian Nursing and Midwifery Accreditation Council and approval by the Nursing and Midwifery Board of Australia. Nursing is the science of professional caring and offers opportunities to promote and restore health, prevent illness and alleviate suffering. In this degree, you will develop key skills for excellent nursing care. You will develop your skills through clinical placements across the health sector and you will have opportunities to undertake rural, remote and overseas placements. The Bachelor of Nursing includes multiple pathways. The degree requirements of each of the pathways are different and you will need to follow the requirements for your pathway to ensure your eligibility to graduate. The Trimester 2 intake is only available to students with one of the following qualifications: Honours is available through an additional year of study.
Career_Outcomes: You will find opportunities in hospitals, in the community, and in urban and rural settings. Nursing graduates are employed in a range of occupations and industries. As well as hospitals, medical centres, community health clinics and aged care centres, you'll be prepared for work in schools, the travel industry, with drug and alcohol service providers, in sporting clubs or in research organisations.

Description:
To be awarded a Bachelor of Nursing (Honours) degree, one additional year of study is required following the successful completion of the Bachelor of Nursing. Graduates of Griffith University's Bachelor of Nursing (Honours) degree have a competitive edge as they are equipped with practical skills, experience and attributes that employers value, coupled with highly developed research capabilities. Offered by Griffith University's School of Nursing and Midwifery, our Bachelor of Nursing (Honours) will give you an opportunity to undertake advanced study and supervised research work. You'll complete coursework and a research preparation course in your first trimester and complete a  dissertation in your second trimester. Coursework 
  Through the 30-credit point coursework component of the Honours program, you'll gain an understanding of how to critically evaluate research. You'll also develop your knowledge of statistical analysis techniques as applied to scientific research  and gain an awareness of how research proposals should be designed. Dissertation
  Through the 50-credit point dissertation component, you'll conduct research on a specific project and complete a seminar and dissertation describing the research in detail. You will be required to find a suitable supervisor for your research project prior to submitting your application for admission into the honours program. If you are unable to find a suitable supervisor, you
Career_Outcomes: As a graduate, you will be able to plan and conduct research in nursing and related health disciplines, and will be well-placed for positions in the private, not for profit, and public sectors. You will find opportunities in hospitals, in the community, and in urban and rural settings. Nursing graduates are employed in a range of occupations and industries. As well as hospitals, medical centres, community health clinics and aged care centres, you'll be prepared for work in schools, the travel industry, with drug and alcohol service providers, in sporting clubs or in research organisations.

Description: In 2021, Griffith University can offer the first year of the Bachelor of Nutrition and Dietetics online for International students outside Australia due to travel restrictions. For students commencing study from outside Australia, online delivery is an interim arrangement. Once travel restrictions are lifted, students will be expected to travel to Australia as soon as they are able, to continue their study on campus, and they will require a student visa for this. Students will need to be in Australia at the commencement of second year; if travel restrictions prevent this, students will need to apply for a Leave of Absence. You will develop knowledge and skills to work as a dietitian and learn how to help improve the health of individuals and the community. You will learn through extensive hands-on experience in state-of-the-art facilities, including a purpose-built teaching kitchen and a nutrition clinic in the new Griffith Health Centre. You will develop skills in anatomy, physiology, and biochemistry before you take advanced study in human nutrition. In the final phase of your degree, you will complete a 20-week industry placement to put your skills into practice.
Career_Outcomes: You will be able to work in the health industry as a dietitian/nutritionist in private and public hospitals, community health services, health promotion and public health units, private practice, health service management and food industries.
Subject_Description_1: This course considers the molecular organisation of cells and the biochemical properties of the major classes of biological compounds which exist in and contribute to the cellular environment. Biochemistry laboratory studies are included. Prerequisite: 1005MSC Genes and Disease AND 1015MSC Chemistry in Biological Systems OR 1042SCG Genetics and Evolutionary Biology AND 1024SCG Chemistry II. Incompatible with: 2005MSC Biochemistry
Subject_Description_2: This course introduces students to important concepts in Pharmacology. The major topic areas will provide an in depth understanding of drug targets, pharmacodynamics, pharmacokinetics and pharmacogenomics. Basic concepts in adverse drug reactions, drug interactions, toxicology and complementary medications will be introduced. The course will comprise lectures, workshops and laboratories. Pharmacology is a fundamental course that brings together chemistry and biology to understand the basis of drug effect. Pre-requisites: There are no pre-requisites for this course, however students will require a good understanding of tertiary level physiology, anatomy, chemistry and mathematics. Incompatible - 3002MSC Pharmacology
Subject_Description_3: This course will extend upon second year physiology by exploring the aetiology of disease and the effects of chronic homeostasis disruption in organ systems. This course will describe the fundamental causes of disease (general pathology) and apply that knowledge to understanding common diseases affecting body systems (systemic pathology) including cancers, cardiovascular, skin and gastrointestinal/hepatic disorders. Prerequisite: 2012AHS Integrated Systems Physiology
Subject_Description_4: This course presents a comprehensive introduction to human nutrition; describing the requirements for macronutrients (carbohydrate, fat, protein, alcohol) and micronutrients (iron, calcium, zinc, thiamine, Vitamin C, folate), their food sources, digestion, absorption, storage, and metabolism. Students will explore energy balance and fad diets, and implications for human health.Students will be introduced to the Australian Guide to Healthy Eating, Nutrient Reference Values and dietary collection methods. Students will gain skills in analysis and interpretation of dietary records, and be able to develop recommendations to meet nutrient requirements. At the completion of this course, students will have knowledge of basic human nutrition, nutrient requirements, nutrient content of foods and the broad role of nutrition in maintaining optimal health.
Subject_Description_5: This placement course introduces students to the practice field of Medical Nutrition Therapy. Students spend a minimum of 50 working days in a hospital and/or other health care setting, delivering Medical Nutrition Therapy to individuals and small groups. Students are placed under the supervision of field Accredited Practising Dietitians with a minimum of two years' experience. During the placement, students observe, practice and are evaluated on the delivery of dietetic care to individuals. Students will be evaluated against the Dietitians Association of Australia (DAA) National competencies for Dietitians in Australia. Pre-requisites: All Year 3 core courses. Co-requisites: 4111AHS Food Service Management Practicum, 4112AHS Community and Public Health Nutrition Practicum.
Subject_Description_6: This course introduces students to the practice field of Food Service Management (FSM). Students are placed in teams of two for a total of 20 days to develop their understanding of the role food service plays in the delivery of nutrition care in the acute care setting. Students will undertake a project aimed at making a quality improvement to the food service system. Students will be based in a setting under the supervision of an Accredited Practicing Dietitian. Students will be evaluated against the Dietitians Association of Australia (DAA) National Competency Standards (2015). Pre-requisites: All Year 3 core courses Co-requisites: 4110AHS Medical Nutrition Therapy Practicum, 4112AHS Community and Public Health Nutrition Practicum
Subject_Description_7: Communication and Counselling in Dietetics (CCD) will provide students with the knowledge and skills necessary to conduct a dietetic consultation, including counselling individuals to change food choice and eating behaviours. Students will develop and practice communication and counselling skills in workshops and in consultations with real and simulated patients, and will learn to work as an effective member of an Inter-professional team. As part of this course students will develop skills in communicating nutrition research to both colleagues and the general public. This course forms part of the knowledge base for the individual case management placement in year 4. Pre-requisites: 1008PSY Interpersonal Skills, 3101AHS Medical Nutrition Therapy, 3104AHS Nutrition Education Co-requisites: 3102 AHS Medical Nutrition Therapy 2
Subject_Description_8: The planning, operation, management and continuous quality improvement of food services plays an important role in providing essential services across a range of settings. This course will critically examine and contrast the processes involved in the provision of food and nutrition services. Furthermore, research skills will be applied to a capstone assessment item focusing on quality improvement in a food service system. The course prepares students for their 4111AHS Food Service Management Practicum in their final year. This is a restricted course offered to Bachelor of Nutrition & Dietetics students only.
Subject_Description_9: Five body systems: Skeletal, Muscle, Nervous, Endocrine and Reproductive Systems are studied in this course, which integrates anatomy with physiology. The theory presented in this course is supported by practical laboratory experiences, which include the study of human cadaveric material.
Subject_Description_10: Medical Nutrition Therapy 2 uses the nutrition care process framework introduced in Medical Nutrition Therapy 1 to consider disease states that require dietary modification in individuals. The content will include gastrointestinal disorders, renal disease and cancer, and the material will be delivered by guest dietitians specialising in these areas through lectures and case studies. This course forms part of the knowledge base for the individual case management placement in year 4. Pre-requisites: 3101AHS Medical Nutrition Therapy 1, 2008MSC Structural Biochemistry Co-requisites: 3100AHS Communication and Counselling for Dietetics
Subject_Description_11: This course covers carbohydrate metabolism; oxidation and synthesis of fatty acids, acylglycerides and phospholipids, nucleic acid and amino acid metabolism; and regulation and the influence of hormones on metabolism. Prerequisite: 2008MSC Structural Biochemistry Incompatible: 2005MSC Biochemistry.
Subject_Description_12: This course describes the general principles of pharmacology from a contemporary viewpoint. Topics include receptor theory, mechanisms of drug action, absorption and distribution, metabolism and excretion of drugs, pharmokinetics, drug delivery systems, toxicology and clinical testing for drugs. Drug classes are illustrated using prototypical drugs. Prerequisite: 2012AHS Integrated Systems Physiology AND either 2008MSC Structural Biochemistry OR 2002AHS Biochemistry of Exercise OR 2005MSC Biochemistry Incompatible: with 2018PHM Pharmacology
Subject_Description_13: This Foundation Year course takes a multi-disciplinary and integrated approach to examine population health in the 21st century. Using a socio-ecological perspective, the course will take a systems approach (i.e. from prevention through to treatment) to introduce students to the environmental, social and behavioural determinants of health and disease. The course will link these determinants with global and national priority health challenges of the 21st century together with the implications for effective health care practice.
Subject_Description_14: This course introduces the process of scientific enquiry and the application of appropriate research methods to address questions relevant to public health. It equips students with the basic knowledge and skills required to critically appraise and practise health research.
Subject_or_Unit_15: COMMUNITY AND PUBLIC HEALTH NUTRITION PRACTICUM
Subject_Description_15: This placement introduces students to the practice field of Community and Public Health Nutrition (CPHN). Students are placed in teams of two or three for 30 days to work on addressing a nutrition problem in a community based setting under the supervision of an Accredited Practicing Dietitian and/or Community and Public Health Nutritionist. Students will conduct a needs assessment, or plan, implement and/or evaluate a program relevant to the work of that setting. The placement will provide students with the opportunity to demonstrate practical skills and the application of theoretical knowledge into practice. By the end of the placement students will be assessed on CPHN competencies. Pre-requisites: All Year 3 core courses Co-requisites: 4110AHS Medical Nutrition Therapy Practicum, 4111AHS Food Service Management Practicum.
Subject_Description_16: This course introduces the basic chemical principles that underlie biological systems. The foundation provided in this course will allow students to be able to further develop their chemistry knowledge and skills relevant to health and medical sciences in later years. Assumed Knowledge: Maths B and One of Biology, Chemistry or Physics. Incompatible with 1023SCG Chemistry I
Subject_Description_17: This course covers the anatomy and physiology of the cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, digestive and immune systems. Both the study of the anatomy and the physiology of these systems draws on the experience gained in the lectures, laboratories and practicums. Prerequisites for Gold Coast students: 1016MSC">1016MSC Anatomy and Physiology Systems I, and 1014MSC Cells, Tissues and Regulation OR 1001AHS Foundations of Exercise and Sport Science. Prerequisites for Nathan students: 1016MSC">1016MSC Anatomy and Physiology Systems I and 1001NSC Human Biology.
Subject_Description_18: This course introduces students to the science of food. The course explores the nutritional composition, chemistry and function of foods and introduces students to theoretical and practical issues of food safety, food regulation and food as a form of therapy in the prevention and management of disease. This course forms the foundation for professional applications of nutrition and food in all domains of dietetic practice. Pre-requisites: 2210AHS Nutrition, 1015MSC Chemistry of Biological Systems Restriction: Student must be in program 1355 BNutrDiet or 1567 Bachelor of Education (Secondary education major with Food and Nutrition teaching area). Other students at course convenor's discretion.
Subject_Description_19: This course advances the physiology taught in first year with particular emphasis on the cardiovascular, respiratory, metabolic and renal body systems. The course focuses on the integrated functions of these systems from a clinical perspective. It forms the foundation of applied physiology courses that follow and will consist of on-line lectures, workshops, laboratory sessions and case study analysis. Prerequisite: 1017MSC Anatomy & Physiology Systems II.
Subject_Description_20: In this course students will explore the biological processes on which the continuity of life is based including cell reproduction, basic genetics and evolution. Case studies and laboratory activities will provide a challenging opportunity to develop the practical and intellectual skills of a scientist or health care worker. Prerequisite: 1014MSC Cells, Tissues and Regulation Assumed Knowledge: Maths B and One of Biology, Chemistry or Physics (4SA)
Subject_Description_21: Nutrition Education will provide students with the knowledge and skills necessary to plan, deliver and evaluate communication and education programs aimed at improving the dietary intake of groups and communities. The theory of behaviour change will form the basis for the course, and the main models will be covered. Students will participate in workshops to develop and implement nutrition education programs to the community and compile resources for use on Professional Placement and in their professional careers. The course prepares students to deliver education programs on all three types of professional placement. Pre-requisites: 2210AHS Nutrition, 2218MED Needs Assessment, Program Planning and Evaluation Co-requisites: 3101AHS Medical Nutrition Therapy 1
Subject_Description_22: This course is an applied skills-oriented course. The aim of this course is to provide you with the opportunity to develop your mastery of the generic interpersonal communication skills necessary for building and maintaining effective working and personal relationships, and managing interpersonal interactions and change. In addition, you will be introduced to skills which are the "building blocks" for more advanced skills that you may use in future professional roles such as Consultant, Counsellor, Lawyer, Manager, Psychologist, Public Health practitioner or Social Worker. INCOMPATIBLE: PSY2002 AND PB12013 AND JAD1006 OR 1006CCJ AND 2007APY AND 7022HSV AND 7322AHS AND 1008HSV AND 2008EHR.
Subject_Description_23: Medical Nutrition Therapy is the evidence-based process used by Dietitians to treat nutrition-related problems in individuals. The course starts by describing the principles of evidence-based research and how they are applied to Medical Nutrition Therapy. The course covers applications in chronic disease and malnutrition. The main areas encountered in dietetics (including adult weight management, cardiovascular disease, hypertension, and malnutrition screening and assessment) are covered in the course through lectures and tutorials including case presentations. This course forms the foundation for Medical Nutrition Therapy 2, which completes the coverage of disease states encountered by dietitians, particularly in the hospital inpatient setting. Pre-requisites: 2220AHS Food Science, 2011MSC Metabolism, 2002MSC Pathophysiology, 2012AHS Integrated Systems Physiology, 2008MSC Structural Biochemistry Co-requisites: 3104AHS Nutrition Education. Restricted to students enrolled in 1355 Bachelor of Nutrition and Dietetics.
Subject_Description_24: Community and public health nutritionists plan, implement and evaluate programs aimed at improving the nutritional health of communities and populations. The course will be delivered through lectures, tutorials and field work. Pebble pad may be used for elements in this course. Topics will include public health nutrition competencies, nutritional epidemiology, and monitoring of the food supply, and nutritional status in communities and populations. The course prepares students to meet the competencies required for the Community and Public Health Nutrition domain of practice. Pre-requisites: 2210AHS Nutrition, 2218MED Needs Assessment, Program Planning and Evaluation and 3104AHS Nutrition Education
Subject_Description_25: Cells, Tissues and Regulation examines how a single cell exists, and how when they come together in their trillions, we end up with human beings who can adapt to changing environments. Fundamental knowledge for any future health professionals. Assumed Knowledge: Maths B and One of Biology, Chemistry or Physics (4SA)
Subject_Description_26: The IPS course is designed to facilitate, guide and stimulate your interest and commitment to an increased understanding of what constitutes effective communication and also to develop the ability to communicate effectively. To assist with your skills acquisition, this course has been designed using an active learning approach. Learning actively will provide you with the opportunity to develop both a theoretical understanding and a practical ability to communicate and interact interpersonally. In preparation for your role as professionals in the field, you will be encouraged in this course to think of yourselves as practitioners-in-training. One of the implications of this, is that we expect you to be self managing in terms of your own learning and the learning of your colleagues. The Mixed Mode offering of this course is restricted for students enrolled in an External HSV Program only. Incompatible: 1801NRS Effective Communication; 1008PSY Interpersonal Skills; 2008EHR Business Communication.
Subject_or_Unit_27: FOOD, SOCIETY AND THE NUTRITION WORKFORCE
Subject_Description_27: This course is designed to engage students with food and nutrition content at this early stage of their degree. Specifically this course will explore student's personal food knowledge, attitudes and beliefs, will investigate food's place in society and describe the professional career options following the successful completion of a nutrition and dietetics degree. Restriction: Student must be in program 1355 BNutrDiet or 1567 Bachelor of Education (Secondary education major with Food and Nutrition teaching area)
Subject_Description_28: This course introduces organic and biological chemistry, which underpins all biochemical processes and the molecular basis of life. Pre-Requisite: 1001MSC Chemistry of Biological Systems I or 1023SCG Chemistry 1 Assumed Knowledge: Maths B and One of Biology, Chemistry or Physics (4SA).
Subject_or_Unit_29: NEEDS ASSESSMENT, PROGRAM PLANNING AND EVALUATION
Subject_Description_29: This course introduces students to the concepts, methodology and practice of public health planning and evaluation. Students develop knowledge and skills in the planning cycle from needs assessment through to program design, program implementation and program evaluation.

Description: The study of nutrition and dietetics focuses on the food we eat in relation to the treatment and prevention of a range of important diseases.  Students in this program will initially study fundamental health sciences (e.g. anatomy, physiology, biochemistry) before completing more advanced study of human nutrition. The final stage of the program involves practicum placements in hospitals and other health facilities. This program prepares students at the appropriate tertiary level to meet Dietitians Association of Australia (DAA) national competency standards for entry into the profession as a dietitian. Students who graduate from this program will be able establish careers in either clinical, public health or food service nutrition. Increased graduate opportunities exist for private practitioners with the recent introduction of Medicare items for services provided to patients with chronic disease and within the corporate nutrition sector. This program is available to students who have met the specified progression requirements to undertake Honours.
Career_Outcomes: You will be well positioned to work as a dietitian/nutritionist in private and public hospitals, community health services, health promotion and public health units and/or in private practice, health service management and the food and pharmaceutical industries.
Subject_Description_1: This course introduces the process of scientific enquiry and the application of appropriate research methods to address questions relevant to public health. It equips students with the basic knowledge and skills required to critically appraise and practise health research.
Subject_Description_2: Five body systems: Skeletal, Muscle, Nervous, Endocrine and Reproductive Systems are studied in this course, which integrates anatomy with physiology. The theory presented in this course is supported by practical laboratory experiences, which include the study of human cadaveric material.

Prerequisite: 2008MSC Structural Biochemistry Incompatible: 2005MSC Biochemistry.
Subject_or_Unit_4: NEEDS ASSESSMENT, PROGRAM PLANNING AND EVALUATION
Subject_Description_4: This course introduces students to the concepts, methodology and practice of public health planning and evaluation. Students develop knowledge and skills in the planning cycle from needs assessment through to program design, program implementation and program evaluation.
Subject_or_Unit_5: COMMUNITY AND PUBLIC HEALTH NUTRITION PRACTICUM

Students are placed in teams of two or three for 30 days to work on addressing a nutrition problem in a community based setting under the supervision of an Accredited Practicing Dietitian and/or Community and Public Health Nutritionist. Students will conduct a needs assessment, or plan, implement and/or evaluate a program relevant to the work of that setting. The placement will provide students with the opportunity to demonstrate practical skills and the application of theoretical knowledge into practice. By the end of the placement students will be assessed on CPHN competencies. Pre-requisites: All Year 3 core courses Co-requisites: 4110AHS Medical Nutrition Therapy Practicum, 4111AHS Food Service Management Practicum.
Subject_Description_6: The planning, operation, management and continuous quality improvement of food services plays an important role in providing essential services across a range of settings. This course will critically examine and contrast the processes involved in the provision of food and nutrition services. Furthermore, research skills will be applied to a capstone assessment item focusing on quality improvement in a food service system. The course prepares students for their 4111AHS Food Service Management Practicum in their final year. This is a restricted course offered to Bachelor of Nutrition & Dietetics students only.
Subject_Description_7: This course. is the first of two 20 Credit Point courses that make up the research component of the Bachelor of Nutrition and Dietetics program. For further course details refer to 6001AHS">6001AHS">6001AHS">6001AHS Part 2. 6001AHS">6001AHS">6001AHS">6001AHS Part 2 is the second of two 20 Credit Point courses that make up the research component of the Bachelor of Nutrition and Dietetics program. The combined 6001AHS">6001AHS">6001AHS">6001AHS courses require students to undertake a research project relevant to their area of specialisation under the guidance of a supervisor. This will involve the identification of a research question, selection of appropriate research design, data analysis and carrying out the research project. At the completion of the two Dissertation courses students will submit for examination a thesis (with an upper limit of 25,000 words).
Subject_Description_8: This Foundation Year course takes a multi-disciplinary and integrated approach to examine population health in the 21st century. Using a socio-ecological perspective, the course will take a systems approach (i.e. from prevention through to treatment) to introduce students to the environmental, social and behavioural determinants of health and disease. The course will link these determinants with global and national priority health challenges of the 21st century together with the implications for effective health care practice.

This course will describe the fundamental causes of disease (general pathology) and apply that knowledge to understanding common diseases affecting body systems (systemic pathology) including cancers, cardiovascular, skin and gastrointestinal/hepatic disorders. Prerequisite: 2012AHS Integrated Systems Physiology

Students will gain skills in analysis and interpretation of dietary records, and be able to develop recommendations to meet nutrient requirements. At the completion of this course, students will have knowledge of basic human nutrition, nutrient requirements, nutrient content of foods and the broad role of nutrition in maintaining optimal health.
Subject_Description_11: This course introduces students to the science of food. The course explores the nutritional composition, chemistry and function of foods and introduces students to theoretical and practical issues of food safety, food regulation and food as a form of therapy in the prevention and management of disease. This course forms the foundation for professional applications of nutrition and food in all domains of dietetic practice. Pre-requisites: 2210AHS Nutrition, 1015MSC Chemistry of Biological Systems Restriction: Student must be in program 1355 BNutrDiet or 1567 Bachelor of Education (Secondary education major with Food and Nutrition teaching area). Other students at course convenor's discretion.
Subject_Description_12: This course introduces the basic chemical principles that underlie biological systems. The foundation provided in this course will allow students to be able to further develop their chemistry knowledge and skills relevant to health and medical sciences in later years. Assumed Knowledge: Maths B and One of Biology, Chemistry or Physics. Incompatible with 1023SCG Chemistry I
Subject_Description_13: This course considers the molecular organisation of cells and the biochemical properties of the major classes of biological compounds which exist in and contribute to the cellular environment. Biochemistry laboratory studies are included. Prerequisite: 1005MSC Genes and Disease AND 1015MSC Chemistry in Biological Systems OR 1042SCG Genetics and Evolutionary Biology AND 1024SCG Chemistry II. Incompatible with: 2005MSC Biochemistry
Subject_Description_14: Cells, Tissues and Regulation examines how a single cell exists, and how when they come together in their trillions, we end up with human beings who can adapt to changing environments. Fundamental knowledge for any future health professionals. Assumed Knowledge: Maths B and One of Biology, Chemistry or Physics (4SA)
Subject_Description_15: This course introduces students to important concepts in Pharmacology. The major topic areas will provide an in depth understanding of drug targets, pharmacodynamics, pharmacokinetics and pharmacogenomics. Basic concepts in adverse drug reactions, drug interactions, toxicology and complementary medications will be introduced. The course will comprise lectures, workshops and laboratories. Pharmacology is a fundamental course that brings together chemistry and biology to understand the basis of drug effect. Pre-requisites: There are no pre-requisites for this course, however students will require a good understanding of tertiary level physiology, anatomy, chemistry and mathematics. Incompatible - 3002MSC Pharmacology
Subject_Description_16: Nutrition Education will provide students with the knowledge and skills necessary to plan, deliver and evaluate communication and education programs aimed at improving the dietary intake of groups and communities. The theory of behaviour change will form the basis for the course, and the main models will be covered. Students will participate in workshops to develop and implement nutrition education programs to the community and compile resources for use on Professional Placement and in their professional careers. The course prepares students to deliver education programs on all three types of professional placement. Pre-requisites: 2210AHS Nutrition, 2218MED Needs Assessment, Program Planning and Evaluation Co-requisites: 3101AHS Medical Nutrition Therapy 1
Subject_Description_17: This course covers the anatomy and physiology of the cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, digestive and immune systems. Both the study of the anatomy and the physiology of these systems draws on the experience gained in the lectures, laboratories and practicums. Prerequisites for Gold Coast students: 1016MSC">1016MSC Anatomy and Physiology Systems I, and 1014MSC Cells, Tissues and Regulation OR 1001AHS Foundations of Exercise and Sport Science. Prerequisites for Nathan students: 1016MSC">1016MSC Anatomy and Physiology Systems I and 1001NSC Human Biology.
Subject_Description_18: The IPS course is designed to facilitate, guide and stimulate your interest and commitment to an increased understanding of what constitutes effective communication and also to develop the ability to communicate effectively. To assist with your skills acquisition, this course has been designed using an active learning approach. Learning actively will provide you with the opportunity to develop both a theoretical understanding and a practical ability to communicate and interact interpersonally. In preparation for your role as professionals in the field, you will be encouraged in this course to think of yourselves as practitioners-in-training. One of the implications of this, is that we expect you to be self managing in terms of your own learning and the learning of your colleagues. The Mixed Mode offering of this course is restricted for students enrolled in an External HSV Program only. Incompatible: 1801NRS Effective Communication; 1008PSY Interpersonal Skills; 2008EHR Business Communication.
Subject_Description_19: This course introduces students to the practice field of Food Service Management (FSM). Students are placed in teams of two for a total of 20 days to develop their understanding of the role food service plays in the delivery of nutrition care in the acute care setting. Students will undertake a project aimed at making a quality improvement to the food service system. Students will be based in a setting under the supervision of an Accredited Practicing Dietitian. Students will be evaluated against the Dietitians Association of Australia (DAA) National Competency Standards (2015). Pre-requisites: All Year 3 core courses Co-requisites: 4110AHS Medical Nutrition Therapy Practicum, 4112AHS Community and Public Health Nutrition Practicum
Subject_Description_20: Community and public health nutritionists plan, implement and evaluate programs aimed at improving the nutritional health of communities and populations. The course will be delivered through lectures, tutorials and field work. Pebble pad may be used for elements in this course. Topics will include public health nutrition competencies, nutritional epidemiology, and monitoring of the food supply, and nutritional status in communities and populations. The course prepares students to meet the competencies required for the Community and Public Health Nutrition domain of practice. Pre-requisites: 2210AHS Nutrition, 2218MED Needs Assessment, Program Planning and Evaluation and 3104AHS Nutrition Education
Subject_Description_21: This course advances the physiology taught in first year with particular emphasis on the cardiovascular, respiratory, metabolic and renal body systems. The course focuses on the integrated functions of these systems from a clinical perspective. It forms the foundation of applied physiology courses that follow and will consist of on-line lectures, workshops, laboratory sessions and case study analysis. Prerequisite: 1017MSC Anatomy & Physiology Systems II.
Subject_Description_22: Medical Nutrition Therapy is the evidence-based process used by Dietitians to treat nutrition-related problems in individuals. The course starts by describing the principles of evidence-based research and how they are applied to Medical Nutrition Therapy. The course covers applications in chronic disease and malnutrition. The main areas encountered in dietetics (including adult weight management, cardiovascular disease, hypertension, and malnutrition screening and assessment) are covered in the course through lectures and tutorials including case presentations. This course forms the foundation for Medical Nutrition Therapy 2, which completes the coverage of disease states encountered by dietitians, particularly in the hospital inpatient setting. Pre-requisites: 2220AHS Food Science, 2011MSC Metabolism, 2002MSC Pathophysiology, 2012AHS Integrated Systems Physiology, 2008MSC Structural Biochemistry Co-requisites: 3104AHS Nutrition Education. Restricted to students enrolled in 1355 Bachelor of Nutrition and Dietetics.
Subject_Description_23: This course introduces organic and biological chemistry, which underpins all biochemical processes and the molecular basis of life. Pre-Requisite: 1001MSC Chemistry of Biological Systems I or 1023SCG Chemistry 1 Assumed Knowledge: Maths B and One of Biology, Chemistry or Physics (4SA).
Subject_Description_24: This placement course introduces students to the practice field of Medical Nutrition Therapy. Students spend a minimum of 50 working days in a hospital and/or other health care setting, delivering Medical Nutrition Therapy to individuals and small groups. Students are placed under the supervision of field Accredited Practising Dietitians with a minimum of two years' experience. During the placement, students observe, practice and are evaluated on the delivery of dietetic care to individuals. Students will be evaluated against the Dietitians Association of Australia (DAA) National competencies for Dietitians in Australia. Pre-requisites: All Year 3 core courses. Co-requisites: 4111AHS Food Service Management Practicum, 4112AHS Community and Public Health Nutrition Practicum.
Subject_Description_25: Communication and Counselling in Dietetics (CCD) will provide students with the knowledge and skills necessary to conduct a dietetic consultation, including counselling individuals to change food choice and eating behaviours. Students will develop and practice communication and counselling skills in workshops and in consultations with real and simulated patients, and will learn to work as an effective member of an Inter-professional team. As part of this course students will develop skills in communicating nutrition research to both colleagues and the general public. This course forms part of the knowledge base for the individual case management placement in year 4. Pre-requisites: 1008PSY Interpersonal Skills, 3101AHS Medical Nutrition Therapy, 3104AHS Nutrition Education Co-requisites: 3102 AHS Medical Nutrition Therapy 2
Subject_Description_26: Medical Nutrition Therapy 2 uses the nutrition care process framework introduced in Medical Nutrition Therapy 1 to consider disease states that require dietary modification in individuals. The content will include gastrointestinal disorders, renal disease and cancer, and the material will be delivered by guest dietitians specialising in these areas through lectures and case studies. This course forms part of the knowledge base for the individual case management placement in year 4. Pre-requisites: 3101AHS Medical Nutrition Therapy 1, 2008MSC Structural Biochemistry Co-requisites: 3100AHS Communication and Counselling for Dietetics
Subject_Description_27: In this course students will explore the biological processes on which the continuity of life is based including cell reproduction, basic genetics and evolution. Case studies and laboratory activities will provide a challenging opportunity to develop the practical and intellectual skills of a scientist or health care worker. Prerequisite: 1014MSC Cells, Tissues and Regulation Assumed Knowledge: Maths B and One of Biology, Chemistry or Physics (4SA)
Subject_Description_28: 6001AHS">6001AHS Part 2 is the second of two 20 Credit Point courses that make up the research component of the Bachelor of Nutrition and Dietetics program. The combined 6001AHS">6001AHS courses require students to undertake a research project relevant to their area of specialisation under the guidance of a supervisor. This will involve the identification of a research question, selection of appropriate research design, data analysis and carrying out the research project. At the completion of the two Dissertation courses students will submit for examination a thesis (with an upper limit of 25,000 words).
Subject_Description_29: This course describes the general principles of pharmacology from a contemporary viewpoint. Topics include receptor theory, mechanisms of drug action, absorption and distribution, metabolism and excretion of drugs, pharmokinetics, drug delivery systems, toxicology and clinical testing for drugs. Drug classes are illustrated using prototypical drugs. Prerequisite: 2012AHS Integrated Systems Physiology AND either 2008MSC Structural Biochemistry OR 2002AHS Biochemistry of Exercise OR 2005MSC Biochemistry Incompatible: with 2018PHM Pharmacology
Subject_or_Unit_30: FOOD, SOCIETY AND THE NUTRITION WORKFORCE
Subject_Description_30: This course is designed to engage students with food and nutrition content at this early stage of their degree. Specifically this course will explore student's personal food knowledge, attitudes and beliefs, will investigate food's place in society and describe the professional career options following the successful completion of a nutrition and dietetics degree. Restriction: Student must be in program 1355 BNutrDiet or 1567 Bachelor of Education (Secondary education major with Food and Nutrition teaching area)
Subject_Description_31: This course is an applied skills-oriented course. The aim of this course is to provide you with the opportunity to develop your mastery of the generic interpersonal communication skills necessary for building and maintaining effective working and personal relationships, and managing interpersonal interactions and change. In addition, you will be introduced to skills which are the "building blocks" for more advanced skills that you may use in future professional roles such as Consultant, Counsellor, Lawyer, Manager, Psychologist, Public Health practitioner or Social Worker. INCOMPATIBLE: PSY2002 AND PB12013 AND JAD1006 OR 1006CCJ AND 2007APY AND 7022HSV AND 7322AHS AND 1008HSV AND 2008EHR.

Description: International students must be in Australia and able to attend campus to commence this program. This program will be available to commencing students at the Gold Coast and Nathan from 2021. In this degree, you will develop the skills needed to work as an occupational therapist to deliver life changing outcomes. You will learn how to enable people to do the activities - occupations - they need or want to do in order to live a meaningful life, but have difficulty with due to illness, injury or other disadvantages. You will study occupational therapy theory and practice, occupational science, and other sciences such as psychology, sociology and anatomy. With 1000 hours of practical placements, starting in first year, you will apply the skills and knowledge to real life situations preparing you for the wide range of opportunities available to occupational therapists. In this degree, you will join a community of students and experts and learn through social media as well as in the classroom. Honours is available for this degree.
Career_Outcomes: You will be prepared for a career in a variety of workplaces, including in hospitals, homeless shelters, refugee detention centres, universities, and government departments. You will be able to work with individuals, groups and communities in social enterprises, charities, large companies, schools and prisons.
Subject_Description_1: This course provides an introduction to the contemporary debates in the social sciences and their relevance to social interventions in the health and human services arena. The social sciences provide human services practitioners with theoretical and methodological frameworks for professional practice. Frameworks, informed by the discipline of sociology, connect important concepts such as class, race, sex and age to social inequalities. This course is intended to expose students to the wider social and cultural context in which health and human services operate, including an understanding of culture, globalisation, environmental sustainability and issues surrounding disadvantage. Incompatible: 1007HUM Social Sciences in Australia. Restriction: Students must have this course listed in their program to enrol. Psychology students can choose this option as a free-choice elective in their program. Students who do not have this listed in their program will need to seek permission to have it approved as an elective in their program. Restriction: The online offering of this course is available for HSV students only. Students outside HSV will not be permitted to complete the online option this includes Psychology students who can only complete the on-campus option. NOTE ONLINE OFFERING: Please be aware that online learning is different to learning on campus. Depending on the structure of the course, you may have access to the same content and resources as on campus students. You will not have separate tutorials or lecture slides as this content is already represented on your Learning@Griffith course site. Online learning requires that you self pace through the content, under weekly direction from your teaching staff, which means that you need to take responsibility for your learning in a different way.
Subject_Description_2: This course prepares graduates across health professions to provide culturally safe health services to Australia's First Peoples. Through the enhancement of the previously introduced capabilities of respect, communication, safety and quality, critical reflection, and advocacy students will be supported to apply these capabilities in First Peoples' health contexts to engender the development of cultural capabilities that reflect a lifelong journey and are tested in every interaction. The course takes a holistic perspective to engage students in exploring the historical, socio-cultural, political and dominant cultural paradigms that influence First Peoples' health today. The First Peoples' Health and Practice course supports students to meet the Griffith University Graduate Attribute E.1 Awareness of and respect for the values and knowledge of Australian Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander First Peoples and to meet the requirements of the relevant professional body's competency standards and codes of professional conduct to provide culturally safe care. Pre-requisite: Students must have successfully completed at least 80CP of undergraduate study. This requirement will be strictly enforced.
Subject_Description_3: This course provides an introductory-level overview of several fields within psychology. It focuses on developmental and social processes and their relationships to individual differences in behaviour, and provides a broad introduction to the areas of developmental, personality, abnormal and social psychology. INCOMPATIBLE: PB11004 AND JAD1004 OR HJ11004 AND 1006APY AND 1015HSV
Subject_Description_4: The course will serve as a capstone for the program. It will provide an opportunity for students to reflect critically on their personal and professional development over the program, and use this as a basis for planning their career. Students will be supported to further develop a reflective approach to professional practice as a foundation for continuing professional development. Students will also be supported to begin career planning including identifying the wide range of potential employment opportunities and how to apply for jobs and market their services. Prerequisites: 4311AHS Advanced Occupational Therapy; 4315AHS Occupational Therapy Professional Practice Education III. Co-requisite: 4325AHS Occupational Therapy Professional Practice Education IV.
Subject_Description_5: This course will introduce students to the profession of occupational therapy and the concept of occupation. Students will begin to develop their knowledge of occupation as the organising construct of occupational therapy. Students will be introduced to occupation, its relationship to health, occupation as a vehicle for living a meaningful life and asserting identity. As well as university based learning, students will participate in community engagement activities to apply their learning and to contribute to the community.
Subject_Description_6: This is part two of a 20CP year long course which will introduce students to the core knowledge, skills and attitudes of occupational therapy practice. Specifically students will become familiar with the occupational therapy process, professional reasoning, information gathering and service provision. The material covered in this course will be returned to in future courses to deepen students' understanding and refine their application. Students will consider these core approaches to occupational therapy in low complexity situations and within the context of a team based approach to service provision. Prerequisite: 2311AHS_Y1 Fundamentals of Occupational Therapy Practice and Fit for Placement Mandatory Requirements
Subject_Description_7: This course will introduce students to the profession of occupational therapy and the concept of occupation. Students will consider the history of the profession and how that influences current practice. Students will be introduced to the diversity of settings in which occupational therapists work. Prerequisite: 1311AHS Occupation & Occupational Therapy I and Fit for Placement Mandatory Requirements
Subject_Description_8: This course covers the anatomy and physiology of the cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, digestive and immune systems. Both the study of the anatomy and the physiology of these systems draws on the experience gained in the lectures, laboratories and practicums. Prerequisites for Gold Coast students: 1016MSC">1016MSC Anatomy and Physiology Systems I, and 1014MSC Cells, Tissues and Regulation OR 1001AHS Foundations of Exercise and Sport Science. Prerequisites for Nathan students: 1016MSC">1016MSC Anatomy and Physiology Systems I and 1001NSC Human Biology.
Subject_Description_9: The IPS course is designed to facilitate, guide and stimulate your interest and commitment to an increased understanding of what constitutes effective communication and also to develop the ability to communicate effectively. To assist with your skills acquisition, this course has been designed using an active learning approach. Learning actively will provide you with the opportunity to develop both a theoretical understanding and a practical ability to communicate and interact interpersonally. In preparation for your role as professionals in the field, you will be encouraged in this course to think of yourselves as practitioners-in-training. One of the implications of this, is that we expect you to be self managing in terms of your own learning and the learning of your colleagues. The Mixed Mode offering of this course is restricted for students enrolled in an External HSV Program only. Incompatible: 1801NRS Effective Communication; 1008PSY Interpersonal Skills; 2008EHR Business Communication.
Subject_or_Unit_10: OCCUPATIONAL THERAPY PROFESSIONAL PRACTICE EDUCATION IV
Subject_Description_10: This course is the final full-time professional practice education placement and the fourth practice education placement. Students will be allocated to a placement provider where they will work under the supervision of an occupational therapist for a period of ten weeks full-time. Students will be assessed using the Student Practice Evaluation For - Revised Edition (SPEF-R). The course learning outcomes relate directly to the SPEF-R but the manner in which these are achieved will vary depending on the nature of the placement. At the completion of this course students are expected to be performing at the level of near entry-level student practitioner. Prerequisites: 4311AHS Advanced Occupational Therapy; 4315AHS Occupational Therapy Professional Practice Education III and Fit for Placement Mandatory Requirements Co-requisite: 4321AHS Emerging as an Occupational Therapist
Subject_Description_11: This is part 1 of a 20 credit point year-long course. The course will introduce students to the core knowledge, skills and attitudes of occupational therapy practice. Specifically students will continue their exploration and application of the occupational therapy process, with an increasing focus on professional reasoning, information gathering and service provision. The material covered in this course will be returned to in future courses to deepen students' understanding and refine their application. Students will consider these fundamentals of occupational therapy practice in low complexity situations. Prerequisite: 1321AHS Occupation and Occupational Therapy II and Fit for Placement Mandatory Requirements
Subject_or_Unit_12: OCCUPATIONAL THERAPY PROFESSIONAL PRACTICE EDUCATION I
Subject_Description_12: This course is the first full-time professional practice education placement. Students will be allocated to a placement provider where they will work under the supervision of an occupational therapist for a period of seven weeks full-time. Students will be assessed using the Student Practice Evaluation Form - Revised Edition (SPEF-R). The course learning outcomes relate directly to the SPEF-R but the manner in which these are achieved will vary depending on the nature of the placement. At the completion of this course students are expected to be performing at the level of beginning student practitioner. Prerequisite: Successful completion of all courses in Years 1 and 2 of 1400 Bachelor of Occupational Therapy or 1587 Bachelor of Occupational Therapy and Fit for Placement Mandatory Requirements Co-requisite: 3311AHS Occupation, Health and Participation (individuals)
Subject_or_Unit_13: OCCUPATIONAL THERAPY PROFESSIONAL PRACTICE EDUCATION II
Subject_Description_13: This is the second Professional Practice Education placement and provides an opportunity for students to examine the occupational therapy contribution to an emerging / future practice area. Students will be allocated to a placement provider, usually in pairs or small groups, where they will work under the day to day supervision of a member of staff at the placement provider. Students will also receive regular supervision from an occupational therapist. At the completion of this course students are expected to be performing at the level of beginning student practitioner. Prerequisites:3311AHS Occupation, Health and Participation - Individuals; 3315AHS Occupational Therapy Professional Practice Education I and Fit for Placement Mandatory Requirements Co-requisite: 3322AHS Occupation, Health and Participation - Communities and Populations
Subject_or_Unit_14: NEEDS ASSESSMENT, PROGRAM PLANNING AND EVALUATION
Subject_Description_14: This course introduces students to the concepts, methodology and practice of public health planning and evaluation. Students develop knowledge and skills in the planning cycle from needs assessment through to program design, program implementation and program evaluation.
Subject_Description_15: This Foundation Year course takes a multi-disciplinary and integrated approach to examine population health in the 21st century. Using a socio-ecological perspective, the course will take a systems approach (i.e. from prevention through to treatment) to introduce students to the environmental, social and behavioural determinants of health and disease. The course will link these determinants with global and national priority health challenges of the 21st century together with the implications for effective health care practice.
Subject_Description_16: This course provides students with an opportunity to consolidate their knowledge, skills and attitudes through a significant project. Students will be supported to explore current local occupational issues. In teams students will select an issue and then plan, develop, deliver and evaluate an occupational intervention. Incompatible: 2043MKT Entrepreneurship and New Business Ventures; 2043IBA Innovation, Creativity and Entrepreneurship Prerequisites: 3322AHS Occupation, Health and Participation - Communities and Populations; 3326AHS Occupational Therapy Professional Practice and Education II.
Subject_Description_17: This course will focus on the ways in which humans, occupational engagement and performance, and participation are located within a range of contexts. Students will be introduced to those contexts and the reciprocal relationship that exists between humans, occupational performance and engagement, participation, and the multitude of contexts (including social, political, economic, attitudinal, physical). This will enable students to appreciate the ways in which humans as occupational beings are contextualised, and the way in which occupational therapy practice is also contextualised. Prerequisites: 2209MED Priorities and Interventions in Public Health and 2311AHS_Y1 Fundamentals of Occupational Therapy Practice.
Subject_or_Unit_18: OCCUPATIONAL THERAPY PROFESSIONAL PRACTICE EDUCATION III
Subject_Description_18: This course is the second full-time professional practice education placement and the third practice education placement. Students will be allocated to a placement provider where they will work under the supervision of an occupational therapist for a period of seven weeks full-time. Students will be assessed using the Student Practice Evaluation Form - Revised Edition (SPEF-R). The course learning outcomes relate directly to the SPEF-R but the manner in which these are achieved will vary depending on the nature of the placement. At the completion of this course students are expected to be performing at the level of emerging student practitioner. Prerequisites: 3322AHS Occupation, Health and Participation - Communities and Populations; 3326AHS Occupational Therapy Professional Practice Education II and Fit for Placement Mandatory Requirements Co-requisite: 4311AHS Advanced Occupational Therapy.
Subject_or_Unit_19: PRIORITIES AND INTERVENTIONS IN PUBLIC HEALTH
Subject_Description_19: This course engages students in a critical examination of health promotion and public health nutrition interventions to priority health issues within local, national and international contexts.
Subject_Description_20: This course will continue to develop students' knowledge, skills and attitudes in occupational therapy, with a focus on working with individuals. Students will explore ways of understanding the occupational issues facing individuals and barriers to health and participation. Students will further develop their professional understanding through application of the occupational therapy process. This course will also prepare students for their first full-time Practice Education experience by examining teamwork, therapeutic communication, ethics and professional reasoning. Prerequisite: Successful completion of all courses in Years 1 and 2 of 1400 - Bachelor of Occupational Therapy or 1587 - Bachelor of Occupational Therapy. Co-requisite: 3315AHS Occupational Therapy Professional Practice and Education.
Subject_Description_21: Five body systems: Skeletal, Muscle, Nervous, Endocrine and Reproductive Systems are studied in this course, which integrates anatomy with physiology. The theory presented in this course is supported by practical laboratory experiences, which include the study of human cadaveric material.
Subject_Description_22: This course provides students with fundamental statistical skills required in many health study areas and in careers as health professionals. Students will explore foundational statistical principles and practice the art of statistical data analysis and reporting of results. Assumed Knowledge: Maths B (or equivalent). Incompatible with 1014SCG.
Subject_or_Unit_23: OCCUPATION, HEALTH AND PARTICIPATION - COMMUNITIES AND POPULATIONS
Subject_Description_23: This course will continue to develop students' knowledge, skills and attitudes in occupational therapy, with a focus on working with communities and populations. Students will consider what constitutes 'community', and explore ways of understanding the occupational issues facing communities and populations, and barriers to health and participation. Students will further develop their ability to devise and implement occupational therapy interventions. Prerequisites: 3311AHS Occupation, Health and Participation - Individuals; 3315AHS Occupational Therapy Professional Practice Education I. Co-requisite: 3326AHS Occupational Therapy Professional Practice Education II
Subject_Description_24: This course provides students with an opportunity to explore key aspects of occupational therapy in greater depth, in preparation for becoming a professional. The course will focus on specific areas of knowledge, skills and attitudes that are relevant to occupational therapy in a range of settings. Topics covered will include professional reasoning, evidence based practice, negotiating complex practice situations, legal, ethical and safe approaches to working with individuals, communities and populations with complex needs. Pre-requisite: 3322AHS Occupation, Health and Participation - Communities and Populations; 3326AHS Occupational Therapy Professional Practice and Education II. Co-requisite: 4315AHS Occupational Therapy Professional Practice and Education III.
Subject_Description_25: This course will provide an opportunity for students to consider contemporary issues facing the profession, health care and society. Students will be supported to understand these current issues from an occupational perspective and to consider the contribution occupational therapy might make. Prerequisite: 4311AHS Advanced Occupational Therapy
Subject_Description_26: This course introduces the process of scientific enquiry and the application of appropriate research methods to address questions relevant to public health. It equips students with the basic knowledge and skills required to critically appraise and practise health research.

Description: This program will be available to commencing students at the Gold Coast and Nathan from 2021. You will learn how to enable people to do the activities - occupations - they need or want to do in order to live a meaningful life, but have difficulty with due to illness, injury or other disadvantages. You will study occupational therapy theory and practice, occupational science, and other sciences such as psychology, sociology and anatomy. This program is available to students who have met the specified progression requirements to undertake Honours.

You will be able to work with individuals, groups and communities in social enterprises, charities, large companies, schools and prisons.

Prerequisite: 1311AHS Occupation & Occupational Therapy I and Fit for Placement Mandatory Requirements

Prerequisites: 4311AHS Advanced Occupational Therapy; 4315AHS Occupational Therapy Professional Practice Education III. Co-requisite: 4325AHS Occupational Therapy Professional Practice Education IV.

Pre-requisite: 3322AHS Occupation, Health and Participation - Communities and Populations; 3326AHS Occupational Therapy Professional Practice and Education II. Co-requisite: 4315AHS Occupational Therapy Professional Practice and Education III.
