As well as university based learning, students will participate in community engagement activities to apply their learning and to contribute to the community.
Subject_or_Unit_6: NEEDS ASSESSMENT, PROGRAM PLANNING AND EVALUATION
Subject_Description_6: This course introduces students to the concepts, methodology and practice of public health planning and evaluation. Students develop knowledge and skills in the planning cycle from needs assessment through to program design, program implementation and program evaluation.
Subject_Description_7: This course prepares graduates across health professions to provide culturally safe health services to Australia's First Peoples. Through the enhancement of the previously introduced capabilities of respect, communication, safety and quality, critical reflection, and advocacy students will be supported to apply these capabilities in First Peoples' health contexts to engender the development of cultural capabilities that reflect a lifelong journey and are tested in every interaction. The course takes a holistic perspective to engage students in exploring the historical, socio-cultural, political and dominant cultural paradigms that influence First Peoples' health today. The First Peoples' Health and Practice course supports students to meet the Griffith University Graduate Attribute E.1 Awareness of and respect for the values and knowledge of Australian Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander First Peoples and to meet the requirements of the relevant professional body's competency standards and codes of professional conduct to provide culturally safe care. Pre-requisite: Students must have successfully completed at least 80CP of undergraduate study. This requirement will be strictly enforced.
Subject_Description_8: This course is the first in the honours pathway that enables students to design, conduct and report a research project, under the supervision of an academic member of staff. This course will culminate in students submitting a written Dissertation and providing a verbal presentation of their research and associated study findings.
Subject_Description_9: This course will continue to develop students' knowledge, skills and attitudes in occupational therapy, with a focus on working with individuals. Students will explore ways of understanding the occupational issues facing individuals and barriers to health and participation. Students will further develop their professional understanding through application of the occupational therapy process. This course will also prepare students for their first full-time Practice Education experience by examining teamwork, therapeutic communication, ethics and professional reasoning. Prerequisite: Successful completion of all courses in Years 1 and 2 of 1400 - Bachelor of Occupational Therapy or 1587 - Bachelor of Occupational Therapy. Co-requisite: 3315AHS Occupational Therapy Professional Practice and Education.
Subject_Description_10: This is part two of a 20CP year long course which will introduce students to the core knowledge, skills and attitudes of occupational therapy practice. Specifically students will become familiar with the occupational therapy process, professional reasoning, information gathering and service provision. The material covered in this course will be returned to in future courses to deepen students' understanding and refine their application. Students will consider these core approaches to occupational therapy in low complexity situations and within the context of a team based approach to service provision. Prerequisite: 2311AHS_Y1 Fundamentals of Occupational Therapy Practice and Fit for Placement Mandatory Requirements
Subject_Description_11: This course provides an introduction to the contemporary debates in the social sciences and their relevance to social interventions in the health and human services arena. The social sciences provide human services practitioners with theoretical and methodological frameworks for professional practice. Frameworks, informed by the discipline of sociology, connect important concepts such as class, race, sex and age to social inequalities. This course is intended to expose students to the wider social and cultural context in which health and human services operate, including an understanding of culture, globalisation, environmental sustainability and issues surrounding disadvantage. Incompatible: 1007HUM Social Sciences in Australia. Restriction: Students must have this course listed in their program to enrol. Psychology students can choose this option as a free-choice elective in their program. Students who do not have this listed in their program will need to seek permission to have it approved as an elective in their program. Restriction: The online offering of this course is available for HSV students only. Students outside HSV will not be permitted to complete the online option this includes Psychology students who can only complete the on-campus option. NOTE ONLINE OFFERING: Please be aware that online learning is different to learning on campus. Depending on the structure of the course, you may have access to the same content and resources as on campus students. You will not have separate tutorials or lecture slides as this content is already represented on your Learning@Griffith course site. Online learning requires that you self pace through the content, under weekly direction from your teaching staff, which means that you need to take responsibility for your learning in a different way.
Subject_Description_12: This course provides students with fundamental statistical skills required in many health study areas and in careers as health professionals. Students will explore foundational statistical principles and practice the art of statistical data analysis and reporting of results. Assumed Knowledge: Maths B (or equivalent). Incompatible with 1014SCG.
Subject_or_Unit_13: OCCUPATIONAL THERAPY PROFESSIONAL PRACTICE EDUCATION I
Subject_Description_13: This course is the first full-time professional practice education placement. Students will be allocated to a placement provider where they will work under the supervision of an occupational therapist for a period of seven weeks full-time. Students will be assessed using the Student Practice Evaluation Form - Revised Edition (SPEF-R). The course learning outcomes relate directly to the SPEF-R but the manner in which these are achieved will vary depending on the nature of the placement. At the completion of this course students are expected to be performing at the level of beginning student practitioner. Prerequisite: Successful completion of all courses in Years 1 and 2 of 1400 Bachelor of Occupational Therapy or 1587 Bachelor of Occupational Therapy and Fit for Placement Mandatory Requirements Co-requisite: 3311AHS Occupation, Health and Participation (individuals)
Subject_Description_14: This course provides an introductory-level overview of several fields within psychology. It focuses on developmental and social processes and their relationships to individual differences in behaviour, and provides a broad introduction to the areas of developmental, personality, abnormal and social psychology. INCOMPATIBLE: PB11004 AND JAD1004 OR HJ11004 AND 1006APY AND 1015HSV
Subject_or_Unit_15: OCCUPATIONAL THERAPY PROFESSIONAL PRACTICE EDUCATION II
Subject_Description_15: This is the second Professional Practice Education placement and provides an opportunity for students to examine the occupational therapy contribution to an emerging / future practice area. Students will be allocated to a placement provider, usually in pairs or small groups, where they will work under the day to day supervision of a member of staff at the placement provider. Students will also receive regular supervision from an occupational therapist. At the completion of this course students are expected to be performing at the level of beginning student practitioner. Prerequisites:3311AHS Occupation, Health and Participation - Individuals; 3315AHS Occupational Therapy Professional Practice Education I and Fit for Placement Mandatory Requirements Co-requisite: 3322AHS Occupation, Health and Participation - Communities and Populations
Subject_Description_16: This course is the third in the honours pathway that enables students to design, conduct and report a research project, under the supervision of an academic member of staff. This course will culminate in students submitting a written Dissertation and providing a verbal presentation of their research and associated study findings.
Subject_Description_17: Five body systems: Skeletal, Muscle, Nervous, Endocrine and Reproductive Systems are studied in this course, which integrates anatomy with physiology. The theory presented in this course is supported by practical laboratory experiences, which include the study of human cadaveric material.
Subject_Description_18: The IPS course is designed to facilitate, guide and stimulate your interest and commitment to an increased understanding of what constitutes effective communication and also to develop the ability to communicate effectively. To assist with your skills acquisition, this course has been designed using an active learning approach. Learning actively will provide you with the opportunity to develop both a theoretical understanding and a practical ability to communicate and interact interpersonally. In preparation for your role as professionals in the field, you will be encouraged in this course to think of yourselves as practitioners-in-training. One of the implications of this, is that we expect you to be self managing in terms of your own learning and the learning of your colleagues. The Mixed Mode offering of this course is restricted for students enrolled in an External HSV Program only. Incompatible: 1801NRS Effective Communication; 1008PSY Interpersonal Skills; 2008EHR Business Communication.
Subject_Description_19: This course covers the anatomy and physiology of the cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, digestive and immune systems. Both the study of the anatomy and the physiology of these systems draws on the experience gained in the lectures, laboratories and practicums. Prerequisites for Gold Coast students: 1016MSC">1016MSC Anatomy and Physiology Systems I, and 1014MSC Cells, Tissues and Regulation OR 1001AHS Foundations of Exercise and Sport Science. Prerequisites for Nathan students: 1016MSC">1016MSC Anatomy and Physiology Systems I and 1001NSC Human Biology.
Subject_Description_20: This course is the second in the honours pathway that enables students to design, conduct and report a research project, under the supervision of an academic member of staff. This course will culminate in students submitting a written Dissertation and providing a verbal presentation of their research and associated study findings.
Subject_Description_21: This course will focus on the ways in which humans, occupational engagement and performance, and participation are located within a range of contexts. Students will be introduced to those contexts and the reciprocal relationship that exists between humans, occupational performance and engagement, participation, and the multitude of contexts (including social, political, economic, attitudinal, physical). This will enable students to appreciate the ways in which humans as occupational beings are contextualised, and the way in which occupational therapy practice is also contextualised. Prerequisites: 2209MED Priorities and Interventions in Public Health and 2311AHS_Y1 Fundamentals of Occupational Therapy Practice.
Subject_or_Unit_22: PRIORITIES AND INTERVENTIONS IN PUBLIC HEALTH
Subject_Description_22: This course engages students in a critical examination of health promotion and public health nutrition interventions to priority health issues within local, national and international contexts.
Subject_Description_23: This is part 1 of a 20 credit point year-long course. The course will introduce students to the core knowledge, skills and attitudes of occupational therapy practice. Specifically students will continue their exploration and application of the occupational therapy process, with an increasing focus on professional reasoning, information gathering and service provision. The material covered in this course will be returned to in future courses to deepen students' understanding and refine their application. Students will consider these fundamentals of occupational therapy practice in low complexity situations. Prerequisite: 1321AHS Occupation and Occupational Therapy II and Fit for Placement Mandatory Requirements
Subject_Description_24: This Foundation Year course takes a multi-disciplinary and integrated approach to examine population health in the 21st century. Using a socio-ecological perspective, the course will take a systems approach (i.e. from prevention through to treatment) to introduce students to the environmental, social and behavioural determinants of health and disease. The course will link these determinants with global and national priority health challenges of the 21st century together with the implications for effective health care practice.
Subject_or_Unit_25: OCCUPATIONAL THERAPY PROFESSIONAL PRACTICE EDUCATION IV
Subject_Description_25: This course is the final full-time professional practice education placement and the fourth practice education placement. Students will be allocated to a placement provider where they will work under the supervision of an occupational therapist for a period of ten weeks full-time. Students will be assessed using the Student Practice Evaluation For - Revised Edition (SPEF-R). The course learning outcomes relate directly to the SPEF-R but the manner in which these are achieved will vary depending on the nature of the placement. At the completion of this course students are expected to be performing at the level of near entry-level student practitioner. Prerequisites: 4311AHS Advanced Occupational Therapy; 4315AHS Occupational Therapy Professional Practice Education III and Fit for Placement Mandatory Requirements Co-requisite: 4321AHS Emerging as an Occupational Therapist
Subject_or_Unit_26: OCCUPATIONAL THERAPY PROFESSIONAL PRACTICE EDUCATION III
Subject_Description_26: This course is the second full-time professional practice education placement and the third practice education placement. Students will be allocated to a placement provider where they will work under the supervision of an occupational therapist for a period of seven weeks full-time. Students will be assessed using the Student Practice Evaluation Form - Revised Edition (SPEF-R). The course learning outcomes relate directly to the SPEF-R but the manner in which these are achieved will vary depending on the nature of the placement. At the completion of this course students are expected to be performing at the level of emerging student practitioner. Prerequisites: 3322AHS Occupation, Health and Participation - Communities and Populations; 3326AHS Occupational Therapy Professional Practice Education II and Fit for Placement Mandatory Requirements Co-requisite: 4311AHS Advanced Occupational Therapy.
Subject_or_Unit_27: OCCUPATION, HEALTH AND PARTICIPATION - COMMUNITIES AND POPULATIONS
Subject_Description_27: This course will continue to develop students' knowledge, skills and attitudes in occupational therapy, with a focus on working with communities and populations. Students will consider what constitutes 'community', and explore ways of understanding the occupational issues facing communities and populations, and barriers to health and participation. Students will further develop their ability to devise and implement occupational therapy interventions. Prerequisites: 3311AHS Occupation, Health and Participation - Individuals; 3315AHS Occupational Therapy Professional Practice Education I. Co-requisite: 3326AHS Occupational Therapy Professional Practice Education II

Description: International students must be in Australia and able to attend campus to commence this program. A limited number of places for International students will be available in the Bachelor of Paramedicine program from 2018. You will be prepared to work as a paramedic in a range of traditional and non-traditional settings. You will gain clinical decision-making, problem-solving and critical thinking skills, and will learn about human body systems, paramedic practice, emergency treatment of disease and response to trauma. You will also develop strong practical skills through clinical simulation delivered through Griffith's extensive range of simulation facilities and will complete a range of clinical placements to enhance your professional practice. Honours is available through an additional year of study.
Career_Outcomes: Graduates of this degree will be able to apply for employment as a graduate level paramedic within Australia (following registration) and a number of other countries. Other careers areas may also include the military, mining and other commercial paramedic opportunities.
Subject_Description_1: Paramedics are deployed to a wide range of non-emergency occurrences. In this course students will develop knowledge and skills required to critically evaluate, assess and examine, non-emergency patients. Students will appraise the factors that contribute to ill-health and also identify clinical and nonclinical issues impacting the non-emergency patients. Students will assess non-emergency patients holistically and formulate plans for ongoing medical care.
Subject_Description_2: This course introduces students to important concepts in Pharmacology. The major topic areas will provide an in depth understanding of drug targets, pharmacodynamics, pharmacokinetics and pharmacogenomics. Basic concepts in adverse drug reactions, drug interactions, toxicology and complementary medications will be introduced. The course will comprise lectures, workshops and laboratories. Pharmacology is a fundamental course that brings together chemistry and biology to understand the basis of drug effect. Pre-requisites: There are no pre-requisites for this course, however students will require a good understanding of tertiary level physiology, anatomy, chemistry and mathematics. Incompatible - 3002MSC Pharmacology
Subject_or_Unit_3: LEGAL AND ETHICAL PRINCIPLES IN HEALTHCARE
Subject_Description_3: Health care practitioners are regularly confronted by legally complex and ethically challenging clinical situations. To ensure that they practice according to current legal and professional standards, a sound understanding of legal and ethical principles that underpin safe and competent practice is required. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: NIL
Subject_Description_4: In this course students will be introduced to the origin and direction of pre-hospital care. Students will also learn the role of interpersonal communication in paramedic practice. Students will also be introduced to a safe systematic clinical approach to assess and manage a non-complicated patient in a pre-hospital setting. Co-Requisites 1014MSC and 1016MSC
Subject_Description_5: This course will address relevant aspects of the spread of disease within health care settings and the community. The online modules are designed to enhance your understanding of medically important microbes and their transmission, infection control measures, effective work practice and procedures and management of infectious diseases. Prerequisites: 1005MSC Genes and Disease or 1042SCG Genetics and Evolutionary Biology| 1812MED Expanding Paramedic Practice 2 Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: NIL
Subject_Description_6: Nurses and Paramedics work closely with individuals across the lifespan. This course introduces students to psychosocial concepts and principles that underpin human behaviour thereby facilitating understanding about the ways in which people engage in health and illness. Students will learn through wide reading, in class discussion in groups and practice of therapeutic skills, and through on-line activities. There will be a focus on presentation skills. NOTE: This course is restricted to Bachelor of Nursing and Bachelor of Paramedicine students ONLY. Prerequisites : NIL Co-requisites : NIL Incompatible : 1010HSV Lifespan Development| 2015PSY Developmental Psychology| 1973NRS Foundations of Psychosocial Care| 3011PSY Lifespan Development
Subject_or_Unit_7: MATERNAL AND NEONATAL CONDITIONS IN PARAMEDIC PRACTICE
Subject_Description_7: This course introduces students to gynaecological, obstetric and neonatal patient presentations encountered in the prehospital setting. Students will explore theoretical knowledge and clinical skills to assess and manage patient presentations. Students will apply a systematic clinical approach and develop their clinical reasoning to gynaecological, obstetric and neonatal patient presentations though this course.
Subject_Description_8: This course follows on from the course 1811MED">1811MED Paramedic Practice 1 that introduced a systematic clinical approach to assess and manage a non-complicated patient in a pre-hospital setting. 1812MED Paramedic Practice 2 continues to build on this foundational knowledge by expanding on this systematic clinical approach to manage the unconscious and/or cardiac arrest patient. In this course students will continue to build professional identity and interpersonal communication skills. Prerequisite is 1811MED">1811MED, 1014MSC, 1016MSC and Co-Req 1017MSC
Subject_Description_9: Five body systems: Skeletal, Muscle, Nervous, Endocrine and Reproductive Systems are studied in this course, which integrates anatomy with physiology. The theory presented in this course is supported by practical laboratory experiences, which include the study of human cadaveric material.
Subject_Description_10: To provide students with their second practical exposure to operational life as a paramedic. Students will be placed on a six (6) week placement within an Operational Ambulance Station as a third officer, rotating through a roster with an operational Paramedic crew. Students will experience shift work that could include day, afternoon, night and weekend shifts and be exposed to the type of everyday work paramedics are faced with whilst on shift. Prerequisite 3810MED and 3820MED.
Subject_Description_11: Students will be allocated a four (4) week clinical placement at the end of their First Year of the Bachelor of Paramedicine Program. Students will be assigned to an Operational Ambulance Station as a third officer, rotating through a roster with an operational Ambulance Paramedic crew. Whilst immersed within the prehospital environment Students will be required to complete associated assessment tasks to further scaffold and foster learning.
Subject_Description_12: This course will focus on the human skills such as general communication skills, team work and the human experience in the health environment along with areas related to being a medical or paramedicine student, including professionalism, ethics, cultural competency, reflective practice and self care. This is a designated course for B.Med Science (programs 1280 and 1306) and B.Paramedicine (1533) students that focuses on development and application of human skills in order to transform the student from being a university student to a "Physician/Paramedic in training" within the Griffith MD program and Bachelor of Paramedicine Programs respectively. There are no presumed prior courses.
Subject_Description_13: This final course in your Paramedicine degree is designed to provide you with the opportunity to consolidate the knowledge, skills and attributes required for safe, competent and professional practice in the health workplace as a beginning level graduate paramedic. Assessment within this unit will be achieved by completing a series of Problem Based Learning activities that build on previous clinical courses and draw upon concepts, principles and theories that have been developed through your studies in paramedic and related sciences to successfully complete this course. Prerequisite courses 3810MED and 3820MED.
Subject_or_Unit_14: MAJOR INCIDENT MANAGEMENT IN PARAMEDIC PRACTICE
Subject_Description_14: This course will enable students to manage a major incident or disaster involving a mass casualty situation in line with current national and international frameworks whilst developing their clinical leadership ability. Prerequisites: Courses 2811MED and 2814MED
Subject_or_Unit_15: TRAUMA AND ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS IN PARAMEDIC PRACTICE
Subject_Description_15: This two-part course covers basic trauma management and environmental emergencies in paramedic practice. Part 1. Traumatic Emergencies and Neurological Care in Paramedic Practice. Concepts introduced will include the patterns and mechanisms of injury as well as the associated physiology, pathophysiology and treatment of such emergencies. Part 2 - Environment Emergencies in Paramedic Practice. Concepts include specific types of injuries with the associated physiology, pathophysiology and treatment of such emergencies. Prerequisite courses 2811MED and 2814MED.
Subject_or_Unit_16: MENTAL HEALTH CONDITIONS IN PARAMEDIC PRACTICE
Subject_Description_16: This course will focus on treatment of Mental Health patients within the pre-hospital setting. The correct treatment and understanding of mental illness and other vulnerable patients is vital skill for all paramedics. Your course will ensure you have a sound understanding of current clinical practice, treatment and social needs when responding to mental health and other vulnerable patients as a paramedic. Prerequisite: 2820MED and 2812MED.
Subject_Description_17: This course introduces cardiovascular conditions that are likely to be encountered in the pre-hospital setting. Students will develop specific theoretical knowledge and clinical skills to assess and manage sub-actute, acute and chronic cardiovascular conditions encountered in the pre-hospital setting. Students will apply a systematic approach, demonstrate clinical reasoning and evidenced based management of pre-hospital cardiovascular conditions. 12 lead ECG acquisition and interpretation knowledge will be developed and integrated into clinical reasoning and practice. Prerequisite: 1801MED Applied Paramedic Clinical Placement 1
Subject_Description_18: This course will examine the epidemiology of respiratory conditions, cancer and palliative care across the lifespan. Students will analyse the factors affecting the prevalence and outcome of these diseases and investigate the role of paramedics in todays prehospital environment. Throughout this course you will further develop critical thinking, knowledge and technical skills required to optimise patient outcomes in cases of respiratory disease. Prerequisite courses 2811MED and 2814MED.
Subject_Description_19: This course introduces the process of scientific enquiry and the application of appropriate research methods to address questions relevant to public health. It equips students with the basic knowledge and skills required to critically appraise and practise health research.
Subject_Description_20: This course covers the anatomy and physiology of the cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, digestive and immune systems. Both the study of the anatomy and the physiology of these systems draws on the experience gained in the lectures, laboratories and practicums. Prerequisites for Gold Coast students: 1016MSC">1016MSC Anatomy and Physiology Systems I, and 1014MSC Cells, Tissues and Regulation OR 1001AHS Foundations of Exercise and Sport Science. Prerequisites for Nathan students: 1016MSC">1016MSC Anatomy and Physiology Systems I and 1001NSC Human Biology.
Subject_Description_21: This Foundation Year course takes a multi-disciplinary and integrated approach to examine population health in the 21st century. Using a socio-ecological perspective, the course will take a systems approach (i.e. from prevention through to treatment) to introduce students to the environmental, social and behavioural determinants of health and disease. The course will link these determinants with global and national priority health challenges of the 21st century together with the implications for effective health care practice.
Subject_Description_22: Cells, Tissues and Regulation examines how a single cell exists, and how when they come together in their trillions, we end up with human beings who can adapt to changing environments. Fundamental knowledge for any future health professionals. Assumed Knowledge: Maths B and One of Biology, Chemistry or Physics (4SA)
Subject_or_Unit_23: MEDICAL AND TOXICOLOGICAL CONDITIONS IN PARAMEDIC PRACTICE
Subject_Description_23: Paramedics are required to develop deep knowledge about medical emergencies across the lifespan. In this course students develop knowledge, critical thinking and technical skills required to undertake assessment of the environment and how to manage patients and initiate prehopsital emergency care. You will develop an understanding of how to opitmize patient outcomes and how to manage medical, neurological and toxilogical conditions. Prerequisites: 1801MED Applied Paramedic Clinical Placement 1.
Subject_Description_24: This course prepares graduates across health professions to provide culturally safe health services to Australia's First Peoples. Through the enhancement of the previously introduced capabilities of respect, communication, safety and quality, critical reflection, and advocacy students will be supported to apply these capabilities in First Peoples' health contexts to engender the development of cultural capabilities that reflect a lifelong journey and are tested in every interaction. The course takes a holistic perspective to engage students in exploring the historical, socio-cultural, political and dominant cultural paradigms that influence First Peoples' health today. The First Peoples' Health and Practice course supports students to meet the Griffith University Graduate Attribute E.1 Awareness of and respect for the values and knowledge of Australian Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander First Peoples and to meet the requirements of the relevant professional body's competency standards and codes of professional conduct to provide culturally safe care. Pre-requisite: Students must have successfully completed at least 80CP of undergraduate study. This requirement will be strictly enforced.

Description: This program is designed to provide students with an opportunity to undertake advanced study and supervised research work in paramedic pre-hospital care. The research skills developed within the program will provide an attractive credential for students seeking employment in the public or private sectors. The program will also provide the necessary preparation for entry into a higher degree research program. The multidisciplinary context of the program, involving team-teaching of students and the sharing of coursework and seminar experiences across disciplines will be invaluable to students given the importance of a multidisciplinary approach to researchers and practitioners seeking to understand complex problems in health.
Career_Outcomes: Graduates of the program will be able to plan and conduct research in pre-hospital care and related disciplines, and therefore will be well-placed for positions in the private, not for profit, and public sectors. In addition, graduates will be eligible to apply for admission to higher degree research programs, thereby preparing them for high level research careers.

Description: In 2021, Griffith University can offer the first year of the Bachelor of Pharmacology and Toxicology online for International students outside Australia due to travel restrictions. For students commencing study from outside Australia, online delivery is an interim arrangement. Once travel restrictions are lifted, students will be expected to travel to Australia as soon as they are able, to continue their study on campus, and they will require a student visa for this. Students will need to be in Australia at the commencement of second year. If travel restrictions prevent this, students will need to apply for a Leave of Absence. This degree provides a pathway to a career in pharmacology, toxicology or drug research, pharmaceutical, biotechnology and other health industries. The degree's focus on pharmacology will provide you with an excellent foundation if you are considering a degree in one of the following areas: You will learn through extensive hands-on experience in state-of-the-art facilities including formulation, pharmacology and analytical laboratories and you can select one of the following majors: Honours is available through an additional year of study.
Career_Outcomes: You will be prepared for professional employment in a wide variety of public and private sector positions such as Regulatory Scientist; Regulatory Affairs Specialist;  Pharmaceutical Sales Representative; Medical Science Liaison; Medical Science Liaison (MSL) - Haematology; Clinical Trials Monitor; Product Manager; Pharmacy Assistant; Pharmacy Technician; Research Assistant; Research Technician; Laboratory Support Technician; Environmental Scientist; Research and Development Scientist; Formulation Chemist.
Subject_Description_1: This course covers the chemistry of the principal functional groups: organic sterochemistry and mechanisms; synthetic organic chemistry; some molecules of biological interest. Prerequisites: 1015MSC Chemistry in Biological Systems II or 1024SCG Chemistry II
Subject_Description_2: Evidence Based Practice (EBP) course is aimed in developing foundation knowledge and skills for best practice (informed by evidence) in health sciences with specific focus on quality use of medicines. Students will develop critical evaluation skills for the purpose of effective implementation of evidence-based health care into practice. This will be achieved by providing a fundamental knowledge and understanding of three domains: (A) applied pharmaceutical sciences (pharmacovigilance, pharmacoepidemiology and pharmacoeconomics), (B) quality use of medicine in specific patient groups, and (C) critical appraisal of research/practice studies for implications in research/clinical practice. This includes research methodologies in clinical set up, interpretation of biomedical data and critical appraisal of published clinical evidence. The aim of this course is also to promote the rational use of drugs and pharmaceutical services, and further prepare students for future higher studies. Prerequisites: 2018PHM Pharmacology & 1002MSC Introduction to Biomedical Data Analysis
Subject_Description_3: Five body systems: Skeletal, Muscle, Nervous, Endocrine and Reproductive Systems are studied in this course, which integrates anatomy with physiology. The theory presented in this course is supported by practical laboratory experiences, which include the study of human cadaveric material.
Subject_Description_4: This course, Research Methods and Statistics provides students with the mathematical skills used in measurement, processing and analysing of data typical of those obtained in Exercise Science. The course also provides an introduction to experimental design and statistical analyses appropriate to investigations in Exercise Science. No Prererquisites.
Subject_Description_5: The Industry Placement course (2000PHM) is grounded in the principles of work-integrated learning (WIL). It aims to actively improve students' work readiness and employment prospects. Students engage in authentic work based activities through industry placements. In placements, students are guided and supported to apply their knowledge and skills learned in the classroom in the 'real world' of industry practice. This course was formally known as 3015PHM">3015PHM and should not be undertaken if students have completed 3015PHM">3015PHM.
Subject_Description_6: 7005PHM Pharmacotherapeutics II provides an in-depth examination of the pharmacist's role in the therapeutic management of infectious disease, pain management, and endocrine disorders. Students are provided with an overview of the epidemiology, risk factors, clinical presentation, pathophysiology, clinical course, and therapeutic management of disease. Special emphasis is placed on the importance of therapeutic drug monitoring in the therapeutic plan. Lectures and problem-based clinical workshops serve to equip students with theoretical knowledge, an evidence-based approach, and practical clinical skills for the promotion and contribution to optimal use of medicines, delivery of health information and provision of health education in relation to the therapeutic areas covered in the course. Pre-requisites: 7001PHM Pharmacotherapeutics I
Subject_Description_7: Language and Communication for Health is offered to students from a non-English speaking background (NESB). Students whose first language is English are NOT PERMITTED to undertake this course. The aim of this course is to introduce students to the language, knowledge and communication skills required for study and practice in their discipline. A further aim is to develop and practice English language skills relevant to the academic culture of Australian universities. It therefore involves intensive English language practice and language immersion activities, with elements applied to contextualised, discipline-specific settings. This course constitutes part of the overall English Language Enhancement Strategy at Griffith University. Prerequisites: NIL; Incompatible: 5901LHS/5901LAL, 5903LHS/5903LAL, 5904LHS/5904LAL and 5902LAL.
Subject_Description_8: This course will provide students with an understanding of the drug discovery and development process including drug design, high throughput screening, lead optimisation, preclinical testing, basic pharmacokinetics and clinical trial design. It will also provide an overview of the commercial and regulatory realities that influence the drug discovery and development process. Prerequisite : 1001MSC Chemistry of Biological Systems I
Subject_Description_9: This course covers the structure and function of three major classes of biological macromolecules (carbohydrates, fats and proteins) and the metabolic pathways used for the biosynthesis and degradation of these macromolecules, including the mechanisms used for integration and regulation of these pathways. Enzymes are also covered. Incompatible: 2011MSC Metabolism and 2008MSC Structural Biochemistry Prerequisite: 1015MSC Chemistry of Biological Systems II
Subject_Description_10: This course provides students with the knowledge to evaluate the design, conduct, and results of clinical trials of healthcare interventions. Graduates will develop a solid understanding of clinical trials methodology, phases of intervention development, regulatory requirements and professional standards surrounding clinical trials. In addition, graduates will develop skills in critiquing the quality of published clinical trials, staff roles and general clinical trial business. Pre-requisites: There is no pre-requisite for this course, however students will need a good understanding of tertiary level statistics and research methods.
Subject_Description_11: This course introduces students to the clinical use of drugs for the treatment of human disease states from a systematic viewpoint. Human Pharmacology I will cover the pharmacology of drugs affecting the autonomic and central nervous systems. Major topics covered include cardiovascular, genitourinary, neurological and psychotropic drugs. Additional topics covered during this semester include eye drugs, diuretics, anaesthetics, analgesics. Pharmacodynamics, pharmacokinetics, therapeutic indications, precautions, adverse drug reactions and potential drug interactions will be overviewed for drugs covered in each topic. Human Pharmacology II will continue to build on this course. Pre-requisite: There are no pre-requisites for this course, however students will need a good understanding of tertiary level physiology and pharmacology.
Subject_Description_12: Health Care Systems is designed to give the student a deeper understanding of key concepts in how health systems are funded, operated and evaluated. The course will introduce the student to concepts such as social determinants of health; how health care decisions are evaluated; health reform; disadvantaged groups and health; and assessing quality of health services. The course will explore the Australian health care system in detail and compare it to other health care systems in developed and developing countries.
Subject_Description_13: In this course students will explore the biological processes on which the continuity of life is based including cell reproduction, basic genetics and evolution. Case studies and laboratory activities will provide a challenging opportunity to develop the practical and intellectual skills of a scientist or health care worker. Prerequisite: 1014MSC Cells, Tissues and Regulation Assumed Knowledge: Maths B and One of Biology, Chemistry or Physics (4SA)
Subject_Description_14: This course deals systematically with important aspects of the main drug groups, including their chemical origin and synthesis (where relevant) as well as their chemical properties that are relevant to their mode of action, side - effects, toxicity, and metabolism. Pre-requisite: 2018PHM Pharmacology
Subject_Description_15: This course provides an in-depth introduction to the principles and concepts of toxicology, with particular focus on the molecular mechanism of toxicity and toxic response to pharmaceuticals, chemicals (such as pesticides) and environmental pollutants (such as asbestos) exposure. The course builds upon introductory knowledge of chemistry and biology gained during the first year of the program and applies it to understanding the way in which chemicals react to produce toxic effect with major focus on target organ toxicity. The purpose of this course is to develop critical thinking skills, knowledge required to work in pharmaceutical industry or related areas regulatory affairs, clinical trials, drug safety and pharmacovigilance. Pre-requisites: There is no pre-requisite for this course, however students will need a good understanding of tertiary level pharmacology.
Subject_Description_16: 7001PHM Pharmacotherapeutics I provides an in-depth look at the pharmacist's role in the therapeutic management of gastrointestinal, respiratory, ophthalmic and cardiac conditions. Students are provided with an overview of the epidemiology, risk factors, clinical presentation, pathophysiology, clinical course, and therapeutic management of these conditions. Furthermore, Pharmacotherapeutics I provides an overview of diagnostic tests and their interpretation, as well as introducing principals of therapeutics and therapeutic drug monitoring. Special emphasis is placed on the importance of therapeutic drug monitoring in the therapeutic plan. Lectures and problem-based clinical workshops serve to equip students with theoretical knowledge, an evidence-based approach, and practical clinical skills for the promotion and contribution to optimal use of medicines, delivery of health information and provision of health education in relation to the therapeutic areas covered in the course. Pre-requisites: There are no pre-requisites for this course, however students will need a good understanding of foundation level pharmacology.
Subject_Description_17: This course covers the anatomy and physiology of the cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, digestive and immune systems. Both the study of the anatomy and the physiology of these systems draws on the experience gained in the lectures, laboratories and practicums. Prerequisites for Gold Coast students: 1016MSC">1016MSC Anatomy and Physiology Systems I, and 1014MSC Cells, Tissues and Regulation OR 1001AHS Foundations of Exercise and Sport Science. Prerequisites for Nathan students: 1016MSC">1016MSC Anatomy and Physiology Systems I and 1001NSC Human Biology.
Subject_Description_18: Specialised Dosage Forms II (7007PHM) builds on knowledge gained in the pharmaceutical studies in MPharm and BPharmTox. The course covers aseptic technique, sterile products, cytotoxics and specialised delivery systems in human and veterinary applications. The course utilizes didactic, practical, tutorial, self-directed learning and on-line resources for content delivery. Pre-requisite: There is no pre-requisite for this course, however students will need a good understanding of foundation level mathematics and chemistry.
Subject_Description_19: Cells, Tissues and Regulation examines how a single cell exists, and how when they come together in their trillions, we end up with human beings who can adapt to changing environments. Fundamental knowledge for any future health professionals. Assumed Knowledge: Maths B and One of Biology, Chemistry or Physics (4SA)
Subject_Description_20: This course introduces organic and biological chemistry, which underpins all biochemical processes and the molecular basis of life. Pre-Requisite: 1001MSC Chemistry of Biological Systems I or 1023SCG Chemistry 1 Assumed Knowledge: Maths B and One of Biology, Chemistry or Physics (4SA).
Subject_Description_21: This course prepares graduates across health professions to provide culturally safe health services to Australia's First Peoples. Through the enhancement of the previously introduced capabilities of respect, communication, safety and quality, critical reflection, and advocacy students will be supported to apply these capabilities in First Peoples' health contexts to engender the development of cultural capabilities that reflect a lifelong journey and are tested in every interaction. The course takes a holistic perspective to engage students in exploring the historical, socio-cultural, political and dominant cultural paradigms that influence First Peoples' health today. The First Peoples' Health and Practice course supports students to meet the Griffith University Graduate Attribute E.1 Awareness of and respect for the values and knowledge of Australian Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander First Peoples and to meet the requirements of the relevant professional body's competency standards and codes of professional conduct to provide culturally safe care. Pre-requisite: Students must have successfully completed at least 80CP of undergraduate study. This requirement will be strictly enforced.
Subject_Description_22: Pharmacy has at its core the discipline of pharmaceutics, which is the study of drug formulations and the processes by which these are designed, manufactured and delivered to the body. Simply stated, pharmaceutics converts drug substances into medicines - delivery systems capable of administering drugs to the body in a safe, efficient, reproducible and convenient manner. Specialised Dosage Forms I provides an in-depth pharmaceutical and biopharmaceutical knowledge of advanced drug delivery technologies utilised in modern medicine and addresses formulation aspects relating to special industries including; cosmetic, dental, veterinary, complementary and alternative medicines. The course builds on knowledge gained in Pharmaceutical Science 2 (3027PHM). Pre-requisite: There is no pre-requisite for this course, however students will need a good understanding of foundation level pharmaceutical science and mathematics.
Subject_Description_23: Pharmacy has at its core the discipline of pharmaceutics, which is the study of drug formulations and the processes by which these are designed, manufactured and delivered to the body. Simply stated, pharmaceutics converts drug substances into medicines - delivery systems capable of administering drugs to the body in a safe, efficient, reproducible and convenient manner. Pharmaceutical Science II provides an in- depth pharmaceutical and biopharmaceutical knowledge of foundational drug delivery technologies utilised in modern medicine. Pre-requisites: Good understanding of tertiary level pharmaceutics.
Subject_Description_24: This course describes the general principles of pharmacology from a contemporary viewpoint. Human Pharmacology II will cover the pharmacology of inflammation and immunology, respiratory pharmacology, cancer including chemotherapy, infectious disease and endocrine & reproductive pharmacology Pre-requisites: There is no pre-requisite for this course, however students will need a good understanding of undergraduate level pharmacology
Subject_Description_25: As the first degree-specific course in your program of study, Medicines - Discovery to Practice has been designed to provide students with a preliminary understanding of the pharmaceutical industry and pharmacy profession. From drug discovery through to medication provision and review, this course explores the multitude of career pathways and specialisation opportunities available. Additionally, particular emphasis is placed on career readiness and the skills, attributes and competencies necessary for enhancing employment potential.
Subject_Description_26: Pharmacy has at its core the discipline of pharmaceutics, which combines the principles of physical, chemical and biological properties of drugs in the design of dosage forms for medicines to achieve maximum therapeutic benefit. An understanding of how medications are formulated is essential to all pharmacists. Medicines - Discovery to Practice II will provide students with an introduction to the basic physicochemical principles of pharmacy formulations. Prerequisites - It is expected that students have completed at least one tertiary level course in chemistry.
Subject_Description_27: This course introduces the basic chemical principles that underlie biological systems. The foundation provided in this course will allow students to be able to further develop their chemistry knowledge and skills relevant to health and medical sciences in later years. Assumed Knowledge: Maths B and One of Biology, Chemistry or Physics. Incompatible with 1023SCG Chemistry I
Subject_Description_28: An understanding of the chemical structure of drugs, as well as the relationships between drug structure and pharmacological activity are fundamental to Pharmacy. Continuing with the themes developed through Chemical Pharmacology I (3023PHM), Chemical Pharmacology II (3025PHM">3025PHM">3025PHM">3025PHM) aims to provide students with a detailed understanding of the mechanism of action of drugs, the medicinal chemistry that underpins drug structures, the relationships between chemical structure and pharmacological activity, and the metabolism of drugs. In conjunction with information gained during first two years of the program, Chemical Pharmacology II (3025PHM">3025PHM">3025PHM">3025PHM) provides essential skills and knowledge required in the MPharm program. Chemical Pharmacology II (3025PHM">3025PHM">3025PHM">3025PHM) is a companion course to Human Pharmacology II (3028PHM). The two courses cove the same general topics and drug classes, but the emphasis here is on structure-activity relationships, mechanism of action, and broader pharmacodynamics (PD) and pharmacokinetics (PK) and physiochemical properties of drugs.
Subject_Description_29: This course introduces students to important concepts in Pharmacology. The major topic areas will provide an in depth understanding of drug targets, pharmacodynamics, pharmacokinetics and pharmacogenomics. Basic concepts in adverse drug reactions, drug interactions, toxicology and complementary medications will be introduced. The course will comprise lectures, workshops and laboratories. Pharmacology is a fundamental course that brings together chemistry and biology to understand the basis of drug effect. Pre-requisites: There are no pre-requisites for this course, however students will require a good understanding of tertiary level physiology, anatomy, chemistry and mathematics. Incompatible - 3002MSC Pharmacology

Description: This program is designed to provide students with an opportunity to undertake advanced study and supervised research work in the specialisation defined by their undergraduate degree program within the context of a multidisciplinary cohort. The research skills developed within this program will provide an attractive credential for students seeking employment in the public or private sectors. The program will also provide the necessary preparation for entry into a higher degree research program. The multidisciplinary context of the program, involving team-teaching of students and the sharing of coursework and seminar experiences across disciplines will be invaluable to students given the importance of a multidisciplinary approach to researchers and practitioners seeking to understand complex problems in health.
Career_Outcomes: Graduates of the program will be able to plan and conduct research in pharmacology, toxicology and related health disciplines, and therefore will be well-placed for positions in the private, not for profit, and public sectors. In addition, graduates will be eligible to apply for admission to higher degree research programs, thereby preparing them for high level research careers.

Description: In 2021, Griffith University can offer the first year of the Bachelor of Pharmacy online for International students outside Australia due to travel restrictions. For students commencing study from outside Australia, online delivery is an interim arrangement. Once travel restrictions are lifted, students will be expected to travel to Australia as soon as they are able, to continue their study on campus, and they will require a student visa for this. Students will need to be in Australia at the commencement of second year. If travel restrictions prevent this, students will need to apply for a Leave of Absence. This degree will put you on the path to a career in the pharmaceutical, biotechnology or nutraceutical industries. You will learn through hands-on experience in state-of-the-art facilities (formulation, pharmacology and analytical laboratories) and during professional practice placements at the new Gold Coast University Hospital and other clinical settings. You will take specialist courses in areas such as pharmacy management, complementary and alternative medicine, and pharmacology.
Career_Outcomes: You will be prepared for a career in community and hospital pharmacy, and medication management. You will also be able to enter careers in the pharmaceutical, biotechnology, nutraceutical and related industries in areas including management, sales, marketing, business development, and local and national government agencies related to medicine use and regulation.
Subject_Description_1: This course covers the chemistry of the principal functional groups: organic sterochemistry and mechanisms; synthetic organic chemistry; some molecules of biological interest. Prerequisites: 1015MSC Chemistry in Biological Systems II or 1024SCG Chemistry II
Subject_Description_2: Pharmacy has at its core the discipline of pharmaceutics, which combines the principles of physical, chemical and biological properties of drugs in the design of dosage forms for medicines to achieve maximum therapeutic benefit. An understanding of how medications are formulated is essential to all pharmacists. Medicines - Discovery to Practice II will provide students with an introduction to the basic physicochemical principles of pharmacy formulations. Prerequisites - It is expected that students have completed at least one tertiary level course in chemistry.
Subject_Description_3: As the main placement-specific course in the Bachelor of Pharmacy program, this course will begin to develop your ability to bridge the gap between your academic learning and the professional practice that will eventually become your full-time learning environment. This will be achieved through 20 days of placement experience, prefaced by 4 weeks of interactive sessions designed to prepare you for these placements and the learning experiences within each of them. In this course you will draw together the knowledge from prior courses in this degree and apply it in both real and simulated practice environments. Pre-requisites: 3004PHM Pharmacy Practice II & 3006PHM Integrated Pharmacotherapeutics II. Co-requisite: 3007PHM Integrated Pharmacotherapeutics III
Subject_Description_4: Pharmacy Practice IV is the culminating capstone practice course that emphasises pharmacists' professional roles as primary health care providers and medication managers in Australian society and within multidisciplinary health care teams. The course integrates attributes of all preceding practice courses and further develops the students' knowledge, skills and attitudes in preparation for pharmacy internship. Topics covered in lectures and workshops will focus on special patient groups, including pregnancy, paediatrics, women's reproductive health and aged care; pharmacy management; medication management; risk management and best practice principles. Applied and problem-based workshops will develop students' skills and professionalism in medication dispensing, counselling and management. An integrated group activity for this course will involve an immersive simulated serious pharmacy game, comprising numerous mini-activities, conducted over an extended time period. Expected outcomes for this course include proficiency in navigating pharmacy law, an ethical approach to problem-solving and case resolution, competency in medicines dispensing, counselling and management, and readiness for intern practice. Prerequisite: 3XXXPHM Pharmacy Practice III
Subject_Description_5: Cells, Tissues and Regulation examines how a single cell exists, and how when they come together in their trillions, we end up with human beings who can adapt to changing environments. Fundamental knowledge for any future health professionals. Assumed Knowledge: Maths B and One of Biology, Chemistry or Physics (4SA)
Subject_Description_6: Pharmacy has at its core the discipline of pharmaceutics, which is the study of drug formulations and the processes by which these are designed, manufactured and delivered to the body. Simply stated, pharmaceutics converts drug substances into medicines - delivery systems capable of administering drugs to the body in a safe, efficient, reproducible and convenient manner. Pharmaceutical Science II provides an in- depth pharmaceutical and biopharmaceutical knowledge of foundational drug delivery technologies utilised in modern medicine. Pre-requisites: Good understanding of tertiary level pharmaceutics.
Subject_Description_7: This course covers the anatomy and physiology of the cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, digestive and immune systems. Both the study of the anatomy and the physiology of these systems draws on the experience gained in the lectures, laboratories and practicums. Prerequisites for Gold Coast students: 1016MSC">1016MSC Anatomy and Physiology Systems I, and 1014MSC Cells, Tissues and Regulation OR 1001AHS Foundations of Exercise and Sport Science. Prerequisites for Nathan students: 1016MSC">1016MSC Anatomy and Physiology Systems I and 1001NSC Human Biology.
Subject_Description_8: Integrated Pharmacotherapeutics I, provides an in-depth look at the pharmacist's role in the therapeutic management of cardiovascular disease, infections and diseases related to the immune system. The course adopts an integrated approach to learning, taking the student through the epidemiology, risk factors, clinical presentation, pathophysiology, clinical course, and therapeutic management of the disease, including a thorough understanding of the pharmacological basis of treatment and its relation to drug structure. Lectures and problem-based clinical workshops serve to equip students with theoretical knowledge, an evidence-based approach, and practical clinical skills for the promotion of and contribution to optimal use of medicines, delivery of health information and provision of health education in relation to the therapeutic areas covered in the course. Pre-requisites: 2014MSC Organic Chemistry, 2018PHM Pharmacology.
Subject_Description_9: 4003PHM Integrated Pharmacotherapeutics (oncology), provides an in-depth look at the pharmacist's role in the therapeutic management of cancer including palliative care and specialised dosage forms. The course adopts an integrated approach to learning, taking the student through the epidemiology, risk factors, clinical presentation, pathophysiology, clinical course, and therapeutic management of the disease, including a thorough understanding of the pharmacological basis of treatment and its relation to drug structure. Lectures and problem-based clinical workshops serve to equip students with theoretical knowledge, an evidence-based approach, and practical clinical skills for the promotion of and contribution to optimal use of medicines, delivery of health information and provision of health education in relation to the therapeutic areas covered in the course. Pre-requisites: 3006PHM Integrated Pharmacotherapeutics II
Subject_Description_10: Pharmacy Practice is the discipline of pharmacy that focuses on the application of scientific and clinical knowledge for patient improved outcomes and the quality use of medicines. The Pharmacy Practice I course involves the development of student's understanding of the professional role of the pharmacist in Australian society as a primary health care provider and medication manager within the multidisciplinary health care team. Students begin to develop skills related to the professional services offered by pharmacists. Each week consists of three hours of lectures and two hours of practical workshops in the dispensary. The course utilises didactic, practical, tutorial, self-directed learning and on-line learning resources for content delivery, with a significant emphasis on the development of inter-professional learning (IPL) and life-long learning skills through an evidence-based approach. Pre-requisite: 1016MSC (Anatomy and Physiology Systems I); Co-requisite: 1017MSC (Anatomy and Physiology Systems II).
Subject_Description_11: Pharmacy has at its core the discipline of pharmaceutics, which is the study of drug formulations and the processes by which these are designed, manufactured and delivered to the body. Simply stated, pharmaceutics converts drug substances into medicines - delivery systems capable of administering drugs to the body in a safe, efficient, reproducible and convenient manner. Pharmaceutical Science III provides an in-depth pharmaceutical and biopharmaceutical knowledge of advanced drug delivery technologies utilised in modern medicine and addresses formulation aspects relating to special industries including; cosmetic, dental, veterinary, complementary and alternative medicines. Pre-requisite: 2013PHM Specialised Delivery Systems I
Subject_or_Unit_12: QUALITY USE OF MEDICINES IN PRACTICE
Subject_Description_12: The pharmacy research project is the culmination of students training in professional practice of pharmacy. Qualitative and quantitative research projects serve to address topical issues relating to the practice of pharmacy (e.g.. quality use of medicines; pharmacoeconomics; pharmacy management; social aspects of pharmacy; rational prescribing; drug utilisation etc.) Projects are undertaken under the supervision of an experienced researcher within the School of Pharmacy
Subject_Description_13: This course, Research Methods and Statistics provides students with the mathematical skills used in measurement, processing and analysing of data typical of those obtained in Exercise Science. The course also provides an introduction to experimental design and statistical analyses appropriate to investigations in Exercise Science. No Prererquisites.
Subject_Description_14: As the first degree-specific course in your program of study, Medicines - Discovery to Practice has been designed to provide students with a preliminary understanding of the pharmaceutical industry and pharmacy profession. From drug discovery through to medication provision and review, this course explores the multitude of career pathways and specialisation opportunities available. Additionally, particular emphasis is placed on career readiness and the skills, attributes and competencies necessary for enhancing employment potential.
Subject_Description_15: This course prepares graduates across health professions to provide culturally safe health services to Australia's First Peoples. Through the enhancement of the previously introduced capabilities of respect, communication, safety and quality, critical reflection, and advocacy students will be supported to apply these capabilities in First Peoples' health contexts to engender the development of cultural capabilities that reflect a lifelong journey and are tested in every interaction. The course takes a holistic perspective to engage students in exploring the historical, socio-cultural, political and dominant cultural paradigms that influence First Peoples' health today. The First Peoples' Health and Practice course supports students to meet the Griffith University Graduate Attribute E.1 Awareness of and respect for the values and knowledge of Australian Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander First Peoples and to meet the requirements of the relevant professional body's competency standards and codes of professional conduct to provide culturally safe care. Pre-requisite: Students must have successfully completed at least 80CP of undergraduate study. This requirement will be strictly enforced.
Subject_Description_16: This course introduces the basic chemical principles that underlie biological systems. The foundation provided in this course will allow students to be able to further develop their chemistry knowledge and skills relevant to health and medical sciences in later years. Assumed Knowledge: Maths B and One of Biology, Chemistry or Physics. Incompatible with 1023SCG Chemistry I
Subject_Description_17: Pharmacy Practice 2 (2012PHM) introduces the core concepts of State and Federal laws and regulations that frame careers in both the pharmaceutical industry and/or the pharmacy profession. This course continues and extends the development of students' understanding of the professional role of pharmacists and pharmaceutical industry workers in Australian society. In this course students will learn how to access legislation relating to control of pharmaceuticals and the practice of pharmacy. Students will learn how to interpret the laws, policies and standards that govern the roles of professionals in industry and pharmacy. An understanding of the application of legislation will be gained by the use of case studies in workshops, and also by completion of an eight hour placement in community pharmacy. Pre-requisite: 1006PHM Pharmacy Practice I
Subject_Description_18: Pharmacists are ideally placed to provide advice on minor ailments, such as skin disorders, and support complex health consumers, such as those with mental health or neurological conditions. Pharmacy Practice III invites students to consider the current evidence of the pharmacist's role/s in these therapeutic areas, and to explore their personal and professional attitudes and beliefs towards supporting mental health consumers. Students will develop skills that are relevant in today's society, such as Mental Health First Aid Training and person-centred practice. The course will engage students with problem-based learning activities and real-life case scenarios that are relevant to pharmacy practice. Pre-requisites: 2009PHM Integrated Pharmacotherapeutics I: 2012PHM Pharmacy Practice II
Subject_Description_19: This course introduces students to important concepts in Pharmacology. The major topic areas will provide an in depth understanding of drug targets, pharmacodynamics, pharmacokinetics and pharmacogenomics. Basic concepts in adverse drug reactions, drug interactions, toxicology and complementary medications will be introduced. The course will comprise lectures, workshops and laboratories. Pharmacology is a fundamental course that brings together chemistry and biology to understand the basis of drug effect. Pre-requisites: There are no pre-requisites for this course, however students will require a good understanding of tertiary level physiology, anatomy, chemistry and mathematics. Incompatible - 3002MSC Pharmacology
Subject_Description_20: This course introduces organic and biological chemistry, which underpins all biochemical processes and the molecular basis of life. Pre-Requisite: 1001MSC Chemistry of Biological Systems I or 1023SCG Chemistry 1 Assumed Knowledge: Maths B and One of Biology, Chemistry or Physics (4SA).
Subject_Description_21: An integrated group activity for this course will involve an immersive simulated serious pharmacy game, comprising numerous mini-activities,conducted over an extended time period.
Subject_Description_22: This course provides an in-depth look at the pharmacist's role in the therapeutic management of neurological and psychiatric diseases. The course adopts an integrated approach to learning, taking the student through the epidemiology, risk factors, clinical presentation, pathophysiology, clinical course, and therapeutic management of the disease, including a thorough understanding of the pharmacological basis of treatment and its relation to drug structure. Lectures and problem-based clinical workshops serve to equip students with theoretical knowledge, an evidence-based approach, and practical clinical skills for the promotion of and contribution to optimal use of medicines, delivery of health information and provision of health education in relation to the therapeutic areas covered in the course. Pre-requisites: 3007PHM Integrated Pharmacotherapeutics III.
Subject_Description_23: In this course students will explore the biological processes on which the continuity of life is based including cell reproduction, basic genetics and evolution. Case studies and laboratory activities will provide a challenging opportunity to develop the practical and intellectual skills of a scientist or health care worker. Prerequisite: 1014MSC Cells, Tissues and Regulation Assumed Knowledge: Maths B and One of Biology, Chemistry or Physics (4SA)
Subject_Description_24: Five body systems: Skeletal, Muscle, Nervous, Endocrine and Reproductive Systems are studied in this course, which integrates anatomy with physiology. The theory presented in this course is supported by practical laboratory experiences, which include the study of human cadaveric material.
Subject_Description_25: Integrated Pharmacotherapeutics III provides an in-depth look at the pharmacist's role in the therapeutic management of diseases of the musculoskeletal system and endocrine diseases. The course will build on knowledge gained in second year and adopts an integrated approach to learning, taking the student through the epidemiology, risk factors, clinical presentation, pathophysiology, clinical course, and therapeutic management of the disease, including a thorough understanding of the pharmacological basis of treatment and its relation to drug structure. Lectures and problem-based clinical workshops serve to equip students with theoretical knowledge, an evidence-based approach, and practical clinical skills for the promotion of and contribution to optimal use of medicines, delivery of health information and provision of health education in relation to the therapeutic areas covered in the course. Pre-requisites: 3006PHM Integrated Pharmacotherapeutics II.
Subject_Description_26: Integrated Pharmacotherapeutics IV provides an in-depth look at the pharmacist's role in the therapeutic management of special populations. Topics covered include geriatric, paediatric, and men's and women's health conditions. This course draws on knowledge gained throughout all courses undertaken to date. The course adopts an integrated approach to learning, taking the student through the epidemiology, risk factors, clinical presentation, pathophysiology, clinical course, and therapeutic management of the disease, including a thorough understanding of the pharmacological basis of treatment and its relation to drug structure. Students are also introduced to research skills as part of this course. Lectures and problem-based clinical workshops serve to equip students with theoretical knowledge, an evidence-based approach, and practical clinical skills for the promotion of and contribution to optimal use of medicines, delivery of health information and provision of health education in relation to the therapeutic areas covered in the course. Prerequisites : 4002PHM Integrated Pharmacotherapeutics (neuro) & 4003PHM Integrated Pharmacotherapeutics (oncology).
Subject_Description_27: This course, provides an in-depth look at the pharmacist's role in the therapeutic management of diseases related to the respiratory tract and ear, nose and throat (ENT), gastrointestinal (GI) tract and genitourinary system. The course builds will builds on knowledge of infections and the immune system gained in second year and adopts an integrated approach to learning, taking the student through the epidemiology, risk factors, clinical presentation, pathophysiology, clinical course, and therapeutic management of the disease, including a thorough understanding of the pharmacological basis of treatment and its relation to drug structure. Relevant microbiology will be incorporated into discussion of infectious diseases. Lectures and problem-based clinical workshops serve to equip students with theoretical knowledge, an evidence-based approach, and practical clinical skills for the promotion of and contribution to optimal use of medicines, delivery of health information and provision of health education in relation to the therapeutic areas covered in the course. Pre-requisites: 2009PHM Integrated Pharmacotherapeutics I.

Description: The Bachelor of Pharmacy (Honours) encompasses 30 credit points of research dissertation. As well as the opportunity for career and skill advancement, the Honours program creates a pathway for Pharmacy students to move into research and higher degree studies via the Master of Philosophy and Doctor of Philosophy programs.
Career_Outcomes: The program ensures that graduates are ethical and innovative thinkers, effective communicators, problem solvers, change facilitators and leaders. You will be prepared for a career in community and hospital pharmacy, and medication management. You will also be able to enter careers in the pharmaceutical, biotechnology, nutraceutical and related industries in areas including management, sales, marketing, business development, and local and national government agencies related to medicine use and regulation.
Subject_Description_1: This course introduces the basic chemical principles that underlie biological systems. The foundation provided in this course will allow students to be able to further develop their chemistry knowledge and skills relevant to health and medical sciences in later years. Assumed Knowledge: Maths B and One of Biology, Chemistry or Physics. Incompatible with 1023SCG Chemistry I
Subject_Description_2: Pharmacy Practice 2 (2012PHM) introduces the core concepts of State and Federal laws and regulations that frame careers in both the pharmaceutical industry and/or the pharmacy profession. This course continues and extends the development of students' understanding of the professional role of pharmacists and pharmaceutical industry workers in Australian society. In this course students will learn how to access legislation relating to control of pharmaceuticals and the practice of pharmacy. Students will learn how to interpret the laws, policies and standards that govern the roles of professionals in industry and pharmacy. An understanding of the application of legislation will be gained by the use of case studies in workshops, and also by completion of an eight hour placement in community pharmacy. Pre-requisite: 1006PHM Pharmacy Practice I
Subject_Description_3: This course is offered as a one week intensive course run in Orientation week (O week) in Tri 1 & Tri 2). It is available to students enrolled in Health Group Honours programs, the Graduate Diploma in Health Research (4161), the Master of Medical Research (5433 and 5626), Master of Advanced Practice with Honours (5425) and Master of Advanced Practice (5424) - Health Care Research strand only. The course must be listed in your program. Students are presented with a framework to develop their research proposal. Students will be expected to clearly define their research topic and communicate this in both written and verbal forms. Students will develop proficiency in searching databases, compiling literature relevant to their dissertation topic and critically reviewing the literature to identify gaps. They will formulate their research aims and explain the significance of their research to an audience of their peers. Finally students will also be required to identify research methods and analytical tools that can be utilized in their study. This course is incompatible with 7001HSV (Foundations of Research Inquiry in Health).
Subject_Description_4: As the first degree-specific course in your program of study, Medicines - Discovery to Practice has been designed to provide students with a preliminary understanding of the pharmaceutical industry and pharmacy profession. From drug discovery through to medication provision and review, this course explores the multitude of career pathways and specialisation opportunities available. Additionally, particular emphasis is placed on career readiness and the skills, attributes and competencies necessary for enhancing employment potential.

Subject_Description_11: 6001PHM">6001PHM_P3 is the third of three 10 Credit Point courses that make up the research component of the School of Pharmacy Honours program. The Dissertation courses (6001PHM">6001PHM_P1-P3) require students to undertake a research project relevant to their area of specialisation under the guidance of a supervisor. This will involve the identification of a research question, selection of appropriate research design, data analysis and carrying out the research project. At the completion of the five Dissertation courses students will submit for examination a thesis (with an upper limit of 25,000 words) describing the research project and will deliver a seminar describing their findings.
Subject_Description_12: This course covers the chemistry of the principal functional groups: organic sterochemistry and mechanisms; synthetic organic chemistry; some molecules of biological interest. Prerequisites: 1015MSC Chemistry in Biological Systems II or 1024SCG Chemistry II

Students are also introduced to research skills as part of this course. Lectures and problem-based clinical workshops serve to equip students with theoretical knowledge, an evidence-based approach, and practical clinical skills for the promotion of and contribution to optimal use of medicines, delivery of health information and provision of health education in relation to the therapeutic areas covered in the course. Prerequisites : 4002PHM Integrated Pharmacotherapeutics (neuro) & 4003PHM Integrated Pharmacotherapeutics (oncology).

The major topic areas will provide an in depth understanding of drug targets, pharmacodynamics, pharmacokinetics and pharmacogenomics. Basic concepts in adverse drug reactions, drug interactions, toxicology and complementary medications will be introduced. The course will comprise lectures, workshops and laboratories.
