Pharmacology is a fundamental course that brings together chemistry and biology to understand the basis of drug effect. Pre-requisites: There are no pre-requisites for this course, however students will require a good understanding of tertiary level physiology, anatomy, chemistry and mathematics. Incompatible - 3002MSC Pharmacology
Subject_Description_17: Pharmacy has at its core the discipline of pharmaceutics, which is the study of drug formulations and the processes by which these are designed, manufactured and delivered to the body. Simply stated, pharmaceutics converts drug substances into medicines - delivery systems capable of administering drugs to the body in a safe, efficient, reproducible and convenient manner. Pharmaceutical Science III provides an in-depth pharmaceutical and biopharmaceutical knowledge of advanced drug delivery technologies utilised in modern medicine and addresses formulation aspects relating to special industries including; cosmetic, dental, veterinary, complementary and alternative medicines. Pre-requisite: 2013PHM Specialised Delivery Systems I
Subject_Description_18: In this course students will explore the biological processes on which the continuity of life is based including cell reproduction, basic genetics and evolution. Case studies and laboratory activities will provide a challenging opportunity to develop the practical and intellectual skills of a scientist or health care worker. Prerequisite: 1014MSC Cells, Tissues and Regulation Assumed Knowledge: Maths B and One of Biology, Chemistry or Physics (4SA)
Subject_Description_19: Pharmacists are ideally placed to provide advice on minor ailments, such as skin disorders, and support complex health consumers, such as those with mental health or neurological conditions. Pharmacy Practice III invites students to consider the current evidence of the pharmacist's role/s in these therapeutic areas, and to explore their personal and professional attitudes and beliefs towards supporting mental health consumers. Students will develop skills that are relevant in today's society, such as Mental Health First Aid Training and person-centred practice. The course will engage students with problem-based learning activities and real-life case scenarios that are relevant to pharmacy practice. Pre-requisites: 2009PHM Integrated Pharmacotherapeutics I: 2012PHM Pharmacy Practice II
Subject_Description_20: Pharmacy has at its core the discipline of pharmaceutics, which combines the principles of physical, chemical and biological properties of drugs in the design of dosage forms for medicines to achieve maximum therapeutic benefit. An understanding of how medications are formulated is essential to all pharmacists. Medicines - Discovery to Practice II will provide students with an introduction to the basic physicochemical principles of pharmacy formulations. Prerequisites - It is expected that students have completed at least one tertiary level course in chemistry.
Subject_Description_21: 6001PHM_P2 is the second of three 10 Credit Point courses that make up the research component of the School of Pharmacy Honours program. The Dissertation courses (4017PHM_P1-P3) require students to undertake a research project relevant to their area of specialisation under the guidance of a supervisor. This will involve the identification of a research question, selection of appropriate research design, data analysis and carrying out the research project. At the completion of the five Dissertation courses students will submit for examination a thesis (with an upper limit of 25,000 words) describing the research project and will deliver a seminar describing their findings.
Subject_Description_22: Pharmacy Practice is the discipline of pharmacy that focuses on the application of scientific and clinical knowledge for patient improved outcomes and the quality use of medicines. The Pharmacy Practice I course involves the development of student's understanding of the professional role of the pharmacist in Australian society as a primary health care provider and medication manager within the multidisciplinary health care team. Students begin to develop skills related to the professional services offered by pharmacists. Each week consists of three hours of lectures and two hours of practical workshops in the dispensary. The course utilises didactic, practical, tutorial, self-directed learning and on-line learning resources for content delivery, with a significant emphasis on the development of inter-professional learning (IPL) and life-long learning skills through an evidence-based approach. Pre-requisite: 1016MSC (Anatomy and Physiology Systems I); Co-requisite: 1017MSC (Anatomy and Physiology Systems II).
Subject_Description_23: 6001PHM">6001PHM_P1 is the first of three 10 Credit Point courses that make up the research component of the School of Pharmacy Honours program. The Dissertation courses (6001PHM">6001PHM_P1-P3) require students to undertake a research project relevant to their area of specialisation under the guidance of a supervisor. This will involve the identification of a research question, selection of appropriate research design, data analysis and carrying out the research project. At the completion of the five Dissertation courses students will submit for examination a thesis (with an upper limit of 25,000 words) describing the research project and will deliver a seminar describing their findings.
Subject_Description_24: Integrated Pharmacotherapeutics I, provides an in-depth look at the pharmacist's role in the therapeutic management of cardiovascular disease, infections and diseases related to the immune system. The course adopts an integrated approach to learning, taking the student through the epidemiology, risk factors, clinical presentation, pathophysiology, clinical course, and therapeutic management of the disease, including a thorough understanding of the pharmacological basis of treatment and its relation to drug structure. Lectures and problem-based clinical workshops serve to equip students with theoretical knowledge, an evidence-based approach, and practical clinical skills for the promotion of and contribution to optimal use of medicines, delivery of health information and provision of health education in relation to the therapeutic areas covered in the course. Pre-requisites: 2014MSC Organic Chemistry, 2018PHM Pharmacology.
Subject_Description_25: This course, provides an in-depth look at the pharmacist's role in the therapeutic management of diseases related to the respiratory tract and ear, nose and throat (ENT), gastrointestinal (GI) tract and genitourinary system. The course builds will builds on knowledge of infections and the immune system gained in second year and adopts an integrated approach to learning, taking the student through the epidemiology, risk factors, clinical presentation, pathophysiology, clinical course, and therapeutic management of the disease, including a thorough understanding of the pharmacological basis of treatment and its relation to drug structure. Relevant microbiology will be incorporated into discussion of infectious diseases. Lectures and problem-based clinical workshops serve to equip students with theoretical knowledge, an evidence-based approach, and practical clinical skills for the promotion of and contribution to optimal use of medicines, delivery of health information and provision of health education in relation to the therapeutic areas covered in the course. Pre-requisites: 2009PHM Integrated Pharmacotherapeutics I.
Subject_Description_26: Pharmacy Practice IV is the culminating capstone practice course that emphasises pharmacists' professional roles as primary health care providers and medication managers in Australian society and within multidisciplinary health care teams. The course integrates attributes of all preceding practice courses and further develops the students' knowledge, skills and attitudes in preparation for pharmacy internship. Topics covered in lectures and workshops will focus on special patient groups, including pregnancy, paediatrics, women's reproductive health and aged care; pharmacy management; medication management; risk management and best practice principles. Applied and problem-based workshops will develop students' skills and professionalism in medication dispensing, counselling and management. An integrated group activity for this course will involve an immersive simulated serious pharmacy game, comprising numerous mini-activities, conducted over an extended time period. Expected outcomes for this course include proficiency in navigating pharmacy law, an ethical approach to problem-solving and case resolution, competency in medicines dispensing, counselling and management, and readiness for intern practice. Prerequisite: 3XXXPHM Pharmacy Practice III
Subject_Description_27: Five body systems: Skeletal, Muscle, Nervous, Endocrine and Reproductive Systems are studied in this course, which integrates anatomy with physiology. The theory presented in this course is supported by practical laboratory experiences, which include the study of human cadaveric material.
Subject_Description_28: Integrated Pharmacotherapeutics III provides an in-depth look at the pharmacist's role in the therapeutic management of diseases of the musculoskeletal system and endocrine diseases. The course will build on knowledge gained in second year and adopts an integrated approach to learning, taking the student through the epidemiology, risk factors, clinical presentation, pathophysiology, clinical course, and therapeutic management of the disease, including a thorough understanding of the pharmacological basis of treatment and its relation to drug structure. Lectures and problem-based clinical workshops serve to equip students with theoretical knowledge, an evidence-based approach, and practical clinical skills for the promotion of and contribution to optimal use of medicines, delivery of health information and provision of health education in relation to the therapeutic areas covered in the course. Pre-requisites: 3006PHM Integrated Pharmacotherapeutics II.

Description: This program is designed to provide students with an opportunity to undertake advanced study and supervised research work in the specialisation defined by their undergraduate degree program within the context of a multidisciplinary cohort.

Since its invention, photography has transformed the way that people see themselves and the way we communicate. Whether you want to be a journalist, work in creative advertising or practice as a fine artist, this degree will help you achieve your goals. You will combine conceptual, critical and creative processes to generate your own distinctive photographic vision. You will also be introduced to the craft,
politics, philosophy, language and ethics of photography. You will have access to analogue and digital facilities. You will also have the opportunity to learn through a specialist work integrated learning
experience in a small creative community atmosphere. In your first year, you will combine photographic courses, studio practice and art theory. You will receive a thorough grounding in the practice of
photography and in developing your conceptual and craft skills. In your second and third years, you will focus on your chosen major.
Career_Outcomes: You will be prepared to work anywhere in the world in advertising and design, fine art and public art, or news, photojournalism and documentary photography.
Subject_Description_1: This course provides an introduction to practices from the Ancient Greeks up until the early 20th century. Students will gain an understanding of key art historical concepts as well as the social, cultural, political and religious contexts for art.
Subject_Description_2: This action research course initiates discourse on ways in which contextual theory informs and shapes the planning stages of arts-based research. Students will establish foundational knowledge of research approaches and methodological innovation towards a preliminary practice-led research project.
Subject_Description_3: In this action research course students will consolidate reflexive, arts-based research processes and informing theoretical discourses established in 3365QCA">3365QCA_P1 towards a major body of work suitable for professional presentation. Students will be able to critically articulate and disseminate their work in professional and higher learning contexts. This course replaces the original 3365QCA">3365QCA (20CP).
Subject_Description_4: Foundation Studies in Art Theory is made up of two first year courses. The first of these is 1216QCA Introduction to Western Art. The second is this course, 1217QCA Modern Art and its Legacies. This course introduces students to the concepts of Modernity, Modernism and Postmodernism and considers their legacy for contemporary creative practices. The course combines a chronological survey of European and American avant-garde art movements with themes and theories relevant to contemporary practice. The course focuses on art and photography as located within a broader field of creative practice including dance, design, film, literature and theatre.
Subject_Description_5: This course provides an intensive introduction to the materials, methods, concepts and concerns of contemporary visual arts practice in a multi-disciplinary matrix. Lecture content and studio exercises engage with visual thinking, concept development, material investigation and a diversity of practice as foundational catalysts for lifelong learning. The course initiates responsive approaches to arts practice and reflective learning in a rich, complex and diverse cultural environment. This course complements Studio Foundations 2.
Subject_Description_6: Conducted through seminars and lectures, this course considers contemporary visual arts in the context of a global cultural landscape. The course is designed to engage students directly with the histories, tensions and circumstances of global visual arts practice. An investigation of the nuances, sensitivities, protocols and complexities of specific practitioners, movements and events will enable the student to apply a sophisticated and critical knowledge to global contexts with an understanding of a diversity of perspectives. Students will also develop communication skills that reflect contextual awareness and responsiveness to rich and complex intercultural dynamics. This is a third year course. Students must have completed all second year art theory and second year visual arts major courses prior to enrolment.
Subject_or_Unit_7: PROFESSIONAL PRACTICES IN THE VISUAL ARTS
Subject_Description_7: This course prepares students for life and work beyond graduation. Students will explore creative arts industries and design strategies for enhancing their professional practice. Specific skills including CV building, writing artist statements, grant writing, networking and proposal development. In conjunction with seminars led by professional practitioners, students will also investigate arts law, finance, business models, entrepreneurship, copyright law, professional protocols and the attitudes and dispositions of professional visual arts practitioners.
Subject_Description_8: Globalisation has had a profound impact on our world, this course examines how these changes have impacted upon the production, exhibition, and consumption of contemporary art. The first part of the course examines the chief theorists of contemporary art (Terry Smith, Hans Belting and Peter Osborne). The second part examines key themes and concepts that have been used to understand the kinds of contemporary art made now. We will consider key theories, such as postcolonialism, and key contemporary themes and issues, such as forced migration, injustice, centre/periphery dynamics, and the fate of the local and the regional in an interconnected world. Pre-requisite: 1209QCA (Mapping the Postmodern) or equivalent.
Subject_Description_9: This course builds on ways in which theory and studio practice may extend and inform each other via an arts-based research project. This course works to consolidate studio processes towards a major body of work suitable for professional presentation and prepares students to critically articulate and disseminate their work in professional and higher learning contexts.
Subject_Description_10: The course complements Studio Foundations 1 to provide an intensive introduction to the materials, methods, concepts and concerns of contemporary visual arts practice. Lecture and studio delivery continues the development of agile and lateral thinking through visual methods rooted in disciplinary and interdisciplinary knowledge frameworks. Studio investigations are grounded in an interdisciplinary framework of sculpture, jewellery/small objects, painting, photography and print media.

Description: The Bachelor of Photography (Honours) is a full-time or part-time program designed to enable students who have demonstrated substantial ability at an undergraduate level, to develop their practical expertise and theoretical understanding to a more advanced level.
Subject_Description_1: Honours Research Project constitutes a 40CP honours research commitment within the (Bachelor of Fine Art (Honours) and Bachelor of Photography (Honours). Each of the four components of the course combine to introduce students to the rigors of research and engage them in an advanced level of study within visual practice. The expectation is that the research project undertaken will be based within the visual and incorporates high levels of visual literacy. Assessment of the four courses will culminate in one assessment item. Honours Research Project is presented with the Exegesis (completed in 6012QCA) for assessment in a professional context at the completion of all four courses. Co-requisite/Pre-requisite: 6303QCA Visual Arts Research Methods.
Subject_Description_2: Excellence in practice is predicated on a reflective and rigorous approach to creative practice as a method of inquiry and comment. This course introduces students to a number of exemplarily research practices through which they may contextualise their work. It looks at different modes of inquiry and encourages students to develop research practices that are appropriate to their particular area of study. This course provides an opportunity for students to explore the basic principles of research methods and consider how these may be applied to their research project. Students will identify their topic/research question and appropriate methods of inquiry through peer review, students will present their research topic, investigations and work-in-progress for scholarly interrogation.
Subject_Description_3: Honours Research Project constitutes a 40CP honours research commitment within the (Bachelor of Fine Art (Honours) and Bachelor of Photography (Honours). Each of the four components of the course combine to introduce students to the rigors of research and engage them in an advanced level of study within visual practice. The expectation is that the research project undertaken will be based within the visual and incorporates high levels of visual literacy. Assessment of the four courses will culminate in one assessment item. Honours Research Project is presented with the Exegesis (completed in 6012QCA) for assessment in a professional context at the completion of all four courses. Co-requisite/Pre-requisite: 6303QCA Visual Arts Research Methods.
Subject_Description_4: Honours Research Project constitutes a 40CP honours research commitment within the (Bachelor of Fine Art (Honours) and Bachelor of Photography (Honours). Each of the four components of the course combine to introduce students to the rigors of research and engage them in an advanced level of study within visual practice. The expectation is that the research project undertaken will be based within the visual and incorporates high levels of visual literacy. Assessment of the four courses will culminate in one assessment item. Honours Research Project includes the practical component and the exegesis for assessment in a professional context at the completion of all four courses Co-requisite/Pre-requisite: 6303QCA">6303QCA Visual Arts Research Methods.Co-requisite/Pre-requisite: 6303QCA">6303QCA Visual Arts Research Methods.
Subject_or_Unit_5: COMMUNICATING RESEARCH IN THE VISUAL ARTS
Subject_Description_5: This course will assist you in resolving the two major outputs of practice-led research in the visual arts: an exegesis and exhibition of creative practice. Seminars are geared towards both academic writing and practice development, with a view to equipping you with the tools required for documenting, critically evaluating and communicating your research. Topics include the writing and refinement of core exegesis writing components as well as appropriate methodologies for creative outcomes. The subject facilitates the communication and management of self- directed research projects with written and creative outputs.
Subject_Description_6: Honours Research Project constitutes a 40CP honours research commitment within the (Bachelor of Fine Art (Honours) and Bachelor of Photography (Honours). Each of the four components of the course combine to introduce students to the rigors of research and engage them in an advanced level of study within visual practice. The expectation is that the research project undertaken will be based within the visual and incorporates high levels of visual literacy. Assessment of the four courses will culminate in one assessment item. Honours Research Project is presented with the Exegesis (completed in 6012QCA) for assessment in a professional context at the completion of all four courses. Co-requisite/Pre-requisite: 6303QCA Visual Arts Research Methods.

Description: International students must be in Australia and able to attend campus to commence this program. This program will be available to commencing students at the Gold Coast and Nathan from 2021. Graduates will be eligible to register to practice as a Physiotherapist within Australia following accreditation. Students will undertake biomedical, physical and behavioural science courses as well as physiotherapy academic and clinical courses. Before graduation, students will be required to demonstrate physiotherapy knowledge and skills required for entry-level clinical physiotherapy practice.  This program provides an innovative, student-centred and employability-focused curriculum with a strong emphasis on client-centred and evidence based-practice as well as experiential and inter-professional learning.
Career_Outcomes: Physiotherapists aim to enhance the movement and function of individuals and populations across the lifespan especially when actual or potential impairments and disability relate to the musculoskeletal, cardiorespiratory, and neurological systems. Physiotherapists work in various settings such as hospitals, private practices, community health centres, schools, sporting teams and the armed forces. Physiotherapists may also be employed at universities to teach or conduct research or consult for industry and government bodies.
Subject_Description_1: This course covers the anatomy and physiology of the cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, digestive and immune systems. Both the study of the anatomy and the physiology of these systems draws on the experience gained in the lectures, laboratories and practicums. Prerequisites for Gold Coast students: 1016MSC">1016MSC Anatomy and Physiology Systems I, and 1014MSC Cells, Tissues and Regulation OR 1001AHS Foundations of Exercise and Sport Science. Prerequisites for Nathan students: 1016MSC">1016MSC Anatomy and Physiology Systems I and 1001NSC Human Biology.
Subject_Description_2: This course prepares graduates across health professions to provide culturally safe health services to Australia's First Peoples. Through the enhancement of the previously introduced capabilities of respect, communication, safety and quality, critical reflection, and advocacy students will be supported to apply these capabilities in First Peoples' health contexts to engender the development of cultural capabilities that reflect a lifelong journey and are tested in every interaction. The course takes a holistic perspective to engage students in exploring the historical, socio-cultural, political and dominant cultural paradigms that influence First Peoples' health today. The First Peoples' Health and Practice course supports students to meet the Griffith University Graduate Attribute E.1 Awareness of and respect for the values and knowledge of Australian Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander First Peoples and to meet the requirements of the relevant professional body's competency standards and codes of professional conduct to provide culturally safe care. Pre-requisite: Students must have successfully completed at least 80CP of undergraduate study. This requirement will be strictly enforced.
Subject_Description_3: Five body systems: Skeletal, Muscle, Nervous, Endocrine and Reproductive Systems are studied in this course, which integrates anatomy with physiology. The theory presented in this course is supported by practical laboratory experiences, which include the study of human cadaveric material.
Subject_Description_4: This is one of five Physiotherapy Practicum courses designed to enable you to develop capabilities reflective of a new graduate physiotherapist with a range of clients in a variety of clinical and environmental settings. The key component of this course is a five week full time clinical placement across the areas of acute care, musculoskeletal, rehabilitation or community. Prerequisite: All Year 1,2 and 3 courses from the Bachelor of Physiotherapy. This pre-requisite will be strictly enforced.
Subject_Description_5: Musculoskeletal Anatomy course has been designed to consolidate knowledge of structure and function of the musculoskeletal system. A thorough understanding of musculoskeletal anatomy is imperative to the practice of physiotherapists, exercise physiologists and other health professionals. Students will build on theoretical knowledge and practical skills obtained in prerequisite courses through a series of online lectures, specialised laboratory sessions and a weekly online tutorial. Prerequisite: 1016MSC Anatomy & Physiology Systems I or other approved anatomy course
Subject_Description_6: This course introduces students to the profession of physiotherapy. Students will develop an awareness of ethical, legal and professional issues related to physiotherapy practice, and have the opportunity to develop strong communication, interpersonal, and rapport-building skills. Students will develop and apply those skills in the context of introductory knowledge and skills related to therapeutic massage. To enrol in this course, Bachelor of Physiotherapy students will need to be enrolled the following co-requisite course: 1402AHS Physiotherapy II, 1016MSC Anatomy and Physiology I.
Subject_Description_7: This course will provide students with knowledge, understanding, and skills in the physiotherapy assessment and treatment of people with neurological conditions. Students will study the pathology, disability, recovery and prognosis of common neurological conditions and be introduced to evidence-based, holistic, and multidisciplinary management approaches. Pre-requisite: 2404AHS Musculoskeletal Physiotherapy 1
Subject_Description_8: This capstone course will provide students with the opportunity to learn, develop, and demonstrate leadership and professional skills relevant to physiotherapy practice. Specialised and emerging areas of practice will be explored, and employability aspects emphasised.
Subject_Description_9: As a physiotherapist your knowledge and skill in musculoskeletal assessment and treatment are critical to your professional competence. This course provides you with valuable opportunities to develop your understanding of, and skill in the assessment, diagnosis and management of patients with peripheral neuromusculoskeletal conditions. The role of observation, manual therapy skills, clinical reasoning and communication in effective musculoskeletal practice will be supported through the use of evidence based practical teaching, critique of the literature and the working through of clinical cases in collaboration with peers and experienced clinicians. Pre-requisites: 2401AHS, 2403AHS & 2010AHS
Subject_Description_10: This course provides students with an opportunity to consolidate their knowledge, skills and attitudes through a significant project. Students will be supported to explore current local occupational issues. In teams students will select an issue and then plan, develop, deliver and evaluate an occupational intervention. Incompatible: 2043MKT Entrepreneurship and New Business Ventures; 2043IBA Innovation, Creativity and Entrepreneurship Prerequisites: 3322AHS Occupation, Health and Participation - Communities and Populations; 3326AHS Occupational Therapy Professional Practice and Education II.
Subject_Description_11: Cells, Tissues and Regulation examines how a single cell exists, and how when they come together in their trillions, we end up with human beings who can adapt to changing environments. Fundamental knowledge for any future health professionals. Assumed Knowledge: Maths B and One of Biology, Chemistry or Physics (4SA)
Subject_Description_12: This course will provide foundational knowledge of medicines and pharmacology for allied health professions. The course will cover principles such as pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, pharmacogenomics; drug interactions and side effects; and orientation to the use of medicines for common disorders of the musculoskeletal, neurological, cardiovascular, respiratory, endocrine, and gastrointestinal, and immune systems. It is expected that students wishing to study 2011PHM will have completed tertiary level courses in anatomy and physiology.
Subject_Description_13: This is one of five Physiotherapy Practicum courses designed to enable you to develop capabilities reflective of a new graduate physiotherapist with a range of clients in a variety of clinical and environmental settings. The key component of this course is a five week full time clinical placement across the areas of acute care, musculoskeletal, rehabilitation or community. Prerequisite: All Year 1,2 and 3 courses from the Bachelor of Physiotherapy. This pre-requisite will be strictly enforced.
Subject_Description_14: The aim of this course is to define health within a biopsychosocial framework and present the current issues in the area, providing students with an introduction to key areas of Health Psychology. The course will situate Health Psychology as a specialisation within psychology and will develop students' understanding of the biopsychosocial factors involved in health promotion and maintenance, illness prevention and treatment, and improving healthcare systems and health policy. The course will have a focus on Health Psychology in an Australian context and will develop students' understanding of the key theoretical, research, and methodological approaches applied to the discipline of Health Psychology. PREREQUISITES: 1002PSY and 1003PSY
Subject_Description_15: As a student in this course, you will explore the role of physiotherapy in assessing and treating individuals across the lifespan, with a focus on paediatric populations. You will emphasise preventative and rehabilitative care in a variety of clinical settings to children as they grow and develop. You will also acquire the knowledge and skills to plan, deliver and evaluate high quality, effective physiotherapy and inter-professional services for paediatric clinical populations within a family-centred model of care. This course builds on the foundations acquired in year one and two and links with future clinical placements. Pre-requistes: Physiotherapy Across the Lifespan 1 (3407AHS), Musculoskeletal Physiotherapy 2 (3401AHS) and Neurological Physiotherapy (3405AHS). Co-requistes: Acute Care Physiotherapy (3403AHS) and Integrated Case Management in Physiotherapy (3409AHS).
Subject_Description_16: This course will provide students with knowledge, understanding, and skills in clinical reasoning and evidence-based practice within physiotherapy. Students will formulate clinically-relevant research questions, source and critically appraise literature, and explore how evidence may inform clinical practice and future research across core areas of physiotherapy practice. Pre-requisite: 2401AHS Therapeutic Exercise for Physiotherapy
Subject_Description_17: This is one of five Physiotherapy Practicum courses designed to enable you to develop capabilities reflective of a new graduate physiotherapist with a range of clients in a variety of clinical and environmental settings. The key component of this course is a five week full time clinical placement across the areas of acute care, musculoskeletal, rehabilitation or community. Prerequisite: All Year 1,2 and 3 courses from the Bachelor of Physiotherapy. This pre-requisite will be strictly enforced.
Subject_Description_18: As a student in this course, you will explore the role of physiotherapy in assessing and treating individuals across the lifespan, with an equitable focus on adult clients and populations. You will emphasise preventative and rehabilitative care in a variety of clinical settings to individuals as they age. You will acquire the knowledge and skills to plan, deliver and evaluate high quality, effective physiotherapy and inter-professional services for these clinical populations. This course builds on the foundations acquired in year one and two and links with future clinical placements. Prerequisite: 2404AHS
Subject_or_Unit_19: RESEARCH METHODS AND STATISTICS IN PSYCHOLOGY
Subject_Description_19: You will learn about the role of scientific data gathering in psychology which underpins all evidence-based practice. Basic research approaches will be described and the manner in which research is communicated (e.g., research psychology report) will be practised. You will gain skills in the description of data using basic graphical (e.g., histograms) and numerical (e.g., mean and standard deviation) methods. The association between variables through scatterplots and correlations is examined and you will learn how to calculate and interpret the confidence interval of the mean and make inferences using t-tests. You will learn to create and interpret output from the statistical software package SPSS for these statistical techniques. Prerequisites: Nil Co-requisites: Nil Incompatible: First Year Tertiary Level Statistics|1003PSY Introduction to Research in Behavioural Sciences| 2009CCJ Statistics for Social Research| 1305AFE Business Data Analysis| 1014SCG Statistics| 1002MSC Introduction to Biomedical Data Analysis| 2013AHS Research Methods and Statistics
Subject_Description_20: This course advances the physiology taught in first year with particular emphasis on the cardiovascular, respiratory, metabolic and renal body systems. The course focuses on the integrated functions of these systems from a clinical perspective. It forms the foundation of applied physiology courses that follow and will consist of on-line lectures, workshops, laboratory sessions and case study analysis. Prerequisite: 1017MSC Anatomy & Physiology Systems II.
Subject_Description_21: This course will introduce students to the structure and function of the central and peripheral nervous system, with particular focus on the sensory and motor systems. Clinical applications of neuroanatomy in physiotherapy will be discussed with reference to healthy and pathological presentations. Students will develop skills in neurological assessment of sensation, strength, reflexes, and balance. Students will also be introduced to principles of motor learning and control, and the impact of attention, memory, practice, and feedback on skill development. Prerequisites: 1016MSC, 1401AHS & 1402AHS
Subject_Description_22: Chronic disease is one of our greatest health challenges, accounting for a high proportion of all deaths in Australia. Within a multi-disciplinary setting, physiotherapists improve quality of life for people living with complex or chronic conditions. The aim of this course is to enable you to successfully manage clients with complex or chronic conditions using an integrated model of care. The focus will be on using valid and reliable outcome measures for assessment and development of clinical reasoning to determine a suitable evidence-based management plan. You will be required to integrate knowledge of medico-legal, cultural, ethical and professional issues with physiotherapy knowledge and clinical skills that are necessary to function competently as a physiotherapist. Pre-requisites: 2012AHS Integrated Systems Physiology, 3401AHS Musculoskeletal Physiotherapy 2 and 3407AHS Physiotherapy Across the Lifespan 1
Subject_Description_23: Human Biology provides the foundation knowledge for human anatomy, physiology and cell biology inherent in the biological and biomedical sciences. The course examines the major body systems along with the integration and regulation of these physiological systems to maintain homeostasis.
Subject_Description_24: This course provides an introductory-level overview of several fields within psychology. It focuses on developmental and social processes and their relationships to individual differences in behaviour, and provides a broad introduction to the areas of developmental, personality, abnormal and social psychology. INCOMPATIBLE: PB11004 AND JAD1004 OR HJ11004 AND 1006APY AND 1015HSV
Subject_Description_25: As a physiotherapist your knowledge, understanding, and skill in the assessment and management of patients with spinal musculoskeletal conditions is critical to your professional competence. For this reason, this course provides you with valuable opportunities to develop your understanding of, and skill in the assessment, diagnosis, treatment and overall management of patients with spinal musculoskeletal conditions. As a student, you will extend your knowledge and skill in musculoskeletal physiotherapy practice through exposure to theoretical and experiential learning activities that focus on manual therapy, exercise rehabilitation, clinical reasoning, communication and education. To enrol in this course, Bachelor of Physiotherapy students will need to have successfully completed the prerequisite course: 2404AHS Musculoskeletal Physiotherapy I.
Subject_Description_26: This is one of five Physiotherapy Practicum courses designed to enable you to develop capabilities reflective of a new graduate physiotherapist with a range of clients in a variety of clinical and environmental settings. The key component of this course is a five week full time clinical placement across the areas of acute care, musculoskeletal, rehabilitation or community. Prerequisite: All Year 1,2 and 3 courses from the Bachelor of Physiotherapy. This pre-requisite will be strictly enforced.
Subject_or_Unit_27: LEGAL AND ETHICAL PRINCIPLES IN HEALTHCARE
Subject_Description_27: Health care practitioners are regularly confronted by legally complex and ethically challenging clinical situations. To ensure that they practice according to current legal and professional standards, a sound understanding of legal and ethical principles that underpin safe and competent practice is required. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: NIL
Subject_Description_28: This course will focus on developing essential physiotherapy knowledge and skills required to assess and treat clients with cardiorespiratory disorders in acute care and rehabilitation settings. Students will apply understanding of anatomy, pathophysiology, and exercise physiology to clients with cardiorespiratory disorders, to interpret assessment findings and implement evidence-based treatment plans. Students will also be taught a range of evidence-based treatment interventions, and need to demonstrate competency in the selection and application of techniques, and evaluation of treatment outcomes. Pre-requisites: 2403AHS Physiotherapy 4, 3407AHS Physiotherapy Across the Lifespan 1
Subject_Description_29: This is one of five Physiotherapy Practicum courses designed to enable you to develop capabilities reflective of a new graduate physiotherapist with a range of clients in a variety of clinical and environmental settings. The key component of this course is a five week full time clinical placement across the areas of acute care, musculoskeletal, rehabilitation or community. Prerequisite: All Year 1,2 and 3 courses from the Bachelor of Physiotherapy. This pre-requisite will be strictly enforced.
Subject_Description_30: This course covers topics including tissue injury and repair and pathology of chronic disease. Assessment and management of conditions will be underpinned by an understanding of pain mechanisms from a biopsychosocial context. Prerequisite: 1403AHS Physiotherapy 3.
Subject_Description_31: This course will introduce students to the important concepts of human movement and function. Students will develop knowledge and understanding of human anatomy, posture, mechanics of movement and function, and an appreciation of the different mechanical properties of different body tissues. Students will develop skills in the observation, description and measurement of joint movement, muscle function and human function including gait. To enrol in this course, Bachelor of Physiotherapy students will need to also enrol in co-requisite courses: 1016MSC Anatomy and Physiology Systems 1 and 1401AHS Physiotherapy I.
Subject_Description_32: Building on knowledge and skills acquired in previous courses, Therapeutic Exercise for Physiotherapy focusses on the use of exercise to optimise musculoskeletal, neuromotor, and cardiovascular system function. Following assessment, exercise programmes will be designed and implemented to improve an individual's physical capacity and health across those three systems. The knowledge and skills acquired in this course form a foundation for the use of exercise across the lifespan in musculoskeletal, neurological, and cardiovascular rehabilitation as part of specialised courses later in the programme. Prerequisites: 1403AHS Physiotherapy 3, 1017MSC Anatomy and Physiology Systems II Co-Requisites: 2010AHS Musculoskeletal Anatomy Assumed background: All AHS and MSC coded courses prior to this trimester.

Description: This program will be available to commencing students at the Gold Coast and Nathan from 2021. After completing two years of study in the Bachelor of Physiotherapy (1589) program, high achieving students with a Grade Point Average of at least 5.0 are eligible to apply to transfer to the Bachelor of Physiotherapy (Honours) program. Similar to the Bachelor of Physiotherapy program, these students will need to demonstrate physiotherapy knowledge and skills required for entry-level clinical physiotherapy practice. In addition, Bachelor of Physiotherapy (Honours) students will develop and demonstrate advanced knowledge and skills relating to research in their final two years of study. Graduates will be eligible to register to practice as a Physiotherapist within Australia following accreditation and also progress directly to higher degree research study such as a Master of Philosophy or Doctor of Philosophy.
Career_Outcomes: Physiotherapists aim to enhance the movement and function of individuals and populations across the lifespan, especially when actual or potential impairments and disability relate to the musculoskeletal, cardiorespiratory, and neurological systems. Physiotherapists work in various settings, such as hospitals, private practices, community health centres, schools, sporting teams, and the armed forces. Physiotherapists may also be employed at universities to teach or conduct research, or consult for industry and government bodies.
Subject_Description_1: As a physiotherapist your knowledge, understanding, and skill in the assessment and management of patients with spinal musculoskeletal conditions is critical to your professional competence. For this reason, this course provides you with valuable opportunities to develop your understanding of, and skill in the assessment, diagnosis, treatment and overall management of patients with spinal musculoskeletal conditions. As a student, you will extend your knowledge and skill in musculoskeletal physiotherapy practice through exposure to theoretical and experiential learning activities that focus on manual therapy, exercise rehabilitation, clinical reasoning, communication and education. To enrol in this course, Bachelor of Physiotherapy students will need to have successfully completed the prerequisite course: 2404AHS Musculoskeletal Physiotherapy I.
Subject_or_Unit_2: RESEARCH METHODS AND STATISTICS IN PSYCHOLOGY
Subject_Description_2: You will learn about the role of scientific data gathering in psychology which underpins all evidence-based practice. Basic research approaches will be described and the manner in which research is communicated (e.g., research psychology report) will be practised. You will gain skills in the description of data using basic graphical (e.g., histograms) and numerical (e.g., mean and standard deviation) methods. The association between variables through scatterplots and correlations is examined and you will learn how to calculate and interpret the confidence interval of the mean and make inferences using t-tests. You will learn to create and interpret output from the statistical software package SPSS for these statistical techniques. Prerequisites: Nil Co-requisites: Nil Incompatible: First Year Tertiary Level Statistics|1003PSY Introduction to Research in Behavioural Sciences| 2009CCJ Statistics for Social Research| 1305AFE Business Data Analysis| 1014SCG Statistics| 1002MSC Introduction to Biomedical Data Analysis| 2013AHS Research Methods and Statistics
Subject_Description_3: This course will introduce students to the important concepts of human movement and function. Students will develop knowledge and understanding of human anatomy, posture, mechanics of movement and function, and an appreciation of the different mechanical properties of different body tissues. Students will develop skills in the observation, description and measurement of joint movement, muscle function and human function including gait. To enrol in this course, Bachelor of Physiotherapy students will need to also enrol in co-requisite courses: 1016MSC Anatomy and Physiology Systems 1 and 1401AHS Physiotherapy I.
Subject_Description_4: This capstone course will provide students with the opportunity to learn, develop, and demonstrate leadership and professional skills relevant to physiotherapy practice. Specialised and emerging areas of practice will be explored, and employability aspects emphasised.
Subject_Description_5: This course prepares graduates across health professions to provide culturally safe health services to Australia's First Peoples. Through the enhancement of the previously introduced capabilities of respect, communication, safety and quality, critical reflection, and advocacy students will be supported to apply these capabilities in First Peoples' health contexts to engender the development of cultural capabilities that reflect a lifelong journey and are tested in every interaction. The course takes a holistic perspective to engage students in exploring the historical, socio-cultural, political and dominant cultural paradigms that influence First Peoples' health today. The First Peoples' Health and Practice course supports students to meet the Griffith University Graduate Attribute E.1 Awareness of and respect for the values and knowledge of Australian Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander First Peoples and to meet the requirements of the relevant professional body's competency standards and codes of professional conduct to provide culturally safe care. Pre-requisite: Students must have successfully completed at least 80CP of undergraduate study. This requirement will be strictly enforced.
Subject_Description_6: Five body systems: Skeletal, Muscle, Nervous, Endocrine and Reproductive Systems are studied in this course, which integrates anatomy with physiology. The theory presented in this course is supported by practical laboratory experiences, which include the study of human cadaveric material.
Subject_Description_7: The aim of this course is to define health within a biopsychosocial framework and present the current issues in the area, providing students with an introduction to key areas of Health Psychology. The course will situate Health Psychology as a specialisation within psychology and will develop students' understanding of the biopsychosocial factors involved in health promotion and maintenance, illness prevention and treatment, and improving healthcare systems and health policy. The course will have a focus on Health Psychology in an Australian context and will develop students' understanding of the key theoretical, research, and methodological approaches applied to the discipline of Health Psychology. PREREQUISITES: 1002PSY and 1003PSY
Subject_Description_8: Musculoskeletal Anatomy course has been designed to consolidate knowledge of structure and function of the musculoskeletal system. A thorough understanding of musculoskeletal anatomy is imperative to the practice of physiotherapists, exercise physiologists and other health professionals. Students will build on theoretical knowledge and practical skills obtained in prerequisite courses through a series of online lectures, specialised laboratory sessions and a weekly online tutorial. Prerequisite: 1016MSC Anatomy & Physiology Systems I or other approved anatomy course
Subject_Description_9: As a physiotherapist your knowledge and skill in musculoskeletal assessment and treatment are critical to your professional competence. This course provides you with valuable opportunities to develop your understanding of, and skill in the assessment, diagnosis and management of patients with peripheral neuromusculoskeletal conditions. The role of observation, manual therapy skills, clinical reasoning and communication in effective musculoskeletal practice will be supported through the use of evidence based practical teaching, critique of the literature and the working through of clinical cases in collaboration with peers and experienced clinicians. Pre-requisites: 2401AHS, 2403AHS & 2010AHS
Subject_Description_10: This course covers topics including tissue injury and repair and pathology of chronic disease. Assessment and management of conditions will be underpinned by an understanding of pain mechanisms from a biopsychosocial context. Prerequisite: 1403AHS Physiotherapy 3.
Subject_Description_11: This course covers the anatomy and physiology of the cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, digestive and immune systems. Both the study of the anatomy and the physiology of these systems draws on the experience gained in the lectures, laboratories and practicums. Prerequisites for Gold Coast students: 1016MSC">1016MSC Anatomy and Physiology Systems I, and 1014MSC Cells, Tissues and Regulation OR 1001AHS Foundations of Exercise and Sport Science. Prerequisites for Nathan students: 1016MSC">1016MSC Anatomy and Physiology Systems I and 1001NSC Human Biology.
Subject_Description_12: This course will focus on developing essential physiotherapy knowledge and skills required to assess and treat clients with cardiorespiratory disorders in acute care and rehabilitation settings. Students will apply understanding of anatomy, pathophysiology, and exercise physiology to clients with cardiorespiratory disorders, to interpret assessment findings and implement evidence-based treatment plans. Students will also be taught a range of evidence-based treatment interventions, and need to demonstrate competency in the selection and application of techniques, and evaluation of treatment outcomes. Pre-requisites: 2403AHS Physiotherapy 4, 3407AHS Physiotherapy Across the Lifespan 1
Subject_Description_13: Human Biology provides the foundation knowledge for human anatomy, physiology and cell biology inherent in the biological and biomedical sciences. The course examines the major body systems along with the integration and regulation of these physiological systems to maintain homeostasis.
Subject_Description_14: This is one of five Physiotherapy Practicum courses designed to enable you to develop capabilities reflective of a new graduate physiotherapist with a range of clients in a variety of clinical and environmental settings. The key component of this course is a five week full time clinical placement across the areas of acute care, musculoskeletal, rehabilitation or community. Prerequisite: All Year 1,2 and 3 courses from the Bachelor of Physiotherapy. This pre-requisite will be strictly enforced.
Subject_Description_15: As a student in this course, you will explore the role of physiotherapy in assessing and treating individuals across the lifespan, with an equitable focus on adult clients and populations. You will emphasise preventative and rehabilitative care in a variety of clinical settings to individuals as they age. You will acquire the knowledge and skills to plan, deliver and evaluate high quality, effective physiotherapy and inter-professional services for these clinical populations. This course builds on the foundations acquired in year one and two and links with future clinical placements. Prerequisite: 2404AHS
Subject_Description_16: This course provides an introductory-level overview of several fields within psychology. It focuses on developmental and social processes and their relationships to individual differences in behaviour, and provides a broad introduction to the areas of developmental, personality, abnormal and social psychology. INCOMPATIBLE: PB11004 AND JAD1004 OR HJ11004 AND 1006APY AND 1015HSV
Subject_Description_17: This course will provide foundational knowledge of medicines and pharmacology for allied health professions. The course will cover principles such as pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, pharmacogenomics; drug interactions and side effects; and orientation to the use of medicines for common disorders of the musculoskeletal, neurological, cardiovascular, respiratory, endocrine, and gastrointestinal, and immune systems. It is expected that students wishing to study 2011PHM will have completed tertiary level courses in anatomy and physiology.
Subject_Description_18: This course is the first in the Physiotherapy Honours pathway that enables students to design, conduct and report a research project, under the supervision of an academic member of staff. This course will culminate in students submitting a written Dissertation and providing a verbal presentation of their research and associated study findings.
Subject_Description_19: This is one of five Physiotherapy Practicum courses designed to enable you to develop capabilities reflective of a new graduate physiotherapist with a range of clients in a variety of clinical and environmental settings. The key component of this course is a five week full time clinical placement across the areas of acute care, musculoskeletal, rehabilitation or community. Prerequisite: All Year 1,2 and 3 courses from the Bachelor of Physiotherapy. This pre-requisite will be strictly enforced.
Subject_Description_20: Chronic disease is one of our greatest health challenges, accounting for a high proportion of all deaths in Australia. Within a multi-disciplinary setting, physiotherapists improve quality of life for people living with complex or chronic conditions. The aim of this course is to enable you to successfully manage clients with complex or chronic conditions using an integrated model of care. The focus will be on using valid and reliable outcome measures for assessment and development of clinical reasoning to determine a suitable evidence-based management plan. You will be required to integrate knowledge of medico-legal, cultural, ethical and professional issues with physiotherapy knowledge and clinical skills that are necessary to function competently as a physiotherapist. Pre-requisites: 2012AHS Integrated Systems Physiology, 3401AHS Musculoskeletal Physiotherapy 2 and 3407AHS Physiotherapy Across the Lifespan 1
Subject_Description_21: As a student in this course, you will explore the role of physiotherapy in assessing and treating individuals across the lifespan, with a focus on paediatric populations. You will emphasise preventative and rehabilitative care in a variety of clinical settings to children as they grow and develop. You will also acquire the knowledge and skills to plan, deliver and evaluate high quality, effective physiotherapy and inter-professional services for paediatric clinical populations within a family-centred model of care. This course builds on the foundations acquired in year one and two and links with future clinical placements. Pre-requistes: Physiotherapy Across the Lifespan 1 (3407AHS), Musculoskeletal Physiotherapy 2 (3401AHS) and Neurological Physiotherapy (3405AHS). Co-requistes: Acute Care Physiotherapy (3403AHS) and Integrated Case Management in Physiotherapy (3409AHS).
Subject_Description_22: This course is offered as a one week intensive course run in Orientation week (O week) in Tri 1 & Tri 2). It is available to students enrolled in Health Group Honours programs, the Graduate Diploma in Health Research (4161), the Master of Medical Research (5433 and 5626), Master of Advanced Practice with Honours (5425) and Master of Advanced Practice (5424) - Health Care Research strand only. The course must be listed in your program. Students are presented with a framework to develop their research proposal. Students will be expected to clearly define their research topic and communicate this in both written and verbal forms. Students will develop proficiency in searching databases, compiling literature relevant to their dissertation topic and critically reviewing the literature to identify gaps. They will formulate their research aims and explain the significance of their research to an audience of their peers. Finally students will also be required to identify research methods and analytical tools that can be utilized in their study. This course is incompatible with 7001HSV (Foundations of Research Inquiry in Health).
Subject_Description_23: This course will introduce students to the structure and function of the central and peripheral nervous system, with particular focus on the sensory and motor systems. Clinical applications of neuroanatomy in physiotherapy will be discussed with reference to healthy and pathological presentations. Students will develop skills in neurological assessment of sensation, strength, reflexes, and balance. Students will also be introduced to principles of motor learning and control, and the impact of attention, memory, practice, and feedback on skill development. Prerequisites: 1016MSC, 1401AHS & 1402AHS
Subject_Description_24: This course is one of a series of courses undertaken to complete dissertation requirements for your program. Each dissertation course has specific milestones to complete, which are available on the program website on Learning@Griffith. Dissertation courses involve the development of a research project, analysis of background literature, and the execution of experimental protocols. Results from these experiments are evaluated and conclusions drawn with findings presented in a formal context both orally and in a scientific research thesis.
Subject_Description_25: This course is one of a series of courses undertaken to complete dissertation requirements for your program. Each dissertation course has specific milestones to complete, which are available on the program website on Learning@Griffith. Dissertation courses involve the development of a research project, analysis of background literature, and the execution of experimental protocols. Results from these experiments are evaluated and conclusions drawn with findings presented in a formal context both orally and in a scientific research thesis.
Subject_Description_26: Building on knowledge and skills acquired in previous courses, Therapeutic Exercise for Physiotherapy focusses on the use of exercise to optimise musculoskeletal, neuromotor, and cardiovascular system function. Following assessment, exercise programmes will be designed and implemented to improve an individual's physical capacity and health across those three systems. The knowledge and skills acquired in this course form a foundation for the use of exercise across the lifespan in musculoskeletal, neurological, and cardiovascular rehabilitation as part of specialised courses later in the programme. Prerequisites: 1403AHS Physiotherapy 3, 1017MSC Anatomy and Physiology Systems II Co-Requisites: 2010AHS Musculoskeletal Anatomy Assumed background: All AHS and MSC coded courses prior to this trimester.
Subject_Description_27: This course introduces students to the profession of physiotherapy. Students will develop an awareness of ethical, legal and professional issues related to physiotherapy practice, and have the opportunity to develop strong communication, interpersonal, and rapport-building skills. Students will develop and apply those skills in the context of introductory knowledge and skills related to therapeutic massage. To enrol in this course, Bachelor of Physiotherapy students will need to be enrolled the following co-requisite course: 1402AHS Physiotherapy II, 1016MSC Anatomy and Physiology I.
Subject_Description_28: This course will provide students with knowledge, understanding, and skills in the physiotherapy assessment and treatment of people with neurological conditions. Students will study the pathology, disability, recovery and prognosis of common neurological conditions and be introduced to evidence-based, holistic, and multidisciplinary management approaches. Pre-requisite: 2404AHS Musculoskeletal Physiotherapy 1
Subject_Description_29: This is one of five Physiotherapy Practicum courses designed to enable you to develop capabilities reflective of a new graduate physiotherapist with a range of clients in a variety of clinical and environmental settings. The key component of this course is a five week full time clinical placement across the areas of acute care, musculoskeletal, rehabilitation or community. Prerequisite: All Year 1,2 and 3 courses from the Bachelor of Physiotherapy. This pre-requisite will be strictly enforced.
Subject_Description_30: This is one of five Physiotherapy Practicum courses designed to enable you to develop capabilities reflective of a new graduate physiotherapist with a range of clients in a variety of clinical and environmental settings. The key component of this course is a five week full time clinical placement across the areas of acute care, musculoskeletal, rehabilitation or community. Prerequisite: All Year 1,2 and 3 courses from the Bachelor of Physiotherapy. This pre-requisite will be strictly enforced.
Subject_Description_31: This course advances the physiology taught in first year with particular emphasis on the cardiovascular, respiratory, metabolic and renal body systems. The course focuses on the integrated functions of these systems from a clinical perspective. It forms the foundation of applied physiology courses that follow and will consist of on-line lectures, workshops, laboratory sessions and case study analysis. Prerequisite: 1017MSC Anatomy & Physiology Systems II.

Description: This program will be available to commencing students at the Gold Coast and Mt Gravatt from 2021. The Bachelor of Psychological Science will give you a thorough grounding in clinical, developmental, biological, cognitive, social and organisational psychology. You will learn how to: As an International student, you will receive dedicated support from your arrival in Australia through to your departure after graduation. You will be introduced to Griffith through an orientation program, and receive ongoing social, personal and academic support throughout your degree. Honours is available through an additional year of study at the Gold Coast or Mt Gravatt campus.
Career_Outcomes: As a Bachelor of Psychological Science graduate you will be prepared for careers in counselling, guidance, health management, social research, human services, social welfare and other related fields. You may also be eligible for entry into a range of postgraduate degrees in areas such as speech pathology, social work, rehabilitation counselling, forensic mental health, criminology and criminal justice, human services, mental health practice, disability studies, health research, and business research. Psychological science graduates are employed in a wide range of occupations and industries including in community corrections, in business as performance and workforce managers and occupational psychologists, in marketing, in the police service and defence forces, and in schools as guidance officers. To practice as a psychologist in Australia, you must be registered with the Psychology Board of Australia. To be eligible for registration, you must complete the Bachelor of Psychological Science with Honours. As a graduate with honours, you will be eligible for associate membership of the Australian Psychological Society and provisional registration as a psychologist with the Psychology Board of Australia. For full registration, you will need to complete a further two years of approved postgraduate study or supervised practice (on-the-job training) with a registered psychologist.
Subject_Description_1: You will be introduced to the theory and practice of psychological testing and assessment of individual differences with particular focus on personality and intelligence assessment. You will learn about the history of psychological testing; definition, advantages, and limitations of psychological tests; ethics in testing; and basic psychometric concepts (test scores and norms, reliability and validity, test construction). You will apply this knowledge to understanding testing and assessment of individual differences in personality and intelligence. Prerequisites: 1001PSY Introduction to Psychology 1I 1002PSY Introduction to Psychology 2I 1003PSY Research Methods and Statistics in Psychology Co-requisites: Nil Incompatible: Nil
Subject_Description_2: Students will be introduced to the major theories of psychological development during childhood, adolescence and adulthood. The course will cover social and cognitive development, drawing on the work of Bowlby, Freud, Erikson, Piaget, Vygotsky, and Baltes, among others. Reviewing both classic and current research, the course will consider conceptual and methodological issues in developmental psychology. The principal topics for discussion include infancy, attachment, socialization, theory of mind, personality development, cognitive development, and adjustment to aging. This course aims to provide a conceptual foundation for practice in clinical, counselling, educational, community and organisational settings with children, adolescents, and adults. Prerequisites must be completed prior to enrolling in this course. It is the students' responsibility to ensure these requirements have been fulfilled. INCOMPATIBLE: 2008APY PREREQUISITE: 1001PSY OR 1005APY AND 1002PSY OR 1006APY AND 1003PSY OR 1002APY
Subject_Description_3: The course aims to facilitate the conceptual, analytic and problem-solving skills relevant to correlational research in the social sciences, as well as generic competencies in critical analysis, communication and data interpretation. The course complements other research methods and statistics courses. Material covered includes practical concerns in conducting this type of research such as selecting a sample, constructing instruments, and ensuring validity. As well, students gain an introduction to issues in the analysis and interpretation of correlational research findings. Topics include: survey and correlational research designs; sampling; regression analysis; and categorical data analysis. Prerequisites must be completed prior to enrolling in this course. It is the students' responsibility to ensure these requirements have been fulfilled. Prerequisites: 1001PSY Introduction to Psychology 1| 1002PSY Introduction to Psychology 2| 1003PSY Research Methods and Statistics in Pscyhology Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: 2001PSY Research Methods & Statistics 3| 3001PSY Research Methods & Statistics 4
Subject_Description_4: Students will be introduced to the major theories of psychological development during childhood, adolescence, and adulthood. The course will cover physical, cognitive, and psychosocial development, drawing on the work of Bowlby, Freud, Erikson, Piaget, Vygotsky, and Baltes among others. Reviewing both classic and current research, the course will consider conceptual and methodological issues in developmental psychology. Important aspects of development from conception to late adulthood will be covered. This course aims to provide a conceptual foundation for practice in clinical, counselling, educational, community, and organisational settings with children, adolescents, and adults. Prerequisites must be completed prior to enrolling in this course. It is the students' responsibility to ensure these requirements have been fulfilled. INCOMPATIBLE: 3011PSY Lifespan Development; 1010HSV Lifespan Development; 1804NRS Psychosocial Development across the Lifespan; 9003HLS Introduction to Lifespan and Social Development; PREREQUISITE: 1001PSY Introductory Cognitive & Biological Psychology AND 1002PSY Introductory Individual & Social Psychology.
Subject_Description_5: This is an applied skills-oriented course in the Bachelor of Psychological Science and associated degrees, Bachelor of Psychology (Hons), and Bachelor of Counselling. The course focuses on effectiveness of practitioners at the small and large group level. The course introduces key models of facilitation and coaching for groups. An important aspect of this course is the linking of these models to the development of students' skills in many aspects of facilitation and coaching. At the end of this course, students will understand and have basic skills in the application of facilitation and coaching in a range of settings such as counselling, clinical, organisational, sport, and health settings. Prerequisite: 1008PSY Interpersonal Skills Incompatible: 2027HSV Group Facilitation
Subject_Description_6: This course is an applied skills-oriented course. The aim of this course is to provide you with the opportunity to develop your mastery of the generic interpersonal communication skills necessary for building and maintaining effective working and personal relationships, and managing interpersonal interactions and change. In addition, you will be introduced to skills which are the "building blocks" for more advanced skills that you may use in future professional roles such as Consultant, Counsellor, Lawyer, Manager, Psychologist, Public Health practitioner or Social Worker. INCOMPATIBLE: PSY2002 AND PB12013 AND JAD1006 OR 1006CCJ AND 2007APY AND 7022HSV AND 7322AHS AND 1008HSV AND 2008EHR.
Subject_Description_7: This intermediate course will introduce students to experimental design and analysis in psychology. Building on basic experimental reseach and statistical concepts, material on statistical hypothesis testing (especially in the ANOVA tradition) is integrated with new material on the design of more complex experiments and on issues concerning measurement, reliability, and manipulation. Topics include: between subjects designs; between subjects analyses including confidence intervals and multiple comparisons up to factorial ANOVA; within subjects designs and analyses up to within subjects factorial ANOVA; and mixed designs and analysis using ANOVA. Prerequisites: 1003PSY Research Methods and Statistics in Psychology| or 1305AFE Business Data Analysis| Competence in using SPSS statistical software Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: NIL
Subject_Description_8: Language and Communication for Health is offered to students from a non-English speaking background (NESB). Students whose first language is English are NOT PERMITTED to undertake this course. The aim of this course is to introduce students to the language, knowledge and communication skills required for study and practice in their discipline. A further aim is to develop and practice English language skills relevant to the academic culture of Australian universities. It therefore involves intensive English language practice and language immersion activities, with elements applied to contextualised, discipline-specific settings. This course constitutes part of the overall English Language Enhancement Strategy at Griffith University. Prerequisites: NIL; Incompatible: 5901LHS/5901LAL, 5903LHS/5903LAL, 5904LHS/5904LAL and 5902LAL.
Subject_or_Unit_9: RESEARCH METHODS AND STATISTICS IN PSYCHOLOGY
Subject_Description_9: You will learn about the role of scientific data gathering in psychology which underpins all evidence-based practice. Basic research approaches will be described and the manner in which research is communicated (e.g., research psychology report) will be practised. You will gain skills in the description of data using basic graphical (e.g., histograms) and numerical (e.g., mean and standard deviation) methods. The association between variables through scatterplots and correlations is examined and you will learn how to calculate and interpret the confidence interval of the mean and make inferences using t-tests. You will learn to create and interpret output from the statistical software package SPSS for these statistical techniques. Prerequisites: Nil Co-requisites: Nil Incompatible: First Year Tertiary Level Statistics|1003PSY Introduction to Research in Behavioural Sciences| 2009CCJ Statistics for Social Research| 1305AFE Business Data Analysis| 1014SCG Statistics| 1002MSC Introduction to Biomedical Data Analysis| 2013AHS Research Methods and Statistics
Subject_Description_10: This course introduces students to the major psychological disorders covered in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (5th ed.). By completing this course successfully, students will have acquired the following types of information about a range of psychological disorders: - Epidemiology (Incidence, prevalence, lifetime prevalence) - Aetiology (Factors predisposing and precipitating the onset of disorders) - Specific diagnostic criteria employed by the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual (5th Ed.) for major psychological disorders - Assessment and treatment approaches for these disorders - Current debates that exist about specific psychological diagnoses and the general field of psychopathology. Prerequisites must be completed prior to enrolling in this course. It is the students' responsibility to ensure these requirements have been fulfilled. INCOMPATIBLE: PB13036 Abnormal Psychology AND 3010APY Abnormal Psychology PREREQUISITES: 1001PSY OR 1005APY AND 1002PSY OR 1006APY.
Subject_Description_11: This course is designed to teach the basic concepts of Cognitive Psychology covering topics such as attention, memory, language, and thinking. Familiarity with a diverse range of experimental methods and techniques is required to understand the research findings in these areas, and to critically evaluate theoretical explanations. Research findings and theoretical explanations will be presented in lectures. Laboratory experiments and demonstrations will complement the lectures by providing direct experience with some experimental techniques. Prerequisites: 1001PSY Introduction to Psychology 1I 1003PSY Research Methods and Statistics in PsychologyI or 2000PSY Experimental Design and Analysis Co-requisites: Nil Incompatible: Nil
Subject_Description_12: This course is a foundation course for development of an understanding of core concepts and basic competencies necessary for effective counselling practice, especially those essential to establish and maintain the client-practitioner relationship and support the therapeutic process. You will also be introduced to the foundations of developing an understanding of the client as a unique person, also termed 'case conceptualisation' and the concept of diversity. The skills you will learn include micro-skills such as listening, attending fully to the client, and creating a safe therapeutic relationship; self-and-other awareness; and self-reflection. Practical exercises allow you to integrate knowledge development with skills application. You will also be provided with opportunities to reflect on how counselling skills will fit within your future career and how you might prepare for further professional education in the field. Prerequisites: Nil
Subject_Description_13: This course provides a foundation for understanding the cognitive and biological bases of human behaviour, including the role of the brain and neural processes in behaviour, perception (how the senses allow you to see, hear, taste, touch and smell the world around you), conditioning and learning (how humans and other animals learn about their environment), cognition and memory (how people think, solve problems and remember). Drawing on various research traditions in experimental psychology, this course demonstrates how cognitive and biological psychology contributes to our knowledge of human well-being and performance. Students apply this knowledge through a series of practical in-class exercises. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: 1004HLS_Y2
Subject_Description_14: This course introduces students to the study of human behaviour from a biological point of view and an understanding of the link between biological systems and human behaviour. Apart from providing students with knowledge in basic areas such as the human nervous system, the human sensory and motor systems, the course also includes more applied topics. For example learning and memory, perception, language, emotion and motivation, sleeping, eating and eating disorders, drugs and brain damage. This course has prerequisites that must be completed prior to enrolling in this course. It is the students' responsibility to ensure these requirements have been fulfilled. INCOMPATIBLE: 2009APY PREREQUISITES: 1001PSY OR 1005APY AND 1003PSY OR 1002APY
Subject_Description_15: This course provides a set of frameworks for examining and understanding human behaviour in a social and cultural context. It integrates the social and the cultural, with the overriding aim to develop an understanding of how the individual's thoughts, feelings, and behaviours can be shaped by the people around them, and the culture of which they are a part. Prerequisites: 1002PSY Introduction to Psychology 2 Co-requisites: Nil Incompatible: Nil
Subject_Description_16: This is an applied, skills-oriented course that is relevant to a range of contexts, including clinical, counselling, health, education, lifecourse, sport, organisational, forensic, and community settings. In this course you will learn about the key principles and processes of behaviour change such as understanding and assessing behaviour; motivation and adherence; individual, social and community level interventions; and evaluating impact. You will also learn about ethical and cultural issues and contemporary applications.
