Subject_Description_3: In this course, students conduct an industry-based placement within a commercial or industrial environment under professional supervision while managing their learning and course assessment. The placement provides students with the opportunity to undertake a substantial body of work that has an industry application. This body of work will be focused on the student's academic degree and major, and may be project based working on a single implementation, or task based supporting the industry partner. Students work in close liaison with their industry supervisor and academic supervisor throughout the placement and are expected to demonstrate a good understanding of their work. To be eligible for placement, students must have completed the online registration form in the trimester prior to enrolment: https://bblearn.griffith.edu.au/webapps/blackboard/content/listContent.jsp?course_id=_66918_1&content_id=_4338944_1. Students must complete all requirements of the Griffith Sciences WIL office in preparation for placement, including confirmed allocation to an industry placement. Prerequisites: Students should be in the final year of study, having completed 80CP of first year level subjects and 80CP of second year level subjects which define the program and have a cumulative GPA of 5.0.
Subject_Description_4: This course is designed for the purpose of educating first year students in basic meteorology in the Australian region, informing them, as well as providing a sound knowledge base of weather systems, which not only impact on flight planning, but could compromise aviation safety. The online offering of this course is only available to 'professional entry' students. Those students should email the Program Officer, Aviation, at aviation@griffith.edu.au for permission to enrol. Incompatible with 1502BPS Atmospheric Science; 2002AVN Atmospheric Science; 1102AVN Atmospheric Science. There are no prerequisites for this course.
Subject_Description_5: "Flight Procedures" is a workshop style course series, where students implement aviation theory and regulatory rules in a simulation laboratory environment. Flight Procedures II uses the Cessna 182RG software to introduce the constant speed propeller, retractable landing gear and glass cockpit design features initially, before exploring Instrument Flight Rules and procedures based on the Private Instrument Rating - all without any weather issues. We cover Instrument Flight Rules and associated Standard Operating Procedures ending with 2D non-precision approaches. Prerequisite: 1505NSC Flight Procedures I
Subject_Description_6: The Flight Procedures I course introduces students to the basic principles associated with each of the different phases of ab initio flying exercises. The course covers the aerodynamic principles, technical and procedural aspects, and regulatory framework of each aspect delivered in lecture format. The aspect is then practised and fully examined in the flight procedures laboratory utilising flight simulation software at workstations fitted with flight controls.
Subject_Description_7: This course is conducted with students participating in a Project-based engagement with industry. Projects are sourced from a range of industry and university partners that require significant analysis, design, development, communication and documentation effort. The problem is addressed by a number of students working in a team within the Agile lifecycle. Significant importance is placed on effective project management and excellent communication strategies between team members, the project manager, and with the industry client. Students work in close liaison with their external client and academic supervisor throughout the project and are expected to demonstrate a good understanding of their project. Prerequisites: 160CP of coursework, with a minimum of 60CP from second or third year courses.
Subject_Description_8: One of the roles of the IT professional is to design and build software systems and integrate them into an organisation. This course develops the skills to gather requirements, then develop/source, evaluate and integrate components into a single system, and finally validate the system. It also covers the fundamentals of software lifecycles, quality, software development processes, project management and the interplay between IT applications and organisational processes and relevant standards and tools.
Subject_Description_9: In Flight Procedures III students are introduced to the added systems complexity of a multi engine aircraft as well as the fundamental performance aspects relating to normal two engine and abnormal one engine in-operative operations. The twin engine platform is also used to extend their exposure to glass panel technology by introducing the full range of departure, arrival and approach procedures available under the Instrument Flight Rules [IFR]. Prerequisites: 1505NSC Flight Procedures I and 2533NSC Flight Procedures II OR 2531NSC Flight Procedures I/II
Subject_Description_10: Towards the higher speed ranges, the forces acting on the aircraft, its controllability and performance changes significantly. In this course, students study the principles underlying high speed design and corresponding flight characteristics. Prerequisite: 2521NSC Aerodynamics Part I or 2505NSC Aerodynamics.
Subject_Description_11: This is an introductory course to law with respect to the aviation industry in Australia. The course will cover two primary topics: (i) Basic principles of law in relation to the aviation industry. - Contract law - Tort law (Negligence, Trespass and Nuisance) - Administrative law (relating to the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA), and - International law (ii) Introduction to Aviation Regulation, designed to guide students through the extensive regulatory system governing aviation. Incompatible: 2509NSC Aviation Legal Studies; 2509BPS Aviation Legal Studies.
Subject_Description_12: This course introduces aspiring IT professionals to two topic areas that are critical to your working life. First, we will help you to unravel the ways in which information underpins business and organisational activity. Second, you will explore ways in which information systems are now critically important for managing activities and relationships with customers and suppliers. Incompatible: 1410ICT Introduction to Information Systems.
Subject_or_Unit_13: AIRCRAFT OPERATIONS, PERFORMANCE AND PLANNING PART I
Subject_Description_13: The course content covers the key areas of; aerodromes and aeroplane landing areas, take off, climb, en route, descent and landing performance; pre-flight and in-flight operational considerations; aeroplane loading; airworthiness and equipment requirements; flight rules and procedures. The course is covered in sufficient depth to enable students with limited flying experience or aviation industry exposure to grasp the fundamentals of aeroplane operation, performance and planning in accordance with the CASA CPL Operations, Performance and Planning syllabus. Incompatible with: 2510BPS/2510NSC Light Aircraft Operations, Performance and Planning
Subject_Description_14: Aviation Science is an introduction to scientific themes as applied in the world of aviation. The syllabus covers selected concepts from algebra, geometry and calculus, and from physics, with emphasis on forces and movement of bodies. The study is essential to understanding of aerodynamics and a variety of aviation-specific studies at a later stage
Subject_Description_15: This course builds on the underpinning knowledge of atmospheric Science and applies this knowledge to a practical aviation environment in accordance with the CASA CPL Meteorology syllabus. Prerequisite: 1304NSC/1304BPS/1502BPS/2002AVN Atmospheric Science Incompatible with: 2507BPS/2507NSC All Weather Operations
Subject_Description_16: Language and Communication for Sciences is offered to students from a non-English speaking background (NESB). Students whose first language is English are NOT PERMITTED to undertake this course. The aim of this course is to introduce students to the language, knowledge and communication skills required for study and practice in their discipline. A further aim is to develop and practice English language skills relevant to the academic culture of Australian universities. It therefore involves intensive English language practice and language immersion activities, with elements applied to contextualised, discipline-specific settings. This course constitutes part of the overall English Language Enhancement Strategy at Griffith University. Prerequisites: NIL; Incompatible: 5901LHS/5901LAL, 5902LHS/5902LAL, 5904LHS/5904LAL and 5903LAL.
Subject_Description_17: 3524NSC focuses on the human factors issues faced by pilots. It considers the human factors relevant to various flying operations in the aviation industry. This course examines human performance and limitations, from both a theoretical and practical perspective; with the aim of improving flight safety.
Subject_Description_18: This course is conducted with students participating in a Project-based engagement with industry. Projects are sourced from a range of industry and university partners that require significant analysis, design, development, communication and documentation effort. The problem is addressed by a number of students working in a team within the Agile lifecycle. Significant importance is placed on effective project management and excellent communication strategies between team members, the project manager, and with the industry client. Students work in close liaison with their external client and academic supervisor throughout the project and are expected to demonstrate a good understanding of their project. Prerequisites: 160CP of coursework, with a minimum of 60CP from second or third year courses. 3820ICT">3820ICT_P2 is a continuation of 3820ICT">3820ICT_P1
Subject_Description_19: A key component to the discipline of Information Technology is the understanding and the advocacy of the user in the development of IT applications and systems. IT graduates must develop a mind-set that recognizes the importance of users and organisational contexts and employ user-centred methodologies in the development, evaluation, and deployment of IT applications and systems. This requires graduates to develop knowledge of HCI, including user and task analysis, human factors, ergonomics, application domains, user interface development tools and GUI frameworks, accessibility standards, and cognitive psychology.
Subject_Description_20: The course introduces students to aerodynamics associated with small fixed-wing aircraft in sufficient depth to enable students to demonstrate their knowledge in subsonic aerodynamics. Note: Incompatible with 2505BPS/2505NSC Aerodynamics
Subject_Description_21: This course is conducted with students participating in a project-based engagement with industry: projects are sought from a range of industry and university partners (project sponsors) that require significant development, communication and documentation effort. The problem is addressed by a number of students working in a group to form a student project team. Significant importance is placed on effective project management and excellent communication strategies between team members, the project manager, and with the industry client. Within this strand, students may undertake different "tracks" depending on the development lifecycle model appropriate to the project. Students work in close liaison with their external client and academic supervisor throughout the project and are expected to demonstrate a good understanding of their project. Students should be in the final year of study, having completed of 80CP of first year level subjects and 80CP of second year level subjects which define the program. Pre-requisite: Must have completed 160CP
Subject_Description_22: Information derived from data is important to the management, productivity and competitive advantage of an organisation. Data must be efficiently collected, organized, retrieved and managed to make it meaningful to the organisation. It is the role of the IT professional to develop, deploy, manage and integrate data and information systems to support the organisation. This course includes the organisation, modeling, transformation and presentation of data. Incompatible with 1804ICT.
Subject_Description_23: This course covers the theory of Navigation under the Visual Flight Rules (VFR) in accordance with the CASA CPL Navigation syllabus. Note: Incompatible with 2508BPS/2508NCS Navigation
Subject_Description_24: Coding is an important part of today's world. In this course you will learn how to code in a creative context, utilising a practical and hands-on approach, producing generative art, data visualisations, and interactive interfaces.
Subject_or_Unit_25: AIRCRAFT OPERATIONS, PERFORMANCE AND PLANNING PART II
Subject_Description_25: This course is the second part of 2520NSC (Light Aircraft Operations, Performance and Planning Part I) in accordance with the CASA CPL Operations, Performance and Planning syllabus.
Subject_Description_26: This course introduces students to aspects of aviation biology and medicine essential for safe and effective pilot performance and for preservation of wellbeing while in overseas locations. Theoretical knowledge is integrated with some practical exercises designed to enhance student learning. The online offering of this course is only available to 'professional entry' students. Those students should email the Program Officer, Aviation, at aviation@griffith.edu.au for permission to enrol. Incompatible: Course AVN2001 Aviation Biology and Medicine
Subject_Description_27: This course educates students in modern onboard navigation systems and associated ground based technology. In addition, the course consolidates prior knowledge gained in the fields of Meteorology, Flight Planning and Performance, Basic Navigation and Aviation Regulation.
Subject_Description_28: This course provides a foundational understanding of computing systems, taking into account the historical, social and technological context within which such systems have developed and are now deployed. The topics covered include the history of computing, the theoretical foundations of computing, the practical foundations of computer hardware and architecture, and an investigation into the theoretical and historical foundations of information technology and the social consequences of the deployment of this technology. This course was previously named Information Technology Fundamentals
Subject_Description_29: Programming is a foundational skill for all computing disciplines. This course develops skills and concepts that are essential to good programming practice and problem solving. It covers fundamental programming concepts, event-driven programming, object-oriented programming, basic data structures, and algorithmic processes.
Subject_Description_30: The importance of managing for safety has been re-emphasised in recent years by the ICAO recommendation for aviation operators to implement a Safety Management System (SMS) based on the published ICAO SMS framework. This course will examine the key elements of a safety management system and the associated systems, processes and procedures used in achieving high safety standards in aviation organisations. There will be a strong emphasis on the importance of leadership and sound management principles and their important contribution to achieving high safety standards. Prior Assumed: Nil Incompatible: AVN3005 Flight Safety, 3005AVN Safety Management, 2511BPS Safety Management
Subject_Description_31: This course aims to equip students with a working knowledge of both global and domestic air traffic management environments, as the transition to the new Communications, Navigation and Surveillance/Air Traffic Management systems described in ICAO's Global Air Navigation Plan for CNS/ATM Systems is implemented. The online offering of this course is only available to 'professional entry' students. Those students should email the Program Officer, Aviation, at aviation@griffith.edu.au for permission to enrol. Incompatible with course AVN3004 Airways Operation and Design.
Subject_Description_32: This course introduces students to the concepts, tools and skills required to participate in the ubiquitous World Wide Web. The course adopts a particular emphasis on the design and implementation of web pages using up to date technologies (html5, css3, javascript).
Subject_Description_33: The real-world performance of any software system depends on the algorithms used and the efficiency of their implementation. The ability to select algorithms appropriate to solving particular problems, based on understanding the range of algorithms that address well-defined problems, analyzing their complexity and performance, and their suitability in particular contexts and implementing them is critical for building effective software. A number of general algorithmic strategies are presented including brute force, heuristics, greedy, recursive backtracking and divide and conquer. Common algorithms pertaining to searching, sorting, binary trees, graphs, and string / expression parsing are also discussed. Also both in-memory and file data structures and their interrelationship with specific algorithms are reviewed. Pre-requisites: 1801ICT">1801ICT Object-Oriented Programming (this course was previously named 1801ICT">1801ICT Programming Languages) and 1020ENG Engineering Mathematics 2.
Subject_Description_34: 2515NSC focuses on the human factors issues faced by pilots. It considers the human factors relevant to single-pilot and multi-crew operations. This course examines human performance and limitations, from both a theoretical and practical perspective; with the aim of improving flight safety
Subject_Description_35: This course introduces the underlying structures and mechanisms of modern computer systems and networks. All students enrolled in an ICT degree need to have an understanding of the basic architecture and operation of computer systems. This course provides an overview of the hardware, software and network technologies that define modern computer systems. The course aims to provide students with the basic knowledge of how the components that define a computer work together and by extension an appreciation of the capabilities and limitations of computer systems. This knowledge assists students in the application of computing technologies to solve real world problems. This course material builds a foundation for further study in the field of information technology, and is a suitable prerequisite for many ICT courses. Incompatible: 1807ICT: Computer and Network Architectures.

Course: Bachelor of Business/Bachelor of Data Science
Description: As digital disruption becomes a reality, the ability to analyse vast quantities of data to extract relevant intelligence for commercial planning is a highly sought after skill. By combining these degrees, you will gain crucial skills in data science that they will be able to apply to business and commercial scenarios; helping to future-proof their careers. You'll gain the skills to analyse, manipulate, model and interpret large data sets using digital platforms and tools, including Python, Tableau, Hadoop and SQL. You will be able to apply these specialised skills to your business major to uncover patterns and generate valuable insights into business operations and decision making. Through the Bachelor of Business you will gain a solid foundation in all aspects of business and develop an understanding of the social, cultural and political dimensions of business. You will enhance this knowledge with further expertise and experience by completing a major.  You may choose not to complete a major and combine a set of skills in their areas of interests. Business majors
Career_Outcomes: With combined qualifications in business and data science, you will find employment opportunities across a range of industries where you will develop data driven solutions for real-world issues in your chosen major.
Subject_Description_1: Information derived from data is important to the management, productivity and competitive advantage of an organisation. Data must be efficiently collected, organized, retrieved and managed to make it meaningful to the organisation. It is the role of the IT professional to develop, deploy, manage and integrate data and information systems to support the organisation. This course includes the organisation, modeling, transformation and presentation of data. Incompatible with 1804ICT.
Subject_or_Unit_2: BIG DATA ANALYTICS AND SOCIAL MEDIA
Subject_Description_2: This course aims to introduce the basic knowledge and necessary skills for analysis of Big Data. Big Data analytics is regarded as one of the important emerging technologies in different fields. The course is designed to stimulate interest in big data analytics in a popular scenario, i.e. social media. As such, some topics will be covered in depth while some will be covered only on an introductory level. Students will be shown how to extract information hidden in huge volumes of social media data. This is important for many businesses to understand the perceptions or opinions of their services or products. THIS COURSE WILL BE OFFERED IN SEMI-INTENSIVE MODE (WEEK 7 TO 12) IN TRIMESTER 2, 2020 AND WILL NOT BE OFFERED IN TRIMESTER 3, 2020.
Subject_Description_3: The course introduces basic vector algebra in two and three dimensions, matrices, complex numbers, probability and revises basic functions. It provides a foundation in the mathematical sciences for later studies in science and engineering. Prior Assumed Knowledge: It will be assumed that students have the knowledge equivalent to a grade of SA over 4 semesters in Mathematics B (Qld high school subject), or equivalent study over 4 semesters of a high school subject that includes the study of differential and integral calculus or 1017SCG">1017SCG Foundation Mathematics (grade of 4 or higher). For students who do not have this level of mathematics background, it is strongly suggested that they first complete 1017SCG">1017SCG Foundation Mathematics. Incompatible: 1010ENG Engineering Mathematics 1, 1011SCG Mathematics 1A, 1201BPS Mathematics 1A.
Subject_Description_4: Foundation Mathematics aims to provide a solid basis from which to build a wider set of mathematical skills across a broad range of disciplines. You may be looking to further studies in Education, IT, Business, Engineering, or any of the Physical or Social Sciences; all of which require a solid grounding in mathematics. The course has been constructed to cater for those who either did not study and pass Mathematical Methods (or Qld Maths B) in Year 11/12, OR have been away from study for some years and wish to refresh the mathematical skills required for further study. Successfully completing this course will satisfy all courses that have Mathematical Methods (or Qld Maths B) as a prerequisite, such as Linear Algebra and Calculus I. Foundation Mathematics covers the following topics. Working with Numbers, Algebraic methods, Solving equations, Understanding Functions, and both Differential and Integral Calculus. Mathematical thinking, as well as problem solving and reasoning, are developed throughout the course. Assumed Background: Basic mathematical skills to Year 10 level. Any Senior School Mathematics course would be an advantage but not necessary. Note that Foundation Mathematics is not permitted for students who have HA or VHA in Year 12 Mathematics B (Qld high school subject), or SA or higher in Year 12 Mathematics C (Qld High school subject), or the equivalent.
Subject_Description_6: The aim of the course is to explain the way people behave and make decisions in a business environment and the role that information has in the context of decision-making. The course will introduce some elements of behavioural sciences and game theory applied to business problems. It will also tackle some of the critical questions around the use of information for business decision making: how to assess the validity/reliability and relevance of the information we receive? how to use it effectively? how to simplify information, make it relevant, and present it to different audiences? The course combines different aspects. First, it encourages students to account for the psychological, cognitive, emotional, cultural, and social factors that affects decisions made by individuals and organisations (e.g. private corporates, government, civil society, etc). Second it provides simple analytical tools to contextualise strategic decision-making in real world situations through lenses such as that of the consumer and the future role of social marketing. Third, it introduces students to the idea that business decision making requires reliable, timely information. The course takes a positive (as opposed to normative) approach to the analysis of interactive strategic decisions and behaviours. Through case studies, the course provides a description of what happens in a variety of business situations, with a focus on understanding the elements/dynamics that leads to a certain outcome of decision. In so doing, the course helps students identify the role of information (qualitative or quantitative), how it is sourced and assessed in terms of its validity/quality, and how it can be used to deal with uncertainty in decision-making. Basic approaches to the analysis, interpretation and presentation of various types of information are also discussed, including the foundations of big data analytics and qualitative data analysis.
Subject_Description_7: Coding is an important part of today's world. In this course you will learn how to code in a creative context, utilising a practical and hands-on approach, producing generative art, data visualisations, and interactive interfaces.
Subject_Description_8: Students in this course are introduced to the idea that there are many ways to identify and solve the complex problems faced by businesses today; hence business success hinges on the ability to think creatively and innovatively, combining knowledge from a variety of disciplines. To this end, the course introduces ideas/tools of creativity and entrepreneurialism and demonstrates how these ideas/tools are applied to a variety of situations through the use of case studies and guest lecturers. The discussion is set in the context of the current debate on what constitutes business success, how it is achieved, and how businesses are under "scrutiny" by the community at large to ensure that they behave and operate in responsible and sustainable manner. In this regard, the course also explores issues related to financial and non-financial reporting, governance framework, risk management, stakeholder and agency, policy and regulatory intervention, indigenous/herniate assets. Lectures will include guest lecturers and will cover a diverse range of topics such as marketing, current and new technologies, future world trends, legal issues, work force issues etc. Workshops will enable students to work on case studies that involve real problems sourced from industry clients and partners. Industry clients will be directly involved in the workshop and students required to present solutions to their problems at the end of the trimester.
Subject_Description_9: This course will cover important concepts in Data Mining including generating new information, discover patterns, and unlock actionable insights from data. Students will be introduced to techniques and tools in mining associative and sequential patterns, abnormality detection, correlation analysis, clustering, and forecasting.
Subject_Description_10: This course introduces students to a perspective of the purpose of business that embeds values such as responsible leadership, integrity and ethical behaviour, respect for others, trust, and sustainable enterprise. The relevance of these values and their impact on behaviour and outcomes in a business context is demonstrated to students through case studies, real world examples, and testimonials from industry partners. Following from the discussion of values, the course then looks at how businesses develop solutions to respond to increasing demand for sustainability, transparency and good governance. The framework of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) is introduced and used to examine the alignment between business practices and sustainable solutions to real life problems faced by a business. The course also considers the role and responsibility (including legal) of professionals and professional standards in today's society.
Subject_Description_11: This course explores the future of work in a rapidly globalizing, knowledge and service-intensive economy. Advances in IT and associated technologies are enabling firms to automate and/or outsource routine work, displacing the jobs of low-skilled workers, while enhancing the power of knowledge workers. In parallel, new industries and forms of collaborative and distance-based work are emerging, offering new challenges and opportunities. This course investigates the causes of technological, industrial and organisational change and their potential impacts of work arrangements and stakeholder relationships. Strategies and policies for managing change and coping with the new world of work outlined, drawing on latest research from Australia and other countries. Students would investigate how the future of work affects the business landscape of both large companies and smaller firms. It would cover sources of value creation and the benefits and challenges of the new technologies. There will be an overview of IoT and futurist thinking and of selected technologies to examine how such digital innovations are being developed and used by leading organisations. Content will address the implications for managers of social media, big data, artificial intelligence and newer technological innovations.
Subject_Description_12: In an increasingly complex financial system, and with an aging and longer living population, financial independence and effective financial decision making are seen as important life attributes and skills. The reality however is that many make poor financial decisions, fail to plan for their financial future, adequately protect themselves, their family and their assets, are easily influenced into poor/inappropriate financial products, and fall foul of schemes and scams. In other words there is low levels of financial literacy in the community, including in higher education graduates. A study of money and life will cover a range of content areas including planning and goal setting, behaviour and decision making, financial markets, services and products, rights and obligations under contracts, financial systems and household finances. This could also introduce fintech (including Bloomberg and the SSMIF). The course would provide a range of personal and professional development outcomes for students as well as improve their overall understanding of business. The course will be designed to be relevant for all students of the university and also has potential for development into a standalone credential/MOOC.
Subject_Description_13: The course introduces the foundations of Big Data in a manner that covers the key concepts and characteristics of big data analytics and its real-world application. Students will learn about the practical applications needed to perform analytical tasks with the primary focus being on the visualisation and representation of that data. THIS COURSE WILL BE OFFERED IN SEMI-INTENSIVE MODE (WEEK 1 TO 6) IN TRIMESTER 2, 2020.
Subject_Description_14: This course will cover important concepts in Data Analytics including preparing, processing, normalizing, modeling, and visualizing data with the goal of summarizing useful information and supporting decision-making. It will introduce students to techniques and tools in data processing, exploratory data analytics, statistical data analytics, visual data analytics, analytics for special types of data. This course will be first offered in 2021 only
Subject_Description_15: Web applications interact with users, connecting to back-end databases and dynamically generating results to the browser through a web server. This course presents a systematic introduction to the development of dynamic, community-based, Web applications through the integration of HTML/CSS, with server-side scripting languages, database systems, modern web frameworks and other related technologies. Prerequisite: 2807ICT Programming Principles or 2701ICT Interactive App Development Incompatible: 2503ICT Web Programming
Subject_Description_16: This course introduces students to the concepts, tools and skills required to participate in the ubiquitous World Wide Web. The course adopts a particular emphasis on the design and implementation of web pages using up to date technologies (html5, css3, javascript).
Subject_Description_17: Information management is the collection, storage, preservation and delivery of information. After an introduction to these areas this course focuses on information storage (data format, data access, file systems, data recovery, concurrency control) and preservation (operational issues, policies and procedures, attacks and defence mechanisms, risk analyses, information recovery and information security). Incompatible: 3623ICT Information and Content Management.
Subject_Description_18: Organisations typically use many disparate technologies to achieve their business objectives. This course first gives an overview of low-level technologies such as programming with a focus on code reuse, scripting techniques and software configuration tools. This is followed by a practical presentation of software packages commonly used for handling data and producing reports and presentations. Pre-Requisite: 2807ICT Programming Principles for BIT students OR 2701ICT Interactive Application Development OR 2702ICT Intelligent Media Systems for BCIM students
Subject_Description_19: Programming is a foundational skill for all computing disciplines. This course develops skills and concepts that are essential to good programming practice and problem solving. It covers fundamental programming concepts, event-driven programming, object-oriented programming, basic data structures, and algorithmic processes.
Subject_Description_20: One of the roles of the IT professional is to design and build software systems and integrate them into an organisation. This course develops the skills to gather requirements, then develop/source, evaluate and integrate components into a single system, and finally validate the system. It also covers the fundamentals of software lifecycles, quality, software development processes, project management and the interplay between IT applications and organisational processes and relevant standards and tools.
Subject_Description_21: Transdisciplinary groups of students work together to solve contemporary challenges in business with a focus on the Sustainability Development Goals in the Asia Pacific region, including first peoples. Students present solutions to real world problems by drawing on the knowledge they have developed throughout their foundation and majors. Students participate in simulations in addition to running a social enterprise or charity event. In addition, students will finalise their program e-portfolio's with evidence of their readiness for their chosen profession or career. Students will also collect and present final evidence of readiness through Griffith Graduate Attributes, Griffith Graduates of Influence and BusinessPlus credentials.

Course: Bachelor of Business/Bachelor of Government and International Relations
Description: This program will be available to commencing students at the Gold Coast and Nathan from 2021. With Griffith Business School's Bachelor of Business/Bachelor of Government and International Relations, you can multiply your career options. In as little as four years, you can graduate with two degrees and a unique skill set that will give you an edge in the employment market. By combining in-depth knowledge and insight into the workings of government with practical business skills, you will be prepared for a future local, state and national governments, non-government organisations and private sector organisations that sectors interact with government agencies. For example, you can blend majors in Logistics and Supply Chain Management with International Relations and work for an international aid organisation providing humanitarian relief to disaster zones. You can also choose not to complete a major, selecting from a range of courses that provide broad knowledge for a career in business management.
Career_Outcomes: Graduates have the competencies required for pursuing a career in government, or organisations in the private, public and not-for-profit sectors that work closely with government. The Bachelor of Business will prepare you for career opportunities in the following fields: No major optionA business degree gives you the foundation to take your career just about anywhere. You will be prepared to use your extensive business skills in a range of increasingly diverse settings including not-for-profit, government and corporate organisations. Asian BusinessYou will find career opportunities in government, businesses with overseas profiles, international aid and other non-governmental organisations, news and media organisations, and the education industry in Asia. Behavioural Science You will find career opportunities in government, private enterprise and not-for-profit organisations across various disciplines including marking and advertising, human services, healthcare, economics, policy development, research and evaluation of programs and services. Employment RelationsYou will be able to work as an employment relations manager or consultant, or in roles dealing with workplace planning and policy, managerial strategy, industrial advocacy, occupational health and safety, and workplace negotiation. Entrepreneurship and Self-EmploymentAs a graduate, you will have an understanding of the strategic and operational issues involved in choosing self-employment or in working for an entrepreneurial new business, small business or family firm. Create a career by moving from employment to self-employment and back again, pursue the long-term growth of a high-potential new business venture, or become a serial entrepreneur, starting and selling new business ventures repeatedly. Event ManagementYou will be prepared for work in local, state, and federal government departments, sporting clubs, sport tourism, marketing, media, sporting and cultural organisations. Human Resource ManagementYou will be prepared for a career as a human resource manager or consultant. Human resource professionals work in many sectors including business management, counselling, workforce planning and policy, and recruiting and training staff for the public and private sectors and non-government organisations. International BusinessYou will be prepared to work with international trade and investment organisations or in the public and private sectors in management, strategic planning, research, corporate government relations, global operations and public relations. Logistics and Supply Chain ManagemenYou will be able to work as a logistics and supply chain manager, purchasing manager, business or strategy manager, or export and import operations manager. Career opportunities exist in the public, private and not-for-profit sectors. ManagementGood managers are needed across all sectors and in businesses of all sizes. With this qualification, you can apply your business management knowledge to an area of personal interest and find work in roles as a business manager in human resources, strategy, planning and policy, and training and development. MarketingYou will be able to work in any industry or organisation that needs to promote its products or services, from entertainment and fashion, to tourism, advertising, public relations, or business consulting. You might work as a brand manager, marketing manager, advertising account manager, market research analyst, public relations manager, or sales manager. Real Estate and Property DevelopmentThe property sector is expanding in Australia and around the world, creating a wide range of employment opportunities in the commercial, residential and tourism sectors of the real estate and property management industries. You will be prepared for a career in property finance, development and investment, real estate agency management, project management, and marketing and promoting real estate. Sport ManagementSport is big business, You will find opportunities in government departments, local, national and international sporting clubs, and event management organisations.There are also positions in sport tourism, marketing, media, and athlete representation. Sustainable EnterpriseIncreasingly, public and private sector organisations are hiring sustainability and corporate social responsibility specialists to their teams. As this field continues to grow, you will find more and more career opportunities in a wide variety of organisations. Tourism ManagementWith this qualification, you could travel the world. Tourism managers are employed by destination marketing organisations and all levels of government throughout Australia and internationally. You will be able to work on major tourism infrastructure and planning projects, shaping the visitor experience in tourism destinations. Bachelor of Government and International Relations: You will find opportunities providing advice to government and business leaders, developing policy and managing programs with domestic and international organisations in areas such as economic, environmental and social policy, diplomacy, and trade relations.
Subject_Description_1: The aim of the course is to explain the way people behave and make decisions in a business environment and the role that information has in the context of decision-making. The course will introduce some elements of behavioural sciences and game theory applied to business problems. It will also tackle some of the critical questions around the use of information for business decision making: how to assess the validity/reliability and relevance of the information we receive? how to use it effectively? how to simplify information, make it relevant, and present it to different audiences? The course combines different aspects. First, it encourages students to account for the psychological, cognitive, emotional, cultural, and social factors that affects decisions made by individuals and organisations (e.g. private corporates, government, civil society, etc). Second it provides simple analytical tools to contextualise strategic decision-making in real world situations through lenses such as that of the consumer and the future role of social marketing. Third, it introduces students to the idea that business decision making requires reliable, timely information. The course takes a positive (as opposed to normative) approach to the analysis of interactive strategic decisions and behaviours. Through case studies, the course provides a description of what happens in a variety of business situations, with a focus on understanding the elements/dynamics that leads to a certain outcome of decision. In so doing, the course helps students identify the role of information (qualitative or quantitative), how it is sourced and assessed in terms of its validity/quality, and how it can be used to deal with uncertainty in decision-making. Basic approaches to the analysis, interpretation and presentation of various types of information are also discussed, including the foundations of big data analytics and qualitative data analysis.
Subject_Description_2: The course explores the impact that government and business have on one another in a national and international context. It asks what consequences these relationships have for both government and business, particularly in the context of the aftermath of the global financial crisis. It offers insights into how government policies and practices affect business and how business influences and relates to government. At the heart of this course lies the issue of government intervention in business in Australia and elsewhere around the world. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatibles: 1004GIR Government-Business Relations, 1004PPP/1184PPP Government-Business Relations, 2004PPP Government-Business Relations.
Subject_Description_3: Note: This course is not offered from 2021. Check program requirements for details of alternative courses. This course is designed as a first formal course in basic statistical methods. It aims to provide recognition of situations where statistical analysis may be of benefit and the range of methods that may apply to a given situation. In this course, students will learn to use statistical methods to extract useful information from a set of data, and to utilize the information gathered appropriately in the business decision making process. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: 1304AFE Business Statistics, 1003PSY Research Methods and Statistics in Psychology
Subject_Description_4: This capstone course acts as the arch at the apex of the Politics and Public Policy major within the Bachelor of Government and International Relations, and associated degrees in which this major is offered. It draws together the knowledge students have gained from previous courses and also looks forward to the workplace. It will focus on both by considering theoretical approaches to problems and their practical solutions. Students will be expected to relate various issues to one another and to understand the implications of different policy approaches. The course will build on and further develop skills which will be useful in the workplace. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatibles: 3001PPP Cases in Public Policy
Subject_Description_5: This course provides students with an overview of the Australian legal system as it pertains to commerce and management. It also provides detailed knowledge in the area of contract law and a knowledge of the law as it applies to torts, particularly professional negligence and to partnership. Prerequisites: Successful completion of a minimum of 40 credit points of first year courses in the Program. Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: 2185AFE">2185AFE Introduction to Business Law, 2007GIR">2007GIR/2087GIR">2087GIR Legal Issues for Managers, 2010EHR">2010EHR Legal Issues for Managers. Students undertaking a Law Degree should make note that 2105AFE">2105AFE is incompatible with the LAW courses and they should seek further advice from the Law School if choosing an elective. NOTE: Students who are undertaking a Double Law degree are restricted from enrolling in either 2007GIR">2007GIR/2087GIR">2087GIR Legal Issues for Managers, 2010EHR">2010EHR Legal Issues for Managers or 2105AFE">2105AFE / 2185AFE">2185AFE Intro to Business Law as a GBS elective course.
Subject_Description_6: This course introduces students to a range of ideas and topics fundamental to the study of political science. These include the state, democracy, political ideology and political culture. It also introduces students to the methodology of political science, in particular the ability to undertake research, think critically and develop coherent, written arguments. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatibles: 1101PPP Introduction to Politics.
Subject_Description_7: This course provides knowledge and practice in the analytical, creative and strategic functions of marketing. The course presents a set of approaches and frameworks centred upon the "4Ps" (Product, Price, Place, and Promotion), to develop your competence to create a marketing plan, one of the major tools of business. Marketing starts with understanding consumer's preferences for products and services and attempts to satisfy their different wants and needs in a profitable manner. Prerequisites:NIL Co- requisites : NIL Incompatible: 1083MKT Introduction to Marketing, 1007IBA International Marketing
Subject_Description_8: Elections, politicians, the media, parliament: these are familiar and powerful features of everyday life in modern democracies. But how do they work? By comparing the experience of different countries, this course explores the ways in which institutions shape the choice and strategies of the various political actors. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatibles: 1102PPP Political Institutions.
Subject_Description_9: Note: This course is not offered from Trimester 2 2021. Check program requirements for details of alternative courses. The course introduces students to the basic concepts, techniques and principles of economics. It examines the role that economic factors can play in influencing business and government decision-making processes. This course serves as an introduction to economics. As such, it provides a foundation for further studies in economics and, more generally, in commerce, business, administration and management. In particular, it complements other courses in economics, accounting, finance, marketing and management that focus on how various business and government activities occur and interact. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: 1383AFE Economics for Decision Making 1 /1303AFE Economics for Managers/ 1002IBA Economics in Action
Subject_Description_10: This course addresses a number of fundamental questions relating to the nature of public policy process by examining a range of relevant concepts and theories, and evaluating their validity through an analysis of a number of specific policy areas. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatibles: 2003GIR Power and Policy Making, 2003PPP Public Policy Processes.
Subject_Description_11: The rise and fall of political parties and their leaders dominates public perceptions of politics but beneath this ephemeral froth and bubble lies the ongoing work of government. How does government fulfil its promises in a climate of reduced resources and heightened public expectations? This course examines the way in which governments use the public sector to provide vital services to the community and the ideas which underpin that work. The course traces the impact of ideas about the role of government, the exercise of authority and styles of management on public sector organisation and practice. The course sets the transformation of the Australian public sector from an old style bureaucracy into a contract or network state within the broader political environment. It is essential study for anyone considering a career in the public service, consultancy or business. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatibles: 2005GIR AND 2005PPP Politics of Public Management
Subject_Description_12: This course provides students with content related to organisations, people and employability and offers practical skills focusing on the development of employable skills whilst providing foundation knowledge of Employment Relations for their transition to and participation in the world of work. The course covers contemporary workplace issues from the employers and the employees perspective. Topics include, the changing nature of work and the contemporary workplace; managing people in organisations; developing employability skills, including professional values and social networking; workplace planning, recruitment and selection; training and talent development; performance in organisations; rewards and motivation; negotiation and communication and ethics in the workplace, in addition to the development of professional skills and awareness, industry knowledge and workplace readiness. Industry engagement will be a core strategy with video vignettes, guest speakers and case studies. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: 1001EHR Employment Relations/ 1081EHR Employment Relations/ EHR101 Employment Relations
Subject_Description_13: This course provides students with a general introduction to organisations and the functions of management. Topic areas will address issues related to organisations, management, and society. The course will cover the core management functions of leading, planning, controlling and organising. Prerequisites: Nil. Co-requisites: Nil. Incompatible: 1181IBA Management Concepts/ 1201HSL Management Concepts/ 1106HSL Leisure Management/ 2031HSV Working in Organisations.
Subject_Description_14: This course is designed to introduce students to the legal system and key aspects of business law that they are likely to encounter in their professional lives, especially as managers. In particular it examines the role of law and the courts, the decision-making process of the courts, the key features of the law of contract, the law relating to business associations and employment law (including workplace health & safety and anti-discrimination law). This course is offered: Gold Coast: Trimester 1 Day Nathan: Trimester 1 Night Incompatible: 2007GIR">2007GIR Legal Issues for Managers AND 2087GIR">2087GIR Legal Issues for Managers AND 2105AFE">2105AFE/2185AFE">2185AFE Introduction to Business Law AND 2007PPP">2007PPP/2087PPP">2087PPP Legal Issues for Managers. Those students who are undertaking a Double Law degree are restricted from enrolling in either 2007PPP">2007PPP/2087PPP">2087PPP/2087GIR">2087GIR/2007GIR">2007GIR/2010EHR Legal Issues for Managers or 2105AFE">2105AFE/2185AFE">2185AFE Intro to Business Law as a GBS elective course.
Subject_Description_15: Note: This course is not offered from Trimester 2 2021. Check program requirements for details of alternative courses. Accounting for Decision Making introduces the basic concepts and principles of accounting with an emphasis on the use of such concepts and principles in business decision-making. The emphasis is on the use of these accounting concepts and principles in business decision-making. It focuses on the practical and functional nature of business decisions from the perspective of financial accounting; managerial costing and budgetary policies; capital investments; and financing of business operations. You will become familiar with basic managerial accounting concepts such as budgeting, profit-planning, capital investments and working capital management. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites:NIL Incompatible: 1101AFE Accounting Principles,1182AFE Accounting for Decision Making
Subject_Description_16: Students in this course are introduced to the idea that there are many ways to identify and solve the complex problems faced by businesses today; hence business success hinges on the ability to think creatively and innovatively, combining knowledge from a variety of disciplines. To this end, the course introduces ideas/tools of creativity and entrepreneurialism and demonstrates how these ideas/tools are applied to a variety of situations through the use of case studies and guest lecturers. The discussion is set in the context of the current debate on what constitutes business success, how it is achieved, and how businesses are under "scrutiny" by the community at large to ensure that they behave and operate in responsible and sustainable manner. In this regard, the course also explores issues related to financial and non-financial reporting, governance framework, risk management, stakeholder and agency, policy and regulatory intervention, indigenous/herniate assets. Lectures will include guest lecturers and will cover a diverse range of topics such as marketing, current and new technologies, future world trends, legal issues, work force issues etc. Workshops will enable students to work on case studies that involve real problems sourced from industry clients and partners. Industry clients will be directly involved in the workshop and students required to present solutions to their problems at the end of the trimester.
Subject_Description_17: In an increasingly interconnected world, an understanding of Australian politics and economics and the business environment requires an appreciation of what is happening in the world outside Australia. The dual effects of globalisation and regionalisation profoundly affect Australia. Globalisation, the Asia-Pacific and Australia offers an introduction to globalisation, the political economy of the Asia-Pacific and their impact on Australia. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatibles: 1003IBA Globalisation Asia-Pacific & Australia AND PAC11 Globalisation the Asia-Pacific and Australia.
Subject_Description_18: In an increasingly complex financial system, and with an aging and longer living population, financial independence and effective financial decision making are seen as important life attributes and skills. The reality however is that many make poor financial decisions, fail to plan for their financial future, adequately protect themselves, their family and their assets, are easily influenced into poor/inappropriate financial products, and fall foul of schemes and scams. In other words there is low levels of financial literacy in the community, including in higher education graduates. A study of money and life will cover a range of content areas including planning and goal setting, behaviour and decision making, financial markets, services and products, rights and obligations under contracts, financial systems and household finances. This could also introduce fintech (including Bloomberg and the SSMIF). The course would provide a range of personal and professional development outcomes for students as well as improve their overall understanding of business. The course will be designed to be relevant for all students of the university and also has potential for development into a standalone credential/MOOC.
Subject_Description_19: This course introduces students to a perspective of the purpose of business that embeds values such as responsible leadership, integrity and ethical behaviour, respect for others, trust, and sustainable enterprise. The relevance of these values and their impact on behaviour and outcomes in a business context is demonstrated to students through case studies, real world examples, and testimonials from industry partners. Following from the discussion of values, the course then looks at how businesses develop solutions to respond to increasing demand for sustainability, transparency and good governance. The framework of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) is introduced and used to examine the alignment between business practices and sustainable solutions to real life problems faced by a business. The course also considers the role and responsibility (including legal) of professionals and professional standards in today's society.
Subject_Description_20: This course introduces students to major political philosophers in the tradition of western political thought. In examining the original works of thinkers from Plato to Marx, students have the opportunity to engage with their challenging ideas and thereby explore foundational political concepts, such as justice, power and liberty. Thoughtful engagement with these thinkers will also allow students to examine the dynamic relationship between political ideas and practice. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatibles: 1103GIR AND 1103PPP Political Ideas and Political Thought
Subject_Description_21: This course explores the future of work in a rapidly globalizing, knowledge and service-intensive economy. Advances in IT and associated technologies are enabling firms to automate and/or outsource routine work, displacing the jobs of low-skilled workers, while enhancing the power of knowledge workers. In parallel, new industries and forms of collaborative and distance-based work are emerging, offering new challenges and opportunities. This course investigates the causes of technological, industrial and organisational change and their potential impacts of work arrangements and stakeholder relationships. Strategies and policies for managing change and coping with the new world of work outlined, drawing on latest research from Australia and other countries. Students would investigate how the future of work affects the business landscape of both large companies and smaller firms. It would cover sources of value creation and the benefits and challenges of the new technologies. There will be an overview of IoT and futurist thinking and of selected technologies to examine how such digital innovations are being developed and used by leading organisations. Content will address the implications for managers of social media, big data, artificial intelligence and newer technological innovations.
Subject_Description_22: International Relations Theory focuses on the theoretical frameworks used to explain, interpret, critique and on rare occasions predict the outcomes of global political events and processes. Events may include the outbreak and cessation of armed conflict, humanitarian intervention, the establishment of international organisations, and responses to transnational threats and challenges such as climate change, refugee flows and pandemic diseases. Processes may include great power competition and rivalry, global economic integration and financial crises, patterns of development and poverty, migration patterns, and the transformation of the international order itself. Major theoretical approaches to be examined will include realism, which centres on power relations between states; liberal internationalism, which gives more emphasis to domestic politics and processes of mutually beneficial cooperation; and constructivism, which looks at the explanatory power of the norms and ideas at work in global politics. We will also consider a range of critical and post-structural approaches, which focus more on interpreting rather than seeking to explain global events and processes. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatibles: 3007IBA International Relations Theory.
Subject_Description_23: The discipline of International Relations (IR) is critical for understanding and explaining how the world operates today. Conflict, humanitarian disasters, terrorism, and large-scale human displacement are not historical events. How do states respond to these events? This introductory course is a study of war, peace, conflict, and diplomacy. In 1001GIR, students study the countries, the political events (i.e. World War II, Rwandan Genocide, Ebola Outbreak in West Africa), and the institutions (i.e. United Nations and the World Bank) that shape world affairs. Students will conduct simulations of diplomacy, trade negotiation, and conflict mediation during the course. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatibles: 1001IBA International Relations

Course: Bachelor of Communication and Journalism/Bachelor of Business
Description: With Griffith University's Bachelor of Communication and  Journalism/Bachelor of Business you can multiply your career options. In as little  as four years, you can graduate with two degrees and a unique skill set that  will give you an edge in the employment market. Developed in close consultation with industry, the Bachelor of  Communication and Journalism will produce communication specialists who  understand the diversity and complexity of the contemporary communication and  media landscape and are able to thrive within it. Specifically designed to respond to the demand for graduates who are  ready for the challenges and opportunities of next generation media and  associated industries, this degree will equip students with a comprehensive set  of advanced writing skills, multimedia production abilities, and the capacity  to think both laterally and creatively. Through the Bachelor of Business you will gain a solid foundation in all  aspects of business and develop an understanding of the social, cultural and  political dimensions of business. You will enhance this knowledge with further  expertise and experience in your areas of interests. Business majors Students can also choose not to complete a major, selecting from a range  of courses that provide broad knowledge for a career in business management.
Career_Outcomes:
Communication and Journalism
Occupations include: social media coordinator, community and stakeholder engagement officer, digital  marketing specialist, communications officer, events manager, social media  manager, public relations consultant, public relations professional, strategic  communications specialist, media liaison officer, campaign manager, media  analyst, promotions officer, copywriter, journalist, reporter, producer,  researcher, editor freelance writer, corporate promotions and communications. Business No major option
A business degree gives you the foundation to take your career  just about anywhere. You will be prepared to use your extensive business skills  in a range of increasingly diverse settings including not-for-profit, government and corporate organisations. Asian Business
  You will find career opportunities in government, businesses with overseas  profiles, international aid and other non-governmental organisations, news and  media organisations, and the education industry in Asia. Behavioural Science You will find career opportunities in government, private enterprise and not-for-profit organisations across various disciplines including marking and advertising, human services, healthcare, economics, policy development, research and evaluation of programs and services. Employment Relations
  You will be able to work as an employment relations manager or consultant, or  in roles dealing with workplace planning and policy, managerial strategy,  industrial advocacy, occupational health and safety, and workplace negotiation. Innovation and EntrepreneurshipAs a graduate of the Innovation and Entrepreneurship major, our courses highlight the ways you can create and develop innovative ideas that enable scale and societal impact. You will have an understanding of the entrepreneurial mindset, ways to identify or create opportunities and the strategic and operational issues in firm creation. Create your own career by starting your own lifestyle or high-potential startup, be entrepreneurial while working in a family business or being an intrapreneur within someone's business. Event Management
  You will be well prepared for an exciting career working for event and conference  organisers in the sport, tourism, marketing, media and cultural sectors as well  as coordinating and managing government event portfolios. Human Resource Management
  You will graduate with a degree recognised by the Australian Human Resources  Institute and be prepared for a career as a human resource manager or  consultant. Human resource professionals work in many sectors including  business management, counselling, workforce planning and policy, and recruiting  and training staff for the public and private sectors and non-government  organisations. International Business
  You will be prepared to work with international trade and investment  organisations or in the public and private sectors in management, strategic  planning, research, corporate government relations, global operations and  public relations.  Management
  Good managers are needed across all sectors and in businesses of all sizes.  With this qualification, you can apply your business management knowledge to an  area of personal interest and find work in roles as a business manager in human  resources, strategy, planning and policy, and training and development. Marketing
  You will be able to work in any industry or organisation that needs to promote  its products or services, including entertainment and fashion, tourism,  advertising, public relations, and business consulting. You might work as a  brand manager, marketing manager, advertising account manager, market research  analyst, public relations manager, or sales manager. Real Estate and Property Development
  The property sector is expanding in Australia and around the world, creating a  wide range of employment opportunities in the commercial, residential and  tourism sectors of the real estate and property management industries. You will  be prepared for a career in property finance, development and investment, real  estate agency management, project management, and marketing and promoting real estate. Sport Management
  Sport is big business. You will find opportunities in government departments,  local, national and international sporting clubs and event management  organisations. There are also positions in sport tourism, marketing, media and  athlete representation.  Tourism Management
  With this qualification, you could travel the world. Tourism managers are  employed by destination marketing organisations and all levels of government  throughout Australia and internationally. You will be able to work on major tourism infrastructure and planning projects, shaping the visitor experience in  tourism destinations.

To this end, the course introduces ideas/tools of creativity and entrepreneurialism and demonstrates how these ideas/tools are applied to a variety of situations through the use of case studies and guest lecturers. The discussion is set in the context of the current debate on what constitutes business success, how it is achieved, and how businesses are under "scrutiny" by the community at large to ensure that they behave and operate in responsible and sustainable manner. In this regard, the course also explores issues related to financial and non-financial reporting, governance framework, risk management, stakeholder and agency, policy and regulatory intervention, indigenous/herniate assets. Lectures will include guest lecturers and will cover a diverse range of topics such as marketing, current and new technologies, future world trends, legal issues, work force issues etc. Workshops will enable students to work on case studies that involve real problems sourced from industry clients and partners. Industry clients will be directly involved in the workshop and students required to present solutions to their problems at the end of the trimester.
Subject_Description_2: This course is designed to help students develop a practical and critical understanding of the communications process. The course introduces students to foundational communication techniques necessary to developing a broadcast voice, non-verbal communication and public 'performance' skills. The course explores the essential physical and vocal processes necessary in a range of journalism and strategic communication settings. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: NIL
Subject_Description_3: This course meets the challenges of the changing media landscape where innovation and entrepreneurship are becoming crucial to the way in which careers are built. Students become professionals engaging in forms of mobile journalism and communication, who are able to work effectively within established newsrooms, communication agencies and pop-up communication spaces.
Subject_Description_4: This course introduces beginning students to the pillars of Australian society, politics and power. It is designed especially, but not exclusively, for communications (PR) and journalism students who will regularly engage professionally with government, business and other powerful groups and figures throughout their careers. Where other introductory communications and journalism courses explore what questions to ask, this course identifies exactly to whom, and why, those questions should be put. Incompatible: 1509LHS Storytellers Toolkit; Prerequisites: NIL.
Subject_Description_6: This course provides an overview of legal constraints on public communication, along with an outline of law as it impacts on the Australian media and social media environment. Topics include free expression, open justice, defamation, contempt of court, publication restrictions, privacy, confidentiality, defamation, hate speech, national security laws and copyright within the context of an information society. It also addresses some key communication business laws affecting freelancers, public relations practitioners and new media entrepreneurs. INCOMPATIBLE: 2513HUM / 2513ART / 2012AMC Media Law; 4080LAW Media Law and Regulation; CMM26 Media Law (OUA Course Equivalent).
Subject_Description_7: This course canvasses the key thinkers and ideas that have established the disciplinary field of Communication, Media and Journalism Studies. This course will position students to both understand and enhance their practice via reflection on the scholarly insights of their chosen discipline. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: NIL
Subject_Description_8: Transdisciplinary groups of students work together to solve contemporary challenges in business with a focus on the Sustainability Development Goals in the Asia Pacific region, including first peoples. Students present solutions to real world problems by drawing on the knowledge they have developed throughout their foundation and majors. Students participate in simulations in addition to running a social enterprise or charity event. In addition, students will finalise their program e-portfolio's with evidence of their readiness for their chosen profession or career. Students will also collect and present final evidence of readiness through Griffith Graduate Attributes, Griffith Graduates of Influence and BusinessPlus credentials.
