Providing an 'in context' atmosphere requires professional behaviour, critical evaluation of work practices, communication with health professionals and the application of teamwork. Practical artistic skills are developed, improved and built on throughout this course. The course allows students to develop their time management and technical skills, while communicating with clinicians at the same time understanding the financial and operational nature of a dental laboratory. Real life real time learning maximises the learning opportunity to prepare the student beyond graduation. Students will have the opportunity to learn in the team environment. Pre-requisites: All year 2 courses must have been successfully completed prior to proceeding to year 3 courses AND students must have successfully completed all trimester 1 courses prior to enrolling in this course.
Subject_Description_8: This course is the practical component of removable partial prosthodontics in which students put into practice knowledge gained in prosthetic technology 3 during the construction of removable partial dentures. This course also gives students an opportunity to improve on the practical skills gained in previous courses. The work integrated learning aspect of the course enables students to develop and utilise skills acquired in a commercial laboratory setting. Pre-requisite: All year 1 courses must have been successfully completed prior to proceeding to year 2 courses. Co-requisite: 2203DOH and 2205DOH must be studied simultaneously.
Subject_Description_9: Comprehensive Prosthetics provides students with knowledge of infection control, the promotion of oral health at the individual, group and community levels, communication skills, treatment planning, patient management, medical conditions, medical emergencies, dental anomalies, dental occlusion, prosthetic problem solving, and preventative dentistry. Students will develop knowledge of oral diagnosis, oral diseases and their prevention, implant retained dentures, the use of dental materials, team work, and radiology. Furthermore, students will obtain knowledge in the areas of oral pathology, oral medicine, and removable prosthodontics. They will apply theoretical skills in all facets of removable prosthetics in clinical and laboratory situations. Treatment planning skills will be developed as a natural extension of all the theoretical knowledge and practical skills gained. Pre-requisite: Students must have successfully completed all preceding year courses to progress to the final year and students must have successfully completed 3055DOH">3055DOH_Y1 in the current year to progress to 3055DOH">3055DOH_Y2.
Subject_Description_10: Language and Communication for Health is offered to students from a non-English speaking background (NESB). Students whose first language is English are NOT PERMITTED to undertake this course. The aim of this course is to introduce students to the language, knowledge and communication skills required for study and practice in their discipline. A further aim is to develop and practice English language skills relevant to the academic culture of Australian universities. It therefore involves intensive English language practice and language immersion activities, with elements applied to contextualised, discipline-specific settings. This course constitutes part of the overall English Language Enhancement Strategy at Griffith University. Prerequisites: NIL; Incompatible: 5901LHS/5901LAL, 5903LHS/5903LAL, 5904LHS/5904LAL and 5902LAL.
Subject_Description_11: This course provides dental hygiene, technology and prosthetic students with knowledge of anatomy, histology and embryology of the mouth, head and neck region. It covers the macroscopic and microscopic anatomy of the dentition, jaws, oral cavity, salivary glands, tongue and temporomandibular joint. Pre-requisites: 1018DOH Oral Biology 1, 1006MSC Fundamentals of Anatomy and Physiology. All year 1 courses must be successfully completed prior to proceeding to year 2 courses.
Subject_Description_12: Prosthetic Technology 3 further develops students' knowledge in removable prosthodontics. This course is integral to the design, biomechanics and functions of removable partial dentures. The principles of design learned in this course will be applied in Laboratory Practicum 3. Pre-requisite: All year 1 courses must have been successfully completed prior to proceeding to year 2 courses. Co-requisite: 2203DOH and 2205DOH must be studied simultaneously.
Subject_Description_13: This course introduces the concepts of entrepreneurship and the development of small health business practices. A summary of the essentials for small business success is presented with the necessary activities involved in getting a new business started as a series of stages. The basics of planning and managing the four key resources and areas of activity found in all small enterprises - marketing and sales, finance, operations and human resources - are presented. Finally, management of small business growth and change is explained. Course Restricted: Not available to first year students.
Subject_Description_14: Comprehensive Prosthetics provides students with knowledge of infection control, the promotion of oral health at the individual, group and community levels, communication skills, treatment planning, patient management, medical conditions, medical emergencies, dental anomalies, dental occlusion, prosthetic problem solving, and preventative dentistry. Students will develop knowledge of oral diagnosis, oral diseases and their prevention, implant retained dentures, the use of dental materials, team work, and radiology. Furthermore, students will obtain knowledge in the areas of oral pathology, oral medicine, and removable prosthodontics. They will apply theoretical skills in all facets of removable prosthetics in clinical and laboratory situations. Treatment planning skills will be developed as a natural extension of all the theoretical knowledge and practical skills gained. Pre-requisite: Students must have successfully completed all preceding year courses to progress to the final year.
Subject_Description_15: This is an introductory pharmacology course on the basic principles influencing drug action in the human body. The content delivered in this course has specific relevance to drugs associated with dental care. Students are only permitted to enrol in this course in the specified year of their program structure.
Subject_Description_16: This course introduces the practical application of dental technology and its relationship to dentistry and oral health. This course allows students time to develop and craft their skills in the precise technical application of design and construction of removable oral prostheses and appliances. It provides students with the opportunity to develop dexterity, hand-eye coordination and pay attention to details using the skills gained in the Laboratory Materials courses. Students will also have the opportunity to improve their skills within a commercial laboratory setting at the Griffith University Dental Clinic and on work placement. All year 1 courses must be successfully completed prior to proceeding to year 2 courses.
Subject_Description_17: This course introduces students to the professional practice of dental technology. Students will study the clinical and technical principles behind the design and fabrication of removable prosthodontics and associated components. It will include theory on occlusion, workplace health and safety, ethics, infection control, care of equipment and efficient use of materials will be included as underlying principles of laboratory practice. All year 1 courses must be successfully completed prior to proceeding to year 2 courses.
Subject_Description_18: This course introduces the student to the practical applications of orthodontic and orthopaedic appliances. It also introduces students to the fundamentals of removable partial acrylic dentures. Students will extend on the foundation skills and knowledge gained in the Laboratory Practicum 1 and Laboratory Materials. This course gives students ample time and opportunity to develop and craft their skills in the manufacture/construction of thermoformed materials, acrylics and the application of metal componentry. Giving the student an opportunity to further develop their level of accuracy and speed using the skills gained in the Laboratory Practicum courses as well as apply knowledge gained in the Prosthetic Technology courses. Students will have an opportunity to begin work integrated learning activities within a commercial laboratory setting at the Griffith University Dental Clinic. Pre-requisite: All year 1 courses must have been successfully completed prior to proceeding to year 2 courses. Co-requisite: 2202DOH and 2204DOH must be studied simultaneously.
Subject_Description_19: This course focuses on fixed prosthodontics and continues the development of the student's theoretical knowledge from Prosthetic Technology 1, 2 and 3. It develops students' theoretical knowledge they require to construct fixed prostheses required to restore and/or improve the aesthetics and functions of the oral cavity. Pre-requisite: All year 2 courses must have been successfully completed prior to proceeding to year 3 courses. Co-requisite: 3031DOH and 3032DOH must be studied simultaneously.
Subject_Description_20: This course prepares graduates across health professions to provide culturally safe health services to Australia's First Peoples. Through the enhancement of the previously introduced capabilities of respect, communication, safety and quality, critical reflection, and advocacy students will be supported to apply these capabilities in First Peoples' health contexts to engender the development of cultural capabilities that reflect a lifelong journey and are tested in every interaction. The course takes a holistic perspective to engage students in exploring the historical, socio-cultural, political and dominant cultural paradigms that influence First Peoples' health today. The First Peoples' Health and Practice course supports students to meet the Griffith University Graduate Attribute E.1 Awareness of and respect for the values and knowledge of Australian Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander First Peoples and to meet the requirements of the relevant professional body's competency standards and codes of professional conduct to provide culturally safe care. Pre-requisite: Students must have successfully completed at least 80CP of undergraduate study. This requirement will be strictly enforced.
Subject_Description_21: Integration of human body structure (Anatomy) and maintenance of healthy function (Physiology) is fundamental biological knowledge, relevant and applied by many health and allied health professions. This comprehensive introductory course facilitates student exploration of each body system through lectures, laboratory classes and on-line resources. Incompatible: 1016MSC Anatomy and Physiology Systems 1; 1017MSC Anatomy and Physiology Systems 2; 1001NSC Human Pre-requisites: None

Description: This program will not be offered in Trimester 3, 2020. The next intake for commencing students will be Trimester 1, 2021. This double degree enables students to combine business management skills with a studio major, developing core competencies such as critical and analytical thinking, business communication and decision-making. The Design program prepares graduates for diverse professional practice as designers through practical and theoretical learning. The first year focuses on the development of manual and technological skills, design thinking, problem-defining and solving. Students will gain an understanding of the changing role of design and how they can become leaders in the industry. In the following years, students work on industry-related and research projects and specialise in selected studio areas. Graduates are skilled in creative design and software application and are able to effectively and efficiently manage creative ventures from a business perspective. Design majors Business majors Students can also choose not to complete a major, selecting from a range of courses that provide broad knowledge for a career in business management.
Career_Outcomes: You will be prepared for work in graphic design, interior design, product design, digital web design, design management, design education, theatre, Furniture design, and Digital media,You will find opportunities in graphic design, interior design, product design, digital web design, design management, design education, film and television, theatre, furniture design, digital media, business development, business management, marketing and sales, market research, government.
Subject_Description_1: This course critiques current construction methods, processes, and material use in commercial and residential construction through the design and construction. You will critically analyse and compare cases and redesign to meet green-star rated sustainable practices. Industry professionals will introduce building/interior construction methods and technical criteria for selection and specification of fixtures and finishes.
Subject_Description_2: This course provides students with an understanding of the theories, principals and concepts of virtual three dimensional space, and the use of human and digital tools to imagine, design and construct effective 3D forms in virtual environments. Students will gain knowledge of the history of 3D systems, from creative sculpture to scientific scanning/information capture, as well as the potential influence these forms have on human experience. Students will develop an understanding of differing approaches to the design of 3D form such as, polygonal, solid & organic modelling). The application of digital modelling, and links to a number of other fields, including design for applied uses in architecture, health, entertainment are explored during the course.
Subject_Description_3: Whilst 3D designers are focused on object outcomes, good design is situational. This course introduces the student to more complex problems, such as design meets disability, or large scale projects where outcomes may require design research, design process and practice with a transdisciplinary approach.
Subject_Description_4: This third year course builds on previous courses to develop an advanced level of theoretical knowledge and practical understanding of typographic design. Curriculum departs from the traditional typographic discourse of form and function and encourages students to consider their work through the lens of form and content. Engaging with experimental and rhetorical approaches to typography, students explore their own position and practice in relation to the overall context of intended (and unintended) audiences, subject matters, social environments, and available media. PREREQUISITES: 2681QCA Typography and Print and 2682QCA Typography and Expression or equivalents.
Subject_Description_5: In an increasingly complex financial system, and with an aging and longer living population, financial independence and effective financial decision making are seen as important life attributes and skills. The reality however is that many make poor financial decisions, fail to plan for their financial future, adequately protect themselves, their family and their assets, are easily influenced into poor/inappropriate financial products, and fall foul of schemes and scams. In other words there is low levels of financial literacy in the community, including in higher education graduates. A study of money and life will cover a range of content areas including planning and goal setting, behaviour and decision making, financial markets, services and products, rights and obligations under contracts, financial systems and household finances. This could also introduce fintech (including Bloomberg and the SSMIF). The course would provide a range of personal and professional development outcomes for students as well as improve their overall understanding of business. The course will be designed to be relevant for all students of the university and also has potential for development into a standalone credential/MOOC.
Subject_or_Unit_6: LANGUAGE AND COMMUNICATION FOR ARTS AND SOCIAL SCIENCES
Subject_Description_6: Language and Communication for Arts and Social Sciences is offered to students from a non-English speaking background (NESB). Students whose first language is English are NOT PERMITTED to undertake this course. The aim of this course is to introduce students to the language, knowledge and communication skills required for study and practice in their discipline. A further aim is to develop and practice English language skills relevant to the academic culture of Australian universities. It therefore involves intensive English language practice and language immersion activities, with elements applied to contextualised, discipline-specific settings. This course constitutes part of the overall English Language Enhancement Strategy at Griffith University. Prerequisites: NIL; Incompatible: 5901LHS/5901LAL, 5902LHS/5902LAL, 5903LHS/5903LAL, 5904LAL and 1019LHS.
Subject_Description_7: Transdisciplinary groups of students work together to solve contemporary challenges in business with a focus on the Sustainability Development Goals in the Asia Pacific region, including first peoples. Students present solutions to real world problems by drawing on the knowledge they have developed throughout their foundation and majors. Students participate in simulations in addition to running a social enterprise or charity event. In addition, students will finalise their program e-portfolio's with evidence of their readiness for their chosen profession or career. Students will also collect and present final evidence of readiness through Griffith Graduate Attributes, Griffith Graduates of Influence and BusinessPlus credentials.
Subject_Description_8: This course introduces designing for 3D printing. This practical course introduces students to key stages of the design development process and human centred design strategies, identifying user behaviours and needs in the development of niche products. Fundamental skills are developed in the design and preparation of digital files, to create resolved 3D printed prototypes.
Subject_Description_9: This course explores the power of motion, in the form of animation in three-dimensional spatial environments, as a tool in presenting both information and narrative for human viewers. The principals of the human sensory system are covered to gain an understanding of how movement, and animation, can be used to enhance the ability to convey knowledge, immersion and understanding to the viewer. Students will gain both a theoretical understanding of the history, principals, mechanics and human interpretation of motion & animation, and will also gain practical skills in the production and presentation of 3D animated content.
Subject_Description_10: Visual communication is a powerful force to drive new ideas, and obtaining access to the tools that 'make media' is an integral part of a perpetually changing world. It has the power to influence society (think: body image, sexualised imagery, consumerism) and environment (think: greenwashing, property development, transport industries) and culture (think: political campaigns, volunteerism, social media).
Subject_Description_11: The purpose of this course is to prepare students for employment by introducing them to the role of effective interpersonal communication, business communication, management, business principles, ethics, and professional association within contemporary contexts. This course explores the major professional issues arising from the widespread use of digital media and highlights dilemmas that may be faced by creative media practitioners. By providing the fundamentals of professionalism, this course aims to make students 'job ready'.
Subject_Description_12: Theory, research methods and design practice will integrate together as solution focused 'praxis' in this capstone course. Students will combine their discipline specific technical and procedural skills with a range of design research methods and procedures, to ideate, plan design, project manage and produce a creative, human focused solution to a specified problem. Students can choose to work independently or in a team. However, each student will be assessed individually. It is expected that the design outcomes will represent each student's potential as an emerging design professional. Pre requisites: Must have completed all 1st year and 2nd year courses.
Subject_Description_13: During this course students will explore the technical, social and ethical dimensions of producing and curating content online. Specific attention will be paid to understanding varying modalities of communication (production, dissemination, consumption) and related impacts for creative arts and design disciplines.
Subject_Description_14: This course expands on the student's understanding of design processes and further explores how people inhabit, interact with and transform interior environments. Systematic approaches to interior design are investigated and applied to a range of design problems requiring interior solutions
Subject_Description_15: This course introduces fundamental precepts of communicating ideas and information, such as grid systems, semiotic analysis and visual hierarchy, as well as typographic knowledge and skills within wider social and cultural contexts. Students are expected to respond through research-based creative studio activity in a timely and professional way and at a level which shows a sophistication of type handling. The course will develop a social and historical framework of typography through Roman lettering, the introduction of moveable type, and the subsequent history of printing.
Subject_Description_16: This course will explore some of the methods, principles, processes and theories that makes design a special form of human inquiry. From analysis to synthesis, students will apply their understanding of 2 and 3 dimensional space through a series of linked, practical exercises, active visual experimentation and resolved production. Through 'praxis', i.e. the convergence of theory and practice, students will apply their understanding of design to real outcomes.
Subject_Description_17: This course covers the field of immersive environments as applied for use in visualization (architectural, 3D, health), reconstruction (archaeology, criminology) and learning (gameplay, education). The application of computer game systems, to create immersive experiences is explored with students gaining knowledge in the theory of immersive design, its history, human physiology and the science behind the technologies that make immersive systems work. Students will develop both skills and a deeper understanding, in the creative design and practical development of strong immersive experiences with digital visualization tools (eg. game engines, VR and AR).
Subject_Description_18: This first-year course critically examines design history and theory. Design history, in its traditional form, focuses on design movements, designers and the materiality of the design object and the ways in which it connects to production and consumption, integrated into circulated systems of meaning. The course distinguishes between the concepts and historical figures of the past to frame and inform the key themes influencing art and design theory, practice and culture today and in the future. The relation between design and its place in history, why the designer needs such knowledge and how they need to employ it in future practice will be examined.
Subject_Description_19: This course emphasises integrating creative and imaginative applications of design and communication processes to contemporary graphic design problems. Wherever possible, industry-based projects are undertaken and students are expected to apply a professional code of ethics to all activities, to solve complex and demanding problems within fixed deadlines, and present work in a professional manner. Assessment is studio-project based. This course reconceptualises design as a profession through broader social, cultural, political, and economic contextualisation. What is design practice and what kind of practices exist? Students explore the friction between different commercial and social visual communication practice-based cultures with the aim of reforming design practice.
Subject_Description_20: This course provides students with an introduction to leading concepts of sustainability (ecological worldview, circular design, bio-inspired design, biophilia) and their application to Interior/Spatial Design. Students will be trained to become ecological design thinkers who can integrate sustainability into their conceptual and practical processes.
Subject_Description_21: This course concentrates on communication design issues relating to interior environments to provide an expansive and critical understanding. This includes a number of approaches to space problem-solving that provide both logical as well as intuitive ways of arriving at solutions to design problems. The ability to select appropriate strategies is as important as the ability to apply those strategies. An essential and deeper knowledge of techniques and process associated with the production of space is taught. The course continues to embrace sustainable design practices but also goes beyond them. Students will further analyse design problems and develop and apply sustainability principles and solutions to interior environment design projects.
Subject_Description_22: Digital Designer Maker: Designing for local studio batch production using digital fabrication to increase design opportunities and efficiencies allows designers to explore creating objects that have valued connections to people, communities and place. This timber-based unit considers the environmental and social impact of technology in design, both positive and negative, in the local context. Connection to community, changing production patterns, re-localisation of production, distributed manufacturing, embodied energy, renewable materials, and value-adding processes are fundamental to the course. Local studio designer makers are involved in the course and students are expected to have practical invested design outcomes, such as digitally fabricated furniture.
Subject_Description_23: This course introduces students to leading edge and experimental design practices, particularly looking at procedural and generative design systems. Students will gain knowledge of node based or visual programming systems within three-dimensional virtual environments using parametric workflows, standard and bespoke modifiers. They will also be introduced to the principals of fractal complexity and how the generation of procedural form can apply to human experience. During this process they will develop knowledge and practical skills in the methodologies used in experimental design practice and the application of experimental systems. Students in this course will become emerging professionals at the leading edge of generative design practice.
Subject_Description_24: The aim of the course is to explain the way people behave and make decisions in a business environment and the role that information has in the context of decision-making. The course will introduce some elements of behavioural sciences and game theory applied to business problems. It will also tackle some of the critical questions around the use of information for business decision making: how to assess the validity/reliability and relevance of the information we receive? how to use it effectively? how to simplify information, make it relevant, and present it to different audiences? The course combines different aspects. First, it encourages students to account for the psychological, cognitive, emotional, cultural, and social factors that affects decisions made by individuals and organisations (e.g. private corporates, government, civil society, etc). Second it provides simple analytical tools to contextualise strategic decision-making in real world situations through lenses such as that of the consumer and the future role of social marketing. Third, it introduces students to the idea that business decision making requires reliable, timely information. The course takes a positive (as opposed to normative) approach to the analysis of interactive strategic decisions and behaviours. Through case studies, the course provides a description of what happens in a variety of business situations, with a focus on understanding the elements/dynamics that leads to a certain outcome of decision. In so doing, the course helps students identify the role of information (qualitative or quantitative), how it is sourced and assessed in terms of its validity/quality, and how it can be used to deal with uncertainty in decision-making. Basic approaches to the analysis, interpretation and presentation of various types of information are also discussed, including the foundations of big data analytics and qualitative data analysis.
Subject_Description_25: This course concentrates on the graphic aspects of visual communication design to provide an expansive and critical understanding of this discipline and its social context. It includes a number of approaches to visual problem solving that provide both logical as well as intuitive ways of arriving at solutions to design problems. The ability to select appropriate strategies is as important as the ability to apply those strategies. The course continues to embrace sustainable design practice but now begins to go beyond them. Students will further analyse design problems and develop and apply sustainability principles and solutions to communication design projects.
Subject_Description_26: This course emphasises integrating creative and imaginative applications of the design and communication processes to contemporary interior environment design problems. Wherever possible, industry-based projects are undertaken and students are expected to apply a professional code of ethics to all activities. They are expected to solve complex and demanding problems within fixed deadlines and present work in a professional manner. Assessment is studio-project based. Wherever possible, assessable items are required to comply with the Design Futuring principles and students are encouraged to see design as a profession through broader social, cultural, political, and economic contextualisation.
Subject_Description_27: How does research feed into design practice? This first-year course investigates how creative research methodologies are used to support and inform the design process. Design research explores issues in a focused and systematic way to arrive at new insights in an ever-changing world.
Subject_Description_28: Design Lab Practice is a core capstone interdisciplinary course for Bachelor of Design and Bachelor of Interactive Media students. Students undertake design research and practice in a team based interdisciplinary environment and within a critical context of socially engaged and sustainable futures. Through strategic and relational thinking, reflection, creation and writing, students practice proficiency in multiple design processes towards a formal grant style submission of their design ideas. In this, students build graduate work-readiness through learning real-world project operational systems.
Subject_Description_29: This course provides an introduction to the fundamental elements and principles of all Art and Design Practices, and cements a platform of visual literacy encompassing perceptual, analytical and expressive skills. The focus of the course is using the two dimensional image as a primary instrument of creative expression, problem solving and communication. This course is a component of the foundation program for the Bachelor of Design and the Bachelor of Architectural Design, and has been designed as a core study to complement activities in both disciplines. This course is incompatible with 1603QCA.
Subject_Description_30: This is an intermediate course that gives students a firm basis for refining their typographic knowledge and skills. This course develops a critical awareness to provide effective expression of meaning through the visible word, which in turn demands an understanding of content and constant attention to detail. The aim is to produce outcomes of a high technical and aesthetic standard through concentrating on the thoughtful combination of word and image. The primary objective of this course is to further prepare students with the technical and cognitive competencies that enable them to deal effectively and professionally with visual communication design problems and prepare sophisticated type outcomes for print.
Subject_Description_31: This course introduces designing for 3D printing. This practical course introduces students to key stages of the design development process and human centred design strategies, identifying user behaviours and needs in the development of niche products. Fundamental skills are developed in the design and preparation of digital files, to create resolved 3D printed prototypes.
Subject_Description_32: This course addresses the diverse and rapidly evolving nature of lens-based digital imagery as a discipline. As an introduction to these processes, both existing and emerging, the course is designed to develop, support and enhance creative practice. Conceptual sophistication and technical aptitude in this area are highly valuable qualities in terms of the potential that they afford us in the creation, documentation and dissemination of visual ideas.
Subject_Description_33: Through the exploration of space, and its design and impact on human interaction, human response and reaction to space, students will apply the principles of design for interior and environmental spaces and develop design communication techniques such as rapid visualisation, drafting, presentation skills and model making. Students will explore the field through theories of interaction which inform practice, studio practice and workshops modelling working in multi-disciplinary companies in fields such as design and construction, retail, games and virtual environments, stage, theatre and exhibitions.
Subject_Description_34: This course extends on industry standard design and parametric solid modelling techniques with a focus on ergonomics and user centred design outcomes. Students develop competencies in complex part, assembly and drawing development including physical dynamics, surfacing, performance enhanced component assembly, applied problem solving with geometric & mathematical dimension relationships, detailed drawing and file management to prepare you for an international working environment. Pre-requisite: 2639QCA - Digital Modelling for Design
Subject_Description_35: This course introduces students to a perspective of the purpose of business that embeds values such as responsible leadership, integrity and ethical behaviour, respect for others, trust, and sustainable enterprise. The relevance of these values and their impact on behaviour and outcomes in a business context is demonstrated to students through case studies, real world examples, and testimonials from industry partners. Following from the discussion of values, the course then looks at how businesses develop solutions to respond to increasing demand for sustainability, transparency and good governance. The framework of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) is introduced and used to examine the alignment between business practices and sustainable solutions to real life problems faced by a business. The course also considers the role and responsibility (including legal) of professionals and professional standards in today's society.
Subject_Description_36: Students in this course are introduced to the idea that there are many ways to identify and solve the complex problems faced by businesses today; hence business success hinges on the ability to think creatively and innovatively, combining knowledge from a variety of disciplines. To this end, the course introduces ideas/tools of creativity and entrepreneurialism and demonstrates how these ideas/tools are applied to a variety of situations through the use of case studies and guest lecturers. The discussion is set in the context of the current debate on what constitutes business success, how it is achieved, and how businesses are under "scrutiny" by the community at large to ensure that they behave and operate in responsible and sustainable manner. In this regard, the course also explores issues related to financial and non-financial reporting, governance framework, risk management, stakeholder and agency, policy and regulatory intervention, indigenous/herniate assets. Lectures will include guest lecturers and will cover a diverse range of topics such as marketing, current and new technologies, future world trends, legal issues, work force issues etc. Workshops will enable students to work on case studies that involve real problems sourced from industry clients and partners. Industry clients will be directly involved in the workshop and students required to present solutions to their problems at the end of the trimester.
Subject_Description_37: This course explores the future of work in a rapidly globalizing, knowledge and service-intensive economy. Advances in IT and associated technologies are enabling firms to automate and/or outsource routine work, displacing the jobs of low-skilled workers, while enhancing the power of knowledge workers. In parallel, new industries and forms of collaborative and distance-based work are emerging, offering new challenges and opportunities. This course investigates the causes of technological, industrial and organisational change and their potential impacts of work arrangements and stakeholder relationships. Strategies and policies for managing change and coping with the new world of work outlined, drawing on latest research from Australia and other countries. Students would investigate how the future of work affects the business landscape of both large companies and smaller firms. It would cover sources of value creation and the benefits and challenges of the new technologies. There will be an overview of IoT and futurist thinking and of selected technologies to examine how such digital innovations are being developed and used by leading organisations. Content will address the implications for managers of social media, big data, artificial intelligence and newer technological innovations.
Subject_Description_38: Australia is geographically situated in the Asia Pacific region, but retains strong cultural links to the Western world. Asia is a community of diverse nations and cultures formed over the millennia. In times of boom and gloom Asian nations and their peoples have exemplified resilience and leadership. This course is designed to engage students in the diverse world of Asian history, culture, business, politics, religion, art and beliefs to develop an appreciation of our near neighbours. It examines the influences of the past and current relationships before delving into the future of the Fourth Industrial Revolution and the potential consequences for the region. The course also looks at how Asia is likely to change over the next 10 to 20 years (e.g. growth of India, evolving role of China, the role of Europe and North America). The Asia region is also a likely constant in all students' future careers and many employers desire a level of Asian literacy in their elite workforce. This course is designed to satisfy that requirement and assist students with employability strategies.
Subject_Description_39: This course introduces students to the fundamental precepts of product design. Building on the introduction to design process in the first year, students have the opportunity to develop their approach to design, their particular interests and focus and the skills to support the resolution of a design idea. The creation of object outcomes using advanced technologies is supported in this course, and the contrast between conventional technology and advanced technology, and designing and specifying for both are explored.
Subject_Description_40: This course enables students to explore the boundaries between reality and virtual space through an understanding of spatial and photorealistic visualization. The course expands upon prior skills in computer aided design in reference to design approaches and principals for objects, structures, interior spaces, and products, inclusive of detailed components. Students will develop methods of design for 3D visualized forms from architectural and scientific reference plans and engineered processes. Visualization is explored through students gaining a deep knowledge of light and material and the correspondence of the real world to virtual environments. A strong knowledge of the science and technology behind rendering systems is developed, particularly how to apply materials and lighting for the purpose of rendering to photo-realistic quality for presentation.

Description: This double degree gives you two clear career pathways. As a graduate, you may choose to be a qualified commercial pilot with engineering qualifications, knowing that airlines prefer their pilots to have an engineering qualification. Or, you could choose to be an engineer with flight qualifications, recognising that engineering companies building aircraft or aviation systems prefer flight-qualified engineers. To become flight-qualified, you must complete the Graduate Diploma of Flight Management (GDFM). It's achievable through this unique degree that combines the Electronic Engineering or Mechanical Engineering major in the Bachelor of Engineering (Honours) with the core requirements of the Bachelor of Aviation, which includes the theoretical component of flight training.  In aviation and engineering, building a professional network and proving your competency in the workplace is a crucial first step in your career. At Griffith, our aviation and engineering schools are well-connected with industry, so we can help our students get a foot in the door through work-integrated learning. You'll undertake a full trimester (full-time) engineering placement with a company in the aviation space, working on a live engineering project that will allow you to put your new knowledge into practice working within a high-achieving, multi-disciplinary team. That's in addition to the many opportunities we provide our students each year to participate in field trips to engineering companies, where you can meet experienced professionals and be inspired.  As a graduate, you'll be qualified as an electronics or mechanical engineer and will have completed the full theory component for your commercial pilot's licence. This is an amazing opportunity to pursue a career as a pilot through further training or to become a highly qualified engineer in the aviation industry.  Engineering Tailor your timetable - Even if you study full-time on-campus, you may still be able to customise your degree to suit your needs. From a range of tutorial times to online access to lectures and other course material, we're here to help you fit study in with your work and life commitments.  Students may be eligible to do an international field trip, organised by the academic staff. This may count towards a component of the degree, depending on its structure.
Career_Outcomes: *Source: Australian Government Job Outlook
Subject_Description_1: This course provides engineering and architecture students with an overview of the principles, skills and techniques required for the evaluation, planning, and management of projects from inception through to completion.
Subject_Description_2: This course incorporates the principles of work integrated learning through exposure to professional engineering practice, undertaken either with an industry partner or at the university. The course allows students to further develop advanced skills in the theory and application of professional aspects of modern engineering practice. This course integrates your professional practice learnings embedded within the engineering degree program with the professional competencies you have achieved during your program. A co requisite of this course is the completion of a minimum of 12 weeks (60 days) of approved experience in an engineering practice environment (or a satisfactory alternative).
Subject_Description_3: The course considers the fundamental properties of metals and non-metallic materials. Students are introduced to the atomic and microstructure of materials and their relationship to mechanical and electrical properties. The course explores the mechanical concepts of stress, strain, elongation and material failure (including testing) and the phenomenon of electrical conduction. This course will be offered from 2017 in trimester 1 and 3, and replaces 1502ENG.
Subject_Description_4: This course introduces students to the basic concepts and principles of thermodynamics, and its selected engineering applications. Topics include the first law of thermodynamics, volumetric properties of pure substances, heat effects, the second law of thermodynamics, thermodynamic properties of fluids, and thermodynamic analysis of processes.
Subject_Description_5: The Thesis is undertaken in the final trimester. Students are required to plan, execute and report on a research project with some independence while working with an academic supervisor who maintains regular contact and provides support and direction in the design and execution of the research. Projects based on industry requirements will be encouraged.
Subject_Description_6: This course covers the theory of Navigation under the Visual Flight Rules (VFR) in accordance with the CASA CPL Navigation syllabus. Note: Incompatible with 2508BPS/2508NCS Navigation
Subject_Description_7: Kinematics & Dynamics equips graduates with a solid understanding of the key concepts of mechanics required for design and analysis of mechanisms and mechanical devices. Topics covered include kinematics and dynamics of mechanical components modelled as particles and plane rigid bodies, interconnected objects, rotational dynamics, work and energy methods, translating and rotating coordinate systems, vector methods, three-dimensional dynamics of rigid bodies and an introduction to vibration Please check the "assumed knowledge" for this course under the course profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. This course is planned to be offered for the first time in 2018, trimester 1 and replaces 3317ENG.
Subject_Description_8: "Flight Procedures" is a workshop style course series, where students implement aviation theory and regulatory rules in a simulation laboratory environment. Flight Procedures II uses the Cessna 182RG software to introduce the constant speed propeller, retractable landing gear and glass cockpit design features initially, before exploring Instrument Flight Rules and procedures based on the Private Instrument Rating - all without any weather issues. We cover Instrument Flight Rules and associated Standard Operating Procedures ending with 2D non-precision approaches. Prerequisite: 1505NSC Flight Procedures I
Subject_Description_9: This course covers fundamental electromagnetic theory including Electrostatics, Magnetostatics, Electromagnetic Induction, Electromagnetic Radiation, Properties of Matter and finally finishing with Maxwell's equations. This basic theory is then used to explore the principles of propagation on guided media such as cables and waveguides. Basic principles such as the Telegraph equations lead to characteristic impedance, reflection and transmission coefficient, standing and travelling waves. Simple modes in rectangular and circular waveguides are examined and fundamental dispersion issues are addressed. Smith charts are used as a calculation tool for transmission problems and numerous matching and coupling problems are attempted. A series of laboratories explore measurements of signals and fields on simple systems.
Subject_Description_10: This course provides the fundamental knowledge of fluid mechanics and hydraulics including fluid properties, fluid statics, conservation of mass, energy equation, flow in conduits, pumps and turbines, flow around objects, open channel flow and compressible flow.
Subject_Description_11: This course introduces students to the programming and interfacing of a modern microprocessor. The course outlines the theory behind microprocessors, with a focus on architecture, memory structures, and peripheral interfacing. The course also involves an insight into programming methodologies in assembler and illustrates ways of successfully debugging embedded systems. The course will give the student the background knowledge to successfully develop an embedded system using any microprocessor. The course is highly practical in approach and covers such areas as data acquisition, sensor interfacing, electronic control, and microprocessor communication protocols. Incompatible: 2010MEE Microprocessor Techniques AND 1073ENG Microprocessors AND 3323ENG MicroController Techniques
Subject_Description_12: This experiential learning based course introduces the natural and physical sciences that underpin the practice of engineering. Through projects students will apply science fundamentals to the systematic investigation, interpretation, and analysis of some engineering problems. Topics covered include Newtonian mechanics and electrical principles. Incompatible: 1031SCG (Physics IA).
Subject_or_Unit_13: AIRCRAFT OPERATIONS, PERFORMANCE AND PLANNING PART I
Subject_Description_13: The course content covers the key areas of; aerodromes and aeroplane landing areas, take off, climb, en route, descent and landing performance; pre-flight and in-flight operational considerations; aeroplane loading; airworthiness and equipment requirements; flight rules and procedures. The course is covered in sufficient depth to enable students with limited flying experience or aviation industry exposure to grasp the fundamentals of aeroplane operation, performance and planning in accordance with the CASA CPL Operations, Performance and Planning syllabus. Incompatible with: 2510BPS/2510NSC Light Aircraft Operations, Performance and Planning
Subject_Description_14: The course introduces students to aerodynamics associated with small fixed-wing aircraft in sufficient depth to enable students to demonstrate their knowledge in subsonic aerodynamics. Note: Incompatible with 2505BPS/2505NSC Aerodynamics
Subject_Description_15: This course is aimed at circuit design and printed circuit board implementation and finally the design of a complete electronic system. It involves PCB design, system and component specification, and design principles including noise reduction, transducers, ergonomics, power supplies, and design for testability. Students are required to complete a practical PCB design and a paper system design as part of their assessment. Incompatible: 3030MEE Pracitical Electronics AND 3076ENG Team Design Project Prerequisites: 1302ENG Introduction to Electronics AND 2301ENG Semiconductor Devices and Circuits
Subject_Description_16: The course introduces basic vector algebra in two and three dimensions, matrices, complex numbers, probability and revises basic functions. It provides a foundation in the mathematical sciences for later studies in science and engineering. Prior Assumed Knowledge: It will be assumed that students have the knowledge equivalent to a grade of SA over 4 semesters in Mathematics B (Qld high school subject), or equivalent study over 4 semesters of a high school subject that includes the study of differential and integral calculus or 1017SCG">1017SCG Foundation Mathematics (grade of 4 or higher). For students who do not have this level of mathematics background, it is strongly suggested that they first complete 1017SCG">1017SCG Foundation Mathematics. Incompatible: 1201SCG Linear Algebra, 1011SCG Mathematics 1A, 1201BPS Mathematics 1A, 1666NSC Mathematics 1A for Engineers.
Subject_Description_17: Mechanical engineers need to possess sound understanding of the physics of the design and use of machine elements such as gears, cams, springs, pulleys, joints etc., that are used in engineered components. This design process is deeply enshrined in established design standards/codes that all engineers should be knowledgeable of. 3511ENG Design of Machine Elements is aimed at integrating and applying prior knowledge in fundamental design, materials sciences, statics and dynamics coupled with design strategies and knowledge of machine elements to design various machines. These skills and knowledge help engineers to design, analyse, synthesize and deliver robust engineering solutions. The main learning outcome of this unit is the students' acquisition of strong analytical knowledge of machine elements, their design and load carriage/power transmission mechanics. This course will be delivered through a combination of specially developed lectures, design problem solving methods, case studies and hands-on design assignments' all rolled together into workshops. Please check the "assumed knowledge" for this course under the course profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. This course is planned to be offered for the first time in 2019, trimester 2 and replaces 2505ENG">2505ENG. Incompatible: 2505ENG">2505ENG Design of Machine Elements
Subject_Description_18: The Flight Procedures I course introduces students to the basic principles associated with each of the different phases of ab initio flying exercises. The course covers the aerodynamic principles, technical and procedural aspects, and regulatory framework of each aspect delivered in lecture format. The aspect is then practised and fully examined in the flight procedures laboratory utilising flight simulation software at workstations fitted with flight controls.
Subject_Description_19: This course introduces students to four fundamental engineering concepts related to electrical and electronic engineering: storage of electrical energy and transport of an electrical charge, interconnection of passive components to make small or large systems, operation of systems under conditions of constant electrical load or excitation, and the operation of systems under conditions of variable electrical load or excitation. The concepts are studied using the physical processes within the components and circuits of electrical systems in a practical context. Incompatible: 1005ENG Electronics for Engineers.
Subject_Description_20: This course educates students in modern onboard navigation systems and associated ground based technology. In addition, the course consolidates prior knowledge gained in the fields of Meteorology, Flight Planning and Performance, Basic Navigation and Aviation Regulation.
Subject_Description_21: This course covers the principles of electric motors and generators. Both DC and AC motors and generators are explored along with the application of single and multi-phase machines. State of the art drive, control and protection circuitry will also be considered along with solid state methods of providing AC supply. Practical work will enhance the understanding of these topics. Please check the "assumed knowledge" for this course under the course profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. This course will be offered from 2018 at the Gold Coast campus, in trimester 2, and replaces 6509ENG.
Subject_Description_22: This is an introductory course to law with respect to the aviation industry in Australia. The course will cover two primary topics: (i) Basic principles of law in relation to the aviation industry. - Contract law - Tort law (Negligence, Trespass and Nuisance) - Administrative law (relating to the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA), and - International law (ii) Introduction to Aviation Regulation, designed to guide students through the extensive regulatory system governing aviation. Incompatible: 2509NSC Aviation Legal Studies; 2509BPS Aviation Legal Studies.
Subject_Description_23: Mechanics of Materials 2 provides techniques by which engineers can determine stress and strain distributions resulting from known loading conditions, so that the stability and strength of structural members under load can be examined. The learners will acquire the knowledge in the analysis and design of structures and machines under load.
Subject_Description_24: This course explores the common modulation techniques including amplitude and angle modulation for both analogue and digital information signals. Applications examined include radio, television and telecommunications. The course looks at both system level and circuit level. Many examples are examined for circuits for mixers, modulators, demodulators, oscillators, frequency synthesisers, RF amplifiers and radio and television receivers and transmitters. Design of amplification stages utilising classes A, B, C and D are examined. Methods and importance of shielding at high frequencies is also covered. A series of laboratories explore construction and measurement of communication circuits. Incompatible: 3007MEE Communication Systems and Circuits AND 3074ENG Telecommunications This course is planned to be offered for the last time in 2018. Please consult your program director for a suitable alternative.
Subject_Description_25: This course introduces the fundamental concepts of electronics from the systems and signals perspective. Hardware implementations, such as A/D and D/A converters, rectifiers, wave-shaping circuits, and amplifiers are developed by making use of operational amplifiers, diodes, resistors, and capacitors to emphasise the system-building concepts (feedback, frequency response, transfer characteristics, impedance matching, and analysis by equivalent circuits). Circuit simulation (using SPICE) is used concurrently with real circuits and measurements to establish links between theory and practice. Incompatibles: 1005MEE Electronic Devices, Circuits and Systems AND 1031MEE Introduction to Electronics. Advised Prerequisites: 1301ENG Electric Circuits
Subject_Description_26: Engineering mechanics is both a foundation and a framework for most engineering disciplines. This course provides a basic knowledge of Newtonian mechanics, rigid-body mechanics, elasticity and structural analysis. In particular, the principles of statics and their applications in engineering, the methods of static analysis, and techniques of engineering computation are expounded. Students are expected not only to acquire a good grasp of the principles but also to develop the computational and analytical skills which are vital in obtaining correct engineering solutions. In practice, a wrong solution can lead to an engineering disaster. This course is designed to enable students to acquire fundamental knowledge in engineering. It forms an integral part of the analysis and design training provided in the Engineering programs. This course is offered in trimester 2 and 3 at both the Gold Coast and Nathan campuses.
Subject_Description_27: This course deals with continuous-time signals and systems and is designed to build on the basic circuit analysis concepts covered in the course Electric Circuits. It provides a detailed study of continuous-time signals and systems in time domain as well as in transformed domain. Signal transforms (Fourier series, Fourier transform and Laplace transforms) are covered in detail. Further concepts such as signal sampling and aliasing are introduced. The theory is exemplified with processing of signals in MATLAB. Incompatible: 2006MEE Signals and Systems AND 2075ENG Signals and Systems
Subject_Description_28: The capstone engineering project is undertaken in the final year of the program. Students are required to plan, execute and report on a research project with some independence while working with an academic supervisor who maintains regular contact and provides support and direction in the design and execution of the research. Projects based on industry requirements will be encouraged.
Subject_Description_29: This course introduces the basic semiconductor concepts, the principles of diode and transistor operation, and the fundamental transistor circuits (common amplifier topologies, op-amp building blocks, and low-frequency amplifiers). Circuit simulation (SPICE) with appropriately set device parameters and simplified equivalent circuits are used for circuit analysis. Circuit design is based on circuit analysis and is facilitated by an understanding of semiconductor properties and device operation. Laboratory exercises will complement the teaching approach for this course. Incompatible: 2030MEE Microelectronic Circuits Prerequisites: 1301ENG Electric Circuits and 1302ENG Introduction to Electronics
Subject_Description_30: This course aims to equip students with a working knowledge of both global and domestic air traffic management environments, as the transition to the new Communications, Navigation and Surveillance/Air Traffic Management systems described in ICAO's Global Air Navigation Plan for CNS/ATM Systems is implemented. The online offering of this course is only available to 'professional entry' students. Those students should email the Program Officer, Aviation, at aviation@griffith.edu.au for permission to enrol. Incompatible with course AVN3004 Airways Operation and Design.
Subject_Description_31: The Course introduces students to advanced materials and their applications with the aim to deepen their understanding about i) how materials properties guide materials selection at the product design stage, ii) how core materials properties (either surface- or bulk properties) are changed, adapted or mended to specific user environment and/or an application field through a variety of manufacturing methods, and iii) how commercial material objects (or products) are manufactured in a factory setting. The Course will endue students with relevant knowledge on current materials surface technology, material treatment processes and manufacturing and production system processes, process technology and manufacturing systems design. Additive and rapid prototyping technology and lean engineering/lean production will be also be discussed in this Course. The Course is designed for 3rd year engineering students that already possess university-level fundamental knowledge on properties of common engineering materials such as metals, polymers, ceramics and attained theoretical and practical knowledge on fabrication and processing methods for these materials. The Course is developed to provide a practical, project-based immersion into materials selection process (with real, commercial products used as study samples) where students will learn how initial material selection process effects the geometry, structure, performance and cost of a final product. Assessment is by group assignment, oral presentation and individual examination. Please check the "Assumed Knowledge" for this course under the Course Profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. Incompatible: 2506ENG Materials and Manufacturing
Subject_Description_32: 2515NSC focuses on the human factors issues faced by pilots. It considers the human factors relevant to single-pilot and multi-crew operations. This course examines human performance and limitations, from both a theoretical and practical perspective; with the aim of improving flight safety
Subject_Description_33: This course provides a practical and theoretical introduction to manufacturing technology with a primary focus on metal processing technologies and their applications in modern manufacturing industry. The course is designed for the 2nd year engineering students that already possess university-level fundamental knowledge about the properties of common engineering materials, the application of forces in engineering systems and have a basic understanding about the tools, machines and processes employed in fabrication of engineered products.
Subject_Description_34: This experiential learning course introduces students to the engineering design process and professional aspects of being an Engineer or Industrial Designer. The course takes into consideration the increasingly complex interactions between engineering systems, project stakeholders and the environment, including the positive role of engineering in sustainable development as well as the potentially adverse impacts of engineering activities. Exposure to engineers and designers who are in the workforce will be a feature of this course.
Subject_Description_35: This course will be conducted at a LAME training organisation. Students will become familiarised with flight systems and maintenance procedures, maintenance regulations and safety procedures vital for the safe maintenance and alteration of modern aircraft.
Subject_Description_36: This course provides some of the essential mathematical techniques to mathematicians and physical scientists, and applies them to scientific problems. The course covers basic material on multiple integrals of scalar functions as well as line and surface integrals of vector fields, the theorems of Gauss, Green and Stokes, Fourier series and integrals. It also introduces some of the common partial differential equations of applied mathematics and methods of solution mostly based on separation of variables. It also covers some topics on ordinary differential equations. Incompatible: 2001ENG Advanced ENG Mathematics, 2203NSC Mathematics 2A. Prerequisites: 1201SCG">1201SCG Linear Algebra and 1202SCG Calculus I. (Please note: for students enrolled in Program 1567 1201SCG">1201SCG Linear Algebra is a co-requisite). Students must pass both courses to enrol in 2205NSC.
Subject_Description_37: This course will explore in detail the modern implementations of electronics in the control of aircraft. Sensors, navigational instruments, control systems, collision avoidance systems and glass cockpit integration will all be studied. Students will gain practical experience in the implementation of these systems by working with real aircraft instrumentation and aircraft. An exposure to maintenance of aircraft is also included and students successfully completing the course will be awarded a Certificate II in Aeroskills. The course is restricted to students enrolled in 1542 BEng(Electronic and UAV major) and 1584 BEng/BAvn
Subject_or_Unit_38: AIRCRAFT OPERATIONS, PERFORMANCE AND PLANNING PART II
Subject_Description_38: This course is the second part of 2520NSC (Light Aircraft Operations, Performance and Planning Part I) in accordance with the CASA CPL Operations, Performance and Planning syllabus.
Subject_Description_39: The main aim of this course is to provide sound knowledge of the principles and practices of digital systems, both at the device and circuit level. The course covers topics in digital electronics including: Number Theory, Boolean Algebra, Logic Circuits, Logic Minimisation Techniques, Multiplexers, Adders, Flip-Flops, Counters, Registers, State Machines, Memory Circuits, Digital / Analog Conversion, Programable Logic Circuits and Microcomputer Bus Architecture. Incompatible: 1004MEE Digital Networks and Systems AND 2072ENG Digital Systems AND 1303ENG Digital Systems
Subject_Description_40: Stress analysis (also known as solid mechanics) provides techniques by which engineers can predict stress and strain distributions resulting from known loading conditions, so that the stability and strength of structural members and machine components under load can be assessed. Stress analysis is an essential tool in the analysis and design of structures and machines under load.

Description: This combined degree produces professional engineers with a  solid foundation in engineering principles and the managerial skills to run complex projects. Students develop knowledge and skills in their preferred Engineering major combined with key business competencies such as organisational behaviour, communication, economics, and quality control. Skills are enhanced through off-campus industry experience to prepare students for  entry to the workforce. Engineering majors Business majors
Career_Outcomes: You will find employment in local council and state government departments, small to large multinational consulting firms, civil construction projects, mining oil, research.
Subject_Description_1: This course provides engineering and architecture students with an overview of the principles, skills and techniques required for the evaluation, planning, and management of projects from inception through to completion.
Subject_Description_2: This course covers fundamental electromagnetic theory including Electrostatics, Magnetostatics, Electromagnetic Induction, Electromagnetic Radiation, Properties of Matter and finally finishing with Maxwell's equations. This basic theory is then used to explore the principles of propagation on guided media such as cables and waveguides. Basic principles such as the Telegraph equations lead to characteristic impedance, reflection and transmission coefficient, standing and travelling waves. Simple modes in rectangular and circular waveguides are examined and fundamental dispersion issues are addressed. Smith charts are used as a calculation tool for transmission problems and numerous matching and coupling problems are attempted. A series of laboratories explore measurements of signals and fields on simple systems.
Subject_Description_3: Kinematics & Dynamics equips graduates with a solid understanding of the key concepts of mechanics required for design and analysis of mechanisms and mechanical devices. Topics covered include kinematics and dynamics of mechanical components modelled as particles and plane rigid bodies, interconnected objects, rotational dynamics, work and energy methods, translating and rotating coordinate systems, vector methods, three-dimensional dynamics of rigid bodies and an introduction to vibration Please check the "assumed knowledge" for this course under the course profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. This course is planned to be offered for the first time in 2018, trimester 1 and replaces 3317ENG.
Subject_Description_4: This experiential learning course introduces students to the engineering design process and professional aspects of being an Engineer or Industrial Designer. The course takes into consideration the increasingly complex interactions between engineering systems, project stakeholders and the environment, including the positive role of engineering in sustainable development as well as the potentially adverse impacts of engineering activities. Exposure to engineers and designers who are in the workforce will be a feature of this course.
Subject_Description_5: Soil Mechanics is an important part of geotechnical engineering that deals with the engineering properties of various soils. This course provides students with valuable opportunities to develop their understanding of the fundamentals of soil behavior, and skills that will allow them to apply their knowledge to solve real-life problems. Students will also have the opportunity to become familiar with various testing procedures and learn how to perform laboratory tests to determine the geotechnical properties of soil such as grain-size distribution, plasticity, compaction characteristics, and permeability. After completing this course, students will acquire sufficient knowledge and develop critical skills that will enable them to solve practical problems related to soil mechanics
Subject_Description_6: This course introduces students to municipal solid waste engineering. The contents include municipal solid waste characteristics, storage and collection, transfer and transport, separation and processing, recycling, composting, incineration and landfilling.
Subject_Description_7: This course provides some of the essential mathematical techniques to mathematicians and physical scientists, and applies them to scientific problems. The course covers basic material on multiple integrals of scalar functions as well as line and surface integrals of vector fields, the theorems of Gauss, Green and Stokes, Fourier series and integrals. It also introduces some of the common partial differential equations of applied mathematics and methods of solution mostly based on separation of variables. It also covers some topics on ordinary differential equations. Incompatible: 2001ENG Advanced ENG Mathematics, 2203NSC Mathematics 2A. Prerequisites: 1201SCG">1201SCG Linear Algebra and 1202SCG Calculus I. (Please note: for students enrolled in Program 1567 1201SCG">1201SCG Linear Algebra is a co-requisite). Students must pass both courses to enrol in 2205NSC.
Subject_Description_8: This course introduces students to the process of structural design including: dealing with a client and defining a design brief, load estimation, elementary structural analysis and the design of timber and steel members and connections using the relevant Australian Standard design codes.
Subject_Description_9: This experiential learning based course introduces the natural and physical sciences that underpin the practice of engineering. Through projects students will apply science fundamentals to the systematic investigation, interpretation, and analysis of some engineering problems. Topics covered include Newtonian mechanics and electrical principles. Incompatible: 1031SCG (Physics IA).
Subject_Description_10: Geotechnical Engineering forms a major part of the work of a professional civil engineer. This course is designed to enable students to do the analysis prior to design of foundations. It also forms an integral part of the civil analysis and design training provided in the four-year Bachelor of Engineering program in Civil Engineering. The course covers: design and construction aspects of shallow foundations, piled foundations, earth pressure calculations, and slope stability analysis. The main purpose of this course is to develop the ability of the students to design the basic geotechnical foundations (i.e., shallow foundation and piled foundation) and analyse the common geotechnical engineering problems (e.g., slope stability).
Subject_Description_11: As an engineer you will be faced with problems that require you to devise innovative and practical solutions. Some problems may be simple and you will solve them drawing on knowledge you acquired through your course of study or using your accumulated experiences. On the other hand, there will be cases where your experience and academic training are not sufficient. In these cases, you will need to engage in research. Being able to source valid and credible information and analyse information statistically in order to formulate viable solutions is an important skill that all engineers need and which Engineers Australia expects you to have. The research and statistics skills you learn in this course will also help you throughout your studies at Griffith University. Research is a key component in Undergraduate degrees at Griffith University. Moreover, the skills learnt in this course are of vital importance to students who intend to pursue higher degree research studies. Therefore, this course aims to equip you with the skills needed to conduct valid research and statistical analysis be it in academic or industrial practice context.
Subject_Description_12: This course deals with continuous-time signals and systems and is designed to build on the basic circuit analysis concepts covered in the course Electric Circuits. It provides a detailed study of continuous-time signals and systems in time domain as well as in transformed domain. Signal transforms (Fourier series, Fourier transform and Laplace transforms) are covered in detail. Further concepts such as signal sampling and aliasing are introduced. The theory is exemplified with processing of signals in MATLAB. Incompatible: 2006MEE Signals and Systems AND 2075ENG Signals and Systems
Subject_Description_13: The course revises and extends basic integral and differential calculus of one variable and introduces differential equations. It provides a foundation in the mathematical sciences needed for later studies both in an engineering and science context. This course is for Engineering or ICT students ONLY. Incompatible: 1202SCG Calculus I
Subject_Description_14: The course introduces basic vector algebra in two and three dimensions, matrices, complex numbers, probability and revises basic functions. It provides a foundation in the mathematical sciences for later studies in science and engineering. Prior Assumed Knowledge: It will be assumed that students have the knowledge equivalent to a grade of SA over 4 semesters in Mathematics B (Qld high school subject), or equivalent study over 4 semesters of a high school subject that includes the study of differential and integral calculus or 1017SCG">1017SCG Foundation Mathematics (grade of 4 or higher). For students who do not have this level of mathematics background, it is strongly suggested that they first complete 1017SCG">1017SCG Foundation Mathematics. Incompatible: 1201SCG Linear Algebra, 1011SCG Mathematics 1A, 1201BPS Mathematics 1A, 1666NSC Mathematics 1A for Engineers.
Subject_Description_15: This course explores the future of work in a rapidly globalizing, knowledge and service-intensive economy. Advances in IT and associated technologies are enabling firms to automate and/or outsource routine work, displacing the jobs of low-skilled workers, while enhancing the power of knowledge workers. In parallel, new industries and forms of collaborative and distance-based work are emerging, offering new challenges and opportunities. This course investigates the causes of technological, industrial and organisational change and their potential impacts of work arrangements and stakeholder relationships. Strategies and policies for managing change and coping with the new world of work outlined, drawing on latest research from Australia and other countries. Students would investigate how the future of work affects the business landscape of both large companies and smaller firms. It would cover sources of value creation and the benefits and challenges of the new technologies. There will be an overview of IoT and futurist thinking and of selected technologies to examine how such digital innovations are being developed and used by leading organisations. Content will address the implications for managers of social media, big data, artificial intelligence and newer technological innovations.
Subject_Description_16: This course covers some aspects of a computer system architecture and organisation. It will introduce the students to the basic components of a computer system showing how the system components interact with the processor such as the operating system, the memory controller, and the I/O subsystem. The course also contains an in depth look at many mainstream bus architectures used in industry. It not only focuses on the hardware components of computer based systems, the students are also taught the importance of the components that make an operating system.
