Students are encouraged to learn about operating systems through the development of a Real-time operating system for a mainstream micro-controller. Throughout the course, the assignments and laboratories will be used to further develop the practical skills of the students. Incompatible: 3021MEE Computer Systems
Subject_Description_17: This course extends the theoretical and practical content of the course 2305ENG Signals and Systems and covers fundamental topics in digital signal processing (DSP) such as A/D and D/A converters, analysis of discrete-time signals and systems, design of finite impulse response (FIR) and infinite impulse response (IIR) digital filters, multirate digital signal processing, etc. MATLAB (software) and digital signal processor boards (hardware) are used to provide hands-on experience to students. This course is planned to be offered for the last time in 2016 at the Gold Coast campus. The Nathan campus offering will continue as normal beyond 2016. Gold Coast students please consult your program director for a suitable alternative. Incompatible: 6321ENG
Subject_Description_18: This course introduces students to the basic concepts and principles of thermodynamics, and its selected engineering applications. Topics include the first law of thermodynamics, volumetric properties of pure substances, heat effects, the second law of thermodynamics, thermodynamic properties of fluids, and thermodynamic analysis of processes.
Subject_Description_19: Mechanical Engineering Design is the creative development of mechanical products or systems. This course focuses on mechanical design through a project based learning approach. Students will work on a design and analyse (and/or build) project, developing a solution to a real-world engineering design problem. Assessment is by a written design report, oral presentation/s and peer group assessment when relevant.
Subject_Description_20: This course mainly covers the analysis and design of reinforced and prestressed concrete structural elements. Both strength and serviceability design requirements are covered. Problem solving exercises based on actual design situations are utilised extensively in this course. After completing this course students will be able to analyse and design structural concrete elements and structures. Assessment is by, tutorial and design assignments, and examinations.
Subject_Description_21: Students in this course are introduced to the idea that there are many ways to identify and solve the complex problems faced by businesses today; hence business success hinges on the ability to think creatively and innovatively, combining knowledge from a variety of disciplines. To this end, the course introduces ideas/tools of creativity and entrepreneurialism and demonstrates how these ideas/tools are applied to a variety of situations through the use of case studies and guest lecturers. The discussion is set in the context of the current debate on what constitutes business success, how it is achieved, and how businesses are under "scrutiny" by the community at large to ensure that they behave and operate in responsible and sustainable manner. In this regard, the course also explores issues related to financial and non-financial reporting, governance framework, risk management, stakeholder and agency, policy and regulatory intervention, indigenous/herniate assets. Lectures will include guest lecturers and will cover a diverse range of topics such as marketing, current and new technologies, future world trends, legal issues, work force issues etc. Workshops will enable students to work on case studies that involve real problems sourced from industry clients and partners. Industry clients will be directly involved in the workshop and students required to present solutions to their problems at the end of the trimester.
Subject_Description_22: This course explores the common modulation techniques including amplitude and angle modulation for both analogue and digital information signals. Applications examined include radio, television and telecommunications. The course looks at both system level and circuit level. Many examples are examined for circuits for mixers, modulators, demodulators, oscillators, frequency synthesisers, RF amplifiers and radio and television receivers and transmitters. Design of amplification stages utilising classes A, B, C and D are examined. Methods and importance of shielding at high frequencies is also covered. A series of laboratories explore construction and measurement of communication circuits. Incompatible: 2304ENG Communication Systems and Circuits AND 3007MEE Communication Systems and Circuits
Subject_Description_23: The supply of good quality water, together with the removal of subsequent wastewater, is essential for modern communities. This course deals with the theory, methods, processes and design principles involved in treating and managing water and wastewater, including reticulation systems. The main focus is on municipal use of water and municipal wastewater production. This course concentrates on providing a solid understanding of conventional practice.
Subject_Description_24: In an increasingly complex financial system, and with an aging and longer living population, financial independence and effective financial decision making are seen as important life attributes and skills. The reality however is that many make poor financial decisions, fail to plan for their financial future, adequately protect themselves, their family and their assets, are easily influenced into poor/inappropriate financial products, and fall foul of schemes and scams. In other words there is low levels of financial literacy in the community, including in higher education graduates. A study of money and life will cover a range of content areas including planning and goal setting, behaviour and decision making, financial markets, services and products, rights and obligations under contracts, financial systems and household finances. This could also introduce fintech (including Bloomberg and the SSMIF). The course would provide a range of personal and professional development outcomes for students as well as improve their overall understanding of business. The course will be designed to be relevant for all students of the university and also has potential for development into a standalone credential/MOOC.
Subject_Description_25: This course introduces the fundamental concepts of electronics from the systems and signals perspective. Hardware implementations, such as A/D and D/A converters, rectifiers, wave-shaping circuits, and amplifiers are developed by making use of operational amplifiers, diodes, resistors, and capacitors to emphasise the system-building concepts (feedback, frequency response, transfer characteristics, impedance matching, and analysis by equivalent circuits). Circuit simulation (using SPICE) is used concurrently with real circuits and measurements to establish links between theory and practice. Incompatibles: 1005MEE Electronic Devices, Circuits and Systems AND 1031MEE Introduction to Electronics. Advised Prerequisites: 1301ENG Electric Circuits
Subject_Description_26: The capstone engineering project is undertaken in the final year of the program. Students are required to plan, execute and report on a research project with some independence while working with an academic supervisor who maintains regular contact and provides support and direction in the design and execution of the research. Projects based on industry requirements will be encouraged.
Subject_Description_27: This course provides the fundamental knowledge of fluid mechanics and hydraulics including fluid properties, fluid statics, conservation of mass, energy equation, flow in conduits, pumps and turbines, flow around objects, open channel flow and compressible flow.
Subject_Description_28: This course introduces students to engineering design practice utilising real world design exercises. The course gives students a solid grounding in current engineering practice and emphasises the importance of incorporating sustainable approaches and sound practices to their designs. This course may involve individual or team approaches, depending on the nature of the design task. Incompatible: 2106ENG Design for Civil Engineers
Subject_Description_29: This course develops an integrated approach to understanding and analysis of natural catchments. Principles and methods in hydrology and hydraulics will be used to analyse the dynamics of water and water-borne substances. We will address their sources, transport, mixing and dispersion in the environment as well as the implications to catchment management. Computer modelling software popular in the water engineering industry will be extensively used in this course.
Subject_Description_30: This course introduces the fundamental concepts and methods of general chemistry. Basic skills of laboratory chemical analysis are developed. Lecture content includes three modules: Introduction and basic concepts; molecular structure and bonding; and energy and physical processes. Incompatible: 1001SCE Chemistry 1A, 1009ENV General Chemistry, 1001ENV Chemistry 1, 1023SCG Chemistry 1
Subject_Description_31: This course introduces students to a perspective of the purpose of business that embeds values such as responsible leadership, integrity and ethical behaviour, respect for others, trust, and sustainable enterprise. The relevance of these values and their impact on behaviour and outcomes in a business context is demonstrated to students through case studies, real world examples, and testimonials from industry partners. Following from the discussion of values, the course then looks at how businesses develop solutions to respond to increasing demand for sustainability, transparency and good governance. The framework of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) is introduced and used to examine the alignment between business practices and sustainable solutions to real life problems faced by a business. The course also considers the role and responsibility (including legal) of professionals and professional standards in today's society.
Subject_Description_32: This course introduces the basic semiconductor concepts, the principles of diode and transistor operation, and the fundamental transistor circuits (common amplifier topologies, op-amp building blocks, and low-frequency amplifiers). Circuit simulation (SPICE) with appropriately set device parameters and simplified equivalent circuits are used for circuit analysis. Circuit design is based on circuit analysis and is facilitated by an understanding of semiconductor properties and device operation. Laboratory exercises will complement the teaching approach for this course. Incompatible: 2030MEE Microelectronic Circuits Prerequisites: 1301ENG Electric Circuits and 1302ENG Introduction to Electronics
Subject_Description_33: Stress analysis (also known as solid mechanics) provides techniques by which engineers can predict stress and strain distributions resulting from known loading conditions, so that the stability and strength of structural members and machine components under load can be assessed. Stress analysis is an essential tool in the analysis and design of structures and machines under load.
Subject_Description_34: Heat and Mass Transfer Engineering aims to equip future engineers with fundamental knowledge together with practical design and implementation skills for applications involving mass and energy balances, mass transfer, psychrometry, convection, heat conduction, and radiation heat transfer. Students will engage in engineering design project(s) involving selection, sizing and/or design of devices such as heat exchangers, fans, pumps, ducting, condensers, distillation columns and air conditioners. Students will be required to propose fit-for-purpose solutions that meet the competing demands of their profession including sustainability, legal issues and commercial aspects. Engineering responsibility and skills in leadership, project control, whole systems design, whole systems thinking, risk management and effective human relations will be refined through this course.
Subject_Description_35: This course will combine an extension of the study of geomechanics to pavement engineering techniques with the principles of traffic flow theory and pavement engineering techniques so that students can apply them to practice. The course covers traffic flow models, headway models, traffic fundamental diagrams, intersection design and assessment, pavement engineering and design, pavement condition survey and pavement management. This course will be assessed by individual based assignment, mid trimester exam, and final exam.
Subject_Description_36: Structural design forms a major part of the work of a professional civil engineer. This course is designed to enable students to do the prerequisite analysis prior to design. It also forms an integral part of the structural analysis and design training provided in the four-year Bachelor of Engineering program in Civil Engineering. This course provides a thorough coverage of the theoretical basis for linear analysis of various types of skeletal (planar) structures encountered in Civil Engineering design work. The main purpose of this course is to develop the ability of the students to analyse planar structures using manual and computer-based methods.
Subject_Description_37: The main aim of this course is to provide sound knowledge of the principles and practices of digital systems, both at the device and circuit level. The course covers topics in digital electronics including: Number Theory, Boolean Algebra, Logic Circuits, Logic Minimisation Techniques, Multiplexers, Adders, Flip-Flops, Counters, Registers, State Machines, Memory Circuits, Digital / Analog Conversion, Programable Logic Circuits and Microcomputer Bus Architecture. Incompatible: 1004MEE Digital Networks and Systems AND 2072ENG Digital Systems AND 1303ENG Digital Systems
Subject_Description_38: The course introduces students to the theory and practice of control systems. It discusses the basic (introductory) methods of control systems analysis and design, with emphasis on the principle of negative feedback which is the essence of operation of control systems. Engineering examples are used to introduce and illustrate the usefulness of the control systems theory and to make the students aware of this important engineering area. Assessment is by lab preliminaries, reports on laboratory experiments, and a final examination.
Subject_Description_39: This course introduces the importance of microorganisms to natural and man made ecosystems, biogeochemical cycles, trophic pathways and their beneficial applications to modern industry. The course provides an understanding of the relationships of living organisms - microorganisms, plants and animals with each other and their abiotic environment. Fundamentals include microbial metabolism (aerobic and anaerobic respiration, photosynthesis, chemosynthesis, energy transformation); cellular transport (diffusion, osmosis and active transport); microbial growth; microbial genetics and environmentally significant biochemical pathways. The taxonomic classification of autotrophic and heterotrophic organisms will be covered together with their resource requirements - light, oxygen and nutrients. Ecosystem concepts of food webs, energy flow and mineral cycles, including the bioaccumulation and biomagnification of pollutants. Particular emphasis is placed on the role of micro-organisms in decomposition, biogeochemical cycles, waste water treatment, bioremediation, water quality and human and ecosystem health. The laboratories cover microbial biodiversity, techniques for the culture, staining and emumeration of microorganisms, animal and plant diversity with emphasis on bioindicators, water quality and macroinvertebrate sampling.
Subject_Description_40: This course covers the principles of electric motors and generators. Both DC and AC motors and generators are explored along with the application of single and multi-phase machines. State of the art drive, control and protection circuitry will also be considered along with solid state methods of providing AC supply. Practical work will enhance the understanding of these topics. Please check the "assumed knowledge" for this course under the course profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. This course will be offered from 2018 at the Gold Coast campus, in trimester 2, and replaces 6509ENG.

Description: This combined degree produces professional engineers with a solid foundation in engineering principles and the managerial skills to run complex projects. Students develop knowledge and skills in their preferred Engineering major combined with key business competencies such as organisational behaviour, communication, economics, and quality control. Skills are enhanced through off-campus industry experience to prepare students for entry to the workforce. Engineering majors Business majors
Career_Outcomes: You will find employment in local council and state government departments, small to large multinational consulting firms, civil construction projects, mining oil, research.
Subject_Description_1: This course introduces students to the basic concepts and principles of thermodynamics, and its selected engineering applications. Topics include the first law of thermodynamics, volumetric properties of pure substances, heat effects, the second law of thermodynamics, thermodynamic properties of fluids, and thermodynamic analysis of processes.
Subject_Description_2: The course introduces students to the theory and practice of control systems. It discusses the basic (introductory) methods of control systems analysis and design, with emphasis on the principle of negative feedback which is the essence of operation of control systems. Engineering examples are used to introduce and illustrate the usefulness of the control systems theory and to make the students aware of this important engineering area. Assessment is by lab preliminaries, reports on laboratory experiments, and a final examination.
Subject_Description_3: This course introduces students to the process of structural design including: dealing with a client and defining a design brief, load estimation, elementary structural analysis and the design of timber and steel members and connections using the relevant Australian Standard design codes.
Subject_Description_4: Geotechnical Engineering forms a major part of the work of a professional civil engineer. This course is designed to enable students to do the analysis prior to design of foundations. It also forms an integral part of the civil analysis and design training provided in the four-year Bachelor of Engineering program in Civil Engineering. The course covers: design and construction aspects of shallow foundations, piled foundations, earth pressure calculations, and slope stability analysis. The main purpose of this course is to develop the ability of the students to design the basic geotechnical foundations (i.e., shallow foundation and piled foundation) and analyse the common geotechnical engineering problems (e.g., slope stability).
Subject_Description_5: This course covers the principles of electric motors and generators. Both DC and AC motors and generators are explored along with the application of single and multi-phase machines. State of the art drive, control and protection circuitry will also be considered along with solid state methods of providing AC supply. Practical work will enhance the understanding of these topics. Please check the "assumed knowledge" for this course under the course profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. This course will be offered from 2018 at the Gold Coast campus, in trimester 2, and replaces 6509ENG.
Subject_Description_6: The capstone engineering project is undertaken in the final year of the program. Students are required to plan, execute and report on a research project with some independence while working with an academic supervisor who maintains regular contact and provides support and direction in the design and execution of the research. Projects based on industry requirements will be encouraged.
Subject_Description_7: Mechanics of Materials 2 provides techniques by which engineers can determine stress and strain distributions resulting from known loading conditions, so that the stability and strength of structural members under load can be examined. The learners will acquire the knowledge in the analysis and design of structures and machines under load.
Subject_Description_8: This course provides some of the essential mathematical techniques to mathematicians and physical scientists, and applies them to scientific problems. The course covers basic material on multiple integrals of scalar functions as well as line and surface integrals of vector fields, the theorems of Gauss, Green and Stokes, Fourier series and integrals. It also introduces some of the common partial differential equations of applied mathematics and methods of solution mostly based on separation of variables. It also covers some topics on ordinary differential equations. Incompatible: 2001ENG Advanced ENG Mathematics, 2203NSC Mathematics 2A. Prerequisites: 1201SCG">1201SCG Linear Algebra and 1202SCG Calculus I. (Please note: for students enrolled in Program 1567 1201SCG">1201SCG Linear Algebra is a co-requisite). Students must pass both courses to enrol in 2205NSC.
Subject_Description_9: In an increasingly complex financial system, and with an aging and longer living population, financial independence and effective financial decision making are seen as important life attributes and skills. The reality however is that many make poor financial decisions, fail to plan for their financial future, adequately protect themselves, their family and their assets, are easily influenced into poor/inappropriate financial products, and fall foul of schemes and scams. In other words there is low levels of financial literacy in the community, including in higher education graduates. A study of money and life will cover a range of content areas including planning and goal setting, behaviour and decision making, financial markets, services and products, rights and obligations under contracts, financial systems and household finances. This could also introduce fintech (including Bloomberg and the SSMIF). The course would provide a range of personal and professional development outcomes for students as well as improve their overall understanding of business. The course will be designed to be relevant for all students of the university and also has potential for development into a standalone credential/MOOC.
Subject_Description_10: This course provides the fundamental knowledge of fluid mechanics and hydraulics including fluid properties, fluid statics, conservation of mass, energy equation, flow in conduits, pumps and turbines, flow around objects, open channel flow and compressible flow.
Subject_Description_11: This experiential learning based course introduces the natural and physical sciences that underpin the practice of engineering. Through projects students will apply science fundamentals to the systematic investigation, interpretation, and analysis of some engineering problems. Topics covered include Newtonian mechanics and electrical principles. Incompatible: 1031SCG (Physics IA).
Subject_Description_12: As an engineer you will be faced with problems that require you to devise innovative and practical solutions. Some problems may be simple and you will solve them drawing on knowledge you acquired through your course of study or using your accumulated experiences. On the other hand, there will be cases where your experience and academic training are not sufficient. In these cases, you will need to engage in research. Being able to source valid and credible information and analyse information statistically in order to formulate viable solutions is an important skill that all engineers need and which Engineers Australia expects you to have. The research and statistics skills you learn in this course will also help you throughout your studies at Griffith University. Research is a key component in Undergraduate degrees at Griffith University. Moreover, the skills learnt in this course are of vital importance to students who intend to pursue higher degree research studies. Therefore, this course aims to equip you with the skills needed to conduct valid research and statistical analysis be it in academic or industrial practice context.
Subject_Description_13: This course explores the future of work in a rapidly globalizing, knowledge and service-intensive economy. Advances in IT and associated technologies are enabling firms to automate and/or outsource routine work, displacing the jobs of low-skilled workers, while enhancing the power of knowledge workers. In parallel, new industries and forms of collaborative and distance-based work are emerging, offering new challenges and opportunities. This course investigates the causes of technological, industrial and organisational change and their potential impacts of work arrangements and stakeholder relationships. Strategies and policies for managing change and coping with the new world of work outlined, drawing on latest research from Australia and other countries. Students would investigate how the future of work affects the business landscape of both large companies and smaller firms. It would cover sources of value creation and the benefits and challenges of the new technologies. There will be an overview of IoT and futurist thinking and of selected technologies to examine how such digital innovations are being developed and used by leading organisations. Content will address the implications for managers of social media, big data, artificial intelligence and newer technological innovations.
Subject_Description_14: Numerical analysis is the area of mathematics and computer science that creates, analyses, and implements algorithms for solving numerically the problems of continuous mathematics. In engineering, these problems arise naturally from the requirement to understand and design physical systems to serve our needs. The aim of this course is to learn how to formulate numerical solutions suitable for resolving the type of calculations commonly encountered in electrical engineering. This course will be offered from 2019 in trimester 2 at the Gold Coast campus.
Subject_Description_15: This course provides engineering and architecture students with an overview of the principles, skills and techniques required for the evaluation, planning, and management of projects from inception through to completion.
Subject_Description_16: Heat and Mass Transfer gives the engineer a firm grounding in the fundamental processes of conduction, convection and radiation heat transfer. Topics covered include transient conduction, forced convection in internal and external flow, free convection, lumped heat capacity analysis, two and three-dimensional heat transfer, radiation exchange between surfaces, diffusion mass transfer, boiling, evaporation and condensation, and heat exchanger design & optimisation. Assessment is by assignments consisting of engineering problems in heat and mass transfer and a final examination. Incompatible: 3505ENG Heat and Mass Transfer
Subject_Description_17: This course deals with continuous-time signals and systems and is designed to build on the basic circuit analysis concepts covered in the course Electric Circuits. It provides a detailed study of continuous-time signals and systems in time domain as well as in transformed domain. Signal transforms (Fourier series, Fourier transform and Laplace transforms) are covered in detail. Further concepts such as signal sampling and aliasing are introduced. The theory is exemplified with processing of signals in MATLAB. Incompatible: 2006MEE Signals and Systems AND 2075ENG Signals and Systems
Subject_Description_18: The course introduces basic vector algebra in two and three dimensions, matrices, complex numbers, probability and revises basic functions. It provides a foundation in the mathematical sciences for later studies in science and engineering. Prior Assumed Knowledge: It will be assumed that students have the knowledge equivalent to a grade of SA over 4 semesters in Mathematics B (Qld high school subject), or equivalent study over 4 semesters of a high school subject that includes the study of differential and integral calculus or 1017SCG">1017SCG Foundation Mathematics (grade of 4 or higher). For students who do not have this level of mathematics background, it is strongly suggested that they first complete 1017SCG">1017SCG Foundation Mathematics. Incompatible: 1201SCG Linear Algebra, 1011SCG Mathematics 1A, 1201BPS Mathematics 1A, 1666NSC Mathematics 1A for Engineers.
Subject_Description_19: This experiential learning course introduces students to the engineering design process and professional aspects of being an Engineer or Industrial Designer. The course takes into consideration the increasingly complex interactions between engineering systems, project stakeholders and the environment, including the positive role of engineering in sustainable development as well as the potentially adverse impacts of engineering activities. Exposure to engineers and designers who are in the workforce will be a feature of this course.
Subject_Description_20: This course is the final design project in the civil engineering programs. It builds on earlier design courses and other engineering knowledge. The course involves a major 'real world' design project where students are encouraged to work in teams, but are individually assessed. Students are also exposed to the project management aspects of engineering projects. The course brings together and further enhances a range of generic skills such as teamwork, problem solving and communication.
Subject_Description_21: This course introduces students to a perspective of the purpose of business that embeds values such as responsible leadership, integrity and ethical behaviour, respect for others, trust, and sustainable enterprise. The relevance of these values and their impact on behaviour and outcomes in a business context is demonstrated to students through case studies, real world examples, and testimonials from industry partners. Following from the discussion of values, the course then looks at how businesses develop solutions to respond to increasing demand for sustainability, transparency and good governance. The framework of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) is introduced and used to examine the alignment between business practices and sustainable solutions to real life problems faced by a business. The course also considers the role and responsibility (including legal) of professionals and professional standards in today's society.
Subject_Description_22: Transdisciplinary groups of students work together to solve contemporary challenges in business with a focus on the Sustainability Development Goals in the Asia Pacific region, including first peoples. Students present solutions to real world problems by drawing on the knowledge they have developed throughout their foundation and majors. Students participate in simulations in addition to running a social enterprise or charity event. In addition, students will finalise their program e-portfolio's with evidence of their readiness for their chosen profession or career. Students will also collect and present final evidence of readiness through Griffith Graduate Attributes, Griffith Graduates of Influence and BusinessPlus credentials.
Subject_Description_23: Stress analysis (also known as solid mechanics) provides techniques by which engineers can predict stress and strain distributions resulting from known loading conditions, so that the stability and strength of structural members and machine components under load can be assessed. Stress analysis is an essential tool in the analysis and design of structures and machines under load.
Subject_Description_24: Soil Mechanics is an important part of geotechnical engineering that deals with the engineering properties of various soils. This course provides students with valuable opportunities to develop their understanding of the fundamentals of soil behavior, and skills that will allow them to apply their knowledge to solve real-life problems. Students will also have the opportunity to become familiar with various testing procedures and learn how to perform laboratory tests to determine the geotechnical properties of soil such as grain-size distribution, plasticity, compaction characteristics, and permeability. After completing this course, students will acquire sufficient knowledge and develop critical skills that will enable them to solve practical problems related to soil mechanics
Subject_Description_25: This course will combine an extension of the study of geomechanics to pavement engineering techniques with the principles of traffic flow theory and pavement engineering techniques so that students can apply them to practice. The course covers traffic flow models, headway models, traffic fundamental diagrams, intersection design and assessment, pavement engineering and design, pavement condition survey and pavement management. This course will be assessed by individual based assignment, mid trimester exam, and final exam.
Subject_Description_26: The aim of the course is to explain the way people behave and make decisions in a business environment and the role that information has in the context of decision-making. The course will introduce some elements of behavioural sciences and game theory applied to business problems. It will also tackle some of the critical questions around the use of information for business decision making: how to assess the validity/reliability and relevance of the information we receive? how to use it effectively? how to simplify information, make it relevant, and present it to different audiences? The course combines different aspects. First, it encourages students to account for the psychological, cognitive, emotional, cultural, and social factors that affects decisions made by individuals and organisations (e.g. private corporates, government, civil society, etc). Second it provides simple analytical tools to contextualise strategic decision-making in real world situations through lenses such as that of the consumer and the future role of social marketing. Third, it introduces students to the idea that business decision making requires reliable, timely information. The course takes a positive (as opposed to normative) approach to the analysis of interactive strategic decisions and behaviours. Through case studies, the course provides a description of what happens in a variety of business situations, with a focus on understanding the elements/dynamics that leads to a certain outcome of decision. In so doing, the course helps students identify the role of information (qualitative or quantitative), how it is sourced and assessed in terms of its validity/quality, and how it can be used to deal with uncertainty in decision-making. Basic approaches to the analysis, interpretation and presentation of various types of information are also discussed, including the foundations of big data analytics and qualitative data analysis.
Subject_Description_27: This course covers the concepts and components of electrical circuits and develops the fundamental circuit analysis and fault finding skills necessary to understand all electrical circuits. Circuit components such as resistors, capacitors and inductors and non-linear components such as diodes are studied progressing onto rectifiers, comparators and A/D and D/A converters. Analysis techniques include Kirchoff's laws, Thevenin/Norton equivalent circuits, time response of energy storage elements, sinusoidal steady state and frequency-domain analysis.
Subject_Description_28: This course covers fundamental and advanced topics in communications systems which are essential for Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Mechatronic Engineers, and Electronic and Biomedical Engineering. Knowledge on signals and systems, and Fourier transform is prerequisite for this course. Topics to be covered: (i) modulation AM, FM, (ii) digital modulation, digital transmission, (iii) introduction to mobile communications system and smart antennas, (iv) Wireless LANs, MIMO-OFDM for wireless, (v) Cellular Radio Communications, (vi) Microwave Engineering and communications, and (vii) introduction to Satellite Communications..
Subject_Description_29: The Course introduces students to advanced materials and their applications with the aim to deepen their understanding about i) how materials properties guide materials selection at the product design stage, ii) how core materials properties (either surface- or bulk properties) are changed, adapted or mended to specific user environment and/or an application field through a variety of manufacturing methods, and iii) how commercial material objects (or products) are manufactured in a factory setting. The Course will endue students with relevant knowledge on current materials surface technology, material treatment processes and manufacturing and production system processes, process technology and manufacturing systems design. Additive and rapid prototyping technology and lean engineering/lean production will be also be discussed in this Course. The Course is designed for 3rd year engineering students that already possess university-level fundamental knowledge on properties of common engineering materials such as metals, polymers, ceramics and attained theoretical and practical knowledge on fabrication and processing methods for these materials. The Course is developed to provide a practical, project-based immersion into materials selection process (with real, commercial products used as study samples) where students will learn how initial material selection process effects the geometry, structure, performance and cost of a final product. Assessment is by group assignment, oral presentation and individual examination. Please check the "Assumed Knowledge" for this course under the Course Profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. Incompatible: 2506ENG Materials and Manufacturing
Subject_Description_30: Students in this course are introduced to the idea that there are many ways to identify and solve the complex problems faced by businesses today; hence business success hinges on the ability to think creatively and innovatively, combining knowledge from a variety of disciplines. To this end, the course introduces ideas/tools of creativity and entrepreneurialism and demonstrates how these ideas/tools are applied to a variety of situations through the use of case studies and guest lecturers. The discussion is set in the context of the current debate on what constitutes business success, how it is achieved, and how businesses are under "scrutiny" by the community at large to ensure that they behave and operate in responsible and sustainable manner. In this regard, the course also explores issues related to financial and non-financial reporting, governance framework, risk management, stakeholder and agency, policy and regulatory intervention, indigenous/herniate assets. Lectures will include guest lecturers and will cover a diverse range of topics such as marketing, current and new technologies, future world trends, legal issues, work force issues etc. Workshops will enable students to work on case studies that involve real problems sourced from industry clients and partners. Industry clients will be directly involved in the workshop and students required to present solutions to their problems at the end of the trimester.
Subject_Description_31: Structural design forms a major part of the work of a professional civil engineer. This course is designed to enable students to do the prerequisite analysis prior to design. It also forms an integral part of the structural analysis and design training provided in the four-year Bachelor of Engineering program in Civil Engineering. This course provides a thorough coverage of the theoretical basis for linear analysis of various types of skeletal (planar) structures encountered in Civil Engineering design work. The main purpose of this course is to develop the ability of the students to analyse planar structures using manual and computer-based methods.
Subject_Description_32: The main aim of this course is to provide sound knowledge of the principles and practices of digital systems, both at the device and circuit level. The course covers topics in digital electronics including: Number Theory, Boolean Algebra, Logic Circuits, Logic Minimisation Techniques, Multiplexers, Adders, Flip-Flops, Counters, Registers, State Machines, Memory Circuits, Digital / Analog Conversion, Programable Logic Circuits and Microcomputer Bus Architecture. Incompatible: 1004MEE Digital Networks and Systems AND 2072ENG Digital Systems AND 1303ENG Digital Systems
Subject_Description_33: All electrical signals produce electromagnetic fields be they communication signals or high current power transmissions. It is therefore vital to understand about the generation and manipulation of these fields. This course covers classical electrostatics in terms of charge and charge density in volumes, force due to charge, electric field intensity, electric potential and electric flux density. It also explores magnetostatics in terms of magnetic field intensity and flux density, magnetic forces, magnetic potential and inductance. Finally time varying fields are covered including moving conductors, transformers, displacement current and generation and motion. The outcome should be a complete understanding of Maxwell's equations applied to engineering problems.
Subject_Description_34: This course introduces students to engineering design practice utilising real world design exercises. The course gives students a solid grounding in current engineering practice and emphasises the importance of incorporating sustainable approaches and sound practices to their designs. This course may involve individual or team approaches, depending on the nature of the design task. Incompatible: 2106ENG Design for Civil Engineers
Subject_Description_35: Mechanical Engineering Design is the creative development of mechanical products or systems. This course focuses on mechanical design through a project based learning approach. Students will work on a design and analyse (and/or build) project, developing a solution to a real-world engineering design problem. Assessment is by a written design report, oral presentation/s and peer group assessment when relevant.
Subject_Description_36: The course revises and extends basic integral and differential calculus of one variable and introduces differential equations. It provides a foundation in the mathematical sciences needed for later studies both in an engineering and science context. This course is for Engineering or ICT students ONLY. Incompatible: 1202SCG Calculus I
Subject_Description_37: Hydrology is concerned with the distribution and dynamics of water and water quality on or near the surface of earth. As fundamental engineering sciences, hydrology plays an important role in developing technical skills in water engineering and in understanding many of the contemporary water management issues. The course covers fundamental hydrologic processes such as rainfall, evaporation, infiltration, surface and ground water, and hydrologic extremes ie floods and droughts. In addition, the course develops technical skills to apply some basic techniques for hydrologic analysis and design with particular emphasis on flood estimation, flood frequency analysis, and flood routing. Learning activities include lectures and workshops.
Subject_Description_38: This course mainly covers the analysis and design of reinforced and prestressed concrete structural elements. Both strength and serviceability design requirements are covered. Problem solving exercises based on actual design situations are utilised extensively in this course. After completing this course students will be able to analyse and design structural concrete elements and structures. Assessment is by, tutorial and design assignments, and examinations.
Subject_Description_39: Electrical Design Project is a practical project based course in which students are challenged to apply fundamental knowledge of analogue and digital components, circuitry and systems to design, implement and demonstrate a functional electronic device meeting prescribed system requirements. Students are guided through a systematic design process involving analysis of requirements, circuit design and simulation, component selection, prototype construction, testing, evaluation and revision. An integral part of the process is the production and maintenance of engineering documentation in the form of technical specifications, schematic diagrams, list of components, test procedures and performance results. Incompatible: 3312ENG Practical Electronics I
Subject_Description_40: This course covers the theory and algorithms of statistical digital signal processing, estimation and modelling together with their applications in the electrical and electronic engineering disciplines. The first half of the course covers the mathematical preliminaries in deterministic digital signal processing, such as the z-transform, discrete-time Fourier transform, FIR and IIR filter design. The second half covers the core of the course, which examines the modelling and estimation of random signals and processes using spectral estimation, optimal filtering, linear MMSE estimation (Wiener and Kalman filtering), and adaptive filters. Emphasis is placed on electrical and electronic engineering applications, such as signal enhancement, signal detection in noise, adaptive noise cancellation, time-series prediction and machine learning. Students will also learn how to implement signal processing algorithms in software (using the Python language) and embedded DSP hardware. Incompatible: 3303ENG Digital Signal Processing

Course: Bachelor of Engineering (Honours)/Bachelor of Computer Science
Description: This double degree is focused on the future, combining a cutting-edge blend of computer science and engineering. The Bachelor of Engineering (Honours) gives you the opportunity to make your mark on major global systems and infrastructure or be at the leading-edge of local urban projects. You'll be involved in hands-on projects from year one, planning and creating clever solutions to real challenges. Your engineering skills are complemented with the future-proofed skills of computer science. You'll gain a broad knowledge of the subject learning the principles and concepts behind computer science problem-solving. For example, using modelling methods and processes to understand core problems and designing solutions that match.  From year one, you'll learn from industry experts and like-minded teachers. Hands-on experience is key to this double degree, and in your final year you can enhance your employment opportunities through an industry-based project or placement.  The future is promising for dual computer science and engineering professionals. With these complementary degrees, you'll be prepared for engineering roles across varied industries that require design, innovation and creative development applied with the latest technology.  Changes effective for students commencing from Trimester 2 2020 onwards: Engineering Computer Science  Tailor your timetable - Even if you study full-time on-campus, you may still be able to customise your degree to suit your needs. From a range of tutorial times to online access to lectures and other course material, we're here to help you fit study in with your work and life commitments.  Students may be eligible to do an international field trip, organised by the academic staff. This may count towards a component of the degree, depending on its structure.
Career_Outcomes: *Source: Australian Government Job Outlook
Subject_Description_1: All electrical signals produce electromagnetic fields be they communication signals or high current power transmissions. It is therefore vital to understand about the generation and manipulation of these fields. This course covers classical electrostatics in terms of charge and charge density in volumes, force due to charge, electric field intensity, electric potential and electric flux density. It also explores magnetostatics in terms of magnetic field intensity and flux density, magnetic forces, magnetic potential and inductance. Finally time varying fields are covered including moving conductors, transformers, displacement current and generation and motion. The outcome should be a complete understanding of Maxwell's equations applied to engineering problems.
Subject_Description_2: Mechanics of Materials 2 provides techniques by which engineers can determine stress and strain distributions resulting from known loading conditions, so that the stability and strength of structural members under load can be examined. The learners will acquire the knowledge in the analysis and design of structures and machines under load.
Subject_Description_3: Mechanical engineers need to possess sound understanding of the physics of the design and use of machine elements such as gears, cams, springs, pulleys, joints etc., that are used in engineered components. This design process is deeply enshrined in established design standards/codes that all engineers should be knowledgeable of. 3511ENG Design of Machine Elements is aimed at integrating and applying prior knowledge in fundamental design, materials sciences, statics and dynamics coupled with design strategies and knowledge of machine elements to design various machines. These skills and knowledge help engineers to design, analyse, synthesize and deliver robust engineering solutions. The main learning outcome of this unit is the students' acquisition of strong analytical knowledge of machine elements, their design and load carriage/power transmission mechanics. This course will be delivered through a combination of specially developed lectures, design problem solving methods, case studies and hands-on design assignments' all rolled together into workshops. Please check the "assumed knowledge" for this course under the course profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. This course is planned to be offered for the first time in 2019, trimester 2 and replaces 2505ENG">2505ENG. Incompatible: 2505ENG">2505ENG Design of Machine Elements
Subject_Description_4: All construction projects have the common feature of utilising engineering principles, people, machines and materials as well as requiring organisation and planning. This course covers the range of construction equipment and techniques in common use and the planning and direction of construction works. Attention is also given to rock and bulk excavations, health and safety at work sites, preliminary works, formwork design and an introduction to engineering economics. Assessment is by assignments and examinations. Incompatible: 2104ENG Construction Engineering
Subject_Description_5: Kinematics & Dynamics equips graduates with a solid understanding of the key concepts of mechanics required for design and analysis of mechanisms and mechanical devices. Topics covered include kinematics and dynamics of mechanical components modelled as particles and plane rigid bodies, interconnected objects, rotational dynamics, work and energy methods, translating and rotating coordinate systems, vector methods, three-dimensional dynamics of rigid bodies and an introduction to vibration Please check the "assumed knowledge" for this course under the course profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. This course is planned to be offered for the first time in 2018, trimester 1 and replaces 3317ENG.
Subject_Description_6: This course introduces students to the process of structural design including: dealing with a client and defining a design brief, load estimation, elementary structural analysis and the design of timber and steel members and connections using the relevant Australian Standard design codes.
Subject_Description_7: Mechanical Engineering Design is the creative development of mechanical products or systems. This course focuses on mechanical design through a project based learning approach. Students will work on a design and analyse (and/or build) project, developing a solution to a real-world engineering design problem. Assessment is by a written design report, oral presentation/s and peer group assessment when relevant.
Subject_Description_8: Numerical analysis is the area of mathematics and computer science that creates, analyses, and implements algorithms for solving numerically the problems of continuous mathematics. In engineering, these problems arise naturally from the requirement to understand and design physical systems to serve our needs. The aim of this course is to learn how to formulate numerical solutions suitable for resolving the type of calculations commonly encountered in electrical engineering. This course will be offered from 2019 in trimester 2 at the Gold Coast campus.
Subject_Description_9: This course covers the principles of electric motors and generators. Both DC and AC motors and generators are explored along with the application of single and multi-phase machines. State of the art drive, control and protection circuitry will also be considered along with solid state methods of providing AC supply. Practical work will enhance the understanding of these topics. Please check the "assumed knowledge" for this course under the course profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. This course will be offered from 2018 at the Gold Coast campus, in trimester 2, and replaces 6509ENG.
Subject_Description_10: This course provides some of the essential mathematical techniques to mathematicians and physical scientists, and applies them to scientific problems. The course covers basic material on multiple integrals of scalar functions as well as line and surface integrals of vector fields, the theorems of Gauss, Green and Stokes, Fourier series and integrals. It also introduces some of the common partial differential equations of applied mathematics and methods of solution mostly based on separation of variables. It also covers some topics on ordinary differential equations. Incompatible: 2001ENG Advanced ENG Mathematics, 2203NSC Mathematics 2A. Prerequisites: 1201SCG">1201SCG Linear Algebra and 1202SCG Calculus I. (Please note: for students enrolled in Program 1567 1201SCG">1201SCG Linear Algebra is a co-requisite). Students must pass both courses to enrol in 2205NSC.
Subject_Description_11: This course introduces students to the basic concepts and principles of thermodynamics, and its selected engineering applications. Topics include the first law of thermodynamics, volumetric properties of pure substances, heat effects, the second law of thermodynamics, thermodynamic properties of fluids, and thermodynamic analysis of processes.
Subject_Description_12: This course provides a practical and theoretical introduction to manufacturing technology with a primary focus on metal processing technologies and their applications in modern manufacturing industry. The course is designed for the 2nd year engineering students that already possess university-level fundamental knowledge about the properties of common engineering materials, the application of forces in engineering systems and have a basic understanding about the tools, machines and processes employed in fabrication of engineered products.
Subject_Description_13: This course provides the fundamental knowledge of fluid mechanics and hydraulics including fluid properties, fluid statics, conservation of mass, energy equation, flow in conduits, pumps and turbines, flow around objects, open channel flow and compressible flow.
Subject_Description_14: This course deals with continuous-time signals and systems and is designed to build on the basic circuit analysis concepts covered in the course Electric Circuits. It provides a detailed study of continuous-time signals and systems in time domain as well as in transformed domain. Signal transforms (Fourier series, Fourier transform and Laplace transforms) are covered in detail. Further concepts such as signal sampling and aliasing are introduced. The theory is exemplified with processing of signals in MATLAB. Incompatible: 2006MEE Signals and Systems AND 2075ENG Signals and Systems
Subject_Description_15: As an engineer you will be faced with problems that require you to devise innovative and practical solutions. Some problems may be simple and you will solve them drawing on knowledge you acquired through your course of study or using your accumulated experiences. On the other hand, there will be cases where your experience and academic training are not sufficient. In these cases, you will need to engage in research. Being able to source valid and credible information and analyse information statistically in order to formulate viable solutions is an important skill that all engineers need and which Engineers Australia expects you to have. The research and statistics skills you learn in this course will also help you throughout your studies at Griffith University. Research is a key component in Undergraduate degrees at Griffith University. Moreover, the skills learnt in this course are of vital importance to students who intend to pursue higher degree research studies. Therefore, this course aims to equip you with the skills needed to conduct valid research and statistical analysis be it in academic or industrial practice context.
Subject_Description_16: The course introduces students to the theory and practice of control systems. It discusses the basic (introductory) methods of control systems analysis and design, with emphasis on the principle of negative feedback which is the essence of operation of control systems. Engineering examples are used to introduce and illustrate the usefulness of the control systems theory and to make the students aware of this important engineering area. Assessment is by lab preliminaries, reports on laboratory experiments, and a final examination.
Subject_Description_17: Stress analysis (also known as solid mechanics) provides techniques by which engineers can predict stress and strain distributions resulting from known loading conditions, so that the stability and strength of structural members and machine components under load can be assessed. Stress analysis is an essential tool in the analysis and design of structures and machines under load.
Subject_Description_18: This course covers the theory and algorithms of statistical digital signal processing, estimation and modelling together with their applications in the electrical and electronic engineering disciplines. The first half of the course covers the mathematical preliminaries in deterministic digital signal processing, such as the z-transform, discrete-time Fourier transform, FIR and IIR filter design. The second half covers the core of the course, which examines the modelling and estimation of random signals and processes using spectral estimation, optimal filtering, linear MMSE estimation (Wiener and Kalman filtering), and adaptive filters. Emphasis is placed on electrical and electronic engineering applications, such as signal enhancement, signal detection in noise, adaptive noise cancellation, time-series prediction and machine learning. Students will also learn how to implement signal processing algorithms in software (using the Python language) and embedded DSP hardware. Incompatible: 3303ENG Digital Signal Processing
Subject_Description_19: The real-world performance of any software system depends on the algorithms used and the efficiency of their implementation. The ability to select algorithms appropriate to solving particular problems, based on understanding the range of algorithms that address well-defined problems, analyzing their complexity and performance, and their suitability in particular contexts and implementing them is critical for building effective software. A number of general algorithmic strategies are presented including brute force, heuristics, greedy, recursive backtracking and divide and conquer. Common algorithms pertaining to searching, sorting, binary trees, graphs, and string / expression parsing are also discussed. Also both in-memory and file data structures and their interrelationship with specific algorithms are reviewed. Pre-requisites: 1801ICT">1801ICT Object-Oriented Programming (this course was previously named 1801ICT">1801ICT Programming Languages) and 1020ENG Engineering Mathematics 2.
Subject_Description_20: Engineering solutions are developed from an in depth understanding of the subject knowledge combined with a creative approach to problem solving that takes a step back from details to consider the challenge as a whole. Complex problem solving involves an understanding of individuals and systems, interconnections and innovation. Furthermore these solutions must also be considered in terms of sustainable development. This course introduces the student to engineering design through a project-based approach to the development of a product or piece of infrastructure as part of small design team.
Subject_Description_21: The main aim of this course is to provide sound knowledge of the principles and practices of digital systems, both at the device and circuit level. The course covers topics in digital electronics including: Number Theory, Boolean Algebra, Logic Circuits, Logic Minimisation Techniques, Multiplexers, Adders, Flip-Flops, Counters, Registers, State Machines, Memory Circuits, Digital / Analog Conversion, Programable Logic Circuits and Microcomputer Bus Architecture. Incompatible: 1004MEE Digital Networks and Systems AND 2072ENG Digital Systems AND 1303ENG Digital Systems
Subject_Description_22: This course mainly covers the analysis and design of reinforced and prestressed concrete structural elements. Both strength and serviceability design requirements are covered. Problem solving exercises based on actual design situations are utilised extensively in this course. After completing this course students will be able to analyse and design structural concrete elements and structures. Assessment is by, tutorial and design assignments, and examinations.
Subject_Description_23: Software engineering applies to small, medium, and large-scale systems. It encompasses all phases of the life cycle of a software system including requirements analysis and specification, design, construction, testing, deployment, and operation, software project management and maintenance. This course aims to provide students with a solid software engineering foundation to support their further study. It focuses on providing introductory material to modelling, requirements engineering, testing and validation as well as formal methods. The course is incompatible with 1809ICT">1809ICT since 1809ICT">1809ICT has overlapping learning outcomes. Prerequisites: 1811ICT or 1806ICT or 1305ICT
Subject_Description_24: Electromagnetic Waves and Propagation is a lecture and laboratory based course in which students are introduced to tools and design techniques for engineering applications in which electromagnetic waves generated by sources of alternating current play a dominant role. These applications typically involve the transmission of waves over metallic or dielectric transmission lines or through free space, with the purpose of transporting either information or electric power.
Subject_Description_25: Web applications interact with users, connecting to back-end databases and dynamically generating results to the browser through a web server. This course presents a systematic introduction to the development of dynamic, community-based, Web applications through the integration of HTML/CSS, with client and server-side scripting languages, database systems, modern web frameworks and other related technologies. Pre-Requisite: 1810ICT Software Development Processes Co-Requisite: 1801ICT Programming Languages Incompatible: 3813ICT Software Frameworks
Subject_Description_26: This course covers fundamental and advanced topics in communications systems which are essential for Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Mechatronic Engineers, and Electronic and Biomedical Engineering. Knowledge on signals and systems, and Fourier transform is prerequisite for this course. Topics to be covered: (i) modulation AM, FM, (ii) digital modulation, digital transmission, (iii) introduction to mobile communications system and smart antennas, (iv) Wireless LANs, MIMO-OFDM for wireless, (v) Cellular Radio Communications, (vi) Microwave Engineering and communications, and (vii) introduction to Satellite Communications..
Subject_Description_27: Geotechnical Engineering forms a major part of the work of a professional civil engineer. This course is designed to enable students to do the analysis prior to design of foundations. It also forms an integral part of the civil analysis and design training provided in the four-year Bachelor of Engineering program in Civil Engineering. The course covers: design and construction aspects of shallow foundations, piled foundations, earth pressure calculations, and slope stability analysis. The main purpose of this course is to develop the ability of the students to design the basic geotechnical foundations (i.e., shallow foundation and piled foundation) and analyse the common geotechnical engineering problems (e.g., slope stability).
Subject_Description_28: The course introduces basic vector algebra in two and three dimensions, matrices, complex numbers, probability and revises basic functions. It provides a foundation in the mathematical sciences for later studies in science and engineering. Prior Assumed Knowledge: It will be assumed that students have the knowledge equivalent to a grade of SA over 4 semesters in Mathematics B (Qld high school subject), or equivalent study over 4 semesters of a high school subject that includes the study of differential and integral calculus or 1017SCG">1017SCG Foundation Mathematics (grade of 4 or higher). For students who do not have this level of mathematics background, it is strongly suggested that they first complete 1017SCG">1017SCG Foundation Mathematics. Incompatible: 1201SCG Linear Algebra, 1011SCG Mathematics 1A, 1201BPS Mathematics 1A, 1666NSC Mathematics 1A for Engineers.
Subject_Description_29: This course will combine an extension of the study of geomechanics to pavement engineering techniques with the principles of traffic flow theory and pavement engineering techniques so that students can apply them to practice. The course covers traffic flow models, headway models, traffic fundamental diagrams, intersection design and assessment, pavement engineering and design, pavement condition survey and pavement management. This course will be assessed by individual based assignment, mid trimester exam, and final exam.
Subject_Description_30: This course introduces students to the programming and interfacing of a modern microprocessor. The course outlines the theory behind microprocessors, with a focus on architecture, memory structures, and peripheral interfacing. The course also involves an insight into programming methodologies in assembler and illustrates ways of successfully debugging embedded systems. The course will give the student the background knowledge to successfully develop an embedded system using any microprocessor. The course is highly practical in approach and covers such areas as data acquisition, sensor interfacing, electronic control, and microprocessor communication protocols. Incompatible: 2010MEE Microprocessor Techniques AND 1073ENG Microprocessors AND 3323ENG MicroController Techniques
Subject_Description_31: This course has a major design project which further develops the practical engineering design skills students have already gained through the Environmental Engineering Design 1 and 2 courses. Students are required to design the basic infrastructure for a proposed site development with significant environmental issues to be addressed. The development of a cost effective and appropriate design solution and development of design and documentation skills are emphasised. The design project is carried out in teams, giving students the opportunity to experience the issues involved in working in teams towards a realistic project outcome. Advised Prerequisite: 4045 EVE - Environmental Engineering Design Project OR 3213ENG Environmental Engineering Design Project
Subject_Description_32: The course considers the fundamental properties of metals and non-metallic materials. Students are introduced to the atomic and microstructure of materials and their relationship to mechanical and electrical properties. The course explores the mechanical concepts of stress, strain, elongation and material failure (including testing) and the phenomenon of electrical conduction. This course will be offered from 2017 in trimester 1 and 3, and replaces 1502ENG.
Subject_Description_33: Heat and Mass Transfer gives the engineer a firm grounding in the fundamental processes of conduction, convection and radiation heat transfer. Topics covered include transient conduction, forced convection in internal and external flow, free convection, lumped heat capacity analysis, two and three-dimensional heat transfer, radiation exchange between surfaces, diffusion mass transfer, boiling, evaporation and condensation, and heat exchanger design & optimisation. Assessment is by assignments consisting of engineering problems in heat and mass transfer and a final examination. Incompatible: 3505ENG Heat and Mass Transfer
Subject_Description_34: This course introduces students to engineering design practice utilising real world design exercises. The course gives students a solid grounding in current engineering practice and emphasises the importance of incorporating sustainable approaches and sound practices to their designs. This course may involve individual or team approaches, depending on the nature of the design task. Incompatible: 2106ENG Design for Civil Engineers
Subject_Description_35: Hydrology is concerned with the distribution and dynamics of water and water quality on or near the surface of earth. As fundamental engineering sciences, hydrology plays an important role in developing technical skills in water engineering and in understanding many of the contemporary water management issues. The course covers fundamental hydrologic processes such as rainfall, evaporation, infiltration, surface and ground water, and hydrologic extremes ie floods and droughts. In addition, the course develops technical skills to apply some basic techniques for hydrologic analysis and design with particular emphasis on flood estimation, flood frequency analysis, and flood routing. Learning activities include lectures and workshops.
Subject_Description_36: This course provides an introduction to the basic concepts and practices of data analysis and inferential statistics. It will provide and understanding of several techniques including testing one or more means from sampled populations (t-Tests and ANOVAs), relationships between scale variables (correlations and regressions), and contingency table analysis (Chi-square tests). The course places emphasis on understanding the use of appropriate data for these tests, the use of exploratory data analysis and the underlying distributions and assumptions associated with these tests. Students will learn how to carry out these tests by hand, via the use of statistical software (SAS or SPSS), check assumptions, interpret results and report findings in plain English. Assumed prior knowledge: Grade 12 Maths A or B or equivalent. Incompatible: 1003ENV Statistics, 2012MSC Biostatistics, 2012HSC, Intro to Biomedical Data Analysis, Bioinformatics, 1003PSY Research Methods and Statistics in Psychology, 1002MSC Introduction to Biomedical Data Analysis
Subject_Description_37: Soil Mechanics is an important part of geotechnical engineering that deals with the engineering properties of various soils. This course provides students with valuable opportunities to develop their understanding of the fundamentals of soil behavior, and skills that will allow them to apply their knowledge to solve real-life problems. Students will also have the opportunity to become familiar with various testing procedures and learn how to perform laboratory tests to determine the geotechnical properties of soil such as grain-size distribution, plasticity, compaction characteristics, and permeability. After completing this course, students will acquire sufficient knowledge and develop critical skills that will enable them to solve practical problems related to soil mechanics
Subject_Description_38: Structural design forms a major part of the work of a professional civil engineer. This course is designed to enable students to do the prerequisite analysis prior to design. It also forms an integral part of the structural analysis and design training provided in the four-year Bachelor of Engineering program in Civil Engineering. This course provides a thorough coverage of the theoretical basis for linear analysis of various types of skeletal (planar) structures encountered in Civil Engineering design work. The main purpose of this course is to develop the ability of the students to analyse planar structures using manual and computer-based methods.
Subject_Description_39: This course is the final design project in the civil engineering programs. It builds on earlier design courses and other engineering knowledge. The course involves a major 'real world' design project where students are encouraged to work in teams, but are individually assessed. Students are also exposed to the project management aspects of engineering projects. The course brings together and further enhances a range of generic skills such as teamwork, problem solving and communication.
Subject_Description_40: This course covers the concepts and components of electrical circuits and develops the fundamental circuit analysis and fault finding skills necessary to understand all electrical circuits. Circuit components such as resistors, capacitors and inductors and non-linear components such as diodes are studied progressing onto rectifiers, comparators and A/D and D/A converters. Analysis techniques include Kirchoff's laws, Thevenin/Norton equivalent circuits, time response of energy storage elements, sinusoidal steady state and frequency-domain analysis.

Course: Bachelor of Engineering (Honours)/Bachelor of Data Science
Description: As factories and other engineering environments transform into an industrial Internet of Things, the ability to analyse vast quantities of data to extract relevant intelligence is an increasingly and highly sought-after skill. Data science provides a broad knowledge of the exploration, gathering, manipulation, visualisation, automation and interpretation of data using digital platforms and can be applied to enable real-time performance optimisation. This double degree will enable you to provide data-based insights based on your specific expertise in engineering, to improve decision-making, reduce costs and increase efficiencies. You'll gain knowledge in your chosen engineering major and skills to access the insights large data sets provide and lead the way in translating data into actionable information, including manipulation, modelling, interpretation and visualisation, using a range of digital platforms and tools. In your final year, you can enhance your employability through an industry placement to gain practical experience and valuable industry networks. You'll also graduate with a degree accredited by the national engineering body (Engineers Australia) and be fully equipped to work in local, national and international sectors.
Career_Outcomes:
Civil Engineering
Civil engineers provide a major contribution to society by supporting the design and development of essential services, and by managing and improving the built environment. Demand for civil engineering professionals has grown and is expected to continue be an area of high demand. You will find employment in jobs such as chief civil engineer, construction engineer, municipal engineer, structural engineer, transport engineer, water supply distribution engineer, project manager and consulting engineer. Electronic Engineering
Our graduates find opportunities in Australia and overseas undertaking the research, design, development and manufacture of electronic systems. You may also find work with employers who specialise in computer-based hardware and software systems. You will be equipped for a career in areas such as communications, including satellite navigation, broadband services and telecommunications, energy production, and transport control systems development. If you specialise in microelectronics you can also look to work in microelectronics design and fabrication. You will find employment in many multinational companies, as well as in specialist technology companies. Environmental Engineering
Environmental professionals with strong ecological social science backgrounds are in demand both in Australia and internationally. You will find opportunities in government departments such as Transport and Main Roads, Natural Resources and Mines, Department of Science, IT and the Arts (DSITIA) and Environment and Resource Management. You will also enjoy opportunities with consulting firms in the construction, mining, oil, smelting and manufacturing industries, as well as with local government and research organisations. Mechanical Engineering
Mechanical engineering is the most diverse of all the engineering disciplines, which means you will be able to use your skills in a variety of avenues including design, research, development or production. As a graduate, you will be qualified for a career in medical, automotive, aerospace, renewable energy, marine and sports-related sectors. Software Engineering
As a graduate, you will be prepared for a career in software development and be equipped to meet the demands of the rapidly changing software industry. You will find employment as a software architect, software developer, software engineer, software tester, IT project manager, systems analyst, security specialist, computational scientist, programmer, networking and communications specialist, and in research and development.
  Not all engineering graduates work as engineers - the transferrable skills and methodology developed through your degree provide a springboard to any career where critical thinking, the ability to analyse and investigate new information and evidenced-based decision making are valued. Data Science
Never have we collected so much data about absolutely everything. From things that happen naturally, like climate change or the birth of galaxies, to all the social businesses, individual movements, corporate decisions and human activities.
