Complex problem solving involves an understanding of individuals and systems, interconnections and innovation. Furthermore these solutions must also be considered in terms of sustainable development. This course introduces the student to engineering design through a project-based approach to the development of a product or piece of infrastructure as part of small design team.
Subject_Description_12: This course has a major design project which further develops the practical engineering design skills students have already gained through the Environmental Engineering Design 1 and 2 courses. Students are required to design the basic infrastructure for a proposed site development with significant environmental issues to be addressed. The development of a cost effective and appropriate design solution and development of design and documentation skills are emphasised. The design project is carried out in teams, giving students the opportunity to experience the issues involved in working in teams towards a realistic project outcome. Advised Prerequisite: 4045 EVE - Environmental Engineering Design Project OR 3213ENG Environmental Engineering Design Project
Subject_Description_13: Mechanical Engineering Design is the creative development of mechanical products or systems. This course focuses on mechanical design through a project based learning approach. Students will work on a design and analyse (and/or build) project, developing a solution to a real-world engineering design problem. Assessment is by a written design report, oral presentation/s and peer group assessment when relevant.
Subject_Description_14: This course is the final design project in the civil engineering programs. It builds on earlier design courses and other engineering knowledge. The course involves a major 'real world' design project where students are encouraged to work in teams, but are individually assessed. Students are also exposed to the project management aspects of engineering projects. The course brings together and further enhances a range of generic skills such as teamwork, problem solving and communication.
Subject_Description_15: The capstone engineering project is undertaken in the final year of the program. Students are required to plan, execute and report on a research project with some independence while working with an academic supervisor who maintains regular contact and provides support and direction in the design and execution of the research. Projects based on industry requirements will be encouraged.
Subject_Description_16: The course introduces the foundations of Big Data in a manner that covers the key concepts and characteristics of big data analytics and its real-world application. Students will learn about the practical applications needed to perform analytical tasks with the primary focus being on the visualisation and representation of that data. THIS COURSE WILL BE OFFERED IN SEMI-INTENSIVE MODE (WEEK 1 TO 6) IN TRIMESTER 2, 2020.
Subject_Description_17: This course provides a broad coverage and detailed discussion of principles and practices of technology and standards, and security protocols for computer networks. It covers topics related to the fundamental concepts needed to understand security in modern networking applications, including cryptography, digital signatures, authentication, access control, trust and privacy. An introduction to a selection of technologies and application areas is given. Current challenges that confront security designers and security administrators, identifying threats, evaluating risks, developing countermeasures are discussed. Security related to wireless networks and cloud, security models and vulnerabilities are also covered. Prerequisite: 1007ICT Computer Systems and Networks OR 1807ICT Computer and Network Architecture.
Subject_Description_18: This course introduces students to four fundamental engineering concepts related to electrical and electronic engineering: storage of electrical energy and transport of an electrical charge, interconnection of passive components to make small or large systems, operation of systems under conditions of constant electrical load or excitation, and the operation of systems under conditions of variable electrical load or excitation. The concepts are studied using the physical processes within the components and circuits of electrical systems in a practical context. Incompatible: 1005ENG Electronics for Engineers.
Subject_Description_19: This course provides an in-depth knowledge of physical, data link and network layer technologies of modern wireless communications. The emphasis is on principles and protocols concerning the lower layers of the OSI model. Prerequisite: 7611ICT Computer Systems and Networks
Subject_Description_20: This course will cover important concepts in Data Mining including generating new information, discover patterns, and unlock actionable insights from data. Students will be introduced to techniques and tools in mining associative and sequential patterns, abnormality detection, correlation analysis, clustering, and forecasting.
Subject_Description_21: The course will initially explore topics in relation to generic data communications, including: OSI model; PSTN modem technology ; Error correction ; Data compression ; Physical layer standards; Line codes ; Signals in noise ; Idle RQ and continuous RQ ; Link utilisation ; Link layer protocols ; Data over terrestrial and satellite radio. The second half of the course will look specifically at topics related to the application to computer networks, including: Network topologies; Network bearers and physical attachment ; LANs and WANs; CSMA and token protocols ; Networking protocol performance ; Bridges and routing ; Encryption and compression; Internet protocols ; SSL. A series of laboratories will cover relevant topics, in particular related to signals and performance of data systems. Please check the "assumed knowledge" for this course under the course profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment.
Subject_Description_22: This course provides some of the essential mathematical techniques to mathematicians and physical scientists, and applies them to scientific problems. The course covers basic material on multiple integrals of scalar functions as well as line and surface integrals of vector fields, the theorems of Gauss, Green and Stokes, Fourier series and integrals. It also introduces some of the common partial differential equations of applied mathematics and methods of solution mostly based on separation of variables. It also covers some topics on ordinary differential equations. Incompatible: 2001ENG Advanced ENG Mathematics, 2203NSC Mathematics 2A. Prerequisites: 1201SCG">1201SCG Linear Algebra and 1202SCG Calculus I. (Please note: for students enrolled in Program 1567 1201SCG">1201SCG Linear Algebra is a co-requisite). Students must pass both courses to enrol in 2205NSC.
Subject_Description_23: The Course introduces students to advanced materials and their applications with the aim to deepen their understanding about i) how materials properties guide materials selection at the product design stage, ii) how core materials properties (either surface- or bulk properties) are changed, adapted or mended to specific user environment and/or an application field through a variety of manufacturing methods, and iii) how commercial material objects (or products) are manufactured in a factory setting. The Course will endue students with relevant knowledge on current materials surface technology, material treatment processes and manufacturing and production system processes, process technology and manufacturing systems design. Additive and rapid prototyping technology and lean engineering/lean production will be also be discussed in this Course. The Course is designed for 3rd year engineering students that already possess university-level fundamental knowledge on properties of common engineering materials such as metals, polymers, ceramics and attained theoretical and practical knowledge on fabrication and processing methods for these materials. The Course is developed to provide a practical, project-based immersion into materials selection process (with real, commercial products used as study samples) where students will learn how initial material selection process effects the geometry, structure, performance and cost of a final product. Assessment is by group assignment, oral presentation and individual examination. Please check the "Assumed Knowledge" for this course under the Course Profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. Incompatible: 2506ENG Materials and Manufacturing
Subject_Description_24: This course introduces students to common computer software packages and develops their computing skills. The course introduces students to basic data analysis and numerical modelling techniques, and prepares students to solve engineering problems using off-shelf computer packages and software. This course includes project-based learning involving laboratory measurement.
Subject_Description_25: Mobile technologies are fast becoming ubiquitous and are being used to meet a diversity of purposes from business and industry, to education, entertainment and medical applications. In this course, students work with popular mobile application development environments and methods to create mobile applications. In so doing, students build the knowledge and skills necessary to develop native mobile applications that exploit the device capabilities including camera, compass, gestures, and sensors such as accelerometer to create effective and highly interactive mobile applications. Pre-requisite: 2807ICT">2807ICT Programming Principles or 2701ICT Interactive Application Development Incompatible: 2501ICT Programming Mobile Applications Note: for students who have already completed 1305ENG or 1806ICT, 2807ICT">2807ICT can be completed as a co-requisite with (at the same time as) 3701ICT
Subject_Description_26: This experiential learning course introduces students to the engineering design process and professional aspects of being an Engineer or Industrial Designer. The course takes into consideration the increasingly complex interactions between engineering systems, project stakeholders and the environment, including the positive role of engineering in sustainable development as well as the potentially adverse impacts of engineering activities. Exposure to engineers and designers who are in the workforce will be a feature of this course.
Subject_Description_27: Hydrology is concerned with the distribution and dynamics of water and water quality on or near the surface of earth. As fundamental engineering sciences, hydrology plays an important role in developing technical skills in water engineering and in understanding many of the contemporary water management issues. The course covers fundamental hydrologic processes such as rainfall, evaporation, infiltration, surface and ground water, and hydrologic extremes ie floods and droughts. In addition, the course develops technical skills to apply some basic techniques for hydrologic analysis and design with particular emphasis on flood estimation, flood frequency analysis, and flood routing. Learning activities include lectures and workshops.
Subject_Description_28: Structural design forms a major part of the work of a professional civil engineer. This course is designed to enable students to do the prerequisite analysis prior to design. It also forms an integral part of the structural analysis and design training provided in the four-year Bachelor of Engineering program in Civil Engineering. This course provides a thorough coverage of the theoretical basis for linear analysis of various types of skeletal (planar) structures encountered in Civil Engineering design work. The main purpose of this course is to develop the ability of the students to analyse planar structures using manual and computer-based methods.
Subject_Description_29: This course extends the theoretical and practical content of the course 2305ENG Signals and Systems and covers fundamental topics in digital signal processing (DSP) such as A/D and D/A converters, analysis of discrete-time signals and systems, design of finite impulse response (FIR) and infinite impulse response (IIR) digital filters, multirate digital signal processing, etc. MATLAB (software) and digital signal processor boards (hardware) are used to provide hands-on experience to students. This course is planned to be offered for the last time in 2016 at the Gold Coast campus. The Nathan campus offering will continue as normal beyond 2016. Gold Coast students please consult your program director for a suitable alternative. Incompatible: 6321ENG
Subject_Description_30: This course introduces the fundamental concepts of electronics from the systems and signals perspective. Hardware implementations, such as A/D and D/A converters, rectifiers, wave-shaping circuits, and amplifiers are developed by making use of operational amplifiers, diodes, resistors, and capacitors to emphasise the system-building concepts (feedback, frequency response, transfer characteristics, impedance matching, and analysis by equivalent circuits). Circuit simulation (using SPICE) is used concurrently with real circuits and measurements to establish links between theory and practice. Incompatibles: 1005MEE Electronic Devices, Circuits and Systems AND 1031MEE Introduction to Electronics. Advised Prerequisites: 1301ENG Electric Circuits
Subject_Description_31: The course introduces students to the theory and practice of control systems. It discusses the basic (introductory) methods of control systems analysis and design, with emphasis on the principle of negative feedback which is the essence of operation of control systems. Engineering examples are used to introduce and illustrate the usefulness of the control systems theory and to make the students aware of this important engineering area. Assessment is by lab preliminaries, reports on laboratory experiments, and a final examination.
Subject_Description_32: This course introduces the basic semiconductor concepts, the principles of diode and transistor operation, and the fundamental transistor circuits (common amplifier topologies, op-amp building blocks, and low-frequency amplifiers). Circuit simulation (SPICE) with appropriately set device parameters and simplified equivalent circuits are used for circuit analysis. Circuit design is based on circuit analysis and is facilitated by an understanding of semiconductor properties and device operation. Laboratory exercises will complement the teaching approach for this course. Incompatible: 2030MEE Microelectronic Circuits Prerequisites: 1301ENG Electric Circuits and 1302ENG Introduction to Electronics
Subject_Description_33: Mechanics of Materials 2 provides techniques by which engineers can determine stress and strain distributions resulting from known loading conditions, so that the stability and strength of structural members under load can be examined. The learners will acquire the knowledge in the analysis and design of structures and machines under load.
Subject_Description_34: Stress analysis (also known as solid mechanics) provides techniques by which engineers can predict stress and strain distributions resulting from known loading conditions, so that the stability and strength of structural members and machine components under load can be assessed. Stress analysis is an essential tool in the analysis and design of structures and machines under load.
Subject_Description_35: Information derived from data is important to the management, productivity and competitive advantage of an organisation. Data must be efficiently collected, organized, retrieved and managed to make it meaningful to the organisation. It is the role of the IT professional to develop, deploy, manage and integrate data and information systems to support the organisation. This course includes the organisation, modeling, transformation and presentation of data. Incompatible with 1804ICT.
Subject_Description_36: A key component to the discipline of Information Technology is the understanding and the advocacy of the user in the development of IT applications and systems. IT graduates must develop a mind-set that recognizes the importance of users and organisational contexts and employ user-centred methodologies in the development, evaluation, and deployment of IT applications and systems. This requires graduates to develop knowledge of HCI, including user and task analysis, human factors, ergonomics, application domains, user interface development tools and GUI frameworks, accessibility standards, and cognitive psychology.
Subject_Description_37: This course introduces students to the basic concepts and principles of thermodynamics, and its selected engineering applications. Topics include the first law of thermodynamics, volumetric properties of pure substances, heat effects, the second law of thermodynamics, thermodynamic properties of fluids, and thermodynamic analysis of processes.
Subject_Description_38: Traditional IT project management approaches work well under stable conditions, when intended project outcomes are well understood. Yet, under conditions of delivering value to clients early, in innovation projects, or new product development, traditional methods of software development are often too restrictive and inflexible. This course offers an alternative approach to software development that values flexibility, time-to-market and self-organisation over rigorous planning and processes. This course is based on the IIBA's Agile Extension to the BABOK. Pre-requisites: 140CP and 1802ICT Foundations of Systems Development
Subject_Description_39: Kinematics & Dynamics equips graduates with a solid understanding of the key concepts of mechanics required for design and analysis of mechanisms and mechanical devices. Topics covered include kinematics and dynamics of mechanical components modelled as particles and plane rigid bodies, interconnected objects, rotational dynamics, work and energy methods, translating and rotating coordinate systems, vector methods, three-dimensional dynamics of rigid bodies and an introduction to vibration Please check the "assumed knowledge" for this course under the course profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. This course is planned to be offered for the first time in 2018, trimester 1 and replaces 3317ENG.
Subject_Description_40: Coding is an important part of today's world. In this course you will learn how to code in a creative context, utilising a practical and hands-on approach, producing generative art, data visualisations, and interactive interfaces.

Course: Bachelor of Engineering (Honours)/Bachelor of Data Science
Description: As factories and other engineering environments transform into an industrial Internet of Things, the ability to analyse vast quantities of data to extract relevant intelligence is an increasingly and highly sought-after skill. Data science provides a broad knowledge of the exploration, gathering, manipulation, visualisation, automation and interpretation of data using digital platforms and can be applied to enable real-time performance optimisation. This double degree will enable you to provide data-based insights based on your specific expertise in engineering, to improve decision-making, reduce costs and increase efficiencies. You'll gain knowledge in your chosen engineering major and skills to access the insights large data sets provide and lead the way in translating data into actionable information including manipulation, modelling, interpretation and visualisation, using a range of digital platforms and tools. In your final year, you can enhance your employability through an industry placement to gain practical experience and valuable industry networks. You'll also graduate with a degree accredited by the national engineering body (Engineers Australia) and be fully equipped to work in local, national and international sectors.
Career_Outcomes:
Civil Engineering
  Civil engineers provide a major contribution to society by supporting the design and development of essential services, and by managing and improving the built environment. Demand for civil engineering professionals has grown and is expected to continue be an area of high demand. You will find employment in jobs such as chief civil engineer, construction engineer, municipal engineer, structural engineer, transport engineer, water supply distribution engineer, project manager and consulting engineer. Electrical and Electronic Engineering
  Electrical devices reach into all aspects of our lives in the form of heating and cooling, lighting and power, communications and computing, entertainment and information systems. As a graduate you will be prepared to work in any of these areas. Electrical and electronic engineers work with senior administrators, civil and mechanical engineers, computer scientists and various workers in the business, building and construction industries. The essential nature of an electrical engineers' role places them in the position to influence the development and application of new and emerging technologies. This includes the fast-growing energy industry. You could work to incorporate locally generated renewable energy resources into our more conventional supply systems, helping to reduce costs, save energy and alleviate global warming. Electrical and electronic engineering is a career for people who want to make a difference. Mechanical Engineering
  Mechanical engineering is the most diverse of all the engineering disciplines, which means you will be able to use your skills in a variety of avenues including design, research, development or production. As a graduate, you will be qualified for a career in medical, automotive, aerospace, renewable energy, marine and sports-related sectors. Software Engineering
  As a graduate, you will be prepared for a career in software development and be equipped to meet the demands of the rapidly changing software industry. You will find employment as a software architect, software developer, software engineer, software tester, IT project manager, systems analyst, security specialist, computational scientist, programmer, networking and communications specialist, and in research and development.
  Not all engineering graduates work as engineers - the transferrable skills and methodology developed through your degree provide a springboard to any career where critical thinking, the ability to analyse and investigate new information and evidenced-based decision making are valued. Data Science
  Never have we collected so much data about absolutely everything. From things that happen naturally, like climate change or the birth of galaxies, to all the social businesses, individual movements, corporate decisions and human activities. The data is there for its exploitation by machine learning technology, bid data, data mining and other artificial intelligence technologies that coupled with traditional statistical analysis enable to produce insights into the future. Nothing is more valuable than anticipation. Thus, data scientist are finding jobs in all disciplines.
Subject_Description_1: Mechanical Engineering Design is the creative development of mechanical products or systems. This course focuses on mechanical design through a project based learning approach. Students will work on a design and analyse (and/or build) project, developing a solution to a real-world engineering design problem. Assessment is by a written design report, oral presentation/s and peer group assessment when relevant.
Subject_Description_2: Heat and Mass Transfer gives the engineer a firm grounding in the fundamental processes of conduction, convection and radiation heat transfer. Topics covered include transient conduction, forced convection in internal and external flow, free convection, lumped heat capacity analysis, two and three-dimensional heat transfer, radiation exchange between surfaces, diffusion mass transfer, boiling, evaporation and condensation, and heat exchanger design & optimisation. Assessment is by assignments consisting of engineering problems in heat and mass transfer and a final examination. Incompatible: 3505ENG Heat and Mass Transfer
Subject_Description_3: Geotechnical Engineering forms a major part of the work of a professional civil engineer. This course is designed to enable students to do the analysis prior to design of foundations. It also forms an integral part of the civil analysis and design training provided in the four-year Bachelor of Engineering program in Civil Engineering. The course covers: design and construction aspects of shallow foundations, piled foundations, earth pressure calculations, and slope stability analysis. The main purpose of this course is to develop the ability of the students to design the basic geotechnical foundations (i.e., shallow foundation and piled foundation) and analyse the common geotechnical engineering problems (e.g., slope stability).
Subject_Description_4: Electromagnetic Waves and Propagation is a lecture and laboratory based course in which students are introduced to tools and design techniques for engineering applications in which electromagnetic waves generated by sources of alternating current play a dominant role. These applications typically involve the transmission of waves over metallic or dielectric transmission lines or through free space, with the purpose of transporting either information or electric power.
Subject_Description_5: This course introduces students to engineering design practice utilising real world design exercises. The course gives students a solid grounding in current engineering practice and emphasises the importance of incorporating sustainable approaches and sound practices to their designs. This course may involve individual or team approaches, depending on the nature of the design task. Incompatible: 2106ENG Design for Civil Engineers
Subject_Description_6: This course introduces students to the process of structural design including: dealing with a client and defining a design brief, load estimation, elementary structural analysis and the design of timber and steel members and connections using the relevant Australian Standard design codes.
Subject_Description_7: This course is the final design project in the civil engineering programs. It builds on earlier design courses and other engineering knowledge. The course involves a major 'real world' design project where students are encouraged to work in teams, but are individually assessed. Students are also exposed to the project management aspects of engineering projects. The course brings together and further enhances a range of generic skills such as teamwork, problem solving and communication.
Subject_Description_8: Programming is a foundational skill for all computing disciplines. This course develops skills and concepts that are essential to good programming practice and problem solving. It covers fundamental programming concepts, event-driven programming, object-oriented programming, basic data structures, and algorithmic processes.
Subject_Description_9: The course revises and extends basic integral and differential calculus of one variable and introduces differential equations. It provides a foundation in the mathematical sciences needed for later studies both in an engineering and science context. This course is for Engineering or ICT students ONLY. Incompatible: 1202SCG Calculus I
Subject_Description_10: This course covers the principles of electric motors and generators. Both DC and AC motors and generators are explored along with the application of single and multi-phase machines. State of the art drive, control and protection circuitry will also be considered along with solid state methods of providing AC supply. Practical work will enhance the understanding of these topics. Please check the "assumed knowledge" for this course under the course profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. This course will be offered from 2018 at the Gold Coast campus, in trimester 2, and replaces 6509ENG.
Subject_Description_11: Engineering Programming is an introductory course to computer programming. It uses the C language to teach basic programming structure, flow and syntax. It also includes a module on the similar language used by the MATLAB package. Incompatible: 2312ENG C Programming and Computer Architecture. From 2017 this course will be offered in trimester 2 at both the Gold Coast and Nathan campuses.
Subject_Description_12: This course deals with continuous-time signals and systems and is designed to build on the basic circuit analysis concepts covered in the course Electric Circuits. It provides a detailed study of continuous-time signals and systems in time domain as well as in transformed domain. Signal transforms (Fourier series, Fourier transform and Laplace transforms) are covered in detail. Further concepts such as signal sampling and aliasing are introduced. The theory is exemplified with processing of signals in MATLAB. Incompatible: 2006MEE Signals and Systems AND 2075ENG Signals and Systems
Subject_Description_13: This course provides an in-depth knowledge of physical, data link and network layer technologies of modern wireless communications. The emphasis is on principles and protocols concerning the lower layers of the OSI model. Prerequisite: 7611ICT Computer Systems and Networks
Subject_Description_14: Structural design forms a major part of the work of a professional civil engineer. This course is designed to enable students to do the prerequisite analysis prior to design. It also forms an integral part of the structural analysis and design training provided in the four-year Bachelor of Engineering program in Civil Engineering. This course provides a thorough coverage of the theoretical basis for linear analysis of various types of skeletal (planar) structures encountered in Civil Engineering design work. The main purpose of this course is to develop the ability of the students to analyse planar structures using manual and computer-based methods.
Subject_Description_15: This course mainly covers the analysis and design of reinforced and prestressed concrete structural elements. Both strength and serviceability design requirements are covered. Problem solving exercises based on actual design situations are utilised extensively in this course. After completing this course students will be able to analyse and design structural concrete elements and structures. Assessment is by, tutorial and design assignments, and examinations.
Subject_Description_16: Traditional IT project management approaches work well under stable conditions, when intended project outcomes are well understood. Yet, under conditions of delivering value to clients early, in innovation projects, or new product development, traditional methods of software development are often too restrictive and inflexible. This course offers an alternative approach to software development that values flexibility, time-to-market and self-organisation over rigorous planning and processes. This course is based on the IIBA's Agile Extension to the BABOK. Pre-requisites: 140CP and 1802ICT Foundations of Systems Development
Subject_Description_17: The capstone engineering project is undertaken in the final year of the program. Students are required to plan, execute and report on a research project with some independence while working with an academic supervisor who maintains regular contact and provides support and direction in the design and execution of the research. Projects based on industry requirements will be encouraged.
Subject_Description_18: This course introduces students to four fundamental engineering concepts related to electrical and electronic engineering: storage of electrical energy and transport of an electrical charge, interconnection of passive components to make small or large systems, operation of systems under conditions of constant electrical load or excitation, and the operation of systems under conditions of variable electrical load or excitation. The concepts are studied using the physical processes within the components and circuits of electrical systems in a practical context. Incompatible: 1005ENG Electronics for Engineers.
Subject_Description_19: This course introduces students to the programming and interfacing of a modern microprocessor. The course outlines the theory behind microprocessors, with a focus on architecture, memory structures, and peripheral interfacing. The course also involves an insight into programming methodologies in assembler and illustrates ways of successfully debugging embedded systems. The course will give the student the background knowledge to successfully develop an embedded system using any microprocessor. The course is highly practical in approach and covers such areas as data acquisition, sensor interfacing, electronic control, and microprocessor communication protocols. Incompatible: 2010MEE Microprocessor Techniques AND 1073ENG Microprocessors AND 3323ENG MicroController Techniques
Subject_Description_20: Hydrology is concerned with the distribution and dynamics of water and water quality on or near the surface of earth. As fundamental engineering sciences, hydrology plays an important role in developing technical skills in water engineering and in understanding many of the contemporary water management issues. The course covers fundamental hydrologic processes such as rainfall, evaporation, infiltration, surface and ground water, and hydrologic extremes ie floods and droughts. In addition, the course develops technical skills to apply some basic techniques for hydrologic analysis and design with particular emphasis on flood estimation, flood frequency analysis, and flood routing. Learning activities include lectures and workshops.
Subject_Description_21: Electrical Design Project is a practical project based course in which students are challenged to apply fundamental knowledge of analogue and digital components, circuitry and systems to design, implement and demonstrate a functional electronic device meeting prescribed system requirements. Students are guided through a systematic design process involving analysis of requirements, circuit design and simulation, component selection, prototype construction, testing, evaluation and revision. An integral part of the process is the production and maintenance of engineering documentation in the form of technical specifications, schematic diagrams, list of components, test procedures and performance results. Incompatible: 3312ENG Practical Electronics I
Subject_Description_22: This course introduces students to the basic concepts and principles of thermodynamics, and its selected engineering applications. Topics include the first law of thermodynamics, volumetric properties of pure substances, heat effects, the second law of thermodynamics, thermodynamic properties of fluids, and thermodynamic analysis of processes.
Subject_Description_23: This course provides the fundamental knowledge of fluid mechanics and hydraulics including fluid properties, fluid statics, conservation of mass, energy equation, flow in conduits, pumps and turbines, flow around objects, open channel flow and compressible flow.
Subject_Description_24: The course introduces students to the theory and practice of control systems. It discusses the basic (introductory) methods of control systems analysis and design, with emphasis on the principle of negative feedback which is the essence of operation of control systems. Engineering examples are used to introduce and illustrate the usefulness of the control systems theory and to make the students aware of this important engineering area. Assessment is by lab preliminaries, reports on laboratory experiments, and a final examination.
Subject_Description_25: The course introduces students to the concepts of Information Systems Architecture (ISA) and demonstrates how Information Systems, Engineering and Management views can be unified by an enterprise architecture approach. The course covers relevant international standards (ISO15704, ISO42010) and discusses frequently used industry frameworks (TOGAF, DoDAF, etc). Pre-Requisite: 2511ICT Business Analysis or 3812ICT Agile Business Analysis
Subject_Description_26: Stress analysis (also known as solid mechanics) provides techniques by which engineers can predict stress and strain distributions resulting from known loading conditions, so that the stability and strength of structural members and machine components under load can be assessed. Stress analysis is an essential tool in the analysis and design of structures and machines under load.
Subject_Description_27: Engineering mechanics is both a foundation and a framework for most engineering disciplines. This course provides a basic knowledge of Newtonian mechanics, rigid-body mechanics, elasticity and structural analysis. In particular, the principles of statics and their applications in engineering, the methods of static analysis, and techniques of engineering computation are expounded. Students are expected not only to acquire a good grasp of the principles but also to develop the computational and analytical skills which are vital in obtaining correct engineering solutions. In practice, a wrong solution can lead to an engineering disaster. This course is designed to enable students to acquire fundamental knowledge in engineering. It forms an integral part of the analysis and design training provided in the Engineering programs. This course is offered in trimester 2 and 3 at both the Gold Coast and Nathan campuses.
Subject_Description_28: The course considers the fundamental properties of metals and non-metallic materials. Students are introduced to the atomic and microstructure of materials and their relationship to mechanical and electrical properties. The course explores the mechanical concepts of stress, strain, elongation and material failure (including testing) and the phenomenon of electrical conduction. This course will be offered from 2017 in trimester 1 and 3, and replaces 1502ENG.
Subject_Description_29: This course covers the concepts and components of electrical circuits and develops the fundamental circuit analysis and fault finding skills necessary to understand all electrical circuits. Circuit components such as resistors, capacitors and inductors and non-linear components such as diodes are studied progressing onto rectifiers, comparators and A/D and D/A converters. Analysis techniques include Kirchoff's laws, Thevenin/Norton equivalent circuits, time response of energy storage elements, sinusoidal steady state and frequency-domain analysis.
Subject_Description_30: The main aim of this course is to provide sound knowledge of the principles and practices of digital systems, both at the device and circuit level. The course covers topics in digital electronics including: Number Theory, Boolean Algebra, Logic Circuits, Logic Minimisation Techniques, Multiplexers, Adders, Flip-Flops, Counters, Registers, State Machines, Memory Circuits, Digital / Analog Conversion, Programable Logic Circuits and Microcomputer Bus Architecture. Incompatible: 1004MEE Digital Networks and Systems AND 2072ENG Digital Systems AND 1303ENG Digital Systems
Subject_Description_31: Information derived from data is important to the management, productivity and competitive advantage of an organisation. Data must be efficiently collected, organized, retrieved and managed to make it meaningful to the organisation. It is the role of the IT professional to develop, deploy, manage and integrate data and information systems to support the organisation. This course includes the organisation, modeling, transformation and presentation of data. Incompatible with 1804ICT.
Subject_Description_32: This course provides a practical and theoretical introduction to manufacturing technology with a primary focus on metal processing technologies and their applications in modern manufacturing industry. The course is designed for the 2nd year engineering students that already possess university-level fundamental knowledge about the properties of common engineering materials, the application of forces in engineering systems and have a basic understanding about the tools, machines and processes employed in fabrication of engineered products.
Subject_Description_33: Mathematics underpins and informs all scientific fields and is the language of science. Quantitative Reasoning is a mathematics course with a difference. Students will learn how to translate scientific problems into mathematical form, and how to understand and interpret mathematical and numerical results. With modern software, they will use case studies to learn how to apply mathematical concepts, from basics up to simple calculus, to real-world scientific problems. Incompatible: 1013SCG
Subject_Description_34: This course introduces students to common computer software packages and develops their computing skills. The course introduces students to basic data analysis and numerical modelling techniques, and prepares students to solve engineering problems using off-shelf computer packages and software. This course includes project-based learning involving laboratory measurement.
Subject_Description_35: This course explores the major ethical, professional, social and legal issues arising from the widespread use of IT, highlighting dilemmas that may be faced by IT practitioners. The subject examines the key debates and controversies pertinent to IT and their social consequences through the use of key case studies. *This course replaces 2003ICT Professional Issues in IT. Prerequisite: Successful completion of 120CP of first or second year Information Technology /Multimedia courses
Subject_Description_36: The course introduces the foundations of Big Data in a manner that covers the key concepts and characteristics of big data analytics and its real-world application. Students will learn about the practical applications needed to perform analytical tasks with the primary focus being on the visualisation and representation of that data. THIS COURSE WILL BE OFFERED IN SEMI-INTENSIVE MODE (WEEK 1 TO 6) IN TRIMESTER 2, 2020.
Subject_Description_37: As an engineer you will be faced with problems that require you to devise innovative and practical solutions. Some problems may be simple and you will solve them drawing on knowledge you acquired through your course of study or using your accumulated experiences. On the other hand, there will be cases where your experience and academic training are not sufficient. In these cases, you will need to engage in research. Being able to source valid and credible information and analyse information statistically in order to formulate viable solutions is an important skill that all engineers need and which Engineers Australia expects you to have. The research and statistics skills you learn in this course will also help you throughout your studies at Griffith University. Research is a key component in Undergraduate degrees at Griffith University. Moreover, the skills learnt in this course are of vital importance to students who intend to pursue higher degree research studies. Therefore, this course aims to equip you with the skills needed to conduct valid research and statistical analysis be it in academic or industrial practice context.
Subject_Description_38: This course will combine an extension of the study of geomechanics to pavement engineering techniques with the principles of traffic flow theory and pavement engineering techniques so that students can apply them to practice. The course covers traffic flow models, headway models, traffic fundamental diagrams, intersection design and assessment, pavement engineering and design, pavement condition survey and pavement management. This course will be assessed by individual based assignment, mid trimester exam, and final exam.
Subject_Description_39: This course provides some of the essential mathematical techniques to mathematicians and physical scientists, and applies them to scientific problems. The course covers basic material on multiple integrals of scalar functions as well as line and surface integrals of vector fields, the theorems of Gauss, Green and Stokes, Fourier series and integrals. It also introduces some of the common partial differential equations of applied mathematics and methods of solution mostly based on separation of variables. It also covers some topics on ordinary differential equations. Incompatible: 2001ENG Advanced ENG Mathematics, 2203NSC Mathematics 2A. Prerequisites: 1201SCG">1201SCG Linear Algebra and 1202SCG Calculus I. (Please note: for students enrolled in Program 1567 1201SCG">1201SCG Linear Algebra is a co-requisite). Students must pass both courses to enrol in 2205NSC.
Subject_Description_40: This course will cover important concepts in Data Analytics including preparing, processing, normalizing, modeling, and visualizing data with the goal of summarizing useful information and supporting decision-making. It will introduce students to techniques and tools in data processing, exploratory data analytics, statistical data analytics, visual data analytics, analytics for special types of data. This course will be first offered in 2021 only

Course: Bachelor of Engineering (Honours)/Bachelor of Environmental Science
Description: With this double degree, you can tackle environmental issues with knowledge  across both engineering and science. With specialist skills in the social, applied and natural sciences, you'll be well prepared to find solutions to pressing environmental issues. With a strong practical focus, you'll develop skills in the planning, design, management, construction and maintenance of engineering projects as well as a solid foundation in biological, physical and social sciences and critical analysis. This is your opportunity to make a real difference to the big environmental issues facing the planet, bringing a fresh perspective and proven skills to the challenges ahead.  From year one, you'll be learning from industry experts and like-minded teachers. Hands-on experience is key to this double degree, and in your final year you can enhance your knowledge through an industry-based project or placement.  You'll have several options available when you graduate as either an engineer or an environmental scientist. This degree could lead to a career in civil, environmental, mechanical or electrical engineering. Your environmental science degree will offer up rewarding careers such as an environmental officer, environmental consultant, wildlife biologist, conservation ecologist or environmental chemist.   Changes effective for students commencing from Trimester 2 2020 onwards: Engineering Environmental Science Tailor your timetable - Even if you study full-time on-campus, you may still be able to customise your degree to suit your needs. From a range of tutorial times to online access to lectures and other course material, we're here to help you fit study in with your work and life commitments.   Students may be eligible to do an international field trip, organised by the academic staff. This may count towards a component of the degree. Visit Go Global Griffith for more information.
Career_Outcomes: Key employment sectors* Potential job outcomes *Source: Australian Government Job Outlook
Subject_Description_1: This course introduces students to the basic concepts and principles of thermodynamics, and its selected engineering applications. Topics include the first law of thermodynamics, volumetric properties of pure substances, heat effects, the second law of thermodynamics, thermodynamic properties of fluids, and thermodynamic analysis of processes.
Subject_Description_2: This course will combine an extension of the study of geomechanics to pavement engineering techniques with the principles of traffic flow theory and pavement engineering techniques so that students can apply them to practice. The course covers traffic flow models, headway models, traffic fundamental diagrams, intersection design and assessment, pavement engineering and design, pavement condition survey and pavement management. This course will be assessed by individual based assignment, mid trimester exam, and final exam.
Subject_Description_3: This course is aimed at circuit design and printed circuit board implementation and finally the design of a complete electronic system. It involves PCB design, system and component specification, and design principles including noise reduction, transducers, ergonomics, power supplies, and design for testability. Students are required to complete a practical PCB design and a paper system design as part of their assessment. Incompatible: 3030MEE Pracitical Electronics AND 3076ENG Team Design Project Prerequisites: 1302ENG Introduction to Electronics AND 2301ENG Semiconductor Devices and Circuits
Subject_Description_4: All construction projects have the common feature of utilising engineering principles, people, machines and materials as well as requiring organisation and planning. This course covers the range of construction equipment and techniques in common use and the planning and direction of construction works. Attention is also given to rock and bulk excavations, health and safety at work sites, preliminary works, formwork design and an introduction to engineering economics. Assessment is by assignments and examinations. Incompatible: 2104ENG Construction Engineering
Subject_Description_5: Geotechnical Engineering forms a major part of the work of a professional civil engineer. This course is designed to enable students to do the analysis prior to design of foundations. It also forms an integral part of the civil analysis and design training provided in the four-year Bachelor of Engineering program in Civil Engineering. The course covers: design and construction aspects of shallow foundations, piled foundations, earth pressure calculations, and slope stability analysis. The main purpose of this course is to develop the ability of the students to design the basic geotechnical foundations (i.e., shallow foundation and piled foundation) and analyse the common geotechnical engineering problems (e.g., slope stability).
Subject_Description_6: This course introduces students to the process of structural design including: dealing with a client and defining a design brief, load estimation, elementary structural analysis and the design of timber and steel members and connections using the relevant Australian Standard design codes.
Subject_Description_7: The course will initially explore topics in relation to generic data communications, including: OSI model; PSTN modem technology ; Error correction ; Data compression ; Physical layer standards; Line codes ; Signals in noise ; Idle RQ and continuous RQ ; Link utilisation ; Link layer protocols ; Data over terrestrial and satellite radio. The second half of the course will look specifically at topics related to the application to computer networks, including: Network topologies; Network bearers and physical attachment ; LANs and WANs; CSMA and token protocols ; Networking protocol performance ; Bridges and routing ; Encryption and compression; Internet protocols ; SSL. A series of laboratories will cover relevant topics, in particular related to signals and performance of data systems. Please check the "assumed knowledge" for this course under the course profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. This course is planned to be offered for the first time in 2018, trimester 2 and replaces 3305ENG.
Subject_Description_8: This course extends the theoretical and practical content of the course 2305ENG Signals and Systems and covers fundamental topics in digital signal processing (DSP) such as A/D and D/A converters, analysis of discrete-time signals and systems, design of finite impulse response (FIR) and infinite impulse response (IIR) digital filters, multirate digital signal processing, etc. MATLAB (software) and digital signal processor boards (hardware) are used to provide hands-on experience to students. This course is planned to be offered for the last time in 2016 at the Gold Coast campus. The Nathan campus offering will continue as normal beyond 2016. Gold Coast students please consult your program director for a suitable alternative. Incompatible: 6321ENG
Subject_Description_9: This course provides a practical and theoretical introduction to manufacturing technology with a primary focus on metal processing technologies and their applications in modern manufacturing industry. The course is designed for the 2nd year engineering students that already possess university-level fundamental knowledge about the properties of common engineering materials, the application of forces in engineering systems and have a basic understanding about the tools, machines and processes employed in fabrication of engineered products.
Subject_Description_10: Kinematics & Dynamics equips graduates with a solid understanding of the key concepts of mechanics required for design and analysis of mechanisms and mechanical devices. Topics covered include kinematics and dynamics of mechanical components modelled as particles and plane rigid bodies, interconnected objects, rotational dynamics, work and energy methods, translating and rotating coordinate systems, vector methods, three-dimensional dynamics of rigid bodies and an introduction to vibration Please check the "assumed knowledge" for this course under the course profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. This course is planned to be offered for the first time in 2018, trimester 1 and replaces 3317ENG.
Subject_Description_11: Genetics and Evolutionary Biology is an introductory course that will provide foundational concepts in molecular genetics and evolutionary biology. Students will gain an understanding of the process of inheritance and mutation, population genetics, and evolutionary theory at the molecular, organismal and population level. Students will also learn commonly used genetic analysis methods and techniques employed by scientists. Course content will be delivered through a combination of lectures, workshops, and online material.
Subject_Description_12: The course revises and extends basic integral and differential calculus of one variable and introduces differential equations. It provides a foundation in the mathematical sciences needed for later studies both in an engineering and science context. This course is for Engineering or ICT students ONLY. Incompatible: 1202SCG Calculus I
Subject_Description_13: This experiential learning based course introduces the natural and physical sciences that underpin the practice of engineering. Through projects students will apply science fundamentals to the systematic investigation, interpretation, and analysis of some engineering problems. Topics covered include Newtonian mechanics and electrical principles. Incompatible: 1031SCG (Physics IA).
Subject_Description_14: The course introduces basic vector algebra in two and three dimensions, matrices, complex numbers, probability and revises basic functions. It provides a foundation in the mathematical sciences for later studies in science and engineering. Prior Assumed Knowledge: It will be assumed that students have the knowledge equivalent to a grade of SA over 4 semesters in Mathematics B (Qld high school subject), or equivalent study over 4 semesters of a high school subject that includes the study of differential and integral calculus or 1017SCG">1017SCG Foundation Mathematics (grade of 4 or higher). For students who do not have this level of mathematics background, it is strongly suggested that they first complete 1017SCG">1017SCG Foundation Mathematics. Incompatible: 1201SCG Linear Algebra, 1011SCG Mathematics 1A, 1201BPS Mathematics 1A, 1666NSC Mathematics 1A for Engineers.
Subject_Description_15: The course introduces students to the theory and practice of control systems. It discusses the basic (introductory) methods of control systems analysis and design, with emphasis on the principle of negative feedback which is the essence of operation of control systems. Engineering examples are used to introduce and illustrate the usefulness of the control systems theory and to make the students aware of this important engineering area. Assessment is by lab preliminaries, reports on laboratory experiments, and a final examination.
Subject_Description_16: Stress analysis (also known as solid mechanics) provides techniques by which engineers can predict stress and strain distributions resulting from known loading conditions, so that the stability and strength of structural members and machine components under load can be assessed. Stress analysis is an essential tool in the analysis and design of structures and machines under load.
Subject_Description_17: The Course introduces students to advanced materials and their applications with the aim to deepen their understanding about i) how materials properties guide materials selection at the product design stage, ii) how core materials properties (either surface- or bulk properties) are changed, adapted or mended to specific user environment and/or an application field through a variety of manufacturing methods, and iii) how commercial material objects (or products) are manufactured in a factory setting. The Course will endue students with relevant knowledge on current materials surface technology, material treatment processes and manufacturing and production system processes, process technology and manufacturing systems design. Additive and rapid prototyping technology and lean engineering/lean production will be also be discussed in this Course. The Course is designed for 3rd year engineering students that already possess university-level fundamental knowledge on properties of common engineering materials such as metals, polymers, ceramics and attained theoretical and practical knowledge on fabrication and processing methods for these materials. The Course is developed to provide a practical, project-based immersion into materials selection process (with real, commercial products used as study samples) where students will learn how initial material selection process effects the geometry, structure, performance and cost of a final product. Assessment is by group assignment, oral presentation and individual examination. Please check the "Assumed Knowledge" for this course under the Course Profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. Incompatible: 2506ENG Materials and Manufacturing
Subject_Description_18: Mechanical engineers need to possess sound understanding of the physics of the design and use of machine elements such as gears, cams, springs, pulleys, joints etc., that are used in engineered components. This design process is deeply enshrined in established design standards/codes that all engineers should be knowledgeable of. 3511ENG Design of Machine Elements is aimed at integrating and applying prior knowledge in fundamental design, materials sciences, statics and dynamics coupled with design strategies and knowledge of machine elements to design various machines. These skills and knowledge help engineers to design, analyse, synthesize and deliver robust engineering solutions. The main learning outcome of this unit is the students' acquisition of strong analytical knowledge of machine elements, their design and load carriage/power transmission mechanics. This course will be delivered through a combination of specially developed lectures, design problem solving methods, case studies and hands-on design assignments' all rolled together into workshops. Please check the "assumed knowledge" for this course under the course profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. This course is planned to be offered for the first time in 2019, trimester 2 and replaces 2505ENG">2505ENG. Incompatible: 2505ENG">2505ENG Design of Machine Elements
Subject_Description_19: This course introduces students to the programming and interfacing of a modern microprocessor. The course outlines the theory behind microprocessors, with a focus on architecture, memory structures, and peripheral interfacing. The course also involves an insight into programming methodologies in assembler and illustrates ways of successfully debugging embedded systems. The course will give the student the background knowledge to successfully develop an embedded system using any microprocessor. The course is highly practical in approach and covers such areas as data acquisition, sensor interfacing, electronic control, and microprocessor communication protocols. Incompatible: 2303ENG Microprocessor Techniques AND 2010MEE Microprocessor Techniques AND 1073ENG Microprocessors
Subject_Description_20: This course explores the common modulation techniques including amplitude and angle modulation for both analogue and digital information signals. Applications examined include radio, television and telecommunications. The course looks at both system level and circuit level. Many examples are examined for circuits for mixers, modulators, demodulators, oscillators, frequency synthesisers, RF amplifiers and radio and television receivers and transmitters. Design of amplification stages utilising classes A, B, C and D are examined. Methods and importance of shielding at high frequencies is also covered. A series of laboratories explore construction and measurement of communication circuits. Incompatible: 2304ENG Communication Systems and Circuits AND 3007MEE Communication Systems and Circuits
Subject_Description_21: Mechanical Engineering Design is the creative development of mechanical products or systems. This course focuses on mechanical design through a project based learning approach. Students will work on a design and analyse (and/or build) project, developing a solution to a real-world engineering design problem. Assessment is by a written design report, oral presentation/s and peer group assessment when relevant.
Subject_Description_22: The capstone engineering project is undertaken in the final year of the program. Students are required to plan, execute and report on a research project with some independence while working with an academic supervisor who maintains regular contact and provides support and direction in the design and execution of the research. Projects based on industry requirements will be encouraged.
Subject_Description_23: This course deals with continuous-time signals and systems and is designed to build on the basic circuit analysis concepts covered in the course Electric Circuits. It provides a detailed study of continuous-time signals and systems in time domain as well as in transformed domain. Signal transforms (Fourier series, Fourier transform and Laplace transforms) are covered in detail. Further concepts such as signal sampling and aliasing are introduced. The theory is exemplified with processing of signals in MATLAB. Incompatible: 2006MEE Signals and Systems AND 2075ENG Signals and Systems
Subject_Description_24: This course introduces the basic semiconductor concepts, the principles of diode and transistor operation, and the fundamental transistor circuits (common amplifier topologies, op-amp building blocks, and low-frequency amplifiers). Circuit simulation (SPICE) with appropriately set device parameters and simplified equivalent circuits are used for circuit analysis. Circuit design is based on circuit analysis and is facilitated by an understanding of semiconductor properties and device operation. Laboratory exercises will complement the teaching approach for this course. Incompatible: 2030MEE Microelectronic Circuits Prerequisites: 1301ENG Electric Circuits and 1302ENG Introduction to Electronics
Subject_Description_25: The course will initially explore topics in relation to generic data communications, including: OSI model; PSTN modem technology ; Error correction ; Data compression ; Physical layer standards; Line codes ; Signals in noise ; Idle RQ and continuous RQ ; Link utilisation ; Link layer protocols ; Data over terrestrial and satellite radio. The second half of the course will look specifically at topics related to the application to computer networks, including: Network topologies; Network bearers and physical attachment ; LANs and WANs; CSMA and token protocols ; Networking protocol performance ; Bridges and routing ; Encryption and compression; Internet protocols ; SSL. A series of laboratories will cover relevant topics, in particular related to signals and performance of data systems. Please check the "assumed knowledge" for this course under the course profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment.
Subject_Description_26: This course mainly covers the analysis and design of reinforced and prestressed concrete structural elements. Both strength and serviceability design requirements are covered. Problem solving exercises based on actual design situations are utilised extensively in this course. After completing this course students will be able to analyse and design structural concrete elements and structures. Assessment is by, tutorial and design assignments, and examinations.
Subject_Description_27: Engineering solutions are developed from an in depth understanding of the subject knowledge combined with a creative approach to problem solving that takes a step back from details to consider the challenge as a whole. Complex problem solving involves an understanding of individuals and systems, interconnections and innovation. Furthermore these solutions must also be considered in terms of sustainable development. This course introduces the student to engineering design through a project-based approach to the development of a product or piece of infrastructure as part of small design team.
Subject_Description_28: Soil Mechanics is an important part of geotechnical engineering that deals with the engineering properties of various soils. This course provides students with valuable opportunities to develop their understanding of the fundamentals of soil behavior, and skills that will allow them to apply their knowledge to solve real-life problems. Students will also have the opportunity to become familiar with various testing procedures and learn how to perform laboratory tests to determine the geotechnical properties of soil such as grain-size distribution, plasticity, compaction characteristics, and permeability. After completing this course, students will acquire sufficient knowledge and develop critical skills that will enable them to solve practical problems related to soil mechanics
Subject_Description_29: This course provides the fundamental knowledge of fluid mechanics and hydraulics including fluid properties, fluid statics, conservation of mass, energy equation, flow in conduits, pumps and turbines, flow around objects, open channel flow and compressible flow.
Subject_Description_30: Understanding Australian Cities is an introductory overview of the origin, patterning and functioning of the urban system. The course specifically examines the dynamics of population, infrastructure, governance and culture in Australian cities. These understandings frame examination of the possibilities of planning intervention. This introductory course will allow students to better appreciate the range of planning challenges and the opportunities for further study. This course is delivered via weekly lectures and tutorials and is supplemented with web materials and readings.
Subject_Description_31: This course introduces students to municipal solid waste engineering. The contents include municipal solid waste characteristics, storage and collection, transfer and transport, separation and processing, recycling, composting, incineration and landfilling.
Subject_Description_32: This course has a major design project which further develops the practical engineering design skills students have already gained through the Environmental Engineering Design 1 and 2 courses. Students are required to design the basic infrastructure for a proposed site development with significant environmental issues to be addressed. The development of a cost effective and appropriate design solution and development of design and documentation skills are emphasised. The design project is carried out in teams, giving students the opportunity to experience the issues involved in working in teams towards a realistic project outcome. Advised Prerequisite: 4045 EVE - Environmental Engineering Design Project OR 3213ENG Environmental Engineering Design Project
Subject_Description_33: This course covers fundamental electromagnetic theory including Electrostatics, Magnetostatics, Electromagnetic Induction, Electromagnetic Radiation, Properties of Matter and finally finishing with Maxwell's equations. This basic theory is then used to explore the principles of propagation on guided media such as cables and waveguides. Basic principles such as the Telegraph equations lead to characteristic impedance, reflection and transmission coefficient, standing and travelling waves. Simple modes in rectangular and circular waveguides are examined and fundamental dispersion issues are addressed. Smith charts are used as a calculation tool for transmission problems and numerous matching and coupling problems are attempted. A series of laboratories explore measurements of signals and fields on simple systems.
Subject_Description_34: This course develops an integrated approach to understanding and analysis of natural catchments. Principles and methods in hydrology and hydraulics will be used to analyse the dynamics of water and water-borne substances. We will address their sources, transport, mixing and dispersion in the environment as well as the implications to catchment management. Computer modelling software popular in the water engineering industry will be extensively used in this course.
Subject_Description_35: This course introduces students to engineering design practice utilising real world design exercises. The course gives students a solid grounding in current engineering practice and emphasises the importance of incorporating sustainable approaches and sound practices to their designs. This course may involve individual or team approaches, depending on the nature of the design task. Incompatible: 2106ENG Design for Civil Engineers
Subject_Description_36: This course introduces the importance of microorganisms to natural and man made ecosystems, biogeochemical cycles, trophic pathways and their beneficial applications to modern industry. The course provides an understanding of the relationships of living organisms - microorganisms, plants and animals with each other and their abiotic environment. Fundamentals include microbial metabolism (aerobic and anaerobic respiration, photosynthesis, chemosynthesis, energy transformation); cellular transport (diffusion, osmosis and active transport); microbial growth; microbial genetics and environmentally significant biochemical pathways. The taxonomic classification of autotrophic and heterotrophic organisms will be covered together with their resource requirements - light, oxygen and nutrients. Ecosystem concepts of food webs, energy flow and mineral cycles, including the bioaccumulation and biomagnification of pollutants. Particular emphasis is placed on the role of micro-organisms in decomposition, biogeochemical cycles, waste water treatment, bioremediation, water quality and human and ecosystem health. The laboratories cover microbial biodiversity, techniques for the culture, staining and emumeration of microorganisms, animal and plant diversity with emphasis on bioindicators, water quality and macroinvertebrate sampling.
Subject_Description_37: Heat and Mass Transfer Engineering aims to equip future engineers with fundamental knowledge together with practical design and implementation skills for applications involving mass and energy balances, mass transfer, psychrometry, convection, heat conduction, and radiation heat transfer. Students will engage in engineering design project(s) involving selection, sizing and/or design of devices such as heat exchangers, fans, pumps, ducting, condensers, distillation columns and air conditioners. Students will be required to propose fit-for-purpose solutions that meet the competing demands of their profession including sustainability, legal issues and commercial aspects. Engineering responsibility and skills in leadership, project control, whole systems design, whole systems thinking, risk management and effective human relations will be refined through this course.
Subject_Description_38: The course considers the fundamental properties of metals and non-metallic materials. Students are introduced to the atomic and microstructure of materials and their relationship to mechanical and electrical properties. The course explores the mechanical concepts of stress, strain, elongation and material failure (including testing) and the phenomenon of electrical conduction. This course will be offered from 2017 in trimester 1 and 3, and replaces 1502ENG.
Subject_Description_39: Structural design forms a major part of the work of a professional civil engineer. This course is designed to enable students to do the prerequisite analysis prior to design. It also forms an integral part of the structural analysis and design training provided in the four-year Bachelor of Engineering program in Civil Engineering. This course provides a thorough coverage of the theoretical basis for linear analysis of various types of skeletal (planar) structures encountered in Civil Engineering design work. The main purpose of this course is to develop the ability of the students to analyse planar structures using manual and computer-based methods.
Subject_Description_40: Mechanics of Materials 2 provides techniques by which engineers can determine stress and strain distributions resulting from known loading conditions, so that the stability and strength of structural members under load can be examined. The learners will acquire the knowledge in the analysis and design of structures and machines under load.

Engineering responsibility and skills in leadership, project control, whole systems design, whole systems thinking, risk management and effective human relations will be refined through this course.
Subject_Description_3: Numerical analysis is the area of mathematics and computer science that creates, analyses, and implements algorithms for solving numerically the problems of continuous mathematics. In engineering, these problems arise naturally from the requirement to understand and design physical systems to serve our needs. The aim of this course is to learn how to formulate numerical solutions suitable for resolving the type of calculations commonly encountered in electrical engineering. This course will be offered from 2019 in trimester 2 at the Gold Coast campus.
Subject_Description_4: All electrical signals produce electromagnetic fields be they communication signals or high current power transmissions. It is therefore vital to understand about the generation and manipulation of these fields. This course covers classical electrostatics in terms of charge and charge density in volumes, force due to charge, electric field intensity, electric potential and electric flux density. It also explores magnetostatics in terms of magnetic field intensity and flux density, magnetic forces, magnetic potential and inductance. Finally time varying fields are covered including moving conductors, transformers, displacement current and generation and motion. The outcome should be a complete understanding of Maxwell's equations applied to engineering problems.
Subject_Description_5: The course introduces basic vector algebra in two and three dimensions, matrices, complex numbers, probability and revises basic functions. It provides a foundation in the mathematical sciences for later studies in science and engineering. Prior Assumed Knowledge: It will be assumed that students have the knowledge equivalent to a grade of SA over 4 semesters in Mathematics B (Qld high school subject), or equivalent study over 4 semesters of a high school subject that includes the study of differential and integral calculus or 1017SCG">1017SCG Foundation Mathematics (grade of 4 or higher). For students who do not have this level of mathematics background, it is strongly suggested that they first complete 1017SCG">1017SCG Foundation Mathematics. Incompatible: 1201SCG Linear Algebra, 1011SCG Mathematics 1A, 1201BPS Mathematics 1A, 1666NSC Mathematics 1A for Engineers.
Subject_Description_6: The course will discuss chemical properties and the mechanisms of chemical change, with everyday examples from environmental science and medicine. The principles of chemical thermodynamics, organic chemistry, biological chemistry and chemical reactions and properties in solution will be reinforced by a laboratory program. Tutorial assignments will be used to develop problem solving skills. Assessment is by laboratory reports, mid-trimester examination and end of trimester examination. Assumed prior knowledge: 1023SCG Chemistry I OR 1001ENV Chemistry I OR 1001EAS Chemistry 1 OR Year 12 Chemistry AND Year 12 Mathematics B OR 1503ENG Physics and Chemistry. Incompatible: 1502ENV Chemistry II, 1502EAS Chemistry 2.
Subject_Description_7: Soil Mechanics is an important part of geotechnical engineering that deals with the engineering properties of various soils. This course provides students with valuable opportunities to develop their understanding of the fundamentals of soil behavior, and skills that will allow them to apply their knowledge to solve real-life problems. Students will also have the opportunity to become familiar with various testing procedures and learn how to perform laboratory tests to determine the geotechnical properties of soil such as grain-size distribution, plasticity, compaction characteristics, and permeability. After completing this course, students will acquire sufficient knowledge and develop critical skills that will enable them to solve practical problems related to soil mechanics
