Topics covered include kinematics and dynamics of mechanical components modelled as particles and plane rigid bodies, interconnected objects, rotational dynamics, work and energy methods, translating and rotating coordinate systems, vector methods, three-dimensional dynamics of rigid bodies and an introduction to vibration Please check the "assumed knowledge" for this course under the course profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. This course is planned to be offered for the first time in 2018, trimester 1 and replaces 3317ENG.
Subject_Description_9: This experiential learning course introduces students to the engineering design process and professional aspects of being an Engineer or Industrial Designer. The course takes into consideration the increasingly complex interactions between engineering systems, project stakeholders and the environment, including the positive role of engineering in sustainable development as well as the potentially adverse impacts of engineering activities. Exposure to engineers and designers who are in the workforce will be a feature of this course.
Subject_Description_10: This course provides the fundamental knowledge of fluid mechanics and hydraulics including fluid properties, fluid statics, conservation of mass, energy equation, flow in conduits, pumps and turbines, flow around objects, open channel flow and compressible flow.
Subject_Description_11: Hydrology is concerned with the distribution and dynamics of water and water quality on or near the surface of earth. As fundamental engineering sciences, hydrology plays an important role in developing technical skills in water engineering and in understanding many of the contemporary water management issues. The course covers fundamental hydrologic processes such as rainfall, evaporation, infiltration, surface and ground water, and hydrologic extremes ie floods and droughts. In addition, the course develops technical skills to apply some basic techniques for hydrologic analysis and design with particular emphasis on flood estimation, flood frequency analysis, and flood routing. Learning activities include lectures and workshops.
Subject_Description_12: All construction projects have the common feature of utilising engineering principles, people, machines and materials as well as requiring organisation and planning. This course covers the range of construction equipment and techniques in common use and the planning and direction of construction works. Attention is also given to rock and bulk excavations, health and safety at work sites, preliminary works, formwork design and an introduction to engineering economics. Assessment is by assignments and examinations. Incompatible: 2104ENG Construction Engineering

The course is designed for the 2nd year engineering students that already possess university-level fundamental knowledge about the properties of common engineering materials, the application of forces in engineering systems and have a basic understanding about the tools, machines and processes employed in fabrication of engineered products.

Students are required to plan, execute and report on a research project with some independence while working with an academic supervisor who maintains regular contact and provides support and direction in the design and execution of the research. Projects based on industry requirements will be encouraged.

Students are required to design the basic infrastructure for a proposed site development with significant environmental issues to be addressed. The development of a cost effective and appropriate design solution and development of design and documentation skills are emphasised. The design project is carried out in teams, giving students the opportunity to experience the issues involved in working in teams towards a realistic project outcome. Advised Prerequisite: 4045 EVE - Environmental Engineering Design Project OR 3213ENG Environmental Engineering Design Project
Subject_Description_16: The course introduces students to the theory and practice of control systems. It discusses the basic (introductory) methods of control systems analysis and design, with emphasis on the principle of negative feedback which is the essence of operation of control systems. Engineering examples are used to introduce and illustrate the usefulness of the control systems theory and to make the students aware of this important engineering area. Assessment is by lab preliminaries, reports on laboratory experiments, and a final examination.
Subject_Description_17: Electromagnetic Waves and Propagation is a lecture and laboratory based course in which students are introduced to tools and design techniques for engineering applications in which electromagnetic waves generated by sources of alternating current play a dominant role. These applications typically involve the transmission of waves over metallic or dielectric transmission lines or through free space, with the purpose of transporting either information or electric power.
Subject_Description_18: This course covers the principles of electric motors and generators. Both DC and AC motors and generators are explored along with the application of single and multi-phase machines. State of the art drive, control and protection circuitry will also be considered along with solid state methods of providing AC supply. Practical work will enhance the understanding of these topics. Please check the "assumed knowledge" for this course under the course profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. This course will be offered from 2018 at the Gold Coast campus, in trimester 2, and replaces 6509ENG.
Subject_Description_19: The course revises and extends basic integral and differential calculus of one variable and introduces differential equations. It provides a foundation in the mathematical sciences needed for later studies both in an engineering and science context. This course is for Engineering or ICT students ONLY. Incompatible: 1202SCG Calculus I
Subject_Description_20: This course mainly covers the analysis and design of reinforced and prestressed concrete structural elements. Both strength and serviceability design requirements are covered. Problem solving exercises based on actual design situations are utilised extensively in this course. After completing this course students will be able to analyse and design structural concrete elements and structures. Assessment is by, tutorial and design assignments, and examinations.
Subject_Description_21: Geotechnical Engineering forms a major part of the work of a professional civil engineer. This course is designed to enable students to do the analysis prior to design of foundations. It also forms an integral part of the civil analysis and design training provided in the four-year Bachelor of Engineering program in Civil Engineering. The course covers: design and construction aspects of shallow foundations, piled foundations, earth pressure calculations, and slope stability analysis. The main purpose of this course is to develop the ability of the students to design the basic geotechnical foundations (i.e., shallow foundation and piled foundation) and analyse the common geotechnical engineering problems (e.g., slope stability).
Subject_Description_22: This course will combine an extension of the study of geomechanics to pavement engineering techniques with the principles of traffic flow theory and pavement engineering techniques so that students can apply them to practice. The course covers traffic flow models, headway models, traffic fundamental diagrams, intersection design and assessment, pavement engineering and design, pavement condition survey and pavement management. This course will be assessed by individual based assignment, mid trimester exam, and final exam.
Subject_Description_23: This course covers the theory and algorithms of statistical digital signal processing, estimation and modelling together with their applications in the electrical and electronic engineering disciplines. The first half of the course covers the mathematical preliminaries in deterministic digital signal processing, such as the z-transform, discrete-time Fourier transform, FIR and IIR filter design. The second half covers the core of the course, which examines the modelling and estimation of random signals and processes using spectral estimation, optimal filtering, linear MMSE estimation (Wiener and Kalman filtering), and adaptive filters. Emphasis is placed on electrical and electronic engineering applications, such as signal enhancement, signal detection in noise, adaptive noise cancellation, time-series prediction and machine learning. Students will also learn how to implement signal processing algorithms in software (using the Python language) and embedded DSP hardware. Incompatible: 3303ENG Digital Signal Processing
Subject_Description_24: This course covers fundamental and advanced topics in communications systems which are essential for Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Mechatronic Engineers, and Electronic and Biomedical Engineering. Knowledge on signals and systems, and Fourier transform is prerequisite for this course. Topics to be covered: (i) modulation AM, FM, (ii) digital modulation, digital transmission, (iii) introduction to mobile communications system and smart antennas, (iv) Wireless LANs, MIMO-OFDM for wireless, (v) Cellular Radio Communications, (vi) Microwave Engineering and communications, and (vii) introduction to Satellite Communications..
Subject_Description_25: The main aim of this course is to provide sound knowledge of the principles and practices of digital systems, both at the device and circuit level. The course covers topics in digital electronics including: Number Theory, Boolean Algebra, Logic Circuits, Logic Minimisation Techniques, Multiplexers, Adders, Flip-Flops, Counters, Registers, State Machines, Memory Circuits, Digital / Analog Conversion, Programable Logic Circuits and Microcomputer Bus Architecture. Incompatible: 1004MEE Digital Networks and Systems AND 2072ENG Digital Systems AND 1303ENG Digital Systems
Subject_Description_26: This course introduces students to the programming and interfacing of a modern microprocessor. The course outlines the theory behind microprocessors, with a focus on architecture, memory structures, and peripheral interfacing. The course also involves an insight into programming methodologies in assembler and illustrates ways of successfully debugging embedded systems. The course will give the student the background knowledge to successfully develop an embedded system using any microprocessor. The course is highly practical in approach and covers such areas as data acquisition, sensor interfacing, electronic control, and microprocessor communication protocols. Incompatible: 2010MEE Microprocessor Techniques AND 1073ENG Microprocessors AND 3323ENG MicroController Techniques
Subject_Description_27: This course examines several major environmental challenges to society where natural systems have been severely affected as a result of the pressures of population growth, technology change, and economic growth based on increasing production and consumption. These issues will be considered from an interdisciplinary natural and social science perspective with a special secondary focus on the traditional knowledge of, and impacts to, First Nations' Peoples. Assessment for this course will emphasise development of diverse communication skills relevant for environmental analysis and effective problem-solving for achieving sustainability.
Subject_Description_28: Stress analysis (also known as solid mechanics) provides techniques by which engineers can predict stress and strain distributions resulting from known loading conditions, so that the stability and strength of structural members and machine components under load can be assessed. Stress analysis is an essential tool in the analysis and design of structures and machines under load.
Subject_Description_29: Structural design forms a major part of the work of a professional civil engineer. This course is designed to enable students to do the prerequisite analysis prior to design. It also forms an integral part of the structural analysis and design training provided in the four-year Bachelor of Engineering program in Civil Engineering. This course provides a thorough coverage of the theoretical basis for linear analysis of various types of skeletal (planar) structures encountered in Civil Engineering design work. The main purpose of this course is to develop the ability of the students to analyse planar structures using manual and computer-based methods.
Subject_Description_30: Understanding Australian Cities is an introductory overview of the origin, patterning and functioning of the urban system. The course specifically examines the dynamics of population, infrastructure, governance and culture in Australian cities. These understandings frame examination of the possibilities of planning intervention. This introductory course will allow students to better appreciate the range of planning challenges and the opportunities for further study. This course is delivered via weekly lectures and tutorials and is supplemented with web materials and readings.
Subject_Description_31: This course introduces students to engineering design practice utilising real world design exercises. The course gives students a solid grounding in current engineering practice and emphasises the importance of incorporating sustainable approaches and sound practices to their designs. This course may involve individual or team approaches, depending on the nature of the design task. Incompatible: 2106ENG Design for Civil Engineers
Subject_Description_32: This course deals with continuous-time signals and systems and is designed to build on the basic circuit analysis concepts covered in the course Electric Circuits. It provides a detailed study of continuous-time signals and systems in time domain as well as in transformed domain. Signal transforms (Fourier series, Fourier transform and Laplace transforms) are covered in detail. Further concepts such as signal sampling and aliasing are introduced. The theory is exemplified with processing of signals in MATLAB. Incompatible: 2006MEE Signals and Systems AND 2075ENG Signals and Systems
Subject_Description_33: Mechanical engineers need to possess sound understanding of the physics of the design and use of machine elements such as gears, cams, springs, pulleys, joints etc., that are used in engineered components. This design process is deeply enshrined in established design standards/codes that all engineers should be knowledgeable of. 3511ENG Design of Machine Elements is aimed at integrating and applying prior knowledge in fundamental design, materials sciences, statics and dynamics coupled with design strategies and knowledge of machine elements to design various machines. These skills and knowledge help engineers to design, analyse, synthesize and deliver robust engineering solutions. The main learning outcome of this unit is the students' acquisition of strong analytical knowledge of machine elements, their design and load carriage/power transmission mechanics. This course will be delivered through a combination of specially developed lectures, design problem solving methods, case studies and hands-on design assignments' all rolled together into workshops. Please check the "assumed knowledge" for this course under the course profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. This course is planned to be offered for the first time in 2019, trimester 2 and replaces 2505ENG">2505ENG. Incompatible: 2505ENG">2505ENG Design of Machine Elements
Subject_Description_34: Electrical Design Project is a practical project based course in which students are challenged to apply fundamental knowledge of analogue and digital components, circuitry and systems to design, implement and demonstrate a functional electronic device meeting prescribed system requirements. Students are guided through a systematic design process involving analysis of requirements, circuit design and simulation, component selection, prototype construction, testing, evaluation and revision. An integral part of the process is the production and maintenance of engineering documentation in the form of technical specifications, schematic diagrams, list of components, test procedures and performance results. Incompatible: 3312ENG Practical Electronics I
Subject_Description_35: This course introduces students to the process of structural design including: dealing with a client and defining a design brief, load estimation, elementary structural analysis and the design of timber and steel members and connections using the relevant Australian Standard design codes.
Subject_Description_36: Mechanical Engineering Design is the creative development of mechanical products or systems. This course focuses on mechanical design through a project based learning approach. Students will work on a design and analyse (and/or build) project, developing a solution to a real-world engineering design problem. Assessment is by a written design report, oral presentation/s and peer group assessment when relevant.
Subject_Description_37: Engineering solutions are developed from an in depth understanding of the subject knowledge combined with a creative approach to problem solving that takes a step back from details to consider the challenge as a whole. Complex problem solving involves an understanding of individuals and systems, interconnections and innovation. Furthermore these solutions must also be considered in terms of sustainable development. This course introduces the student to engineering design through a project-based approach to the development of a product or piece of infrastructure as part of small design team.
Subject_Description_38: Mechanics of Materials 2 provides techniques by which engineers can determine stress and strain distributions resulting from known loading conditions, so that the stability and strength of structural members under load can be examined. The learners will acquire the knowledge in the analysis and design of structures and machines under load.
Subject_Description_39: This experiential learning based course introduces the natural and physical sciences that underpin the practice of engineering. Through projects students will apply science fundamentals to the systematic investigation, interpretation, and analysis of some engineering problems. Topics covered include Newtonian mechanics and electrical principles. Incompatible: 1031SCG (Physics IA).
Subject_Description_40: Genetics and Evolutionary Biology is an introductory course that will provide foundational concepts in molecular genetics and evolutionary biology. Students will gain an understanding of the process of inheritance and mutation, population genetics, and evolutionary theory at the molecular, organismal and population level. Students will also learn commonly used genetic analysis methods and techniques employed by scientists. Course content will be delivered through a combination of lectures, workshops, and online material.

Course: Bachelor of Engineering (Honours)/Bachelor of Industrial Design
Description: Now you can combine the creative skills of industrial design with the practical solutions of mechanical engineering. This double degree will arm you with the techniques and technical skills you need to excel in this vibrant industry. You'll study a combination of in-depth theoretical frameworks that make up the mechanical engineering discipline, including project planning and management. Plus, you'll learn industrial design principles and concepts like development, problem-solving and modelmaking. So much more than just theory, this degree gets you learning hands-on from year one and delivers you a qualification that employers find hard to ignore.  From year one, you'll be learning from industry experts and like-minded teachers. Hands-on experience is key to this double degree, and in your final year you can enhance your knowledge through an industry-based project or placement.  You'll be at the forefront of a number of rapidly growing career paths. You can choose to design consumer products, putting your skills into play to make every day more user-friendly. Or, you can choose to specialise in the design and manufacture of products for a range of industries including mining, transportation, building services and medical supplies.  Engineering Tailor your timetable - Even if you study full-time on-campus, you may still be able to customise your degree to suit your needs. From a range of tutorial times to online access to lectures and other course material, we're here to help you fit study in with your work and life commitments.  Students may be eligible to do an international field trip, organised by the academic staff. This may count towards a component of the degree, depending on its structure.
Career_Outcomes: Key employment sectors* Potential job outcomes *Source: Australian Government Job Outlook
Subject_Description_1: The course considers the fundamental properties of metals and non-metallic materials. Students are introduced to the atomic and microstructure of materials and their relationship to mechanical and electrical properties. The course explores the mechanical concepts of stress, strain, elongation and material failure (including testing) and the phenomenon of electrical conduction. This course will be offered from 2017 in trimester 1 and 3, and replaces 1502ENG.
Subject_Description_2: The course introduces basic vector algebra in two and three dimensions, matrices, complex numbers, probability and revises basic functions. It provides a foundation in the mathematical sciences for later studies in science and engineering. Prior Assumed Knowledge: It will be assumed that students have the knowledge equivalent to a grade of SA over 4 semesters in Mathematics B (Qld high school subject), or equivalent study over 4 semesters of a high school subject that includes the study of differential and integral calculus or 1017SCG">1017SCG Foundation Mathematics (grade of 4 or higher). For students who do not have this level of mathematics background, it is strongly suggested that they first complete 1017SCG">1017SCG Foundation Mathematics. Incompatible: 1201SCG Linear Algebra, 1011SCG Mathematics 1A, 1201BPS Mathematics 1A, 1666NSC Mathematics 1A for Engineers.
Subject_Description_3: This course provides some of the essential mathematical techniques to mathematicians and physical scientists, and applies them to scientific problems. The course covers basic material on multiple integrals of scalar functions as well as line and surface integrals of vector fields, the theorems of Gauss, Green and Stokes, Fourier series and integrals. It also introduces some of the common partial differential equations of applied mathematics and methods of solution mostly based on separation of variables. It also covers some topics on ordinary differential equations. Incompatible courses: 2223SCE Physical Mathematics IIA, 2001ENG Advanced ENG Mathematics, 2610SCE Continuous Mathematics, 2203BPS">2203BPS Mathematics 2A Prerequisites: 1201BPS">1201BPS Mathematics 1A and 1202BPS">1202BPS Mathematics 1B Students must pass both 1201BPS">1201BPS AND 1202BPS">1202BPS to enrol in 2203BPS">2203BPS
Subject_Description_4: This course enables development of a deeper level of understanding of the laws that govern the conversion of energy from one form to another. Knowledge of thermodynamics is essential for the engineer to recognize the possibilities and limitations for improvement of energy efficiency in the design of engineering systems. Topics covered include: properties of pure substances, first and second laws of thermodynamics, closed systems, control volumes, entropy, second law analysis of engineering systems, power and refrigeration cycles and internal combustion engines. Assessment is by assignments consisting of problems in engineering thermodynamics, laboratory work, and a final examination.
Subject_Description_5: Engineering solutions are developed from an in depth understanding of the subject knowledge combined with a creative approach to problem solving that takes a step back from details to consider the challenge as a whole. Complex problem solving involves an understanding of individuals and systems, interconnections and innovation. Furthermore these solutions must also be considered in terms of sustainable development. This course introduces the student to engineering design through a project-based approach to the development of a product or piece of infrastructure as part of small design team.
Subject_Description_6: This course extends on industry standard design and parametric solid modelling techniques with a focus on ergonomics and user centred design outcomes. Students develop competencies in complex part, assembly and drawing development including physical dynamics, surfacing, performance enhanced component assembly, applied problem solving with geometric & mathematical dimension relationships, detailed drawing and file management to prepare you for an international working environment. Pre-requisite: 2639QCA - Digital Modelling for Design
Subject_Description_7: The Thesis is undertaken in the final trimester. Students are required to plan, execute and report on a research project with some independence while working with an academic supervisor who maintains regular contact and provides support and direction in the design and execution of the research. Projects based on industry requirements will be encouraged.
Subject_Description_8: This course introduces designing for 3D printing. This practical course introduces students to key stages of the design development process and human centred design strategies, identifying user behaviours and needs in the development of niche products. Fundamental skills are developed in the design and preparation of digital files, to create resolved 3D printed prototypes.
Subject_Description_9: Mechanics of Materials 2 provides techniques by which engineers can determine stress and strain distributions resulting from known loading conditions, so that the stability and strength of structural members under load can be examined. The learners will acquire the knowledge in the analysis and design of structures and machines under load.
Subject_Description_10: Heat and Mass Transfer gives the engineer a firm grounding in the fundamental processes of conduction, convection and radiation heat transfer. Topics covered include transient conduction, forced convection in internal and external flow, free convection, lumped heat capacity analysis, two and three-dimensional heat transfer, radiation exchange between surfaces, diffusion mass transfer, boiling, evaporation and condensation, and heat exchanger design & optimisation. Assessment is by assignments consisting of engineering problems in heat and mass transfer and a final examination. Incompatible: 3505ENG Heat and Mass Transfer
Subject_Description_11: This course incorporates the principles of work integrated learning through exposure to professional engineering practice, undertaken either with an industry partner or at the university. The course allows students to further develop advanced skills in the theory and application of professional aspects of modern engineering practice. This course integrates your professional practice learnings embedded within the engineering degree program with the professional competencies you have achieved during your program. A co requisite of this course is the completion of a minimum of 12 weeks (60 days) of approved experience in an engineering practice environment (or a satisfactory alternative).
Subject_Description_12: This course provides some of the essential mathematical techniques to mathematicians and physical scientists, and applies them to scientific problems. The course covers basic material on multiple integrals of scalar functions as well as line and surface integrals of vector fields, the theorems of Gauss, Green and Stokes, Fourier series and integrals. It also introduces some of the common partial differential equations of applied mathematics and methods of solution mostly based on separation of variables. It also covers some topics on ordinary differential equations. Incompatible: 2001ENG Advanced ENG Mathematics, 2203NSC Mathematics 2A. Prerequisites: 1201SCG">1201SCG Linear Algebra and 1202SCG Calculus I. (Please note: for students enrolled in Program 1567 1201SCG">1201SCG Linear Algebra is a co-requisite). Students must pass both courses to enrol in 2205NSC.
Subject_Description_13: Whilst 3D designers are focused on object outcomes, good design is situational. This course introduces the student to more complex problems, such as design meets disability, or large scale projects where outcomes may require design research, design process and practice with a transdisciplinary approach.
Subject_Description_14: Mechanical engineers need to possess sound understanding of the physics of the design and use of machine elements such as gears, cams, springs, pulleys, joints etc., that are used in engineered components. This design process is deeply enshrined in established design standards/codes that all engineers should be knowledgeable of. 3511ENG Design of Machine Elements is aimed at integrating and applying prior knowledge in fundamental design, materials sciences, statics and dynamics coupled with design strategies and knowledge of machine elements to design various machines. These skills and knowledge help engineers to design, analyse, synthesize and deliver robust engineering solutions. The main learning outcome of this unit is the students' acquisition of strong analytical knowledge of machine elements, their design and load carriage/power transmission mechanics. This course will be delivered through a combination of specially developed lectures, design problem solving methods, case studies and hands-on design assignments' all rolled together into workshops. Please check the "assumed knowledge" for this course under the course profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. This course is planned to be offered for the first time in 2019, trimester 2 and replaces 2505ENG">2505ENG. Incompatible: 2505ENG">2505ENG Design of Machine Elements
Subject_Description_15: As an engineer you will be faced with problems that require you to devise innovative and practical solutions. Some problems may be simple and you will solve them drawing on knowledge you acquired through your course of study or using your accumulated experiences. On the other hand, there will be cases where your experience and academic training are not sufficient. In these cases, you will need to engage in research. Being able to source valid and credible information and analyse information statistically in order to formulate viable solutions is an important skill that all engineers need and which Engineers Australia expects you to have. The research and statistics skills you learn in this course will also help you throughout your studies at Griffith University. Research is a key component in Undergraduate degrees at Griffith University. Moreover, the skills learnt in this course are of vital importance to students who intend to pursue higher degree research studies. Therefore, this course aims to equip you with the skills needed to conduct valid research and statistical analysis be it in academic or industrial practice context.
Subject_Description_16: Engineering Programming is an introductory course to computer programming. It uses the C language to teach basic programming structure, flow and syntax. It also includes a module on the similar language used by the MATLAB package. Incompatible: 2312ENG C Programming and Computer Architecture. From 2017 this course will be offered in trimester 2 at both the Gold Coast and Nathan campuses.
Subject_Description_17: This course provides a practical and theoretical introduction to manufacturing technology with a primary focus on metal processing technologies and their applications in modern manufacturing industry. The course is designed for the 2nd year engineering students that already possess university-level fundamental knowledge about the properties of common engineering materials, the application of forces in engineering systems and have a basic understanding about the tools, machines and processes employed in fabrication of engineered products.
Subject_Description_18: This is the capstone course for all third year students. The course allows students to critically examine their place within their chosen discipline and to respond by producing a major studio outcome. Students are encouraged to scope and develop their own project. The course emphasises the integration of creative and innovative applications of the design and visual communication processes to project outcomes. Wherever possible, folio-based projects are undertaken.
Subject_Description_19: This course covers the principles of electric motors and generators. Both DC and AC motors and generators are explored along with the application of single and multi-phase machines. State of the art drive, control and protection circuitry will also be considered along with solid state methods of providing AC supply. Practical work will enhance the understanding of these topics. Please check the "assumed knowledge" for this course under the course profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. This course will be offered from 2018 at the Gold Coast campus, in trimester 2, and replaces 6509ENG.
Subject_Description_20: This course introduces students to the basic concepts and principles of thermodynamics, and its selected engineering applications. Topics include the first law of thermodynamics, volumetric properties of pure substances, heat effects, the second law of thermodynamics, thermodynamic properties of fluids, and thermodynamic analysis of processes.
Subject_Description_21: The capstone engineering project is undertaken in the final year of the program. Students are required to plan, execute and report on a research project with some independence while working with an academic supervisor who maintains regular contact and provides support and direction in the design and execution of the research. Projects based on industry requirements will be encouraged.
Subject_Description_22: This course introduces students to the fundamental precepts of product design. Building on the introduction to design process in the first year, students have the opportunity to develop their approach to design, their particular interests and focus and the skills to support the resolution of a design idea. The creation of object outcomes using advanced technologies is supported in this course, and the contrast between conventional technology and advanced technology, and designing and specifying for both are explored.
Subject_Description_23: This course provides engineering and architecture students with an overview of the principles, skills and techniques required for the evaluation, planning, and management of projects from inception through to completion.
Subject_Description_24: Design history in its traditional form focuses on design movements, designers and the materiality of the design object and the ways it is connected to production and consumption, integrated in circulated systems of meaning. This course will investigate the social dimension of design in and beyond Western culture and will pose a series of critical questions that will reveal design's wider historical impact, consequences and relation transformations of human understanding in and of the organic and artificial material world.
Subject_Description_25: Mechanical Engineering Design is the creative development of mechanical products or systems. This course focuses on mechanical design through a project based learning approach. Students will work on a design and analyse (and/or build) project, developing a solution to a real-world engineering design problem. Assessment is by a written design report, oral presentation/s and peer group assessment when relevant.
Subject_Description_26: The Course introduces students to advanced materials and their applications with the aim to deepen their understanding about i) how materials properties guide materials selection at the product design stage, ii) how core materials properties (either surface- or bulk properties) are changed, adapted or mended to specific user environment and/or an application field through a variety of manufacturing methods, and iii) how commercial material objects (or products) are manufactured in a factory setting. The Course will endue students with relevant knowledge on current materials surface technology, material treatment processes and manufacturing and production system processes, process technology and manufacturing systems design. Additive and rapid prototyping technology and lean engineering/lean production will be also be discussed in this Course. The Course is designed for 3rd year engineering students that already possess university-level fundamental knowledge on properties of common engineering materials such as metals, polymers, ceramics and attained theoretical and practical knowledge on fabrication and processing methods for these materials. The Course is developed to provide a practical, project-based immersion into materials selection process (with real, commercial products used as study samples) where students will learn how initial material selection process effects the geometry, structure, performance and cost of a final product. Assessment is by group assignment, oral presentation and individual examination. Please check the "Assumed Knowledge" for this course under the Course Profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. Incompatible: 2506ENG Materials and Manufacturing
Subject_Description_27: Globalisation, Industrial revolution 2.0 and Web 2.0 are changing the way that industrial designers operate. It is now much easier for graduates to work overseas, to work in Australia but with global partners, or to create and market their own products. Innovation in design through a response to changing practice, the changing relationship of designers and consumers, of designers and off shore production, of designers to making through innovations in digital fabrication mean that students need to be introduced to new ways of working and thinking about work. This course supports the development of an internationalized cohort of graduate entrepreneurs and innovators who can take advantage of the emerging opportunities in industrial design practice in response to improved global communication, global networks and advanced technologies.
Subject_Description_28: Heat and Mass Transfer Engineering aims to equip future engineers with fundamental knowledge together with practical design and implementation skills for applications involving mass and energy balances, mass transfer, psychrometry, convection, heat conduction, and radiation heat transfer. Students will engage in engineering design project(s) involving selection, sizing and/or design of devices such as heat exchangers, fans, pumps, ducting, condensers, distillation columns and air conditioners. Students will be required to propose fit-for-purpose solutions that meet the competing demands of their profession including sustainability, legal issues and commercial aspects. Engineering responsibility and skills in leadership, project control, whole systems design, whole systems thinking, risk management and effective human relations will be refined through this course.
Subject_Description_29: Stress analysis (also known as solid mechanics) provides techniques by which engineers can predict stress and strain distributions resulting from known loading conditions, so that the stability and strength of structural members and machine components under load can be assessed. Stress analysis is an essential tool in the analysis and design of structures and machines under load.
Subject_Description_30: Engineering mechanics is both a foundation and a framework for most engineering disciplines. This course provides a basic knowledge of Newtonian mechanics, rigid-body mechanics, elasticity and structural analysis. In particular, the principles of statics and their applications in engineering, the methods of static analysis, and techniques of engineering computation are expounded. Students are expected not only to acquire a good grasp of the principles but also to develop the computational and analytical skills which are vital in obtaining correct engineering solutions. In practice, a wrong solution can lead to an engineering disaster. This course is designed to enable students to acquire fundamental knowledge in engineering. It forms an integral part of the analysis and design training provided in the Engineering programs. This course is offered in trimester 2 and 3 at both the Gold Coast and Nathan campuses.
Subject_Description_31: For product solutions (commercial, industrial, medical etc) to work effectively, the industrial designer needs to design for the ergonomics relating to the human machine interface and the psychology that drives the emotional and action responses of the user to the product. In this course students study and evaluate current human machine interfaces, redesign and test examples of current products and, through project based learning, design for innovative interface interaction. The project outcomes are achieved through the application of research, design thinking, electronics and programming.
Subject_Description_32: This course introduces designing for 3D printing. This practical course introduces students to key stages of the design development process and human centred design strategies, identifying user behaviours and needs in the development of niche products. Fundamental skills are developed in the design and preparation of digital files, to create resolved 3D printed prototypes.
Subject_Description_33: Mechanical engineers need to possess sound understanding of the physics of the design and use of machine elements such as gears, cams, springs, pulleys, joints etc., that are used in engineered components. This design process is deeply enshrined in established design standards/codes that all engineers should be knowledgeable of. 2505ENG Design of Machine Elements is aimed at integrating and applying prior knowledge in fundamental design, materials sciences, statics and dynamics coupled with design strategies and knowledge of machine elements to design various machines. These skills and knowledge help engineers to design, analyse, synthesize and deliver robust engineering solutions. The main learning outcome of this unit is the students' acquisition of strong analytical knowledge of machine elements, their design and load carriage/power transmission mechanics. This unit will be delivered through a combination of specially developed lectures, design problem solving methods, case studies and hands-on design assignments' all rolled together into workshops. Please check the "assumed knowledge" for this course under the course profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. This course is planned to be offered for the last time in 2018. Please consult your program director for a suitable alternative. This course will be replaced by 3511ENG">3511ENG from 2019. Incompatible: 3511ENG">3511ENG Design of Machine Elements
Subject_Description_34: Kinematics & Dynamics equips graduates with a solid understanding of the key concepts of mechanics required for design and analysis of mechanisms and mechanical devices. Topics covered include kinematics and dynamics of mechanical components modelled as particles and plane rigid bodies, interconnected objects, rotational dynamics, work and energy methods, translating and rotating coordinate systems, vector methods, three-dimensional dynamics of rigid bodies and an introduction to vibration Please check the "assumed knowledge" for this course under the course profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. This course is planned to be offered for the first time in 2018, trimester 1 and replaces 3317ENG.
Subject_Description_35: The course introduces students to the theory and practice of control systems. It discusses the basic (introductory) methods of control systems analysis and design, with emphasis on the principle of negative feedback which is the essence of operation of control systems. Engineering examples are used to introduce and illustrate the usefulness of the control systems theory and to make the students aware of this important engineering area. Assessment is by lab preliminaries, reports on laboratory experiments, and a final examination.
Subject_Description_36: This course provides an introduction to designing for students working in 3D across related disciplines, such as product and interiors, art and engineering, jewellery and graphic objects. Students develop a design process during the course that they can build on in future courses, with the creativity, research skills and understanding to frame design problems, create design intent, develop their designs fed by active research, and present concepts that respond to those problems. It also involves practical activities to develop drawing for design skills, studio modelling skills (e.g. cardboard and foam) and creative communication skills.
Subject_Description_37: This course provides the fundamental knowledge of fluid mechanics and hydraulics including fluid properties, fluid statics, conservation of mass, energy equation, flow in conduits, pumps and turbines, flow around objects, open channel flow and compressible flow.
Subject_Description_38: This experiential learning course introduces students to the engineering design process and professional aspects of being an Engineer or Industrial Designer. The course takes into consideration the increasingly complex interactions between engineering systems, project stakeholders and the environment, including the positive role of engineering in sustainable development as well as the potentially adverse impacts of engineering activities. Exposure to engineers and designers who are in the workforce will be a feature of this course.
Subject_Description_39: The course revises and extends basic integral and differential calculus of one variable and introduces differential equations. It provides a foundation in the mathematical sciences needed for later studies both in an engineering and science context. This course is for Engineering or ICT students ONLY. Incompatible: 1202SCG Calculus I
Subject_Description_40: This experiential learning based course introduces the natural and physical sciences that underpin the practice of engineering. Through projects students will apply science fundamentals to the systematic investigation, interpretation, and analysis of some engineering problems. Topics covered include Newtonian mechanics and electrical principles. Incompatible: 1031SCG (Physics IA).

Course: Bachelor of Engineering (Honours)/Bachelor of Information Technology
Description: When you combine engineering and IT, you'll gain the knowledge and skills needed to plan, manage, design and build engineering projects. You'll also develop communication, research and critical analysis skills that will make you highly employable. In fact, two of the fastest growing sectors for jobs growth are engineering and IT. With these two disciplines at its core, this double degree will set you up for a wide choice of career opportunities. You'll develop the knowledge and practical skills in planning, management, design and build of engineering projects, with your choice of major allowing you to specialise in the area you're most interested in. You'll also achieve a high level of core IT technical knowledge and a specialisation in either information systems or networks and security. What makes our Engineering and IT double degree stand out is the opportunity to put what you learn in the classroom into practice through work-integrated learning. We have a wide range of industry contacts and partnerships, ensuring you get to experience hands-on learning throughout your study. In your final year, you'll enhance your employability by working in a engineering organisation where you will complete a design project while working alongside professionals. You'll graduate with a degree accredited by the national engineering body, Engineers Australia, and by the Australian Computer Society. You'll be set to work in local, national and international sectors across complex systems and projects. Employment opportunities include roles in civil construction, engineering consulting, manufacturing, mining, oil, corporate IT, research, technology companies and government authorities. Changes effective for students commencing from Trimester 2 2020 onwards: Engineering Information technology Alternatively, you can choose not to complete a major and select from an extensive list of information technology electives. Tailor your timetable - Even if you study full-time on-campus, you may still be able to customise your degree to suit your needs. From a range of tutorial times to online access to lectures and other course material, we're here to help you fit study in with your work and life commitments.  Students may be eligible to do an international field trip, organised by the academic staff. This may count towards a component of the degree, depending on its structure.
Career_Outcomes: Key employment sectors* Potential job outcomes *Source: Australian Government Job Outlook
Subject_Description_1: Mechanical Engineering Design is the creative development of mechanical products or systems. This course focuses on mechanical design through a project based learning approach. Students will work on a design and analyse (and/or build) project, developing a solution to a real-world engineering design problem. Assessment is by a written design report, oral presentation/s and peer group assessment when relevant.
Subject_Description_2: This course introduces students to municipal solid waste engineering. The contents include municipal solid waste characteristics, storage and collection, transfer and transport, separation and processing, recycling, composting, incineration and landfilling.
Subject_Description_3: One of the roles of the IT professional is to design and build software systems and integrate them into an organisation. This course develops the skills to gather requirements, then develop/source, evaluate and integrate components into a single system, and finally validate the system. It also covers the fundamentals of software lifecycles, quality, software development processes, project management and the interplay between IT applications and organisational processes and relevant standards and tools.
Subject_Description_4: This course covers some aspects of a computer system architecture and organisation. It will introduce the students to the basic components of a computer system showing how the system components interact with the processor such as the operating system, the memory controller, and the I/O subsystem. The course also contains an in depth look at many mainstream bus architectures used in industry. It not only focuses on the hardware components of computer based systems, the students are also taught the importance of the components that make an operating system. Students are encouraged to learn about operating systems through the development of a Real-time operating system for a mainstream micro-controller. Throughout the course, the assignments and laboratories will be used to further develop the practical skills of the students. Incompatible: 3021MEE Computer Systems
Subject_Description_5: This course introduces the fundamental concepts and methods of general chemistry. Basic skills of laboratory chemical analysis are developed. Lecture content includes three modules: Introduction and basic concepts; molecular structure and bonding; and energy and physical processes. Incompatible: 1001SCE Chemistry 1A, 1009ENV General Chemistry, 1001ENV Chemistry 1, 1023SCG Chemistry 1
Subject_Description_6: This course mainly covers the analysis and design of reinforced and prestressed concrete structural elements. Both strength and serviceability design requirements are covered. Problem solving exercises based on actual design situations are utilised extensively in this course. After completing this course students will be able to analyse and design structural concrete elements and structures. Assessment is by, tutorial and design assignments, and examinations.
Subject_Description_7: Programming is a foundational skill for all computing disciplines. This course develops skills and concepts that are essential to good programming practice and problem solving. It covers fundamental programming concepts, event-driven programming, object-oriented programming, basic data structures, and algorithmic processes.
Subject_Description_8: This course introduces students to engineering design practice utilising real world design exercises. The course gives students a solid grounding in current engineering practice and emphasises the importance of incorporating sustainable approaches and sound practices to their designs. This course may involve individual or team approaches, depending on the nature of the design task. Incompatible: 2106ENG Design for Civil Engineers
Subject_Description_9: Hydrology is concerned with the distribution and dynamics of water and water quality on or near the surface of earth. As fundamental engineering sciences, hydrology plays an important role in developing technical skills in water engineering and in understanding many of the contemporary water management issues. The course covers fundamental hydrologic processes such as rainfall, evaporation, infiltration, surface and ground water, and hydrologic extremes ie floods and droughts. In addition, the course develops technical skills to apply some basic techniques for hydrologic analysis and design with particular emphasis on flood estimation, flood frequency analysis, and flood routing. Learning activities include lectures and workshops.
Subject_Description_10: Soil Mechanics is an important part of geotechnical engineering that deals with the engineering properties of various soils. This course provides students with valuable opportunities to develop their understanding of the fundamentals of soil behavior, and skills that will allow them to apply their knowledge to solve real-life problems. Students will also have the opportunity to become familiar with various testing procedures and learn how to perform laboratory tests to determine the geotechnical properties of soil such as grain-size distribution, plasticity, compaction characteristics, and permeability. After completing this course, students will acquire sufficient knowledge and develop critical skills that will enable them to solve practical problems related to soil mechanics
Subject_Description_11: Stress analysis (also known as solid mechanics) provides techniques by which engineers can predict stress and strain distributions resulting from known loading conditions, so that the stability and strength of structural members and machine components under load can be assessed. Stress analysis is an essential tool in the analysis and design of structures and machines under load.
Subject_Description_12: This course explores the common modulation techniques including amplitude and angle modulation for both analogue and digital information signals. Applications examined include radio, television and telecommunications. The course looks at both system level and circuit level. Many examples are examined for circuits for mixers, modulators, demodulators, oscillators, frequency synthesisers, RF amplifiers and radio and television receivers and transmitters. Design of amplification stages utilising classes A, B, C and D are examined. Methods and importance of shielding at high frequencies is also covered. A series of laboratories explore construction and measurement of communication circuits. Incompatible: 2304ENG Communication Systems and Circuits AND 3007MEE Communication Systems and Circuits
Subject_Description_13: Engineering solutions are developed from an in depth understanding of the subject knowledge combined with a creative approach to problem solving that takes a step back from details to consider the challenge as a whole. Complex problem solving involves an understanding of individuals and systems, interconnections and innovation. Furthermore these solutions must also be considered in terms of sustainable development. This course introduces the student to engineering design through a project-based approach to the development of a product or piece of infrastructure as part of small design team.
Subject_Description_14: This course introduces the underlying structures and mechanisms of modern computer systems and networks. All students enrolled in an ICT degree need to have an understanding of the basic architecture and operation of computer systems. This course provides an overview of the hardware, software and network technologies that define modern computer systems. The course aims to provide students with the basic knowledge of how the components that define a computer work together and by extension an appreciation of the capabilities and limitations of computer systems. This knowledge assists students in the application of computing technologies to solve real world problems. This course material builds a foundation for further study in the field of information technology, and is a suitable prerequisite for many ICT courses. Incompatible: 1807ICT: Computer and Network Architectures.
Subject_Description_15: Information derived from data is important to the management, productivity and competitive advantage of an organisation. Data must be efficiently collected, organized, retrieved and managed to make it meaningful to the organisation. It is the role of the IT professional to develop, deploy, manage and integrate data and information systems to support the organisation. This course includes the organisation, modeling, transformation and presentation of data. Incompatible with 1804ICT.
Subject_Description_16: A key component to the discipline of Information Technology is the understanding and the advocacy of the user in the development of IT applications and systems. IT graduates must develop a mind-set that recognizes the importance of users and organisational contexts and employ user-centred methodologies in the development, evaluation, and deployment of IT applications and systems. This requires graduates to develop knowledge of HCI, including user and task analysis, human factors, ergonomics, application domains, user interface development tools and GUI frameworks, accessibility standards, and cognitive psychology.
Subject_Description_17: Heat and Mass Transfer Engineering aims to equip future engineers with fundamental knowledge together with practical design and implementation skills for applications involving mass and energy balances, mass transfer, psychrometry, convection, heat conduction, and radiation heat transfer. Students will engage in engineering design project(s) involving selection, sizing and/or design of devices such as heat exchangers, fans, pumps, ducting, condensers, distillation columns and air conditioners. Students will be required to propose fit-for-purpose solutions that meet the competing demands of their profession including sustainability, legal issues and commercial aspects. Engineering responsibility and skills in leadership, project control, whole systems design, whole systems thinking, risk management and effective human relations will be refined through this course.
Subject_Description_18: This course introduces students to the process of structural design including: dealing with a client and defining a design brief, load estimation, elementary structural analysis and the design of timber and steel members and connections using the relevant Australian Standard design codes.
Subject_Description_19: The course introduces students to the theory and practice of control systems. It discusses the basic (introductory) methods of control systems analysis and design, with emphasis on the principle of negative feedback which is the essence of operation of control systems. Engineering examples are used to introduce and illustrate the usefulness of the control systems theory and to make the students aware of this important engineering area. Assessment is by lab preliminaries, reports on laboratory experiments, and a final examination.
Subject_Description_20: The course will initially explore topics in relation to generic data communications, including: OSI model; PSTN modem technology ; Error correction ; Data compression ; Physical layer standards; Line codes ; Signals in noise ; Idle RQ and continuous RQ ; Link utilisation ; Link layer protocols ; Data over terrestrial and satellite radio. The second half of the course will look specifically at topics related to the application to computer networks, including: Network topologies; Network bearers and physical attachment ; LANs and WANs; CSMA and token protocols ; Networking protocol performance ; Bridges and routing ; Encryption and compression; Internet protocols ; SSL. A series of laboratories will cover relevant topics, in particular related to signals and performance of data systems. Please check the "assumed knowledge" for this course under the course profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment.
Subject_Description_21: This course deals with continuous-time signals and systems and is designed to build on the basic circuit analysis concepts covered in the course Electric Circuits. It provides a detailed study of continuous-time signals and systems in time domain as well as in transformed domain. Signal transforms (Fourier series, Fourier transform and Laplace transforms) are covered in detail. Further concepts such as signal sampling and aliasing are introduced. The theory is exemplified with processing of signals in MATLAB. Incompatible: 2006MEE Signals and Systems AND 2075ENG Signals and Systems
Subject_Description_22: This course extends the theoretical and practical content of the course 2305ENG Signals and Systems and covers fundamental topics in digital signal processing (DSP) such as A/D and D/A converters, analysis of discrete-time signals and systems, design of finite impulse response (FIR) and infinite impulse response (IIR) digital filters, multirate digital signal processing, etc. MATLAB (software) and digital signal processor boards (hardware) are used to provide hands-on experience to students. This course is planned to be offered for the last time in 2016 at the Gold Coast campus. The Nathan campus offering will continue as normal beyond 2016. Gold Coast students please consult your program director for a suitable alternative. Incompatible: 6321ENG
Subject_Description_23: Kinematics & Dynamics equips graduates with a solid understanding of the key concepts of mechanics required for design and analysis of mechanisms and mechanical devices. Topics covered include kinematics and dynamics of mechanical components modelled as particles and plane rigid bodies, interconnected objects, rotational dynamics, work and energy methods, translating and rotating coordinate systems, vector methods, three-dimensional dynamics of rigid bodies and an introduction to vibration Please check the "assumed knowledge" for this course under the course profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. This course is planned to be offered for the first time in 2018, trimester 1 and replaces 3317ENG.
Subject_Description_24: This course introduces the importance of microorganisms to natural and man made ecosystems, biogeochemical cycles, trophic pathways and their beneficial applications to modern industry. The course provides an understanding of the relationships of living organisms - microorganisms, plants and animals with each other and their abiotic environment. Fundamentals include microbial metabolism (aerobic and anaerobic respiration, photosynthesis, chemosynthesis, energy transformation); cellular transport (diffusion, osmosis and active transport); microbial growth; microbial genetics and environmentally significant biochemical pathways. The taxonomic classification of autotrophic and heterotrophic organisms will be covered together with their resource requirements - light, oxygen and nutrients. Ecosystem concepts of food webs, energy flow and mineral cycles, including the bioaccumulation and biomagnification of pollutants. Particular emphasis is placed on the role of micro-organisms in decomposition, biogeochemical cycles, waste water treatment, bioremediation, water quality and human and ecosystem health. The laboratories cover microbial biodiversity, techniques for the culture, staining and emumeration of microorganisms, animal and plant diversity with emphasis on bioindicators, water quality and macroinvertebrate sampling.
Subject_Description_25: This course introduces aspiring IT professionals to two topic areas that are critical to your working life. First, we will help you to unravel the ways in which information underpins business and organisational activity. Second, you will explore ways in which information systems are now critically important for managing activities and relationships with customers and suppliers. Incompatible: 1410ICT Introduction to Information Systems.
Subject_Description_26: The course considers the fundamental properties of metals and non-metallic materials. Students are introduced to the atomic and microstructure of materials and their relationship to mechanical and electrical properties. The course explores the mechanical concepts of stress, strain, elongation and material failure (including testing) and the phenomenon of electrical conduction. This course will be offered from 2017 in trimester 1 and 3, and replaces 1502ENG.
Subject_Description_27: This course has a major design project which further develops the practical engineering design skills students have already gained through the Environmental Engineering Design 1 and 2 courses. Students are required to design the basic infrastructure for a proposed site development with significant environmental issues to be addressed. The development of a cost effective and appropriate design solution and development of design and documentation skills are emphasised. The design project is carried out in teams, giving students the opportunity to experience the issues involved in working in teams towards a realistic project outcome. Advised Prerequisite: 4045 EVE - Environmental Engineering Design Project OR 3213ENG Environmental Engineering Design Project
Subject_Description_28: This course explores the major ethical, professional, social and legal issues arising from the widespread use of IT, highlighting dilemmas that may be faced by IT practitioners. The subject examines the key debates and controversies pertinent to IT and their social consequences through the use of key case studies. *This course replaces 2003ICT Professional Issues in IT. Prerequisite: Successful completion of 120CP of first or second year Information Technology /Multimedia courses
Subject_Description_29: This course provides some of the essential mathematical techniques to mathematicians and physical scientists, and applies them to scientific problems. The course covers basic material on multiple integrals of scalar functions as well as line and surface integrals of vector fields, the theorems of Gauss, Green and Stokes, Fourier series and integrals. It also introduces some of the common partial differential equations of applied mathematics and methods of solution mostly based on separation of variables. It also covers some topics on ordinary differential equations. Incompatible: 2001ENG Advanced ENG Mathematics, 2203NSC Mathematics 2A. Prerequisites: 1201SCG">1201SCG Linear Algebra and 1202SCG Calculus I. (Please note: for students enrolled in Program 1567 1201SCG">1201SCG Linear Algebra is a co-requisite). Students must pass both courses to enrol in 2205NSC.
Subject_Description_30: Geotechnical Engineering forms a major part of the work of a professional civil engineer. This course is designed to enable students to do the analysis prior to design of foundations. It also forms an integral part of the civil analysis and design training provided in the four-year Bachelor of Engineering program in Civil Engineering. The course covers: design and construction aspects of shallow foundations, piled foundations, earth pressure calculations, and slope stability analysis. The main purpose of this course is to develop the ability of the students to design the basic geotechnical foundations (i.e., shallow foundation and piled foundation) and analyse the common geotechnical engineering problems (e.g., slope stability).
Subject_Description_31: This course provides a practical and theoretical introduction to manufacturing technology with a primary focus on metal processing technologies and their applications in modern manufacturing industry. The course is designed for the 2nd year engineering students that already possess university-level fundamental knowledge about the properties of common engineering materials, the application of forces in engineering systems and have a basic understanding about the tools, machines and processes employed in fabrication of engineered products.
Subject_Description_32: This course covers the principles of electric motors and generators. Both DC and AC motors and generators are explored along with the application of single and multi-phase machines. State of the art drive, control and protection circuitry will also be considered along with solid state methods of providing AC supply. Practical work will enhance the understanding of these topics. Please check the "assumed knowledge" for this course under the course profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. This course will be offered from 2018 at the Gold Coast campus, in trimester 2, and replaces 6509ENG.
Subject_Description_33: This experiential learning based course introduces the natural and physical sciences that underpin the practice of engineering. Through projects students will apply science fundamentals to the systematic investigation, interpretation, and analysis of some engineering problems. Topics covered include Newtonian mechanics and electrical principles. Incompatible: 1031SCG (Physics IA).
Subject_Description_34: The capstone engineering project is undertaken in the final year of the program. Students are required to plan, execute and report on a research project with some independence while working with an academic supervisor who maintains regular contact and provides support and direction in the design and execution of the research. Projects based on industry requirements will be encouraged.
Subject_Description_35: This course develops an integrated approach to understanding and analysis of natural catchments. Principles and methods in hydrology and hydraulics will be used to analyse the dynamics of water and water-borne substances. We will address their sources, transport, mixing and dispersion in the environment as well as the implications to catchment management. Computer modelling software popular in the water engineering industry will be extensively used in this course.
Subject_Description_36: This course introduces students to the programming and interfacing of a modern microprocessor. The course outlines the theory behind microprocessors, with a focus on architecture, memory structures, and peripheral interfacing. The course also involves an insight into programming methodologies in assembler and illustrates ways of successfully debugging embedded systems. The course will give the student the background knowledge to successfully develop an embedded system using any microprocessor. The course is highly practical in approach and covers such areas as data acquisition, sensor interfacing, electronic control, and microprocessor communication protocols. Incompatible: 2010MEE Microprocessor Techniques AND 1073ENG Microprocessors AND 3323ENG MicroController Techniques
Subject_Description_37: This course covers fundamental electromagnetic theory including Electrostatics, Magnetostatics, Electromagnetic Induction, Electromagnetic Radiation, Properties of Matter and finally finishing with Maxwell's equations. This basic theory is then used to explore the principles of propagation on guided media such as cables and waveguides. Basic principles such as the Telegraph equations lead to characteristic impedance, reflection and transmission coefficient, standing and travelling waves. Simple modes in rectangular and circular waveguides are examined and fundamental dispersion issues are addressed. Smith charts are used as a calculation tool for transmission problems and numerous matching and coupling problems are attempted. A series of laboratories explore measurements of signals and fields on simple systems.
Subject_Description_38: Mechanics of Materials 2 provides techniques by which engineers can determine stress and strain distributions resulting from known loading conditions, so that the stability and strength of structural members under load can be examined. The learners will acquire the knowledge in the analysis and design of structures and machines under load.
Subject_Description_39: The supply of good quality water, together with the removal of subsequent wastewater, is essential for modern communities. This course deals with the theory, methods, processes and design principles involved in treating and managing water and wastewater, including reticulation systems. The main focus is on municipal use of water and municipal wastewater production. This course concentrates on providing a solid understanding of conventional practice.
Subject_Description_40: The Course introduces students to advanced materials and their applications with the aim to deepen their understanding about i) how materials properties guide materials selection at the product design stage, ii) how core materials properties (either surface- or bulk properties) are changed, adapted or mended to specific user environment and/or an application field through a variety of manufacturing methods, and iii) how commercial material objects (or products) are manufactured in a factory setting. The Course will endue students with relevant knowledge on current materials surface technology, material treatment processes and manufacturing and production system processes, process technology and manufacturing systems design. Additive and rapid prototyping technology and lean engineering/lean production will be also be discussed in this Course. The Course is designed for 3rd year engineering students that already possess university-level fundamental knowledge on properties of common engineering materials such as metals, polymers, ceramics and attained theoretical and practical knowledge on fabrication and processing methods for these materials. The Course is developed to provide a practical, project-based immersion into materials selection process (with real, commercial products used as study samples) where students will learn how initial material selection process effects the geometry, structure, performance and cost of a final product. Assessment is by group assignment, oral presentation and individual examination. Please check the "Assumed Knowledge" for this course under the Course Profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. Incompatible: 2506ENG Materials and Manufacturing

Course: Bachelor of Engineering (Honours)/Bachelor of Information Technology
Description: When you combine engineering and IT, you'll gain the knowledge and skills needed to plan, manage, design and build engineering projects. You'll also develop communication, research and critical analysis skills that will make you highly employable. In fact, two of the fastest growing sectors for jobs growth are engineering and IT. With these two disciplines at its core, this double degree will set you up for a wide choice of career opportunities. You'll develop the knowledge and practical skills in planning, management, design and build of engineering projects, with your choice of major allowing you to specialise in the area you're most interested in. You'll also achieve a high level of core IT technical knowledge and a specialisation in either information systems or networks and security. What makes our Engineering and IT double degree stand out is the opportunity to put what you learn in the classroom into practice through work-integrated learning. We have a wide range of industry contacts and partnerships, ensuring you get to experience hands-on learning throughout your study. In your final year, you'll enhance your employability by working in a engineering organisation where you will complete a design project while working alongside professionals. You'll graduate with a degree accredited by the national engineering body, Engineers Australia, and by the Australian Computer Society. You'll be set to work in local, national and international sectors across complex systems and projects. Employment opportunities include roles in civil construction, engineering consulting, manufacturing, mining, oil, corporate IT, research, technology companies and government authorities. Changes effective for students commencing from Trimester 2 2020 onwards: Engineering Information technology Alternatively, you can choose not to complete a major and select from an extensive list of information technology electives. Tailor your timetable - Even if you study full-time on-campus, you may still be able to customise your degree to suit your needs. From a range of tutorial times to online access to lectures and other course material, we're here to help you fit study in with your work and life commitments.  Students may be eligible to do an international field trip, organised by the academic staff. This may count towards a component of the degree, depending on its structure.
Career_Outcomes: Key employment sectors* Potential job outcomes *Source: Australian Government Job Outlook
Subject_Description_1: This course provides the fundamental knowledge of fluid mechanics and hydraulics including fluid properties, fluid statics, conservation of mass, energy equation, flow in conduits, pumps and turbines, flow around objects, open channel flow and compressible flow.
Subject_Description_2: Programming is a foundational skill for all computing disciplines. This course develops skills and concepts that are essential to good programming practice and problem solving. It covers fundamental programming concepts, event-driven programming, object-oriented programming, basic data structures, and algorithmic processes.
Subject_Description_3: This course deals with continuous-time signals and systems and is designed to build on the basic circuit analysis concepts covered in the course Electric Circuits. It provides a detailed study of continuous-time signals and systems in time domain as well as in transformed domain. Signal transforms (Fourier series, Fourier transform and Laplace transforms) are covered in detail. Further concepts such as signal sampling and aliasing are introduced.
