The theory is exemplified with processing of signals in MATLAB. Incompatible: 2006MEE Signals and Systems AND 2075ENG Signals and Systems
Subject_Description_4: This course covers the theory and algorithms of statistical digital signal processing, estimation and modelling together with their applications in the electrical and electronic engineering disciplines. The first half of the course covers the mathematical preliminaries in deterministic digital signal processing, such as the z-transform, discrete-time Fourier transform, FIR and IIR filter design. The second half covers the core of the course, which examines the modelling and estimation of random signals and processes using spectral estimation, optimal filtering, linear MMSE estimation (Wiener and Kalman filtering), and adaptive filters. Emphasis is placed on electrical and electronic engineering applications, such as signal enhancement, signal detection in noise, adaptive noise cancellation, time-series prediction and machine learning. Students will also learn how to implement signal processing algorithms in software (using the Python language) and embedded DSP hardware. Incompatible: 3303ENG Digital Signal Processing
Subject_Description_5: The course revises and extends basic integral and differential calculus of one variable and introduces differential equations. It provides a foundation in the mathematical sciences needed for later studies both in an engineering and science context. This course is for Engineering or ICT students ONLY. Incompatible: 1202SCG Calculus I
Subject_Description_6: This experiential learning based course introduces the natural and physical sciences that underpin the practice of engineering. Through projects students will apply science fundamentals to the systematic investigation, interpretation, and analysis of some engineering problems. Topics covered include Newtonian mechanics and electrical principles. Incompatible: 1031SCG (Physics IA).
Subject_Description_7: Hydrology is concerned with the distribution and dynamics of water and water quality on or near the surface of earth. As fundamental engineering sciences, hydrology plays an important role in developing technical skills in water engineering and in understanding many of the contemporary water management issues. The course covers fundamental hydrologic processes such as rainfall, evaporation, infiltration, surface and ground water, and hydrologic extremes ie floods and droughts. In addition, the course develops technical skills to apply some basic techniques for hydrologic analysis and design with particular emphasis on flood estimation, flood frequency analysis, and flood routing. Learning activities include lectures and workshops.
Subject_Description_8: The course introduces basic vector algebra in two and three dimensions, matrices, complex numbers, probability and revises basic functions. It provides a foundation in the mathematical sciences for later studies in science and engineering. Prior Assumed Knowledge: It will be assumed that students have the knowledge equivalent to a grade of SA over 4 semesters in Mathematics B (Qld high school subject), or equivalent study over 4 semesters of a high school subject that includes the study of differential and integral calculus or 1017SCG">1017SCG Foundation Mathematics (grade of 4 or higher). For students who do not have this level of mathematics background, it is strongly suggested that they first complete 1017SCG">1017SCG Foundation Mathematics. Incompatible: 1201SCG Linear Algebra, 1011SCG Mathematics 1A, 1201BPS Mathematics 1A, 1666NSC Mathematics 1A for Engineers.
Subject_Description_9: Information derived from data is important to the management, productivity and competitive advantage of an organisation. Data must be efficiently collected, organized, retrieved and managed to make it meaningful to the organisation. It is the role of the IT professional to develop, deploy, manage and integrate data and information systems to support the organisation. This course includes the organisation, modeling, transformation and presentation of data. Incompatible with 1804ICT.
Subject_Description_10: All electrical signals produce electromagnetic fields be they communication signals or high current power transmissions. It is therefore vital to understand about the generation and manipulation of these fields. This course covers classical electrostatics in terms of charge and charge density in volumes, force due to charge, electric field intensity, electric potential and electric flux density. It also explores magnetostatics in terms of magnetic field intensity and flux density, magnetic forces, magnetic potential and inductance. Finally time varying fields are covered including moving conductors, transformers, displacement current and generation and motion. The outcome should be a complete understanding of Maxwell's equations applied to engineering problems.
Subject_Description_11: This course covers the principles of electric motors and generators. Both DC and AC motors and generators are explored along with the application of single and multi-phase machines. State of the art drive, control and protection circuitry will also be considered along with solid state methods of providing AC supply. Practical work will enhance the understanding of these topics. Please check the "assumed knowledge" for this course under the course profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. This course will be offered from 2018 at the Gold Coast campus, in trimester 2, and replaces 6509ENG.
Subject_Description_12: This course introduces students to the programming and interfacing of a modern microprocessor. The course outlines the theory behind microprocessors, with a focus on architecture, memory structures, and peripheral interfacing. The course also involves an insight into programming methodologies in assembler and illustrates ways of successfully debugging embedded systems. The course will give the student the background knowledge to successfully develop an embedded system using any microprocessor. The course is highly practical in approach and covers such areas as data acquisition, sensor interfacing, electronic control, and microprocessor communication protocols. Incompatible: 2010MEE Microprocessor Techniques AND 1073ENG Microprocessors AND 3323ENG MicroController Techniques
Subject_Description_13: Numerical analysis is the area of mathematics and computer science that creates, analyses, and implements algorithms for solving numerically the problems of continuous mathematics. In engineering, these problems arise naturally from the requirement to understand and design physical systems to serve our needs. The aim of this course is to learn how to formulate numerical solutions suitable for resolving the type of calculations commonly encountered in electrical engineering. This course will be offered from 2019 in trimester 2 at the Gold Coast campus.
Subject_Description_14: The course considers the fundamental properties of metals and non-metallic materials. Students are introduced to the atomic and microstructure of materials and their relationship to mechanical and electrical properties. The course explores the mechanical concepts of stress, strain, elongation and material failure (including testing) and the phenomenon of electrical conduction. This course will be offered from 2017 in trimester 1 and 3, and replaces 1502ENG.
Subject_Description_15: Kinematics & Dynamics equips graduates with a solid understanding of the key concepts of mechanics required for design and analysis of mechanisms and mechanical devices. Topics covered include kinematics and dynamics of mechanical components modelled as particles and plane rigid bodies, interconnected objects, rotational dynamics, work and energy methods, translating and rotating coordinate systems, vector methods, three-dimensional dynamics of rigid bodies and an introduction to vibration Please check the "assumed knowledge" for this course under the course profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. This course is planned to be offered for the first time in 2018, trimester 1 and replaces 3317ENG.
Subject_Description_16: This course will combine an extension of the study of geomechanics to pavement engineering techniques with the principles of traffic flow theory and pavement engineering techniques so that students can apply them to practice. The course covers traffic flow models, headway models, traffic fundamental diagrams, intersection design and assessment, pavement engineering and design, pavement condition survey and pavement management. This course will be assessed by individual based assignment, mid trimester exam, and final exam.
Subject_Description_17: Electromagnetic Waves and Propagation is a lecture and laboratory based course in which students are introduced to tools and design techniques for engineering applications in which electromagnetic waves generated by sources of alternating current play a dominant role. These applications typically involve the transmission of waves over metallic or dielectric transmission lines or through free space, with the purpose of transporting either information or electric power.
Subject_Description_18: Organisations typically use many disparate technologies to achieve their business objectives. This course first gives an overview of low-level technologies such as programming with a focus on code reuse, scripting techniques and software configuration tools. This is followed by a practical presentation of software packages commonly used for handling data and producing reports and presentations. Pre-Requisite: 2807ICT Programming Principles for BIT students OR 2701ICT Interactive Application Development OR 2702ICT Intelligent Media Systems for BCIM students
Subject_Description_19: The course introduces students to the theory and practice of control systems. It discusses the basic (introductory) methods of control systems analysis and design, with emphasis on the principle of negative feedback which is the essence of operation of control systems. Engineering examples are used to introduce and illustrate the usefulness of the control systems theory and to make the students aware of this important engineering area. Assessment is by lab preliminaries, reports on laboratory experiments, and a final examination.
Subject_Description_20: Geotechnical Engineering forms a major part of the work of a professional civil engineer. This course is designed to enable students to do the analysis prior to design of foundations. It also forms an integral part of the civil analysis and design training provided in the four-year Bachelor of Engineering program in Civil Engineering. The course covers: design and construction aspects of shallow foundations, piled foundations, earth pressure calculations, and slope stability analysis. The main purpose of this course is to develop the ability of the students to design the basic geotechnical foundations (i.e., shallow foundation and piled foundation) and analyse the common geotechnical engineering problems (e.g., slope stability).
Subject_Description_21: This course explores the major ethical, professional, social and legal issues arising from the widespread use of IT, highlighting dilemmas that may be faced by IT practitioners. The subject examines the key debates and controversies pertinent to IT and their social consequences through the use of key case studies. *This course replaces 2003ICT Professional Issues in IT. Prerequisite: Successful completion of 120CP of first or second year Information Technology /Multimedia courses
Subject_Description_22: The capstone engineering project is undertaken in the final year of the program. Students are required to plan, execute and report on a research project with some independence while working with an academic supervisor who maintains regular contact and provides support and direction in the design and execution of the research. Projects based on industry requirements will be encouraged.
Subject_Description_23: This course introduces students to engineering design practice utilising real world design exercises. The course gives students a solid grounding in current engineering practice and emphasises the importance of incorporating sustainable approaches and sound practices to their designs. This course may involve individual or team approaches, depending on the nature of the design task. Incompatible: 2106ENG Design for Civil Engineers
Subject_Description_24: This course covers fundamental and advanced topics in communications systems which are essential for Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Mechatronic Engineers, and Electronic and Biomedical Engineering. Knowledge on signals and systems, and Fourier transform is prerequisite for this course. Topics to be covered: (i) modulation AM, FM, (ii) digital modulation, digital transmission, (iii) introduction to mobile communications system and smart antennas, (iv) Wireless LANs, MIMO-OFDM for wireless, (v) Cellular Radio Communications, (vi) Microwave Engineering and communications, and (vii) introduction to Satellite Communications..
Subject_Description_25: Mechanics of Materials 2 provides techniques by which engineers can determine stress and strain distributions resulting from known loading conditions, so that the stability and strength of structural members under load can be examined. The learners will acquire the knowledge in the analysis and design of structures and machines under load.
Subject_Description_26: This course has a major design project which further develops the practical engineering design skills students have already gained through the Environmental Engineering Design 1 and 2 courses. Students are required to design the basic infrastructure for a proposed site development with significant environmental issues to be addressed. The development of a cost effective and appropriate design solution and development of design and documentation skills are emphasised. The design project is carried out in teams, giving students the opportunity to experience the issues involved in working in teams towards a realistic project outcome. Advised Prerequisite: 4045 EVE - Environmental Engineering Design Project OR 3213ENG Environmental Engineering Design Project
Subject_Description_27: All construction projects have the common feature of utilising engineering principles, people, machines and materials as well as requiring organisation and planning. This course covers the range of construction equipment and techniques in common use and the planning and direction of construction works. Attention is also given to rock and bulk excavations, health and safety at work sites, preliminary works, formwork design and an introduction to engineering economics. Assessment is by assignments and examinations. Incompatible: 2104ENG Construction Engineering
Subject_Description_28: This course provides a practical and theoretical introduction to manufacturing technology with a primary focus on metal processing technologies and their applications in modern manufacturing industry. The course is designed for the 2nd year engineering students that already possess university-level fundamental knowledge about the properties of common engineering materials, the application of forces in engineering systems and have a basic understanding about the tools, machines and processes employed in fabrication of engineered products.
Subject_Description_29: Mechanical Engineering Design is the creative development of mechanical products or systems. This course focuses on mechanical design through a project based learning approach. Students will work on a design and analyse (and/or build) project, developing a solution to a real-world engineering design problem. Assessment is by a written design report, oral presentation/s and peer group assessment when relevant.
Subject_Description_30: This course is the final design project in the civil engineering programs. It builds on earlier design courses and other engineering knowledge. The course involves a major 'real world' design project where students are encouraged to work in teams, but are individually assessed. Students are also exposed to the project management aspects of engineering projects. The course brings together and further enhances a range of generic skills such as teamwork, problem solving and communication.
Subject_Description_31: A key component to the discipline of Information Technology is the understanding and the advocacy of the user in the development of IT applications and systems. IT graduates must develop a mind-set that recognizes the importance of users and organisational contexts and employ user-centred methodologies in the development, evaluation, and deployment of IT applications and systems. This requires graduates to develop knowledge of HCI, including user and task analysis, human factors, ergonomics, application domains, user interface development tools and GUI frameworks, accessibility standards, and cognitive psychology.
Subject_Description_32: Electrical Design Project is a practical project based course in which students are challenged to apply fundamental knowledge of analogue and digital components, circuitry and systems to design, implement and demonstrate a functional electronic device meeting prescribed system requirements. Students are guided through a systematic design process involving analysis of requirements, circuit design and simulation, component selection, prototype construction, testing, evaluation and revision. An integral part of the process is the production and maintenance of engineering documentation in the form of technical specifications, schematic diagrams, list of components, test procedures and performance results. Incompatible: 3312ENG Practical Electronics I
Subject_Description_33: This course introduces the underlying structures and mechanisms of modern computer systems and networks. All students enrolled in an ICT degree need to have an understanding of the basic architecture and operation of computer systems. This course provides an overview of the hardware, software and network technologies that define modern computer systems. The course aims to provide students with the basic knowledge of how the components that define a computer work together and by extension an appreciation of the capabilities and limitations of computer systems. This knowledge assists students in the application of computing technologies to solve real world problems. This course material builds a foundation for further study in the field of information technology, and is a suitable prerequisite for many ICT courses. Incompatible: 1807ICT: Computer and Network Architectures.
Subject_Description_34: One of the roles of the IT professional is to design and build software systems and integrate them into an organisation. This course develops the skills to gather requirements, then develop/source, evaluate and integrate components into a single system, and finally validate the system. It also covers the fundamentals of software lifecycles, quality, software development processes, project management and the interplay between IT applications and organisational processes and relevant standards and tools.
Subject_Description_35: As an engineer you will be faced with problems that require you to devise innovative and practical solutions. Some problems may be simple and you will solve them drawing on knowledge you acquired through your course of study or using your accumulated experiences. On the other hand, there will be cases where your experience and academic training are not sufficient. In these cases, you will need to engage in research. Being able to source valid and credible information and analyse information statistically in order to formulate viable solutions is an important skill that all engineers need and which Engineers Australia expects you to have. The research and statistics skills you learn in this course will also help you throughout your studies at Griffith University. Research is a key component in Undergraduate degrees at Griffith University. Moreover, the skills learnt in this course are of vital importance to students who intend to pursue higher degree research studies. Therefore, this course aims to equip you with the skills needed to conduct valid research and statistical analysis be it in academic or industrial practice context.
Subject_Description_36: This course covers the concepts and components of electrical circuits and develops the fundamental circuit analysis and fault finding skills necessary to understand all electrical circuits. Circuit components such as resistors, capacitors and inductors and non-linear components such as diodes are studied progressing onto rectifiers, comparators and A/D and D/A converters. Analysis techniques include Kirchoff's laws, Thevenin/Norton equivalent circuits, time response of energy storage elements, sinusoidal steady state and frequency-domain analysis.
Subject_Description_37: The Course introduces students to advanced materials and their applications with the aim to deepen their understanding about i) how materials properties guide materials selection at the product design stage, ii) how core materials properties (either surface- or bulk properties) are changed, adapted or mended to specific user environment and/or an application field through a variety of manufacturing methods, and iii) how commercial material objects (or products) are manufactured in a factory setting. The Course will endue students with relevant knowledge on current materials surface technology, material treatment processes and manufacturing and production system processes, process technology and manufacturing systems design. Additive and rapid prototyping technology and lean engineering/lean production will be also be discussed in this Course. The Course is designed for 3rd year engineering students that already possess university-level fundamental knowledge on properties of common engineering materials such as metals, polymers, ceramics and attained theoretical and practical knowledge on fabrication and processing methods for these materials. The Course is developed to provide a practical, project-based immersion into materials selection process (with real, commercial products used as study samples) where students will learn how initial material selection process effects the geometry, structure, performance and cost of a final product. Assessment is by group assignment, oral presentation and individual examination. Please check the "Assumed Knowledge" for this course under the Course Profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. Incompatible: 2506ENG Materials and Manufacturing
Subject_Description_38: This course introduces students to the process of structural design including: dealing with a client and defining a design brief, load estimation, elementary structural analysis and the design of timber and steel members and connections using the relevant Australian Standard design codes.
Subject_Description_39: Structural design forms a major part of the work of a professional civil engineer. This course is designed to enable students to do the prerequisite analysis prior to design. It also forms an integral part of the structural analysis and design training provided in the four-year Bachelor of Engineering program in Civil Engineering. This course provides a thorough coverage of the theoretical basis for linear analysis of various types of skeletal (planar) structures encountered in Civil Engineering design work. The main purpose of this course is to develop the ability of the students to analyse planar structures using manual and computer-based methods.
Subject_Description_40: This experiential learning course introduces students to the engineering design process and professional aspects of being an Engineer or Industrial Designer. The course takes into consideration the increasingly complex interactions between engineering systems, project stakeholders and the environment, including the positive role of engineering in sustainable development as well as the potentially adverse impacts of engineering activities. Exposure to engineers and designers who are in the workforce will be a feature of this course.

Description: Engineering is a precise practice, and this double degree will arm you with the science disciplines to hone your technical precision. You'll study applied mathematics or physics and learn to balance the numbers with the art of creative and critical thinking. You'll also gain highly useful skills in mathematical modelling. In your final year, you can enhance your employability through an industry placement. With an internationally recognised qualification, you'll be prepared for work on complex projects in Australia and overseas. What makes our engineering and science double degree stand out is the opportunity to put what you learn in the classroom into practice through work-integrated learning. We have a wide range of industry contacts and partnerships, ensuring you get to experience hands-on learning throughout your study. In your final year, you'll enhance your employability by completing a project within industry. You'll graduate with a degree accredited by the national engineering body, Engineers Australia, and depending on your specialisation, you'll also be eligible for membership with the Australian Institute of Physics or the Australian Mathematical Society. With highly-sought after qualifications in engineering and science, you'll find inspiring career opportunities in government, construction, telecommunications, mining, oil, smelting and manufacturing industries.  Changes effective for students commencing from Trimester 2 2020 onwards: Engineering Science
Career_Outcomes: Key employment sectors* Potential job outcomes *Source: Australian Government Job Outlook
Subject_Description_1: This course introduces students to municipal solid waste engineering. The contents include municipal solid waste characteristics, storage and collection, transfer and transport, separation and processing, recycling, composting, incineration and landfilling.
Subject_Description_2: This course introduces students to the programming and interfacing of a modern microprocessor. The course outlines the theory behind microprocessors, with a focus on architecture, memory structures, and peripheral interfacing. The course also involves an insight into programming methodologies in assembler and illustrates ways of successfully debugging embedded systems. The course will give the student the background knowledge to successfully develop an embedded system using any microprocessor. The course is highly practical in approach and covers such areas as data acquisition, sensor interfacing, electronic control, and microprocessor communication protocols. Incompatible: 2303ENG Microprocessor Techniques AND 2010MEE Microprocessor Techniques AND 1073ENG Microprocessors
Subject_Description_3: Kinematics & Dynamics equips graduates with a solid understanding of the key concepts of mechanics required for design and analysis of mechanisms and mechanical devices. Topics covered include kinematics and dynamics of mechanical components modelled as particles and plane rigid bodies, interconnected objects, rotational dynamics, work and energy methods, translating and rotating coordinate systems, vector methods, three-dimensional dynamics of rigid bodies and an introduction to vibration Please check the "assumed knowledge" for this course under the course profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. This course is planned to be offered for the first time in 2018, trimester 1 and replaces 3317ENG.
Subject_Description_4: This course introduces the importance of microorganisms to natural and man made ecosystems, biogeochemical cycles, trophic pathways and their beneficial applications to modern industry. The course provides an understanding of the relationships of living organisms - microorganisms, plants and animals with each other and their abiotic environment. Fundamentals include microbial metabolism (aerobic and anaerobic respiration, photosynthesis, chemosynthesis, energy transformation); cellular transport (diffusion, osmosis and active transport); microbial growth; microbial genetics and environmentally significant biochemical pathways. The taxonomic classification of autotrophic and heterotrophic organisms will be covered together with their resource requirements - light, oxygen and nutrients. Ecosystem concepts of food webs, energy flow and mineral cycles, including the bioaccumulation and biomagnification of pollutants. Particular emphasis is placed on the role of micro-organisms in decomposition, biogeochemical cycles, waste water treatment, bioremediation, water quality and human and ecosystem health. The laboratories cover microbial biodiversity, techniques for the culture, staining and emumeration of microorganisms, animal and plant diversity with emphasis on bioindicators, water quality and macroinvertebrate sampling.
Subject_Description_5: This course is aimed at circuit design and printed circuit board implementation and finally the design of a complete electronic system. It involves PCB design, system and component specification, and design principles including noise reduction, transducers, ergonomics, power supplies, and design for testability. Students are required to complete a practical PCB design and a paper system design as part of their assessment. Incompatible: 3030MEE Pracitical Electronics AND 3076ENG Team Design Project Prerequisites: 1302ENG Introduction to Electronics AND 2301ENG Semiconductor Devices and Circuits
Subject_Description_6: The supply of good quality water, together with the removal of subsequent wastewater, is essential for modern communities. This course deals with the theory, methods, processes and design principles involved in treating and managing water and wastewater, including reticulation systems. The main focus is on municipal use of water and municipal wastewater production. This course concentrates on providing a solid understanding of conventional practice.
Subject_Description_7: This course introduces students to the basic concepts and principles of thermodynamics, and its selected engineering applications. Topics include the first law of thermodynamics, volumetric properties of pure substances, heat effects, the second law of thermodynamics, thermodynamic properties of fluids, and thermodynamic analysis of processes.
Subject_Description_8: The Course introduces students to advanced materials and their applications with the aim to deepen their understanding about i) how materials properties guide materials selection at the product design stage, ii) how core materials properties (either surface- or bulk properties) are changed, adapted or mended to specific user environment and/or an application field through a variety of manufacturing methods, and iii) how commercial material objects (or products) are manufactured in a factory setting. The Course will endue students with relevant knowledge on current materials surface technology, material treatment processes and manufacturing and production system processes, process technology and manufacturing systems design. Additive and rapid prototyping technology and lean engineering/lean production will be also be discussed in this Course. The Course is designed for 3rd year engineering students that already possess university-level fundamental knowledge on properties of common engineering materials such as metals, polymers, ceramics and attained theoretical and practical knowledge on fabrication and processing methods for these materials. The Course is developed to provide a practical, project-based immersion into materials selection process (with real, commercial products used as study samples) where students will learn how initial material selection process effects the geometry, structure, performance and cost of a final product. Assessment is by group assignment, oral presentation and individual examination. Please check the "Assumed Knowledge" for this course under the Course Profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. Incompatible: 2506ENG Materials and Manufacturing
Subject_Description_9: Stress analysis (also known as solid mechanics) provides techniques by which engineers can predict stress and strain distributions resulting from known loading conditions, so that the stability and strength of structural members and machine components under load can be assessed. Stress analysis is an essential tool in the analysis and design of structures and machines under load.
Subject_Description_10: This course provides the fundamental knowledge of fluid mechanics and hydraulics including fluid properties, fluid statics, conservation of mass, energy equation, flow in conduits, pumps and turbines, flow around objects, open channel flow and compressible flow.
Subject_Description_11: Heat and Mass Transfer Engineering aims to equip future engineers with fundamental knowledge together with practical design and implementation skills for applications involving mass and energy balances, mass transfer, psychrometry, convection, heat conduction, and radiation heat transfer. Students will engage in engineering design project(s) involving selection, sizing and/or design of devices such as heat exchangers, fans, pumps, ducting, condensers, distillation columns and air conditioners. Students will be required to propose fit-for-purpose solutions that meet the competing demands of their profession including sustainability, legal issues and commercial aspects. Engineering responsibility and skills in leadership, project control, whole systems design, whole systems thinking, risk management and effective human relations will be refined through this course.
Subject_Description_12: This course covers fundamental aspects of linear algebra and differential equations with applications to physical problems. Topics include: matrices and determinants; vector spaces; linear independence; basis sets; orthogonality; innner product spaces; eigenvalues and eigenvectors; series/sequences analysis; vector analysis; special functions and Laplace transforms. Incompatible: 2225SCE Physical Mathematics 2B, Concurrent prerequisite: 2205NSC Calculus 11
Subject_Description_13: Geotechnical Engineering forms a major part of the work of a professional civil engineer. This course is designed to enable students to do the analysis prior to design of foundations. It also forms an integral part of the civil analysis and design training provided in the four-year Bachelor of Engineering program in Civil Engineering. The course covers: design and construction aspects of shallow foundations, piled foundations, earth pressure calculations, and slope stability analysis. The main purpose of this course is to develop the ability of the students to design the basic geotechnical foundations (i.e., shallow foundation and piled foundation) and analyse the common geotechnical engineering problems (e.g., slope stability).
Subject_Description_14: Hydrology is concerned with the distribution and dynamics of water and water quality on or near the surface of earth. As fundamental engineering sciences, hydrology plays an important role in developing technical skills in water engineering and in understanding many of the contemporary water management issues. The course covers fundamental hydrologic processes such as rainfall, evaporation, infiltration, surface and ground water, and hydrologic extremes ie floods and droughts. In addition, the course develops technical skills to apply some basic techniques for hydrologic analysis and design with particular emphasis on flood estimation, flood frequency analysis, and flood routing. Learning activities include lectures and workshops.
Subject_Description_15: This course covers the principles of electric motors and generators. Both DC and AC motors and generators are explored along with the application of single and multi-phase machines. State of the art drive, control and protection circuitry will also be considered along with solid state methods of providing AC supply. Practical work will enhance the understanding of these topics. Please check the "assumed knowledge" for this course under the course profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. This course will be offered from 2018 at the Gold Coast campus, in trimester 2, and replaces 6509ENG.
Subject_Description_16: Soil Mechanics is an important part of geotechnical engineering that deals with the engineering properties of various soils. This course provides students with valuable opportunities to develop their understanding of the fundamentals of soil behavior, and skills that will allow them to apply their knowledge to solve real-life problems. Students will also have the opportunity to become familiar with various testing procedures and learn how to perform laboratory tests to determine the geotechnical properties of soil such as grain-size distribution, plasticity, compaction characteristics, and permeability. After completing this course, students will acquire sufficient knowledge and develop critical skills that will enable them to solve practical problems related to soil mechanics
Subject_Description_17: The capstone engineering project is undertaken in the final year of the program. Students are required to plan, execute and report on a research project with some independence while working with an academic supervisor who maintains regular contact and provides support and direction in the design and execution of the research. Projects based on industry requirements will be encouraged.
Subject_Description_18: Structural design forms a major part of the work of a professional civil engineer. This course is designed to enable students to do the prerequisite analysis prior to design. It also forms an integral part of the structural analysis and design training provided in the four-year Bachelor of Engineering program in Civil Engineering. This course provides a thorough coverage of the theoretical basis for linear analysis of various types of skeletal (planar) structures encountered in Civil Engineering design work. The main purpose of this course is to develop the ability of the students to analyse planar structures using manual and computer-based methods.
Subject_Description_19: This course provides engineering and architecture students with an overview of the principles, skills and techniques required for the evaluation, planning, and management of projects from inception through to completion.
Subject_Description_20: This course introduces students to engineering design practice utilising real world design exercises. The course gives students a solid grounding in current engineering practice and emphasises the importance of incorporating sustainable approaches and sound practices to their designs. This course may involve individual or team approaches, depending on the nature of the design task. Incompatible: 2106ENG Design for Civil Engineers
Subject_Description_21: The course introduces basic vector algebra in two and three dimensions, matrices, complex numbers, probability and revises basic functions. It provides a foundation in the mathematical sciences for later studies in science and engineering. Prior Assumed Knowledge: It will be assumed that students have the knowledge equivalent to a grade of SA over 4 semesters in Mathematics B (Qld high school subject), or equivalent study over 4 semesters of a high school subject that includes the study of differential and integral calculus or 1017SCG">1017SCG Foundation Mathematics (grade of 4 or higher). For students who do not have this level of mathematics background, it is strongly suggested that they first complete 1017SCG">1017SCG Foundation Mathematics. Incompatible: 1201SCG Linear Algebra, 1011SCG Mathematics 1A, 1201BPS Mathematics 1A, 1666NSC Mathematics 1A for Engineers.
Subject_Description_22: The course introduces students to the theory and practice of control systems. It discusses the basic (introductory) methods of control systems analysis and design, with emphasis on the principle of negative feedback which is the essence of operation of control systems. Engineering examples are used to introduce and illustrate the usefulness of the control systems theory and to make the students aware of this important engineering area. Assessment is by lab preliminaries, reports on laboratory experiments, and a final examination.
Subject_Description_23: As an engineer you will be faced with problems that require you to devise innovative and practical solutions. Some problems may be simple and you will solve them drawing on knowledge you acquired through your course of study or using your accumulated experiences. On the other hand, there will be cases where your experience and academic training are not sufficient. In these cases, you will need to engage in research. Being able to source valid and credible information and analyse information statistically in order to formulate viable solutions is an important skill that all engineers need and which Engineers Australia expects you to have. The research and statistics skills you learn in this course will also help you throughout your studies at Griffith University. Research is a key component in Undergraduate degrees at Griffith University. Moreover, the skills learnt in this course are of vital importance to students who intend to pursue higher degree research studies. Therefore, this course aims to equip you with the skills needed to conduct valid research and statistical analysis be it in academic or industrial practice context.
Subject_Description_24: This course covers some aspects of a computer system architecture and organisation. It will introduce the students to the basic components of a computer system showing how the system components interact with the processor such as the operating system, the memory controller, and the I/O subsystem. The course also contains an in depth look at many mainstream bus architectures used in industry. It not only focuses on the hardware components of computer based systems, the students are also taught the importance of the components that make an operating system. Students are encouraged to learn about operating systems through the development of a Real-time operating system for a mainstream micro-controller. Throughout the course, the assignments and laboratories will be used to further develop the practical skills of the students. Incompatible: 3021MEE Computer Systems
Subject_Description_25: This course explores the common modulation techniques including amplitude and angle modulation for both analogue and digital information signals. Applications examined include radio, television and telecommunications. The course looks at both system level and circuit level. Many examples are examined for circuits for mixers, modulators, demodulators, oscillators, frequency synthesisers, RF amplifiers and radio and television receivers and transmitters. Design of amplification stages utilising classes A, B, C and D are examined. Methods and importance of shielding at high frequencies is also covered. A series of laboratories explore construction and measurement of communication circuits. Incompatible: 2304ENG Communication Systems and Circuits AND 3007MEE Communication Systems and Circuits
Subject_Description_26: The course revises and extends basic integral and differential calculus of one variable and introduces differential equations. It provides a foundation in the mathematical sciences needed for later studies both in an engineering and science context. This course is for Engineering or ICT students ONLY. Incompatible: 1202SCG Calculus I
Subject_Description_27: Engineering solutions are developed from an in depth understanding of the subject knowledge combined with a creative approach to problem solving that takes a step back from details to consider the challenge as a whole. Complex problem solving involves an understanding of individuals and systems, interconnections and innovation. Furthermore these solutions must also be considered in terms of sustainable development. This course introduces the student to engineering design through a project-based approach to the development of a product or piece of infrastructure as part of small design team.
Subject_Description_28: This course has a major design project which further develops the practical engineering design skills students have already gained through the Environmental Engineering Design 1 and 2 courses. Students are required to design the basic infrastructure for a proposed site development with significant environmental issues to be addressed. The development of a cost effective and appropriate design solution and development of design and documentation skills are emphasised. The design project is carried out in teams, giving students the opportunity to experience the issues involved in working in teams towards a realistic project outcome. Advised Prerequisite: 4045 EVE - Environmental Engineering Design Project OR 3213ENG Environmental Engineering Design Project
Subject_Description_29: This course extends the theoretical and practical content of the course 2305ENG Signals and Systems and covers fundamental topics in digital signal processing (DSP) such as A/D and D/A converters, analysis of discrete-time signals and systems, design of finite impulse response (FIR) and infinite impulse response (IIR) digital filters, multirate digital signal processing, etc. MATLAB (software) and digital signal processor boards (hardware) are used to provide hands-on experience to students. This course is planned to be offered for the last time in 2016 at the Gold Coast campus. The Nathan campus offering will continue as normal beyond 2016. Gold Coast students please consult your program director for a suitable alternative. Incompatible: 6321ENG
Subject_Description_30: This course extends the physics presented in Physics 1A and provides a basis for further studies in physics and physical chemistry. It introduces students to Newton's Universal Law of Gravity, Special Relativity, Thermodynamics, multi-dimensional Wave phenomena, and Optics through lectures, tutorials, and laboratory classes. Prerequisites: 1031SCG Physics 1A or 1018ENG Engineering Science AND or 1011SCG Mathematics 1A or 1201SCG Linear Algebra. Co-Assumed: 1202SCG Calculus I or 1020ENG Engineering Mathematics 2.
Subject_Description_31: Mechanics of Materials 2 provides techniques by which engineers can determine stress and strain distributions resulting from known loading conditions, so that the stability and strength of structural members under load can be examined. The learners will acquire the knowledge in the analysis and design of structures and machines under load.
Subject_Description_32: This course provides some of the essential mathematical techniques to mathematicians and physical scientists, and applies them to scientific problems. The course covers basic material on multiple integrals of scalar functions as well as line and surface integrals of vector fields, the theorems of Gauss, Green and Stokes, Fourier series and integrals. It also introduces some of the common partial differential equations of applied mathematics and methods of solution mostly based on separation of variables. It also covers some topics on ordinary differential equations. Incompatible: 2001ENG Advanced ENG Mathematics, 2203NSC Mathematics 2A. Prerequisites: 1201SCG">1201SCG Linear Algebra and 1202SCG Calculus I. (Please note: for students enrolled in Program 1567 1201SCG">1201SCG Linear Algebra is a co-requisite). Students must pass both courses to enrol in 2205NSC.
Subject_Description_33: This course introduces students to the programming and interfacing of a modern microprocessor. The course outlines the theory behind microprocessors, with a focus on architecture, memory structures, and peripheral interfacing. The course also involves an insight into programming methodologies in assembler and illustrates ways of successfully debugging embedded systems. The course will give the student the background knowledge to successfully develop an embedded system using any microprocessor. The course is highly practical in approach and covers such areas as data acquisition, sensor interfacing, electronic control, and microprocessor communication protocols. Incompatible: 2010MEE Microprocessor Techniques AND 1073ENG Microprocessors AND 3323ENG MicroController Techniques
Subject_Description_34: This experiential learning based course introduces the natural and physical sciences that underpin the practice of engineering. Through projects students will apply science fundamentals to the systematic investigation, interpretation, and analysis of some engineering problems. Topics covered include Newtonian mechanics and electrical principles. Incompatible: 1031SCG (Physics IA).
Subject_Description_35: This course introduces students to the process of structural design including: dealing with a client and defining a design brief, load estimation, elementary structural analysis and the design of timber and steel members and connections using the relevant Australian Standard design codes.
Subject_Description_36: This course covers fundamental electromagnetic theory including Electrostatics, Magnetostatics, Electromagnetic Induction, Electromagnetic Radiation, Properties of Matter and finally finishing with Maxwell's equations. This basic theory is then used to explore the principles of propagation on guided media such as cables and waveguides. Basic principles such as the Telegraph equations lead to characteristic impedance, reflection and transmission coefficient, standing and travelling waves. Simple modes in rectangular and circular waveguides are examined and fundamental dispersion issues are addressed. Smith charts are used as a calculation tool for transmission problems and numerous matching and coupling problems are attempted. A series of laboratories explore measurements of signals and fields on simple systems.
Subject_Description_37: The course considers the fundamental properties of metals and non-metallic materials. Students are introduced to the atomic and microstructure of materials and their relationship to mechanical and electrical properties. The course explores the mechanical concepts of stress, strain, elongation and material failure (including testing) and the phenomenon of electrical conduction. This course will be offered from 2017 in trimester 1 and 3, and replaces 1502ENG.
Subject_Description_38: This course provides a practical and theoretical introduction to manufacturing technology with a primary focus on metal processing technologies and their applications in modern manufacturing industry. The course is designed for the 2nd year engineering students that already possess university-level fundamental knowledge about the properties of common engineering materials, the application of forces in engineering systems and have a basic understanding about the tools, machines and processes employed in fabrication of engineered products.
Subject_Description_39: This course introduces the fundamental concepts of electronics from the systems and signals perspective. Hardware implementations, such as A/D and D/A converters, rectifiers, wave-shaping circuits, and amplifiers are developed by making use of operational amplifiers, diodes, resistors, and capacitors to emphasise the system-building concepts (feedback, frequency response, transfer characteristics, impedance matching, and analysis by equivalent circuits). Circuit simulation (using SPICE) is used concurrently with real circuits and measurements to establish links between theory and practice. Incompatibles: 1005MEE Electronic Devices, Circuits and Systems AND 1031MEE Introduction to Electronics. Advised Prerequisites: 1301ENG Electric Circuits
Subject_Description_40: This course develops an integrated approach to understanding and analysis of natural catchments. Principles and methods in hydrology and hydraulics will be used to analyse the dynamics of water and water-borne substances. We will address their sources, transport, mixing and dispersion in the environment as well as the implications to catchment management. Computer modelling software popular in the water engineering industry will be extensively used in this course.

Description: Engineering is a precise practice, and this double degree will arm you with the science disciplines to hone your technical precision. You'll study applied mathematics or physics and learn to balance the numbers with the art of creative and critical thinking. You'll also gain highly useful skills in mathematical modelling. In your final year, you can enhance your employability through an industry placement. With an internationally recognised qualification, you'll be prepared for work on complex projects in Australia and overseas. What makes our engineering and science double degree stand out is the opportunity to put what you learn in the classroom into practice through work-integrated learning. We have a wide range of industry contacts and partnerships, ensuring you get to experience hands-on learning throughout your study. In your final year, you'll enhance your employability by completing a project within industry. You'll graduate with a degree accredited by the national engineering body, Engineers Australia, and depending on your specialisation, you'll also be eligible for membership with the Australian Institute of Physics or the Australian Mathematical Society. With highly-sought after qualifications in engineering and science, you'll find inspiring career opportunities in government, construction, telecommunications, mining, oil, smelting and manufacturing industries.  Changes effective for students commencing from Trimester 2 2020 onwards: Engineering Science Tailor your timetable - Even if you study full-time on-campus, you may still be able to customise your degree to suit your needs. From a range of tutorial times to online access to lectures and other course material, we're here to help you fit study in with your work and life commitments.  Students may be eligible to do an international field trip, organised by the academic staff. This may count towards a component of the degree, depending on its structure.
Career_Outcomes: Key employment sectors* Potential job outcomes *Source: Australian Government Job Outlook
Subject_Description_1: The course introduces basic vector algebra in two and three dimensions, matrices, complex numbers, probability and revises basic functions. It provides a foundation in the mathematical sciences for later studies in science and engineering. Prior Assumed Knowledge: It will be assumed that students have the knowledge equivalent to a grade of SA over 4 semesters in Mathematics B (Qld high school subject), or equivalent study over 4 semesters of a high school subject that includes the study of differential and integral calculus or 1017SCG">1017SCG Foundation Mathematics (grade of 4 or higher). For students who do not have this level of mathematics background, it is strongly suggested that they first complete 1017SCG">1017SCG Foundation Mathematics. Incompatible: 1201SCG Linear Algebra, 1011SCG Mathematics 1A, 1201BPS Mathematics 1A, 1666NSC Mathematics 1A for Engineers.
Subject_Description_2: Hydrology is concerned with the distribution and dynamics of water and water quality on or near the surface of earth. As fundamental engineering sciences, hydrology plays an important role in developing technical skills in water engineering and in understanding many of the contemporary water management issues. The course covers fundamental hydrologic processes such as rainfall, evaporation, infiltration, surface and ground water, and hydrologic extremes ie floods and droughts. In addition, the course develops technical skills to apply some basic techniques for hydrologic analysis and design with particular emphasis on flood estimation, flood frequency analysis, and flood routing. Learning activities include lectures and workshops.
Subject_Description_3: The capstone engineering project is undertaken in the final year of the program. Students are required to plan, execute and report on a research project with some independence while working with an academic supervisor who maintains regular contact and provides support and direction in the design and execution of the research. Projects based on industry requirements will be encouraged.
Subject_Description_4: Mechanical engineers need to possess sound understanding of the physics of the design and use of machine elements such as gears, cams, springs, pulleys, joints etc., that are used in engineered components. This design process is deeply enshrined in established design standards/codes that all engineers should be knowledgeable of. 3511ENG Design of Machine Elements is aimed at integrating and applying prior knowledge in fundamental design, materials sciences, statics and dynamics coupled with design strategies and knowledge of machine elements to design various machines. These skills and knowledge help engineers to design, analyse, synthesize and deliver robust engineering solutions. The main learning outcome of this unit is the students' acquisition of strong analytical knowledge of machine elements, their design and load carriage/power transmission mechanics. This course will be delivered through a combination of specially developed lectures, design problem solving methods, case studies and hands-on design assignments' all rolled together into workshops. Please check the "assumed knowledge" for this course under the course profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. This course is planned to be offered for the first time in 2019, trimester 2 and replaces 2505ENG">2505ENG. Incompatible: 2505ENG">2505ENG Design of Machine Elements
Subject_Description_5: This course covers the principles of electric motors and generators. Both DC and AC motors and generators are explored along with the application of single and multi-phase machines. State of the art drive, control and protection circuitry will also be considered along with solid state methods of providing AC supply. Practical work will enhance the understanding of these topics. Please check the "assumed knowledge" for this course under the course profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. This course will be offered from 2018 at the Gold Coast campus, in trimester 2, and replaces 6509ENG.
Subject_Description_6: This course provides some of the essential mathematical techniques to mathematicians and physical scientists, and applies them to scientific problems. The course covers basic material on multiple integrals of scalar functions as well as line and surface integrals of vector fields, the theorems of Gauss, Green and Stokes, Fourier series and integrals. It also introduces some of the common partial differential equations of applied mathematics and methods of solution mostly based on separation of variables. It also covers some topics on ordinary differential equations. Incompatible: 2001ENG Advanced ENG Mathematics, 2203NSC Mathematics 2A. Prerequisites: 1201SCG">1201SCG Linear Algebra and 1202SCG Calculus I. (Please note: for students enrolled in Program 1567 1201SCG">1201SCG Linear Algebra is a co-requisite). Students must pass both courses to enrol in 2205NSC.
Subject_Description_7: Stress analysis (also known as solid mechanics) provides techniques by which engineers can predict stress and strain distributions resulting from known loading conditions, so that the stability and strength of structural members and machine components under load can be assessed. Stress analysis is an essential tool in the analysis and design of structures and machines under load.
Subject_Description_8: Mechanical Engineering Design is the creative development of mechanical products or systems. This course focuses on mechanical design through a project based learning approach. Students will work on a design and analyse (and/or build) project, developing a solution to a real-world engineering design problem. Assessment is by a written design report, oral presentation/s and peer group assessment when relevant.
Subject_Description_9: This course introduces students to the basic concepts and principles of thermodynamics, and its selected engineering applications. Topics include the first law of thermodynamics, volumetric properties of pure substances, heat effects, the second law of thermodynamics, thermodynamic properties of fluids, and thermodynamic analysis of processes.
Subject_Description_10: The course revises and extends basic integral and differential calculus of one variable and introduces differential equations. It provides a foundation in the mathematical sciences needed for later studies both in an engineering and science context. This course is for Engineering or ICT students ONLY. Incompatible: 1202SCG Calculus I
Subject_Description_11: Structural design forms a major part of the work of a professional civil engineer. This course is designed to enable students to do the prerequisite analysis prior to design. It also forms an integral part of the structural analysis and design training provided in the four-year Bachelor of Engineering program in Civil Engineering. This course provides a thorough coverage of the theoretical basis for linear analysis of various types of skeletal (planar) structures encountered in Civil Engineering design work. The main purpose of this course is to develop the ability of the students to analyse planar structures using manual and computer-based methods.
Subject_Description_12: Geotechnical Engineering forms a major part of the work of a professional civil engineer. This course is designed to enable students to do the analysis prior to design of foundations. It also forms an integral part of the civil analysis and design training provided in the four-year Bachelor of Engineering program in Civil Engineering. The course covers: design and construction aspects of shallow foundations, piled foundations, earth pressure calculations, and slope stability analysis. The main purpose of this course is to develop the ability of the students to design the basic geotechnical foundations (i.e., shallow foundation and piled foundation) and analyse the common geotechnical engineering problems (e.g., slope stability).
Subject_Description_13: This course covers the theory and algorithms of statistical digital signal processing, estimation and modelling together with their applications in the electrical and electronic engineering disciplines. The first half of the course covers the mathematical preliminaries in deterministic digital signal processing, such as the z-transform, discrete-time Fourier transform, FIR and IIR filter design. The second half covers the core of the course, which examines the modelling and estimation of random signals and processes using spectral estimation, optimal filtering, linear MMSE estimation (Wiener and Kalman filtering), and adaptive filters. Emphasis is placed on electrical and electronic engineering applications, such as signal enhancement, signal detection in noise, adaptive noise cancellation, time-series prediction and machine learning. Students will also learn how to implement signal processing algorithms in software (using the Python language) and embedded DSP hardware. Incompatible: 3303ENG Digital Signal Processing
Subject_Description_14: This course provides a practical and theoretical introduction to manufacturing technology with a primary focus on metal processing technologies and their applications in modern manufacturing industry. The course is designed for the 2nd year engineering students that already possess university-level fundamental knowledge about the properties of common engineering materials, the application of forces in engineering systems and have a basic understanding about the tools, machines and processes employed in fabrication of engineered products.
Subject_Description_15: This course deals with continuous-time signals and systems and is designed to build on the basic circuit analysis concepts covered in the course Electric Circuits. It provides a detailed study of continuous-time signals and systems in time domain as well as in transformed domain. Signal transforms (Fourier series, Fourier transform and Laplace transforms) are covered in detail. Further concepts such as signal sampling and aliasing are introduced. The theory is exemplified with processing of signals in MATLAB. Incompatible: 2006MEE Signals and Systems AND 2075ENG Signals and Systems
Subject_Description_16: The Course introduces students to advanced materials and their applications with the aim to deepen their understanding about i) how materials properties guide materials selection at the product design stage, ii) how core materials properties (either surface- or bulk properties) are changed, adapted or mended to specific user environment and/or an application field through a variety of manufacturing methods, and iii) how commercial material objects (or products) are manufactured in a factory setting. The Course will endue students with relevant knowledge on current materials surface technology, material treatment processes and manufacturing and production system processes, process technology and manufacturing systems design. Additive and rapid prototyping technology and lean engineering/lean production will be also be discussed in this Course. The Course is designed for 3rd year engineering students that already possess university-level fundamental knowledge on properties of common engineering materials such as metals, polymers, ceramics and attained theoretical and practical knowledge on fabrication and processing methods for these materials. The Course is developed to provide a practical, project-based immersion into materials selection process (with real, commercial products used as study samples) where students will learn how initial material selection process effects the geometry, structure, performance and cost of a final product. Assessment is by group assignment, oral presentation and individual examination. Please check the "Assumed Knowledge" for this course under the Course Profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. Incompatible: 2506ENG Materials and Manufacturing
Subject_Description_17: Mechanics of Materials 2 provides techniques by which engineers can determine stress and strain distributions resulting from known loading conditions, so that the stability and strength of structural members under load can be examined. The learners will acquire the knowledge in the analysis and design of structures and machines under load.
Subject_Description_18: This course covers the concepts and components of electrical circuits and develops the fundamental circuit analysis and fault finding skills necessary to understand all electrical circuits. Circuit components such as resistors, capacitors and inductors and non-linear components such as diodes are studied progressing onto rectifiers, comparators and A/D and D/A converters. Analysis techniques include Kirchoff's laws, Thevenin/Norton equivalent circuits, time response of energy storage elements, sinusoidal steady state and frequency-domain analysis.
Subject_Description_19: This experiential learning based course introduces the natural and physical sciences that underpin the practice of engineering. Through projects students will apply science fundamentals to the systematic investigation, interpretation, and analysis of some engineering problems. Topics covered include Newtonian mechanics and electrical principles. Incompatible: 1031SCG (Physics IA).
Subject_Description_20: The main aim of this course is to provide sound knowledge of the principles and practices of digital systems, both at the device and circuit level. The course covers topics in digital electronics including: Number Theory, Boolean Algebra, Logic Circuits, Logic Minimisation Techniques, Multiplexers, Adders, Flip-Flops, Counters, Registers, State Machines, Memory Circuits, Digital / Analog Conversion, Programable Logic Circuits and Microcomputer Bus Architecture. Incompatible: 1004MEE Digital Networks and Systems AND 2072ENG Digital Systems AND 1303ENG Digital Systems
Subject_Description_21: Electromagnetic Waves and Propagation is a lecture and laboratory based course in which students are introduced to tools and design techniques for engineering applications in which electromagnetic waves generated by sources of alternating current play a dominant role. These applications typically involve the transmission of waves over metallic or dielectric transmission lines or through free space, with the purpose of transporting either information or electric power.
Subject_Description_22: Numerical analysis is the area of mathematics and computer science that creates, analyses, and implements algorithms for solving numerically the problems of continuous mathematics. In engineering, these problems arise naturally from the requirement to understand and design physical systems to serve our needs. The aim of this course is to learn how to formulate numerical solutions suitable for resolving the type of calculations commonly encountered in electrical engineering. This course will be offered from 2019 in trimester 2 at the Gold Coast campus.
Subject_Description_23: All construction projects have the common feature of utilising engineering principles, people, machines and materials as well as requiring organisation and planning. This course covers the range of construction equipment and techniques in common use and the planning and direction of construction works. Attention is also given to rock and bulk excavations, health and safety at work sites, preliminary works, formwork design and an introduction to engineering economics. Assessment is by assignments and examinations. Incompatible: 2104ENG Construction Engineering
Subject_Description_24: This course provides the fundamental knowledge of fluid mechanics and hydraulics including fluid properties, fluid statics, conservation of mass, energy equation, flow in conduits, pumps and turbines, flow around objects, open channel flow and compressible flow.
Subject_Description_25: This course will combine an extension of the study of geomechanics to pavement engineering techniques with the principles of traffic flow theory and pavement engineering techniques so that students can apply them to practice. The course covers traffic flow models, headway models, traffic fundamental diagrams, intersection design and assessment, pavement engineering and design, pavement condition survey and pavement management. This course will be assessed by individual based assignment, mid trimester exam, and final exam.
Subject_Description_26: This course covers fundamental and advanced topics in communications systems which are essential for Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Mechatronic Engineers, and Electronic and Biomedical Engineering. Knowledge on signals and systems, and Fourier transform is prerequisite for this course. Topics to be covered: (i) modulation AM, FM, (ii) digital modulation, digital transmission, (iii) introduction to mobile communications system and smart antennas, (iv) Wireless LANs, MIMO-OFDM for wireless, (v) Cellular Radio Communications, (vi) Microwave Engineering and communications, and (vii) introduction to Satellite Communications..
Subject_Description_27: Electrical Design Project is a practical project based course in which students are challenged to apply fundamental knowledge of analogue and digital components, circuitry and systems to design, implement and demonstrate a functional electronic device meeting prescribed system requirements. Students are guided through a systematic design process involving analysis of requirements, circuit design and simulation, component selection, prototype construction, testing, evaluation and revision. An integral part of the process is the production and maintenance of engineering documentation in the form of technical specifications, schematic diagrams, list of components, test procedures and performance results. Incompatible: 3312ENG Practical Electronics I
Subject_Description_28: The course introduces students to the theory and practice of control systems. It discusses the basic (introductory) methods of control systems analysis and design, with emphasis on the principle of negative feedback which is the essence of operation of control systems. Engineering examples are used to introduce and illustrate the usefulness of the control systems theory and to make the students aware of this important engineering area. Assessment is by lab preliminaries, reports on laboratory experiments, and a final examination.
Subject_Description_29: Soil Mechanics is an important part of geotechnical engineering that deals with the engineering properties of various soils. This course provides students with valuable opportunities to develop their understanding of the fundamentals of soil behavior, and skills that will allow them to apply their knowledge to solve real-life problems. Students will also have the opportunity to become familiar with various testing procedures and learn how to perform laboratory tests to determine the geotechnical properties of soil such as grain-size distribution, plasticity, compaction characteristics, and permeability. After completing this course, students will acquire sufficient knowledge and develop critical skills that will enable them to solve practical problems related to soil mechanics
Subject_Description_30: This course mainly covers the analysis and design of reinforced and prestressed concrete structural elements. Both strength and serviceability design requirements are covered. Problem solving exercises based on actual design situations are utilised extensively in this course. After completing this course students will be able to analyse and design structural concrete elements and structures. Assessment is by, tutorial and design assignments, and examinations.
Subject_Description_31: The course considers the fundamental properties of metals and non-metallic materials. Students are introduced to the atomic and microstructure of materials and their relationship to mechanical and electrical properties. The course explores the mechanical concepts of stress, strain, elongation and material failure (including testing) and the phenomenon of electrical conduction. This course will be offered from 2017 in trimester 1 and 3, and replaces 1502ENG.
Subject_Description_32: As an engineer you will be faced with problems that require you to devise innovative and practical solutions. Some problems may be simple and you will solve them drawing on knowledge you acquired through your course of study or using your accumulated experiences. On the other hand, there will be cases where your experience and academic training are not sufficient. In these cases, you will need to engage in research. Being able to source valid and credible information and analyse information statistically in order to formulate viable solutions is an important skill that all engineers need and which Engineers Australia expects you to have. The research and statistics skills you learn in this course will also help you throughout your studies at Griffith University. Research is a key component in Undergraduate degrees at Griffith University. Moreover, the skills learnt in this course are of vital importance to students who intend to pursue higher degree research studies. Therefore, this course aims to equip you with the skills needed to conduct valid research and statistical analysis be it in academic or industrial practice context.
Subject_Description_33: This course introduces students to engineering design practice utilising real world design exercises. The course gives students a solid grounding in current engineering practice and emphasises the importance of incorporating sustainable approaches and sound practices to their designs. This course may involve individual or team approaches, depending on the nature of the design task. Incompatible: 2106ENG Design for Civil Engineers
Subject_Description_34: This course is the final design project in the civil engineering programs. It builds on earlier design courses and other engineering knowledge. The course involves a major 'real world' design project where students are encouraged to work in teams, but are individually assessed. Students are also exposed to the project management aspects of engineering projects. The course brings together and further enhances a range of generic skills such as teamwork, problem solving and communication.
Subject_Description_35: Kinematics & Dynamics equips graduates with a solid understanding of the key concepts of mechanics required for design and analysis of mechanisms and mechanical devices. Topics covered include kinematics and dynamics of mechanical components modelled as particles and plane rigid bodies, interconnected objects, rotational dynamics, work and energy methods, translating and rotating coordinate systems, vector methods, three-dimensional dynamics of rigid bodies and an introduction to vibration Please check the "assumed knowledge" for this course under the course profile to ensure you meet the pre-requisites required for enrolment. This course is planned to be offered for the first time in 2018, trimester 1 and replaces 3317ENG.
Subject_Description_36: This course introduces students to the programming and interfacing of a modern microprocessor. The course outlines the theory behind microprocessors, with a focus on architecture, memory structures, and peripheral interfacing. The course also involves an insight into programming methodologies in assembler and illustrates ways of successfully debugging embedded systems. The course will give the student the background knowledge to successfully develop an embedded system using any microprocessor. The course is highly practical in approach and covers such areas as data acquisition, sensor interfacing, electronic control, and microprocessor communication protocols. Incompatible: 2010MEE Microprocessor Techniques AND 1073ENG Microprocessors AND 3323ENG MicroController Techniques
Subject_Description_37: Heat and Mass Transfer Engineering aims to equip future engineers with fundamental knowledge together with practical design and implementation skills for applications involving mass and energy balances, mass transfer, psychrometry, convection, heat conduction, and radiation heat transfer. Students will engage in engineering design project(s) involving selection, sizing and/or design of devices such as heat exchangers, fans, pumps, ducting, condensers, distillation columns and air conditioners. Students will be required to propose fit-for-purpose solutions that meet the competing demands of their profession including sustainability, legal issues and commercial aspects. Engineering responsibility and skills in leadership, project control, whole systems design, whole systems thinking, risk management and effective human relations will be refined through this course.
Subject_Description_38: Engineering solutions are developed from an in depth understanding of the subject knowledge combined with a creative approach to problem solving that takes a step back from details to consider the challenge as a whole.
