You will take courses that cover areas such as crime, contracts, property, corporate law, torts and theories of law. If you complete the five Canadian Law courses, you will be eligible for entry into the legal profession in Canada's common law provinces, when accompanied by a Certificate of Qualification from the National Committee on Accreditation (NCA) of the Federation of Law Societies of Canada. Environmental Science component You will gain knowledge and skills from across the broad environmental science spectrum, exploring environmental issues from social, physical and biological perspectives. Students will also be equipped with the skills required of an environmental practitioner and have the opportunity to undertake capstone projects or an industry placement.
Career_Outcomes: A law degree from Griffith University is your passport to the world and is recognised as a qualifying degree for admission into the legal profession in many countries around the world. As a graduate, you will be prepared to work in areas such as environmental and planning law, government, industry, environmental organisations and development companies.
Subject_Description_1: This course examines several major environmental challenges to society where natural systems have been severely affected as a result of the pressures of population growth, technology change, and economic growth based on increasing production and consumption. These issues will be considered from an interdisciplinary natural and social science perspective with a special secondary focus on the traditional knowledge of, and impacts to, First Nations' Peoples. Assessment for this course will emphasise development of diverse communication skills relevant for environmental analysis and effective problem-solving for achieving sustainability.
Subject_Description_2: This course provides a range of activities that will further develop inquiry and problem-solving skills and put the professional responsibilities of environmental science students into practice. A range of authentic learning experiences will see students conduct investigations (open investigations, experiments, field assessments, application of theory) as individuals, occasionally working in small teams if necessary, in which data is collected, recorded and interpreted using appropriate discipline specific approaches. Conclusions will be drawn and questions for future investigation highlighted. Assessment will be by the combination of a high-quality written report and an oral defense of this report. Incompatible: 3992SCG Science Capstone OR 3992NSC_Y1 & Y2 Science Capstone.
Subject_Description_3: This course introduces students to the law of civil wrongs. This is the body of principles aimed at compensating, rather than punishing, the victims of conduct causing harm, distress, or interference with property or reputation. Prerequisite Bachelor of Laws (Honours) students: 1031LAW">1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW">1011LAW Law and the Modern State. Co-requisite Bachelor of Laws (Honours) graduate entry students: 1031LAW">1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW">1011LAW Law and the Modern State. Incompatible: 2013LAW Introduction to Torts.
Subject_Description_4: Students are introduced to Geographic Information Systems that enable the capture, storage, manipulation and analysis of different types of spatial or geographical data. These systems are important tools for environmental scientists in managing environmental systems. Incompatible: 2205ENV Geographic Information Systems, 3047ENV Geographic Information Systems
Subject_Description_5: This course focuses upon the relationship between the natural environment and economic systems. It includes both the analysis and understanding of human economy impacts upon the natural systems that support it, as well as, approaches for the sustainable management of natural resources. The role of economics in the various decision-making approaches relevant to environmental resources is outlined. The content covers the major concepts and specific methods for the economic assessment of costs and benefits of ecosystems and other natural resources. The course also highlights concepts and theory for the economic analysis and policy for the sustainable management of both renewable and non-renewable resources. It covers and compares the contributions of both mainstream economic extensions as well as broader sustainability sciences such as ecological economics. Prerequisite: Completion of 80CP. Incompatible: 2281ENV Economics and Natural Resources, 2281AES Economics and Natural Resources.
Subject_Description_6: This course covers frameworks and approaches used for managing society's impacts on the environment. Topics include: environmental protection, environmental health, quality assurance and regulation, impact assessment and environmental auditing, catchment management and water resources, waste management, contaminated land; and environmental management in practice. Field work focused on environmental relevant activities will demonstrate how environmental management programs are implemented in industry settings.
Subject_Description_7: This course highlights the important role of environmental politics and policy in furthering understanding of and addressing constructively questions such as: Who is responsible for protecting the Australian environment? What is being done? How might more be done to achieve ecological sustainable development? How do we analyse this? As such, Environmental Politics and Policy introduces key environmental political institutions; policy actors, processes and policies; and issues, in the ecopolitical terrain, central to achieving effective environmental management for long term environmental sustainability. The course is essential for the fields of environmental politics, policy, management and planning. This is a condensed course taught in the first 6 weeks of the trimester. That said, assignments are due in Weeks 6, 7 and 10. Prerequisite: Completion of 80CP
Subject_Description_8: This course covers the laws that govern the creation and operation of government institutions within their political, social and economic contexts, especially the powers and limits on powers of parliaments to make laws under Australia's federal Constitution. Prerequisite: 1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW Law and the Modern State. Incompatible: 2002LAW Constitutional Law AND 2018LAW Introduction to Public Law.
Subject_Description_9: This course considers core aspects of the private law governing compensation for injuries and economic loss. The course focuses on common law remedies arising out of the law of negligence and non-intentional tort, as affected and modified by recent statutory tort reforms. Students are also introduced to other sources of injury compensation. These include the related torts of Breach of Statutory Duty, and statutory schemes such as Products Liability and Workers' Compensation. The course is taught and assessed in a critical vein, with students asked to consider the goals and efficacy of the common law and statutory compensation schemes, and the central role of policy in shaping legal responses to social problems. Co-requisite: 1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW Law and the Modern State. Incompatible: 3003LAW Negligence and Accident Compensation.
Subject_Description_10: This course introduces students to the concept of environmental sustainability and its uses in solving real world problems. It explores the relationships between the natural, rural, industrial and urban environments and includes the study of the impact humans have upon nature. The course also considers the way environmental sustainability can be used to address environmental, economic and social issues in an integrated way. Assessment includes on-line tests, a written assignment, workshop exercises and an end of trimester examination. Incompatible: 1301ENV The Global Environment, 1181ENV Sustainable Development, 1161ENV Environmental Economics and Policy.
Subject_Description_11: This course introduces students to the law of associations and partnerships, before turning to focus on the nature and legal structure of the corporation in Australia. The doctrinal areas of corporate law covered include: pre-incorporation issues, incorporation, authority and agency, directors' duties, members rights, corporate finance and external administration. Students are encouraged to examine these through theoretical frameworks. Prerequisites: 1030LAW Contracts 2 OR 1015LAW Contracts and Civil Obligations 2; 4024LAW Equity and Trusts OR 2010LAW Equity AND 2011LAW Trusts; Students must be enrolled in a Law program. Incompatible: 3002LAW Corporate Governance and Regulation AND 3005LAW Law of Associations.
Subject_Description_12: Environmental Anthropology is a sub-field of Anthropology that takes an active role in examining the relationships between humans and their environment across space and time. The course uses the lens of Anthropology to help students, as future environmental scientists, planners and managers, develop an understanding of the cultural beliefs, values and practices that inform how societies relate to their environments. This diverse cultural knowledge, and the practical implications of understanding alternative ways of engaging with the environment, assists us in the search for sustainable ways to manage the earth's natural resources. Prerequisite: Completion of 80CP. Incompatible: 2011ENV Anthropological Perspectives
Subject_Description_13: This course explores transitioning to future societies that can provide sustained and positive levels of wellbeing, and acceptable conditions of justice. The course is based upon the assumption that the environmental and social dimensions of human futures will be closely related. It considers the key role of indigenous peoples in transitioning towards preferred futures and takes into account the context for nations with different income and development situations. Creating communities that are sustainable, and produce high levels of wellbeing, is a major objective of almost all societies and there is growing demand for skilled practitioners who can contribute to this transformation. The primary topics for the course are team-taught across three major areas. These areas share many essential concepts and themes but are focus upon three core themes (1) potential future scenarios and their key dimensions, and the importance of ethics and values in assessing these scenarios, (2) indigeneity, the postcolonial contemporary world, human-human relationships, and human-nonhuman relationships, and (3) transformation paths to preferred environmental and social futures. Assessment is concentrated upon a major project outlining the form and pathway to positive community environmental and social futures. Online quizzes are also used for progressive assessment of key course content. Readings and materials, beyond lecture sources, will be provided via Learning@Griffith, to help students in their understanding of the course content, development of skills, and for assessment. Prerequisite: 1043SCG, OR 1444ENV or equivalent Completion of minimum 80CP Incompatible: 3041ENV.
Subject_Description_14: In this course, students will engage in a comprehensive examination of the substantive law, rules, and policies governing criminal justice in Queensland. The course covers a series of related criminal procedural issues and the sentencing process in the context of criminal investigations, trials, and appeals. Each week, legal, ethical, and policy issues relevant to substantive and procedural matters will be studied, discussed, and critically reflected upon. You will be encouraged to consider the effectiveness and fairness of Australia's adversarial criminal justice system. You will learn to interpret and apply the general principles and statutory laws governing criminal procedure. Prerequisites: 1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW Law and the Modern State; 2019LAW Crime 1 OR 4032LAW The Principles of Criminal Law; Students must be enrolled in a Law program. Incompatible: 4031LAW Criminal Procedure and Sentencing.
Subject_Description_15: Property 2 complements the content of Property 1, and continues to explore the concepts introduced there through a detailed consideration of key land law doctrines. The Course focuses on land law and features the regulation of land through the introduction and operation of the Torrens System, and covers doctrinal areas including boundaries to land, co-ownership, covenants, easements, equitable interests, mortgages and general law leasing. Students in Property 2 will develop and refine their skills in hypothetical problem-solving in the context of property disputes involving land. Prerequisite: 3014LAW Property 1 OR 3011LAW Property Law 1; Students must be enrolled in a Law program. Incompatible: 3012LAW Property Law 2.
Subject_Description_16: This course is conducted primarily as individual placements, or small teams of students within an industrial or research environment and emphasizes academic and vocational aspects of modern industry practice. Students consolidate their technical knowledge by undertaking a project in a professional workplace (which may include a University lab) whilst simultaneously managing their learning and course assessment. The project provides students with the opportunity to undertake a substantial project that usually has an industry application. Students work in close liaison with their industry and university supervisor throughout the project and are expected to demonstrate a good understanding of their project. The course also emphasizes that competence in management, business and social responsibilities are essential components in all fields within the environment and science professions and the key attributes of a contemporary industry or research environment. Prerequisites Students should be in the third or final year of study and must have completed the online registration form which can be followed by clicking on the red 'Access Learning@Griffith' link provided here: https://www.griffith.edu.au/griffith-sciences/partnerships/wil-for-student To be eligibile for enrolment in this course, students must have completed all requirements of the WIL Office in preparation for placement, including allocation to an industry placement or project. Student must have completed 140CP and have gained a GPA of 4.5 or higher. Enquiries are to be directed to the Course Convenor. Incompatible: 3103ENV Industry Placement
Subject_Description_17: This course provides an introduction to the basic concepts and practices of data analysis and inferential statistics. It will provide and understanding of several techniques including testing one or more means from sampled populations (t-Tests and ANOVAs), relationships between scale variables (correlations and regressions), and contingency table analysis (Chi-square tests). The course places emphasis on understanding the use of appropriate data for these tests, the use of exploratory data analysis and the underlying distributions and assumptions associated with these tests. Students will learn how to carry out these tests by hand, via the use of statistical software (SAS or SPSS), check assumptions, interpret results and report findings in plain English. Assumed prior knowledge: Grade 12 Maths A or B or equivalent. Incompatible: 1003ENV Statistics, 2012MSC Biostatistics, 2012HSC, Intro to Biomedical Data Analysis, Bioinformatics, 1003PSY Research Methods and Statistics in Psychology, 1002MSC Introduction to Biomedical Data Analysis
Subject_Description_18: Foundations of Law introduces key legal concepts and ways of understanding the law that are fundamental to the entire law program. Throughout the trimester, you will develop your awareness of the key principles and institutions that underpin the operation of Australia's legal systems, including the separation of powers (incorporating the differing roles of Parliament, the Executive and the Judiciary); and the rule of law. We introduce legal ethics and examine the roles played by lawyers in Australian society. We provide you with frameworks for effectively accessing state and national laws and conducting other forms of legal research. Building on that knowledge, we develop and apply key legal skills, including reading, analysing and summarising the essential features of cases and legislation, and interpreting statutes, collectively helping you to respond effectively to legal problems. Incompatible: 1011LAW Law and the Modern State. THIS COURSE IS ONLY OPEN TO LAW STUDENTS. Prerequisite: Students must be enrolled in a Bachelor of Laws program
Subject_Description_19: Administrative Law is the body of common law, statute law and procedural rules through which government institutions and bureaucratic actions are supervised and regulated. This course examines the major principles of administrative law and the various institutions through which the law is developed and applied in practice. Prerequisite:1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW Law and the Modern State; Students must be enrolled in a Law program. Incompatible: 5003LAW Administrative Law.
Subject_Description_20: This capstone course recalls and extends main traditions and themes in Western jurisprudence and the philosophy of law, and integrates signature themes and methods from our law degree. It engages students in critical reflection and analysis of the purpose of law and lawyers, and of the exercise of law-making, law-application, and legal interpretation. Essentially, it investigates, via applied studies and targeted readings in context, the relevance of select theoretical issues to contemporary law. This course must be completed in students' final year of study. LLB(Hons) prerequisites: 1031LAW Foundations of Law; 1028LAW Global Law; 4024LAW Equity and Trusts. Co-requisite: 4025LAW Corporations and Associations. JD Prerequisites: 7731LAW Foundations of Law; 7728LAW Global Law; 7724LAW Equity and Trusts. Co-requisite: 7725LAW Corporations and Associations.
Subject_or_Unit_21: ETHICS AND PROFESSIONAL RESPONSIBILITY IN PRACTICE
Subject_Description_21: Ethics and Professional Responsibility in Practice is a 10 credit point compulsory capstone course intended for students in their final year of study. It describes and evaluates key aspects of ethical lawyering and lawyers' professional responsibility including professional rules and their application, lawyers' duties, regulation and discipline of lawyers and aspects of trust accounting required for the purposes of admission to the profession. The course also investigates concepts relevant to legal practice and contemporary issues such as the changing nature of the profession and access to justice. Prerequisites Bachelor of Laws (Honours) students: 2020LAW Crime 2; 2022LAW Torts 2; Students must be in their final year of study. Prerequisites Juris Doctor students: 7720LAW Crime 2; 7722LAW Torts 2.
Subject_Description_22: This course explores the history and nature of Equity and its relationship to the common law, and covers equitable rights and assignments, estoppel, fiduciary duties and unconscionability. It also describes the law relating to trusts including informal trusts, family settlements, superannuation and managed investment funds. Prerequisite: 1030LAW Contracts 2 OR 1015LAW Contracts and Civil Obligations 2. Incompatible: 2010LAW Equity AND 2011LAW Trusts.
Subject_Description_23: This course provides a broad introduction to the law of contracts. We will examine which promises are legally binding and how contracts are formed. We will also be examining the different categorisations of contracts and the contents and effects of contracts. This course provides students with an understanding of contractual principles which will be built upon in 1030LAW Contracts 2. Co-requisite: 1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW Law and the Modern State. Incompatible: 1014LAW Contracts and Civil Obligations 1. THIS COURSE IS ONLY OPEN TO LAW STUDENTS.
Subject_Description_24: The course will introduce the student to the fundamental theoretical and practical principles of the Chemical sciences. Students will be encouraged to develop problem solving skills and apply these to the solution of real chemical problems. Assessment is by laboratory reports, quizzes and a final examination. Incompatible: 1001ENV, 1001MSC
Subject_Description_25: Global Law introduces students to the legal systems, traditions and procedures that have importance to Australia but which exist and operates beyond our national jurisdiction and boundaries. In this course you will learn about the basic features of the civil law system and tradition, which in different forms operate in countries like Germany, Brazil, France and Japan. Of particular relevance to Australia's foreign relations is the Chinese legal system and tradition, which has developed out of the Socialist and Confucianist cultural tradition. Knowing some basic things about these other markedly different legal systems will support your learning throughout the law degree and will enable you to become more innovative and entrepreneurial as global lawyers. This will also help you to understand the origins and modes of practice of both private and public international law, which are legal systems that aim to support how people, private entities and States cooperate at the international level. This course will also introduce you to private international law and the way in which people and corporations rely on it to communicate, trade and generally engage with each other globally while ensuring that their transactions are legally secure. Most importantly, this course will introduce you to the basic features of public international law, which is the legal system for ensuring that states like Australia can continue to cooperate and co-exist peacefully with other countries in the world. This course is designed to give you an introductory experience of the range of legal systems and traditions that as global lawyers you need to be aware of and be able to draw on and use as legal advisers or consultants. It also aims to enrich your engagement with other courses in the law degree, so that you can broaden your understanding of the legal and intellectual influences that bear upon Australia's legal system and the people as globally engaged lawyers. Co-requisite: 1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW Law and the Modern State. Incompatible: 1012LAW Introduction to Legal Theory.
Subject_Description_26: This course introduces the main environmental spheres and important natural processes of the Earth, considered as a series of systems interacting at various scales. Features of the lithosphere, atmosphere, hydrosphere and biosphere are explained, with emphasis given to the interrelationships between these spheres. In doing so, basic concepts of the more specialized fields of meteorology, climatology, hydrology, oceanography, soil science, geology, geomorphology and biogeochemistry will be studied. Incompatible: 1303ENV Earth Sciences, 1051AES Earth Sciences, 1302EAS Earth Sciences, 1004EAS Earth Sciences and GIS, 1004ENV Earth Science and GIS.
Subject_Description_27: This course introduces students to fundamental elements of the law of property providing the basis for further study in the core course 3015LAW Property 2. This course critically assesses the justifications for property and considers the delineation of property using a variety of examples such as land, chattels and intangibles (intellectual property), illustrating how property is defined and limited through the legal concepts of "ownership", "title" and "possession". A significant focus of this course is a critical assessment of the legal justifications for property and the manner in which particular groups have used conceptual tools to secure their property rights. Prerequisite: 1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW Law and the Modern State. Incompatible: 3011LAW Property Law 1.
Subject_Description_28: This course examines the processes involved in the resolution of civil disputes in the context of our court systems. Following a consideration of the differences between, and the interrelationship of, substantive and procedural law and the theoretical foundations of our procedural system, students will closely examine the various steps involved in a civil matter. The emphasis of the course will be on the operation of the Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 1999 (Qld). Consideration will also be given to Federal procedure. Prerequisites: 1029LAW Contracts 1 OR 1014LAW Contracts and Civil Obligations 1; 1030LAW Contracts 2 OR 1015LAW Contracts and Civil Obligations 2; 2021LAW Torts 1 OR 2013LAW Introduction to Torts; 2022LAW Torts 2 OR 3003LAW Negligence and Accident Compensation. Incompatible: 4021LAW Civil Procedure.
Subject_Description_29: Evidence Law aims to introduce students to the law governing proof in civil and criminal litigation. The subject matter of the course includes study of doctrinal rules in relation to the differentiated roles of judge and jury, evidential and persuasive burdens of proof, the standards of proof, admissibility of evidence, testimony, privilege and judicial warnings. There will also be consideration of the principles underlying particular doctrinal rules. Emphasis will be on the rules of evidence pursuant to provisions of the Evidence Act 1977 (Qld) and common law. Materials from other jurisdictions may be considered to elucidate principles relevant to practice in Queensland and elsewhere. Prerequisites: 1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW Law and the Modern State; 2019LAW Crime 1 OR 4032LAW The Principles of Criminal Law. Incompatible: 4022LAW Evidence.
Subject_Description_30: Mathematics underpins and informs all scientific fields and is the language of science. Quantitative Reasoning is a mathematics course with a difference. Students will learn how to translate scientific problems into mathematical form, and how to understand and interpret mathematical and numerical results. With modern software, they will use case studies to learn how to apply mathematical concepts, from basics up to simple calculus, to real-world scientific problems. Incompatible: 1013SCG
Subject_Description_31: The course explores the impact that government and business have on one another in a national and international context. It asks what consequences these relationships have for both government and business, particularly in the context of the aftermath of the global financial crisis. It offers insights into how government policies and practices affect business and how business influences and relates to government. At the heart of this course lies the issue of government intervention in business in Australia and elsewhere around the world. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatibles: 1004GIR Government-Business Relations, 1004PPP/1184PPP Government-Business Relations, 2004PPP Government-Business Relations.
Subject_Description_32: In the context of an introduction to civil obligations, this course provides a broad introduction to legal processes, the legal system and legal theory. The emphasis in this course is on contract law, but it also introduces related areas of civil obligations, particularly negligence and restitution. Prerequisites: 1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW Law and the Modern State; 1029LAW Contracts 1 OR 1014LAW Contracts and Civil Obligations 1; Students must be enrolled in a Law program. Incompatible: 1015LAW Contracts and Civil Obligations 2.
Subject_Description_33: Crime 1 will examine the criminal law of Queensland, though reference may also be made to the criminal law of the Commonwealth and to that of the other Code and 'common law' states. Emphasis will be placed on the more significant indictable offences. The range of excuses, defences and justifications that apply to criminal offences will be canvassed, as will the important central concept of criminal responsibility. Prerequisite Bachelor of Laws (Honours) students: 1031LAW">1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW">1011LAW Law and the Modern State. Co-requisite Bachelor of Laws (Honours) graduate entry students: 1031LAW">1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW">1011LAW Law and the Modern State. Incompatible: 4032LAW The Principles of Criminal Law.
Subject_Description_34: This course introduces the fundamental concepts and methods of general chemistry. Basic skills of laboratory chemical analysis are developed. Lecture content includes three modules: Introduction and basic concepts; molecular structure and bonding; and energy and physical processes. Incompatible: 1001SCE Chemistry 1A, 1009ENV General Chemistry, 1001ENV Chemistry 1, 1023SCG Chemistry 1
Subject_Description_35: Biological Systems is an introductory course that provides an appreciation of the main concepts of modern biology. Students will gain an understanding of the origin, function and structure of living organisms by examining life at increasing levels of biological complexity, from the molecular and cellular level to whole organisms and ecosystems. Course content will be delivered through a combination of lectures, workshops, laboratory sessions and online material. Incompatible: 1601ENV Biological Systems; 1

Course: Bachelor of Laws (Honours)/Bachelor of Government and International Relations
Description: Combining Government and International Relations with Law will help you develop a solid understanding of the world we live in. You will learn about the forces that shape politics, public administration and international affairs. In the Law component, you will study within a number of special subject areas called 'vertical subjects'. Through these subject areas, you will make connections between law and ethics, legal theory, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander issues, and internationalisation. You will also develop interdisciplinary understandings of law and legal work. If you complete the five Canadian Law courses, you will be eligible for entry into the legal profession in Canada's common law provinces, when accompanied by a Certificate of Qualification from the National Committee on Accreditation (NCA) of the Federation of Law Societies of Canada. In the Government and International Relations component, you will learn about political institutions and processes, business-government relations, and foreign policy and globalisation. In your first and second years, you will develop your understanding of politics and international relations. In your second, third and fourth years, you will expand this knowledge by completing a major in either International Relations or Politics and Public Policy.
Career_Outcomes: A law degree from Griffith University is your passport to the world and is recognised as a qualifying degree for admission into the legal profession in many countries around the world. You will be prepared for a career in the legal profession, with a special interest in public law or international issues. You will also find employment in areas such as diplomacy, strategic analysis or trade relations, or in businesses with overseas profiles, and international aid and non-government organisations.
Subject_Description_1: In this course, students will engage in a comprehensive examination of the substantive law, rules, and policies governing criminal justice in Queensland. The course covers a series of related criminal procedural issues and the sentencing process in the context of criminal investigations, trials, and appeals. Each week, legal, ethical, and policy issues relevant to substantive and procedural matters will be studied, discussed, and critically reflected upon. You will be encouraged to consider the effectiveness and fairness of Australia's adversarial criminal justice system. You will learn to interpret and apply the general principles and statutory laws governing criminal procedure. Prerequisites: 1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW Law and the Modern State; 2019LAW Crime 1 OR 4032LAW The Principles of Criminal Law; Students must be enrolled in a Law program. Incompatible: 4031LAW Criminal Procedure and Sentencing.
Subject_Description_2: The rise and fall of political parties and their leaders dominates public perceptions of politics but beneath this ephemeral froth and bubble lies the ongoing work of government. How does government fulfil its promises in a climate of reduced resources and heightened public expectations? This course examines the way in which governments use the public sector to provide vital services to the community and the ideas which underpin that work. The course traces the impact of ideas about the role of government, the exercise of authority and styles of management on public sector organisation and practice. The course sets the transformation of the Australian public sector from an old style bureaucracy into a contract or network state within the broader political environment. It is essential study for anyone considering a career in the public service, consultancy or business. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatibles: 2005GIR AND 2005PPP Politics of Public Management
Subject_Description_3: Evidence Law aims to introduce students to the law governing proof in civil and criminal litigation. The subject matter of the course includes study of doctrinal rules in relation to the differentiated roles of judge and jury, evidential and persuasive burdens of proof, the standards of proof, admissibility of evidence, testimony, privilege and judicial warnings. There will also be consideration of the principles underlying particular doctrinal rules. Emphasis will be on the rules of evidence pursuant to provisions of the Evidence Act 1977 (Qld) and common law. Materials from other jurisdictions may be considered to elucidate principles relevant to practice in Queensland and elsewhere. Prerequisites: 1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW Law and the Modern State; 2019LAW Crime 1 OR 4032LAW The Principles of Criminal Law. Incompatible: 4022LAW Evidence.
Subject_Description_4: This course introduces students to the law of associations and partnerships, before turning to focus on the nature and legal structure of the corporation in Australia. The doctrinal areas of corporate law covered include: pre-incorporation issues, incorporation, authority and agency, directors' duties, members rights, corporate finance and external administration. Students are encouraged to examine these through theoretical frameworks. Prerequisites: 1030LAW Contracts 2 OR 1015LAW Contracts and Civil Obligations 2; 4024LAW Equity and Trusts OR 2010LAW Equity AND 2011LAW Trusts; Students must be enrolled in a Law program. Incompatible: 3002LAW Corporate Governance and Regulation AND 3005LAW Law of Associations.
Subject_Description_5: Elections, politicians, the media, parliament: these are familiar and powerful features of everyday life in modern democracies. But how do they work? By comparing the experience of different countries, this course explores the ways in which institutions shape the choice and strategies of the various political actors. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatibles: 1102PPP Political Institutions.
Subject_Description_6: This course introduces students to fundamental elements of the law of property providing the basis for further study in the core course 3015LAW Property 2. This course critically assesses the justifications for property and considers the delineation of property using a variety of examples such as land, chattels and intangibles (intellectual property), illustrating how property is defined and limited through the legal concepts of "ownership", "title" and "possession". A significant focus of this course is a critical assessment of the legal justifications for property and the manner in which particular groups have used conceptual tools to secure their property rights. Prerequisite: 1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW Law and the Modern State. Incompatible: 3011LAW Property Law 1.
Subject_or_Unit_7: ETHICS AND PROFESSIONAL RESPONSIBILITY IN PRACTICE
Subject_Description_7: Ethics and Professional Responsibility in Practice is a 10 credit point compulsory capstone course intended for students in their final year of study. It describes and evaluates key aspects of ethical lawyering and lawyers' professional responsibility including professional rules and their application, lawyers' duties, regulation and discipline of lawyers and aspects of trust accounting required for the purposes of admission to the profession. The course also investigates concepts relevant to legal practice and contemporary issues such as the changing nature of the profession and access to justice. Prerequisites Bachelor of Laws (Honours) students: 2020LAW Crime 2; 2022LAW Torts 2; Students must be in their final year of study. Prerequisites Juris Doctor students: 7720LAW Crime 2; 7722LAW Torts 2.
Subject_Description_8: This course introduces students to a range of ideas and topics fundamental to the study of political science. These include the state, democracy, political ideology and political culture. It also introduces students to the methodology of political science, in particular the ability to undertake research, think critically and develop coherent, written arguments. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatibles: 1101PPP Introduction to Politics.
Subject_Description_9: This course introduces students to the law of civil wrongs. This is the body of principles aimed at compensating, rather than punishing, the victims of conduct causing harm, distress, or interference with property or reputation. Prerequisite Bachelor of Laws (Honours) students: 1031LAW">1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW">1011LAW Law and the Modern State. Co-requisite Bachelor of Laws (Honours) graduate entry students: 1031LAW">1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW">1011LAW Law and the Modern State. Incompatible: 2013LAW Introduction to Torts.
Subject_Description_10: This course examines the processes involved in the resolution of civil disputes in the context of our court systems. Following a consideration of the differences between, and the interrelationship of, substantive and procedural law and the theoretical foundations of our procedural system, students will closely examine the various steps involved in a civil matter. The emphasis of the course will be on the operation of the Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 1999 (Qld). Consideration will also be given to Federal procedure. Prerequisites: 1029LAW Contracts 1 OR 1014LAW Contracts and Civil Obligations 1; 1030LAW Contracts 2 OR 1015LAW Contracts and Civil Obligations 2; 2021LAW Torts 1 OR 2013LAW Introduction to Torts; 2022LAW Torts 2 OR 3003LAW Negligence and Accident Compensation. Incompatible: 4021LAW Civil Procedure.
Subject_Description_11: The discipline of International Relations (IR) is critical for understanding and explaining how the world operates today. Conflict, humanitarian disasters, terrorism, and large-scale human displacement are not historical events. How do states respond to these events? This introductory course is a study of war, peace, conflict, and diplomacy. In 1001GIR, students study the countries, the political events (i.e. World War II, Rwandan Genocide, Ebola Outbreak in West Africa), and the institutions (i.e. United Nations and the World Bank) that shape world affairs. Students will conduct simulations of diplomacy, trade negotiation, and conflict mediation during the course. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatibles: 1001IBA International Relations
Subject_Description_12: This course introduces students to major political philosophers in the tradition of western political thought. In examining the original works of thinkers from Plato to Marx, students have the opportunity to engage with their challenging ideas and thereby explore foundational political concepts, such as justice, power and liberty. Thoughtful engagement with these thinkers will also allow students to examine the dynamic relationship between political ideas and practice. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatibles: 1103GIR AND 1103PPP Political Ideas and Political Thought
Subject_Description_13: This course explores the history and nature of Equity and its relationship to the common law, and covers equitable rights and assignments, estoppel, fiduciary duties and unconscionability. It also describes the law relating to trusts including informal trusts, family settlements, superannuation and managed investment funds. Prerequisite: 1030LAW Contracts 2 OR 1015LAW Contracts and Civil Obligations 2. Incompatible: 2010LAW Equity AND 2011LAW Trusts.
Subject_Description_14: Global Law introduces students to the legal systems, traditions and procedures that have importance to Australia but which exist and operates beyond our national jurisdiction and boundaries. In this course you will learn about the basic features of the civil law system and tradition, which in different forms operate in countries like Germany, Brazil, France and Japan. Of particular relevance to Australia's foreign relations is the Chinese legal system and tradition, which has developed out of the Socialist and Confucianist cultural tradition. Knowing some basic things about these other markedly different legal systems will support your learning throughout the law degree and will enable you to become more innovative and entrepreneurial as global lawyers. This will also help you to understand the origins and modes of practice of both private and public international law, which are legal systems that aim to support how people, private entities and States cooperate at the international level. This course will also introduce you to private international law and the way in which people and corporations rely on it to communicate, trade and generally engage with each other globally while ensuring that their transactions are legally secure. Most importantly, this course will introduce you to the basic features of public international law, which is the legal system for ensuring that states like Australia can continue to cooperate and co-exist peacefully with other countries in the world. This course is designed to give you an introductory experience of the range of legal systems and traditions that as global lawyers you need to be aware of and be able to draw on and use as legal advisers or consultants. It also aims to enrich your engagement with other courses in the law degree, so that you can broaden your understanding of the legal and intellectual influences that bear upon Australia's legal system and the people as globally engaged lawyers. Co-requisite: 1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW Law and the Modern State. Incompatible: 1012LAW Introduction to Legal Theory.
Subject_Description_15: Crime 1 will examine the criminal law of Queensland, though reference may also be made to the criminal law of the Commonwealth and to that of the other Code and 'common law' states. Emphasis will be placed on the more significant indictable offences. The range of excuses, defences and justifications that apply to criminal offences will be canvassed, as will the important central concept of criminal responsibility. Prerequisite Bachelor of Laws (Honours) students: 1031LAW">1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW">1011LAW Law and the Modern State. Co-requisite Bachelor of Laws (Honours) graduate entry students: 1031LAW">1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW">1011LAW Law and the Modern State. Incompatible: 4032LAW The Principles of Criminal Law.
Subject_Description_16: Property 2 complements the content of Property 1, and continues to explore the concepts introduced there through a detailed consideration of key land law doctrines. The Course focuses on land law and features the regulation of land through the introduction and operation of the Torrens System, and covers doctrinal areas including boundaries to land, co-ownership, covenants, easements, equitable interests, mortgages and general law leasing. Students in Property 2 will develop and refine their skills in hypothetical problem-solving in the context of property disputes involving land. Prerequisite: 3014LAW Property 1 OR 3011LAW Property Law 1; Students must be enrolled in a Law program. Incompatible: 3012LAW Property Law 2.
Subject_Description_17: This capstone course acts as the arch at the apex of the Politics and Public Policy major within the Bachelor of Government and International Relations, and associated degrees in which this major is offered. It draws together the knowledge students have gained from previous courses and also looks forward to the workplace. It will focus on both by considering theoretical approaches to problems and their practical solutions. Students will be expected to relate various issues to one another and to understand the implications of different policy approaches. The course will build on and further develop skills which will be useful in the workplace. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatibles: 3001PPP Cases in Public Policy
Subject_Description_18: This course addresses a number of fundamental questions relating to the nature of public policy process by examining a range of relevant concepts and theories, and evaluating their validity through an analysis of a number of specific policy areas. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatibles: 2003GIR Power and Policy Making, 2003PPP Public Policy Processes.
Subject_Description_19: This course provides a broad introduction to the law of contracts. We will examine which promises are legally binding and how contracts are formed. We will also be examining the different categorisations of contracts and the contents and effects of contracts. This course provides students with an understanding of contractual principles which will be built upon in 1030LAW Contracts 2. Co-requisite: 1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW Law and the Modern State. Incompatible: 1014LAW Contracts and Civil Obligations 1. THIS COURSE IS ONLY OPEN TO LAW STUDENTS.
Subject_Description_20: International Relations Theory focuses on the theoretical frameworks used to explain, interpret, critique and on rare occasions predict the outcomes of global political events and processes. Events may include the outbreak and cessation of armed conflict, humanitarian intervention, the establishment of international organisations, and responses to transnational threats and challenges such as climate change, refugee flows and pandemic diseases. Processes may include great power competition and rivalry, global economic integration and financial crises, patterns of development and poverty, migration patterns, and the transformation of the international order itself. Major theoretical approaches to be examined will include realism, which centres on power relations between states; liberal internationalism, which gives more emphasis to domestic politics and processes of mutually beneficial cooperation; and constructivism, which looks at the explanatory power of the norms and ideas at work in global politics. We will also consider a range of critical and post-structural approaches, which focus more on interpreting rather than seeking to explain global events and processes. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatibles: 3007IBA International Relations Theory.
Subject_Description_21: In the context of an introduction to civil obligations, this course provides a broad introduction to legal processes, the legal system and legal theory. The emphasis in this course is on contract law, but it also introduces related areas of civil obligations, particularly negligence and restitution. Prerequisites: 1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW Law and the Modern State; 1029LAW Contracts 1 OR 1014LAW Contracts and Civil Obligations 1; Students must be enrolled in a Law program. Incompatible: 1015LAW Contracts and Civil Obligations 2.
Subject_Description_22: This capstone course recalls and extends main traditions and themes in Western jurisprudence and the philosophy of law, and integrates signature themes and methods from our law degree. It engages students in critical reflection and analysis of the purpose of law and lawyers, and of the exercise of law-making, law-application, and legal interpretation. Essentially, it investigates, via applied studies and targeted readings in context, the relevance of select theoretical issues to contemporary law. This course must be completed in students' final year of study. LLB(Hons) prerequisites: 1031LAW Foundations of Law; 1028LAW Global Law; 4024LAW Equity and Trusts. Co-requisite: 4025LAW Corporations and Associations. JD Prerequisites: 7731LAW Foundations of Law; 7728LAW Global Law; 7724LAW Equity and Trusts. Co-requisite: 7725LAW Corporations and Associations.
Subject_Description_23: In an increasingly interconnected world, an understanding of Australian politics and economics and the business environment requires an appreciation of what is happening in the world outside Australia. The dual effects of globalisation and regionalisation profoundly affect Australia. Globalisation, the Asia-Pacific and Australia offers an introduction to globalisation, the political economy of the Asia-Pacific and their impact on Australia. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatibles: 1003IBA Globalisation Asia-Pacific & Australia AND PAC11 Globalisation the Asia-Pacific and Australia.
Subject_Description_24: Foundations of Law introduces key legal concepts and ways of understanding the law that are fundamental to the entire law program. Throughout the trimester, you will develop your awareness of the key principles and institutions that underpin the operation of Australia's legal systems, including the separation of powers (incorporating the differing roles of Parliament, the Executive and the Judiciary); and the rule of law. We introduce legal ethics and examine the roles played by lawyers in Australian society. We provide you with frameworks for effectively accessing state and national laws and conducting other forms of legal research. Building on that knowledge, we develop and apply key legal skills, including reading, analysing and summarising the essential features of cases and legislation, and interpreting statutes, collectively helping you to respond effectively to legal problems. Incompatible: 1011LAW Law and the Modern State. THIS COURSE IS ONLY OPEN TO LAW STUDENTS. Prerequisite: Students must be enrolled in a Bachelor of Laws program
Subject_Description_25: This course considers core aspects of the private law governing compensation for injuries and economic loss. The course focuses on common law remedies arising out of the law of negligence and non-intentional tort, as affected and modified by recent statutory tort reforms. Students are also introduced to other sources of injury compensation. These include the related torts of Breach of Statutory Duty, and statutory schemes such as Products Liability and Workers' Compensation. The course is taught and assessed in a critical vein, with students asked to consider the goals and efficacy of the common law and statutory compensation schemes, and the central role of policy in shaping legal responses to social problems. Co-requisite: 1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW Law and the Modern State. Incompatible: 3003LAW Negligence and Accident Compensation.
Subject_Description_26: This course covers the laws that govern the creation and operation of government institutions within their political, social and economic contexts, especially the powers and limits on powers of parliaments to make laws under Australia's federal Constitution. Prerequisite: 1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW Law and the Modern State. Incompatible: 2002LAW Constitutional Law AND 2018LAW Introduction to Public Law.
Subject_Description_27: Administrative Law is the body of common law, statute law and procedural rules through which government institutions and bureaucratic actions are supervised and regulated. This course examines the major principles of administrative law and the various institutions through which the law is developed and applied in practice. Prerequisite:1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW Law and the Modern State; Students must be enrolled in a Law program. Incompatible: 5003LAW Administrative Law.

Course: Bachelor of Laws (Honours)/Bachelor of Psychological Science
Description: Combining law with psychological science will give you a unique skill set that will prepare you for work either in the community sector or in commerce and industry. You will also develop analytical, research and communication skills. Griffith Law School offers a professional legal curriculum that focuses on core areas of legal practice and the legal skills that lawyers must have. You will have the opportunity to choose law electives based on your interests, including clinical courses that emphasise practical legal skills, insights and experience. You will make connections between law and ethics, legal theory, Indigenous issues, and internationalisation. You will also develop interdisciplinary understandings of law and legal work. You will take courses that cover areas such as Crime, Contracts, Property, Corporate Law, Torts and Theories of Law. If you complete the five Canadian Law courses, you will eligible for entry into the legal profession in Canada's common law provinces, when accompanied by a Certificate of Qualification from the National Committee on Accreditation (NCA) of the Federation of Law Societies of Canada. You will learn how to apply psychological theories to topics such as thinking and perceiving, motivation, stress, health, criminal activity, and group behaviour. You will also learn how to evaluate and understand tests that measure intellectual, behavioural and emotional states. You will develop interpersonal and communication skills and learn about the principles of counselling and core areas of psychology. You will learn how to help people with personal, health, vocational and social difficulties.
Career_Outcomes: A law degree from Griffith University is your passport to the world and is recognised as a qualifying degree for admission into the legal profession in many countries around the world. You will be prepared for work in community legal centres or in other support organisations and in business organisations. You will also be well positioned to seek a career in forensic psychology.
Subject_Description_1: This capstone course recalls and extends main traditions and themes in Western jurisprudence and the philosophy of law, and integrates signature themes and methods from our law degree. It engages students in critical reflection and analysis of the purpose of law and lawyers, and of the exercise of law-making, law-application, and legal interpretation. Essentially, it investigates, via applied studies and targeted readings in context, the relevance of select theoretical issues to contemporary law. This course must be completed in students' final year of study. LLB(Hons) prerequisites: 1031LAW Foundations of Law; 1028LAW Global Law; 4024LAW Equity and Trusts. Co-requisite: 4025LAW Corporations and Associations. JD Prerequisites: 7731LAW Foundations of Law; 7728LAW Global Law; 7724LAW Equity and Trusts. Co-requisite: 7725LAW Corporations and Associations.
Subject_Description_2: This course explores the history and nature of Equity and its relationship to the common law, and covers equitable rights and assignments, estoppel, fiduciary duties and unconscionability. It also describes the law relating to trusts including informal trusts, family settlements, superannuation and managed investment funds. Prerequisite: 1030LAW Contracts 2 OR 1015LAW Contracts and Civil Obligations 2. Incompatible: 2010LAW Equity AND 2011LAW Trusts.
Subject_Description_3: You will learn what core skills are gained through the study of psychology and how these are used in the various professional contexts that psychology graduates are qualified to work in. You will learn psychology theories that inform how people come to understand themselves as they relate to the world of work and their place in it and how this understanding of themselves can change across the lifespan. Relevant careers in counselling, community and welfare, human resources, justice, marketing, policy, professional psychology, and social research are described. You will gain skills in selecting a suitable study pathway, selecting appropriate elective courses, and identifying paid and volunteer work opportunities that will enhance your employability in these areas. You will be able to describe the role of ethics, interprofessional learning, work integrated learning, and ongoing professional development in a successful career. Additional skills are gained in building a professional profile, including through LinkedIn and other public portfolios, and in managing your public identity on social media. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: NIL
Subject_Description_4: In this course, students will engage in a comprehensive examination of the substantive law, rules, and policies governing criminal justice in Queensland. The course covers a series of related criminal procedural issues and the sentencing process in the context of criminal investigations, trials, and appeals. Each week, legal, ethical, and policy issues relevant to substantive and procedural matters will be studied, discussed, and critically reflected upon. You will be encouraged to consider the effectiveness and fairness of Australia's adversarial criminal justice system. You will learn to interpret and apply the general principles and statutory laws governing criminal procedure. Prerequisites: 1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW Law and the Modern State; 2019LAW Crime 1 OR 4032LAW The Principles of Criminal Law; Students must be enrolled in a Law program. Incompatible: 4031LAW Criminal Procedure and Sentencing.
Subject_Description_5: Evidence Law aims to introduce students to the law governing proof in civil and criminal litigation. The subject matter of the course includes study of doctrinal rules in relation to the differentiated roles of judge and jury, evidential and persuasive burdens of proof, the standards of proof, admissibility of evidence, testimony, privilege and judicial warnings. There will also be consideration of the principles underlying particular doctrinal rules. Emphasis will be on the rules of evidence pursuant to provisions of the Evidence Act 1977 (Qld) and common law. Materials from other jurisdictions may be considered to elucidate principles relevant to practice in Queensland and elsewhere. Prerequisites: 1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW Law and the Modern State; 2019LAW Crime 1 OR 4032LAW The Principles of Criminal Law. Incompatible: 4022LAW Evidence.
Subject_Description_6: This is an applied, skills-oriented course that is relevant to a range of contexts, including clinical, counselling, health, education, lifecourse, sport, organisational, forensic, and community settings. In this course you will learn about the key principles and processes of behaviour change such as understanding and assessing behaviour; motivation and adherence; individual, social and community level interventions; and evaluating impact. You will also learn about ethical and cultural issues and contemporary applications. By the end of the course, you will have a practical framework for developing and evaluating behaviour change interventions in your own area of interest. Note: Students enrolled in the Behavioural Science major in B Business or B Commerce programs are exempt from the prerequisites. PREREQUISITES: 1001PSY OR EQUIVALENT AND 1002PSY OR EQUIVALENT.
Subject_Description_7: Students will be introduced to the major theories of psychological development during childhood, adolescence, and adulthood. The course will cover physical, cognitive, and psychosocial development, drawing on the work of Bowlby, Freud, Erikson, Piaget, Vygotsky, and Baltes among others. Reviewing both classic and current research, the course will consider conceptual and methodological issues in developmental psychology. Important aspects of development from conception to late adulthood will be covered. This course aims to provide a conceptual foundation for practice in clinical, counselling, educational, community, and organisational settings with children, adolescents, and adults. Prerequisites must be completed prior to enrolling in this course. It is the students' responsibility to ensure these requirements have been fulfilled. INCOMPATIBLE: 3011PSY Lifespan Development; 1010HSV Lifespan Development; 1804NRS Psychosocial Development across the Lifespan; 9003HLS Introduction to Lifespan and Social Development; PREREQUISITE: 1001PSY Introductory Cognitive & Biological Psychology AND 1002PSY Introductory Individual & Social Psychology.
Subject_Description_8: This course examines the processes involved in the resolution of civil disputes in the context of our court systems. Following a consideration of the differences between, and the interrelationship of, substantive and procedural law and the theoretical foundations of our procedural system, students will closely examine the various steps involved in a civil matter. The emphasis of the course will be on the operation of the Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 1999 (Qld). Consideration will also be given to Federal procedure. Prerequisites: 1029LAW Contracts 1 OR 1014LAW Contracts and Civil Obligations 1; 1030LAW Contracts 2 OR 1015LAW Contracts and Civil Obligations 2; 2021LAW Torts 1 OR 2013LAW Introduction to Torts; 2022LAW Torts 2 OR 3003LAW Negligence and Accident Compensation. Incompatible: 4021LAW Civil Procedure.
Subject_Description_9: This course is designed to teach the basic concepts of Cognitive Psychology covering topics such as attention, memory, language, and thinking. Familiarity with a diverse range of experimental methods and techniques is required to understand the research findings in these areas, and to critically evaluate theoretical explanations. Research findings and theoretical explanations will be presented in lectures. Laboratory experiments and demonstrations will complement the lectures by providing direct experience with some experimental techniques. Prerequisites: 1001PSY Introduction to Psychology 1I 1003PSY Research Methods and Statistics in PsychologyI or 2000PSY Experimental Design and Analysis Co-requisites: Nil Incompatible: Nil
Subject_Description_10: This course introduces students to fundamental elements of the law of property providing the basis for further study in the core course 3015LAW Property 2. This course critically assesses the justifications for property and considers the delineation of property using a variety of examples such as land, chattels and intangibles (intellectual property), illustrating how property is defined and limited through the legal concepts of "ownership", "title" and "possession". A significant focus of this course is a critical assessment of the legal justifications for property and the manner in which particular groups have used conceptual tools to secure their property rights. Prerequisite: 1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW Law and the Modern State. Incompatible: 3011LAW Property Law 1.
Subject_Description_11: Global Law introduces students to the legal systems, traditions and procedures that have importance to Australia but which exist and operates beyond our national jurisdiction and boundaries. In this course you will learn about the basic features of the civil law system and tradition, which in different forms operate in countries like Germany, Brazil, France and Japan. Of particular relevance to Australia's foreign relations is the Chinese legal system and tradition, which has developed out of the Socialist and Confucianist cultural tradition. Knowing some basic things about these other markedly different legal systems will support your learning throughout the law degree and will enable you to become more innovative and entrepreneurial as global lawyers. This will also help you to understand the origins and modes of practice of both private and public international law, which are legal systems that aim to support how people, private entities and States cooperate at the international level. This course will also introduce you to private international law and the way in which people and corporations rely on it to communicate, trade and generally engage with each other globally while ensuring that their transactions are legally secure. Most importantly, this course will introduce you to the basic features of public international law, which is the legal system for ensuring that states like Australia can continue to cooperate and co-exist peacefully with other countries in the world. This course is designed to give you an introductory experience of the range of legal systems and traditions that as global lawyers you need to be aware of and be able to draw on and use as legal advisers or consultants. It also aims to enrich your engagement with other courses in the law degree, so that you can broaden your understanding of the legal and intellectual influences that bear upon Australia's legal system and the people as globally engaged lawyers. Co-requisite: 1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW Law and the Modern State. Incompatible: 1012LAW Introduction to Legal Theory.
Subject_Description_12: This intermediate course will introduce students to experimental design and analysis in psychology. Building on basic experimental reseach and statistical concepts, material on statistical hypothesis testing (especially in the ANOVA tradition) is integrated with new material on the design of more complex experiments and on issues concerning measurement, reliability, and manipulation. Topics include: between subjects designs; between subjects analyses including confidence intervals and multiple comparisons up to factorial ANOVA; within subjects designs and analyses up to within subjects factorial ANOVA; and mixed designs and analysis using ANOVA. Prerequisites: 1003PSY Research Methods and Statistics in Psychology| or 1305AFE Business Data Analysis| Competence in using SPSS statistical software Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: NIL
Subject_Description_13: This course covers the laws that govern the creation and operation of government institutions within their political, social and economic contexts, especially the powers and limits on powers of parliaments to make laws under Australia's federal Constitution. Prerequisite: 1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW Law and the Modern State. Incompatible: 2002LAW Constitutional Law AND 2018LAW Introduction to Public Law.
Subject_Description_14: This course is an applied skills-oriented course. The aim of this course is to provide you with the opportunity to develop your mastery of the generic interpersonal communication skills necessary for building and maintaining effective working and personal relationships, and managing interpersonal interactions and change. In addition, you will be introduced to skills which are the "building blocks" for more advanced skills that you may use in future professional roles such as Consultant, Counsellor, Lawyer, Manager, Psychologist, Public Health practitioner or Social Worker. INCOMPATIBLE: PSY2002 AND PB12013 AND JAD1006 OR 1006CCJ AND 2007APY AND 7022HSV AND 7322AHS AND 1008HSV AND 2008EHR.
Subject_Description_15: This course introduces students to the law of associations and partnerships, before turning to focus on the nature and legal structure of the corporation in Australia. The doctrinal areas of corporate law covered include: pre-incorporation issues, incorporation, authority and agency, directors' duties, members rights, corporate finance and external administration. Students are encouraged to examine these through theoretical frameworks. Prerequisites: 1030LAW Contracts 2 OR 1015LAW Contracts and Civil Obligations 2; 4024LAW Equity and Trusts OR 2010LAW Equity AND 2011LAW Trusts; Students must be enrolled in a Law program. Incompatible: 3002LAW Corporate Governance and Regulation AND 3005LAW Law of Associations.
Subject_Description_16: You will be introduced to the theory and practice of psychological testing and assessment of individual differences with particular focus on personality and intelligence assessment. You will learn about the history of psychological testing; definition, advantages, and limitations of psychological tests; ethics in testing; and basic psychometric concepts (test scores and norms, reliability and validity, test construction). You will apply this knowledge to understanding testing and assessment of individual differences in personality and intelligence. Prerequisites: 1001PSY Introduction to Psychology 1I 1002PSY Introduction to Psychology 2I 1003PSY Research Methods and Statistics in Psychology Co-requisites: Nil Incompatible: Nil
Subject_Description_17: This course provides a set of frameworks for examining and understanding human behaviour in a social and cultural context. It integrates the social and the cultural, with the overriding aim to develop an understanding of how the individual's thoughts, feelings, and behaviours can be shaped by the people around them, and the culture of which they are a part. Prerequisites: 1002PSY Introduction to Psychology 2 Co-requisites: Nil Incompatible: Nil
Subject_Description_18: This course provides a broad introduction to the law of contracts. We will examine which promises are legally binding and how contracts are formed. We will also be examining the different categorisations of contracts and the contents and effects of contracts. This course provides students with an understanding of contractual principles which will be built upon in 1030LAW Contracts 2. Co-requisite: 1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW Law and the Modern State. Incompatible: 1014LAW Contracts and Civil Obligations 1. THIS COURSE IS ONLY OPEN TO LAW STUDENTS.
Subject_Description_19: In the context of an introduction to civil obligations, this course provides a broad introduction to legal processes, the legal system and legal theory. The emphasis in this course is on contract law, but it also introduces related areas of civil obligations, particularly negligence and restitution. Prerequisites: 1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW Law and the Modern State; 1029LAW Contracts 1 OR 1014LAW Contracts and Civil Obligations 1; Students must be enrolled in a Law program. Incompatible: 1015LAW Contracts and Civil Obligations 2.
Subject_Description_20: This course introduces students to the law of civil wrongs. This is the body of principles aimed at compensating, rather than punishing, the victims of conduct causing harm, distress, or interference with property or reputation. Prerequisite Bachelor of Laws (Honours) students: 1031LAW">1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW">1011LAW Law and the Modern State. Co-requisite Bachelor of Laws (Honours) graduate entry students: 1031LAW">1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW">1011LAW Law and the Modern State. Incompatible: 2013LAW Introduction to Torts.
Subject_Description_21: Foundations of Law introduces key legal concepts and ways of understanding the law that are fundamental to the entire law program. Throughout the trimester, you will develop your awareness of the key principles and institutions that underpin the operation of Australia's legal systems, including the separation of powers (incorporating the differing roles of Parliament, the Executive and the Judiciary); and the rule of law. We introduce legal ethics and examine the roles played by lawyers in Australian society. We provide you with frameworks for effectively accessing state and national laws and conducting other forms of legal research. Building on that knowledge, we develop and apply key legal skills, including reading, analysing and summarising the essential features of cases and legislation, and interpreting statutes, collectively helping you to respond effectively to legal problems. Incompatible: 1011LAW Law and the Modern State. THIS COURSE IS ONLY OPEN TO LAW STUDENTS. Prerequisite: Students must be enrolled in a Bachelor of Laws program
Subject_Description_22: Crime 1 will examine the criminal law of Queensland, though reference may also be made to the criminal law of the Commonwealth and to that of the other Code and 'common law' states. Emphasis will be placed on the more significant indictable offences. The range of excuses, defences and justifications that apply to criminal offences will be canvassed, as will the important central concept of criminal responsibility. Prerequisite Bachelor of Laws (Honours) students: 1031LAW">1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW">1011LAW Law and the Modern State. Co-requisite Bachelor of Laws (Honours) graduate entry students: 1031LAW">1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW">1011LAW Law and the Modern State. Incompatible: 4032LAW The Principles of Criminal Law.
Subject_Description_23: This is an applied skills-oriented course in the Bachelor of Psychological Science and associated degrees, Bachelor of Psychology (Hons), and Bachelor of Counselling. The course focuses on effectiveness of practitioners at the small and large group level. The course introduces key models of facilitation and coaching for groups. An important aspect of this course is the linking of these models to the development of students' skills in many aspects of facilitation and coaching. At the end of this course, students will understand and have basic skills in the application of facilitation and coaching in a range of settings such as counselling, clinical, organisational, sport, and health settings. Prerequisite: 1008PSY Interpersonal Skills Incompatible: 2027HSV Group Facilitation
Subject_Description_24: This course provides an introductory-level overview of several fields within psychology. It focuses on developmental and social processes and their relationships to individual differences in behaviour, and provides a broad introduction to the areas of developmental, personality, abnormal and social psychology. INCOMPATIBLE: PB11004 AND JAD1004 OR HJ11004 AND 1006APY AND 1015HSV
Subject_Description_25: This course introduces students to the major psychological disorders covered in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (5th ed.). By completing this course successfully, students will have acquired the following types of information about a range of psychological disorders: - Epidemiology (Incidence, prevalence, lifetime prevalence) - Aetiology (Factors predisposing and precipitating the onset of disorders) - Specific diagnostic criteria employed by the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual (5th Ed.) for major psychological disorders - Assessment and treatment approaches for these disorders - Current debates that exist about specific psychological diagnoses and the general field of psychopathology. Prerequisites must be completed prior to enrolling in this course. It is the students' responsibility to ensure these requirements have been fulfilled. INCOMPATIBLE: PB13036 Abnormal Psychology AND 3010APY Abnormal Psychology PREREQUISITES: 1001PSY OR 1005APY AND 1002PSY OR 1006APY.
Subject_Description_26: Property 2 complements the content of Property 1, and continues to explore the concepts introduced there through a detailed consideration of key land law doctrines. The Course focuses on land law and features the regulation of land through the introduction and operation of the Torrens System, and covers doctrinal areas including boundaries to land, co-ownership, covenants, easements, equitable interests, mortgages and general law leasing. Students in Property 2 will develop and refine their skills in hypothetical problem-solving in the context of property disputes involving land. Prerequisite: 3014LAW Property 1 OR 3011LAW Property Law 1; Students must be enrolled in a Law program. Incompatible: 3012LAW Property Law 2.
Subject_or_Unit_27: ETHICS AND PROFESSIONAL RESPONSIBILITY IN PRACTICE
Subject_Description_27: Ethics and Professional Responsibility in Practice is a 10 credit point compulsory capstone course intended for students in their final year of study. It describes and evaluates key aspects of ethical lawyering and lawyers' professional responsibility including professional rules and their application, lawyers' duties, regulation and discipline of lawyers and aspects of trust accounting required for the purposes of admission to the profession. The course also investigates concepts relevant to legal practice and contemporary issues such as the changing nature of the profession and access to justice. Prerequisites Bachelor of Laws (Honours) students: 2020LAW Crime 2; 2022LAW Torts 2; Students must be in their final year of study. Prerequisites Juris Doctor students: 7720LAW Crime 2; 7722LAW Torts 2.
Subject_Description_28: This course provides a foundation for understanding the cognitive and biological bases of human behaviour, including the role of the brain and neural processes in behaviour, perception (how the senses allow you to see, hear, taste, touch and smell the world around you), conditioning and learning (how humans and other animals learn about their environment), cognition and memory (how people think, solve problems and remember). Drawing on various research traditions in experimental psychology, this course demonstrates how cognitive and biological psychology contributes to our knowledge of human well-being and performance. Students apply this knowledge through a series of practical in-class exercises. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: 1004HLS_Y2
Subject_Description_29: Administrative Law is the body of common law, statute law and procedural rules through which government institutions and bureaucratic actions are supervised and regulated. This course examines the major principles of administrative law and the various institutions through which the law is developed and applied in practice. Prerequisite:1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW Law and the Modern State; Students must be enrolled in a Law program. Incompatible: 5003LAW Administrative Law.
Subject_or_Unit_30: RESEARCH METHODS AND STATISTICS IN PSYCHOLOGY
Subject_Description_30: You will learn about the role of scientific data gathering in psychology which underpins all evidence-based practice. Basic research approaches will be described and the manner in which research is communicated (e.g., research psychology report) will be practised. You will gain skills in the description of data using basic graphical (e.g., histograms) and numerical (e.g., mean and standard deviation) methods. The association between variables through scatterplots and correlations is examined and you will learn how to calculate and interpret the confidence interval of the mean and make inferences using t-tests. You will learn to create and interpret output from the statistical software package SPSS for these statistical techniques. Prerequisites: Nil Co-requisites: Nil Incompatible: First Year Tertiary Level Statistics|1003PSY Introduction to Research in Behavioural Sciences| 2009CCJ Statistics for Social Research| 1305AFE Business Data Analysis| 1014SCG Statistics| 1002MSC Introduction to Biomedical Data Analysis| 2013AHS Research Methods and Statistics
Subject_Description_31: This course is a foundation course for development of an understanding of core concepts and basic competencies necessary for effective counselling practice, especially those essential to establish and maintain the client-practitioner relationship and support the therapeutic process.
