You will also be introduced to the foundations of developing an understanding of the client as a unique person, also termed 'case conceptualisation' and the concept of diversity. The skills you will learn include micro-skills such as listening, attending fully to the client, and creating a safe therapeutic relationship; self-and-other awareness; and self-reflection. Practical exercises allow you to integrate knowledge development with skills application. You will also be provided with opportunities to reflect on how counselling skills will fit within your future career and how you might prepare for further professional education in the field. Prerequisites: Nil
Subject_Description_32: This course considers core aspects of the private law governing compensation for injuries and economic loss. The course focuses on common law remedies arising out of the law of negligence and non-intentional tort, as affected and modified by recent statutory tort reforms. Students are also introduced to other sources of injury compensation. These include the related torts of Breach of Statutory Duty, and statutory schemes such as Products Liability and Workers' Compensation. The course is taught and assessed in a critical vein, with students asked to consider the goals and efficacy of the common law and statutory compensation schemes, and the central role of policy in shaping legal responses to social problems. Co-requisite: 1031LAW Foundations of Law OR 1011LAW Law and the Modern State. Incompatible: 3003LAW Negligence and Accident Compensation.
Subject_Description_33: The course aims to facilitate the conceptual, analytic and problem-solving skills relevant to correlational research in the social sciences, as well as generic competencies in critical analysis, communication and data interpretation. The course complements other research methods and statistics courses. Material covered includes practical concerns in conducting this type of research such as selecting a sample, constructing instruments, and ensuring validity. As well, students gain an introduction to issues in the analysis and interpretation of correlational research findings. Topics include: survey and correlational research designs; sampling; regression analysis; and categorical data analysis. Prerequisites must be completed prior to enrolling in this course. It is the students' responsibility to ensure these requirements have been fulfilled. Prerequisites: 1001PSY Introduction to Psychology 1| 1002PSY Introduction to Psychology 2| 1003PSY Research Methods and Statistics in Pscyhology Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: 2001PSY Research Methods & Statistics 3| 3001PSY Research Methods & Statistics 4
Subject_Description_34: This course introduces students to the study of human behaviour from a biological point of view and an understanding of the link between biological systems and human behaviour. Apart from providing students with knowledge in basic areas such as the human nervous system, the human sensory and motor systems, the course also includes more applied topics. For example learning and memory, perception, language, emotion and motivation, sleeping, eating and eating disorders, drugs and brain damage. This course has prerequisites that must be completed prior to enrolling in this course. It is the students' responsibility to ensure these requirements have been fulfilled. INCOMPATIBLE: 2009APY PREREQUISITES: 1001PSY OR 1005APY AND 1003PSY OR 1002APY

Description: This double degree enables students to combine business management skills with a studio major, developing core competencies such as critical and analytical thinking, business communication and decision-making. Graduates are skilled in the practice of photography and in developing conceptual and craft skills and are able to effectively and efficiently manage creative ventures from a business perspective. Photography majors Business majors Students can also choose not to complete a major, selecting from a range of courses that provide broad knowledge for a career in business management.
Career_Outcomes: The Bachelor of Photography/Bachelor of Business will prepare graduates for employment in advertising photography, commercial photography, art practice, arts administration, public art, curatorship, picture editing, photojournalism, Documentary photography; marketing; management; event management.
Subject_Description_1: In an increasingly complex financial system, and with an aging and longer living population, financial independence and effective financial decision making are seen as important life attributes and skills. The reality however is that many make poor financial decisions, fail to plan for their financial future, adequately protect themselves, their family and their assets, are easily influenced into poor/inappropriate financial products, and fall foul of schemes and scams. In other words there is low levels of financial literacy in the community, including in higher education graduates. A study of money and life will cover a range of content areas including planning and goal setting, behaviour and decision making, financial markets, services and products, rights and obligations under contracts, financial systems and household finances. This could also introduce fintech (including Bloomberg and the SSMIF). The course would provide a range of personal and professional development outcomes for students as well as improve their overall understanding of business. The course will be designed to be relevant for all students of the university and also has potential for development into a standalone credential/MOOC.
Subject_Description_2: The course complements Studio Foundations 1 to provide an intensive introduction to the materials, methods, concepts and concerns of contemporary visual arts practice. Lecture and studio delivery continues the development of agile and lateral thinking through visual methods rooted in disciplinary and interdisciplinary knowledge frameworks. Studio investigations are grounded in an interdisciplinary framework of sculpture, jewellery/small objects, painting, photography and print media.
Subject_Description_3: Australia is geographically situated in the Asia Pacific region, but retains strong cultural links to the Western world. Asia is a community of diverse nations and cultures formed over the millennia. In times of boom and gloom Asian nations and their peoples have exemplified resilience and leadership. This course is designed to engage students in the diverse world of Asian history, culture, business, politics, religion, art and beliefs to develop an appreciation of our near neighbours. It examines the influences of the past and current relationships before delving into the future of the Fourth Industrial Revolution and the potential consequences for the region. The course also looks at how Asia is likely to change over the next 10 to 20 years (e.g. growth of India, evolving role of China, the role of Europe and North America). The Asia region is also a likely constant in all students' future careers and many employers desire a level of Asian literacy in their elite workforce. This course is designed to satisfy that requirement and assist students with employability strategies.
Subject_Description_4: This course provides an intensive introduction to the materials, methods, concepts and concerns of contemporary visual arts practice in a multi-disciplinary matrix. Lecture content and studio exercises engage with visual thinking, concept development, material investigation and a diversity of practice as foundational catalysts for lifelong learning. The course initiates responsive approaches to arts practice and reflective learning in a rich, complex and diverse cultural environment. This course complements Studio Foundations 2.
Subject_or_Unit_5: PROFESSIONAL PRACTICES IN THE VISUAL ARTS
Subject_Description_5: This course prepares students for life and work beyond graduation. Students will explore creative arts industries and design strategies for enhancing their professional practice. Specific skills including CV building, writing artist statements, grant writing, networking and proposal development. In conjunction with seminars led by professional practitioners, students will also investigate arts law, finance, business models, entrepreneurship, copyright law, professional protocols and the attitudes and dispositions of professional visual arts practitioners.
Subject_Description_6: This course provides an introduction to practices from the Ancient Greeks up until the early 20th century. Students will gain an understanding of key art historical concepts as well as the social, cultural, political and religious contexts for art.
Subject_Description_7: Foundation Studies in Art Theory is made up of two first year courses. The first of these is 1216QCA Introduction to Western Art. The second is this course, 1217QCA Modern Art and its Legacies. This course introduces students to the concepts of Modernity, Modernism and Postmodernism and considers their legacy for contemporary creative practices. The course combines a chronological survey of European and American avant-garde art movements with themes and theories relevant to contemporary practice. The course focuses on art and photography as located within a broader field of creative practice including dance, design, film, literature and theatre.
Subject_Description_8: Students in this course are introduced to the idea that there are many ways to identify and solve the complex problems faced by businesses today; hence business success hinges on the ability to think creatively and innovatively, combining knowledge from a variety of disciplines. To this end, the course introduces ideas/tools of creativity and entrepreneurialism and demonstrates how these ideas/tools are applied to a variety of situations through the use of case studies and guest lecturers. The discussion is set in the context of the current debate on what constitutes business success, how it is achieved, and how businesses are under "scrutiny" by the community at large to ensure that they behave and operate in responsible and sustainable manner. In this regard, the course also explores issues related to financial and non-financial reporting, governance framework, risk management, stakeholder and agency, policy and regulatory intervention, indigenous/herniate assets. Lectures will include guest lecturers and will cover a diverse range of topics such as marketing, current and new technologies, future world trends, legal issues, work force issues etc. Workshops will enable students to work on case studies that involve real problems sourced from industry clients and partners. Industry clients will be directly involved in the workshop and students required to present solutions to their problems at the end of the trimester.
Subject_Description_9: This course introduces students to a perspective of the purpose of business that embeds values such as responsible leadership, integrity and ethical behaviour, respect for others, trust, and sustainable enterprise. The relevance of these values and their impact on behaviour and outcomes in a business context is demonstrated to students through case studies, real world examples, and testimonials from industry partners. Following from the discussion of values, the course then looks at how businesses develop solutions to respond to increasing demand for sustainability, transparency and good governance. The framework of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) is introduced and used to examine the alignment between business practices and sustainable solutions to real life problems faced by a business. The course also considers the role and responsibility (including legal) of professionals and professional standards in today's society.
Subject_Description_10: The aim of the course is to explain the way people behave and make decisions in a business environment and the role that information has in the context of decision-making. The course will introduce some elements of behavioural sciences and game theory applied to business problems. It will also tackle some of the critical questions around the use of information for business decision making: how to assess the validity/reliability and relevance of the information we receive? how to use it effectively? how to simplify information, make it relevant, and present it to different audiences? The course combines different aspects. First, it encourages students to account for the psychological, cognitive, emotional, cultural, and social factors that affects decisions made by individuals and organisations (e.g. private corporates, government, civil society, etc). Second it provides simple analytical tools to contextualise strategic decision-making in real world situations through lenses such as that of the consumer and the future role of social marketing. Third, it introduces students to the idea that business decision making requires reliable, timely information. The course takes a positive (as opposed to normative) approach to the analysis of interactive strategic decisions and behaviours. Through case studies, the course provides a description of what happens in a variety of business situations, with a focus on understanding the elements/dynamics that leads to a certain outcome of decision. In so doing, the course helps students identify the role of information (qualitative or quantitative), how it is sourced and assessed in terms of its validity/quality, and how it can be used to deal with uncertainty in decision-making. Basic approaches to the analysis, interpretation and presentation of various types of information are also discussed, including the foundations of big data analytics and qualitative data analysis.
Subject_Description_11: Conducted through seminars and lectures, this course considers contemporary visual arts in the context of a global cultural landscape. The course is designed to engage students directly with the histories, tensions and circumstances of global visual arts practice. An investigation of the nuances, sensitivities, protocols and complexities of specific practitioners, movements and events will enable the student to apply a sophisticated and critical knowledge to global contexts with an understanding of a diversity of perspectives. Students will also develop communication skills that reflect contextual awareness and responsiveness to rich and complex intercultural dynamics. This is a third year course. Students must have completed all second year art theory and second year visual arts major courses prior to enrolment.
Subject_Description_12: This course explores the future of work in a rapidly globalizing, knowledge and service-intensive economy. Advances in IT and associated technologies are enabling firms to automate and/or outsource routine work, displacing the jobs of low-skilled workers, while enhancing the power of knowledge workers. In parallel, new industries and forms of collaborative and distance-based work are emerging, offering new challenges and opportunities. This course investigates the causes of technological, industrial and organisational change and their potential impacts of work arrangements and stakeholder relationships. Strategies and policies for managing change and coping with the new world of work outlined, drawing on latest research from Australia and other countries. Students would investigate how the future of work affects the business landscape of both large companies and smaller firms. It would cover sources of value creation and the benefits and challenges of the new technologies. There will be an overview of IoT and futurist thinking and of selected technologies to examine how such digital innovations are being developed and used by leading organisations. Content will address the implications for managers of social media, big data, artificial intelligence and newer technological innovations.
Subject_Description_13: This course builds on ways in which theory and studio practice may extend and inform each other via an arts-based research project. This course works to consolidate studio processes towards a major body of work suitable for professional presentation and prepares students to critically articulate and disseminate their work in professional and higher learning contexts.
Subject_Description_14: Transdisciplinary groups of students work together to solve contemporary challenges in business with a focus on the Sustainability Development Goals in the Asia Pacific region, including first peoples. Students present solutions to real world problems by drawing on the knowledge they have developed throughout their foundation and majors. Students participate in simulations in addition to running a social enterprise or charity event. In addition, students will finalise their program e-portfolio's with evidence of their readiness for their chosen profession or career. Students will also collect and present final evidence of readiness through Griffith Graduate Attributes, Griffith Graduates of Influence and BusinessPlus credentials.

Course: Bachelor of Psychological Science/Bachelor of Business
Description: This program will be available to commencing students at the Gold Coast and Mt Gravatt/Nathan from 2021. Combining business with psychological science can give you the skills and knowledge needed to work as a specialist providing advice to organisations on management and personnel issues, and helping them develop training programs, set policies, or manage organisational change. Business majors You can also choose not to complete a major, selecting from a range of courses that provide broad knowledge for a career in business management.
Career_Outcomes: You will be ideally placed to directly enter a wide range of management positions in business, counselling, and training and development.
Subject_or_Unit_1: RESEARCH METHODS AND STATISTICS IN PSYCHOLOGY
Subject_Description_1: You will learn about the role of scientific data gathering in psychology which underpins all evidence-based practice. Basic research approaches will be described and the manner in which research is communicated (e.g., research psychology report) will be practised. You will gain skills in the description of data using basic graphical (e.g., histograms) and numerical (e.g., mean and standard deviation) methods. The association between variables through scatterplots and correlations is examined and you will learn how to calculate and interpret the confidence interval of the mean and make inferences using t-tests. You will learn to create and interpret output from the statistical software package SPSS for these statistical techniques. Prerequisites: Nil Co-requisites: Nil Incompatible: First Year Tertiary Level Statistics|1003PSY Introduction to Research in Behavioural Sciences| 2009CCJ Statistics for Social Research| 1305AFE Business Data Analysis| 1014SCG Statistics| 1002MSC Introduction to Biomedical Data Analysis| 2013AHS Research Methods and Statistics
Subject_Description_2: This course introduces students to the major psychological disorders covered in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (5th ed.). By completing this course successfully, students will have acquired the following types of information about a range of psychological disorders: - Epidemiology (Incidence, prevalence, lifetime prevalence) - Aetiology (Factors predisposing and precipitating the onset of disorders) - Specific diagnostic criteria employed by the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual (5th Ed.) for major psychological disorders - Assessment and treatment approaches for these disorders - Current debates that exist about specific psychological diagnoses and the general field of psychopathology. Prerequisites must be completed prior to enrolling in this course. It is the students' responsibility to ensure these requirements have been fulfilled. INCOMPATIBLE: PB13036 Abnormal Psychology AND 3010APY Abnormal Psychology PREREQUISITES: 1001PSY OR 1005APY AND 1002PSY OR 1006APY.
Subject_Description_3: This course is an applied skills-oriented course. The aim of this course is to provide you with the opportunity to develop your mastery of the generic interpersonal communication skills necessary for building and maintaining effective working and personal relationships, and managing interpersonal interactions and change. In addition, you will be introduced to skills which are the "building blocks" for more advanced skills that you may use in future professional roles such as Consultant, Counsellor, Lawyer, Manager, Psychologist, Public Health practitioner or Social Worker. INCOMPATIBLE: PSY2002 AND PB12013 AND JAD1006 OR 1006CCJ AND 2007APY AND 7022HSV AND 7322AHS AND 1008HSV AND 2008EHR.
Subject_Description_4: This course provides an introductory-level overview of several fields within psychology. It focuses on developmental and social processes and their relationships to individual differences in behaviour, and provides a broad introduction to the areas of developmental, personality, abnormal and social psychology. INCOMPATIBLE: PB11004 AND JAD1004 OR HJ11004 AND 1006APY AND 1015HSV
Subject_Description_5: This course introduces students to a perspective of the purpose of business that embeds values such as responsible leadership, integrity and ethical behaviour, respect for others, trust, and sustainable enterprise. The relevance of these values and their impact on behaviour and outcomes in a business context is demonstrated to students through case studies, real world examples, and testimonials from industry partners. Following from the discussion of values, the course then looks at how businesses develop solutions to respond to increasing demand for sustainability, transparency and good governance. The framework of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) is introduced and used to examine the alignment between business practices and sustainable solutions to real life problems faced by a business. The course also considers the role and responsibility (including legal) of professionals and professional standards in today's society.
Subject_Description_6: This course is designed to teach the basic concepts of Cognitive Psychology covering topics such as attention, memory, language, and thinking. Familiarity with a diverse range of experimental methods and techniques is required to understand the research findings in these areas, and to critically evaluate theoretical explanations. Research findings and theoretical explanations will be presented in lectures. Laboratory experiments and demonstrations will complement the lectures by providing direct experience with some experimental techniques. Prerequisites: 1001PSY Introduction to Psychology 1I 1003PSY Research Methods and Statistics in PsychologyI or 2000PSY Experimental Design and Analysis Co-requisites: Nil Incompatible: Nil
Subject_Description_7: This is an applied skills-oriented course in the Bachelor of Psychological Science and associated degrees, Bachelor of Psychology (Hons), and Bachelor of Counselling. The course focuses on effectiveness of practitioners at the small and large group level. The course introduces key models of facilitation and coaching for groups. An important aspect of this course is the linking of these models to the development of students' skills in many aspects of facilitation and coaching. At the end of this course, students will understand and have basic skills in the application of facilitation and coaching in a range of settings such as counselling, clinical, organisational, sport, and health settings. Prerequisite: 1008PSY Interpersonal Skills Incompatible: 2027HSV Group Facilitation
Subject_Description_8: This intermediate course will introduce students to experimental design and analysis in psychology. Building on basic experimental reseach and statistical concepts, material on statistical hypothesis testing (especially in the ANOVA tradition) is integrated with new material on the design of more complex experiments and on issues concerning measurement, reliability, and manipulation. Topics include: between subjects designs; between subjects analyses including confidence intervals and multiple comparisons up to factorial ANOVA; within subjects designs and analyses up to within subjects factorial ANOVA; and mixed designs and analysis using ANOVA. Prerequisites: 1003PSY Research Methods and Statistics in Psychology| or 1305AFE Business Data Analysis| Competence in using SPSS statistical software Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: NIL
Subject_Description_9: In an increasingly complex financial system, and with an aging and longer living population, financial independence and effective financial decision making are seen as important life attributes and skills. The reality however is that many make poor financial decisions, fail to plan for their financial future, adequately protect themselves, their family and their assets, are easily influenced into poor/inappropriate financial products, and fall foul of schemes and scams. In other words there is low levels of financial literacy in the community, including in higher education graduates. A study of money and life will cover a range of content areas including planning and goal setting, behaviour and decision making, financial markets, services and products, rights and obligations under contracts, financial systems and household finances. This could also introduce fintech (including Bloomberg and the SSMIF). The course would provide a range of personal and professional development outcomes for students as well as improve their overall understanding of business. The course will be designed to be relevant for all students of the university and also has potential for development into a standalone credential/MOOC.
Subject_Description_10: Australia is geographically situated in the Asia Pacific region, but retains strong cultural links to the Western world. Asia is a community of diverse nations and cultures formed over the millennia. In times of boom and gloom Asian nations and their peoples have exemplified resilience and leadership. This course is designed to engage students in the diverse world of Asian history, culture, business, politics, religion, art and beliefs to develop an appreciation of our near neighbours. It examines the influences of the past and current relationships before delving into the future of the Fourth Industrial Revolution and the potential consequences for the region. The course also looks at how Asia is likely to change over the next 10 to 20 years (e.g. growth of India, evolving role of China, the role of Europe and North America). The Asia region is also a likely constant in all students' future careers and many employers desire a level of Asian literacy in their elite workforce. This course is designed to satisfy that requirement and assist students with employability strategies.
Subject_Description_11: This is an applied, skills-oriented course that is relevant to a range of contexts, including clinical, counselling, health, education, lifecourse, sport, organisational, forensic, and community settings. In this course you will learn about the key principles and processes of behaviour change such as understanding and assessing behaviour; motivation and adherence; individual, social and community level interventions; and evaluating impact. You will also learn about ethical and cultural issues and contemporary applications. By the end of the course, you will have a practical framework for developing and evaluating behaviour change interventions in your own area of interest. Note: Students enrolled in the Behavioural Science major in B Business or B Commerce programs are exempt from the prerequisites. PREREQUISITES: 1001PSY OR EQUIVALENT AND 1002PSY OR EQUIVALENT.
Subject_Description_12: Students will be introduced to the major theories of psychological development during childhood, adolescence, and adulthood. The course will cover physical, cognitive, and psychosocial development, drawing on the work of Bowlby, Freud, Erikson, Piaget, Vygotsky, and Baltes among others. Reviewing both classic and current research, the course will consider conceptual and methodological issues in developmental psychology. Important aspects of development from conception to late adulthood will be covered. This course aims to provide a conceptual foundation for practice in clinical, counselling, educational, community, and organisational settings with children, adolescents, and adults. Prerequisites must be completed prior to enrolling in this course. It is the students' responsibility to ensure these requirements have been fulfilled. INCOMPATIBLE: 3011PSY Lifespan Development; 1010HSV Lifespan Development; 1804NRS Psychosocial Development across the Lifespan; 9003HLS Introduction to Lifespan and Social Development; PREREQUISITE: 1001PSY Introductory Cognitive & Biological Psychology AND 1002PSY Introductory Individual & Social Psychology.
Subject_Description_13: Language and Communication for Health is offered to students from a non-English speaking background (NESB). Students whose first language is English are NOT PERMITTED to undertake this course. The aim of this course is to introduce students to the language, knowledge and communication skills required for study and practice in their discipline. A further aim is to develop and practice English language skills relevant to the academic culture of Australian universities. It therefore involves intensive English language practice and language immersion activities, with elements applied to contextualised, discipline-specific settings. This course constitutes part of the overall English Language Enhancement Strategy at Griffith University. Prerequisites: NIL; Incompatible: 5901LHS/5901LAL, 5903LHS/5903LAL, 5904LHS/5904LAL and 5902LAL.
Subject_Description_14: You will be introduced to the theory and practice of psychological testing and assessment of individual differences with particular focus on personality and intelligence assessment. You will learn about the history of psychological testing; definition, advantages, and limitations of psychological tests; ethics in testing; and basic psychometric concepts (test scores and norms, reliability and validity, test construction). You will apply this knowledge to understanding testing and assessment of individual differences in personality and intelligence. Prerequisites: 1001PSY Introduction to Psychology 1I 1002PSY Introduction to Psychology 2I 1003PSY Research Methods and Statistics in Psychology Co-requisites: Nil Incompatible: Nil
Subject_Description_15: You will learn what core skills are gained through the study of psychology and how these are used in the various professional contexts that psychology graduates are qualified to work in. You will learn psychology theories that inform how people come to understand themselves as they relate to the world of work and their place in it and how this understanding of themselves can change across the lifespan. Relevant careers in counselling, community and welfare, human resources, justice, marketing, policy, professional psychology, and social research are described. You will gain skills in selecting a suitable study pathway, selecting appropriate elective courses, and identifying paid and volunteer work opportunities that will enhance your employability in these areas. You will be able to describe the role of ethics, interprofessional learning, work integrated learning, and ongoing professional development in a successful career. Additional skills are gained in building a professional profile, including through LinkedIn and other public portfolios, and in managing your public identity on social media. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: NIL
Subject_Description_16: This course introduces students to the study of human behaviour from a biological point of view and an understanding of the link between biological systems and human behaviour. Apart from providing students with knowledge in basic areas such as the human nervous system, the human sensory and motor systems, the course also includes more applied topics. For example learning and memory, perception, language, emotion and motivation, sleeping, eating and eating disorders, drugs and brain damage. This course has prerequisites that must be completed prior to enrolling in this course. It is the students' responsibility to ensure these requirements have been fulfilled. INCOMPATIBLE: 2009APY PREREQUISITES: 1001PSY OR 1005APY AND 1003PSY OR 1002APY
Subject_Description_17: This course provides a set of frameworks for examining and understanding human behaviour in a social and cultural context. It integrates the social and the cultural, with the overriding aim to develop an understanding of how the individual's thoughts, feelings, and behaviours can be shaped by the people around them, and the culture of which they are a part. Prerequisites: 1002PSY Introduction to Psychology 2 Co-requisites: Nil Incompatible: Nil
Subject_Description_18: This course explores the future of work in a rapidly globalizing, knowledge and service-intensive economy. Advances in IT and associated technologies are enabling firms to automate and/or outsource routine work, displacing the jobs of low-skilled workers, while enhancing the power of knowledge workers. In parallel, new industries and forms of collaborative and distance-based work are emerging, offering new challenges and opportunities. This course investigates the causes of technological, industrial and organisational change and their potential impacts of work arrangements and stakeholder relationships. Strategies and policies for managing change and coping with the new world of work outlined, drawing on latest research from Australia and other countries. Students would investigate how the future of work affects the business landscape of both large companies and smaller firms. It would cover sources of value creation and the benefits and challenges of the new technologies. There will be an overview of IoT and futurist thinking and of selected technologies to examine how such digital innovations are being developed and used by leading organisations. Content will address the implications for managers of social media, big data, artificial intelligence and newer technological innovations.
Subject_Description_19: The course aims to facilitate the conceptual, analytic and problem-solving skills relevant to correlational research in the social sciences, as well as generic competencies in critical analysis, communication and data interpretation. The course complements other research methods and statistics courses. Material covered includes practical concerns in conducting this type of research such as selecting a sample, constructing instruments, and ensuring validity. As well, students gain an introduction to issues in the analysis and interpretation of correlational research findings. Topics include: survey and correlational research designs; sampling; regression analysis; and categorical data analysis. Prerequisites must be completed prior to enrolling in this course. It is the students' responsibility to ensure these requirements have been fulfilled. Prerequisites: 1001PSY Introduction to Psychology 1| 1002PSY Introduction to Psychology 2| 1003PSY Research Methods and Statistics in Pscyhology Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: 2001PSY Research Methods & Statistics 3| 3001PSY Research Methods & Statistics 4
Subject_Description_20: This course is a foundation course for development of an understanding of core concepts and basic competencies necessary for effective counselling practice, especially those essential to establish and maintain the client-practitioner relationship and support the therapeutic process. You will also be introduced to the foundations of developing an understanding of the client as a unique person, also termed 'case conceptualisation' and the concept of diversity. The skills you will learn include micro-skills such as listening, attending fully to the client, and creating a safe therapeutic relationship; self-and-other awareness; and self-reflection. Practical exercises allow you to integrate knowledge development with skills application. You will also be provided with opportunities to reflect on how counselling skills will fit within your future career and how you might prepare for further professional education in the field. Prerequisites: Nil
Subject_Description_21: Students in this course are introduced to the idea that there are many ways to identify and solve the complex problems faced by businesses today; hence business success hinges on the ability to think creatively and innovatively, combining knowledge from a variety of disciplines. To this end, the course introduces ideas/tools of creativity and entrepreneurialism and demonstrates how these ideas/tools are applied to a variety of situations through the use of case studies and guest lecturers. The discussion is set in the context of the current debate on what constitutes business success, how it is achieved, and how businesses are under "scrutiny" by the community at large to ensure that they behave and operate in responsible and sustainable manner. In this regard, the course also explores issues related to financial and non-financial reporting, governance framework, risk management, stakeholder and agency, policy and regulatory intervention, indigenous/herniate assets. Lectures will include guest lecturers and will cover a diverse range of topics such as marketing, current and new technologies, future world trends, legal issues, work force issues etc. Workshops will enable students to work on case studies that involve real problems sourced from industry clients and partners. Industry clients will be directly involved in the workshop and students required to present solutions to their problems at the end of the trimester.
Subject_Description_22: This course provides a foundation for understanding the cognitive and biological bases of human behaviour, including the role of the brain and neural processes in behaviour, perception (how the senses allow you to see, hear, taste, touch and smell the world around you), conditioning and learning (how humans and other animals learn about their environment), cognition and memory (how people think, solve problems and remember). Drawing on various research traditions in experimental psychology, this course demonstrates how cognitive and biological psychology contributes to our knowledge of human well-being and performance. Students apply this knowledge through a series of practical in-class exercises. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: 1004HLS_Y2
Subject_Description_23: Transdisciplinary groups of students work together to solve contemporary challenges in business with a focus on the Sustainability Development Goals in the Asia Pacific region, including first peoples. Students present solutions to real world problems by drawing on the knowledge they have developed throughout their foundation and majors. Students participate in simulations in addition to running a social enterprise or charity event. In addition, students will finalise their program e-portfolio's with evidence of their readiness for their chosen profession or career. Students will also collect and present final evidence of readiness through Griffith Graduate Attributes, Griffith Graduates of Influence and BusinessPlus credentials.
Subject_Description_24: The aim of the course is to explain the way people behave and make decisions in a business environment and the role that information has in the context of decision-making. The course will introduce some elements of behavioural sciences and game theory applied to business problems. It will also tackle some of the critical questions around the use of information for business decision making: how to assess the validity/reliability and relevance of the information we receive? how to use it effectively? how to simplify information, make it relevant, and present it to different audiences? The course combines different aspects. First, it encourages students to account for the psychological, cognitive, emotional, cultural, and social factors that affects decisions made by individuals and organisations (e.g. private corporates, government, civil society, etc). Second it provides simple analytical tools to contextualise strategic decision-making in real world situations through lenses such as that of the consumer and the future role of social marketing. Third, it introduces students to the idea that business decision making requires reliable, timely information. The course takes a positive (as opposed to normative) approach to the analysis of interactive strategic decisions and behaviours. Through case studies, the course provides a description of what happens in a variety of business situations, with a focus on understanding the elements/dynamics that leads to a certain outcome of decision. In so doing, the course helps students identify the role of information (qualitative or quantitative), how it is sourced and assessed in terms of its validity/quality, and how it can be used to deal with uncertainty in decision-making. Basic approaches to the analysis, interpretation and presentation of various types of information are also discussed, including the foundations of big data analytics and qualitative data analysis.

Course: Bachelor of Psychological Science/Bachelor of Criminology and Criminal Justice
Description: This program will be available to commencing students at the Gold Coast and Mt Gravatt from 2021. Understanding human behaviour and what makes people tick is a crucial skill in the world of criminology and justice. With this double degree, you'll be prepared for a range of crime-related career opportunities with a focus on the psychological side of criminology. You'll also learn about the trends in crime control, along with new tactics and techniques for solving crime. At Griffith, criminology has always had a strong industry connection and a high level of cooperation from police agencies and other crime-related bodies. This double degree continues the tradition with a multitude of opportunities to meet with and hear from industry experts. In your final year, you'll have the option to complete a professional practice placement one day a week in a justice-related workplace. Combining criminology with psychological science will give you the skills and understanding needed to deal with the human behaviour of crime. You'll find work in probation and parole, community corrections, family services, counselling, child protection, program and policy development, research and administration. There are also opportunities for crime trend analysis and the role of psychology in crime prevention. Tailor your timetable - Even if you study full-time on-campus, you may still be able to customise your degree to suit your needs. From a range of tutorial times to online access to lectures and other course material, we're here to help you fit study in with your work and life commitments. Students in this degree may be able to participate in an overseas program specifically designed to fit the degree's teaching objectives such as 3023CCJ Thailand Study Tour: Sex, Drugs, Violence and Imprisonment.
Career_Outcomes: *Source: Australian Government Job Outlook.

Prerequisites: 1001PSY Introduction to Psychology 1I 1003PSY Research Methods and Statistics in PsychologyI or 2000PSY Experimental Design and Analysis Co-requisites: Nil Incompatible: Nil
Subject_Description_2: This course is designed to complement Sociology of Crime. The course focuses on individual-level explanations of criminal behaviour. The contributions of biological theories, psychodynamic theory, learning theory, personality theory and moral development theory are examined. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: CCJ20 Psychology of Crime

By the end of the course, you will have a practical framework for developing and evaluating behaviour change interventions in your own area of interest. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: NIL

You will also be introduced to the foundations of developing an understanding of the client as a unique person, also termed 'case conceptualisation' and the concept of diversity. The skills you will learn include micro-skills such as listening, attending fully to the client, and creating a safe therapeutic relationship; self-and-other awareness; and self-reflection. Practical exercises allow you to integrate knowledge development with skills application. You will also be provided with opportunities to reflect on how counselling skills will fit within your future career and how you might prepare for further professional education in the field. Prerequisites: Nil
Subject_Description_7: This course is an applied skills-oriented course. The aim of this course is to provide you with the opportunity to develop your mastery of the generic interpersonal communication skills necessary for building and maintaining effective working and personal relationships, and managing interpersonal interactions and change. In addition, you will be introduced to skills which are the "building blocks" for more advanced skills that you may use in future professional roles such as Consultant, Counsellor, Lawyer, Manager, Psychologist, Public Health practitioner or Social Worker. INCOMPATIBLE: PSY2002 AND PB12013 AND JAD1006 OR 1006CCJ AND 2007APY AND 7022HSV AND 7322AHS AND 1008HSV AND 2008EHR.
Subject_Description_8: This is an applied skills-oriented course in the Bachelor of Psychological Science and associated degrees, Bachelor of Psychology (Hons), and Bachelor of Counselling. The course focuses on effectiveness of practitioners at the small and large group level. The course introduces key models of facilitation and coaching for groups. An important aspect of this course is the linking of these models to the development of students' skills in many aspects of facilitation and coaching. At the end of this course, students will understand and have basic skills in the application of facilitation and coaching in a range of settings such as counselling, clinical, organisational, sport, and health settings. Prerequisite: 1008PSY Interpersonal Skills Incompatible: 2027HSV Group Facilitation
Subject_Description_9: This course provides the 'capstone' for the combined degree, explicitly drawing together the psychology and criminology and criminal justice strands. The course examines the criminal justice system in terms of psychological theories and perspectives, and examines the role which psychologists can play within the system. Topics covered include police occupational stress, the accuracy of eyewitness testimony, psychologists as expert witnesses, jury dynamics and decision-making, sentencing adjudication, and the prediction of dangerousness. Students must be in the Bachelor of Psychological Science/ Bachelor of Criminology and Criminal Justice to undertake this course, and must have 220CP.
Subject_Description_10: This course introduces students to the criminal justice process by illustration. Starting with a focus on the key elements of the crime event, students will develop an understanding of serious violent offences through the lens of offenders and victims of violence. Students then learn how the criminal justice system responds to serious violence offences with particular emphasis on lethal violence. Using a case study approach, students first learn how serious violent offences are detected and investigated by the policing arm of the criminal justice system. Students then consider how these offences are processed in the courts, which includes the criminal trial process and sentencing. Finally, students review the various forms of custodial sentencing and correctional settings. Throughout the course students review the ways that criminological theory has informed the various ways that the criminal justice system responds to serious violent offences (e.g., from policing initiatives and responses to sentencing to correctional rehabilitation). Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: CCJ11 Introduction to Criminal Justice, CCJ114 Homicide
Subject_Description_11: This course introduces the major 19th and 20th century theories of crime, their historical antecedents and ideological dimensions. Attention is given to street crime, white collar crime, and violence between intimates. Prior Assumed: NIL Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: CCJ27 Sociology of Crime
Subject_or_Unit_12: RESEARCH METHODS AND STATISTICS IN PSYCHOLOGY
Subject_Description_12: You will learn about the role of scientific data gathering in psychology which underpins all evidence-based practice. Basic research approaches will be described and the manner in which research is communicated (e.g., research psychology report) will be practised. You will gain skills in the description of data using basic graphical (e.g., histograms) and numerical (e.g., mean and standard deviation) methods. The association between variables through scatterplots and correlations is examined and you will learn how to calculate and interpret the confidence interval of the mean and make inferences using t-tests. You will learn to create and interpret output from the statistical software package SPSS for these statistical techniques. Prerequisites: Nil Co-requisites: Nil Incompatible: First Year Tertiary Level Statistics|1003PSY Introduction to Research in Behavioural Sciences| 2009CCJ Statistics for Social Research| 1305AFE Business Data Analysis| 1014SCG Statistics| 1002MSC Introduction to Biomedical Data Analysis| 2013AHS Research Methods and Statistics
