It will be assumed that students have the knowledge equivalent to a grade of SA over 4 semesters in Mathematics B (Qld high school subject), or equivalent study, or 1017SCG Foundation Mathematics (grade of 4 or higher). Incompatible: 1018ENG Engineering Science
Subject_Description_10: The course revises and extends basic integral and differential calculus of one variable and introduces differential equations, in applied scientific contexts. It provides a foundation in the mathematical sciences needed for later studies. Prerequisite: A grade of SA over 4 semesters in Mathematics B (Qld high school subject), or equivalent study over 4 semesters of a high school subject that includes the study of differential and integral calculus or 1011SCG Mathematics 1A (grade equivalent to 4 or higher) .
Subject_Description_11: This course introduces students to the concept of environmental sustainability and its uses in solving real world problems. It explores the relationships between the natural, rural, industrial and urban environments and includes the study of the impact humans have upon nature. The course also considers the way environmental sustainability can be used to address environmental, economic and social issues in an integrated way. Assessment includes on-line tests, a written assignment, workshop exercises and an end of trimester examination. Incompatible: 1301ENV The Global Environment, 1181ENV Sustainable Development, 1161ENV Environmental Economics and Policy.
Subject_Description_12: This course introduces the fundamental concepts and methods of general chemistry. Basic skills of laboratory chemical analysis are developed. Lecture content includes three modules: Introduction and basic concepts; molecular structure and bonding; and energy and physical processes. Incompatible: 1001SCE Chemistry 1A, 1009ENV General Chemistry, 1001ENV Chemistry 1, 1023SCG Chemistry 1
Subject_Description_13: This course extends the physics presented in Physics 1A and provides a basis for further studies in physics and physical chemistry. It introduces students to Newton's Universal Law of Gravity, Special Relativity, Thermodynamics, multi-dimensional Wave phenomena, and Optics through lectures, tutorials, and laboratory classes. Prerequisites: 1031SCG Physics 1A or 1018ENG Engineering Science AND or 1011SCG Mathematics 1A or 1201SCG Linear Algebra. Co-Assumed: 1202SCG Calculus I or 1020ENG Engineering Mathematics 2.
Subject_Description_14: Genetics and Evolutionary Biology is an introductory course that will provide foundational concepts in molecular genetics and evolutionary biology. Students will gain an understanding of the process of inheritance and mutation, population genetics, and evolutionary theory at the molecular, organismal and population level. Students will also learn commonly used genetic analysis methods and techniques employed by scientists. Course content will be delivered through a combination of lectures, workshops, and online material.
Subject_Description_15: The course introduces basic vector algebra in two and three dimensions, matrices, complex numbers, probability and revises basic functions. It provides a foundation in the mathematical sciences for later studies in science and engineering. Prior Assumed Knowledge: It will be assumed that students have the knowledge equivalent to a grade of SA over 4 semesters in Mathematics B (Qld high school subject), or equivalent study over 4 semesters of a high school subject that includes the study of differential and integral calculus or 1017SCG">1017SCG Foundation Mathematics (grade of 4 or higher). For students who do not have this level of mathematics background, it is strongly suggested that they first complete 1017SCG">1017SCG Foundation Mathematics. Incompatible: 1010ENG Engineering Mathematics 1, 1011SCG Mathematics 1A, 1201BPS Mathematics 1A.
Subject_Description_16: The course will introduce the student to the fundamental theoretical and practical principles of the Chemical sciences. Students will be encouraged to develop problem solving skills and apply these to the solution of real chemical problems. Assessment is by laboratory reports, quizzes and a final examination. Incompatible: 1001ENV, 1001MSC
Subject_Description_17: Biological Systems is an introductory course that provides an appreciation of the main concepts of modern biology. Students will gain an understanding of the origin, function and structure of living organisms by examining life at increasing levels of biological complexity, from the molecular and cellular level to whole organisms and ecosystems. Course content will be delivered through a combination of lectures, workshops, laboratory sessions and online material. Incompatible: 1601ENV Biological Systems; 1
Subject_Description_18: This course considers the molecular organisation of cells and the biochemical properties of the major classes of biological compounds which exist in, and contribute to, the cellular environment eg amino acids, carbohydrates and lipids. It covers the properties of water, pH and buffers, the structure and function of proteins, including an introduction to enzymes, the cell membrane and membrane transport.

Course: Bachelor of Sport Development/Bachelor of Business
Description: For International students commencing study from outside Australia in Trimester 1-2021 due to travel restrictions, Griffith University can offer the first year of study for this program online. This may require a variation to the courses undertaken in the first year and students will be required to liaise with the Bachelor of Sport Development Program Director to confirm the program structure for online study in the first year. For students commencing study from outside Australia, online delivery is an interim arrangement. Once travel restrictions are lifted, students will be expected to travel to Australia as soon as they are able, to continue their study on campus, and they will require a student visa for this. Students will need to be in Australia at the commencement of second year. If travel restrictions prevent this, students will need to apply for a Leave of Absence. You'll learn about sport development, business management and delivering recreation activities in the community. This degree explores four main streams of study: sport and exercise science; business, sport management and marketing; health promotion; and sports coaching. You'll also study the specialist field of community development through sport which is concerned with increasing participation in sport through the design of sport systems and pathways to attract, retain and nurture participants. You'll gain comprehensive knowledge of the academic and applied aspects of sport, health and fitness while developing business management skills to prepare you for a wide range of career opportunities. You'll also undertake studies in physiology, biomechanics, sport psychology, sociology, sports management, event management, fitness and sports coaching. Honours is available through an additional year of study.
Career_Outcomes: This program will prepare graduates for employment in community sport and recreation including health promotion officers, development officers within amateur and professional sporting organisations, program staff and managers at sport and recreation centres and resorts, executive officers with national and state sporting organisations, event managers/coordinators, and sport marketing and media officers.
Subject_Description_1: The aim of the course is to explain the way people behave and make decisions in a business environment and the role that information has in the context of decision-making. The course will introduce some elements of behavioural sciences and game theory applied to business problems. It will also tackle some of the critical questions around the use of information for business decision making: how to assess the validity/reliability and relevance of the information we receive? how to use it effectively? how to simplify information, make it relevant, and present it to different audiences? The course combines different aspects. First, it encourages students to account for the psychological, cognitive, emotional, cultural, and social factors that affects decisions made by individuals and organisations (e.g. private corporates, government, civil society, etc). Second it provides simple analytical tools to contextualise strategic decision-making in real world situations through lenses such as that of the consumer and the future role of social marketing. Third, it introduces students to the idea that business decision making requires reliable, timely information. The course takes a positive (as opposed to normative) approach to the analysis of interactive strategic decisions and behaviours. Through case studies, the course provides a description of what happens in a variety of business situations, with a focus on understanding the elements/dynamics that leads to a certain outcome of decision. In so doing, the course helps students identify the role of information (qualitative or quantitative), how it is sourced and assessed in terms of its validity/quality, and how it can be used to deal with uncertainty in decision-making. Basic approaches to the analysis, interpretation and presentation of various types of information are also discussed, including the foundations of big data analytics and qualitative data analysis.
Subject_Description_2: Students in this course are introduced to the idea that there are many ways to identify and solve the complex problems faced by businesses today; hence business success hinges on the ability to think creatively and innovatively, combining knowledge from a variety of disciplines. To this end, the course introduces ideas/tools of creativity and entrepreneurialism and demonstrates how these ideas/tools are applied to a variety of situations through the use of case studies and guest lecturers. The discussion is set in the context of the current debate on what constitutes business success, how it is achieved, and how businesses are under "scrutiny" by the community at large to ensure that they behave and operate in responsible and sustainable manner. In this regard, the course also explores issues related to financial and non-financial reporting, governance framework, risk management, stakeholder and agency, policy and regulatory intervention, indigenous/herniate assets. Lectures will include guest lecturers and will cover a diverse range of topics such as marketing, current and new technologies, future world trends, legal issues, work force issues etc. Workshops will enable students to work on case studies that involve real problems sourced from industry clients and partners. Industry clients will be directly involved in the workshop and students required to present solutions to their problems at the end of the trimester.
Subject_Description_3: Fitness Practicum II follows 3011AHS">3011AHS Fitness Practicum I and provides Sport Development and Exercise Science students with the skills required to design and deliver exercise science programs for low risk individuals and (in small groups) in a variety of indoor and outdoor fitness environments. Particular attention will be given to working with low risk clients in both predictable and unpredictable circumstances; developing, conducting and evaluating long term period fitness plans and the performance of individual clients; undertaking basic dynamic postural screening using applied biomechanics; applying teaching methods and instructional styles; and supervising and training other fitness staff. Prerequisite: 3011AHS">3011AHS Fitness Practicum I. Course is only available to Bachelor of Sport Development (1493) or Bachelor of Sport Development/Bachelor of Business (1615) students and 3rd Year Bachelor of Exercise Science (1171).
Subject_Description_4: Injury Management and Prevention will be studied from anatomical, biomechanical and patho-physiological perspectives, building upon knowledge from previous courses. The emphasis is on understanding the mechanisms, prevention and immediate management of injury in different populations and environments. The theoretical knowledge will be integrated with a variety of practical aspects including accurate identification of important joint lines, tendons, ligaments, bony landmarks, application of modalities such as ice, bandaging, taping, therapeutic massage and spinal board management procedures. This course will broadly examine the context in which sport is situated in our society, discussing in particular moral, ethical and medico-legal aspects. Prerequisite: 1016MSC Anatomy & Physiology I OR 1006MSC Foundational Anatomy and Physiology
Subject_Description_5: This course explores the future of work in a rapidly globalizing, knowledge and service-intensive economy. Advances in IT and associated technologies are enabling firms to automate and/or outsource routine work, displacing the jobs of low-skilled workers, while enhancing the power of knowledge workers. In parallel, new industries and forms of collaborative and distance-based work are emerging, offering new challenges and opportunities. This course investigates the causes of technological, industrial and organisational change and their potential impacts of work arrangements and stakeholder relationships. Strategies and policies for managing change and coping with the new world of work outlined, drawing on latest research from Australia and other countries. Students would investigate how the future of work affects the business landscape of both large companies and smaller firms. It would cover sources of value creation and the benefits and challenges of the new technologies. There will be an overview of IoT and futurist thinking and of selected technologies to examine how such digital innovations are being developed and used by leading organisations. Content will address the implications for managers of social media, big data, artificial intelligence and newer technological innovations.
Subject_Description_6: This Foundation Year course takes a multi-disciplinary and integrated approach to examine population health in the 21st century. Using a socio-ecological perspective, the course will take a systems approach (i.e. from prevention through to treatment) to introduce students to the environmental, social and behavioural determinants of health and disease. The course will link these determinants with global and national priority health challenges of the 21st century together with the implications for effective health care practice.
Subject_Description_7: The IPS course is designed to facilitate, guide and stimulate your interest and commitment to an increased understanding of what constitutes effective communication and also to develop the ability to communicate effectively. To assist with your skills acquisition, this course has been designed using an active learning approach. Learning actively will provide you with the opportunity to develop both a theoretical understanding and a practical ability to communicate and interact interpersonally. In preparation for your role as professionals in the field, you will be encouraged in this course to think of yourselves as practitioners-in-training. One of the implications of this, is that we expect you to be self managing in terms of your own learning and the learning of your colleagues. The Mixed Mode offering of this course is restricted for students enrolled in an External HSV Program only. Incompatible: 1801NRS Effective Communication; 1008PSY Interpersonal Skills; 2008EHR Business Communication.
Subject_Description_8: This course prepares graduates across health professions to provide culturally safe health services to Australia's First Peoples. Through the enhancement of the previously introduced capabilities of respect, communication, safety and quality, critical reflection, and advocacy students will be supported to apply these capabilities in First Peoples' health contexts to engender the development of cultural capabilities that reflect a lifelong journey and are tested in every interaction. The course takes a holistic perspective to engage students in exploring the historical, socio-cultural, political and dominant cultural paradigms that influence First Peoples' health today. The First Peoples' Health and Practice course supports students to meet the Griffith University Graduate Attribute E.1 Awareness of and respect for the values and knowledge of Australian Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander First Peoples and to meet the requirements of the relevant professional body's competency standards and codes of professional conduct to provide culturally safe care. Pre-requisite: Students must have successfully completed at least 80CP of undergraduate study. This requirement will be strictly enforced.
Subject_Description_9: In an increasingly complex financial system, and with an aging and longer living population, financial independence and effective financial decision making are seen as important life attributes and skills. The reality however is that many make poor financial decisions, fail to plan for their financial future, adequately protect themselves, their family and their assets, are easily influenced into poor/inappropriate financial products, and fall foul of schemes and scams. In other words there is low levels of financial literacy in the community, including in higher education graduates. A study of money and life will cover a range of content areas including planning and goal setting, behaviour and decision making, financial markets, services and products, rights and obligations under contracts, financial systems and household finances. This could also introduce fintech (including Bloomberg and the SSMIF). The course would provide a range of personal and professional development outcomes for students as well as improve their overall understanding of business. The course will be designed to be relevant for all students of the university and also has potential for development into a standalone credential/MOOC.
Subject_Description_10: Fitness Practicum I will provide students with the skills required to design and deliver exercise programs for low risk individuals and group clients in a controlled environment. Particular attention will be given to application of instructional skills in today's fitness centre environment. Conducting initial client inductions, including basic screening, fitness appraisal, program development and exercise instruction. Designing individualized training programs. Critique technique and regularly appraise client's fitness and skill acquisition and modify their program accordingly. Prerequisite: Enrolled in 1171 BExSci and completed 140CP of 1st and 2nd year courses, OR enrolled in Bachelor of Sport Development or 1615 Bachelor of Sport Development/Bachelor of Business
Subject_Description_11: Transdisciplinary groups of students work together to solve contemporary challenges in business with a focus on the Sustainability Development Goals in the Asia Pacific region, including first peoples. Students present solutions to real world problems by drawing on the knowledge they have developed throughout their foundation and majors. Students participate in simulations in addition to running a social enterprise or charity event. In addition, students will finalise their program e-portfolio's with evidence of their readiness for their chosen profession or career. Students will also collect and present final evidence of readiness through Griffith Graduate Attributes, Griffith Graduates of Influence and BusinessPlus credentials.
Subject_Description_12: This course introduces students to a perspective of the purpose of business that embeds values such as responsible leadership, integrity and ethical behaviour, respect for others, trust, and sustainable enterprise. The relevance of these values and their impact on behaviour and outcomes in a business context is demonstrated to students through case studies, real world examples, and testimonials from industry partners. Following from the discussion of values, the course then looks at how businesses develop solutions to respond to increasing demand for sustainability, transparency and good governance. The framework of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) is introduced and used to examine the alignment between business practices and sustainable solutions to real life problems faced by a business. The course also considers the role and responsibility (including legal) of professionals and professional standards in today's society.
Subject_Description_13: This course is designed as an introduction to the sport development profession. Students will explore aspects of sport development across the lifespan and factors influencing sport and physical activity participation. Restriction: Student must be in program 1493 BSportDev or 1615 BSportDev/BBus
Subject_Description_14: This introductory course explores the application of psychological knowledge to real-world human behaviour and problems in non-psychology fields including business, health, education, and science. It takes a 21st century and global perspective on how psychology can address issues of public concern such as changes in the world of work, multiculturalism, adaptation to global crises, and personal optimisation. This online free choice elective will complement your discipline-specific knowledge by developing your 'psychological literacy' and teaching you how to apply that in your future career and personal life.
Subject_Description_15: This course provides students the opportunity to develop and refine their employability skills. The course has a strong focus on the development of a personal brand and ensures students are employment ready upon graduation. Restriction 1: Student must be in program 1493 BSportDev, 1615 BSportDev/BBus, 1171 BExSci or 1355 BNutrDiet. Restriction 2: Students must complete 3535AHS in their last trimester of study in the program.
Subject_Description_16: Australia is geographically situated in the Asia Pacific region, but retains strong cultural links to the Western world. Asia is a community of diverse nations and cultures formed over the millennia. In times of boom and gloom Asian nations and their peoples have exemplified resilience and leadership. This course is designed to engage students in the diverse world of Asian history, culture, business, politics, religion, art and beliefs to develop an appreciation of our near neighbours. It examines the influences of the past and current relationships before delving into the future of the Fourth Industrial Revolution and the potential consequences for the region. The course also looks at how Asia is likely to change over the next 10 to 20 years (e.g. growth of India, evolving role of China, the role of Europe and North America). The Asia region is also a likely constant in all students' future careers and many employers desire a level of Asian literacy in their elite workforce. This course is designed to satisfy that requirement and assist students with employability strategies.
Subject_Description_17: The course introduces students to the fundamental principles of psychology as applied to the areas of exercise, sport and rehabilitation. Issues relevant to participants (across the lifespan and functional capacity), patients, coaches, practitioners, and promoters involved in the optimization of individual and group performance are considered. Prerequisite: 1001PSY - Introduction to Psychology 1 OR 1002PSY - Introduction to Psychology 2 OR equivalent
Subject_Description_18: Language and Communication for Health is offered to students from a non-English speaking background (NESB). Students whose first language is English are NOT PERMITTED to undertake this course. The aim of this course is to introduce students to the language, knowledge and communication skills required for study and practice in their discipline. A further aim is to develop and practice English language skills relevant to the academic culture of Australian universities. It therefore involves intensive English language practice and language immersion activities, with elements applied to contextualised, discipline-specific settings. This course constitutes part of the overall English Language Enhancement Strategy at Griffith University. Prerequisites: NIL; Incompatible: 5901LHS/5901LAL, 5903LHS/5903LAL, 5904LHS/5904LAL and 5902LAL.
Subject_Description_19: Integration of human body structure (Anatomy) and maintenance of healthy function (Physiology) is fundamental biological knowledge, relevant and applied by many health and allied health professions. This comprehensive introductory course facilitates student exploration of each body system through lectures, laboratory classes and on-line resources. Incompatible: 1016MSC Anatomy and Physiology Systems 1; 1017MSC Anatomy and Physiology Systems 2; 1001NSC Human Pre-requisites: None
Subject_Description_20: This course is ONLY available to those students enrolled in AHS Programs. This course outlines the skills and knowledge to provide athletes, regardless of age and ability, with the best possible methods of applying principles to enhance coaching performance.
Subject_Description_21: This is the capstone course for the Bachelor of Sport Development. This course requires students to complete 80 hours of Professional Practice Education placement. It also provides students with the opportunity to develop and refine their employability skills, CV and portfolio to ensure they are employment ready upon graduation. Please note that for Trimester 2, 2020, the placement will be a virtual placement. Restriction: Student must be in program 1493 BSportDev or 1615 BSportDev/BBus
Subject_Description_22: This course is designed to provide students with an insight into the practices involved in the Sport Development industry. Students will explore aspects of Sport Development including: performance analysis; interpersonal relationships and considerations; sociological issues; and reflective practice in Sport Development. Restriction: Student must be in program 1493 BSportDev or 1615 BSportDev/BBus Prerequisite: 1212AHS Sport Development I

Course: Bachelor of Urban and Environmental Planning/Bachelor of Science
Description: International students must be in Australia and able to attend campus to commence this program. This program will be available to commencing students at the Gold Coast and Nathan from 2021. Urban environments are a key part of our future, and we need to make sustainably minded decisions that not only consider but prioritise the social and ecological elements of planning for cities. In this degree, you'll bring social and natural sciences together to prepare for a career as an environmental scientist. Your foundation first year will introduce basic concepts, theories and methods of planning and environmental sciences. From your second year, you'll select one of three majors to develop specific technical skills and knowledge to    complement your fundamental education in planning and environmental science. This degree has a strong focus on practical, hands-on learning opportunities. You'll have access to our cutting-edge drawing studios, labs and facilities to help test your theories and bring your ideas to life. You'll also have a range of opportunities to learn outside the classroom, including international and national field trips, wildlife and environmental surveys, research opportunities and internships. In your final year, you can add a point of difference to your resume by working with a professional planning practitioner. Through the placement, you'll make valuable connectionsas you work on a practical project with tangible outcomes, giving you industry experience before you graduate. You'll be prepared for a career as an environmental scientist and planner. You'll find employment in government and in resources development and consultancy companies. You'll also find opportunities in land and water management, conservation, natural resources, mining or energy. Additionally, with all of our urban and environmental planning degrees recognised by the Planning Institute of Australia, our students are able to go on to work overseas in countries such as New Zealand and the United Kingdom. Tailor your timetable - Even if you study full-time on-campus, you may still be able to customise your degree to suit your needs. From a range of tutorial times to online access to lectures and other course material, we're here to help you fit study in with your work and life commitments.
Career_Outcomes: *Source: Australian Government Job Outlook
Subject_Description_1: This course focuses upon the relationship between the natural environment and economic systems. It includes both the analysis and understanding of human economy impacts upon the natural systems that support it, as well as, approaches for the sustainable management of natural resources. The role of economics in the various decision-making approaches relevant to environmental resources is outlined. The content covers the major concepts and specific methods for the economic assessment of costs and benefits of ecosystems and other natural resources. The course also highlights concepts and theory for the economic analysis and policy for the sustainable management of both renewable and non-renewable resources. It covers and compares the contributions of both mainstream economic extensions as well as broader sustainability sciences such as ecological economics. Prerequisite: Completion of 80CP. Incompatible: 2281ENV Economics and Natural Resources, 2281AES Economics and Natural Resources.
Subject_Description_2: This course explores the theory and practice of transport and land use planning. The course involves a lecture series and course readings, a set of interlinked workshops to design, administer and analyse a travel survey, and a literature review exercise that allows students to more deeply explore a significant issue in transport and land use planning. The course covers such topics as the theoretical underpinnings of transport planning, contemporary transport policy, the impacts of transport systems on the environment, transport modelling, planning for walking, cycling and public transport, disruptive technology and transport and transport and land use integration. Students must have completed 130 credit points or have the permission of the course convenor before enrolling in this course.
Subject_Description_3: This course provides a range of activities that will further develop inquiry and problem-solving skills and put the professional responsibilities of science students into practice. A range of authentic learning experiences will see students conduct investigations (open investigations, experiments, field assessments, application of theory) as individuals, occasionally working in small teams if necessary, in which data is collected, recorded and interpreted using appropriate discipline specific approaches. Conclusions will be drawn and questions for future investigation highlighted. Assessment will be by the combination of a high-quality written report and an oral defence of this report.
Subject_Description_4: Biological Systems is an introductory course that provides an appreciation of the main concepts of modern biology. Students will gain an understanding of the origin, function and structure of living organisms by examining life at increasing levels of biological complexity, from the molecular and cellular level to whole organisms and ecosystems. Course content will be delivered through a combination of lectures, workshops, laboratory sessions and online material. Incompatible: 1601ENV Biological Systems; 1
Subject_Description_5: This course introduces students to the concept of environmental sustainability and its uses in solving real world problems. It explores the relationships between the natural, rural, industrial and urban environments and includes the study of the impact humans have upon nature. The course also considers the way environmental sustainability can be used to address environmental, economic and social issues in an integrated way. Assessment includes on-line tests, a written assignment, workshop exercises and an end of trimester examination. Incompatible: 1301ENV The Global Environment, 1181ENV Sustainable Development, 1161ENV Environmental Economics and Policy.
Subject_Description_6: The course will discuss chemical properties and the mechanisms of chemical change, with everyday examples from environmental science and medicine. The principles of chemical thermodynamics, organic chemistry, biological chemistry and chemical reactions and properties in solution will be reinforced by a laboratory program. Tutorial assignments will be used to develop problem solving skills. Assessment is by laboratory reports, mid-trimester examination and end of trimester examination. Assumed prior knowledge: 1023SCG Chemistry I OR 1001ENV Chemistry I OR 1001EAS Chemistry 1 OR Year 12 Chemistry AND Year 12 Mathematics B OR 1503ENG Physics and Chemistry. Incompatible: 1502ENV Chemistry II, 1502EAS Chemistry 2.
Subject_Description_7: This course is conducted primarily as individual placements, or small teams of students within an industrial or research environment and emphasizes academic and vocational aspects of modern industry practice. Students consolidate their technical knowledge by undertaking a project in a professional workplace (which may include a University lab) whilst simultaneously managing their learning and course assessment. The project provides students with the opportunity to undertake a substantial project that usually has an industry application. Students work in close liaison with their industry and university supervisor throughout the project and are expected to demonstrate a good understanding of their project. The course also emphasizes that competence in management, business and social responsibilities are essential components in all fields within the environment and science professions and the key attributes of a contemporary industry or research environment. Prerequisites Students should be in the third or final year of study and must have completed the online registration form which can be followed by clicking on the red 'Access Learning@Griffith' link provided here: https://www.griffith.edu.au/griffith-sciences/partnerships/wil-for-student To be eligibile for enrolment in this course, students must have completed all requirements of the WIL Office in preparation for placement, including allocation to an industry placement or project. Student must have completed 140CP and have gained a GPA of 4.5 or higher. Enquiries are to be directed to the Course Convenor. Incompatible: 3103ENV Industry Placement
Subject_Description_8: The course introduces basic vector algebra in two and three dimensions, matrices, complex numbers, probability and revises basic functions. It provides a foundation in the mathematical sciences for later studies in science and engineering. Prior Assumed Knowledge: It will be assumed that students have the knowledge equivalent to a grade of SA over 4 semesters in Mathematics B (Qld high school subject), or equivalent study over 4 semesters of a high school subject that includes the study of differential and integral calculus or 1017SCG">1017SCG Foundation Mathematics (grade of 4 or higher). For students who do not have this level of mathematics background, it is strongly suggested that they first complete 1017SCG">1017SCG Foundation Mathematics. Incompatible: 1010ENG Engineering Mathematics 1, 1011SCG Mathematics 1A, 1201BPS Mathematics 1A.
Subject_Description_9: This course introduces the main environmental spheres and important natural processes of the Earth, considered as a series of systems interacting at various scales. Features of the lithosphere, atmosphere, hydrosphere and biosphere are explained, with emphasis given to the interrelationships between these spheres. In doing so, basic concepts of the more specialized fields of meteorology, climatology, hydrology, oceanography, soil science, geology, geomorphology and biogeochemistry will be studied. Incompatible: 1303ENV Earth Sciences, 1051AES Earth Sciences, 1302EAS Earth Sciences, 1004EAS Earth Sciences and GIS, 1004ENV Earth Science and GIS.
Subject_Description_10: This course introduces the fundamental concepts and methods of general chemistry. Basic skills of laboratory chemical analysis are developed. Lecture content includes three modules: Introduction and basic concepts; molecular structure and bonding; and energy and physical processes. Incompatible: 1001SCE Chemistry 1A, 1009ENV General Chemistry, 1001ENV Chemistry 1, 1023SCG Chemistry 1
Subject_Description_11: THIS COURSE IS RESTRICTED TO STUDENTS ENROLLED IN THE FOLLOWING PROGRAMS: 1279 / 1086 Bachelor of Urban and Environmental Planning 1512/1516 Bachelor of Urban and Environmental Planning/Bachelor of Science 1431/1432 Bachelor of Urban and Environmental Planning (Honours). This studio will address the strategic and multi-disciplinary nature of broad scale regional planning. It could take the form of a conservation, community development or a resource management study and involve the preparation of a spatially based, geographic specific plan or policies. Emphasis will be given to scientific input and research techniques, handling of multiple objectives, integration of ecological, social, economic, cultural aspects, forecasting techniques, and to strategic thinking. Pre-requisite: Students must have passed 1027ENV Introductory Planning Studio, 1511ENV Environmental Planning Studio, 2067ENV Development Processes Studio and 2056ENV Urban Analysis and Planning Studio and completed 160 credit points or have the permission of the course convenor before enrolling in this course.
Subject_or_Unit_12: POLICYMAKING AND PLANNING FOR CLIMATE CHANGE
Subject_Description_12: This course offers students the opportunity to develop an understanding of the policymaking process and how it can be applied in responding to the problem of climate change. A cross-section of adaptation and mitigation policies are analysed, from the international to the national, state and local levels of government. No prior knowledge of policymaking or climate change is assumed. Pre-requisite: Undergraduate students must have completed at least 120CP of study before enrolling in this course. Incompatible courses: 7057ENV">7057ENV Policy Planning; 7057ENV">7057ENV Climate Change Policy; 4117EVP Policy Planning Studio; 4087EVP Policy Planning Studio; 4118ENV">4118ENV Policy Planning; and, 4118ENV">4118ENV Climate Change Policy. Restricted: Course must be listed in Program
Subject_Description_13: Understanding Australian Cities is an introductory overview of the origin, patterning and functioning of the urban system. The course specifically examines the dynamics of population, infrastructure, governance and culture in Australian cities. These understandings frame examination of the possibilities of planning intervention. This introductory course will allow students to better appreciate the range of planning challenges and the opportunities for further study. This course is delivered via weekly lectures and tutorials and is supplemented with web materials and readings.
Subject_Description_14: This course provides a range of activities that will further develop inquiry and problem-solving skills and put the professional responsibilities of science students into practice. A range of authentic learning experiences will see students conduct investigations (open investigations, experiments, field assessments, application of theory) as individuals, occasionally working in small teams if necessary, in which data is collected, recorded and interpreted using appropriate discipline specific approaches. Conclusions will be drawn and questions for future investigation highlighted. Assessment will be by the combination of a high-quality written report and an oral defence of this report.
Subject_Description_15: The course will introduce the student to the fundamental theoretical and practical principles of the Chemical sciences. Students will be encouraged to develop problem solving skills and apply these to the solution of real chemical problems. Assessment is by laboratory reports, quizzes and a final examination. Incompatible: 1001ENV, 1001MSC
Subject_Description_16: Students are introduced to Geographic Information Systems that enable the capture, storage, manipulation and analysis of different types of spatial or geographical data. These systems are important tools for environmental scientists in managing environmental systems. Incompatible: 2205ENV Geographic Information Systems, 3047ENV Geographic Information Systems
Subject_Description_17: Urban Analysis and Planning Studio builds upon earlier studio courses in the degree, and will provide you with essential research methods and analytical techniques that planners use to understand the ecological, social, cultural, economic and political relationships that comprise the urban environment. Drawing upon diverse theories, the course will teach you to analyze cities from multiple perspectives e.g. historical, spatial, cultural, ecological etc. You will undertake extensive fieldwork to collect data for weekly course activities. Throughout the course you will be required to demonstrate your reading, critical thinking and analytical skills, and to reflect upon what you have read and learned, when writing activity reports. You will learn to reference impeccably and to communicate effectively. As this is a 20CP studio course, students should expect to spend twice as long on it as a standard, 10CP course. Incompatible: EP32006 Urban Analysis; 2057EVP Urban Analysis; 2057ENV Urban Analysis, 2056ENV Urban Analysis. Prerequisites: 1027ENV Introductory Planning Studio, 1511ENV Environmental Planning Studio, 1037ENV Understanding the Australian City.
Subject_Description_18: This course introduces students to planning theory and how this relates to the practice of planning. The course will include presentations by practicing planners and be run as an interative workshop. The course will be offered at both Nathan and Gold Coast campuses.
Subject_Description_19: Genetics and Evolutionary Biology is an introductory course that will provide foundational concepts in molecular genetics and evolutionary biology. Students will gain an understanding of the process of inheritance and mutation, population genetics, and evolutionary theory at the molecular, organismal and population level. Students will also learn commonly used genetic analysis methods and techniques employed by scientists. Course content will be delivered through a combination of lectures, workshops, and online material.
Subject_Description_20: This course discusses the strategies employed by Aboriginal activists to establish a political relationship between Australia's Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal peoples in the 20th century. By contextualising a few of the many individuals who have contributed towards social and political change we can acknowledge the active agency of Aboriginal people to promote their interests in local, national and international forums. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: NIL
Subject_Description_21: This course provides an introduction to the basic concepts and practices of data analysis and inferential statistics. It will provide and understanding of several techniques including testing one or more means from sampled populations (t-Tests and ANOVAs), relationships between scale variables (correlations and regressions), and contingency table analysis (Chi-square tests). The course places emphasis on understanding the use of appropriate data for these tests, the use of exploratory data analysis and the underlying distributions and assumptions associated with these tests. Students will learn how to carry out these tests by hand, via the use of statistical software (SAS or SPSS), check assumptions, interpret results and report findings in plain English. Assumed prior knowledge: Grade 12 Maths A or B or equivalent. Incompatible: 1003ENV Statistics, 2012MSC Biostatistics, 2012HSC, Intro to Biomedical Data Analysis, Bioinformatics, 1003PSY Research Methods and Statistics in Psychology, 1002MSC Introduction to Biomedical Data Analysis
Subject_Description_22: This course covers core chemistry concepts in a biological and physical context in the areas of organic chemistry, inorganic chemistry and the energetics of matter and living systems. Incompatible courses: 1102SCE Chemistry 1B, 1104SCE Foundations of Biological and Medicinal Chemistry, 1106SCE Chemistry B, 1111AES Introduction to Environmental Chemistry, 1502ENV Chemistry II, 1502SCE Introduction to Nanoscience,
Subject_Description_23: Students will prepare a development application (e.g. subdivision; mixed use; tourism), working completely through the process from the perspective of the proponent including site evaluation, design, negotiations and financial appraisal. A strong competency in the incorporation of environmental management principles in the completed physical design and supporting material is expected. Please note: Students not enrolled in the planning programs may enrol with the permission of the course convenor. Students must be aware that in undertaking this course prior knowledge is assumed. Prerequisite: 1027ENV Introduction to Planning Studio. Incompatible: 2047ENV Development Processes Studio; 2047EVP Development Processes Studio; 2067EVP Development Processes Studio.
Subject_Description_24: This course focuses on the design and evaluation of participatory processes in urban and environmental planning. You will research and apply different methods and approaches for involving people in planning and learn the importance of contextually appropriate engagement. You will also conduct an independent evaluation of a real life public event using desktop and field based research. You will deliver a comphrensive professional-quality evaluation report which critically evaluates, develops robust conclusions, and provides clear recommendations for best practice public participation in planning . Students must have completed 130CP credit points or have the permission of the course convenor before enrolling in this course. Incompatible: 4047EVP Public Involvement and Community Development
Subject_Description_25: This course equips students with a good knowledge of planning law with particular reference to the law in Queensland. The course involves statutory interpretation, case law analysis and a contextual critique of the principal statutes, including the Planning Act, Qld, 2016, principles and doctrines. It includes a case study of planning and climate change. It is recommended that students have successfully completed at least 80 credit points of courses towards their degree program before enrolling in this course.
Subject_Description_26: This course provides a range of activities that will further develop inquiry and problem-solving skills and put the professional responsibilities of environmental science students into practice. A range of authentic learning experiences will see students conduct investigations (open investigations, experiments, field assessments, application of theory) as individuals, occasionally working in small teams if necessary, in which data is collected, recorded and interpreted using appropriate discipline specific approaches. Conclusions will be drawn and questions for future investigation highlighted. Assessment will be by the combination of a high-quality written report and an oral defense of this report. Incompatible: 3992SCG Science Capstone OR 3992NSC_Y1 & Y2 Science Capstone.
Subject_Description_27: This course highlights the important role of environmental politics and policy in furthering understanding of and addressing constructively questions such as: Who is responsible for protecting the Australian environment? What is being done? How might more be done to achieve ecological sustainable development? How do we analyse this? As such, Environmental Politics and Policy introduces key environmental political institutions; policy actors, processes and policies; and issues, in the ecopolitical terrain, central to achieving effective environmental management for long term environmental sustainability. The course is essential for the fields of environmental politics, policy, management and planning. This is a condensed course taught in the first 6 weeks of the trimester. That said, assignments are due in Weeks 6, 7 and 10. Prerequisite: Completion of 80CP
Subject_Description_28: The course explores the impact that government and business have on one another in a national and international context. It asks what consequences these relationships have for both government and business, particularly in the context of the aftermath of the global financial crisis. It offers insights into how government policies and practices affect business and how business influences and relates to government. At the heart of this course lies the issue of government intervention in business in Australia and elsewhere around the world. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatibles: 1004GIR Government-Business Relations, 1004PPP/1184PPP Government-Business Relations, 2004PPP Government-Business Relations.
Subject_Description_30: THIS COURSE IS RESTRICTED TO STUDENTS ENROLLED IN THE FOLLOWING PROGRAMS: 1086/1279 Bachelor of Urban and Environmental Planning (Pass Stream); OR 1087/1459 Bachelor of Urban and Environmental Planning/ Bachelor of Science (Environment) (Pass Stream); OR 1357/1460 Bachelor of Urban and Environmental Planning/Bachelor of Science (Pass Stream); OR 1121 Bachelor of Laws/ Bachelor of Science (Environment) (Urban and Regional Planning Stream). Undertaking a Planning Practicum Course is compulsory for all students studying within the Urban and Environmental Planning Programs at Griffith University. In this course we collegially explore issues underpinning contemporary planning practice such as: planning ethics; professionalism; education and the practice-theory relationship; and the boundaries, scope and role of the profession. Students also contribute their ideas for the continuing development and advancement of the profession. To participate, students must either (a) undertake a specified period of approved work placement in a planning related role within a specified time frame or (b) be employed in a professional planning role. Pre-enrolment assistance and guidance is provided for students seeking work placement. Pre-requisite: Students must have completed 210 credit points or have the permission of the Course Convenor before enrolling in this course. Incompatible course: 4017EVP Planning Practicum 20.
Subject_Description_31: Mathematics underpins and informs all scientific fields and is the language of science. Quantitative Reasoning is a mathematics course with a difference. Students will learn how to translate scientific problems into mathematical form, and how to understand and interpret mathematical and numerical results. With modern software, they will use case studies to learn how to apply mathematical concepts, from basics up to simple calculus, to real-world scientific problems. Incompatible: 1013SCG
Subject_Description_32: This course covers frameworks and approaches used for managing society's impacts on the environment. Topics include: environmental protection, environmental health, quality assurance and regulation, impact assessment and environmental auditing, catchment management and water resources, waste management, contaminated land; and environmental management in practice. Field work focused on environmental relevant activities will demonstrate how environmental management programs are implemented in industry settings.
Subject_Description_33: Environmental Planning Studio is a foundation course within the Urban and Environmental Planning programs. The course addresses discipline specific content aligned with an introduction to generic academic skills including critical thinking, written and oral communication, research skills and reflective learning practices. Learning and teaching activities within the course are designed to encourage students to develop and hone these generic academic skills. The discipline specific planning content covered in the course includes definitions of planning, history of planning, formal and informal planning frameworks, and the spatial and temporal scales through which planning occurs. Students are also introduced to notions of environment and environmental sustainability, to build an understanding of the evolution and practice of urban and environmental planning. THIS COURSE IS RESTRICTED TO STUDENTS ENROLLED IN THE FOLLOWING PROGRAMS: 1279 / 1086 Bachelor of Urban and Environmental Planning, 1460 Bachelor of Urban and Environmental Planning/Bachelor of Science, 1459 Bachelor of Urban and Environmental Planning/Bachelor of Science in Environment Incompatible: 2017EVP Planning Systems, 2017ENV Planning Systems, 1017ENV">1017ENV Planning Systems, 1017ENV">1017ENV Introduction to Environmental Planning

Course: Bachelor of Urban and Environmental Planning (Honours)/Bachelor of Science
Description: This program gives you a unique opportunity to prepare for a career as an environmental scientist or as an urban and environmental planner. Upon graduating, you will be equipped to play an important role in bringing social and natural sciences together to find solutions for complex planning issues and problems. Combining the knowledge and skills of planning with in-depth study of core environmental areas, the program integrates all aspects of environmental sciences (natural, social and economic) with planning principles. Your foundation year introduces you to basic concepts, theories and methods of planning and environmental sciences. Interdisciplinary skills in environmental problem-solving are developed along with generic skills in project management, group work, research, critical thinking, research and writing for professional practice. In Years 2 to 5, you will undertake a range of planning courses and receive training in environmental science and continue the development of specific and generic skills. In your final year you will undertake an industry placement and work with a professional planning practitioner. After the first year, based on your individual interests, you select a major from the following list of Bachelor of Science majors that focus on environmental studies:
Career_Outcomes: As the importance of environmental issues continues to grow, your specialised knowledge and skills, and your ability to solve complex planning issues and problems, will give you an expanded range of rewarding career opportunities. Graduates from the program have gained employment within local, state and federal government, consulting firms and within small, local or large, multinational development companies, as well as in the high demand areas of management of land and water, conservation, natural resources or environmental pollution.
Subject_Description_1: Genetics and Evolutionary Biology is an introductory course that will provide foundational concepts in molecular genetics and evolutionary biology. Students will gain an understanding of the process of inheritance and mutation, population genetics, and evolutionary theory at the molecular, organismal and population level. Students will also learn commonly used genetic analysis methods and techniques employed by scientists. Course content will be delivered through a combination of lectures, workshops, and online material.
Subject_Description_2: The course explores the impact that government and business have on one another in a national and international context. It asks what consequences these relationships have for both government and business, particularly in the context of the aftermath of the global financial crisis. It offers insights into how government policies and practices affect business and how business influences and relates to government. At the heart of this course lies the issue of government intervention in business in Australia and elsewhere around the world. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatibles: 1004GIR Government-Business Relations, 1004PPP/1184PPP Government-Business Relations, 2004PPP Government-Business Relations.
Subject_Description_3: THIS COURSE IS RESTRICTED TO STUDENTS ENROLLED IN THE FOLLOWING PROGRAMS: 1279 / 1086 Bachelor of Urban and Environmental Planning 1512/1516 Bachelor of Urban and Environmental Planning/Bachelor of Science 1431/1432 Bachelor of Urban and Environmental Planning (Honours). This studio will address the strategic and multi-disciplinary nature of broad scale regional planning. It could take the form of a conservation, community development or a resource management study and involve the preparation of a spatially based, geographic specific plan or policies. Emphasis will be given to scientific input and research techniques, handling of multiple objectives, integration of ecological, social, economic, cultural aspects, forecasting techniques, and to strategic thinking. Pre-requisite: Students must have passed 1027ENV Introductory Planning Studio, 1511ENV Environmental Planning Studio, 2067ENV Development Processes Studio and 2056ENV Urban Analysis and Planning Studio and completed 160 credit points or have the permission of the course convenor before enrolling in this course.
Subject_Description_4: Environmental Planning Studio is a foundation course within the Urban and Environmental Planning programs. The course addresses discipline specific content aligned with an introduction to generic academic skills including critical thinking, written and oral communication, research skills and reflective learning practices. Learning and teaching activities within the course are designed to encourage students to develop and hone these generic academic skills. The discipline specific planning content covered in the course includes definitions of planning, history of planning, formal and informal planning frameworks, and the spatial and temporal scales through which planning occurs. Students are also introduced to notions of environment and environmental sustainability, to build an understanding of the evolution and practice of urban and environmental planning. THIS COURSE IS RESTRICTED TO STUDENTS ENROLLED IN THE FOLLOWING PROGRAMS: 1279 / 1086 Bachelor of Urban and Environmental Planning, 1460 Bachelor of Urban and Environmental Planning/Bachelor of Science, 1459 Bachelor of Urban and Environmental Planning/Bachelor of Science in Environment Incompatible: 2017EVP Planning Systems, 2017ENV Planning Systems, 1017ENV">1017ENV Planning Systems, 1017ENV">1017ENV Introduction to Environmental Planning
Subject_Description_5: Students enrolled in the Honours stream will undertake a Research Project relevant to their study of urban and environmental planning under the guidance of one or more supervisors appointed by the Honours Convenor. The topic and nature of the Research Project will be determined through consultation and mutual agreement of the student and supervisor, and must be approved by the Program Convenor. The Research Project will involve original research but this can include the collection and analysis of primary data, the analysis of secondary data or the development of new theoretical or conceptual models. The Research Project will be conducted under the direct supervision of an academic staff member of Griffith University, although appropriate supervisor(s) from beyond the University may form part of the supervisory team, with the approval of the Honours Convenor and the Program Convenor (if financial remuneration is proposed). Assessment will comprise a written report of the work, prepared in the form of a thesis and submitted for independent examination by at least two assessors. Students will also be required to make two presentations: one of their research plans and one describing their work and provisional conclusions. The quality of these presentations will contribute to the overall assessment of the Project. Students are advised to consult the Honours Program Convenor, the Handbook and relevant Learning@Griffith website for detailed information on appropriate word limits, thesis format and other expectations concerning the amount of work to be produced in their disciplines.
Subject_Description_6: This course provides a range of activities that will further develop inquiry and problem-solving skills and put the professional responsibilities of science students into practice. A range of authentic learning experiences will see students conduct investigations (open investigations, experiments, field assessments, application of theory) as individuals, occasionally working in small teams if necessary, in which data is collected, recorded and interpreted using appropriate discipline specific approaches. Conclusions will be drawn and questions for future investigation highlighted. Assessment will be by the combination of a high-quality written report and an oral defence of this report.
Subject_Description_7: Students will prepare a development application (e.g. subdivision; mixed use; tourism), working completely through the process from the perspective of the proponent including site evaluation, design, negotiations and financial appraisal. A strong competency in the incorporation of environmental management principles in the completed physical design and supporting material is expected. Please note: Students not enrolled in the planning programs may enrol with the permission of the course convenor. Students must be aware that in undertaking this course prior knowledge is assumed. Prerequisite: 1027ENV Introduction to Planning Studio. Incompatible: 2047ENV Development Processes Studio; 2047EVP Development Processes Studio; 2067EVP Development Processes Studio.
Subject_Description_8: The course will discuss chemical properties and the mechanisms of chemical change, with everyday examples from environmental science and medicine. The principles of chemical thermodynamics, organic chemistry, biological chemistry and chemical reactions and properties in solution will be reinforced by a laboratory program. Tutorial assignments will be used to develop problem solving skills. Assessment is by laboratory reports, mid-trimester examination and end of trimester examination. Assumed prior knowledge: 1023SCG Chemistry I OR 1001ENV Chemistry I OR 1001EAS Chemistry 1 OR Year 12 Chemistry AND Year 12 Mathematics B OR 1503ENG Physics and Chemistry. Incompatible: 1502ENV Chemistry II, 1502EAS Chemistry 2.
Subject_Description_9: This course highlights the important role of environmental politics and policy in furthering understanding of and addressing constructively questions such as: Who is responsible for protecting the Australian environment? What is being done? How might more be done to achieve ecological sustainable development? How do we analyse this? As such, Environmental Politics and Policy introduces key environmental political institutions; policy actors, processes and policies; and issues, in the ecopolitical terrain, central to achieving effective environmental management for long term environmental sustainability. The course is essential for the fields of environmental politics, policy, management and planning. This is a condensed course taught in the first 6 weeks of the trimester. That said, assignments are due in Weeks 6, 7 and 10. Prerequisite: Completion of 80CP
Subject_Description_10: Mathematics underpins and informs all scientific fields and is the language of science. Quantitative Reasoning is a mathematics course with a difference. Students will learn how to translate scientific problems into mathematical form, and how to understand and interpret mathematical and numerical results. With modern software, they will use case studies to learn how to apply mathematical concepts, from basics up to simple calculus, to real-world scientific problems. Incompatible: 1013SCG
Subject_Description_11: This course introduces students to planning theory and how this relates to the practice of planning. The course will include presentations by practicing planners and be run as an interative workshop. The course will be offered at both Nathan and Gold Coast campuses.
Subject_Description_12: This course introduces students to the concept of environmental sustainability and its uses in solving real world problems. It explores the relationships between the natural, rural, industrial and urban environments and includes the study of the impact humans have upon nature. The course also considers the way environmental sustainability can be used to address environmental, economic and social issues in an integrated way. Assessment includes on-line tests, a written assignment, workshop exercises and an end of trimester examination. Incompatible: 1301ENV The Global Environment, 1181ENV Sustainable Development, 1161ENV Environmental Economics and Policy.
Subject_Description_13: This course is a supervised program of study. Students will work with their Honours supervisors towards the production of a proposal for their honours dissertation. Prerequisite: 2056ENV Urban Analysis and Planning Studio or convenor's approval
Subject_Description_14: This course introduces the fundamental concepts and methods of general chemistry. Basic skills of laboratory chemical analysis are developed. Lecture content includes three modules: Introduction and basic concepts; molecular structure and bonding; and energy and physical processes. Incompatible: 1001SCE Chemistry 1A, 1009ENV General Chemistry, 1001ENV Chemistry 1, 1023SCG Chemistry 1
Subject_Description_15: This foundation studio provides an introduction to the practice of planning and is designed to underpin the program by application of the students' knowledge and skills to practical planning projects. Students are required to complete studio exercises to develop fundamental planning skills in site inspection, site analysis, design and communication. These skills will be applied in the analysis of a planning issue and the development of a solution. The studio requires work in small groups and individually throughout the semester. Field work will be an integral component of the studio. THIS COURSE IS RESTRICTED TO STUDENTS ENROLLED IN THE FOLLOWING PROGRAMS: 1279/1086 Bachelor of Urban and Environmental Planning, 1087/1459 Bachelor of Urban and Environmental Planning/Bachelor of Science (Environment), 1121 Bachelor of Laws/Bachelor of Science (Environment), 1140 Bachelor of Laws/Bachelor of Urban and Environmental Planning, 1356 Bachelor of Environmental Design, 1357/1460/1512/1516 Bachelor of Urban and Environmental Planning/Bachelor of Science. Incompatible course: 2037EVP Introductory Planning Studio; 1027EVP Introductory Planning Studio.
Subject_Description_16: Students enrolled in the Honours stream will undertake a Research Project relevant to their study of urban and environmental planning under the guidance of one or more supervisors appointed by the Honours Convenor. The topic and nature of the Research Project will be determined through consultation and mutual agreement of the student and supervisor, and must be approved by the Program Convenor. The Research Project will involve original research but this can include the collection and analysis of primary data, the analysis of secondary data or the development of new theoretical or conceptual models. The Research Project will be conducted under the direct supervision of an academic staff member of Griffith University, although appropriate supervisor(s) from beyond the University may form part of the supervisory team, with the approval of the Honours Convenor and the Program Convenor (if financial remuneration is proposed). Assessment will comprise a written report of the work, prepared in the form of a thesis and submitted for independent examination by at least two assessors. Students will also be required to make two presentations: one of their research plans and one describing their work and provisional conclusions. The quality of these presentations will contribute to the overall assessment of the Project. Students are advised to consult the Honours Program Convenor, the Handbook and relevant Learning@Griffith website for detailed information on appropriate word limits, thesis format and other expectations concerning the amount of work to be produced in their disciplines.
Subject_Description_17: Biological Systems is an introductory course that provides an appreciation of the main concepts of modern biology. Students will gain an understanding of the origin, function and structure of living organisms by examining life at increasing levels of biological complexity, from the molecular and cellular level to whole organisms and ecosystems. Course content will be delivered through a combination of lectures, workshops, laboratory sessions and online material. Incompatible: 1601ENV Biological Systems; 1
Subject_Description_18: This course discusses the strategies employed by Aboriginal activists to establish a political relationship between Australia's Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal peoples in the 20th century. By contextualising a few of the many individuals who have contributed towards social and political change we can acknowledge the active agency of Aboriginal people to promote their interests in local, national and international forums. Prerequisites: NIL Co-requisites: NIL Incompatible: NIL
Subject_Description_19: Language and Communication for Sciences is offered to students from a non-English speaking background (NESB). Students whose first language is English are NOT PERMITTED to undertake this course. The aim of this course is to introduce students to the language, knowledge and communication skills required for study and practice in their discipline. A further aim is to develop and practice English language skills relevant to the academic culture of Australian universities. It therefore involves intensive English language practice and language immersion activities, with elements applied to contextualised, discipline-specific settings. This course constitutes part of the overall English Language Enhancement Strategy at Griffith University. Prerequisites: NIL; Incompatible: 5901LHS/5901LAL, 5902LHS/5902LAL, 5904LHS/5904LAL and 5903LAL.
Subject_Description_20: Students enrolled in the Honours stream will undertake a Research Project relevant to their study of urban and environmental planning under the guidance of one or more supervisors appointed by the Honours Convenor. The topic and nature of the Research Project will be determined through consultation and mutual agreement of the student and supervisor, and must be approved by the Program Convenor. The Research Project will involve original research but this can include the collection and analysis of primary data, the analysis of secondary data or the development of new theoretical or conceptual models. The Research Project will be conducted under the direct supervision of an academic staff member of Griffith University, although appropriate supervisor(s) from beyond the University may form part of the supervisory team, with the approval of the Honours Convenor and the Program Convenor (if financial remuneration is proposed). Students will also be required to make two presentations: one of their research plans and one describing their work and provisional conclusions. The quality of these presentations will contribute to the overall assessment of the Project. Students are advised to consult the Honours Program Convenor, the Handbook and relevant Learning@Griffith website for detailed information on appropriate word limits, thesis format and other expectations concerning the amount of work to be produced in their disciplines.

A range of authentic learning experiences will see students conduct investigations (open investigations, experiments, field assessments, application of theory) as individuals, occasionally working in small teams if necessary, in which data is collected, recorded and interpreted using appropriate discipline specific approaches. Conclusions will be drawn and questions for future investigation highlighted. Assessment will be by the combination of a high-quality written report and an oral defense of this report. Incompatible: 3992SCG Science Capstone OR 3992NSC_Y1 & Y2 Science Capstone.
Subject_Description_22: This course is conducted primarily as individual placements, or small teams of students within an industrial or research environment and emphasizes academic and vocational aspects of modern industry practice. Students consolidate their technical knowledge by undertaking a project in a professional workplace (which may include a University lab) whilst simultaneously managing their learning and course assessment. The project provides students with the opportunity to undertake a substantial project that usually has an industry application. Students work in close liaison with their industry and university supervisor throughout the project and are expected to demonstrate a good understanding of their project. The course also emphasizes that competence in management, business and social responsibilities are essential components in all fields within the environment and science professions and the key attributes of a contemporary industry or research environment. Prerequisites Students should be in the third or final year of study and must have completed the online registration form which can be followed by clicking on the red 'Access Learning@Griffith' link provided here: https://www.griffith.edu.au/griffith-sciences/partnerships/wil-for-student To be eligibile for enrolment in this course, students must have completed all requirements of the WIL Office in preparation for placement, including allocation to an industry placement or project. Student must have completed 140CP and have gained a GPA of 4.5 or higher. Enquiries are to be directed to the Course Convenor. Incompatible: 3103ENV Industry Placement
Subject_Description_23: The course introduces basic vector algebra in two and three dimensions, matrices, complex numbers, probability and revises basic functions. It provides a foundation in the mathematical sciences for later studies in science and engineering. Prior Assumed Knowledge: It will be assumed that students have the knowledge equivalent to a grade of SA over 4 semesters in Mathematics B (Qld high school subject), or equivalent study over 4 semesters of a high school subject that includes the study of differential and integral calculus or 1017SCG">1017SCG Foundation Mathematics (grade of 4 or higher). For students who do not have this level of mathematics background, it is strongly suggested that they first complete 1017SCG">1017SCG Foundation Mathematics. Incompatible: 1010ENG Engineering Mathematics 1, 1011SCG Mathematics 1A, 1201BPS Mathematics 1A.
Subject_Description_24: This course provides an introduction to the basic concepts and practices of data analysis and inferential statistics. It will provide and understanding of several techniques including testing one or more means from sampled populations (t-Tests and ANOVAs), relationships between scale variables (correlations and regressions), and contingency table analysis (Chi-square tests). The course places emphasis on understanding the use of appropriate data for these tests, the use of exploratory data analysis and the underlying distributions and assumptions associated with these tests. Students will learn how to carry out these tests by hand, via the use of statistical software (SAS or SPSS), check assumptions, interpret results and report findings in plain English. Assumed prior knowledge: Grade 12 Maths A or B or equivalent. Incompatible: 1003ENV Statistics, 2012MSC Biostatistics, 2012HSC, Intro to Biomedical Data Analysis, Bioinformatics, 1003PSY Research Methods and Statistics in Psychology, 1002MSC Introduction to Biomedical Data Analysis

Incompatible courses: 1102SCE Chemistry 1B, 1104SCE Foundations of Biological and Medicinal Chemistry, 1106SCE Chemistry B, 1111AES Introduction to Environmental Chemistry, 1502ENV Chemistry II, 1502SCE Introduction to Nanoscience,
