A range of authentic learning experiences will see students conduct investigations (open investigations, experiments, field assessments, application of theory) as individuals, occasionally working in small teams if necessary, in which data is collected, recorded and interpreted using appropriate discipline specific approaches. Conclusions will be drawn and questions for future investigation highlighted. Assessment will be by the combination of a high-quality written report and an oral defence of this report.
Subject_Description_29: Students are introduced to Geographic Information Systems that enable the capture, storage, manipulation and analysis of different types of spatial or geographical data. These systems are important tools for environmental scientists in managing environmental systems. Incompatible: 2205ENV Geographic Information Systems, 3047ENV Geographic Information Systems
Subject_Description_30: This course introduces the main environmental spheres and important natural processes of the Earth, considered as a series of systems interacting at various scales. Features of the lithosphere, atmosphere, hydrosphere and biosphere are explained, with emphasis given to the interrelationships between these spheres. In doing so, basic concepts of the more specialized fields of meteorology, climatology, hydrology, oceanography, soil science, geology, geomorphology and biogeochemistry will be studied. Incompatible: 1303ENV Earth Sciences, 1051AES Earth Sciences, 1302EAS Earth Sciences, 1004EAS Earth Sciences and GIS, 1004ENV Earth Science and GIS.
Subject_Description_31: The course will introduce the student to the fundamental theoretical and practical principles of the Chemical sciences. Students will be encouraged to develop problem solving skills and apply these to the solution of real chemical problems. Assessment is by laboratory reports, quizzes and a final examination. Incompatible: 1001ENV, 1001MSC
Subject_Description_32: Understanding Australian Cities is an introductory overview of the origin, patterning and functioning of the urban system. The course specifically examines the dynamics of population, infrastructure, governance and culture in Australian cities. These understandings frame examination of the possibilities of planning intervention. This introductory course will allow students to better appreciate the range of planning challenges and the opportunities for further study. This course is delivered via weekly lectures and tutorials and is supplemented with web materials and readings.
Subject_Description_33: This course explores the theory and practice of transport and land use planning. The course involves a lecture series and course readings, a set of interlinked workshops to design, administer and analyse a travel survey, and a literature review exercise that allows students to more deeply explore a significant issue in transport and land use planning. The course covers such topics as the theoretical underpinnings of transport planning, contemporary transport policy, the impacts of transport systems on the environment, transport modelling, planning for walking, cycling and public transport, disruptive technology and transport and transport and land use integration. Students must have completed 130 credit points or have the permission of the course convenor before enrolling in this course.
Subject_Description_34: Urban Analysis and Planning Studio builds upon earlier studio courses in the degree, and will provide you with essential research methods and analytical techniques that planners use to understand the ecological, social, cultural, economic and political relationships that comprise the urban environment. Drawing upon diverse theories, the course will teach you to analyze cities from multiple perspectives e.g. historical, spatial, cultural, ecological etc. You will undertake extensive fieldwork to collect data for weekly course activities. Throughout the course you will be required to demonstrate your reading, critical thinking and analytical skills, and to reflect upon what you have read and learned, when writing activity reports. You will learn to reference impeccably and to communicate effectively. As this is a 20CP studio course, students should expect to spend twice as long on it as a standard, 10CP course. Incompatible: EP32006 Urban Analysis; 2057EVP Urban Analysis; 2057ENV Urban Analysis, 2056ENV Urban Analysis. Prerequisites: 1027ENV Introductory Planning Studio, 1511ENV Environmental Planning Studio, 1037ENV Understanding the Australian City.
Subject_Description_35: This course focuses upon the relationship between the natural environment and economic systems. It includes both the analysis and understanding of human economy impacts upon the natural systems that support it, as well as, approaches for the sustainable management of natural resources. The role of economics in the various decision-making approaches relevant to environmental resources is outlined. The content covers the major concepts and specific methods for the economic assessment of costs and benefits of ecosystems and other natural resources. The course also highlights concepts and theory for the economic analysis and policy for the sustainable management of both renewable and non-renewable resources. It covers and compares the contributions of both mainstream economic extensions as well as broader sustainability sciences such as ecological economics. Prerequisite: Completion of 80CP. Incompatible: 2281ENV Economics and Natural Resources, 2281AES Economics and Natural Resources.
Subject_Description_36: This course focuses on the design and evaluation of participatory processes in urban and environmental planning. You will research and apply different methods and approaches for involving people in planning and learn the importance of contextually appropriate engagement. You will also conduct an independent evaluation of a real life public event using desktop and field based research. You will deliver a comphrensive professional-quality evaluation report which critically evaluates, develops robust conclusions, and provides clear recommendations for best practice public participation in planning . Students must have completed 130CP credit points or have the permission of the course convenor before enrolling in this course. Incompatible: 4047EVP Public Involvement and Community Development
